On 08/24/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Slusher conducted an unannounced annual inspection following a pre-visit Covid Assessment. Met at the facility by Facility Manager Victor Lockett. 1. Facility Grounds were inspected and generally free from Hazard. 2. Outdoor space observed. Facility has a pool, which is locked and meets fencing requirements. 3. Chemicals were stored in locked closets/cabinets. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications were observed on this date 5. First aid kit complete with appropriate manual was present upon inspection. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. One mattress cover is being replaced due to a tear, but client is not present in the room. 8. The house has 5 bedrooms, double occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings 9. Adequate food storage space observed. 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of non-perishable foods observed 10. Weekly menu observed 11. Dining room observed. Table and benches provide seating for 6 youth. 12.Facility has two full restrooms, both for client use. Water temperature was within the regulatory range. 13. Licensee has a vehicle for use at the facility. insurance and registration are both current. Client files (5) were reviewed. Agency will forward LIC 308, 309, 500, 9020 Current Accreditation certification, current mental health certificate. Annual Inspection to be continued at a later date.

On the above date, LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Lisa Slusher continued an annual inspection for the above facility. LPA reviewed personnel records, including training records. Prior to this inspection, LPA reviewed Personnel Report and Criminal Record Clearance Information for the above facilities. According to documentation reviewed, Facility is meeting regulatory staff/child ratios. All staff are fingerprint cleared or have current exemptions on file and are associated to the facility in which they work. Agency has current Mental Health Program Approval through Fresno County Department of Behavioral Health. MHPA is current through 1/27/23. Agency is accredited by CARF and accreditation is current and expires June 30 2025. LPA Reviewed 14 personnel records. All staff have current Emergency Intervention, First Aid/CPR and Water Safety Certificates.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAS) Lisa Slusher and Danny Macias travelled to the facility listed above to conduct an Annual Inspection. Met at the facility at 8:30 am by Supervisor Victor Lockett. Two additional staff members and 6 clients present upon inspection. A physical plant inspection was conducted with Victor Lockett. The facility has current Mental Health Program Approval through Fresno County expiring in January 2025. The facility is accredited through CARF and their accreditation expires June 30, 2025. 1. Facility Grounds are clean and free of debris or observable hazard. Facility pool is appropriately fenced and maintained. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. 3. Chemicals appropriately locked. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Licensee has made provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. Observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications. 5. First aid kit complete with appropriate manual observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. 8. The house has 5 bedrooms, a mixture of single and double occupancy all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. 10. Weekly menu posted and accessible to clients. 11.Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 12.Facility has two full restrooms in the house for client use, both are operable 13. Facility has no animals or firearms

9. Recommend training matrix table. 14.Facility managers are required the following training topics 87065.1(b)(5): • (A)Interaction with the Department, including inspection authority. • (B) Licensee appeal rights. • (C) Interaction with placement agencies, neighbors, mental health agencies, law enforcement, medical/emergency personnel, children’s family members and child and family teams. • (D) Laws and regulations governing short-term residential therapeutic programs. • (E) Emergency and disaster response. • (F) Implementation of the assessment by the Qualified Individual, as specified in section 87022.1(b)(8)(A), and information about the Qualified Individual’s assessment process pursuant to Sections 4096 and 11462.01 of the Welfare and Institution’s Code. • (G) Facilitation of participation of family members in child’s treatment program and documentation of integration of family members into the treatment process, as specified in section 87022.1(b)(13)(A). • (H) Facilitation of outreach to family members and documentation of outreach, as specified in section 87022.1(b)(13)(A). • *(I) A child’s right to receive gender affirming sexual and reproductive health care and information.

If so , please describe in the training plan and please ensure to state it is “in addition to initial and annual training. Section E, Policies Regarding Child Abuse Reporting- Does Not Meet Standards • Did not specify that the facility will not sanction, punish or discipline any staff for making a report. Section F, Administrative Policies and Procedures- Meets Standards • Are the first four pages necessary? • Much is not required in this the section. Section G, Admission Determination Procedures- Does Not Meet Standards 1. This section shall be used to discuss the facilities procedures for determining admission only. This section appears to discuss some intake procedures that are best fit in section H. some examples include “a copy of admission agreement, county/private placement, Procedures between placing agency and the STRTP no later than seven (7) days after admission of a youth/NMD, Medical assessment and physical examination requirements, including TB results, Procedures for accepting emergency placements, Procedures for admission agreements for NMDs including modifying agreements. 2. When a child is referred for placement in a short-term residential therapeutic program, the licensee shall document the referral including 87068.05(b): • Documentation of referrals shall include but not be limited to the following:

• The placing agency making the referral request. • The date and time that the referral was received. • The name, age, and gender identity of the child being referred. 3. Please specify the procedures by which a determination is made in response to a referral from a placing agency to include 87068.05 ©: a. Consideration of the child’s needs and strengths, the likelihood that the child will benefit from the program, 4. Determination procedures shall include an explanation of how the program will evaluate the appropriateness of placement for referred children with any of the following behaviors or characteristics, including how the licensee defines these characteristics for the purposes of assessing appropriateness of fit. Appears to be somewhat discussed in section H. please move the content from section H. to G. 5. Please Include an explanation of how the program will evaluate the appropriateness of placement for referred children with any of the following behaviors or characteristics (see below), o Frequent runaways o Gang-related activity o Fire-starting o Sexually assaultive behaviors o History of Commercial Sexual Exploitation o Substance abuse 6. Please also include how the licensee defines these characteristics (above) for the purposes of assessing appropriateness of fit 87068.05 ©(3): • -as a reminder , the licensee shall not utilize the behaviors and characteristics (frequent runaways, gag activity, fire-starting, CSEC, substance abuse, etc.) as the sole basis to assess or determine placement appropriateness or deny admission.* 87087068.05 (e) 3. Please include a statement that recognizes interviews with youth are not used to assess or determine placement appropriateness or deny admission.* 87068.05 (d) 6. Determination procedures shall specify the following .* 87068.05 ©(4): 1. The facility shall establish timeframes for response to the county placing agency regarding referrals for placement. a. The established timeframes must include, but are not limited to, an initial response period in which the facility accepts, denies, or requires more information for the consideration of the referral for placement. The facility’s initial response period shall not exceed 5 days following the receipt of referral for placement and ,

b. a final response period in which the facility accepts or denies the referral for placement. 7. Elevated review procedures appears somewhat discussed in section H, on page 183 as “Process for engaging and collaborating with inter-agency placement committee and Child and Family Team.” • Upon the request of a placing agency director and the authorized representative of the county mental health plan, or their designees, the licensee shall engage in a good-faith effort, together with the placing agency director and the authorized representative of the county mental health plan, or their designees, to determine the appropriateness of the placement. 87068.05(f) • If the licensee determines that the program is not capable of meeting the child’s needs without additional services and/or supports, the licensee shall request such assistance from the placing agency, Community Based Organization, or any other resource, and shall document this request. 87068.05 (g) • If the licensee determines that the program is not capable of meeting the child’s needs, even with additional services and/or supports, or if the identified services and supports are not available, the licensee shall document this denial, including the reason for denial. 87068.05 (h) Section H, Intake Policies and Procedures- Does Not Meet Standards • In this section, I did not see a description of trauma-informed and evidence-based intervention and de-escalation techniques that will be used to promote the safety of all individuals in the facility, including but not limited to children or NMDs who have the propensity for behaviors that result in harm to self or others. 1. This section is to discuss procedures and policies after a youth has been accepted for admission. It appears to discuss many procedures for “admission determination”. On October 11, 2025, at 9:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daniel Mena conducted a pre licensing inspection of the facility. At time of inspection LPA met with applicant Emmett Downs. The facility was toured inside and out with Applicant, Emmett Downs and Facility Managers, Victoria Valadez and Devin Downs. The home is a one-story four bedroom home with three bathrooms. Facility has a detached therapy office, which includes a storage room, small kitchen and one bathroom. Bedroom # 1 is furnished with two twin beds and sleeps two clients. Bedroom # 2 is furnished with two twin beds and sleeps two clients. Bedroom # 3 is furnished with two twin beds and sleeps two clients. Bedroom # 4 is designated as a staff office and includes one bathroom which is designated for staff. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. Hot water in bathroom number one measured to be around 112.0 degrees, and bathroom number two will be also be accessible to clients. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications will be stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. Cleansers/chemicals and sharp knives are stored and locked also in staff office. (continued on next page)

The is currently no First Aid Kit on the premises. The facility's smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were operable. There are no guns/weapons in the facility. The following required posted items will be made accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, and Visitation policies. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There are no pools or other body of water on grounds. Applicant will provide photo as proof that a first aid kit has been purchased for the facility by Monday, October 14th. The applicant completed Component III on October 9, 2024. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Applicant, Emmett Downs on this date.

On 08/01/2025 at 9:48 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Julian Lucas conducted an unannounced visit at Downs and Martins (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to conduct an unannounced annual required inspection. LPA Lucas met with Facility Manager, Devin Downs and completed a walkthrough of the facility. LPA began a physical plant inspection at 9:51 am assisted by the Facility Manager, Devin Downs. During the physical plant inspection, LPA observed a formal entry with a closet that consisted of board games, and backpacks for client outings. The living room consisted of two sofas, the dining room consisted of a formal table with six chairs and one sofa. The kitchen includes a refrigerator/freezer, food storage areas. There is an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods, and the food menu is posted. All sharps are kept in a lock box located in the staff office. There are three client bedrooms, all bedrooms have individual beds, there are two clients per bedroom, with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. There is dresser drawer space for each client’s clothing. There is one youth restroom and an extra restroom for emergencies. Both restroom sinks read above 105 degrees Fahrenheit. In the dining room LPA observed postings of Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, and Clients Bill of Rights posted on the wall in English and Spanish. There is a staff office that is kept locked. The staff office consists of a staff restroom, three desks with three computers and one printer. There is a closet used to keep staff and client files and client medicine that is locked in a medicine cabinet. LPA observed a CARF Certificate, CPR and First Aid, Community Care Licensing postings, and emergency evacuation facility sketch posting. The first aid kit is also kept in staff office. The First Aid Kit consists of bandages, tweezers and scissors. Continued on LIC 809C

The facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. All cleaning supplies are locked in the staff office. There is a detached mental health office used for therapist and the rehabilitation specialist. The office has two desks and two computers, and a restroom. There is also a kitchen for cooking activities for the clients. The office has extra refrigerator and freezer where client food is stored. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order and located throughout the facility. Fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced and located in staff office and kitchen. The facility has one vehicle to transport clients to appointments and recreational activities. The vehicle is maintained in a safe operating condition. LPA reviewed five client’s records, and five personnel records. LPA interviewed three staff members and three clients. Based on the annual required inspection on this date, there were no deficiencies found. An exit interview was conducted with the Facility Manager, Devin Downs and a copy of this report was given to the Facility Manager. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was provided to the Facility Manager, Devin Downs.

On October 13, 2020 at 3:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst, LaTonya Wilson, arrived at Downs and Martin Children Services to interview a foster youth pertaining to concerns reported on a separate corporation/facility in Riverside county. A copy of this report was provided to the facility.

The facility staff indicated clients are supervised at all time. Staff will attempt to counsel and redirect clients when clients are talking about drug use. The facility staff indicated no clients have had sexual relations at the facility. The confidential interviews conducted did not collaborate the allegations. The placement agency social workers indicated having no concerns with the facility. There was no corroborating information obtained through interviews nor review of records to confirm the allegations. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On July 21, 2021 at 12:15 PM Licensing Program Analyst Larry Cabral (LPA) conducted a follow-up inspection for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA Cabral met with Facility Administrator Emmett Downs. During the course of the investigation, LPA Cabral interviewed three facility staff, three clients and attempted to interview one client on 3/17/21(see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated July 21, 2021). LPA interviewed one county social worker and attempted to interview three county social workers on 7/13/21. LPA interview one county social worker on 7/20/21. LPA reviewed other agencies investigative narrative, delivered service logs and the facility’s incident reports on 7/20/21. The facility staff denied the allegations that a client was sexually abused by another client and that facility staff did not adequately supervise clients.

narrative: Continue from page 1 . . . . The staff denied the allegations and stated that clients obtained alcohol and marijauna when they AWOL from the facility. The staff stated that the clients conduct a self search when coming back to the facility from AWOL. The staff indicated that the staff confiscates and disposes of contraband when found in the facility. The staff stated that the staff have not choked a client when conducting a restraint and that the alleged victim was not put on a restraint. The confidential interviews stated that the staff does not provide the clients with alcohol or drugs. The confidential interviews indicated that alcohol or drugs were obtained during the client's AWOL. The confidential interviews indicated that clients would sneak contraband by hiding it or sneaking in without the staff knowledge. The confidential interviews indicated that the alleged victim was not put on a restraint hold or the client was not choked by a staff. There was no corroborating information obtained through interviews and review of records to confirm the allegations. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegation are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report was left with above staff.

narrative: On 07/25/2021, the Department received a complaint alleging that a client is being hit by another resident in care while under the care and supervision of staff workers. The focused client (FC) who was identified in the referral provided inconsistent information. The focused client (FC) denied the allegation and stated that the conversation he had with an individual identified as other was not accurate information and stated "it's not really like that". The focused client admitted that he reported that he was being hit by another peer and that the staff present was not responding accordingly, however, the FC said it was not true. The FC stated that staff working is always present and is quick to intervene when clients are out of line. The FC identified another client that was bothering him by being hit and stated that it was not true. The focused client (FC) admitted that he likes to horseplay with others and stated that everything is fine and that he feels safe living at the facility. Staff workers who were interviewed denied the allegation that they are allowing a client to bother or harass another resident (peers). Staff workers were in agreement that the focused client (FC) is the one who is actually horse-playing around with other clients. Five of the six clients provided consistent information in confidential interviews and denied the allegation. One client who was identified as hitting the focused client categorically denied the allegation and stated "it's the other way around". All clients reported that staff at the facility are always present and had no concerns or complaints overall about the operations at the facility. The individual identified as other who reportedly had direct information about the allegation could not be contacted after several attempts to speak with other by telephone went unanswered. Statements obtained could not corroborate the allegation reported for neglect/lack of supervision by staff working at the facility. Therefore, the above allegation is determined unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility representative for review and signature. No deficiencies were cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On 07/25/2022 at 08:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joseph Vargas conducted a follow-up inspection for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint. LPA met with Facility Manager Ms. Valadez. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted in-person visits, and telephone interviews with four staff workers, six clients on 03/17/2022, that includes one individual identified as other on 7/21/2022 (reference confidential names list LIC811 dated 07/25/2022). During the inspection LPA requested for review and obtained copy of the staff and client facility roster reports, special incident reports, clients Needs and Service Plan and placement history, including a review of the county report associated to this complaint investigation.

narrative: Page 2 The Department received a complaint alleging a youth in placement was sexually assaulted when he was thirteen years old. However, it was unknown if the assault occurred at, or away from the facility. Based on statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted by the Department, LEA and placing agency, the alleged incident occurred in 2021 when Ref. #1 (See Confidential Names list LIC811 dated 10/16/23) accompanied his brother to visit a friend’s home. During the visit Ref. #1 met a female who he reportedly had an intimate relationship with and who inappropriately touched him twice. Ref. #1 was unable to identify the female and unwilling to provide further information regarding the inappropriate contact. Based on information gathered from interviews conducted and records review, the allegations is Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. A copy of this report and Confidential Names list LIC811 dated 10/16/23 were given to the above-mentioned facility representative. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted.
investigation_findings: An unannounced follow up complaint inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 10/16/23 at 10:55 AM. deficiencies.description:
ILS 87068.2 (g) 
Needs and Services and Plan: The licensee shall obtain written approval from the child, if age and developmentally appropriate, and the child's authorized representative prior to implementing the child's needs and services plan. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:

Based on the LPA's record reviews, 3 out of 3 client's (C1, C2, C3) Needs and Services Plan did not have the  authorized representative's signatures,  which poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator he will ensure that the  Needs and Services Plan will be checked on a regular basis and will have the authorized representative signatures. Signed copies of the NSPs will be submitted on or before the due date.

met_with: Emmett Downs Admin, Rita Hill HR Mannager,Devoin Downs- Assistant Manager
narrative: On December 8, 2023, at 9:43 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility. LPA met with the Emmett Downs Administrator. The purpose of the inspection is to issue a deficiency citation and civil penalty assessment after a staff was allowed to work in the facility (see Ref#1 on the LIC 811 Confidential Names Form dated 12/8/23), who does not have a criminal record clearance. - Records obtained and reviewed by the undersigned LPA show that staff did not have a criminal record clearance and was allowed to work at the facility on 11/01/23, 11/03/23,11/04/23,11/16/23, 11/23/23 and on 11/24/23. Based on the above information, a deficiency citation is issued under 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. This violation pose an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care. A violation of Section 80019(e) will result in an immediate assessment of civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100) per violation for a maximum of 5 days by the Department therefore, a civil penalty assessment of $500.00 is issued. An exit interview was conducted, and the following reports were provided: LIC809, LIC 809-D, LIC421BG and LIC811 Confidential Names Form. Appeal rights forms were provided and explained.

deficiencies.description:
80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance
(e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility:
This requirment is not met as
evidanced by: Based on LPA observation and record review, the licensee did not ensure a complete fingerprint clearance or exemption was not obtained for Ref# 1 prior to work or be present at the facility which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Per Administrator the said staff was notified on 12/4/23 not to come back to work until he/she obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption.
Facility will provide review of onbording new staff and backgrourd clearance process by 12/29/23 and email LPA copy training log by end of day.

narrative: On January 4, 2024, at 9:13 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Timika Martin and Angelina Garibaldo conducted an unannounced annual/required inspection to the facility. LPA’s met with Emmett Downs Administrator and Victoria Valadez Facility manager, who gave the tour of the facility. There are six (6) clients placed in the facility currently. Physical Plant The facility is a one-story building. The facility consists of a living and dining area, a kitchen, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, and two staff offices. One bathroom is located inside the staff’s office and designated for staff. The bedrooms are set up so there are two residents in a bedroom and one resident per bed. There is adequate drawer space for residents’ belongings. The resident’s bathroom was observed to be clean. LPA's checked water temperature in the resident’s bathroom and thermometer read 105 degrees Fahrenheit. The following was observed at the time of the inspection. The posted license, Emergency Disaster Plan, Foster Care Ombudsman's information and Youth's Personal Rights, Complaint and Grievance Procedure, and Mental Health Program Approval. The fire alarm was tested and working. Cleaning solutions and hazardous items observed to be stored in a locked cabinet in the hallway. Sharp knives were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked box in one of the staff’s offices. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet inside of one of the staff’s offices. The facility's smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by the Administrator. Children’s Personal Rights form is also posted, accessible to residents. LPAs observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food and snacks available to the residents. The exterior of the facility was also inspected and observed to be clean, and the landscape well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is no swimming pool or other body of water located on the facility grounds. LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: ·LIC 500 Personnel and client roster Biannual Reports for the use of Emergency Interventions MHPA Certificate- renewal visit was conducted on 12/21-12/22/23. Anticipated to receive approval by: 01/12/24 and will email LPA copy of certificate. CARF Accreditation LIC 610C and mass casualty and disaster plan Annual compliance Review consisted of the following (7) domains: physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness plan, emergency intervention, staffing, core-therapeutic services, and client files. Staff and Clients were interviewed. A signed copy of this report, LIC 811 Confidential Names list dated 01/04/24, and 2 Technical advisory and 1 civil penalty was provided to the Administrator for review. No further inspection required.

met_with: Emmett Downs- Aministrator and Victoria Valadez- Facility Manager
narrative: On May 20, 2024, at 11:24 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo made an unannounced visit to Downs and Martin. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on information the Department received regarding an unusual incident 03/09/24 involving C1. During this inspection, LPA met with Emmett Downs Administrator and Victoria Valadez- Facility Manager. Summary of Incident: On 03/09/24 While on a group outing C1 was physically assaulted by an unknown male. Staff was present and broke up fight. Law enforcement was call and all involved were interview. C1 sustained facial bruising and was taken to hospital. LPA requested to review Special Incident Reports (SIR’s). While reviewing documents, LPA observed that facility had completed an SIR but had not been submitted to the department. Based on a review of records it was indicated that the facility did not meet the reporting requirements for an incident that occurred on 03/09/24. The incident required notification to the Department by telephone, email, or fax within 24 hours or by the next business day following the event, followed by a written incident report within 7 days of the incident. SIR for incident on 03/09/24 was never submitted to CCL. The reporting requirement was not met. Based upon the above information, it is determined that the facility is in violation of General Licensing Regulations: 1. Section 80061(b)(1)(E). Reporting Requirements. Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. An exit interview was conducted where the citations and plan of corrections were discussed. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the representative facility representative mentioned above.

deficiencies.description:
Reporting Requirements:  …Upon the occurrence... of any events specified below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency’s next working day...or a written report shall be submitted within 7 days…(E) Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:

The facility did not report an unusual incident regarding C1 that occurred on 09/03/24.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will conduct staff training on Reporting Requirements. Proof of training will include training topics, date and time of training, participants and their signature, and the instructor. Proof of training will be submitted via email to Angelina.garibaldo@dss.ca.gov by end of POC date 06/03/24/

narrative: On April 23, 2024, the Department received a complaint alleging that STRTP staff did not ensure that minor had appropriate fitting shoes resulting in injury. It was also alleged that the STRTP staff did not report missing client. Based on review of the client's clothing inventory and statements obtained during interviews, client had several pair of well fitting shoes as well as the boots he was wearing the day of 04/22/24, which belonged to him and fit him well when purchased. Client enjoyed wearing his boots and never informed facility that they did not fit him. Client chose to wear that pair of boots when he left the home without authorization. Same interviews revealed that as client had been consistently leaving the facility in unauthorized fashion upon return, the local Police Department had been leaving an earlier law enforcement report as an open report, therefore, filing another missing person's report is unnecessary at times. Confidential statements obtained during the investigation were unable to corroborate the allegations, revealing inconsistencies. Social worker interviewed by LPA had no concerns regarding the allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited at this time. Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC9099-C, and LIC811 were provided to Vickie Valadez, Office Manager. Appeal rights provided.
investigation_findings: 13On Monday, July 22, 2024 at 10:30 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced follow-up complaint inspection at Downs & Martin Children Services, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), for the purpose of delivering findings concerning the above allegations. LPA met with Vickie Valadez, Facility Manager. During the course of this inspection LPA reviewed, the STRTP's complaint history and interviewed by phone 2 adults on April 29, 2024. On May 1, 2024, LPA interviewed 5 clients at the STRTP and interviewed 4 adults at a collateral location. On May 9, 2024, LPA interviewed focused client (C1) (See LIC811 Confidential Names list dated 05/10/24) at a collateral location. On July 18, 2024, LPA interviewed two facility staff via telephone. On July 18, 2024, LPA reviewed documents provided by the STRTP including but not limited to register of clients, LIC500 Facility Personnel list, C1's clothing receipts, allowance logs, clothing logs, C1's Needs and Services Plan (NSP), and C1's Child and Family Team (CFT) meeeting notes. LPA also reviewed Department databases and reports from other agencies. (Continued...)

On September 11, 2020 at 2:30 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cameo Banks made an unannounced tele-visit to Dream Home Care Inc. V for the purpose of conducting a Case Management- Deficiencies Visit. LPA spoke with Chief Operating Officer Cora Manalang. During a complaint investigation dated 2/26/2020 #34-CR-20200226150131, it was discovered that Staff #2 threatened Child #1 during a verbal altercation. After conducting confidential interviews with Child #1 and facility staff, it was confirmed that Staff #2 did make a threat to Child #1. LPA informed Chief Operating Officer that according to Title 22 regulations and Interim Licensing Standards, staff can not make threats to a child in care and children must be accorded dignity and respect. Per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 9.5, the following deficiency was cited at the time of this tele-visit. (See LIC809-D) Exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Ms. Manalang for signature.

On 11/10/2021 at 8:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the said facility to complete the facility’s required annual inspection. LPA met with Lisa Seibel, administrator who provided the tour of the facility. This facility is licensed to provide care and supervision up to six (6) children ages 11-17 years ambulatory only and non-minor dependents. Currently there are four (4) clients and four (4) staff in the facility at the time of the inspection. LPA Karnsrithong has reviewed two (2) client files and five (5) staff files. Client records are locked and stored in the Therapy room for safe keeping purposes. LPA also conducted two (2) staff interviews. Staff files are currently stored at the corporate office but is available for audit and inspection. Database Compliance Officer had brought the staff files to the facility for inspection. LPA Karnsrithong has observed the following during the time of the inspection: *Grievances/Complaint Box is located in the living room area. Key to the contraceptives cabinet is also located in the living room area.Contraceptives are stored in a different locked cabinet inside the office. Clients may obtain access to it if needed. Outdoor Area: There is a screen door that leads towards the outdoor area from the living room. There is a garden in the backyard. There is a picnic table with an umbrella outside that clients may use. There is also a door from the office area that leads towards the outdoor area. The air condition unit and the utility shut off valves are located along the side of the home. The entire perimeter of the facility is fenced in. The front of the home is fenced in with a black wrought iron fence. (Page 1 of 2)

Garage: There is a detached garage in the facility. There are two freezers stored in the garage which is used to store extra frozen food supplies. Sports and play equipment are also being stored in the garage (pool table, surf boards, and balls). Clients can take out the sports equipment to use when they wish to do so. Most activities are done outside the garage. Office: There is an office area located next to the Laundry Room. This office is mainly used by direct care and clinical staff. Licensing postings are also found in the office area. Emergency Polices and Emergency Safety Drill Logs are kept in the office area. The Mental Health Program Certificate is also posted in the bulletin board in the office area. The staff's schedule is also posted in the office area. There are six (6) desks and five (5) chairs in the office that staff uses. There is one (1) bathroom and a storage room located inside the office. The storage room contains toiletries, hygiene supplies, extra clothes, personal protective equipment (PPE), towels, linens, baby supplies, medication cabinet and medication log. The storage room is kept locked when not in use. The client’s allowances and cash resources log are documented in the individual client files and are also logged in the Weekly Allowances and Targeted Behavior Binder that is stored and locked in a cabinet in the office. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of the inspection. A copy of this report will be emailed to the facility at a later date. (Page 2 of 2)

On 11/05/2021 at 8:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the said facility to conduct an annual inspection. LPA met with Lisa Seibel, administrator who provided the tour of the facility. This facility is licensed to provide care and supervision up to six (6) children ages 11-17 years ambulatory only and non-minor dependents. There are currently three (3) clients in the facility at the time of inspection. There are no bodies of water on the premises. LPA Karnsrithong has conducted three (3) client interviews and two (2) staff interviews during the time of inspection. There are two (2) fire alarms and (1) carbon monoxide alarm in the facility. There is a centralized alarm system located in the office. There is a locked thermostat located in the hallway next to the staff bathroom. There are two (2) first aid kits located one in the kitchen and one in the office area. Living Room: It is located next to the kitchen area. There are sectional couches and an office desk. There is a television and media equipment at the center of the living room area. There are books and gameboards for clients to use. There is a standing fan in the living room as well. There is a locked armoire that has another television and a game console that clients can use. Staff supervises the use of the video games to ensure that clients maintain their schedules and able to meet their individual goals. The Foster Youth Bill of Rights is also posted in the living room area. Dining/Kitchen Area: It is located across the door/hallway. The dining area has a table and four (4) chairs. There is a four-burner stove oven, microwave, rice cooker, coffee maker, refrigerator, and toaster oven that clients can use to prepare food for themselves. A menu is posted in the kitchen area. All cabinets are labeled and used to store utensils, plates, can goods, and other food supplies. All canned goods have a sticker where staff documents the food’s expiration date. There is a dishwasher in the kitchen but is currently not being used. There is one (1) operating fire extinguisher located in the kitchen area. The kitchen area is clean and well maintained.

Reception Area: It is located directly in front of the doorway. Licensing postings are posted in the wall, including the emergency disaster plan for the facility. COVID-19 safety checks are conducted in the reception area. All staff and visitors check in upon arrival. AWOL policies are also posted in the reception area. Bedroom Area: All bedrooms are equipped with two (2) twin size beds, closet space, and lighting, and drawers for clients to use. All bedrooms have carpeted flooring. There is a closet in between the bedrooms that stores linens. No more than two (2) clients share one bedroom. There is an additional wall shelf in between the bedrooms that client may use to store their belongings as needed. There is also a house phone located in between bedroom 2 and 3 that clients may use if needed. Bedroom 1: C1 Bedroom 2: C2 and C3 Bedroom 3: C4 Laundry Room: It is located outside the office area. There is washer and dryer that is being used by clients. There are laundry supplies on the shelf. The laundry room can be accessed at anytime by clients if needed. Bathroom: There is one (1) client bathroom located next to bedrooms. It is full sized bathroom with a sink and toilet. The bathroom is maintained and deemed safe and in sanitary condition during the time of inspection. Next to the laundry room, there is another full sized bathroom that is mostly used by staff but if needed clients may use it as well. This bathroom is kept locked when not in use. There is another full sized bathroom that is being used by staff located in the office area. This bathroom is also being used to store cleaning and disinfecting supplies for the facility. Therapy Room: This room is located across the reception area. This room is used for client therapies and Child and Family Team Meetings. It has a table and three (3) chairs and one (1) reclining chair used during these meetings. There is sufficient lighting in the said room. This room is kept locked by staff when not in used. This area is also used during family visits for privacy. This is typically done during weekends.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with the administrator to evaluate the home for a capacity decrease. The following was observed. This is a three bedroom, three bathroom home locate in the City of Torrance, CA. There are currently five clients in placement. All bedrooms have two twin beds with linens in good condition. There are no security bars on the bedroom windows. There are no bodies of water. There are working smoke detectors in the bedrooms and hallways. There is a carbon monoxide detector in the kitchen. The fire extinguisher is fully charged. Client #1 will be transitioning out of the home on 11/19/2021. Once there are only 4 clients in placement and an updated fire clearance is received, the capacity can be reduced to four.

investigation_findings: 13On May 18, 2021, at 1PM Bernice Karnsrithong, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived at the facility to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. Health and safety risk assessment were conducted upon arriving at the facility. LPA Karnsrithong met with Lisa Seibel, Administrator. During the investigation of the allegations, staff member verbally abused minor in care and staff member had a physical altercation with minor in care, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documentary evidences. Statements were consistent and documentary evidences indicated that staff did not comply with the facility’s crisis intervention and client’s safety plan and engaged in a verbal and physical altercation with a minor while in care. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80072(a)(3) Personal Rights. Staff engaged in a verbal and physical altercation with a minor while in care.

deficiencies.description:
80072(a)(3) Personal Rights: To be free from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature, including but not limited to... This requirement is not met by evidence:
Based on confidential statements and documentary evidences, Staff engaged in a verbal and physical altercation with a minor while in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee must ensure that all clients are accorded personal rights at all times while in care even during a crisis. Licensee must conduct a Personal Rights and Crisis Intervention Training to all facility staff. Copies of training agenda, sign-in sheet, materials to be provided to LPA by 06/20/2022 During the visit licensee provided LPA training agenda, sign-in sheet, and materials for Crisis Intervention Training held on 04/22/2022 for facility staff

narrative: On 08/10/2022 at 10:50 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a case management-other; regarding recent Administrator and Personnel Changes in the facility. LPA Karnsrithong met with Ruth Mares, Facility Manager. Health and safety risk assessment was conducted upon arriving at the facility. COVID-19 checks are conducted in the front entryway of the facility. During the visit, LPA Karnsrithong has observed that the window in the therapy room is broken. The window is covered and boarded up and no child is using this room as a bedroom. LPA Karnsrithong also has observed the client bedrooms. Bedroom 1 has one twin sized bed with clean linens and a sturdy mattress. There is adequate closet space and lighting that was observed. Bedroom 1 carpet floor was observed to have visible large stains. Bedroom 2 was observed to have two (2) twin sized beds, adequate closet space and lighting. There are clean sheets and sturdy mattress on the beds. Bedroom 3 was observed to be clean and free of any debris. It has two (2) twin sized beds with sturdy mattress and clean sheets. There is adequate closet space and lighting in this room as well. The carpet in the middle of the room in bedroom 3 was observed by LPA Karnsrithong to be ripped. A deficiency is cited at this time based on: Title 22 Division 6 Article 7 Section 80087 (a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. Plan of correction is discussed with the licensee. Exit interview was conducted with Facility Manager and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

On 08/24/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility at 2pm to conduct a Plan of Correction Visit. LPA Karnsrithong met with Ruth Mares, Facility Manager. During the visit, there were three (3) staff and two (2) clients onsite. Health and safety risk assessment was conducted upon arriving at the facility. LPA Karnsrithong toured the three (3) client bedrooms. Currently only Room 2 and Room 3 are occupied. Each bedroom has new carpet floors, two (2) twin sized beds, dresser, closet, and adequate lighting. Each bedroom has clean and sturdy mattress. All carpet floors in all bedrooms are clean and in good working condition. All passageways are free of any obstruction or debris. During the visit LPA Karnsrithong also observed the two (2) office rooms. The front office room is used for Therapy Services. The windows in the Therapy Office is in good repair and free of insects and debris. The staff office room is in the back area of the facility. It has six (6) desks and six (6) chairs. The staff office also has its own restroom used by staff only. The facility storage room is also located inside the office. Plan of Correction has been cleared for the facility through today’s visit. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Ruth Mares, Facility Manager. A copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward visited the facility in response to SIR 847377 which reports that a Staff #1 posted a video of C1 to her personal social media account. LPA Jones-Steward will contact CEO/Administrator Cora Manalang to discuss the issues mentioned above.

The facility has already submitted documentation of their internal investigation and discipline of the two staff members. Ms. Manalang was requested to write a letter stating what has been done.

It was reported to LPA if medication is refused incident reports are submitted and documentation is noted in facility records. It was reported to LPA that haircuts are done every two weeks. narrative:
On April 2, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at Dream Home Care Inc. V, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Random inspection. LPA met with Administrator, Corazon Manalang who granted access to the facility and together a tour of the interior and exterior premises was conducted. This facility is licensed to provide care and supervision up to four (4) children ages 11-17 years ambulatory only and non-minor dependents. There are currently no clients in placement. Facility overview: The facility is a single story 3-bedroom, 3-bathroom house located in a residential neighborhood, which includes Living room, Dining room, Kitchen, Laundry room, staffing offices, a detached Garage, and a backyard. Living Room: has two sofas, a desk, chair, bookshelves, and an armoire with a television and gaming console. Dining Room: has a wooden table and four (4) chairs. Kitchen: has refrigerator/freezer, a four-burner gas stove/oven (all operable at the time of the inspection), microwave, a toaster oven, rice cooker, and a dishwasher. LPA observed the facility to have a one-week supply of non-perishable foods. There were no perishable foods as the facility does not have clients in placement. The menu is posted, there are plenty of utensils, plates, and cups. The sharp knives are kept in a locked kitchen cabinet and made inaccessible to clients when in care. Laundry Room: has a washer and dryer. Staffing Offices: There is one office is located at the front of the home used as a therapy room. The room contains two chairs, a desk, and locked file cabinets. The second office is located at the back of the home. The room contains several desk and chairs, locked file cabinets, and a storage closet that remains locked at all times. Bedroom 1: contains one (1) twin bed, closet space, drawers, a working light and windows. Bedroom 2: contains one (1) twin bed, closet space, drawers, a working light and windows. Bedroom 3: contains two (2) twin beds, closet space, drawers, a working light and windows. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 2)

Bathrooms: One bathroom located in the front of the home next to bedroom #1, the second bathroom is located off the living room next to the laundry room, and the third bathroom is located at the back of the home inside of staffing office. All bathrooms contain a shower, tub, sinks, and toilet. All bathrooms were observed to be in good repair and working order. The hot water temperature was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). The carbon monoxide and smoke detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The first aid kit was checked and found to be complete. The home has 2 regulation fire extinguishers. There is a working telephone readily accessible. Overall LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. There are no bars on the windows. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. There was no swimming pool or bodies of water located at the facility. When clients are in care the facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The Program does not have any clients or staff at this time. LPA interviewed the Administrator. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. (Page 2 of 2).

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA interviewed all three staff that were present during the incident and C1. C2 could not be reached and C3 was not present during the incident. LPA Jones-Steward also viewed SIRs related to this incident. During the interviews and SIR review process, LPA Jones-Steward received conflicting accounts about who was the aggressor and who attacked whom during the incident. Although C1 and one staff reported C1 as the victim, other staff and reports indicated that C1 was the aggressor. Based on conflicting information, this allegation is resolved as unsubstantiated. An unsubstantiated finding means that although an allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that it did happen.

13On 1/31/25 at 11:08 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Liscensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith arrived at Dream Home Care V and met with Admin Kevin Bennett for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegation. LPA interviewed involved staff and clients. Multiple staff interviews stated that the Head of Service does not retaliate against staff. However, other interviews confirmed the Head of service retaliated against staff. LPA received multiple conflicting reports from staff when asked about the allegations. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met, therefore the allegation of “Head of Service retaliates against staff” has been found to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, during which LPA provided the Administrator with a copy of this report.

narrative: Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and observation of the facility complaint procedures, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation of “Staff are not implementing proper written complaint procedures for minors in care” is found to be substantiated. The Facility is being cited for violating the Interim Licensing Standards Article 6 Section 87072.2 (a) Complaint Procedures. An exit interview was conducted, during which LPA provided the Administrator with a copy of this report and a copy of their appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 1/31/25 at 11:08 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at Dream Home Care V and met with Admin Kevin Benett for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegations. LPA interviewed involved staff and clients. Interview evidence and record review revealed that the facility is not implementing proper written complaint procedures for minors in care. Interviews reveal that clients don’t know or remember the complaint procedures and don’t feel they will remain anonymous. Additionally, interviews reveal that complaints are discussed publicly which also contributes to the lack of anonymity for the complainant. The actions to address and correct received complaints should allow the complainant to remain anonymous during the process.

deficiencies.description: Complaint Procedures. The licensee shall develop, maintain and implement accessible written complaint procedures by which children,... are permitted to file complaints, without fear of retaliation, with the facility administrator regarding facility staff or operations. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on interview evidence and records review, facility is not implementing proper written complaint procedures allowing for complainants to have anonymity and freedom of fear of retaliation which poses a potential personal rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will read and review ILS section 87072.2 Complaint Procedures and update complaint policy to have facility complaint procedures require and enforce complainants’ anonymity, including but not limited to practices that the facility will not publicly discuss complaints in a forum with clients/staff and more frequent reminders to the clients of the complaint box and instructions on how to use it. Provide staff training on ILS Complaint Procedures and update the facility Complaint Procedures and send verification of  training  procedures to licensing.

investigation_findings: 13On 1/31/25 at 11:08 AM , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at Dream Home Care V and met with Administrator Kevin Bennett for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegations. 13On November 15, 2023 at 1:19 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at Dream Home Care V. for the purpose of delivering findings for the allegations listed above. During the course of this investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews, gathered pertinent information, and performed a walk through of the facility. Client statements did not provide information to support the allegation. Based on information obtained, the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was completed, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. Multiple staff interviews admitted that that the family visits for the client were not happening, but it was due to either the client or the family member declining the visits. Staff testimony stated that family visits were always offered, but they did need to adhere to court mandated monitored visits, and the client or the family member had some refusals in the beginning. The client interview shared that they did not know why visits did not happen in the beginning but admitted that they are taking place now. LPA preformed a records review shows notes from the Intensive Care Coordinator (ICC) who recorded all the offered/set up visits that were declined by the client or the family. Due to conflicting testimonial evidence and the visitation notes, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met, therefore, the allegation of the “Staff have not properly facilitated family visits” has been found to be unsubstantiated. LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. A client interview shared that a staff member would at times “get frustrated and leave shift early” causing supervision and staff-to-client ratio issues. Multiple staff interviews stated that staff never left their shift early and never caused care and supervision issues. LPA received conflicting testimony regarding the allegation, though most interviews stated that staff did not leave work early and always ensured adequate supervision for minors in care. Due to conflicting testimonial evidence and based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met, therefore the allegation of “Staff did not ensure adequate supervision was provided to minors in care” is found to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, during which LPA provided the Administrator with a copy of this report and a copy of their appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/2/25 at 11:48 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at DReam Home Care V facility and met with Administrator Kevin Bennett for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegations. Multiple staff interviews reported that there was an event where a client yelled at a staff member, but the staff member remained calm and did not escalate the incident. A client interview stated that the staff did engage in yelling and cursing. LPA received conflicting testimonial information regarding the event, but more interviews stated that the staff did not engage in cursing or yelling at a client. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met, therefore the allegation of “Staff spoke inappropriately to minors in care” is found to be unsubstantiated.

deficiencies.description: 87065.5 Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios(a) a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows(2) During the hours of 10 pm to 7 am, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Confidential interviews and documentary evidence such as written warning of staff sleep while on duty.

narrative:
On 12/22/2023 at 10:00 AM, (LPA) Licensing Program Analyst - Dennis Jarmin made an unannounced visit to Dream Home Care Inc. I to conduct the annual required inspection. LPA met with Rodgnell Hays, Direct Care Personnel who granted access to the facility. LPA then inspected the entire physical plant of the facility. The Group Home is licensed and provides care and supervision for six (6) children, aged 11-17 years, Ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises and State of California License was posted. The Group Home Administrator was very ill and staff were not available to review personnel records and (1) client records will also be reviewed on the continuation of the inspection. There are no weapons stored on the premises. The facility is a one 1- story home with 3 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. LPA observed the facility clean and sanitized with clean linens, appropriate drawer storage and closet available for clients clothing. The 3 bathrooms were observed clean and sanitary with the required hot water temperature within the regulation; however, during the walk through, LPA observed the hot water at 60 degrees and took 30 minutes to rise to the required hot water temperature of 105 to 120 degrees. The dining room and living room area had appropriate seatings, and furniture were in good repair condition. The facility has central air conditioning unit that provides suitable air temperature throughout the home with appropriate lighting. LPA observed all the windows in good condition including screens and blinds that are styled double hang with no bars in the event of an emergency evacuation. All passageway and porches were clear of obstruction and all required posting were met (meal plan, daily activities, required licenses and regulations, personal rights and emergency disaster plan) that are posted in the common area readily accessible to clients.

LPA observed cleaning supplies solutions, bleaches and disinfectants are properly stored at the lock cabinet in the hallway. Medication was at the storage room; staff office locked and inaccessible without a key. Sharp knives were also observed locked and inaccessible on a separate cabinet in the kitchen area. The clients were sleeping at the time of visit and LPA was able to interview 1 client only. LPA observed 3 battery operated combined smoke detectors and 1 Carbon Monoxide monitor, all system was tested with audible sounds and operable. The laundry area was inspected with no safety issues or concerns noted and an office for staff/administrator were on the rear of the home adjacent to the patio. The facility had outdoor area that are located in the front and back perimeter with no debris or hazardous materials noted. The facility has a 2 working telephone and 2 cordless unit that clients can use. The facility accord clients with dignity in personal relationships with personnel and others. Overall, the licensee operates within the conditions and limitations of the license including capacity limitations. The facility has a current written plan of operation and all personnel are directed to report violations of Personal Rights. The Licensee reports any changes in operation that affects clients service and reports clients’ injuries. LPA conducted 2 Staff interviews; 1 client interviews due to clients still asleep and reviewed 3 client records. During this inspection, LPA observed the facility clean, sanitary, safe and free of hazards, and there are no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA will return for continuation of inspection to review all personnel records and conduct 1 client interview. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report will be emailed to Jerell Nero, Facility Administrator.

On January 18, 2024 at 8:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an unannounced visit to Dream Home Care Inc. I for the purpose of conducting a collateral visit regarding an allegation from a previous placement. LPA met with Tianna Gammage, Facility Manager. LPA was informed that the Administrator was currently not at the facility. LPA conducted confidential interviews. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with facility staff.
