investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward conducted a thorough investigation of the allegations that staff called client names, staff made inappropriate comments to client, staff pushed another client and staff tries to intimidate client. LPA interviewed staff including the accused staff (S1), facility manager, shift supervisor and administrator. LPA also interviewed three of the four clients and reviewed the disciplinary notice and documentation of retraining given to S1. All staff denied both that they personally committed any of the above allegations and that they witnessed any co-workers committing these allegations, although it was acknowledged that S1 has an aggresive tone of voice and was suspended for speaking harshly to C1. The interviews provided by C1, C2 abd C4 were inconsistent and vague. During the course of the investigation, LPA Jones-Steward was unable to gather enough cohesive information to substantiate or disprove the allegations. Therefore they are resolved as unsubstantiated.

narrative:
LPA received multiple conflicting testimonies regarding the facility's timely response with medical attention. All staff and most client testimonies state that the facility does offer consistent medical care in a timely manner when requested. Staff interviews also clarified how some situations may appear to be neglecting medical concerns but are actually following facility policies. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation of “Staff does not seek medical attention to minors in a timely manner” is found to be unsubstantiated. Allegations: “Minor has access to marijuana while in care.” During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. Witness and client interviews stated that certain clients would smoke marijuana and abuse substances in the facility. Staff interviews stated that while there was a suspicion of a client smoking marijuana in the facility, it was never proven, and a client was never caught actively smoking marijuana in the facility. Staff interviews also shared that the facility consistently offered clients substance abuse help, including offering classes and therapy sessions, but the clients never accepted the offers. LPA received multiple conflicting testimonies regarding minors having access to marijuana while in care. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation of “Minor has access to marijuana while in care” is found to be unsubstantiated.

Allegations: “Staff are not meeting minor's mental health needs.” During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. A witness interview claimed that a client was struggling with suicide and was not helped by the facility. LPA interviewed involved staff who reported that clients are always offered mental health services, including therapy sessions, both individual and group sessions on a consistent basis. Staff interviews explain that while clients often refuse to engage or participate in the clinical services they are still always offered. Staff interviews claimed that no client has ever reported struggling with suicide. Client testimonies confirmed that mental health assistance is offered, but not always accepted by clients. LPA received multiple conflicting testimonies regarding the mental health services being provided by the facility. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation of “Staff are not meeting minor's mental health needs” is found to be unsubstantiated. Allegations: “Staff does not accord minor privacy.” During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. A witness interview claimed that a client was not being afforded privacy by the facility and would lock themselves in the bathroom to obtain privacy. Staff interviews shared that clients are always afforded privacy, around the facility, and especially in their bedrooms. Client interviews also stated that the facility offered privacy, and clients never had to lock themselves away to get privacy. LPA received multiple conflicting testimonies regarding privacy in the facility. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation of “Staff does not accord minor privacy” is found to be unsubstantiated. Allegations: “Staff does not allow minor phone calls.” During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. A witness interview claimed that clients were not allowed to make phone calls freely. Staff interviews shared that clients have access to the facility phone and can make calls freely whenever they want. Staff shared that the only call restrictions were court-ordered restrictions. LPA observed the landline at the facility. Client testimony stated that clients had access to the facility phone at all times, and most clients had their own phones and were able to make calls freely.

LPA received multiple conflicting testimonies regarding the public phone policy for the facility. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation of “Staff does not allow minor phone calls” is found to be unsubstantiated. Allegations: “Staff does not prevent other minors from being bullied.” During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. A witness interview stated that younger clients often get bullied by older clients. Staff interviews shared that some older clients did pick on and tease younger clients, but the younger clients would also tease and agitate the older clients to get them in trouble. Staff would always intervene and discourage any bullying from any clients. Client interviews stated that there was some bullying happening at the facility. Clients stated that sometimes staff would intervene when it was happening in public, but sometimes they would not follow up on bullying complaints. LPA received multiple conflicting testimonies regarding bullying in the facility. No other evidence besides testimonies were provided by any interviewed parties. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation of “Staff does not prevent other minors from being bullied” is found to be unsubstantiated. Allegations: “Staff does not ensure minor is provided adequate clothing.” During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. A witness interview claimed that a client was not adequately clothed, often walking around without shoes and with shirts with holes in them. Staff interviews stated that clients are always informed and offered to go clothes shopping using the facility budget for new clothes. Staff interviews shared that sometimes clients are comfortable with their current clothes, don’t like change, and don’t care enough to go shopping for new clothes. Client interviews shared that they were adequately clothed and always provided the opportunity to get new clothes. LPA received multiple conflicting testimonies regarding clients being adequately clothed. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation of “Staff does not ensure minor is provided adequate clothing” is found to be unsubstantiated.

Allegations: “Staff does not follow facility's activity calendar.” During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. A witness interview shared that the staff do not update or follow the facility activity calendar. Staff interviews stated that the facility calendar is updated monthly with the participation of the clients. Staff shared that sometimes the activity schedule is not followed only because the clients refuse or deny the scheduled outings and activities. Staff said that it is common for clients on one day to agree to do an activity and then on the next day refuse, which results in the activity or outing being canceled. LPA observed the activity schedule posted in the facility with the correct dates. Client testimonies confirm that the activity schedule is accurate and updated often, but that clients can and often decline to participate in the activities. LPA received multiple conflicting testimonies regarding the facility's activity schedule. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation of “Staff does not follow facility's activity calendar” is found to be unsubstantiated. Allegations: “Facility is operating out of ratio.” During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. A witness interview stated that the facility often operated out of ration with only 1 staff for every 4/5 clients. The witness claimed that this ratio would last for entire shifts and that it wasn’t uncommon. Client testimonies confirmed that the facility sometimes operated with only one direct care staff. Clients also claimed that it wasn’t unusual and would last for long periods of time, not just in between shifts. Staff interviews said that the facility never operates out of ratio. Staff interviews state that other staff, including the clinical team, facility managers, and even the administrator, will step in to provide extra coverage when necessary. Sometimes coverage is needed between swing shifts if a staff member is running late, but this is extremely rare. LPA observed the LIC 500 staff roster and schedule and observed adequate 24-hour. coverage. LPA received multiple conflicting testimonies regarding the facility operation out of ratio. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation of “Facility is operating out of ratio” is found to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, during which LPA provided the Administrator with a copy of this report and a copy of their appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/18/25 at 9:13 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the above facility and met with Administrator Nero for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegation. Allegations: “Staff does not seek medical attention to minors in a timely manner.“ During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. Client interviews share that the facility does offer consistent medical care when requested. One client and witness interview shared a time when a client AWOLed from the facility to obtain over-the-counter medications. Staff testimonies stated that clients are always afforded medical care and services when requested. Staff testimonies clarified that the facility is not only allowed to offer clients prescribed medication, and can not provide over-the-counter medications. During the event, where a client AWOLed the facility clarified to the client that they could not provide over-the-counter meds but would work quickly to get prescribed medication. The client did not want to wait and AWOLed to obtain their desired medication.

13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA interviewed the administrator, Client #1 (alleged victim) and Client #2 (roommate/witness). Based on the conflicting accounts, LPA Jones-Steward was not able to subtantiate or negate the allegation that client was negligently given the incorrect medication. Therefore the allegation was resolved as "unsubstantiated". A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

Kitchen and bathroom equipment was in working condition. The food supply met Title 22 requirements The yard area was clear of hazards. Trash cans were covered. narrative:
On 1/04/2024 at 01:30 PM, (LPA) Licensing Program Analyst - Dennis Jarmin made an unannounced visit to Dream Home Care Inc. III to conduct the annual inspection. LPA met with Kevin Bennett, Program Administrator, who granted access to the facility. LPA then inspected the entire physical plant of the facility. The Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Home is licensed and provides care and supervision for six (6) children, aged 11-17 years old, Ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises and this facility provides services to the non-minor dependents per regulation. The State of California License was posted and visible. The Program Administrator was on site and provided all the client records for LPA to review but the personnel records were located at the corporate office. LPA then will come back and continue the inspection and review the files on 01/05/2024. The administrator also provided LPA with the LIC 500 and current census. There are no weapons stored on the premises. The facility is a 1- story home with 3 bedrooms and 4 bathrooms with one ½ bath. LPA observed the facility was clean and sanitized with clean linens, appropriate drawer storage, and a closet available for clients' clothing. The 3 bathrooms were observed clean and sanitary with the required hot water temperature of 105 to 120 degrees. LPA was informed by the Administrator that the boarded-up broken window in bedroom 1 is being repaired. LPA was then given a copy of the work order with the expected time of completion. The dining room and living room area had appropriate seatings, and the furniture was in good repair condition. The facility has several air conditioning units installed to provide suitable air temperature throughout the home with appropriate lighting. LPA observed all the windows in good condition including screens and blinds that are styled double hang with no bars in the event of an emergency evacuation. The bedrooms had no screens due to the installation of the AC units.

During the inspection, LPA observed that all passageways and porches were clear of obstruction, and all required postings were met (meal plan, daily activities, required licenses and regulations, personal rights, and emergency disaster plan, etc.) which are located in the common area of the home. The facility has a garage that is utilized as a game room for the clients adjacent to the main entrance. The facility properly stored cleaning supplies solutions, bleaches, and disinfectants in a locked cabinet in the hallway. Medications were stored in the office room, which was inaccessible without a key. Sharp knives were locked also and inaccessible in a separate cabinet in the office area. The facility had installed 5 battery operated combined smoke detectors, 2 carbon monoxide monitors, and 2 fire extinguishers, all of which were tested and operable per regulation. The laundry area was inspected, and there were no safety issues. The facility has a room designated as an office for staff/administrators in the middle section of the home. The outdoor areas of the facility were free of debris and hazardous materials. The facility had one working telephone and one cordless unit that clients could use. The clients were treated with dignity in their relationships with personnel and others. There were 7 days' supply of non-perishable food and 2 days' perishable food at the home. The refrigerators and freezers had appropriate temperature gauges per regulation where food was stored. Overall, the licensee operated within the conditions and limitations of the license, including capacity limitations. The facility had a current written plan of operation, and all personnel were directed to report violations of personal rights. The licensee reported any changes in operation that affected clients' service and reported clients' injuries. During the inspection, 2 staff interviews and 1 client interview were conducted. All personnel records will be reviewed on the continuation of the inspection. The facility was found to be clean, sanitary, safe, and free of hazards, with no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report will be emailed to Kevin Bennett, Program Administrator.

Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations. Due to conflicting statements gathered in the interviews. LPA Phillips was unable to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. narrative: On 1/16/25 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived unannounced at Dream Home Care (III) facility and conducted an investigation regarding a case management-Incident inspection. LPA met with Administrator Kevin Bennett and discussed SIR #1209737 which happened on 1/3/25, and involved two clients AWOLing, stealing a car, and being arrested by the police. LPA requested and received a copy of the staff and client roster for the facility, LPA also received a facility copy of the SIR. LPA interviewed 3 staff regarding the above incident. LPA requested and recived a copy of the Needs and Services Plan (NSP) for both clients. LPA also requested copies of the police reports from the incident, Admin stated they do not have the police reports and suggested asking DCFS. LPA requested and received contact info facility staff to continue investigation. LPA informed Administrator that more information is needed prior to making any decisions or recommendations. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Administrator Bennett.

LPA and LPM met with Facility Manager Beatriz Alvarado and discussed SIR #1205855 which happened on 12/28/24, and involved two clients physically assaulting a staff member and being arrested. On February 13, 2025 at 9:00AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Connie Jones'Steward, Kenrick Ellis, and Rosslyn Gray, made an announced visit at DREAM HOME CARE, INC.III to conduct the Psychotropic Case Medication Inspection. LPAs conducted a Health and safety risk assessment upon arriving at the facility. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9(a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs Jones-Steward, Ellis, and Gray, met with the Administrator Kevin Bennett conducted a brief walk through of the physical plant inside and out. LPAs reviewed one (1) of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA did not interview the one (1) client currently prescribed psychotropic medication due a mandatory scheduled court appointment. LPAs reviewed three (3) staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs interviewed three (3) of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. The Administrator provided a physical hard copy of the psychotropic medication training topics during the training for for LPA’s to review. LPA's reviewed the LIC-500 to confirm the shift which starts in the evening and ends early morning and reviewed the staff Criminal Records Clearances. The Administrator provided a physical hard copy of the psychotropic medication training topics during the training for LPA’s to review. No deficiency were cited per Group Home Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 5. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator Kevin Bennett

On 5/2/25 at 10:52 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the Dream Home Care facility and met with Facility Manager Beatriz Alvarado for the purpose of delivering Case Management other findings regarding SIR #1205855 which happened on 12/28/24, and involved two clients physically assaulting a staff member and being arrested. During the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff and clients and performed record reviews. Records review of the Dream Home Care III Program Statement revealed that Dream Home Care III’s policy is that “violation of the above rules will never reduce the resident's guaranteed allowance.“ Interview evidence from both staff and clients revealed that staff involved mentioned ‘withholding the allowance’ of the clients as punishment for not cleaning their rooms. Client interviews admitted that the mentioned notion of withholding allowances is what triggered them. Therefore, based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and records review evidence, the facility is found to be out of compliance with ILS section 87022 Plan of Operation and will be cited. A copy of this report was given to the Facility Manager.

deficiencies.description:
87022 (f) Plan of Operation: "The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the plan of operation and may be cited for not doing so." This requirement is not met as evidence by: 
Based on witness testimony staff mentioned withholding allowance as a punishment to clients for not cleaning their rooms. Based in records review this is a violation of the facilities program statment.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will re-train all staff on ILS section 87022 Plan of Oporation. Facility will also re-train staff on facility policies regarding allowances. Facility will also re-train staff on how to work with clients and encourage them to do their chores. Facility will submit to LPA training logs as proof of training.

narrative: On 5/2/25 at 2:18 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at Dream Home Care III Facility and met with Facility Manager Beatriz Alvarado for the purpose of delivering IR-Follow Up findings regarding SIR #1209737, which happened on 1/3/25, and involved two clients AWOLing, stealing a car, and being arrested by the police. During the investigation, LPA interviewed involved staff and clients and performed record reviews. Staff and client interviews stated that a staff member left their personal items, including the keys to their personal car, out in the facility's general areas. Clients found the keys and AWOLed with the staff member's car. While the facility knew about the AWOL and made the proper reports, it was not known until later that the staff member's car was stolen. The clients also ended up in a police chase, a car accident, and arrest during the incident. While no deficiencies are being cited. LPA is giving a TA to the facility regarding employees storing their personal items in facility-supplied employee-only lockers/storage areas. Exit Interview Conducted. A copy of this report was given to the Facility Manager.

LPA also received a copy of the therapy session notes from December 2024 to February 2025, showing that therapy sessions were still being offered. Also, these notes confirm staff statements that therapy sessions are offered twice a week for a minimum of two hours. While some staff disagree on the required amount of time offered weekly for therapy sessions, all interviewed parties, including staff and clients, agreed that therapy sessions were still offered weekly at all times. Also, the received therapy notes show that therapy sessions were always being offered. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met, therefore, the allegation of “Staff did not ensure adequate therapeutic services were provided to minors in care” is found to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, during which LPA provided the Administrator with a copy of this report and a copy of their appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/2/25 at 3:01 PM , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the above facility and met with Administrator Kevin Bennett for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegation. LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. Staff interviews stated that the facilities policy is to provide “a minimum of two hours per week of group therapy and one and a half hour of individual therapy”. Multiple staff and client interviews reported that these group and individual therapy sessions are being provided and are in line with facility policy. Multiple clients shared that though the sessions are offered, they often either decline or don’t actively speak and participate in the sessions, making them shorter. All staff and clients stated that therapy sessions are offered on a weekly basis. One staff interview stated that “STRTP regulations require an on site therapist from 9-5… (the facility) has not been providing 9-5 coverage.” LPA researched both the STRTP regulations and the facility program statement and could not find any minimum time requirement for a therapist to be present, only that therapy sessions are required to be offered.

narrative:
On December 29, 2021 at 12:30pm, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Hillary Hall and Danielle Walker-Flores arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of completing an Annual Inspection. LPA's met with Administrator (AD) Diana Tichenor and left at 5:30pm. LPA's returned on December 30, 2021 at 9am to continue the inspection. LPA's met with AD and left at 12:30pm. *Due to LPA's local FAS database being inaccessible, the CARE tool Annual Inspection forms were unable to be recorded in FAS on the date of the inspection. LPA's referenced copies of the CARE tool as well as Staff/client interviews. Findings were further delayed from being delivered to the facility as a staff member and client tested positive for Covid. LPA Hall met with AD on 1/25/2022 to deliver findings. On 12/29/21, LPA’s completed a facility inspection using the CARE tool. Facility is clean and organized. More than 7 days of non-perishable food was observed and more than 3 days of perishable food was observed. Each client has sufficient bedding and storage space. Facility vehicles were in good repair. Facility has a pool which is properly fenced with a locked gate. Staff supervision was higher than regulations require. Smoke alarms and fire extinguishers were in compliance. Medications and cleaning supplies were locked behind doors with combination locks. No deficiencies were noted in the physical grounds. The facility currently has five clients. On 12/29/21, LPA Hall interviewed all four clients present. The remaining client was not available due to an extended visit. LPA's interviewed 6 staff who were on site. LPA's reviewed five client files. On 12/30/21, LPA's reviewed ten staff files. No deficiencies were noted with the staff files. LPA's observed all five client files to have Needs and Services Plans (NSP) which were not updated or individualized for each client. All five client files reviewed had NSP which were completed timely, but did not document the client's progress toward their goals or any modification of the goals. Each NSP was nearly identical and resubmitted every 30 days. Continued on 809C.

Continued from 809 Each client had an additional Mental health Treatment Plan with supplemental therapeutic goals, however, these Treatment Plans were also not updated to reflect the clients needs, or how the client met their goals in the preceding 30 days. A Citation is being issued per Interim Licensing Standards STRTP version 4, Section 87068.3(a): Modifications to The Needs and Services Plan: (a) The needs and services plan specified in Section 87068.2 shall be updated at least every 30 days to determine the following: (1) The child's need for continuing services. (2) The facility's recommendation regarding the feasibility of the child's return to their home; placement in a less restrictive family-like setting consistent with the facility’s program statement...or move to independent living. (3) The need for modification in services. (4) The progress of the child toward their transfer goal. A signed copy of this LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC-809D were provided to the administrator.

On 12/01/2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Hillary Hall and Misty Valencia arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual Inspection. LPA's met with Facility Manager (FM) Hannah Ellis. LPA's utilized the CARES tool to conduct the inspection. Facility is clean and organized. More than 7 days of non-perishable food was observed and more than 3 days of perishable food was observed. The facility currently has 6 clients. Each client has sufficient bedding and storage space. Facility vehicles were in good repair. Facility has a pool which is properly fenced. Staff supervision was was within ratio. Smoke alarms and fire extinguishers were in compliance. Medications and cleaning supplies were locked. *No deficiencies were noted in the physical grounds. On 11/30/22, LPA Valencia interviewed one client, as LPAs were on site this date for a SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection. LPA Hall reviewed 5 client files. LPA Valencia interviewed 3 staff and reviewed 3 staff files. On 12/01/22, LPA's interviewed 5 clients and reviewed 1 remaining client file. LPA's observed all 6 client files to have current Needs and Service Treatment Plans (NSP). *No deficiencies were noted with the staff or client files. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC-809C was provided to the administrator.

A Continuation to the SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Hillary Hall and Misty Valencia. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). As the inspection could not be completed on 11/30/22, LPA's returned to the facility on 12/2/22. The facility has five clients prescribed psychotropic medication. On 12/2/22, LPA Valencia interviewed two clients and attempted to interview two additional clients, who declined to be interviewed. This completed the inspection. LPAs provided a signed copy of this licensing report (LIC-809) to the Facility Manager and conducted an exit interview. No deficiencies are being cited.

An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Hillary Hall and Misty Valencia 11/30/22 at 9 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Hannah Ellis, Facility Manager, and inspected the facility inside and out. The facility has five clients prescribed psychotropic medication. LPAs reviewed 5 client's records and 3 staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed 5 client's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed 3 staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPAs interviewed 1 client currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPAs provided a signed copy of this licensing report (LIC-809) to the Facility Manager and conducted an exit interview. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPAs were unable to complete the psychotropic medication inspection on this date and will follow up on subsequent day to complete the inspection.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia and Lyta Vue on 11/07/2023 at 8:00(AM). This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Valencia and Vue met with Dianna Tichenor, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed four out of five (4 out of 5) of child’s records and three out of ten (3 out of 10) of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed four out of five (4 out of 5) of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed three out of ten (3 out of 10) of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed four out of five (4 out of 5) of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Dianna Tichenor, Administrator. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Dianna Tichenor, Administrator.

Interviews and records reviewed were consistent that one minor was restrained one time, on the first day of placement at the facility, following attempts by the minor to hurt themselves. The restraint was less than 5 minutes and was documented to have followed regulatory requirements of a Small Child Restraint. Record review indicates that comments made during a supervised visit with the minor, indicate the minor was restrained, but there was no mention of the restraint being inappropriate or causing injury. The visit monitor remained within earshot of the minor during the visit and did not hear any comments about the restraint being inappropriate. One of the four minors interviewed indicated having been hurt by staff in the past during a restraint, but no details were reported about how the minor was hurt. Staff records indicated that the staff were current on their annual training, including restraint training. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED, meaning that the allegation is false, could not have happened, or is without reasonable basis. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report and the LIC-9099C were provided to the facility, along with appeal rights. An exit interview was conducted.

narrative:
On October 17, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Administrator Diana Tichenor. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required, Biennial Inspection of the facility. The last inspection for the facility was on 01/25/2022. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized, and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility is a home like setting, with three client bedrooms, a large open plan kitchen/dining area, and one locked staff office. The backyard was free from hazards, safely fenced, with a variety of sports equipment accessible to clients. Facility has a pool which is properly fenced with a locked gate. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, client personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. The facility bathrooms were all were observed to be clean and fully functioning. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. LPA observed the kitchen to have at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on hand, with additional food stored in the garage. LPA observed client files and client medications were stored in a locked file cabinet in the locked staff office. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility currently has six clients, with a licensed maximum capacity of six. Staff to client ratio is at least 2:1 by day and 1:6 by night. LPA reviewed five staff files. Staff files had completed criminal record clearances and all required initial and annual training. LPA interviewed three staff on site. LPA reviewed five client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements on file. Client files had completed initial Needs and Service Treatment Plans, signed by clients and staff, and updated Needs and Service plans every 30 days and goals and progress were noted. Needs and Service Plans detailed

adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. Clients were current on CHDP physical exams and dental exams. Five of the clients were taking court ordered psychotropic medications and had current JV-220’s on file. LPA interviewed two clients. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC-809-C report was provided to the Administrator. An exit interview was conducted.

continuation from on 9099 LPA Brown reviewed records to include case notes, Needs and Services plan, Child and Family Team meeting notes, staff training record regarding discipline and restraints, pest control service receipt, client medical records, incident reports, menus, recent grocery receipt, and a facility roster. Photographs were provided of one child having two scratches, one on their cheek and one on their neck. Interviews were consistent that the origin of the scratches were unknown. The client reported that it had happened in the shower that morning. Staff report that the client did not take a shower prior to coming to school that day. It was alleged that staff scratched a client when rubbing the client’s own spit back on them. Staff denied ever taking or observing anyone take spite off of themselves and smearing it onto the client. Records review demonstrate that staff are trained in Therapeutic Crisis Intervention and included incident reports where client was restrained for assaultive behavior 18 times in a four-month period. Attempted interventions, circumstances surrounding the restraints, as well as duration were outlined in the reports submitted to the Department. It was alleged that a staff member sat on a client during a restraint. Interviews were consistent that staff members do not and did not sit on clients during a restraint. Records review demonstrate that the reporting party repeatedly brought up concerns with a point system used by the facility. The same records demonstrate, and interviews were consistent, that these levels are used as positive reinforcement for good behavior. Staff interviews were consistent that discipline includes conversation and natural consequences. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews, and records reviewed, although the allegations may have happened, or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violations did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins made an unannounced annual required inspection to Eagle Eye Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Derrick Kennedy Administrator and inspect the facility inside and out. The STRTP is licensed to served 6 clients ages 13-17 and non minor dependents. Present during the inspection there were 2 staff and 1 client. The facility consists of four bedrooms (3 for clients and 1 for storage) and 2 1/2 Bathrooms (1/2 for Staff and 2 for clients). The facility is a two story home with a side office. The facility is licensed for 6 residents and currently 6 clients reside in facility. No more than two clients share a bedroom. At 11:15 AM, LPA and Administrator conducted a walk through of the facility and office. LPA observed the kitchen to be clean. The hot water in the bathroom, shower and kitchen measured 110 degrees F which is currently between 105 - 120 degrees. The facility has plenty of nonperishable and perishable food supply. Medication, knives and cleaning supplies is locked away. There are enough folks, spoons, plates and cups. All passageways are unobstructed. All smoke detectors are update and working. The home is clean, safe, and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. The fire extinguisher has been checked and is up to date. There are no bodies of water on the property. The home is maintained at a comfortable temperature. Personal rights, floor plan, food menu and Emergency disaster forms were posted and in clear view.

At 12:20 PM, LPA reviewed five clients files with Administrator. Administrator notified LPA that one client was accepted in on 9/8/21 and Administrator is still putting together his file. LPA observed all five client files to be complete and found no deficiencies. LPA observed medication log to be up to date and complete. At 1:20 PM, LPA reviewed seven staff files with Administrator. LPA observed all seven staff files to be complete and found no deficiencies. LPA observed all staff files to have the correct up to date documentation and all staff were up to date with their staff training for the year. At 2:20 PM, LPA conducted 2 staff Interviews and 2 client interviews. During inspection, LPA receive an updated copy of the LIC 500 Personnel Report and updated client list to maintain their file current. A review of Licensing Information System on September 9, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during the inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at Eagle Eye and spoke with Derrick Kennedy Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation, LPA Rollins conducted confidential interviews with facility staff, clients, social workers and conducted clients file review. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories about Lack of Supervision resulted in client in care engaging in physical altercation. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories about facility staff to provide a safe enviroment for client client in care and client in care has access to weapons. Based on interviews and documentation there was not enough evidence to prove lack of supervision resulted in client in care engaging in physical altercation, facility staff failed to provide a safe enviroment for client in care and client in care has access to weapons. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove lack of supervision resulted in client in care engaging in physical altercation, facility staff failed to provide a safe enviroment for client in care and client in care has access to weapons, therefore the above allegation is unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted with FM and LPA left report at the facility.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Paul Simien made an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility on 2/9/2022 at 10:05 AM. The purpose for this inspection is to conduct a case management regarding an incident report the that was received by the department. The incident report involved a runaway report for C1 (see lic 811 dated 2/9/2022). LPA discussed the with administrator that the reports were not submitted within the required time frame and the report was missing information regarding the incident. This report also provides information for multiple events that were not provided to the department when they occurred. Facility cited for violation of section 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. During a review of client files, LPA attempted to review C1’s file and the file could not be located. All other client files were present in the facility however, C1’s file was not able to be located by staff and they did not know where it was. Facility cited for violation of section 80070(a) Client Records. LPA Belfield requested all Incident reports from December 2021 and January 2022. During this inspection a walk through was conducted of the facility with facility manager Beverly Trent. During the walk-through LPA observed client bedrooms and bathroom on two floors. First client bedroom on the first floor had broken blinds and no screen on the window, LPA observed the screens outside the windows on the ground. Also observed during the walk-through were holes in the wall in the second floor bathroom and hallway. Currently there are repairs being done to the facility and the holes, along with all other repairs will be completed by 2/18/2022. Advisory issued. LPA discussed adding more storage to client’s rooms for clothing. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80061(b) Reporting Requirements and section 80070(a) Client Records. Advisory Note issued regarding repairs.

Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA) Alyssa Ng and Shikya Belfield, made an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility on 3/11/2022 at 10:25 AM. The purpose for this inspection is to conduct a case management regarding incidents involving law enforcement, that were not reported to the department. Program Director Larry Hickman and administrator Derrick Kennedy assisted with the inspection. On 2/9/2022 LPA Belfield and LPA Simeon discussed with the administrator Derrick Kennedy during a case management inspection, that all incident reports from December 1, 2021 to January 2022 needed to be submitted to the department for review. The administrator informed LPA's Belfield and Simeon on 2/18/2022 and 2/23/22 via email and follow up phone call, that there were no incidents that took place from December 1, 2021 to January 31, 2022 outside of a run away report that was submitted in January 2022 with C1 (see Lic 811 dated 3/11/2022). Based on a review of communication logs submitted on 2/18/2022 by the administrator, C3 was in the hospital for approximately one month and no report was submitted to the department regarding the incident or the reason for hospitalization. This incident report was submitted to LPA Belfield by the administrator via email on 2/23/2022 after a phone discussion. A call log report obtained by Law Enforcement ( Oakland Police Department) displays 18 calls of service to the facility from 12/1/21 to 1/31/2022. LPA asked the administrator why none this incidents were reported to the department. Administrator stated that they need to talk to the staff to determine the reason for reports not being submitted. During this inspection it was stated by program director that the administrator is responsible for writing all incident reports. Facility cited for violation of section 80061(b) Reporting Requirements.

During the inspection on 2/9/2022 LPA Belfield requested and reviewed client files. There were no files present in the facility for clients C1 and C2. LPA requested these files and they were not available for review. Based on email communication with director Larry Hickman, these files would be submitted to the department. The files for C1 and C2 have not been received for review. During this inspection LPA requested the files for C1 and C2, staff Trent was able to provide the client files for review by LPA Belfield. Although some client information was available, the client file was incomplete as documents were missing. During a review of the file of C1, it was observed by LPA Belfield that C1's medication log was signed off by staff as meds given and during this time the client was on runaway status and not at the facility to receive medication. Facility cited for violation of Section 80070(a) Client records. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six / Interim Licensing Standards, Section 80070(a) client records and 80061(b). An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to the administrator Derrick Kennedy and licensee Larry Hickman.

narrative:
On 8/1/22 at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced case management inspection with Eagle Eye and spoke with Adrian Peebles (ADM), Administrator and Larry Hickman (LIC), Licensee. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on food requirements and an incident involving clients bringing in contraband in the facility. LPA Ng and George Karkazis went to listed facility on 7/15/22 and 7/22/22 to open complaints and observed the main fridge having little to no fresh produce. LPAs saw one stalk of celery and leftovers in the fridge. On the kitchen counter, LPA observed the fruit bowl to have bananas, chips, cookies, and apples. When inspecting the extra fridge and freezer upstairs, LPA’s saw no fresh produce. LPA Ng also reviewed recent receipts and saw that there was one purchase of broccoli and the rest was frozen foods, meat, and some fruits. LPA Ng let ADM know that this did not meet at least 1/3 of the servings recommended in the USDA Basic Food Group Plan. During confidential interviews with clients and staff, all parties disclosed that it was easy to bring in contraband after an outing, approved pass, and coming back from an AWOL or community walk. All parties stated that there is no search conducted, perform room checks a few times a week and will confiscate contraband if found. LPA Ng reviewed incident reports and saw that there is a pattern contraband being brought in. LPA Ng and name, title discussed different techniques to try and prevent/reduce the times clients are bringing in contraband. ---CONT. ON 9099-C -------------

ADM and LIC brainstormed and came to the conclusion that informing youth about their rights and bag searches. ADM will hold a meeting with staff in regards to establishing house rules and informing/requesting bag searches when coming back from an outing. LPA asked the nine staff members, "Do you feel Eagle Eye provides a safe environment for kids?". All Nine staff members responded, "Yes ". LPA asked the five clients, "Have you ever seen a client bullied by staff or other clients?". Four out of five said no, including the client that the Reporting Party was referring to. One did mention that sometimes one client gets "messed with" because he does not follow Covid protocols and other clients feel that he is putting their health and safety at risk. LPA asked the nine staff members, "Have you ever seen a client bullied by staff or other clients?". All nine said that the clients do mess with each other but it's within reason for teenage boys and they do not feel like there is any targeting bullying happening. Most of the staff mentioned that if they see bulling they would stop it immediately. Although the allegations, minor is being bullied while in care and facility does not provide a safe environment for minor in care, may have happened or is valid, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Derrick Kennedy, Administrator..

deficiencies.description:
Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following: (1)	To be accorded dignity in his/her personal relationships with staff and other persons.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by, Based on confidential interviews, clients stated that staff spoke to clients inappropriately. Staff cursed at 2 clients on 3/30/22. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will hold a training in regards to handling sensitive situations that may arise, trauma informed training, and other training related to client relationships. Facility has agree to send training material and sign in sheet to LPA by POC due date.

narrative: They said that a staff member was under the influence of cannabis while driving them. Both witness highlighted that the staff member was driving unsafely as the main reason why they felt the staff was under the influence of cannabis. LPA asked the nine staff members, “Have you ever observed or know of a Staff member being intoxicated or ‘high’ while on duty?” All nine said either “no” or “not sure”. All nine staff members mentioned that they did not physically see it. Some mentioned they only heard about it from some of the clients. One staff member claimed that the allegation is false. They said a staff member was never under the influence around clients. LPA Simien followed up with the question, “why would clients come together and make this up?” The staff member said that the clients made up the story to get back at this staff member because they don’t like them because they enforce the rules. The staff member said that the clients are roommates and have an agenda against that staff member. On 5/18/22 Riverside County Investigator contacted LPA Simien to discuss above listed complaint. The Investigator explained that he was investigating the same complaint. During the discussion it was discovered that one of the clients who told LPA Simien they saw a staff member under the influence of a substance told the Investigator that have never seen a staff member under the influence of a substance. The two statements the client made contradicts each other. Although the allegations, staff transported minor while under influence of a substance, may have happened or is valid, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Adrian Peebles, Administrator .

The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During Investigation, confidential interviews were conducted and needs and services plans reveal that facility followed procedure when discharging C1 (See LIC 811, dated 7/22/22). C1’s reason for discharge was environmental alternatives and refusal of COVID vaccination. All parties confirmed that C1 was adamant on not receiving the COVID vaccination but since Eagle Eye is in Oakland, Oakland Unified School District require all students to be vaccinated. C1’s Social Worker and the facility was in contact with the Education Liaison during this time. C1 grew up in a more rural area and both the facility and C1’s Social Worker felt that Oakland was not the right environment for him. To add to this, an incident with C1 and C2 occurred. C2 reported to staff that C1 touched him inappropriately and felt uncomfortable. C2 was moved downstairs and was on enhanced supervision. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence of Inappropriate discharge and violation of personal rights, therefore the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy was sent to Adrian Peebles, Administrator.

narrative:
brandished a knife at school, not consistently going to school, AWOLS, damaging the facility van door. and failure to improve behavior. CQ was informed of the 14-day notice verbally on 4/25/22. LPA looked up the facility incident report (IR) archive and found the knife incident which occurred on 11/27/21, three IRs for missing school (on 5/2/22, 5/3/22, and 5/4/22 which was after 14-day notice), one AWOL (4/23/22), and the van incident (4/27/22, which was two days after verbal 14-day notice). CQ stated they were told on 4/25/22 that they were given a 14-day notice for missing school and AWOLs. CQ stated they were discriminated against because other clients AWOLed, missed school, and do worse things. CQ said stated that they missed some school and got kicked out at their previous school but had been consistently attending their current school. They stated they only missed school this week (the week starting on 4/25/22) due to having a sore throat and not feeling well. Most individuals interviewed said that other clients were also missing school, AWOLing, with some doing worse/more dangerous things than CQs but did not get 14-day notice. When LPA inquired about the knife incident, CQ stated that they brought the knife to school because they felt threaten by another student and needed it for self-defense. When LPA inquired about the van door incident, CQ stated that it was an accident. They said that the Van door was previously broken and hard to close. When they attempted to close it the first time it did not close, so they closed the door with more force to close it which result in the door flying off the hinge and breaking a window. Most individuals interviewed stated that they knew or heard the van door was broken before that incident. LPA asked individuals interviewed if IUM has ever made them sign a training sheet without receiving training. Most answered not remember ever signing a training sheet, with one individual stating if their name was on a training sheet (it was on the sheet) it was forged and another admitting upper management asked them to create fake training sheets and to fill out the signatures. When LPA inquired about training provided by upper management most individuals stated that it was inadequate. LPA requested and received training material for IRs and trauma informed care (TIC). For IR training the facility sent staff training sign in sheet and a Word document that had reporting requirements regulations copied onto it. For TIC the facility sent a one page flyer that gives a brief general explanation of trauma informed care, unsigned LIC 613B (which lists personal rights), and a staff training sign in sheet. The sheet indicated that one of the trainers was upper management and was qualified to conduct this training since they were STRTP Administrator certified (this is not a qualification to be a trainer of TIC). Facility also stated that TIC training included a 30 minute video but didn't list the title so there was no way for LPA to verify the video. Facility did not provide LPA with certification of TIC for staff.

LPA asked individuals if there were some staff that could not do the basic duties of the job. Individuals stated at least one or more could not or would not do basic job duties. Some examples given are not providing food and not picking up medicine for clients. Not preforming room checks, watching tv, doing personal Laundry, washing personal car, and falling sleep while on duty allowing clients to AWOL unnoticed. These examples indicate that some staff members did not provide adequate care and supervision. Most individuals indicated that management was aware of this. Based on LPA interviews and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the list above allegations, are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. As a result of this visit, there is three General Licensing Standards violations (80072 Personal Rights(a)(3), 80065 Personnel Requirements(a), and 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision(a)) and one Interim Licensing Standards v.4 87065.1 Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirement (c)(5) violation. The facility will be cited (see 809-Ds for details). Appeal rights were discussed and provided to HOS. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Derrick Kennedy, HOS whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

narrative:
On February 22, 2022 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA met and toured the facility with Larry Hickman, Administrator. This Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program is a two story facility located in a residential area. The facility consists of 3 client bedrooms and 2 client bathrooms, living and dining areas, recreational room, kitchen, and office. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There is no pool on the premises. Fire arms are not allowed on the facility premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguishers are throughout the house. Smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors are throughout the house and operational. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. Facility has a fire clearance. First aid kit was observed. Hot water temperature measured at 150 degrees Fahrenheit and hot water heater was turned down during LPA inspection.

Staff and client records will be stored and locked on site. Medications will be centrally stored and locked on site. Disinfectants and other toxic materials will be locked in the garage. Extra bedding and towels are kept unlocked, in the hallway closet. Knives and sharps will be kept locked in the garage. Head of Services (HOS) for this location is Derrick Kennedy. The following items are needed for licensure and pictures will be sent to LPA: - kitchen items arriving (plates, cups, pots/pans) - hot water temperature to read between 105 - 120 degrees Fahrenheit - loose boards will be removed from back and side yard - Board Resolution/Board Minutes, in writing, of changing population age to be served Component II: LPA Pavia discussed with the following, with Administrator: - Administrator on site required hours - facility core services and support - facility emergency intervention plan

On 5/19/23 11:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced Post Licensing inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Larry Hickman, Administrator and toured the facility inside and out. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask wearing. The Short Term Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve six clients. Present during the inspection were two staff and three clients. One client was sleep during the time of the inspection. At 11: 20 AM, LPA Ng observed three bedrooms and three bathrooms. All three bedrooms were double occupancy. Two bathrooms is for clients and the other one is downstairs for staff. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA tested the water temperature and found it to be 118. degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 68 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in the facility office. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Ng interviewed one staff and 1 client. At 11:40 AM Ng toured the backyard. Backyard had a wooden fence and a basketball hoop. The wooden fence is leaning towards the neighbors yard. Administrator stated that he will speak with the neighbors about the fence and let LPA know. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At 12:00 PM, LPA Ng reviewed staff and client files. A review of Guardian Background Check System printed on May 19th, 2023 indicated that all facility staff have DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances (CAIC). At this time, 0 deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Larry Hickman, Administrator.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli made an unannounced visit to the facility and met with Agency Social Worker Alexandra Karagosian. LPA Bertoli inspected the facility at 10:45am and was able to view upstairs and downstairs and front and back yard, and it appears to be clean and passageways are clear of obstructions. The main upstairs bathroom had recent damage to the door and a broken window, but the facility covered the glass and has ordered repairs. There is an ample supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. Water temperature was observed to be at 132.8 degrees (see photo). LPA advised ASW that it would need to be between 105 and 120 prior to LPA leaving the facility or he would have to cite for it. ASW stated that the water heater was inaccessible as they built a solid cabinet around it (no doors - see photo) to keep the youth away from it. LPA is issuing a Type A citation for Section 80088 Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. During the course of reviewing records, it was determined that some Law Enforcement Contacts had not been reported to CCL. It was also determined that some Incident Reports do not identify staff corresponding with the actions taken. LPA is issuing a Technical Advisory on both issues. An exit interview was conducted and Appeal Rights were given to the facility. A copy of this report was given to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
80088  Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies.
(e)(1)	Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to ... attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F ... and not more than 120 degrees F ...  This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA observation, the facility did not ensure that the water temperature was maintained between 105 and 120 degrees, which is an immediate Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will reset water heater to between 105 and 120 degrees and will send photo to CCL of thermometer reading by 4/24/24.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli made an unannounced visit to the facility and met with Agency Social Worker Alexandra Karagosian. Per discussion with LPM Diego, LPA is issuing an advisory note for Section 80088 Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies (e)(1). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
87065.5	Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios(a) In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows:

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli made an unannounced visit to the facility and met with Administrator Melvyn Mahon and Mental Health Rehab Specialist Som Souksumphhan. LPA Bertoli inspected the facility and was able to view upstairs and downstairs and front and back yard, and it appears to be clean and passageways are clear of obstructions. There is an ample supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. During a previous record review, LPA Bertoli observed that staff schedules are not being completed properly. The staff schedule received had time slots indicating 'available', and when asked which staff filled those time slots, it was indicated that they "don't keep track of that". LPA is issuing a Type B citation for Section 87066 Personnel Records. LPA observed that there was only one staff person present at the facility during the visit. Interviews indicated that there had been only one staff person during the morning shift, which began at 7am. The facility was cited under 87065.5(a)(1) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratio of the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 5. An exit interview was conducted and Appeal Rights were discussed and given to the facility. A copy of this report was given to the facility.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA observation and confidential interviews, the facility did not ensure that an adequate staffing ratio was maintained, which is an immediate Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

investigation_findings: 13On 12/11/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of delivering findings from a complaint investigation. LPA met with met with Mental Health Residential Specialist (MHRS), Som Souksumphan and spoke with Administrator, Derrick Kennedy over the phone and informed of the purpose of the visit. The complaint alleged that staff did not prevent a physical altercation between children resulting in a child's injuries. Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, the following was found. On 10/5/24 a physical altercation occurred at the Vista facility which resulted in two clients’ injuries. Before the physical altercation, two Vista residents appeared at the Horizons facility unannounced. Staff at Horizons was aware of the conflicts between the residents and did not allow the Vista residents to enter, however, staff did not communicate the Vista resident’s presence at Horizon facility to Vista staff. There had been no internal communication between staff on shift at either facility on 10/5/24 regarding the resident’s whereabouts, therefore, staff did not prevent the physical altercation that occurred. (Report continued on LIC9099-C)

deficiencies.description:
87065.2 Personal Duties
(b)Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and document research, licensee did not ensure the protection and care of children at all times which poses a immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees send email to all staff in organization identifying staff contacts, guidance on reporting incidents, best practices for internal communication, and a plan for a training to be held on the mentioned topics. Licensee agrees to send proof of the email being sent to all staff to LPA by 12/12/24 at 5pm.

87072  Personal Rights 
(c)	The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights...: (1)To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect...
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and document research, licensee did not ensure children in care were accorded the right to live in a healthy and comfortable home which poses a immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to hold training on maintaining a trauma informed environment and dealing with difficult members in residents care provider team. Licensee will send a copy of training materials and topics to LPA via email by 12/12/24 5pm

narrative: On 11/06/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio conducted a visit to the facility for a case management inspection. LPA met with (TITLE) and (TITLE) informed on the purpose of the visit. During an earlier inspection conducted at the facility on 11/06/24 at 11am related to complaint control #21-CR-20241016122832 and 21-CR-20241015215221, LPA observed an incident in which resident became escalated with S1. S1 expressed frustration to LPA, LPA reminded S1 about having a trauma informed approach with the residents in care. LPA identified an area in which a technical advisory maybe beneficial. LPA is issuing a Technical Advisory regarding Personal Rights Section 87072(c)(16). LPA discussed with S1 about a trauma informed care approach and treating clients in care with dignity and respect. See LIC811. During this inspection LPA conducted a walk through of the facility and observed there to be no menu posted in the facility and less than a two day supply of fresh perishable foods. LPA asked staff if menu could be provided during the inspection, staff was able to email LPA a copy of the menu however food menu was unable to be posted due to the facility printer being broken. LPA is issuing a citation of per STRTP ILS Section 87076 (b) Food Service and Section 87076 (c)(1). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights, and a copy of this report was emailed and left with the facility Administrator whose signature confirms the receipt of this report.

investigation_findings: 13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli made an unannounced visit and met with Mental Health Rehabilitation Specialist Som Souksumphhan at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of the investigation, the LPA inspected the facility, reviewed records and conducted confidential interviews. It was confirmed that the overnight staff had been sleeping during the shift and that the facility is not following their Program Statement regarding room checks. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the allegations occurred. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Title 22 deficiencies were cited and Appeal Rights were provided and discussed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was given to the facility.

deficiencies.description: 87065.5	Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios	(a) In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children,... (2) 	During the hours of 10 pm to 7 am, there shall be one awake ... direct care staff for every six children...  This requirement was not met, as evidenced by: Based on LPA interviews and record review, the facility did not ensure that the overnight staff was awake during their shift, which is an immediate Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will do notification to all staff that overnight shift must be awake. Overnight staff will send hourly texts to management during shift for one week and management will email CCL after that week to confirm texts were received and confirm staff was awake.  Facility will send acknowledgement of this POC by 11/15/24.

deficiencies.description: 87022 Plan of Operation (f)	The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the plan of operation and may be cited for not doing so.  This requirement was not met, as evidenced by: Based on LPA interviews and record review, the facility did not ensure that the facility followed the Program Statement portion of the Plan of Operations, which is an immediate Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will send notification to staff that bedchecks are required every 15 minutes by overnight staff, and will submit weekly logs to CCL by 12/2/24.  Facility will send acknowledgement of this POC by 11/15/24.

narrative: On 10-30-24 11:16AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis was conducting a complaint investigation for Eagle Eye Horizons, complaint #21-CR-20240824081656, dated 8-24-24. The purpose of the visit was to conduct confidential interviews and conduct document research. LPA asked Melvin Mahon for his staff file. Melvin Mahon stated he did not know where staff files are kept, not on premise. Melvin Mahon stated that staff files may be located at Eagle Eye Vistas or at company headquarters, located in Oakland. LPA Karkazis was unable to view Melvin Mahon's file to conduct document research. Staff files are not present or available to view at this facility. A citation is being issued for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 4, Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency 80044(c), Type B. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was given to Melvin Mahon, Administrator

On the above date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Brian Bertoli and George Karkasis made an unannounced visit to the facility and met with Mental Health Rehab Specialist Som Souksumphhan and Facility Manager Beverly Trent. LPAs inspected the facility at 11:05am and found the following: The kitchen oven was turned on and the door was left open. When LPAs inquired, staff indicated that the heater wasn't working and it was supposed to be fixed the next day. LPAs are issuing an Advisory Note for ILS section 87072 Personal Rights. LPAs also observed that the water temperature in the kitchen was 138 degrees and are citing General Requirement section 80088. LPAs also observed that the upstairs bathroom had garbage on the floor and in the tub and the sink had debris in it, and are citing under section 80087 Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to the facility.

On 11-1-2024, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis and Brian Bertoli conducted an unannounced inspection at Eagle Eye Horizons. LPAs met with Beverly Trent, Facility Manager and toured the facility. The purpose of the visit was to deliver deficiencies that were discovered during the complaint investigation of complaint #21-CR-20240824081656 dated 8-24-24. These are the deficiencies: A physical altercation occurred on 8-15-24 between the Administrator and a C1. Based on confidential interviews and document research, the Administrator grabbed the C1 by the neck. The facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards, Article 10.1 Emergency Interventions Prohibition 87095.01(a)(1). Type A A physical altercation occurred on 8-15-24 between the Administrator and a C1. The Administrator physically attacked C1 in care while the C1 was having behavioral issues. The facility is being cited for Health and Safety Code, Chapter 3, Article 05, Conduct Inimical 1550(c). Type A On 10-9-24 LPA Karkazis conducted document research at the facility and requested Needs and Service plans for two clients. C1 did not have needs and service plans, C2’s last Needs and Service Plan was dated 07-2024. The facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards, Article 06, Modifications to Needs and Service Plans 87068.3(a). Type B During the complaint investigation #21-CR-20240824081656, it was discovered that the Administrator did not follow a trauma-informed care approach nor the C1’s treatment plan. The facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards, Article 6, Personnel Duties 87065.2(b)(8). Type B During a physical altercation that occurred on 8-15-24 between the Administrator and a C1, it was discovered that the Administrator did not follow the facility’s emergency intervention plan. The facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards, Article 03, Plan of Operation 87022(f). Type B An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was given to Beverly Trent, Facility Manager.
