On the above date, a Legal Non-Compliance Conference was held at the San Bruno Community Care Licensing office regarding the Eagle Eye-Horizons STRTP facility . The following persons were in attendance: From CCL: Regional Manager Helga Wong, Licensing Program Manager Isabel Diego, Licensing Program Analysts Brian Bertoli and George Karkazis From Quest Programs: Executive Director Larry Hickman, Board Member Ben Johnson, and Program Manager/Administrator Derrick Kennedy From Alameda County (via Teams): Mia Buckner-Preston, Division Director From DHCS (via Teams): Blair Hock, Lead Analyst; Stephen Conn, SSM The issues discussed included: Complaints and citations since the facility started in February 2023 Interest in possible other facility type Staff training for: Personal Rights; Needs and Services Plans and Modifications to Needs and Services Plan; Emergency Interventions; and Title 22 Regulations. The Personal Rights training will be obtained through an outside training program, and the other trainings may be held in-house. Continuation on page 2.

Quarterly submission of LIC 500 and staff schedules. Administrator should be on the premises for a minimum of 30 hours per week. The Administrator cannot oversee both sister facilities, and the facility will send monthly update and progress until they find another Administrator for Eagle Eye-Vista Facility will create a plan to make staff and youth files readily available for LPA access on inspection. Also, will ensure that all Needs and Service Plans and Updates are available upon request for review. The facility will have quarterly inspections by CCL to confirm compliance. The facility will notify CCL if they are interested in TSP with a written notice within 30 days.

On 4/9/25, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Celeste Aparicio made an announced collateral visit to the facility to conduct a confidential interview. LPA met with Facility Manager, Eric Stocker and informed Facility Manager on the purpose of the visit. LPAs conducted one client confidential interview related to an outside investigation. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with, Facility Manager whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli made an unannounced visit to the facility and met with Administrator Derrick Kennedy. The purpose of the visit was to complete a follow-up inspection for Legal/Non-Compliance. On 2/19/2025 the licensee participated in a Legal Non-Compliance Conference at the San Bruno CCL office. The Licensee agreed to do the following in order to bring the facility into compliance no later than the following dates: Quarterly Inspections: The facility will be subject to increased monitoring by (Community Care Licensing) CCL, which may include but is not limited to increased inspections, record reviews, and interviews with facility residents and personnel. CCL will conduct quarterly inspections for 2 years assessing facility premises compliance and completeness of records and trainings. Training Binder: Facility will create training binder/folder within 30 days of NCC to show initial training for each staff person, annual training logs, and separate training records for facility manager and Administrator. Which include: Training topics, training hours, training materials, training dates, and trainers information. Training binders must be available upon demand, and in the facility during regular business hours. Personnel Records(80044)(c) Staff Training: Within 60 days of this NCC, Licensee will ensure that each staff member who interacts with residents receives additional training on the California Code of Regulations, Title 22 requirements for (1) Personal Rights; (2) Needs and Services Plans and Modifications to Needs and Services Plan; (3) Emergency Interventions; and (4) Title 22 Regulations. The Personal Rights training will be obtained through an outside training program, and the other trainings may be held in-house. The certificates for outside training(s) and the detailed training materials for in-house trainings will be submitted to the licensing agency as well as maintained on site for future training purposes. The licensee shall develop a post-training competency test/evaluation covering the above topics, and completed tests/evaluations for each training participant shall be available for review on site.

4. LIC 500: Beginning the month of this NCC, facility will complete quarterly submission of LIC 500/staff schedules to CCL, including Administrator hours worked at the facility. Administrator should be on the premises for a minimum of 30 hours per week. Administrator cannot oversee both facilities, and the facility is to send CCL a monthly update and process until they find another Administrator. 5. Access to Files, Needs and Services Plans: Facility will create a plan within 30 days to make staff and youth files readily available for LPA access on inspection. Also, will ensure that all Needs and Service Plans and Updates are available upon request for review. 6. Technical Support Program (optional): CCL has recommended TSP (Technical Support Program) for the facility. If the facility is interested they will notify CCL within 30 days with a written notice. LPA Bertoli reviewed the above items with Administrator Kennedy. The discussion was as follows: Quarterly inspections will continue as stated. LPA will contact Administrator upon arrival to the facility (if not already present) to facilitate access to records. Facility is starting to put together training binder and is expected to be completed by next inspection. Staff training is being completed as stated. No changes in staff since last visit. Training records will be reviewed during next inspection. LIC 500 has been received and is up to date. Facility has a staff person that is a prior Administrator that is in the process of reactivating his Administrator Certificate. This will result in having separate Administrators for each facility. Facility is working on more direct access to staff files. This will likely result in having records available online so that they can be sent to LPA if Administrator is not available on site to access them. Facility may utilize Technical Support Program and will notify LPA when they are ready to do so. No deficiencies were cited at this visit. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Kennedy and a copy of this report was given to him.

investigation_findings: 13On 05/16/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings regarding the above allegation. LPA met with the Direct Care Staff, Jenny Chung and informed on the purpose of the visit. On the allegations of Staff did not prevent inappropriate sexual behavior between children in care: LPA reviewed documentation and conducted confidential interviews. After the review of documentation and interviews with relevant parties, it was found that the allegation could not be confirmed due to inconsistent statements and documentation obtained. Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with the Direct Care Staff.

narrative:
On November 8, 2022 at 10:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA met and toured the facility with Larry Hickman, Administrator. This Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program is a two story facility located in a residential area. The facility consists of 3 client bedrooms and 3 client bathrooms, living and dining areas, kitchen, and offices. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There is a pool on the facility premises, and meets safety standards. Fire arms are not allowed on the facility premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguishers are throughout the house. Smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors are throughout the house and operational. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. Facility has a fire clearance. First aid kit was observed. Hot water temperature measured at 110 degrees Fahrenheit.

Staff and client records will be stored and locked on site. Medications will be centrally stored and locked on site. Disinfectants and other toxic materials will be locked in the garage. Extra bedding and towels are kept unlocked, in the hallway closet. Knives and sharps will be kept locked in the garage. Head of Services (HOS) for this location is Sohavani Mand. This property is licensed as of today, 11/8/22. LPA will mail Administrator a copy of the license. Component II: LPA Pavia discussed with the following, with Administrator: - Administrator on site required hours - facility core services and support - facility emergency intervention plan

On 4-13-23 10:18AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Post Licensing inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Derrick Kennedy, Head of Services and toured the facility inside and out. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask wearing. The Short Term Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve six clients. Present during the inspection were two staff and three clients. Two clients declined to be interviewed. At 10:35AM, LPA Karkazis reviewed five client and five staff files. All files reviewed were complete and in good order. At 1:14PM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed three bedrooms and three bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 112.4 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 68 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in the facility office. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed two staff and NUMBER clients. At 2:12PM Karkazis toured the backyard. There was a swimming pool, with a six foot locked fence surrounding the pool. The swimming pool was secure The backyard was in good repair and clean. continued on LIC 809-C

continued from LIC 809 At this time there were two deficiencies. A Technical Violation was issued, Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87088(c)(4) Physical Plant. A Technical Advisory was issued, California Code of Regulations 80023(d)(2) Disaster Preparedness. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Derrick Kennedy, Head of Services.

investigation_findings: 13Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent a shooting attempt at a minor while in care: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews and document research. During confidential interviews with staff and clients, interviews were inconsistent with the description of the gun, its usage, where it was drawn from, or if law enforcement found a gun upon searches. During document research, LPA reviewed shift notes, the incident report dated 11-10-22, and law enforcement reports. There was no evidence of a gun or any weapon used in shift notes, the incident report 11-10-22, or law enforcement reports. Searches were conducted by law enforcement of staff, the facility, and surrounding areas, no gun or weapons found. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff did not prevent a shooting attempt at a minor while in care. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Derrick Kennedy, Head of Serv..

narrative: continued from LIC 9099 Regarding the allegation that staff do not treat minors with dignity and respect: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews and document research. During confidential interviews with staff and clients, interviews were inconsistent. Interviews revealed that staff always yell at clients, but cannot recall who was yelling, when, how many times, why, or what was stated. Other interviews revealed that staff were always respectful and treated clients with dignity. LPA conducted document research in shift notes, incident reports, and law enforcement reports. There was no evidence to support that staff do not treat minors with dignity and respect. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff did not treat minors with dignity and respect. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation that staff did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for minors in care: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews and document research. During confidential interviews with staff and clients, interviews were inconsistent. Interviews revealed that staff always provide safety and comfort for minors in care. Other interviews revealed that weapons are present at the facility, or safety and comfort are compromised when clients tease each other or argue. LPA conducted document research in shift notes, incident reports, and law enforcement reports. There was no evidence to support that staff do not provide safety and comfort for clients. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for minors in care. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent minors from AWOLing: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews and document research. During confidential interviews with staff and clients, interviews were inconsistent. Interviews revealed that when a client attempts to AWOL, staff will try to redirect the client, ask why they are AWOLing, how can they help, provide assistance, ask where they are going and when they will return. Staff always advise clients to make a good choice. Other interviews revealed that staff never tried to stop clients from AWOLing. LPA conducted document research in shift notes, incident reports, and law enforcement reports. There was no evidence to support that staff do not prevent minors from AWOLing. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff did not prevent minors from AWOLing. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Derrick Kennedy, Head of Services.
investigation_findings: 13Regarding the allegation that staff member intimidates and threatens minors: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews and document research. During confidential interviews with staff and clients, interviews were inconsistent, there were no threats or intimidation, or weapons were present at the facility. However, there were other conversations regarding weapons, which may have created false threats and intimidation. LPA conducted document research in shift notes, incident reports, and law enforcement reports. There was no evidence of intimidation or threats to minors by staff. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff member intimidates and threatens minors. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED continued on LIC 9099-C

deficiencies.description:
80066(f) Personel Records-In all cases, personnel records shall document the hours actually worked.

narrative: At 5/19/23 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Derrick Kennedy, Head of Service. It was discovered during a review that the facility accepted a client over the age of 17, which is beyond the terms of the facility license. The facility was cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80022(k) Plan of Operation: The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. Based on documentation obtained on 5/15/23, the facility acted beyond the terms of its license by admitting C1 (see LIC811 dated 5/19/23) who was over the age of 17. deficiencies.description:
80022(k) Plan of Operation. The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.
 This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on documentation obtained on 5/15/23, the facility acted beyond the terms of it’s license by admitting a client who was over the age of 17 which is an immediate Health, Safety, and Personal Rights Risk to clients in care.

narrative: continued from LIC 9099 Clients stated that they preferred more ready prepared snacks such as ramen and frozen burritos. Staff state that they try to limit these types of prepared snacks because of the poor nutritional value. LPA conducted document research in shift notes, and grocery receipts. There was no evidence found of clients’ dietary needs not being met. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff do not meet minor’s dietary needs. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation that staff do not properly supervise minors: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. During confidential interviews with staff and clients, inconsistent information was provided. Confidential interviews stated two staff always walk around the facility and watch from the living room, checking on clients. While other interviews stated that two staff members are present, while one staff member is in the office conducting administrative duties, frequently exiting to conduct checks on clients. Document research in shift notes and LIC 500 dated 5-3-23 reveals two staff on duty except for graveyard shift. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff do not properly supervise minors. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation that Licensee does not provide minors with activities: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. During confidential interviews with staff and clients, inconsistent information was provided. Most staff and clients state that the facility takes clients weekly to arcades, restaurants, movies and the beach. Some staff stated there were few activities in the beginning of the year. LPA conducted document research in shift notes and found weekly outing for arcades, drives, and restaurants, and beach visits. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that Licensee does not provide minors with activities. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. At this time there are no violations. Technical Assistance was issued. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Derrick Kennedy, Head of Service.
investigation_findings: 13On 5-31-23 1:58PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at Eagle Eye Vistas and met with Derrick Kennedy, Head of Service. continued from LIC 9099-A Regarding the allegation that unqualified staff are writing clinician notes: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, clinicians, and conducted document research. During confidential interviews with staff, clients and clinicians, inconsistent information was provided. Some staff members stated they were asked by management to write clinician notes, while other staff said they were not asked and have no knowledge of this. Clients interviewed have no knowledge of unqualified staff writing clinician notes. Current and former clinicians were interviewed and stated they have no knowledge of unqualified staff writing clinician notes. LPA conducted document research in shift notes, rehabilitation notes, clinician notes, and SharePoint files from the Department of Health Care Service (DHCS). All notes submitted were written by qualified personnel. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that unqualified staff are writing clinician notes. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation that facility does not ensure clients educational rights: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, high school officials and conducted document research. During confidential interviews with staff, clients, and high school officials, inconsistent information was provided. Interviewees stated that staff always encourage clients to go to school, always mentioning the benefits and future opportunities that attendance will bring. Interviewees stated that increased allowance is offered for regular school attendance. Other interviewees stated that staff provide no encouragement at the time of refusal. High school officials stated that attendance was poor in the beginning of the year, now attendance has greatly improved. High school officials stated that the facility cooperates and communicates with the school to ensure client attendance. LPA conducted document research in shift notes and high school attendance records. There were above average of unexcused absences with clients in the beginning of the school year. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove facility does not ensure clients educational rights. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation facility does not have a proper food menu: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. During confidential interviews with staff and clients, inconsistent information was provided. Some interviewees stated that there is a food menu, and it is always followed and posted. Other interviewees stated that the menu sometimes is not posted nor followed. LPA conducted document research upon unannounced visits and found a meal menu posted with food inventory to match. continued on LIC 9099-C

continued from LIC 9099-A Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove facility does not have a proper food menu. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation that clients are being denied services: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. During confidential interviews with staff and clients, inconsistent information was provided. Some interviewees stated that facility takes clients to all scheduled appointments and activities. Other interviewees stated that they do not take clients out for planned activities. LPA conducted document research in shift notes and found no evidence of clients being denied services, only refusals by clients. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that clients are being denied services. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the allegation that client nutritional needs are not being met: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. During confidential interviews with staff and clients, inconsistent information was provided. Some staff and clients stated that clients’ nutritional needs were met, while other staff and clients stated that the facility might run out of milk or need more fruits and vegetables. Clients stated that alternative and modified meals are available to meet client nutritional needs. LPA witnessed two days supply of perishable food and seven days supply of non-perishable food during every inspection, 5-16-23, 5-17-23, 5-23-23, 6-23-23, and 8-4-23. Clients stated that they preferred more ready prepared snacks such as ramen and frozen burritos. Staff state that they try to limit these types of prepared snacks because of the poor nutritional value. LPA conducted document research in shift notes, and grocery receipts. There was no evidence found of clients’ nutritional needs not being met. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff do not meet minor’s nutritional needs. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and provided. A copy of this report was left with Derrick Kennedy, Head of Service.

narrative: On 02/14/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio conducted a case management visit to the facility to discuss necessary revisions in client files. met_with: Case Manager Teresa McNeally; Facility Manager Amandra Trent
narrative:
On 11/26/24, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Mariah Hawkins and Celeste Aparicio conducted a required annual inspection. LPAs met with Case Manager Teresa McNeally and Facility Manager Beverly Trent at the facility and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPAs spoke with Administrator Derrick Kennedy over the phone and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPAs toured the facility site, reviewed 5 client files, and interviewed 2 staff and 1 client. 5 clients were in care, 4 clients were present, and 3 declined an interview. LPAs observed the facility to maintain individual client files. The facility is a two-story house in a residential neighborhood and has 3 double-occupancy bedrooms and 3 client bathrooms. LPAs observed the hot water to measure within the permitted range. There is a pool in the backyard that is surrounded by a tall fence with a locked gate. During the tour, around 12:40PM, LPAs observed some areas in need of cleaning. There was trash and food debris and substance residue on the stairs, trash piles in the downstairs den, and unwashed plates in client room and in den, one of the downstairs bathroom vents was blocked with dust, and the kitchen refrigerator had food residue and debris throughout interiors and had the bottom vent blocked with dust. LPAs observed unsecured medications in a client's bedroom. Case Manager was unfamiliar with the items and removed them from the client's bedroom. LPAs also observed multiple beds with none to limited bed linens and linens in the linen closet were not readily accessible due to disorganization of closet and it being unclear whether linens were clean and unused. During the personnel file review, LPAs found that staff S1 (See LIC 811) does not have a background clearance associated to the facility. LPAs informed Administrator about the need to remove the staff from the premises. SEE PAGE 2

PAGE 2 During the client file review, LPAs observed that 4 of 5 client files were missing tuberculosis (TB) test results and 5 of 5 client files were missing current allowance distribution records. LPAs are issuing citations of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Sections 80076 Food Service, 80087 Buildings and Grounds, 80019 Criminal Record Clearance, 80069 Client Medical Assessments, 80070 Client Records, and Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87088 Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies. Additionally, due to the criminal record clearance violation, per CCR 80019(g), LPAs are assessing an immediate civil penalty of $100 per day in violation up to 5 days in violation, for a total of $500. See LIC 421BG. A continuation visit will be conducted to complete this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, the LIC 811, the LIC 421BG, and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Facility Manager Beverly Trent, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Case Manager Teresa McNeally; Facility Manager Amandra Trent
narrative: On 12/18/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to continue the annual inspection initiated on 11/26/24. A previous continuation visit was conducted on 12/11/24. LPA met with Administrator Derrick Kennedy and informed of the purpose of the visit. During visit, LPA reviewed 5 personnel files, emergency intervention records, disaster preparedness records, and other operations-related records. LPA also discussed with Administrator inspection authority and ways to ensure the availability of personnel files upon request at the facility site while also ensuring the privacy of staff members' confidential information. During the record review, LPA observed files to be well-organized and complete with all required sections. However, LPA observed deficiencies within some sections. LPA learned that the emergency intervention training does not include a hands-on competency test. LPA observed that 4 of 5 staff files reviewed had expired emergency intervention certification. LPA observed that 4 of 4 care staff files were missing performance evaluations. LPA observed that no staff files contained facility manager training, including those staff indicated by Administrator to be facility managers. LPA learned that an emergency drill had not been conducted in the past quarter and that documentation of an emergency drill was not available for review on site. Based on the above, LPA Hawkins is issuing citations of Health and Safety Code Section 1565(c) and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Sections 87095.65(b)(6), 87095.65(e), 87066(b)(6), and 87065(f)(2). LPA identified additional area(s) in which technical support may be beneficial. Refer to the LIC 9102s dated 12/18/24. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, the LIC 811 Confidential Names List, the LIC 9102s, and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Administrator Derrick Kennedy.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
investigation_findings: 13On 11/18/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted a complaint inspection for Edgewood-San Francisco Protestant Orphanage to conclude the investigation with regards to the above-mentioned allegations. LPA spoke with Augie Arballo, Administrator on 7/30/2020 and informed him that the finding were unsubstantiated. The LPAs conducting the investigation received and reviewed additional documents provided by the facility. LPA Mendoza and Aoki conducted interviews of witnesses, conducted a physical plant inspection, reviewed facility documentation and facility video. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the Facility Managers were not qualified at the time and the premises were not free of obstructions. Therefore, the above allegations have been changed to substantiated. Appeal rights were provided and discussed with the Administrator. Due to Covid-19 requirements, the closing of the allegation was conducted via telephone with a scan of this LIC9099 to Administrator Augie Arballo for a signature and a scan back to Community Care Licensing.

deficiencies.description: 80087(c) Buildings and Grounds- All outdoor and indoor passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, open porches and other areas of potential hazard shall be kept free of obstruction. Electrical cords observed in the hallways Stow East &West and Halleck Common Area. This poses an immediate risk to the Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care. .
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility has already removed all extension cords and portable heaters from the hallways in all the cottages. Staff have been informed that they are no longer to be used as they are a potential hazard.

deficiencies.description: 87022(c)(3)(A) PLAN OF OPERATION - (A) Complete job descriptions of all positions, including the number of staff employed, and their respective classifications, qualifications, and duties. Facility Managers (FM1 & FM2) failed to meet the 2 year work experience in the mental health field when hired for this position which poses an immediate risk to the Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in c
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility shall follow the job description of Facility Managers must have 2 years work experience  in the mental health field.  The Facility Managers in question have since met the requirement and are in compliance.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza, on 01/27/2020 at 11:30 AM, conducted scheduled case management via Microsoft Team (virtual inspection) due to COVID-19. During the inspection, LPA Mendoza met with Administrator Augie Arballo and Justine Underhill, Chief Program Officer. The purpose of today's meeting was to discuss the recent incident/discharge on (C1) (please refer to LIC 811, dated 01/27/2021 for confidential names.) Also, to discuss the facility's current implementation/ COVID-19 Mask Wearing Policy. On 12/10/21 San Francisco Department of Public Health (SFDPH) and Community Care Licensing (CCL) held a COVID-19 Migration meeting with the facility. During the meeting, the facility informed both agencies that the facility implemented a Mask Wearing Policy for the clients in care, approved by Licensing Program Manager Zaid Hakim and Regional Manager Nelson Martinez. The Mask Wearing Policy is to ensure that the facility maintains the safest possible environment. That all clients and staff must wear a mask while on campus and when around others. The Mask Wearing Policy is administered to all new clients and their authorized representatives at intake and discussed with both parties. Per the conditions, the youth is given three incidents/chances. During each incident the facility/ clients team will be working closely with the authorized representative and scheduling meetings/phone calls, and coming up with a safety plan on getting the youth to wear their masks. If it gets to three incidents, then the facility will be discussing discharging the child from the program. During the 12/10/20 meeting, CCL stressed the importance of a behavioral approach that is consistent with their Program Statement and the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards. Cont. LIC 809-C

There would need to be a reasonable process to engage in before discharging the youth. If the facility happens to come across this, they must notify LPA Mendoza and would need to start with having incident reports sent on initial and subsequent refusals to wear masks. Also, should follow all recent ACL (All County Letters) and PINS (Provider Information Notices). The facility informed CCL that they would comply with the above. On 1/19/21 via email LPA Mendoza was informed by Justine that the facility has a new client (C1) who is showing early signs of refusing to wear their mask. The facility will start implementing their Mask Wearing Policy and will reach out to the authorized representative if there are no changes. They wanted guidance on what to do if the client continues. LPA responded, the staff should be documenting all of this, and must include how frequent the client needs prompting on this behavior. If the behavior continues after the facility meets with the authorized representative and create a safety plan an incident report must be submitted to LPA Mendoza. In the incident report, the facility should include the safety plan/strategies that the facility will be doing with the youth, and include what was discussed in the meeting and who attended. Also, to include the number of interventions that the facility staff took with the youth, and what they were and they outcomes. If it gets to the final stages where the facility will be discharging the youth the facility must send another incident report/follow up. Include in the IR that this is the clients final stage on Mask Wearing Policy and include what was discussed with the authorized representative and attach the discharge notice that was submitted to the authorized representative. On 1/25/2020 LPA Mendoza received another email from Justine informing LPA that C1 is still refusing to wear their mask, and the facility staff have had three separate meetings with the C1, C1's treatment team, and parent. The facility is planning to discharge the C1. LPA received two SIR on 1/26/21, dated 1/20/21 and 1/21/21. After reviewing both SIR the facility did not include what the clients safety plan around mask wearing, or what was discussed in the meetings. The SIR had no information on dates or times the facility meeting with C1's authorized representative. The facility asked C1 open ended questions about the mask wearing policy. Both SIRs did not elaborate on steps or methods that the

facility took. Also, what were the outcomes from each step. Per the IR, C1 would struggle with following staff instructions to keep her mask on above her nose and mouth throughout the day. 1/21/21 was the final warning and IR did not include discharge notices or written notice that was sent to authorized representative. During todays inspection, LPA took the time to go over CCL's expectations when it comes to Mask Wearing Policy and ILS 87068.4 Removal And/Or Transfer Procedures. LPA expressed the importance of the facility sending detailed IRs to LPA Mendoza and to submit them to LPA within 24-48 hours if the youth is exhibiting daily struggles with mask wearing. The IRs must include all the interventions that were taken, outcomes, issue around mask wearing, and include the seriousness/urgency on removing the youth. IR must include the timeline on discussions, meetings, and phone calls. If it reaches to the level of discharging the youth. The facility must follow ILS 87068.4 and ensure they submit a written notice to authorized representative and include the authorized rep in discharge procedure. C1 struggled with wearing her mask on a daily. The facility has to constantly prompt the youth to wear or mask. The facility even got the C1 different types of mask, however C1 still refused. C1 will be getting discharged today at 3:30. C1 was a private placement/hospital diversion and was only scheduled to receive services with the facility for 14 days. C1's mother agreed to pick up the youth. The facility informed LPA that the facility had a total of 5 SIRs on C1 regarding mask wearing. Administrator, will forward SIRs the additional 3 IRs that LPA is missing 2nd 21st IR, 23rd, and 26th) to LPA by end of day. No citations were cited during todays inspection. An exit interview was conducted. Administrator agrees to sign all three documents and will return back to LPA via email.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
met_with: Chief Executive Officer Lynn Dolce, Chief Program Officer Justine Underhill, Human Resources Director Michael Russel, and Administrator Augie Arballo.
narrative:
A Case Management Legal/Non-Compliance on 02/02/2020 at 3:30 pm was conducted virtually via Microsoft Teams due the COVID-19 pandemic. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the Non-Compliance quarterly submissions from April 2020 to December 2020 and other conditions of the NCC. During the meeting CCL staff and facility staff also discussed a new electronic staff training system that the facility would like to incorporate. Present in the meeting were Chief Executive Officer, Lynn Dolce, Chief Program Officer Justine Underhill, Human Resources Director, Michael Russel, and Administrator, Augie Arballo. Present from CDSS were Regional Manager (RM) Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Zaid Hakim, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett. On 10/07/2019 a Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) was held with facility representatives. Following the 10/07/2019 NCC, it was determined the facility was not in full compliance in meeting CCL’s expectations regarding policies, procedures, and documentation. On 03/06/2020 an Informal Meeting was conducted to clarify CCL’s expectations on NCC submissions. Per the NCC requirements, it was agreed that the facility will submit the below items to CCL in one complete package, on a quarterly basis on the 1st of every month. 1. Personal Rights Training- All staff training on CCL Personal Rights. The facility is to include a sign-in sheet, training materials, trainer’s information/credentials, and include the length of this training. Please refer to LIC 809-C..

2. “What Grooming Looks Like” Training-. All staff and clients at intake must be trained on this topic. The facility is to include a sign-in sheet. Sign-in sheets for clients will include the youths full name, DOB, authorized representatives full name, and date of placement. Training for both staff and youth will include training materials and trainer’s qualification along with summary. 3. Training on Boundaries- An all staff training. The facility is to include a sign-in sheet, training materials, trainer’s information/credentials, and include the length of this training. 4. Twice a month Upper Management team will conduct unannounced up night visits and submit log, with date time, and summary. This will be submitted quarterly. 5. Up night Bed Check Logs-Submit up night bed logs on a quarterly basis for all cottages. Complete full overnight bed log. Enter all information, youths name, room number, circle shift. Two staff conduct room checks. Both signatures, and manager initials and signs on bottom of each shift. LPA Mendoza received the following quarterly submissions: 05/01/2020, 08/01/2020, and 12/01/2020. The facility requested an extension in October 2020 to submit the 11/01/2020 submission on 12/01/2020 due to the facility having a COVID-19 outbreak, which was approved by LPM Hakim. The facility submitted all three NCC submissions on time and in a full package. LPA Mendoza notes the facility did not submit a complete submission on 05/01/2020, the facility submitted all items in various emails to LPA Mendoza. Which were observed to be complete after receipt of all items. Per the comprehensive review of all quarterly submissions from February 2020 to October 2020, LPA Mendoza found no issues with client training on grooming. This training is performed with new clients at intake. LPA observed the following inconsistencies with the bed logs and NCC submissions: Please cont.to LIC 809-C for additional page.

· Per the NCC, the facility is only required to submit the overnight logs. The facility submitted staff shift logs for all staff shifts (AM, Swing, and Overnight), rather than just the overnight records. This was acknowledged during the meeting on 02/02/2021 and the facility committed to correcting this item. · Throughout LPA's review, LPA found several staff shift logs that did not have all items completed on the bed logs. At times, LPA could not always confirm the appropriate shift log, client's room number, or entry date. The facility must ensure to complete all items on overnight bed logs. This was acknowledged during the meeting on 02/02/2021 and the facility committed to correcting this item. Example: For February 2020, Halleck cottage did not have overnight bed logs for 2/1,2/2, 2/7, and 2/16. For February 2020, the upper managers only performed one random up night visit and not two. For the 08/1/2020 submission, which covers May 2020 to July 2020: May 2020 Halleck Cottage bed logs were missing: 5/6/20 and 5/12/2020. July Bed logs missing: 7/25/20, 7/29/20,7/30/20. Also, several entries did not have management approvals/signatures. For June 2020, there was only one upper management inspection performed. For the 12/01/2020 submission, which covers August 2020 to October 2020: September Stow Cottage, LPA observed numerous entries with only one staff performing bed checks due to the facility being short-staffed. Also, a few entries where bed checks started at 1-2 am. Overnight bed logs are to be performed from 10:15 pm- 6:45 am, with 15-minute bed checks. LPA Mendoza also found this with the October 2020 Halleck cottage. Also, for October 2020, LPA observed the facility did not conduct the twice a month upper management unannounced visit. Please cont. LIC 809-C.

Staff training- The facility submitted several excel spreadsheets and a list of names for all staff training (Personal Rights, Personal Boundaries, and Grooming/Child Abuse). LPA found in every submission that all staff did not complete all three pieces of training. For the staff that did not complete any of the trainings, the facility did not give any explanation. Due to the high volume of excel sheets and the list of names, LPA had a difficult time cross-reference names because excel sheets did not always include all three training pieces in one excel sheet or list. Also, reports did not include the length of time of each training. The excel sheet only had the time the staff member completed the training. · The facility is not required to submit Up night Facility manager logs. Moving forward, CCL is only asking for Upper Manager oversight logs to ensure staff accountability, to be verified 2x per month, captured on the training reporting tool. During today's meeting, CCL provided the facility with a new training reporting tool/excel sheet template that meets the Department’s requirements per terms of the NCC. CCL would like the facility to incorporate this tool for all staff training and client grooming submissions, the benefit being a centralized document that is user-friendly and easy to understand. CCL informed the facility that CCL wants to ensure the facility follows all NCC guidelines, but that the tools used by both parties are practical and efficient. During the meeting LPA Hiett provided a demonstration of a sample training reporting tool and provided instruction as to how to navigate and use the training reporting tool. Facility staff mentioned that their own Staff Training team have existing internal methods and tools. The facility agreed to combine efforts in this area to produce a training reporting tool that meets the Department’s requirements. The facility and CCL staff have agreed to work collaboratively on a training reporting tool. The primary focus of this NCC item is to ensure staff and client training(s) are conducted and reported, clearly. After discussing the NCC submission review, on 02/02/2021 CCL informed the facility that the facility had not yet fulfilled all NCC requirements. Therefore, the facility is to remain on Please refer to LIC 909-C.

the NCC status. The facility is to submit two more quarterly submissions, Due 04/01/2021 and 07/01/2021. After each submission, CCL will promptly complete a review of the submissions and schedule a meeting with the facility to review findings. The facility will continue to submit all NCC items along with the new training reporting tool. They are also requested to submit with their quarterly submission an updated LIC 500 (Staff schedule). LPA Mendoza will use this to cross-reference staff names with the staff training submission to ensure all staff has completed the required quarterly training. LPA Mendoza reminded the facility for the 04/01/20 submission to include the overnight bed logs for November 2020 and December 2020. The facility agreed to submit the following on 04/01/2021 and 07/01/2021: 1. Up night bed check logs for that quarter 2. Training Reporting Tool (or variation) including the following: Client Grooming training during intake, Staff training – Personal Rights, Grooming, Client / Staff Boundaries, Upper Manager up night bed check log oversight 2x per month 3. Training material 4. LIC 500 for that quarter ** Up night bed check logs for November 2020 and December 2020 to be submitted on 04/01/2021 as well. Following the future quarterly submissions on 04/01/2021 and 07/01/2021 – CCL and facility staff will conduct a meeting to review findings and discuss facility standing. Based on quarterly submissions and overall facility performance with respect to compliance and health safety, CCL will re-evaluate NCC status. Please continue to LIC 809-C...

Lastly, the facility informed CCL that due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the facility HR team have been working remotely, and the facility is looking to create all staff personnel folders and training electronically. Michael, the new HR Director, is currently working on this and wanted to ensure that it would follow all CCL standards. CCL informed the facility that the department does not have an issue with them migrating their personnel files to be stored electronically. CCL stressed the importance of ensuring that all staff files and training must be readily available during all inspections. All staff must have the required LIC forms per annual reviews, initial training, ongoing training, etc. The facility can either do them electronically or keep a file at the facility. Also, the facility must ensure that it follows all policies and requirements per Title 22 Regulations. CEO informed CCL that the HR director or HR personnel would only have access to staff records/training. CCL advised the facility that a staff that is physically in the facility must have access. CCL inspections are unannounced, so the facility needs to ensure that the files are readily available within 20-30 minutes of LPA’s arrival and request. The facility agreed to these conditions. CCL understands the limitations imposed by the COVID-19 pandemic and is committed to being flexible and working collaboratively with the facility. This report was sent via email to Chief Executive Officer Lynn Dolce, Chief Program Officer Justine Underhill, Human Resources Director Michael Russel, and Administrator Augie Arballo for signature. The facility agrees to sign and scan back to LPA Mendoza no later than 02/04/2021. This report was revised on 02/04/2021 to correct typos. The facility received a corrected version of this report on 02/04/2021.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
narrative:
On Thursday, February 25, 2021 at 9 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made a case management visit to deliver findings of investigation that was conducted by the Investigation Branch (IB) on 04/22/2020 by Investigator, Victoria McIntosh. LPA met with Administrator Augie Arballo. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was scheduled in advance as a tele-visit. On 04/20/2020 it was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that a former overnight staff member (S1) (please refer to LIC 811 for confidential names, dated 02/16/21) sexually abused (C1) while in care. Based on the severity, it was referred to IB and accepted as a full investigation. Based on the IB report, Case No: CD1420-04069 in which Investigator, interviewed numerous individuals; Edgewood staff(s), former, and former residents, and reviewed documentation. There was no sufficient evidence to confirm if (C1) was sexually abused by (S1) while in care. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the above allegation therefore, the above allegation is Unsubstantiated. After LPA Mendoza thoroughly reviewed the IB report and reviewed all interviews and documentation it was learned that the facility failed to keep C1 safe back in 2018 when C1 was in care. The facility failed to keep all of C1’s records from 2018. It was reported that (C1) reported feeling very uncomfortable and unsafe in the facility because of another client (C2). This client would try to touch (C1) inappropriately when staff members were not around and wrote inappropriate love letters to C1. Due to this, the facility conducted an internal investigation, on 06/08/2018 in which showed that (C2) wrote two love letters C1 and prove the above to be true. The above information, could have helped IB Investigator, McIntosh with their investigation because it was reported to CCL that S1 wrote love letters to C1. However, IB was unable to obtain copies of these love letters. Please refer to LIC 809-C for additional pages.

Because the facility no longer had these letters in C1's file. The facility is cited for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Interim Licensing Standards, Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program: 87070(f) Children’s Records and 87072(10) Personal Rights. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Administrator for signature. Please refer to LIC 809-D. Appeal rights were discussed.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
narrative:
On Wednesday, April 14, 2021, at 2:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made a case management visit to the facility regarding several Special Incident Report (SIRs) that were submitted to Community Care Licensing on April 6, 2021, regarding inappropriate touching between clients. The SIR dated (04/01/21) stated that Client #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811), dated April 14, 2021}) reported to staff that (C1) has been "sexually touched" by another client (C2). The purpose of today's inspection was to gather additional information and interview the Administrator and (C1). Also, collect Need and Service and Behavior Plan for the three involved clients: (C1), (C2), and (C3). Based on documentation/incident reports, two dated 4/1/21 for (C1 and C3), 4/5/21 SIR (C1) and 4/6/21 SIR (C1), and interviews that LPA Mendoza conducted with staff members and clients, it was confirmed that there was inappropriate touching between C1 and C2 and another client (C3) witnessed it. All three clients were watching a movie in a common area, and C2 touched C1's private part over his pants. Also, staff members found a letter that former client (C2) wrote to (C1) about the incident. The facility submitted a copy of this letter to LPA Mendoza on 04/09/21 and submitted an incident report. Based on interviews it was confirmed that inappropriate touching occurred between C1 and C2. A staff member was present but was sitting at a far distance and did not see the incident. Also, interviews confirmed that (C1) and (C2) dated for a short time while at the facility. Both clients would write letters to each other to support one another during their stay at the facility, which would bring comfort to both youth. Also, based on interviews, it was reported when (C2) was first admitted at the facility, (C3) would harass (C2). (C3) would write inappropriate letters to (C2) expressing their feelings. Also, touched (C2) inappropriately when staff was not around. PLEASE REFER TO LIC 809-C FOR CONT. PAGE..

(C2) reported this to staff and asked for support on how to handle this situation and wanting help. Staff immediately implemented a staffing plan around (C2) and (C3), so they would not be left alone. Interviews and documentation confirmed this to be true. (C3) has a history of having poor boundaries and constantly needs to be reminded by the facility staff. Based on the above information and information gathered, LPA is issuing an advisory per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 87065.5 Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. The facility will also be cited under 87072(11) Personal Rights and 87065.2(b)(1) Personnel Duties. Appeal Rights were discussed and a copy of the report was emailed to the Administrator for signature.
