The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating inappropriate interaction with (C1), please refer to LIC 811, dated 4/14/21 for confidential names) and a staff member. LPA Mendoza reviewed documentation, interviewed staff members, and attempted to interview (C1), but the client later canceled the interview. LPA Mendoza also contacted (C1's) legal guardian/authorized rep, and other former clients but did not hear back from these individuals. Due to the nature of the incident occurring 3-4 years ago, LPA Mendoza could not prove or disprove the above allegation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is no preponderance of the evidence to prove inappropriate interaction with client and staff; therefore, the above allegations are

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
narrative:
On Tuesday 6/22/21 at 9AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Isabel Mendoza and Mariah Hawkins met with facility Administrator Augie Arballo for an unannounced annual/required inspection. The STRTP facility consists of four cottages, and only two cottages are being used (Stow and Halleck). This STRTP is licensed for a capacity of 48 and currently has a census of 15 with 7 residents in Halleck and 8 in Stow. At 9:20AM, LPA's Mendoza and Hawkins inspected Stow Cottage. At 10:45AM, LPA's inspected Hallek. LPA's observed the following: Water temperature measured 85 F throughout the cottage. LPA advised the facility to change the temperature. The heater was adjusted, and at 10:38AM the water measured 105 F. At 9:31AM, LPA's observed that the Stow living room / lounge spaces were untidy. There were cards and games pieces spread out on shelves in a disorganized fashion. Halleck was inspected afterwards and was observed to be tidier, but LPA's still observed games pieces on the floor and tossed into drawers without being put away properly, such as back in the puzzle or game box. At 9:54AM, LPA's observed the Stow recreation room to be untidy and unclean. There were toys, game pieces, and other items on the floor and disorganized on the shelves. There was debris on the carpet, which did not appear to have been recently cleaned. Surfaces were unclean. Curtains were missing or in need of repair. At 9:49AM, LPA's observed three rat traps in the downstairs Stow utility room. Administrator stated the site does not have nor recently had a bug or mouse infestation or concern but does have an exterminator come out weekly. Multiple cobwebs and spiders were observed throughout the facility site. At 9:55AM, LPA's observed a trail of ants observed on two walls of the recreation room.

At 9:57AM, LPA's observed the table and couch in the hallway outside the Stow recreation room were dirty. At 9:58AM, LPA's observed behind the hallway table an exposed glue trap with dead bugs and a large dead spider on it. The trap appeared to be old and needed to be replaced. At 10:05AM, LPA's observed rat droppings, an exposed glue trap, and a plate underneath the sofa in the clinician's office in the Stow Cottage basement. At 12:50PM, LPA's inspected the exterminator invoices and observed the following: 6/14/21, 1 mouse removed from admin building, 1 mouse removed from Stow Cottage; 5/24/21, 2 mice removed from Lane Cottage basement and laundry room; 5/10/21, removed 2 mice from admin building, removed 1 mouse from Halleck Cottage kitchen dry food storage; 4/26/21, removed 1 mouse from admin building; 4/12/21, removed 2 mice from Halleck Cottage kitchen area and basement; 1/25/21, removed 1 mouse from admin building; 12/28/20, removed 1 rat from Stow Cottage, removed 2 mice from Williams Building (CSU building), removed 1 mouse from Lane Cottage basement, currently vacant; 11/30/20, removed 1 mouse from Lane Cottage basement; 11/17/20, removed 1 rat from admin building, removed 1 rat from Halleck Cottage; 8/14/20, removed 1 mouse from Stow Cottage under sink, removed 1 mouse from admin building basement, removed 1 mouse from Lane Cottage under stove; 7/21/20, removed 1 rat and 1 mouse. Per the invoice records for June 2020 through June 2021, the exterminator has removed over 20 rodents (mice, rats) from the various cottages and admin building, including from the kitchen, basement, and laundry, as well as rodents from external traps. No report regarding these incidents was made to CCL, and Administrator stated he was not aware of the issue. At 9:33AM, LPA's observed the Stow kitchen to be messy. Cabinets and drawers in each cottage have food crumbs and grime, the refrigerators in each cottage were dirty, pantry shelves in Halleck Cottage were dirty and had dripping containers. The kitchen and dining areas need to be cleaned and sanitized. LPA's observed a nonfunctional dishwasher in the Stow kitchen, a nonfunctional oven (glass door broken this morning) in the Halleck kitchen, and a nonfunctional refrigerator in the Halleck dining room. Staff stated the oven would be replaced and the refrigerator will be checked for functionality by the licensee's facilities department. Additionally, no menu was posted in the Stow kitchen, but staff moved the menu from upstairs to the kitchen.

LPA's observed multiple spills of food or paint on walls throughout the site, including coffee spill on fan in upstairs Halleck, brown splatter in bedroom in Halleck, and unknown splatters near trash cans in Stow basement hallway. LPA's also observed small graffiti, such as a small drawing of male genitalia in the Halleck lounge; old ink marks, such as the billiards game list of client names from 4/06/06 on a cabinet door in the Stow recreation room; paint splatters, such as in the Halleck basement classroom cabinet areas and Halleck client bedroom; and stickers on the high ceilings of the upstairs Stow Cottage near the bedrooms. Staff were not clear as to how youth got the stickers on the ceiling. Administrator reported the facility is cleaned and disinfected at least three times each day at shift changes. Facility Manager S1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) reported that there is a cleaning crew who clean most of the site twice daily but focus more on frequently used spaces rather than pass-through spaces like hallways. At 10:30AM, and throughout the tour, LPA's observed the client bedrooms to be disorganized. Client belongings in the wardrobes and in the under bed storage were messy with items scattered around. Wardrobes were somewhat empty, clothes unfolded and piled inside, and not all clothes appeared to be clean. Staff reported clients are not always comfortable with staff touching their belongings, but clients do not appear to be assisted effectively with organization and related life skills. Administrator stated they will get cloth bins for wardrobe storage. At 10:33AM, LPA's observed more than 5 windows propped open with various items. Multiple bedroom windows were propped open with large books. One window was propped open with a puzzle box, one with a sweatshirt, and another window in one of the upstairs Stow bathrooms was propped open with a wad of paper towels. Some items, such as the books, could be hazardous if they fell from the window sill to the ground below. At 10:22AM, LPA's observed a posting in Stow Cottage of a dress code with policies such as disallowing shoulders from being uncovered. Administrator stated this is in the program plan, and LPA's requested this be checked. At approximately 11:30AM, Administrator reported to LPA's that after checking the program plan, the dress code policy is not included and was not approved by the Licensing agency.

LPA's observed both first aid kits, in Stow and Halleck, to be incomplete with the following items missing or in very low supply: tweezers; alcohol pads; bandages; antiseptic solution. LPA's observed chairs in the upstairs hallways near the bedrooms blocking the passageway. The chairs were for staff providing supervision. LPA's advised that the chairs be moved to avoid obstructing the hallway or that smaller chairs be used, since the hallways are somewhat narrow. LPA's discussed the medication administration procedures with staff. Per staff, medications are transferred from the medication bottle to envelopes and given to evening/night staff to administer to youth who are to take medications at a time after the nursing staff have left for the day. LPA's advised the facility does not transfer medications between containers and instead have staff who have access to the medications administer the medications. Grounds were free of obstruction and hazards. There are no bodies of water on the premises. Administrator reported that there are no firearms or ammunition at the facility site. Medications are stored in medication cabinets in locked staff closets in the upstairs staff offices of each cottage and in the nursing office. Sharps were stored in locked cabinets in the kitchens and were inaccessible to clients. The facility had food to meet the 7-day nonperishable, 2-day perishable mandate. Clients have individual beds. Facility sketches were posted throughout the facility site. Room temperatures were maintained at comfortable temperatures within the permitted range. At visit, Administrator and LPA's discussed the facility policy to have clients be required to wear a mask while at the facility with a 3-step intervention plan for youth who do not wear a mask, which was implemented on 2/02/21. Administrator stated this policy was now under review by their agency in response to the mask mandate being partially lifted in the state. LPA's are issuing 4 citations per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 80087 Buildings and Grounds, 80076 Food Services, 80075 Health Related Services, and 80022 Plan of Operation.

An annual continuation will be conducted to complete this annual inspection. LPA's received 15 staff files and 10 client files, which will be reviewed. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Augie Arballo, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
narrative:
On Wednesday 6/30/21 at 9 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Isabel Mendoza met with facility Administrator Augie Arballo for an unannounced annual/required continuation inspection. On 6/22/21 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza received 10 client files, and 15 staff files. All client files were complete. After LPA completed all staff files, it was confirmed that LPA only received 11 staff files and not 15 staff files. During inspection, LPA requested and reviewed the following due to the below items missing in staff files. LPA Mendoza found the following on client staff files: Staff (S1), (please refer to LIC 811, dated 6/30/21 for confidential names) First Aid and CPR expired on 2/28/21. Also, (S2) and (S3) did not have First Aid/CPR on file. During inspection, LPA requested to see updated CPR/First Aid for all three staff members. All three staff have current First Aid/CPR. The facility developed an in house Certificate of Completion for staff members that attended in house training. LPA Mendoza advised the facility to include the hours of training so LPA or other agencies can confirm hours that were complete. During todays inspection LPA Mendoza reviewed three staff files. All three files were complete. LPA Mendoza inspected medication and interviewed Director of Nursing (S4). All medications were properly stored and locked. At 10:15 AM LPA Mendoza conducted a walk thru in both cottages to confirm that all plan of corrections were corrected. During the walk thru at Stow cottage LPA observed a cleaning crew and painters working inside the stow basement. PLEASE REFER TO LIC-809-C.

At 10:30 AM LPA observed Hallecks pantry/kitchen closets not being fully clean or wiped down. This was corrected during todays inspection. Due to cleanliness still being an issue LPA requested the facility to develop a daily cleaning checklist for staff. Per, POC the facility created a weekly cleaning checklist and now agreed to a daily cleaning checklist. During inspection, LPA obtained copy of two new daily cleaning checklist: 1) Deep rec cleaning log 2) Daily Cleaning Log Checklist. During bedroom walk thru LPA noticed that all closets did not have storage bins. Also, clients did not have enough bins to properly store all their items, so LPA requested the facility to purchase more storage bins. The Administrator agreed and during inspection Administrator showed proof of purchase. They will be arriving on Friday 7/2/21. LPA interviewed 7 clients (please refer to LIC 811, for confidential names, dated 6/30/21) and during interviews it was consistent that clients would like a change to the food menu. Clients expressed an interest on developing their own food menu, incorporating a fun cook day or cooking their own meals. Also, expressed interest on specific kinds of food that they would like to have in the facility. LPA Mendoza communicated all ideas and concerns to Milieu Manager and Administrator. The facility will schedule a house meeting with all clients to further discuss food menu and food ideas. At visit Administrator confirmed that the Three step mask intervention plan has been removed. There are no citations.Two advisories are being issued, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 87070 Children's Records and Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87076 Food Service. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
met_with: CEO Lynn Dolce, Administrator Augie Arballo, and SF Regional Director, Christina Garcia.
narrative: On Wednesday, September 15, 2021, at 01:15 PM, Regional Manager (RM) Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Zaid Hakim and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza conducted a Case Management Legal/Non-compliance meeting virtually via Microsoft Teams due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Community Care Licensing (CCL) met with CEO Lynn Dolce, Administrator Augie Arballo, and additional staff members. The purpose of today's meeting was to go over the facility's terms with their NCC plan. On 10/07/2019, a Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) was held with facility representatives. Per their condition, the facility was to submit quarterly submissions to CCL. The most recent quarterly submission of 07/01/21 was comprehensive and complete. Therefore, the facility will be removed from NCC status, and as of today 09/15/21 the facility is in good standing. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was emailed to Administrator Augie Arballo for signature. Augie agreed to sign and would email it back to LPA Mendoza.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
narrative:
On Wednesday, July 21, 2021, at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza and Christopher Rollins conducted a Case Management legal/non-compliance inspection. LPA's met with Administrator Augie Arballo, and SF Regional Director, Christina Garcia . The purpose of the inspection was to provide the facility feedback on the 7/1/21 NCC submission. The 7/1/21 quarterly submission covers April 2021-June 2021 items. Please note, the April quarterly submission, which covers Jan - March 2021, was provided to the facility via email on 7/13/21. Per the NCC requirements, the facility submitted the below items via thumb drive to LPA Mendoza. 1. All staff is required to take the following training topics quarterly. Also, to provide a list of staff and training on the Excel template that CCL created. · Personal Rights Training · Child Abuse/" What Grooming Looks Likes" · Boundaries 2. At intake, all youth trained on "What grooming looks like" 3. Twice a month, Upper Management conducts unannounced up-night visits. 4. Up night Bed Check Logs- for the following three months (April, May, and June) 5. November and December 2020 Up night bed check logs. CCL requested the facility to submit this on 4/1/21 submission during the 2/3/21 inspection. However, the facility did not, so LPA Mendoza asked the facility to submit it with the 7/1/21 submission. [CONT. to LIC 809-C]

6. LIC 500/Staff schedule. The facility did not include the LIC 500 on the original submission, so LPA requested it on 7/8/21. Later that day, LPA obtained a copy of LIC 500. After conducting a comprehensive review on 7/1/21 submission, LPA observed the following items: LPA Mendoza found no issues with client training on grooming. This training is performed with new clients at intake. All staff required training has been complete. Twice a month, upper management random up night visits were completed in April, May, and June. During LPA’s review of Excel training spreadsheet, it was learned that the facility includes all employees on the excel sheet. This information was communicated to LPA Mendoza via telephone. However, LIC 500 only listed all staff that provide care and supervision. The facility had a meeting with LPM Juanita Arroyo on 7/20/21 regarding the training excel sheet. The facility will update excel sheet and highlight all staff members who require all three training's. Due to the high volume of entries, LPA made a random selection and reviewed Halleck cottage overnight bed logs for the month of April and May. In April, there were 12 entries where staff performed single bed checks for long periods or several 15 min entries. In May, there was a total of 6-bed logs where staff performed two-person bed checks; all other entries were single bed checks. Based on internal "justification forms," single bed checks were performed by one staff because of either; low staffing, insufficient staffing, or [CONT. to LIC 809-C]

, or not enough staff coverage during breaks. LPA Mendoza obtained copies of the April and May justification forms. For the month of June, none were submitted. During LPA's review of May bed logs, the facility updated their overnight bed logs on 5/27/21. The overnight bed logs now request staff members to mark either "yes" or "no" if they performed single bed checks. This information was not communicated to LPA Mendoza per NCC condition. The facility will submit an updated Up night Policy reflecting change to the overnight bed logs. Also, LPA noticed that the overnight shift changed from 10:15 PM-6:45 AM to 10 PM to 8 AM. For the month of June, LPA reviewed Stow cottage logs and found a total of 13 entries where staff performed single bed checks. November and December 2020 bed logs: LPA reviewed November (Stow) cottage, and upon review, the facility only submitted 11/1/2020-11/5/2020 overnight bed logs. Administrator confirmed after 11/5/20 the facility did not have any clients in care, due to COVID-19 outbreak. LPA Mendoza reviewed Halleck's November bed logs, and 11/22/20-11/24/20 were missing. Also, there were four entries where staff performed single bed checks, or staff only did one-hour bed checks. LPA reviewed Stow December bed logs from 12/1/2020-12/10/2020, and bed checks were performed by two staff members every 15 minutes. Halleck bed logs from 12/1/20-12/14/20 were reviewed, and LPA observed five entries where staff did single bed checks. During the inspection, LPA Mendoza provided the facility with a copy of LPA's overnight bed log review for all five months, including all specific dates and times of single bed checks. CCL notified the facility that the facilities NCC status is still under review by CCL. Currently, the facility needs to submit the following items for 4/1/21 submission, which was provided via email. LIC 500 for the April NCC submission, justification forms for Stow cottage from Jan-March, and a written plan on what the Administrator and upper management team plan to do to ensure that the overnight has adequate coverage and following all NCC requirements. LPA Mendoza received a thumb drive for most recent bed logs for July, and reviewed several Halleck and found several single bed checks. Justification forms were not included, so LPA Mendoza gave it back to Administrator to include justification forms and submit to LPA. [ PLEASE REFER TO LIC 809-C]

During todays inspection, Augie and Christina stated that the facilities initial overnight bed check policy stated if a single bed check was performed that the facility would do a justification form. The justification form would cover all single bed checks. During inspection, LPA reviewed all NCC/meeting reports and 812's and could not find anything on this matter. LPA will send policy to LPM for review for future clarification. An exit interview was conducted, and the facility was cited under California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 87065.5 Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. A copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
narrative: On December 23, 2021 at 12:40 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made a case management visit to deliver findings of an investigation that was conducted by the Investigation Branch (IB) on 01/07/2021 by Investigator, Dinah Watkins. LPA met with Milieu Manager Rachel Avila. On 01/07/2021 Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an unusual incident report regarding lack of supervision. It was reported that former client (C1) was forced by another client (C2) to commit a sexual act. (Please refer to LIC 811 for confidential names, dated 12/23/21). Based on the severity, it was referred to IB and accepted as a full investigation. Based on the IB report, Case No: CD1421-01003 and during the course of the investigation, there was insufficient evidence to substantiate that a sexual act occurred between two clients due to a lack of supervision. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a sex act occurred between two clients while in care; therefore, the above allegations is Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies cited. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
narrative: As a result, the facility had to pull staff from other cottages to assist (C1), and being out of ratio. On allegation the facility failed to follow the up-night staff ratio during night hours. Interviews were consistent that the facility did not follow their up-night staff ratio, and their two person bed check because of staff shortages. As a result, staff had to perform single bed checks. Interviews also revealed that staff requested assistance from the upper management team, and based on the information LPA obtained it appeared to be a lack of communication between line staff and upper management team around coverage plan. LPA reviewed overnight bed logs for Halleck for April and May and Stow cottage for June. LPA found the following: In April, there were 12 entries where staff performed single bed checks. In May, there was a total of 6-bed logs where staff performed two-person bed checks, and all other entries were single bed checks. Based on "justification forms," single bed checks were performed because "low staffing, insufficient staffing, or not enough staff coverage during breaks." In June, there were 13 entries where staff performed single bed checks. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility did not have enough staff to meet the needs of the children. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility, and deficiencies were cited.
investigation_findings: 13On Thursday, 12/23/21, at 12:55 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza delivered investigation findings for the above allegations. LPA met with Milieu Manager Rachel Avila and was informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA interviewed staff, clients, witnesses, reviewed files and staff overnight logs. Based on confidential interviews and record review, minor C1 (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated {December 23, 2021}) had a history of property damage and being aggressive towards staff members. This resulted in 9 staff members being injured by (C1) within five months, from January to May of 2021, and unable to work. In May, four staff members were out at one time. The facility was short staffed, and interviews revealed that (C1) required more support and supervision during escalation. [ PLEASE REFER TO LIC 9099-C..]

deficiencies.description:
87065 Personnel Requirements.
(g) The licensee shall...comply with the staff to child ratios... specified in 87065.5, meet the needs of children... 87065.2, and provide adequate care and supervision to children.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and records the facility was not able to meet the needs of (C1). This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
(C1) is no longer in the care of the facility. 
The facility agrees to submit a written plan on steps that the facility will take if they have another staff shortage. The facility will submit a plan to LPA Mendoza by 1/14/21.

deficiencies.description:
Plan of Operation (f) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the plan of operation and may be cited for not doing so.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, and documentation the licensee is operating outside of its Plan of Operation/Program Statement. Facility not performing two-person bed checks. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: On 09/15/21 the facility was removed from Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) status. The facility will submit something in writing to LPA Mendoza by 01/20/22 if the facility will continue two person bed checks, and justification forms. If not, the facility will submit an addendum to their PO/PS.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
narrative:
Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA’s observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report provided to Facility Manager Chloe Lischinsky, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Still, due to not meeting the required hours, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065.1 Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report provided to Facility Manager Chloe Lischinsky, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 1/20/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver findings for an investigation of the above allegation. LPA met with Facility Manager Chloe Lischinsky and informed of the purpose of the visit. The complaint came in when the facility was still licensed as a short-term residential therapeutic program (STRTP), and the facility has recently transitioned into a group home (GH). Based on the received report, the allegation pertains to a concern that the overnight staff are not properly trained. Based on confidential interviews with residents and staff, observation, and record review, the facility was not meeting the 40hrs of training per year requirement for all staff. Of 24 staff training records reviewed for 2019 through 2022, 5 staff, including 1 overnight staff, had less than 40 hours of training in a 12 month period. However, the majority of staff met the hours, and many far exceeded the hours required. Further, interviews with residents and staff indicate that staff perceive themselves and colleagues and are perceived by residents to be competent to complete their job.

deficiencies.description:
87065.1 Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements
(e)(1) Notwithstanding California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 80065(f)(1) through (6), all direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 40 hours of annual training, except as specified in (2) below.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, licensee did not ensure all staff had required training due to 5 staff having less than 40 hours of training in a 12 month period, which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The facility is no longer a STRTP, and the GH annual training requirement is 20 hours.  However, the overnight staff with insufficient hours reflects less than 20 hours.
Licensee agrees to submit to LPA the weekly overnight training each Friday for four weeks.  The dates will be 1/27/23, 2/3/23, 2/10/23, and 2/17/23.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD - THE SAN FRANCISCO PROTESTANT ORPHANAGE
investigation_findings: 13On 2/2/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit at the facility to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Administrator Alyssa Kiandehkian and informed of the purpose of the visit. The investigation was conducted fully or in part by the licensing agency's investigations branch (IB). Based on confidential interviews and record review, there was not enough information that could be obtained to prove or disprove the allegation. The involved parties could not be identified, and residents and staff residing/working at the facility during the alleged time of occurrence were not aware of the incident/allegation, could not provide information regarding the incident, and/or did not have concerns that a lack of supervision resulting in minors left unattended would have occurred. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA’s observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Alyssa Kiandehkian, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: Although, the allegation as written is true as written there isn't a preponderance of evidence, or documentation to prove the relationship occurred while the foster child was placed at Eggleston. Or that the group home staff was aware that foster child who was placed with the group home for 30 days was dating anyone. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this allegation. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via email.
investigation_findings: 13On 4/23/21, at 9:15 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Gilmer conducted a follow-up tele-inspection to deliver the findings of the above complaint allegation. LPA Gilmer spoke with group home Administrator, Jaime Caballero to discuss and answer any questions he might have regarding this complaint and finding. During this investigation process LPA Gilmer interviewed the group home Administrator, and a County Social Worker on 04/16/21, the non-minor dependent and her County Social Worker were interviewed on 04/19/21. The alleged victim was unavailable to be interviewed. The non-minor dependent stated she had a non-sexual relationship with a minor when he was 13 or 14 and she was 17 that continued until January 2021, when she was 19 and he was 16. Giving the timeline from the foster child's girlfriend (the non-minor dependent) the foster child wasn't placed at this group home when their relationship started, and she never visited him at the group home.

narrative: On December 2, 2021 Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility at 10:10 AM. LPA met with Jaime Caballero, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection of the facility. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory males ages 13-17 and also to provide services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1 (C)(1). There are five (5) ambulatory clients currently in placement. This facility is a two story- level house located in a residential neighborhood. This house has 6 bedrooms and 4 bathrooms. There is also a living room, entertainment room, 2 kitchens’, and a dining room. There are no bodies of water on the premises. During the inspection, LPA conducted a physical tour (inside and out) and reviewed operational requirements: (physical plant; operations; disaster preparedness; emergency intervention plan, staff files, client files, and core-therapeutic services. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: The Emergency Disaster Plan, facility sketch, Personnel Schedule, Clients' Personal Rights, Client’s Bill of Rights, and Foster Care Ombudsman, Grievance Procedures, planned activities, facility license, accreditation certificate, visitation policies, current menu and Sexual and Reproductive Health Rights were posted. The kitchen area was observed to be clean and sanitary. There was one-week supply of non-perishable & two days of perishable foods, including nutritious snacks. The carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in good working condition. The facility is equipped with a fire alarm system which is tested monthly by the Administrator and staff. LPA reviewed three staff and two client files. One client and one staff were interviewed. A review of Licensing Information System on December 2, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the FFA have DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index clearances. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative along with LIC 809 and LIC 811s (Confidential Names list).

On 2023, December 14, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo, conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the facility and met with Jaime Caballero, Administrator. LPA stated the purpose of the inspection to the STRTP representative. LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: · LIC 500 Personnel and client roster Biannual Reports for the use of Emergency Interventions MHPA Certificate COA Certificate LIC 610C Activity Calendar Food Menu Fire Drills Annual compliance Review consisted of the following (7) domains: physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness plan, emergency intervention, staffing, core-therapeutic services and client files. Only (4) domains were reviewed during today's visit: physical plant, operations, core-therapeutic services and disaster preparedness plan. A signed copy of this report, LIC 811 Confidential Names list dated 12/11/23, and 2 Technical advisory was provided to the Administrator for review. No further inspection required

Continue from page 1 . . . On 03/08/2024, the Department received a complaint alleging that a staff hit youth. The focused staff (S1) who was identified in the report denied the allegation and stated that the youth became aggressive toward her when the youth was told to hurry up because the facility van was waiting for the youth to be taken to a home pass. S1 stated that the youth spat on her several times and told her that he was going to shoot her and her grand kids. S1 stated that the she confronted the youth about his statement and the youth spat on her and was physically close to her. S1 stated that she put her hand out to make space between herself and the youth. S1 stated that she did not slapped or punch the youth. The focus youth (C1) stated that he went up to his room to pack his stuff because the facility van was going to take the kids on their home passes. C1 stated that S1 kept rushing him and told him to hurry up about five times. C1 stated that he went downstairs with his play station (PS5) and told S1 that he hoped she and her grand son died. C1 stated that S1 pushed him and told him that he did not want any problems but he spat at S1 and S1 slapped him on the left side of his face. C1 stated that he spat on S1 again and S1 slapped him again. C1 stated that he spat on S1 for a third time and S1 punched him on the face and kicked the PS5. C1 stated that there was another staff that got there just before S1 punched him and the other kids were in the van. A second staff worker who was present and witness the incident stated that S1 punched C1 on the face. Another youth that was in the facility heard the arguing between C1 and S1 and came out the room to see S1 kicking C1's PS5 and another youth stated that C1's face was red and was teary eye when C1 got to the facility's van. Based on the staff statements and confidential interviews the allegation is found to be substantiated. A substantiated finding means that the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation is found to be true. Exit interview completed. The following deficiencies cited and a copy of this report and appeal rights were left with facility representative mention above.
investigation_findings: 13On May 16, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Heriberto Perez conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with Jaime Caballero, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the revised finding for the above complaint allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed one youth in person in the facility and conducted telephone interviews with one staff (S2) and one youth on 03/22/24, LPA interviewed one staff (S1) via telephone on 03/25/24, LPA interviewed Probation Investigator via telephone on 03/28/24, LPA interviewed probation office (PO1) via telephone on 05/07/24, LPA interviewed Probation Supervisor via telephone on 05/08/24, LPA interviewed probation officer (PO2) via telephone and one youth in person on 05/09/24 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated May 16, 2023). LPA also reviewed documents including but not limited to Client's Need and Service Plans, Special Incident Reports (SIR) and other documents. It was alleged Staff hit youth.

deficiencies.description: 87072 (c) (16) PERSONAL RIGHTS: To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature......... This requirement has not been met by evidence of: Based on the information obtained, staff and youth indicating that the staff punch a youth when the staff and youth were having an argument, this violation poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC: The facility will provide the LPA a Plan of Action regarding the staff (S1) and the facility will provide a termination letter once is active. The facility will disassociate the S1 when terminated. The facility will provide training to the facility staff on personal rights, de-escalation techniques and interaction with clients. The facility will provide training sign in sheet and covered material. The facility will provide proof of POC on the due date or before via email to LPA to Heriberto.Perez@dss.ca.gov

narrative: On July 25, 2024 at 01:50 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Heriberto Perez conducted a case management inspection at the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) in order to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). LPA Perez discussed the following with the facility representative named above. On 05/16/24, the Department concluded a complaint investigation on the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) which alleged personal rights violation. A foster minor client was punched by a staff which caused a scratch on the client’s face. The allegation was substantiated, and the STRTP was cited for personal rights under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87072(c)(16) Personal Rights. The Department has concluded an analysis and determined that an Enhanced Civil Penalty is warranted for physical abuse. Under Health and Safety (H&S) code section 1548 (C)(i)(2), for a violation that the Department determines constitutes physical abuse, the civil penalty shall be $2,500. Copies of the following reports were provided to the facility representative: LIC 809, LIC 811 Confidential Names Form and LIC 421D Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse. Appeal Rights forms were given and explained.

On 10/27/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted an SB484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection and met Billy McDaniel, Administrator. The inspection was conducted via tele-inspection using facetime video due to COVID-19 restrictions at 08:10 AM. The facility was inspected inside and out. All staff files and medication documents/procedures were sent to this LPA on dates prior to the inspection. LPA reviewed three staff records on 10/23/2020 and 10/27/20 at 11:00 AM LPA interviewed one staff via telephone on 10/27/20 at 7:30 AM and the second staff at 7:45 AM LPA interviewed the third staff via facetime at 08:10 AM LPA did not interview or conduct file review of the youths in placement due to them being probation placement only. LPA conducted an exit interview with Billy McDaniel, Administrator at 9:00 AM. No deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA provided the summary report to Billy McDaniel upon completion by email with a request for signature and a scan back to this LPA on this date.

On 1/9/2023 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Dawn Mahecha and Ashley Ruacho made an unannounced visit to the Eggleston Ontario STRTP for the purpose of a Case management incident report. LPAs met with Administrator and discussed the following incident. Child being detained for driving a stolen vehicle: Administrator stated the following: Two (2) children involved with this incident were dropped off at school by 8:30 AM on 10/17/2022. Staff went to pick up children from school and children weren't at school. Administrator stated when notifications were being made of children leaving school and being Awoled from facility biological grandmother to one child informed Administrator that child was being held at police department. Administrator went to pick up one child from police department but upon arrival to police department additional child was not at location. Police stated that one child was released on their own recognisance due to age and believed to be only a passenger in vehicle. Child who was in custody was picked up and brought back to facility and other outstanding child was dropped off later that evening by an unknown person. Administrator provided submitted documentation of incident and notifications made to various involved agencies. Based on the information provided facility followed up with children's probation officers and court case dates. At this time child who was arrested Awoled from facility on 12/25/2022 and is now currently under the jurisdiction of probation department. Additional child who was involved with being a potential passenger still resides at location. No further information was provided at this time. Exit interview completed and no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator.

On July 11, 2023, at 01:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced case management inspection at Eggleston Ontario Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program to follow up on a death incident involving Client #1 (C1). LPA Portillo met with Administrator, Billy McDaniel. LPA took a tour of the home. On July 9, 2023, Eggleston Ontario Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) reported to the Department that on the morning of July 9, 2023, C1 went on an approved home pass (July 7th to July 9th) to visit with his mother. On July 8th, the Therapist contacted the mother to check on the C1’s wellbeing and C1 appeared to be doing well. At approximately 9:00 am, on July 9, 2023, staff contacted the mother to arrange pick up for C1, when they were informed that on July 8, 2023, in the night, the youth had snuck out of the house, went to a pizza place with some friends and was shot and killed (date and time is unknown). C1’s mother was not able to provide any additional information besides letting staff know that C1 was killed by a gunshot wound. LPA Portillo interviewed the Administrator and Therapist and obtained documentation for the incident. A copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 11/17/20 at 11:51 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Noubar Yerkatyan conducted a follow-up complaint tele-inspection to the above facility and spoke with above staff. The purpose of the call was to discuss and deliver findings for the above compliant allegation. While investigating the allegation, LPA Joseph Vargas and LPA Yerkatyan conducted interviews with staff, residents, and probation officers (see Confidential Names LIC 811 dated November 17, 2020). Certain files were reviewed such as psychotropic medication administration records, facility personal report, resident case plans, resident identification and emergency information, resident placement agreements, along with previous facility inspection reports. Confidential interviews revealed that only one staff would transport six residents in an eight-passenger van four times a week. Staff stated they were unaware of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) staff/resident ratios. LPA’s received sufficient information indicating the facility was out of ratio during transportation of the residents. Based on confidential interviews, it was determined that facility staff failed to abide by the required STRTP staff/resident ratio. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility failed to meet STRTP Interim Licensing Standards. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were given.

deficiencies.description: Direct care staff/child ratios: In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Interviews revealed that only one staff would transport six residents in an eight-passenger van four times a week, which posed a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: On 11/11/2019 training was provided to staff regarding Administration of Medication and Staff Ratio Procedures. Proof of training was provided to LPA.

narrative: It was alleged that a facility staff engaged in a physical altercation with facility clients, facility staff hit a facility client resulting in injuries, a facility staff choked facility clients during an altercation, and facility staff did not intervene in facility clients being abused. The investigation revealed that two facility clients attacked a staff, Reference #1, at the facility. Reference #1 allegedly retaliated by hitting and choking the facility clients, but interviews with Reference #1 and other staff present during the incident did not corroborate the allegations that the staff hit or choked facility clients. Reference #1 stated that he re-directed the clients when they started to attack him, and when re-direction did not work, he distanced himself from the facility by leaving in his vehicle as the clients followed and attacked him even as he went to his vehicle that was parked right outside of the facility. There were two other staff present during the incident which indicated that the facility had adequate staffing during the incident. Other staff indicated that Reference #1 never hit or choked any of the clients, and staff did not neglect to intervene during the incident as they attempted to re-direct and stand between the clients and Reference #1 during the incident. Another staff indicated that none of the clients sustained any injuries from physical abuse by Reference #1. Confidential statements obtained from a facility client indicated that there were no injuries observed on any of the residents at the facility after the incident, and staff treat clients well and does not neglect intervening when necessary. Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged that facility staff does not treat youth in a respectful manner. Administrator and staff had similar statements denying the allegation. Administrator and staff stated they do not speak to children inappropriately or rudely or overhear other staff treating children unfairly or rudely. Additionally, they stated that all children are treated the same and that they have not received complaints or information from children that suggest staff disrespect anyone in or out of the home. Interviews conducted with children varied in that one (1) child stated that they felt as though staff were disrespectful and that one (1) staff called them and another person an inappropriate name. However, child could not recall the specific date of when incident occurred or in what context and recounted the incident occurring only once. Interviews conducted with two (2) other children stated that all staff are nice and that they do not recall hearing anyone residing in the home or out being called inappropriate names by staff. Documents reviewed identified no incidents being documented of staff treating children disrespectfully. It was also alleged, facility feeds youths burnt food. Staff and Administrator denied the allegation and again had similar statements that various staff and children cook meals in the home. Staff could not recall an incident when staff or a child burned a meal or tried serving a burnt meal for someone to eat. Staff stated they monitor the children while they are cooking and if staff or children ever burned food, they would throw it out and cook something else. Children had similar statements in that they could not recall a specific incident of being served burnt food. Children stated that children and staff cook meals and that there is ample food to cook in the home. Lastly, it was alleged facility has expired food. During initial inspection LPA Mahecha and Administrator toured the home including the food supply. LPA observed perishable and non-perishable foods as well as the emergency food supply. LPA observed dates of when food was bought and dates of expiration. All food observed was properly marked and expiration dates were marked appropriately. Food was not observed to be moldy or have any past expiration dates. Staff had similar statements and stated that food is checked weekly, groceries are bought weekly and if moldy food is observed it is discarded immediately. Interviews conducted with children varied in that two (2) children stated that they had not observed expired or moldy food but one (1) child stated that they observed two-week-old expired food. LPA observed documented observation of alleged expired food, however, date observed was date of food being bought and not of expiration date. Additionally, documents reviewed identified groceries being bought weekly and ample food being bought for all children in care.

LPA was unable to contact county social workers but documents reviewed identified incidents and issues occurring with one child but no documents identified issues with facility or staff within the facility. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: On 12/8/22 the Department received a complaint alleging S1 made a sexual gesture towards C1. S1 denied the allegation stating S1 never made an inappropriate sexual gesture towards C1. S2 indicated C1 disclosed that S1 made the sexual gesture, however S1 denied making a sexual gesture. S2 stated the other clients denied witnessing S1 make a sexual gesture towards C1. C3 and C4 when interviewed denied witnessing S1 make a sexual gesture towards C1. The CSW indicated having no concerns with the facility. PO1 and PO4 indicated having no concerns with the facility. PO1 indicated C1 disclosed that S1 made a sexual gesture towards C1, however C1 was not able to provide details about the alleged incident. IPO indicated S1 and the other clients interviewed denied witnessing S1 make a sexual gesture towards C1. The others agency’s investigative report indicated all clients except C1 denied witnessing S1 make a sexual hand gesture towards C1. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited

On December 6, 2021 at 10:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting an annual random inspection. LPA met with Billy McDaniel. The facility was toured inside and out with the Facility Administrator. There were no clients and staff present at time of inspection. The site is on a temporary, voluntary hold. LPA began facility ground inspection with Administrator at 10:55 AM. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The First Aid Kit contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors in the bedrooms and hallways were checked and were operable. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and emergency disaster plan. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There are no swimming pool/bodies of water located on the premises. Based on the facility inspection there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator. LPA provided a copy of the following report: LIC 809 to Billy McDaniel.

On 02/01/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted a Case Management Inspection for the agency above and spoke with Administrator, Don Gutierrez. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, the case management was conducted by telephone. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on a Special Incident Report received by the Department on January 29, 2021. LPA Portillo interviewed the Administrator and it was discovered that there were two staff monitoring the three clients (FC1, FC2, and FC3) while they were working out (See confidential names, LIC 811 dated 2/9/21). The staff ratio is 1/3 and due to the type of activity that was held outdoors, the ratio was 2/3. One facility manager and a mental health rebab specialist were present when FC1 and FC2 had an altercation over the FC1’s wireless speaker. The two staff members were attempting to deescalate the situation between FC1 and FC2 when FC3 hide behind a sofa that was inside the gym area and removed a wooden leg that was attached to the couch from the bottom of the sofa. The Administrator stated that FC1 and FC3 had a previous argument a week before this incident took place. FC3 walked behind FC1 and hit him on the right side of his head near his temple with the wooden leg and went running to his room. FC1 was transported to the hospital and during an interview with the police officers, he decided to press charges against FC3. The officers viewed the surveillance video and arrested FC3 for Assault with A Deadly Weapon. FC3 was arrested and transported to Baldwin Park Police Dept station and his bed was closed. FC1 and FC2 were checked and cleared of any visible injuries. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility.

On June 21, 2022, at 12:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced case management inspection at Eggleston Youth Center II Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program to follow up on a death incident involving client #1. LPA met with Don Gutierrez, Administrator. On June 21, 2022, reported to the Department that an 18-year-old male probation resident was found deceased in the facility bathroom. Resident died from a fentanyl overdose. The STRTP reported that the Administrator received a call on June 20, 2022, at approximately 10:30 pm, from the resident’s girlfriend stating that she was on the phone with resident when he entered the bathroom to take a shower when suddenly he stopped talking. Administrator advised staff to check on resident’s status. Staff then entered the restroom and saw resident lying on the ground. Staff called out his name, checked him and immediately administered 2 sprays of Narcan and began CPR as another staff called 911. Though facility staff responded immediately, Baldwin Park Police and Fire Department arrived within minutes, and the Fire Department immediately took over CPR and placed an oxygen mask on resident. Baldwin Park Fire Department pronounced resident deceased at the scene and contacted Los Angeles County Coroner’s office who picked up resident from the STRTP. During the inspection, LPA requested the following documents: POLICE REPORT # A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative along with LIC 811 (Confidential names list.)

On 7/27/2022 at 10:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted a case management inspection at the facility and met with the facility representatives named above. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an incident that occurred on 6/20/22 involving C1 (clients). On June 21, 2022, the STRTP reported to the Department that an 18-year-old male probation resident was found deceased in the facility bathroom. Resident died from a fentanyl overdose. On 6/21/22, LPA Portillo conducted an initial case management (CM) for this incident and informed the Administrator that a continuance of the CM was going to take place at a later date. During today's inspection, LPA Portillo interviewed the Administrator and two clients. LPA will interview two staff over the phone on 7.29.22. LPA also reviewed client records and obtained copies of pertinent documents. LPA has scheduled phone interviews with staff members to discuss the incident. There is no further follow up required regarding the incident involving C1. This licensing report was reviewed and discussed with the facility representative and a signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative at the conclusion of the inspection along with Confidential Names list (LIC 811)

On November 16, 2023, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Claudia Portillo, conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the facility and met with Don Gutierrez, Administrator. LPA stated the purpose of the inspection to the STRTP representative. LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: · LIC 500 Personnel and client roster Biannual Reports for the use of Emergency Interventions MHPA Certificate COA Certificate LIC 610C Activity Calendar Food Menu Annual compliance Review consisted of the following (7) domains: physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness plan, emergency intervention, staffing, core-therapeutic services and client files. Only (4) domains were reviewed during today's visit: physical plant, operations, core-therapeutic services and disaster preparedness plan. Pending documentation to fully complete the domain for operations: CQI report, car insurance cards for both vehicle (confirmation of renewal was emailed to Administrator but no proof of cards was attached) and Board of Director Minutes. Further inspection is required on a separate day. The following domains require a continuance of review (staff, client, and emergency intervention). An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report were provided to the facility administrator..

The facility (GH) staff denied the allegation and stated that clients are given wake up calls during during the school week. The staff stated that several wake up calls are given to the client every 15 minutes or so to get ready to go to school. The staff stated that the clients are encourage to go to school and are reminded of their program. Information revealed that a client refused to go to school several times because the weekend home passes were taken away from the Department but the staff still was working with the client and tried to motivate the client to go to school. The confidential interviews indicated that the staff does wake up call to the clients several times and are told that it time to get ready for school. The interviews revealed that the staff tell the clients that not going to school can affect their privileges and community passes. The confidential interviews indicated that the staff encourages the clients to go to school. Information indicated that a client stop going to school because the passes were taken away from the clients and the client was upset. The confidential interviews revealed that the clients did not have any concerns with the GH and felt that the staff does enough to get them to go to school. The County Social Worker stated that she got reports from the GH saying that attempts were done to get the client to go to school but that maybe the client stopped going to school for other reasons. Based on the interviews and records reviewed, the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Copies of LIC9099, LIC9099C, LIC811 and Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.

narrative: On November 11, 2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Claudia Portillo, conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at Eggleston Youth Center V and met with Jaime Caballero, Administrator. LPA stated the purpose of the inspection to the STRTP representative. During the inspection a copy of the Register of Facility Clients and Personnel Report was provided upon request. The following topics were inspected: PHYSICAL PLANT: A tour of the facility was conducted, along with Jaime Caballero. The License, Children’s’ foster youth bill of rights, Office of the Ombudsman, Emergency disaster plan, personal rights and Covid-19 information was placed in a prominent place that was accessible to clients in care. Passageways and ramps are unobstructed. The disinfectants and cleaning solutions were stored away from the kitchen areas, food preparation areas to the children. The Menu identifies the meals for each day of the week and ach meal meets at least 1/3 of the recommended in the USDA Basic Food Group Plan-Daily Food Guide. Supplies of staples non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days are maintained in the facility. However, LPA Portillo observed approximately 6 food cans that were expired and later discarded by staff. Medications are locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. The temperature in the rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F) and the hot water temperature was at 107 degrees (F). OPERATIONAL REQUIREMENTS: During the inspection review, LPA observed the facility maintained an updated roster of the clients with pertinent information. The facility administrator and manager are the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. The facility has developed, maintained, and implemented written complaint procedures. DISASTER PREPAREDNESS PLAN: LPA Portillo reviewed the disaster and mass casualty plan and other provisions by reviewing the program statement. The facility conducts monthly fire and emergency evacuation drills. Drills are documented and kept in the facilty for at least one year. Further inspection is required on a separate day.

On November 18, 2021, at 09:05 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced Annual inspection continuation at Eggleston Youth Center V Short Term Therapeutic Residential Treatment (STRTP) and met with Jaime Caballero. LPA stated the purpose of the inspection to the STRTP representative. During the inspection the following topics were inspected: Emergency Intervention Plan: LPA Portillo reviewed the program statement and PROACT instruction manual and identified that training is provided for all staff. The staff receive on-going training to maintain certification. A monthly log is utilized to document manual restraints to assist with the Bi-Annual Restraint Report. However, the agency has not implemented a competency test for staff and is in the process of developing a test your knowledge form. CORE THERAPEUTIC SERVICES: During the inspection review, LPA reviewed documentation that the facility is providing the Short-Term Therapeutic Program (STRTP) core services and support to the individuals in placement through Eggleston Behavioral Health Services (EBHS) which is a division of Eggleston Youth Center, Inc. The facility has trauma informed, culturally relevant, age, and developmentally appropriate.

cont#2 CLIENT RECORDS: LPA Portillo reviewed the two (2) client file records. Needs and services plans for all two clients were trauma informed, culturally relevant, and age and developmentally appropriate and identified the child’s needs: reason for placement, education, personal care and grooming, ability to manage money, visitation information, mental health services and placement information STAFFING RECORDS: During the inspection review, LPA Portillo inspected two (2) staff files and verified that all facility staff was subject to criminal records review, fingerprinted and cleared DOJ, FBI and CACI. Interviews were conducted with 2 staff and 1 client. LPA issued a Citation and Advisory Note-Technical Violation. The facility representative was provided information on where to locate Provider Information Notices (PINs), and shared PIN 21-20-CRP Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) Tools, for Children’s Residential licensees. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to the facility manager, Jonathan Marquez. Exit interview conducted.

An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo at the above-named facility on 05/8/24 at 11:00 AM. LPA met and toured the facility with George Bojorquez, Administrator. There are 3 clients placed in the facility. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a quick review of the operations of the short term residential therapeutic program (STRTP) that was reopened on 4/15/24. During a home inspection the following were observe: · The license, listing of personal rights and additional resources was posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. · Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, poisons, and other items that could pose a danger if readily available to clients were stored and inaccessible to clients. · There were non-perishable and perishable foods for clients in care (menus were displayed) · No more than two children shared a bedroom. Individual beds were maintained in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillow(s) which were clean and in good repair. · Toiletries, and grooming and personal hygiene products respect the child’s or nonminor dependent’s culture, ethnicity, and gender identity and expression. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. A copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

narrative: On July 13, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst arrived at the Elite Family Systems Inc, Banyon Home facility for an unannounced inspection for the purpose of delivering a case management report. On April 25, 2022, a client was picked up from school by a staff member. During this interaction the client was very agitated and attempted to walk away (AWOL) form the school property furthermore client attempted to strike the staff member multiple times. The incident report states Initially the staff member attempted to redirect the client using humor, change of staff, change of voice and counseling. Ultimately, the staff took the client down to the ground utilizing an improper unauthorized restraint. The client was returned to the facility by the same staff member. No medical attention was required. As soon as staff returned client, staff was sent home. A deficiency is being issued today for inappropriate restraint.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- BANYAN HOME
narrative:
On 11/02/2022, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez and Vanessa Galvan traveled to Elite Family Systems – Banyan Home in Ceres, CA to conduct an announced SB484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection at 10:00 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA’s met with Facility Manager, Melissa Armendariz and CEO, Bill Sneed. At 10:15 AM LPA’s reviewed 2 client's files. At 11:00 AM LPA’s inspected the facility inside and out. LPA observed all medication, knives, and disinfectants locked. All medications were stored in a lock container inside a locked cabinet. All required documentation was posted and accessible for both staff and client’s review. The facility was clean and in good sanitary conditions. Each client was provided a bed, linens, and storage space in their bedrooms. The facilities food supply was inadequate. The facility’s refrigerator, freezer, and water temperature were all at a safe range. The front and back outdoor areas where free from dangers and hazards. At 11:30 AM LPA’s reviewed 2 Client medications and medication records. At 12:30 PM LPA’s interviewed Facility Manager on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. At 1:20 PM LPA’s reviewed 2 Staff files on site at the facility. At 2:00 PM LPA’s interviewed CEO on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. Continued on Page 2...

Continued from Page 1... At 2:30 PM’s LPA interviewed 1 client currently prescribed psychotropic medication. The other client refused to be interviewed. LPA conducted an exit interview with CEO, Bill Sneed at 3:00 PM. Two deficiencies are being cited on this date on the attached LIC 809-D . A copy of this report was left with Bill Sneed at the conclusion of the inspection.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- BANYAN HOME
narrative: On this date, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPAs) Jessica Rodriguez and Vanessa Galvan conducted an unannounced Case Management and spoke with CEO, Bill Sneed. The purpose of Case Management was to discuss food services in the home. LPA’s observed the food supply in the home to be inadequate. LPA’s reviewed the weekly menu and found the facility did not have adequate items needed to make dinner according to the menu for today’s date. While LPA’s were at the facility, food was delivered to the facility. LPA took pictures to document that food was brought in. Based on LPA’s observations, Interim Licensing Standards are being cited on the attached 809D. The plan of correction was discussed with Bill Sneed. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights - 87072(c)(11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, ...This requirement is not met as evidenced by staff making statements to clients in care, stating that they will be be injured if they do not obey and listen to the rules; which poses which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

investigation_findings: On the above date, LPA (Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd conducted a complaint inspection for the purpose of resolving the investigation into the above allegations. An incident with a client resulted with FS12 using restraint techniques that were excessive to the threats posed by the client. The client hit FS12 car with his fist and was making verbal threats of throwing rocks and vandalizing cars with the rocks and was subsequently put in a restraint by FS12 which pinned the clients arm behind his back. FS12 has also been seen by multiple clients and staff occasionally bringing a pocket knife on his person into the facility. Type A: This poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. Based on the LPA’s observations, confidential interviews, and the records review conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. A copy of the report and Appeal Rights was provided to the STRTP.

deficiencies.description: 87095(c)(2)Genreral Provisions-Short-term residential therapeutic program staff may be justified in using restraints as an emergency intervention if all of the following conditions are met: (2)The force used does not exceed that reasonably necessary to avert the injury or danger… This requirement has not been met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, staff restrained minor by bending clients arm behind his back when client hit staff car with his fist and was verbally threatening to throw rocks and use rocks to vandalize a car, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Faciltiy will retrain staff FS12 on proper restraint techniques and when restraints are needed.  Facility will provide CCL with proof of retraining by April 14, 2023

deficiencies.description: 87072(c)(11) Personal Rights-To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from… intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat,… This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, staff occasionally carried a knife in his possession, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will retrain FS12 in personal rights and carring for clients. Proof of retraining will be provided to CCL by April 14, 2023

narrative: On June 21, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd conducted an unannounced Required Inspection at Elite Family Systems Banyan Home. LPA was met by Administrator Tyler Ayala. Centrally stored medications are maintained in a locked box within a locked cabinet. Sharps and toxic chemicals are kept locked. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Closet space for hanging clothes was adequate and drawers were provided There is at least one week supply of nonperishable and a two day supply of perishable foods. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. LPA completed 1 client interview. LPA reviewed 2 client files. No citations were issued on this day. LPA will complete this inspection at a later time. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

deficiencies.description:
87068.2 Needs and Services Plan
(d) The licensee shall ensure and document that the child, and their authorized representative(s)... were offered the opportunity to participate in the development of the needs and services plan. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
Based on record review, licensee did not ensure authorized representatives for Client 1 and Client 2 were offered the opportunity to participate in the development of the needs and services plan, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will provide CCL with updated Needs and Services Plans for Client 1 and Client 2, with signatures from the client and their authorized representative, upon completion.

investigation_findings: 13On January 7, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan conducted a complaint inspection at Elite Family Serives- Blaker Home and spoke with Bill Sneed. The purpose of the inspection was deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. The Department has investigated the complaint alleging a "Staff handled minor in a rough manner." LPA Barragan spoke with staff, clients, reviewed police reports and other predominate documents. All the clients and staff stated that Staff 1 (S1) did not handle at any of the clients in care in a rough manner; however, the Reporting Party's (RP) story did not change. Based on documents reviewed, an inspection, and conversations with staff and clients all the information that was gathered was contradicting. "Although the allegation may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED." An exit interview was conducted with Bill Sneed. A copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to Bill Sneed.
