facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- BLAKER HOME
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura conducted an announced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting a psychotropic medication inspection. LPA Segura met with executive director Bill Smeed and both toured the facility. The STRTP is licensed to serve six clients, ages 7 - 17 years old and non-minor dependents. Currently in placement are five clients. All of whom are taking psychotropic medication and subject to this inspection. At approximately 10:15am LPA Segura began to review three staff files. At approximately 10:30 LPA switched to review client files with the arrival of the administrator Tony Keye. In the course of reviewing client files, LPA Segura observed that none of the client ANSP (Assessment Needs and Services Plans) indicate which mental health services the child should be receiving. LPA Segura observed that C4 had a court authorization document which expired on 08/14, the facility indicates that they have been attempting to obtain the current court authorization from the county social worker. No deficiency issued at this time. Interviews were conducted with Administrator and Facility Manager at 1:45pm. One interview was attempted with C5 (see confidential Names list, LIC 811 dated 08/31/2021); however, the child ended interview. Continued on 809c

Interviews were conducted with C1 and C2 at approximately 3:00 A review of Guardian on August 31, 2021 indicates that the three staff who's files were reviewed on todays inspection were associated to the facility and had criminal record clearances. Per Title 22 Regulations, deficiencies were cited during this inspection. A follow up inspection is required at a future date. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of the report was left at the facility with Tony Keye.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- BLAKER HOME
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura conducted an announced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting a psychotropic medication inspection. LPA continued this inspection from 08/31/2021. LPA Segura met with staff Mimi Kaur to begin the inspection and was met shortly after by the administrator Tony Keye. The STRTP is licensed to serve six clients, ages 7 - 17 years old and non-minor dependents. Currently in placement are five clients. All of whom are taking psychotropic medication and subject to this inspection. On Todays inspection LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) conducted an interview with C3 (Child 3 See confidential Names list, LIC 811 dated 08/31/21). During todays inspection LPA toured the home inside and out with the administrator at around 9:45am. At approximately 10:30am LPA Segura and administrator Tony Keye began the medication count for the clients in placement. In the course of conducting medication counts LPA Segura found that counts for Clients 1, 2, 3 and 5 were found to be in compliance. However, count for C4 was found to have an extra 30 pills that were not accounted for in the centrally stored log or the PMAR. Continued on 809c

In the course of medication counts LPA and administrator also found that C5 is being administered M3 (Medication 3, see confidential names list LIC 811 dated 9/2/2002). The facility does not have documented court authorization for this medication or emergency authorization. This medication was not found during the initial inspection on 08/31/2021. The administrator stated the child was prescribed the medication on an emergency basis due to behavioral issues. See Technical Violation Advisory note LIC 9102. Per Title 22 Regulations, deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of the report was left at the facility with Tony Keye.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- BLAKER HOME
investigation_findings: 13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted a complaint inspection at Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) Elite Family Services Blaker Home for the purpose of delivering the findings of the above complaint allegations. LPA Bruce met with Heather Tearney, Case Manager. During the investigation, LPAs Daiquiri Boyd and Rachel Bruce inspected the facility, reviewed staff and client files, and conducted confidential interviews which revealed that staff used inappropriate language with the clients in care and additionally, knowingly caused emotional and mental distress and/or abuse to clients. Based on LPA's observations, confidential interviews and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations 87072(c)(11) Personal Rights is cited on the attached LIC 9099D. LPA provided a copy of this report to the STRTP. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the Appeal Rights were provided to the STRTP.

deficiencies.description: To be free of… emotional, or other abuse, and from… humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature… This requirement is not met as evidenced by: based on confidential interviews, staff used inappropriate language directly with a client that was sexual in nature. Additionally, staff took personal belongings of a client without cause, knowing the client had an emotional attachment to the items taken, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will conduct refresher training to all staff regarding trauma informed care and personal rights.  Training to be conducted and documentation provided to CCL by due date of October 19, 2023. Any staff unable to attend scheduled training will complete training by October 31, 2023.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- BLAKER HOME
narrative: On October 25, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd visited the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Elite Blaker Home for the purpose of a Case Management visit after a review of Incident Reports. Upon arriving at the home, LPA Boyd was greeted by Facility Manager Roy Wiley. LPA was told Administrator Tony Keyes was in a meeting and would arrive later, possibly after lunch. LPA Boyd found the following Incident Reports to be incomplete and not contain the required information: 6/5/23 for C1, the report is incomplete, more details are needed 6/10/23 for C2, the report is incomplete, more details are needed 6/11/23 for C3, the report is incomplete, more details are needed 6/12/23 for C3, the report is incomplete, more details are needed 7/4/23 for C4, the report is incomplete, more details are needed 8/27/23 for C5, the report is incomplete, more details are needed 8/28/23 for C5, the report is incomplete, more details are needed 9/23/23 for C6, the report needs more details, this was Law Enforcement and not on LIC 624LE or a report with the required information. On Incident Report dated 6/10/23, client C2 was told that his boundaries will be reinforced through education of the point and zone system. On Incident Report dated 6/8/23, client C2 was told he will lose points for making inappropriate statements and not following staff directions. LPA Boyd discussed incident reports with Administrator. Deficiencies were cited on this date for Reporting Requirements and Personal Rights. A copy of this report was left with the facility.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights: To be free of… emotional, or other abuse, and from… humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature… This requirement is not met as evidenced by:  client was threatened for not "following directive and staff stated to client that he will lose points for making inappropriate statements and not followingstaff directions." Staff stated he can choose to not follow staff directions or choose to keep his points, which poses an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to the residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Administrator advised Licensing that he will develope a training plan to train staff on proper techniques when a client needs intervention.
Administrator to provide documentation to Licensing by 10/26/23.

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements: Incident reports must include the following:...detailed narrative, analysis, plan, action taken....This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Incident reports submitted to Licensing from June to present 2023, were found to be missing details of the incident, including but not li limited to ; de-escalation techniques used, staff involved, time incident began and ended, what the child was doing before, what did staff do to reintegrate client back into program after incident, detailed description of restraints and who did the restraint and who observed, which poses a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to the residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator advised Licensing that he will resubmit Incident Reports that were listed on the front page of 809 for correction by November 1, 2023.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- BLAKER HOME
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd made an unannounced visit to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA requested to see the Manual Restraint Log for the facility and found that there were no restraints documented on this log. Upon reviewing submitted Incident Reports, it was found that there were restraints on clients on February 5, 2024 (C3), December 4, 2023 (C1), August 28, 2023 (C3), August 27, 2023 (C3), and July 4, 2023 (C2). STRTP was cited Type B deficiency on this date CCR 87095.61(g) for incomplete Manual Restraint log.

deficiencies.description: Documentation and Reporting Requirements: The licensee must maintain a monthly log of each use of manual restraints. The log must include: 1. name of each child. 2. date and time of the intervention. 3. duration of the intervention. 4. name of facility staff members who participated in the manual restraint. 5. description of the intervention and type used. 6. result of licensee review. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: No restraints were documented on the log when LPA asked to see it. Upon review of submitted incident reports, manual restraints were used 12/4/23, 8/27/23, 8/28/23; which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will review incident reports submitted and complete the log for all restraints done within the last six months.  Updated restraint log is to be submitted to Licensing by February 19, 2024.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- BLAKER HOME
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd visited Elite Family Systems main office on February 23, 2024. During my visit, LPA Boyd reviewed staff files for Blaker Home. Staff files contained loose documents in folders and were in no order. LPA requested that all staff files be placed in binders and tabbed as to the contents of each section. LPA Boyd obtained the LIC500 for Blaker Home. Ten staff files were reviewed, which included a recently terminated staff. Seven of ten staff were found to have expired CPI training. Proof of certification of the CPI trainer is found to be expired. Deficiency cited on this date, ILS Emergency Intervention Staff Training 87095.65(c) and ILS 87095.65(e). See LIC859 for list of staff files reviewed. Appeal rights were given to Licensee, along with a copy of this report and the LIC859. John Sarhadi, CFO, signed for these documents today.

deficiencies.description: Emergency Intervention Staff Training-  Staff must receive on-going training to maintain certification.  This requirement is not met as evidenced by seven of the ten files reviewed, did not prove training for emergency interventions was current, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: CPI training to be completed by February 24, 2024.  Licensee to provide proof to CCL by email.

deficiencies.description: Emergency Intervention Staff Training- The training must be provided by an individual who holds a valid instructor certificate from a program of managing assaultive behavior that is consistent with Article 10 of these regulations. This requirement is not met as evidenced by no valid trainers card or letter of verification for trainers certificate was found in the staff file for the stated Emergency Intervention Trainer, which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee to provide proof of active certification of trainer or that you find an alternative certified trainer. Provide proof to CCL by email by March 1, 2024.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- BLAKER HOME
narrative: On May 29, 2024 Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd and Charles Kinney, made an unannounced visit to the main office of Elite Family Systems Blaker Home Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Licensee Bill Sneed Jr. and Administrator Tyler Ayala. On complaint control number 24-CR-20240207160938, an allegation of a personal rights violation was SUBSTANTIATED by Licensing. The facility was cited for ILS 87072(c)(1) on April 10, 2024. Due to client suffering serious bodily injury, an enhanced civil penalty is being assessed. The complaint alleged that the facility staff S4 did not use an appropriate restraint on client, causing injury of a broken wrist to client C1. See confidential names list LIC811 Based on the findings from the medical reports and Investigation Branch, the Department has determined that an enhanced civil penalty is warranted for the facility. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, H&S Code section 1548 (f)(1)(C)(i), the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2,500.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, Appeal Rights and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) were provided to the Administrator and Licensee. The signed copy will be retained in the facility file.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco conducted an unannounced tele-visit inspection with Elite in order to deliver the findings of the above allegations and spoke with Bill Sneed. On June 15, 2020 the above allegation was referred to Community Care Licensing for investigation. The investigation included an inspection of the youths records, calls to the police department, calls to the hospital, interviews with facility staff and administrator, interviews of the reporting party and the youth. The complaint alleged that the facility staff left the minor at the hospital without supervision which resulted in minor not receiving care in a timely manner. The interviews conducted provided conflicting information regarding this issue. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to provide the allegation occurred. Therefore, the allegation that the Staff left minor without supervision resulting in delayed medical evaluation is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Bill Sneed and Juanita Sneed via email along with appeal rights. facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME
narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Slusher conducted a tele-visit as a result of Covid-19 related restrictions, and in accordance with Regional Office Memo (ROM 20-11-CCLD). The purpose of this inspection is to follow up on concerns noted during a recent complaint investigation. Client #1 ( See LIC 811 dated 1/28/2021) had medical issues and concerns. The placement agency requested weekly weight checks as well as food logs. The facility failed to provide this documentation to the placement agency for more than 4 months. Additionally, the youth missed two CFT meetings due to a lack of appropriate communication. LPA reviewed the Needs and Services plans for the youth, which appear to have been written within appropriate time frames, but lacked information about the youth's nutrition supplement and were not approved by the authorized representative. On this date, the facility is issued deficiencies for the following violations of CCR title 22, Division 6 section 80065(a) Personnel Requirements and STRT P ILS Section 87068.2(d)(e) Needs and Services Plan.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME
investigation_findings: 13On 01/28/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Slusher conducted an unannounced complaint inspection for the Saratoga House STRTP and med with Executive Director Bill Sneed. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via telephone with a scan of this document and a request for signature and scan back to this LPA. Interviews were conducted with clients and staff and documents were obtained. Based on the interviews and documents obtained, there is differing opinions on how medical needs were to be followed up on. It is clear that there was a lack of documentation and communication with the placing agency, but not clear that the facility failed to get necessary medical care for youth. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was scanned to the Assistant Program Director on this date. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME
narrative: On May 18, 2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco conducted a Tele-Visit Case Management inspection with the Elite Family Systems and met with Bill Sneed. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss information discovered during the investigation of a complaint. During the investigation it was discovered that in January 2021 the agency was experiencing a shortage of staff, at the Scoffield House, the staff ratio was 2 staff to 6 children. On 1/26/21 a child in the home was restrained by a staff and an untrained staff observed the restraint which resulted in injury. When LPA asked staff if it was a choice to reach out to another house for help it was stated that it was not an option due to being short staffed. Per Bill this information is not true, and it was a possibility to reach out to other staff for support. While LPA reviewed the incident reports for 1/26/21 LPA observed that there was missing pertinent information in the report. LPA addressed these concerns with Bill Sneed. Bill and LPA Tinoco discussed the information that needs to be included in incident reports, Bill stated he will be making those corrections by retraining staff. The Department determined this to be an immediate risk to health and safety of the children in care at this time, therefore the Facility was cited for The Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) Chapter 7.5 Version 3.1 Articles 1 through 10. The Agency is being cited for violations of Sections 87095.65(a)(1) Emergency Intervention Staff Training and 87095.61(b) Documentation and Reporting Requirements. Due to COVID-19 An exit interview was conducted over the phone, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email. Signatures were also requested via email and will be documented on an LIC812.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME
investigation_findings: 13On August 31, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted a follow up complaint inspection to Elite Family Systems- Scoffield Home and met with Administrator, Richard Padilla. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. Based on confidential interviews, and file documentation review for both clients and staff, it was determined that staff did not refill a client's psychotropic medication nor did staff ensure that the same client received psychiatric care. It was also determined that staff did not report incidents regarding this client to Community Care Licensing. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove the above allegations are substantiated. Deficiencies were cited. A copy of the report was provided to the agency along with appeal rights. On 10/4/22 LPA Bruce arrived at Scoffield Home to amend the deficiency page (changing Regulation Code) No other chages were made. Signing the amended documents on today's date is Janelle Sicairos, Mental Health Rehab Specialist/Social Worker. Copies of the amended document were provided to the facility. On 10/20/22 LPA Bruce arrived at Scoffield Home to amend the deficiency page (changing Regulation Code) No other chages were made. Signing the amended documents on today's date is Richard Padilla, Administrator. Copies of the amended document were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
Health Related Services:  Once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions.  
This requirement was not met as evidenced by Mental Health Specialist Staff did not refill client's medication timely.  This poses an immediate risk to the health and safety of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Supervising Social Worker, Anthony Guzman will ensure that all medication is refilled and dispensed appropriately and timely.  Records will be maintained at each STRTP and will be accessible to CCL. This modification to the process is effective immediately.

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision:  (a) The licensee shall provide care and upervision as necessary to meet the clien'ts needs.  This requirement was not met as   evidenced by Staff not ensuring client received psychiatric care both in house and out.  This poses an immediate risk to the health and safety of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Supervising Social Worker, Anthony Guzman will maintain records of and ensure that all  psychiatric appointments for clients in care are kept and tracked.   All of client’s treatment will be noted in their personal file. as well as in the Needs and Services Plan.  This modification to the process is effective immediately.

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements:  Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency with the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. This requirement was not met s evidenced by staff did not report all incidents of restraints to Client C1 to CCL as required.  This poses an immediate risk to health and safety of the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: In light of recent staff changes, COO Bill Sneed will arrange for retraining of all staff on IR reporting system.  Training will include deadlines as well as streamlines in place for IR approvals and submissions to CCL. Proof of this training will be submitted to CCL by deadline of October 1, 2022.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME
narrative: On 4/7/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd visited the Short Term Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Elite Scoffield Home. During this visit, LPA conducted a physical inspection of the home. LPA met with MHRS Janelle Sicairos and discussed a prior incident in the home and LPA Boyd notified Janelle that a deficiency was being issued. An incident occurred in the home in which staff was speaking with a client who was refusing to get off of the floor and the staff began to push on client’s body with his foot in effort to get client to comply. A deficiency is being for Personal Rights violation 87072(c)(11) from Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the Appeal Rights were provided to the facility.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Janelle Sicairos. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation regarding the staff handled minor in an inappropriate manner. During the course of the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted confidential interviews. The information obtained during the interviews, indicated that the staff FS12 twisted a clients hand behind his back and pushed him to the floor.. Type A: This poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. Based on the LPA’s observations, interviews, and the records review conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegation is found to be substantiated. A copy of the report and Appeal Rights was provided to the STRTP.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights To be free of physical, or other abuse... infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, This requirement is not met as evidenced by: staff used excessive force and did not councel with client prior to restraint. which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: STRTP will retrain staff in personal rights and de-escalation techniques. Proof of retraining will be completed by April 13, 2023 and proof of retraining to be sent to CCL by this date.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Janelle Sicairos. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations regarding the staff not treating the clients with respect and the discipline policies are not trauma informed. During the course of the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted confidential interviews. The information obtained during the interviews, indicated that staff would speak about clients in front of other clients in a demeaning manner. Review of policy and confidential interviews found that discipline policies are positively based and are not trauma-informed. Type A: This poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. Based on the LPA’s observations, interviews, and the records review conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegation is found to be substantiated. A copy of the report and Appeal Rights was provided to the STRTP.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights-The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9,...To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect.This requirement is not met as evidenced by staff talking about clients in the presence of other clients, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff will be retrained in Personal Rights and care and supervision. Proof of retraining to be provided to CCL by April 14, 2023

deficiencies.description: Discipline Policies and Procedures-The positive discipline policies and procedures shall be trauma-informed, as specified in Section 87078.2. This requiement is not met as evidenced by clients discipline does not reflect individual trama informed care and all clients have the same discipline, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff will be retrained on trauma-informed discipline and appropriate positive disipline. Proof of retraining to be provided to CCL by April 14, 2023

narrative: On July 19, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) made an unannounced visit to the STRTP Scoffield Home for the purpose of continuing the Annual Inspection. LPA was met on this day by Administrator Richard Padilla. LPA discussed the results of the previous day's inspection with Administrator. Administrator provided LPA with LIC500. Administrator provided LPA with current fire clearance. LPA and Administrator discussed Emergency Evacuation Plans. Administrator provided LPA with Manual Restraint Log and LPA discussed the need to have a more detailed follow up and explanations on the log. Fire extinguishers were checked and were valid. A new LIC203A Facility License was printed for the facility as the old one was invalid. Medication binder was reviewed for all clients. No deficiencies were cited on this day. Annual will be continued on a later date.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME
narrative: On July 18, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd made an unannounced visit to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Scoffield Home for the purpose of an Annual Inspection. LPA was met on this day by Mental Health Resource Specialist (MHRS) Janelle Sicairos. Administrator Richard Padilla was not in on this day. MHRS advised LPA that a new client was coming and being admitted around 12:30 or 1:00 pm and she also had a scheduled CFT this afternoon. MHRS had additional staff to assist her. LPA toured the facility inside and out. Water temperature in the kitchen and the bathroom was at 115 degrees. Perishable and nonperishable food was within regulation requirements. The home is an older home and the kitchen cabinets are an older wood style. There are a few drawers in the kitchen that do not open easily and fall due to broken drawer glides. In general the home was in order. Staff was doing laundry and cleaning the rooms and vacuuming the carpets. There is a fireplace in the living room that is inoperable. There are whiteboards in the living area with client schedules and possible consequences. LPA viewed the client bathroom to be generally clean, but nothing seemed to be wiped down. There was toothpaste and spit in the sink, the counters had hair and hygiene products on it, the mirror was dirty with drips and spatter, the tub had soap or shampoo drips and there was a layer of dust around the rim. Staff bathroom had no paper towels and the trash can was overflowing. LPA reviewed one client file on this day. LPA to return to complete the inspection on another day.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME
narrative: On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted a case management visit at the STRTP and met with Janelle Sicairos, Mental Health Specialist. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the necessity to report incidents timely to remain in compliance. Two recent incident reports received in the Community Care Licensing (CCL) incident mailbox were beyond the seven day deadline. 1- August 5, 2023 was the date of the occurrence and it was signed and reviewed by overnight staff and administration on that date, however it was not sent to CCL until August 14, 2023. 2- August 4, 2023 was the date of occurrence and it was signed and reviewed by overnight and administration on August 5, 2023 however it was not sent to CCL until August 14, 2023. Based on the above, a citation is being issued for not being in compliance General Licensing Standards are being cited on the attached LIC809D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description: Rep. Req (b)..in addition, a written report ... shall be submitted ..within seven days following the occurrence of such event..which threaten the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. This poses a potential risk to the health safety and personal rights of the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Janelle Sicarios has developed a refresher training for staff.  The class is scheduled for September 1, 2023.  Evidence of the training, topics covered and sign in sheet will be provided to CCL by September 5, 2023. Make up classes will be held by the end of the month for any staff that missed it.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME
met_with: Desiree Castaneda, Richard Padilla, Jennifer Duarte
narrative: On December 2, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Danny Macias, Melissa Renovato, Olivia Medran and Complaint Specialist (CS) C.K. Kinney conducted an unannounced required two year inspection at Elite Scoffield STRTP located in Ceres CA. LPAs and CS met with Facility Manager Desiree Castaneda, Richard Padilla and Jennifer Duarte. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 72 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced in June 5, 2024. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed. STRTP was approved on 07/19/2023. The facility is accredited through CARF with accreditation through 01/31/2025, and they are approved through Alameda County Department of Behavioral Health through July 2025. . No firearms or weapons are observed in the facility. LPA reviewed 5 client files, and 5 staff files. LPAs interviewed 4 staff and 1 client. LPA discussed repairs needed for the fence, including a missing fence plank, a missing gate latch, a hole and a loose fence post not secured to the building. Deficiencies are being cited on today’s visit, that include one Type A violation. Interim licensing standards Section 87087.2(a), Outdoor Activity Space (a) Children shall have access to safe outdoor activity space. A copy of this report, LIC811 Confidential Names, LIC9058 Appeal Rights was left at the facility at the conclusion of today’s inspection.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC- SCOFFIELD HOME

The facility is maintained at 73°F. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced on June 1, 2025. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed. STRTP was approved on 06/26/2020. The facility is accredited through CARF with accreditation through October 31, 2027. Per letter from Alameda County Behavioral Health Department dated June 2, 2025, the agency is approved through April 30, 2028. No firearms or weapons are in the facility per PD. LPAs reviewed 4 client files, and 5 staff files. LPAs interviewed two staff. LPAs discussed buildings and grounds, specifically client's bathroom sink drain stopper and client's bathroom cabinet. There is a Type B violation and a Technical Violation being cited on today’s visit. A copy of the reports was left with Jennifer Duarte at the conclusion of today’s inspection.

The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. The Department has investigated the complaint alleging a "Minor sustained injury while in care." LPA Barragan spoke with staff, clients, a social worker and reviewed predominate documents. Based on a conversation with Client 1 (C1), his story did not change and he continued to state that Staff 1 (S1) threw the chair at him. After reviewing incident reports and interviewing staff, it revieled that C1 did substain an injury incare; however, the injury was self inflected. Based on documents reviewed, an inspection, and conversations with staff and client the all the information that was gathered was contradicting. "Although the allegation may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED." An exit interview was conducted with Bill Sneed, Administrator. A copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to Bill Sneed, Administrator.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC.- LESLIE HOME
narrative: On 04/20/21 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lidia Tinoco conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection visit with Elite, Leslie house and met with Administrator Tammy Scoffield. While reviewing video footage of the facility, LPA Tinoco observed that in the living room area of the Leslie home there was a couch in front of the glass door that leads to the backyard, obstructing the exit. On 12/20/2018 Complaint Specialist Charles Kinney issued an Advisory Note to the agency regarding the same issue. This violates the Children's Personal Rights as cited on the California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6. The Agency is being cited for violation of Section 80087(c) Buildings and Grounds. facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC.- LESLIE HOME
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura conducted an announced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting a psychotropic medication inspection. LPA Segura met with Administrator Jaime Puga and both toured the facility inside and out. The STRTP is licensed to serve six clients, ages 7 - 17 years old and non-minor dependents. Currently in placement are five clients. All of whom are taking psychotropic medication; LPA only reviewed files for four clients as one has been placed less than 30 days. At approximately 9:45am LPA Segura began to review four client files. The administrator Jaime Puga assisted LPA Segura with reviewing the files. In the course of reviewing client files LPA Segura noted that the facility is not including services the child is receiving from the facility such as group therapy, this was found to be the case for all four clients. The facility however, is noting when children attend outside mental health services in the client file. See advisory note. At approximately 11:30am LPA Segura and Administrator Puga conducted a medication count and found it to be in compliance. LPA counted medication based on the centrally stored log start dates. The facility receives bubble packs from the pharmacy which made observing and count of the pills easier. Continued on 809C

Interviews were conducted with two staff, facility managers S2 and S3 and administrator Puga (Staff 2, 3, see confidential Names list, LIC 811 dated 09/29/21; includes names for four children subject to this review). Interviews with S2 and S3 occurred at approximately 12:30pm and interview with C2 occurred at approximately 1pm; Interviews with C1, C3, and C4 ocurred at approximatley 2:45pm. There were no deficiencies noted at today's evaluation. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with Jaime Puga.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC.- LESLIE HOME
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Michelle P. Kyane conducted a case management inspection on 05/26/2022 based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 7 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 05/26/2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Kyane observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Alvaro Juarez, Facility Administrator.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC.- LESLIE HOME
narrative:
On 11/09/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to Elite Leslie Home in Ceres, CA to conduct an announced SB484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection at 9:30 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Galvan met with Administrator Alvaro Juarez. At 9:45 AM LPA inspected the facility inside and out. LPA observed the following during the inspection. All medication, knives, and disinfectants locked. All medications are stored in a lock container inside a locked cabinet. All required documentation is posted and accessible for both staff and client to review. The facility is clean and in good sanitary conditions. Each client is provided a bed, linens, and storage space in their bedrooms. The facility has three days of perishables and seven days of non-perishable. The facility’s refrigerator, freezer, and water temperature are all at a safe temperature range. The front and back outdoor areas are free from dangers and hazards. At 10:15 AM LPA reviewed two client files on site at the facility. At 11:30 AM LPA reviewed two client medications, medication records, and PMARs. At 12:00 PM LPA reviewed one Administrator and one staff file on site at the facility. At 1:00 PM LPA interviewed two staff on site to discuss the facility's psychotropic medication management, policies and procedures of operation. At 1:45 PM LPA interviewed two clients currently prescribed psychotropic medication and ward of the courts. CONTINUED ON PAGE 2...

CONTINUED FROM PAGE 1... LPA conducted exit interview with Administrator Alvaro Juarez at 2:00 PM. No deficiencies were observed and cited on today's visit. A copy of this report was left with Alvaro Juarez at the conclusion of the inspection.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC.- LESLIE HOME
narrative: On July 11, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd made an unannounced visit to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Leslie Home for the purpose of an Annual Inspection. LPA was met on this day by Administrator Alvaro Juarez. LPA toured the facility inside and out. LPA observed water temperature to be within regulation at 117 degrees Fahrenheit. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature of 75 degrees Fahrenheit. All trash cans are covered. Centrally stored medications are maintained in a locked box within a locked cabinet. There is a dedicated refrigerator that would store medication if needed, locked in the office. Toxic chemicals are kept locked. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and was last serviced June 13, 2023. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Closet space for hanging clothes was adequate and drawers were provided There is at least one week supply of nonperishable and a two day supply of perishable foods. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Swimming pool is located in the back yard and is secured with a chain link fence and a locking gate as per regulation. Life saving devices are located at the pool entrance. LPA will complete this inspection at a later time. No deficiencies were cited on this day. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

Citation was issued on this date.

deficiencies.description: Food Services- Commercial foods shall be approved by appropriate federal, state and local authorities.  All foods shall be selected, transported, stored, prepared and served so as to be free from contamination and spoilage and shall be fit for human consumption.  Food in damaged containers shall not be accepted, used or retained. This requirement is not met as evidenced by a dented can in the pantry and frozen meat in an unmarked container in the freezer, which which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: STRTP threw away defective food containers and unmarked frozen food in the freezer.  LPA observed the discarded food on 1/26/24.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC.- LESLIE HOME
narrative: On May 2, 2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd made an unannounced visit to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Elite Leslie Home. LPA met with Alvaro Juarez. LPA reviewed client files. As a result of the file review, it was found that in four out of four client files reviewed, there were no signatures from client or placing county or authorized representatives on the Needs and Service Plan. See LIC 811 for confidential names list. Type B citation was issued on this day. Copy of this report was left at the facility.

deficiencies.description: Needs and Service Plan- (g) The licensee shall obtain written approval from the child, if age and developmentally appropriate, and the child’s authorized representative prior to implementing the child’s needs and services plan. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: in four out of four client client files reviewed, there were no signautures of acknowledgement or approval from any party, including the child or the child's authorized representative, prior to implementation, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator shall work with appropriate staff to obtain signatures from four clients and authorized representatives for all four clients.  Documentation of attempts to obtain signatures shall be kept in the client files. Proof of signatures and attempts shall be sent to CCL by 5/10/24.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC.- LESLIE HOME
narrative: On June 26, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd visited the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Elite Family Systems Leslie Home for the purpose of a Case Management, discussing incident reports that had been submitted for the facility. LPA discussed restraints and procedures for talking to clients when they may be escalating and attempting to runaway. LPA also discussed missed medications and the procedures for daily medication dispensing. Procedures were discussed with Administrator Alavaro Juarez and Assistant Program Director Jennifer Duarte. investigation_findings: 13Complaint Specialist C.K. Kinney(CS) traveled to Elite Family Systems Leslie Home and met with Jennifer Duarte to deliver findings of investigation. CS conducted investigation that included review of documentation and confidential interviews. Based on information obtained a preponderance of the evidence was found that staff handled minors in rough manner during restraints. Allegation is substantiated. This facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards for STRTP Version 5 section 87095.01(a)(4) Emergency Interventions Prohibition. Copy of this report, ILS citation, LIC 811 Confidential Names and LIC 9058 Appeal Rights left at the facility at conclusion of inspection.

deficiencies.description:
Emergency Intervention Prohibitions: (a)	The following emergency interventions techniques must not be used on a child at any time...(4)	Prone restraint.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Confidential interviews revealed staff are using restraints where client is taken to the floor by two staff, one holding and pulling back on each arm. This presents an immediate risk to the health, safety or welfare to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will conduct a staff training to ensure prone restraints are no longer in use. Licensee will provide plan by due date.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC.- LESLIE HOME
narrative: An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reyna Martinez. LPA met with Jennifer Duarte, Program Director and inspected the facility, inside and out. LPA provided the Program Director the entrance checklist and requested the necessary documents. Licensee's CARF Accreditation is valid until October 31, 2027 and the MHPA was is approved until April 30, 2028. There are no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Swimming pool is located in the back yard and is secured with a chain link fence and a locking gate as per regulation. Life saving devices are located at the pool entrance. A physical plant was inspected and included the following checks: There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space observed. The facility is maintained at 74 degrees and the water temperature was at 117 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced on June 1, 2025. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, and are in good repair. LPAs reviewed Board meeting minutes dated May 13, 2025. LPA discussed with Program Director the requirements for the biannual review of the EIP that will be submitted to the department for review. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs 1 administrator, 9 facility manager's, 1 case manager, 1 clinician/social worker, and 1 mental health rehabilitation specialist. 5 staff files were reviewed and meet all regulatory requirements. 2 staff were available to be interviewed. 5 records of clients were reviewed. 2 clients were available for interview, 3 clients declined to be interview. No Deficiencies were cited on today's visit. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC.- LESLIE HOME
narrative: On July 2, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Danny Macias and Briana Placencia conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility. LPAs met with Chief Operations Officer (COO) Bill Sneed. Based on record review, the facility failed to provide incident reports within the allotted time frame to Community Care Licensing. The Department determined this to be an immediate risk to the health and safety of clients in care at this time, therefore the STRTP is being issued a deficiency under Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, 80061(b) Reporting Requirements on the attached LIC809-D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were left with Bill Sneed at the conclusion.

facility_name: ELITE FAMILY SYSTEMS, INC.- LESLIE HOME
narrative: On August 12, 2025, a Non-compliance conference was held at the Fresno Children's Residential Program, Fresno Office. Present with Community Care Licensing are Regional Manager Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Manager Tamara Melikian, Licensing Program Manager Lourey Bartolome and Licensing Program Analyst Danny Macias. Present with Elite Family Services is Chief Operations Officer (COO) Bill Sneed and Program Director (PD) Jennifer Duarte. The purpose of the conference is to address deficiencies assessed at the facility and a plan for compliance. Facility will be training STRTP staff on incident reporting and implementing a process to submit incident reports in a timely manner. In addition, the services of the Technical Support Program and Systems of Care were offered and the licensee is interested in these support systems. A copy of this report was left with COO Bill Sneed.

met_with: Natasha Bourbonnais, Human Services Manager II, and Julia Barbosa, House Manager.
narrative: On March 5, 2021 at 2:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza conducted an inspection. LPA Mendoza met with Natasha Bourbonnais, Human Services Manager and Julia Barbosa, Facility Manager. On 2/24/21 the facility requested to decrease there capacity from 12 to a capacity of 6. The facility submitted an application for the Emergency-Temporary Shelter Care Facility (E-TSCF) due to Governors COVID-19 statewide waiver. Once the Governor's Emergency Proclamation is lifted the facility will change their capacity back to 12 or possible look at other options. LPA Mendoza will mail the updated license on Monday 03/08/21 and email a copy to the facility. Exit interview was conducted.

On Tuesday October 26, 2021 at 8:40 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made an unannounced inspection to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with Administrator Saila Martinez. The facility has a census of three clients. Two clients were at school, and one client 51/50. At 08:55 AM LPA Mendoza conducted a walk thru. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. There are no pools or bodies of water. All disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are locked. Per Administrator there are no firearms in the facility. The inspected bedrooms were furnished accordingly. The kitchen is clean and sanitary. Menus are posted in the kitchen area. The facility has sufficient two day perishable and seven day nonperishable food supply. The facility has Personal Rights, Foster Youth Rights, and Emergency Disaster Plans posted and in clear view. At 09:53 AM LPA Mendoza inspected the medication binder. Currently one client is on psychotropic medication. The facility has all required documents and medications are kept locked in the staff office. At 10 AM, LPA Mendoza reviewed all three client files, and all files were complete. At 10:44 AM LPA Mendoza reviewed 10 staff files at the facility and staff training. All staff files had everything in personnel file, except TB test results. [ PLEASE CONT. TO LIC 809-C.]

All TB test results are located at the San Mateo County Building, located at (1 Davis Drive, Belmont, CA). After staff file and training review LPA Mendoza went to county office to review TB test results. All TB test were complete and on file. LPA interviewed two staff members. All staff training hours meet the minimum requirements. During inspection, LPA obtained a copy of LIC 500, LIC 610. No deficiencies were cited during todays inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

met_with: Saila Martinez- Administrator, Senior Human Services Care Counselor, Aimee Salazar-Nunez
narrative: On Wednesday, March 09, 2022, at 9:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made a case management visit to the facility regarding Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing on March 2, 2022, regarding staff member refusing a client a snack. LPA Mendoza met with Administrator, Saila Martinez and Senior Human Services Care Counselor, Aimee Salazar-Nunez. The purpose of today's inspection was to gather additional information and interview the Administrator, staff members, and (C1). The SIR dated (02/25/22) stated that Client #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811), dated March 09, 2022}) asked for a bag of chips from (S1). (S1) refused to give (C1) a bag of chips because (C1) had a bag 30 minutes prior and had breakfast. Which then resulted in (C1) becoming escalated. During inspection, LPA obtained a copy of the facilities food menu, and inspected the facility kitchen. The facility has snacks available at all time. LPA interviewed staff members, and (C1). Also, observed (C1's) destructive behavior of self inflicting. LPA also obtained copies of (C1's) Needs and Service Plan, Safety Plan, Mental Health Review, (C1) behavior plan, Staff shift notes from 2/25-3/8/22. Based on interviews and documentation, (C1) is particular about his food and its presentation. In addition, would prefer to eat unhealthy food and chips for all meals of the day. The facility developed a plan for (C1) to have spicy chips three times a day after eating each meal. However, on multiple occasions (C1) has refused to eat and would exhibit destructive behavior and become escalated. The facility has been working very closely with (C1's) authorized rep and clinical treatment team. In addition, has weekly meetings with all parties regarding (C1)'s behaviors and needs. No deficiencies cited during todays inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng on 6/7/2022 at 10:30AM. During the inspection, LPA Ng met with Aimee Salazar, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 1 of child’s records on site at the facility at 11:40 AM. LPA reviewed 3 of staff personnel files on site at the facility at 11:02 AM. LPA reviewed 1 of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records at 12:00 PM. LPA interviewed 2 of staff on site at 12:30 PM. LPA interviewed 0 of children currently taking psychotropic medication at 11:40 AM. There is one client in care and they are currently in summer school. LPA conducted exit interview with Aimee Salazar, Administrator at 12:45 PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Aimee Salazar, Administrator upon completion. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Aimee Salazar, Administrator at 1:00 PM.

On 4/7/2023 at 10:20AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an announced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the SB484 Psychotropic Medications Inspection. LPA met with Aimee Salazar, Administrator, and Julia Barboza, Senior Human Services Care Counselor, who assisted with a tour of the facility. LPA observed the facility to have six bedrooms. The facility was sufficiently stocked with fresh and frozen foods. The facility was observed to be clean, tidy, and in good repair. LPA was shown the locked medication storage cabinet. The facility currently has a census of four clients. All four clients are currently prescribed psychotropic medications, one client is over 18 years old. At the time of the inspection, there were three staff members and one client present. LPA reviewed five staff files. LPA reviewed three client files. LPA reviewed the centrally stored medications binder. LPA interviewed two staff members. LPA interviewed one client. LPA conducted a pill count with Aimee Salazar and Julia Barboza. No deficiencies were cited at this time. This inspection is not complete as LPA needs to interview three other clients. LPA conducted an exit interview with Aimee Salazar, Administrator at 2:45PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

met_with: Senior Human Services Care Counselor Julia Barboza
investigation_findings: 13On 11/17/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Senior Human Services Care Counselor Julia Barboza and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, observations, and record review, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. It was found that documentation and statement from administering staff reflect a prescribed contraceptive medication was administered to the appropriate resident and not to the involved resident. However, a statement could not be obtained from the involved resident due to hospitalization and later runaway behavior resulting in the resident being unavailable for interview. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Senior Human Services Care Counselor Julia Barboza, whose signature on this report confirms receipt.
