narrative: On 04/03/24 at 11:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made an unannounced visit to the facility for the purpose of conducting a case management to follow up on an incident report that was received by the Department. LPA met with Administrator Aimee Salazar who helped facilitate the inspection and was informed on the purpose of this visit. LPA conducted an interview with the Administrator, a walk through of the facility, requested documentation, and attempted to interview youth regarding the incident. No citations were issued during this visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Aimee Salazar, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 05/24/24 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) made an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting a case management visit to follow up on an incident report received by the Department for an incident that occurred on 04/17/24. Upon reviewing the incident report and conducting confidential interviews, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio observed that staff violated a resident’s personal rights by locking a youth in a room of the facility. LPA determined that the facility acted appropriately in referring the involved staff to the Employee Assistance Program and having a discussion with the staff about the concerns around their actions. During the review LPA identified an area in which a technical assistance advisory may be beneficial regarding personal rights for clients in care. See LIC 9102 dated 05/09/24. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Aimee Salazar, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Administrator Aimee Salazar-Nunez; Senior Human Services Care Counselor Julia Barboza
narrative: On 5/30/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required 2-year inspection. LPA met with Administrator Aimee Salazar-Nunez and Senior Human Services Care Counselor Julia Barboza and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to complete this inspection. There are no children in care, and no children have been in care in the past 30 days. LPA toured the facility site and grounds and reviewed 5 personnel files, including files for management staff, daytime care staff, and overnight care staff. LPA observed the facility site and grounds to be in safe condition, and dangerous items were observed to be inaccessible to residents. All files were observed to be complete with all staff having met training requirements from 2023 to 2024. LPA obtained a current LIC 500 and observed all staff listed to be on the Guardian background clearance roster. However, four staff members were observed to not have a LIC 508 uploaded to the Guardian site but did have a LIC 508 in the personnel files. LPA discussed with Administrator and demonstrated where to locate the current version of the LIC 508 and LIC 508D forms on the licensing website, how to upload the form to the Guardian site, and how to check for eligibility status on the Guardian roster. See LIC 9102. No deficiency citations were issued at today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator.

On 5/1/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to the facility. LPA met with Administrator Aimee Salazar Nunez and informed of the purpose of the visit. The purpose of the visit was to follow-up on a submitted incident report (IR). Per the IR, a client in care disclosed a personal rights violation involving another client in care. LPA discussed the IR and attachments submitted to LPA with Administrator. LPA informed Administrator that the licensing agency's investigation into the matter would be conducted fully or in part by the agency's Investigations Bureau (IB) and that another investigator may be contacting the facility. LPA obtained copies of relevant documents at visit. Further investigation is needed in order to resolve this matter. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and licensee's rights were provided to Administrator.

On July 17, 2025, at 2:15 PM, Component II of the application process for Embolden Youth Service - Iris House located at 643 W. 95th Street Los Angeles, CA. 90044 was held at the El Segundo Children’s Residential Regional Office in El Segundo. Attending Component II were the following individuals: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Charmetha White, Applicant, Kendra Bolden. The following incomplete application forms were discussed at the meeting: · Personnel Report (LIC 500) · Guardian Association · Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610) · Criminal Clearance Transfer · New Administrator Requirements · STRTP Orientation Certificate · Financial Responsibility Program Statement was reviewed and discussed. Pre-Licensing Inspection will be scheduled for a future date, as applicant is waiting for smoke detectors fully installed. A copy of this report was issued to the Applicant, Kendra Bolden.

On August 7, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at the above location for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA was met by Applicant, Kendra Bolden. The facility is requesting to be licensed as a Short-Term Residential Program to provide to provide care and supervision to six (6) female children, ages 13-17 years old, ambulatory only. The facility will also provide services to non-minor dependents. Currently the census is zero (0). The home is set up as follows: This is a single story 3 bedroom, 2 bathroom, home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry area, a backyard, and a detached garage. Living room: is equipped two (2) sofas, a lounge chair, two (2)chairs, a coffee table, two (2) end tables with lamps, a mounted flat screen TV, a entry way table equipped with a printer and a small lamp. Dining room: is equipped with a wooden table and six (6) chairs. There is also a small bookshelf that contains board games. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five (5) burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), and a microwave. Sharp knives are kept locked in a cabinet located under the kitchen sink. LPA observed a covered trash can, ample plates, cups, and eating utensils. LPA observed ample nonperishable food items in the pantry. The applicant will ensure that three (3) nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to clients in care. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 3)

Laundry area: is located off of the kitchen. The area has a washer, dryer, locked cabinets, and a door leading to the backyard. This area also contains a hot water heater. (Note: Hot water heater needs to have a secured framed separation). Backyard: Contains a sitting area for private visitation purposes. Detached garage: is equipped with two (2) desks, chairs, a table and multiple seating. This area will be utilized by Facility staff and the Mental Health Team. Bedrooms: A, B, and C: are equipped with two (2) twin beds, drawers, and ample closet space. All bedrooms have a ceiling fan/working light, and security bars. The security bar emergency latches were tested and found to be operational at the time of this inspection. Bathroom #1: is located in the hallway near the back of the home, between bedroom C and bedroom B. The bathroom contains a toilet, sink, and a tub/shower combination. Bathroom #2: is located in the hallway near the front of the home, between bedroom B and bedroom A. The bathroom contains a toilet, sink, and a tub/shower combination. All bathrooms were checked and found to be in working order. Vehicle: Applicant does not currently have a facility vehicle. LPA observed the facility to have two (2) regulation fire extinguishers. The facility has a working telephone. Extra linens are stored in hallway cabinets. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The First Aid kit was checked and found to be complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, gauzes, antiseptics, and First Aid Manual Guide. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in a locked cabinet in the laundry area. Medications will be kept in a locked cabinet in the staffing office. Medications requiring refrigeration will be kept in a combination lock box in the refrigerator. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. There are no bodies of water on the premises. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 2 of 3)

LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The backyard is fenced in, both were clean and free of debris. Clients and Staff Records will be stored in locked file cabinets located in the staffing office. LPA’s informed Applicant, Kendra Bolden, that the following needs to be fixed prior to licensure: 1. Facility Vehicle 2. Thermometer for freezer & fridge 3.) Frame for Hot Water Heater 4.) Completed LIC 610C This concludes the pre licensing inspection. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was emailed to the applicant, Kendra Bolden. (Page 3 of 3)

On March 28, 2025, at 9:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Butler, Empowering Experience for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA with Applicant Yvette Duncan who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. The home is set up as follows: This is a three bedroom, two bathroom home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry space, and backyard area. The garage has been converted in to a bedroom that has a Murphy bed, stove, and bathroom. Living room: is equipped with mounted TV, couch, ottoman, coffee table, and cabinet. Dining room: is equipped with a table with bench seating. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), and microwave. Sharp knives will be kept inaccessible in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. LPA observed a covered trash can. LPA observed ample and non-perishable food items. The Applicant will ensure that three nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. 809 continued on page 1 of 3

Bedroom #1: staff office equipped with 2 desk, file cabinet, lockers, chair, adequate lighting, and window with bars that open and close freely. Bedroom #2: client's bedroom equipped with bunk beds, drawer space, adequate closet space, adequate lighting, and window with bars that open and close freely. Bedroom #3: client's bedroom equipped with bunk beds, drawers space, adequate closet space, lighting, and window bars that open and close freely. Bathroom: Bathroom #1 is located in staff office, and bathroom #2 is located in the hallway. Bathrooms were observed to be clean and in working condition. Vehicle: The Applicant will use a 2006 Lexus GS to transport clients. Insurance is valid from January32, 2025 - January 3, 2026. The vehicle was observed to be in good condition. The home’s temperature is maintained by central air/heating. LPA observed two fully charged fire extinguishers which are located in the kitchen. Extra linens will be stored in drawers in the hallway. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid kit was found to be be complete with required items, except for a thermometer. The applicant has lockers for the clients to store there belongings. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in a locked cabinet in the hallway. LPA reminded Applicant to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Applicant will ensure grievance process, Disaster Plan, discipline policies and procedures will be posted in dining room area. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 2 of 3)

LPA observed Ring camera at the front door and on the side of the home. Door sensors were observed on all exit doors. During the inspection, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Applicant informed that the following corrections will need to be made. Applicant will email a additional facility sketch to include the garage conversion. Applicant will purchase a lock box for refrigerated medication. Applicant will purchase a thermometers for the home. Applicant will purchase lock boxes for contraceptives. Applicant will add the use of cameras in the facility to the Program Statement by April 8, 2025. Applicant will purchase an additional drawer for bedroom #2. Applicant will remove radio, and dvd player out of closet in bedroom #2. Applicant needs a fire clearance. Applicant needs to set up a Guardian Account. LPA received a copy of applicants Property Taxes. LPA informed Applicant that a Component III meeting will be held April 8, 2025, at 9 AM. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of report will be emailed to Applicant Yvette Duncan.

On April 8, 2025, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Erika Butler, and Licensing Program Manager conducted a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Component III office meeting with Applicant,Yvette Duncan. LPA Butler met with Applicant to discuss forms required to be maintained, available, and posted at the facility for inspections. We discussed child and personnel records that are required to be documented, retained and available for inspection. We also discussed specific requirements, concerns and issues operating a STRTP, such as, reporting requirements, personnel requirements, supervision, intake issues, compatibility, removal/discharge policies, complaint procedures, transportation, health services, food, hygiene, visitation, personal property, searches, and community sensitivity. Licensing of facility is pending final approval due to fire clearance, association to Guardian, and corrections to facility plant, and Systems of Care revisions, A copy of this report was provided to the Applicant, Yvette Duncan.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall conducted a case management inspection at the facility for the purpose of following up on a Serious Incident Report submitted by the facility to the Department on 10/12/21. Administrator Eric Perry (AD) notified LPA on 10/5/21 and 10/6/21 of a incident involving two youth in the facility engaging in sexual behavior with one another. AD informed LPA that the placing counties for the youth had been notified. One youth, C2, was removed from the facility by Probation on 10/7/21 as a result of the incident. The other youth, C1, who reported the incident to staff, did not disclose the day the incident occurred, just that the incident had occurred sometime in the last month, during the night. Both youth were interviewed by law enforcement and C2 was examined by a medical professional. LPA interviewed C2 in person on 10/4/21. C2 reported feeling safe at the facility and that the staff were very supportive. C2 had no concerns about his placement. AD reported to LPA that there are 2-3 night staff on duty each night, plus an administrative designee. AD has retrained the staff on expectations of night staff to check the bedrooms of clients every 15-30 minutes. Staff are to keep eye sight on any youth who get up and exit their rooms at night. Based on interviews and record reviews, no citations are issued at this time.

Continued from 812 LPA conducted a record review of the following documents: Client Placement roster for 3 months, staff roster with weekly schedules, current staff training logs, recent Serious Incident Reports, Needs and Services Treatment Plans for current clients, and an employee disciplinary notice. Based on observation, record review, and interviews, the allegation Staff pushed client in care is SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is cited under Interim Licensing Standards STRTP, Article 6, Personal Rights 87072(d)(11): To be free of physical…or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment…intimidation…or other actions of a punitive nature.” A signed copy of this report and the 9099C/9099D was provided to the facility. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the appeal rights were given to the administrator. The facility has already documented and submitted a Plan of Correction to the Department, which satisfies regulations. The Staff member who pushed the client received disciplinary action and will complete additional training. He reports receiving helpful supervision and feedback from other staff since the incident.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall arrived at the facility on 10/29/21 for the purpose of delivering findings following a complaint investigation. LPA met with Eric Perry, Administrator, to discuss the complaint findings. LPA opened the complaint virtually with the Administrator on 9/1/21, due to the roads to the facility being closed. LPA interviewed one former client on 10/1/21, and one county social worker on 9/23/21. LPA then toured the facility in person on 10/4/21, and interviewed four staff and three clients. A client (C1-See LIC 811: Confidential Names list 10/29/21) became physically and verbally aggressive on the evening on 8/22/21. C1 approached a Staff member, “bumped chests and began yelling and swearing.” Staff admitted to pushing C1 away from him when C1 approached. C1 fell back onto his bed, and was not physically injured. Statements were consistent between C1, and the other staff and clients who witnessed the incident. The facility reported the incident to the Department via Serious Incident Report which was submitted on 8/25/21. Continued on 9099C

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights 87072(d)(11): "to be free of physical…or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment…intimidation…or other actions of a punitive nature.”
This regulation was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and record reviews, a staff member pushed a client, causing a risk to the personal health and safety of the client in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility has already completed Plan of Correction and submitted documentation to the Department, satisfying requirements. Plan of Correction is included in Record Review.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall received a phone call from Administrator (AD) Eric Perry on 12/30/2022 reporting a 24 hour notice of a Serious Incident. AD reported that the new facility therapist picked up a client on 12/29/21 from a visit in Colusa and was driving the client back to facility in Susanville. Client had just been picked up from a family visit and was emotionally distraught. The therapist stopped at a bank in Red Bluff and ran in, leaving the client in the car. While in the bank, the client stole the car. Law enforcement was notified. The car was found in Stonyford, CA and had minimal damage. The client had not been located. Facility was willing to take the client back. LPA interviewed therapist on 1/19/22. Therapist is now aware to not leave clients unsupervised in the vehicle. It was very cold the day of the incident and the therapist chose to allow the client to remain warm in the car. AD has completed a disciplinary write up with additional training for the therapist. LPA interviewed the county social worker (CSW) for the client on 1/26/2022. The client has no history of theft. CSW indicated that prior to the therapist picking up the client, CSW had just told the client they would not be able to return to their previous foster home and the client was distraught. On 1/11/2022, the client mailed a letter to their previous foster home indicating they were alive and well. The county believes the client is residing in Stonyford, CA with his biological father. The county will do a surprise visit to the home in an attempt to locate the client and would like to return the client to the facility if he is found timely. LPA reviewed the full Serious Incident Report and disciplinary write up. No citation is being issued for this case management. A signed copy of this report was delivered to the facility by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Whitlow on 1/27/2022.

Continued from 9099 The reporting party alleged one client was sexually abused by another client. Interviews and record reviews were consistent that one client (C1) alleged abuse by another client (C2). C2 denied any abuse or involvement with C1. There were no witnesses to the alleged abuse. C1 gave different accounts of the abuse, and was vague in reporting dates and times of when it occurred, but stated it happened at night and lasted a few minutes. The same day that C1 informed staff of the alleged abuse, C1 was taken the doctor for an exam. C2 was removed from the facility the following day. Within three weeks, the Administrator had retrained all staff on night time supervision policies and procedures. LPA reviewed staff schedules and observed the facility had maintained appropriate staff ratio. C1 indicated to LPA he felt safe in the facility and was well cared for by staff. The Juvenile attorney added they did not feel the facility was neglectful in their level of supervision for the clients. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews, and record reviews, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this LIC-9099 and LIC-9099C were provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Alonzo Nall, Co-Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to deliver findings for a complaint investigation. LPA discussed the findings for the allegation: Lack of supervision by staff resulting in sexual interactions between minors. During the investigation, LPA interviewed one client (C1), one Therapist, and one Administrator on 1/19/2022. LPA had previously interviewed the same client on 10/4/21, which was after the alleged sexual incident took place, but prior to the alleged incident being reported by the client on 10/5/21. The client is a private placement and does not have a County Social Worker or Probation Officer. LPA initially interviewed the Administrator about the incident when it was first reported on 10/5/21, 10/6/21, 10/8/21, and 10/29/21. LPA interviewed a Juvenile attorney and two Probation officers on 4/11/2022. LPA reviewed the facility Program Statement, Serious incident reports, staff schedules, and Needs and Service Plan for the client. Continued on 9099

narrative:
An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Hillary Hall and LPA Shannon Parks on 07/14/2022 at 10:30am. During the inspection, LPA Hall and LPA Parks met with Eric Perry, Administrator, and inspected the facility inside and out. During the tour of the facility, LPA's observed the facility to be clean and organized. Medication was properly locked in a closet inside the locked office. LPA's reviewed 6 client files on site at the facility. LPA's interviewed 6 clients currently taking psychotropic medication. LPA's reviewed 2 staff personnel files and interviewed 2 staff. LPA's completed a medication count of all client medications. All clients had current JV-220’s or parental consent. During the review of client’s records, LPA's observed four Needs and Services Plans did not describe the services provided to the client. Five Needs and Service Plans were not signed by the client. LPA's observed 4 client files did not have current Needs and Service Plans. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and cited from the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Section 87068.2(c): The needs and services plan shall include a description of the services to be provided or arranged to meet the short- and long-term needs and goals of the child. Continued on 809C

Continued from 809 One deficiency was observed and cited from ILS Section 87068.2 (f): The licensee shall obtain written approval from the child, if age and developmentally appropriate, and the child’s authorized representative prior to implementing the child’s needs and services plan. One deficiency was observed and cited from the ILS Section 87068.3(a) Modifications to The Needs and Services Plan (a) The needs and services plan specified in Section 87068.2 shall be updated at least every 30 days. LPA conducted exit interview with Administrator Eric Perry at 5:30pm. A signed copy of this LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC-809D were provided to the facility.

On July 15, 2022 at 10am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Hillary Hall and Shannon Parks arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of completing an Annual Inspection. LPA's met with Administrator (AD) Eric Perry and left at 3:00pm. LPA's previously completed an SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection on July 14, 2022. LPA's used the CARE tool to complete the Annual inspection. On 7/15/22, LPA’s completed a facility inspection. Facility is clean and organized. The facility currently has 9 clients, with a capacity of 10 clients. Staff ratio was maintained. More than 7 days of non-perishable food was observed and more than 3 days of perishable food was observed. Each client has sufficient bedding and storage space. Facility vehicles were in good repair. Facility does not have any bodies of water on the property. Outdoor space was safe and free of hazards. Smoke alarms, carbon monoxide detectors, and fire extinguishers were in compliance. Medications and cleaning supplies were locked per regulations. No deficiencies were noted in the physical grounds. On 7/14/22, LPA's interviewed eight clients who were on site. The remaining client was not on site due to a visit. LPA's interviewed two staff on 7/14/22 and two staff on 7/15/22. LPA's reviewed nine client files and six staff files. No deficiencies were noted with staff files. LPA's observed four client files had Needs and Services Plans (NSP) which were not updated within 30 days. Five Needs and Service Plans had not been signed by the client. Four Needs and Service Plans did not accurately include the services provided to the clients. No deficiencies were cited during this Annual Inspection. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC-809C were provided to the administrator.

On 02/5/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown met with Administrator Diana Tichenor at the Chico office of Community Care Licensing, to discuss and review the Program Statement information submitted to date on behalf of the several Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Programs (STRTP) in northern California. Discussion to move the process forward included, in part, -layout (specifically section headings); -specific required and sometimes repetitive wording; -addressing each section and being sure information is comprehensive -clarity in wording (i.e. client will review personal rights “regularly”); and -missing information The modified Program Statement will be provided to LPA by 03/05/2024.

On 4 April 2024 at Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Carmel Smith,Facility Supervisor. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Biennial Inspection of the facility. The last inspection that occurred was the Pre-licensing Inspection of 07/15/2022. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized, and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility is a home like setting, with five client bedrooms, a large open plan kitchen/dining area, and two locked staff office. Each client had a closet and dresser in good repair. Mattresses and bedding were observed to be clean. Clients were able to decorate their rooms with their personal belongings. The backyard was free from hazards, and safely fenced on shared property lines. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, client personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. Grievance Policy information and weekly menus were also in main living areas. The facility has two client bathrooms and one staff bathroom. The shower in one client bathroom is under repair and the Facility has contractor quotes. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. LPA observed the kitchen to have at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on hand. LPA observed client files and client medications were stored in a locked office in the refrigerator, non-refrigerated medications were stored in a locked office, in a locked closet.

On 04/03/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown returned to the facility unannounced to complete the Biennial Inspection. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility currently has nine clients, with a licensed maximum capacity of 10. Staff to client ratio is 4:9. LPA reviewed five staff files. Staff files had completed criminal record clearances and all required initial and annual training. Training certificates were in file and all First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for staff. LPA interviewed four staff on site. LPA reviewed five client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements on file. Client files had completed initial Needs and Service Treatment Plans, signed by clients and staff, and updated Needs and Service plans every 30 days. Needs and Service Plans detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. Clients were current on CHDP physical exams and dental exams. Three of the five of clients whose files were reviewed were taking court ordered psychotropic medications and had current JV-220’s on file. LPA interviewed all three clients available at the facility on this date. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of the two LIC-809 reports were provided to Carmel Smith. An exit interview was conducted.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) NAME arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management inspection following a record review during a complaint investigation. LPA Wendy Brown reviewed records from the facility and conducted eight interviews. Records indicate that one staff member observed an incident between a staff and a client on 7/30/2024. The staff provided a written report via email on 7/31/24, of the incident they observed, to the administrator, a senior facility manager, and the engineering supervisor. The facility initially determined the incident involved horseplay between the staff and client. After further internal review by the facility, the incident was interpreted as offensive and a potential safety risk for the client, warranting the facility filing a Serious Incident/Injury Report, a Suspected Child Abuse Report (SCAR), and termination of the involved staff. The SCAR was not submitted until 8/12/2024 and the 24-hour notice of the incident was submitted to the Department on 08/13/2024. The facility is being issued one citation per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80061(b)(1)(E): Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. (1) Events reported shall include the following: (E) Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights.

deficiencies.description: Upon the occurrence… of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours…1) Events reported shall include the following: (E) Any unusual incident or.... This requirement was not met as evidenced by: The agency did not report one serious incident between staff and client timely, posing a potential risk to the Health, Safety, and Personal Rights of a client in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility Agrees provide LPA verification that the current staff completed additional training  acknowledging awareness of timely reporting and to report incidents involving personal rights violations to the Department.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Misty Valencia and Lyta Vue on 08/28/24 at 11:00 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs Valencia and Vue met with Eric Perry, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 5/8 child’s records and 3/3 of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed 5/8 child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed 3/3 staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed 5/8 of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Eric Perry, Administrator. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Eric Perry, Administrator.

All interviews were consistent that an employee was involved in horseplay with a client wherein both wound up on the floor together. Interviews were inconsistent about what occurred during the horseplay. The involved client reported no harm, threat, or inappropriate action occurred. The witness did not report observing the employee doing anything that threatened the health, safety or wellbeing of the client. The involved client reported feeling safe at the facility and that staff never behaved in ways which made them feel uncomfortable. The involved employee was discharged from employment for violation of company policy around horseplay. The agency is developing training and an accompanying syllabus to present to staff around appropriate boundaries. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove a violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Misty Valencia and Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. narrative: Based on LPA’s interview and records review the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Therefore, the allegation is SUBSTANTIATED. One citation is being issued for violating Interim Licensing Standards Section 87095.01(b) and (c). An exit interview was conducted. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and LIC-9099D, and appeal rights were provided to Amy Green, Supervisor.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Amy Green, Supervisor. LPA Brown and LPA Yesenia Vallejo conducted the complaint investigation. LPA Brown initiated the investigation with the facility on 04/08/2025 and three staff members were interviewed. A Health and Safety Inspection was conducted. LPA Vallejo interviewed two county social workers and LPA Brown conducted a total of nine confidential interviews. LPA reviewed records including: incident reports, staff training records, Needs and Services plans, daily progress notes, and Child and Family Team meeting notes. The complaint allegation indicates that staff inappropriately restrained a minor in care. While there was some discrepancy as to how the client was restrained, the staff member in question admitted to having the client by the arm to prevent them from leaving, and witnesses were consistent that the staff member had grabbed and held the client by the arm. Restricting the client from leaving in this manner is not an approved restraint as part of the facility’s emergency intervention plan.

deficiencies.description:
ILS87095.01(b) and (c)  “(b)…any emergency intervention technique not approved as part of the licensee’s emergency intervention plan must not be used at any time. (c) Manual restraints must never be used for the following purposes: …(7) To prevent a child from leaving the facility…”

This has not been me as evidenced by interviews and records review.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will conduct training, specifically addressing restraint (when to do them and when not too) and ILS regulations for personal rights. LPA will be provided with staff sign in sheet to verify participation, along with the training outline.

narrative: action is taken. One staff person indicated they have seen clients smack each other on the buttocks and told them to stop. Interviews were consistent that staff had not received a report of a client being inappropriately touched by another client. It was alleged that a client received clothing that did not fit and did not receive new clothes when requested. Fifteen of sixteen interviewees were consistent that upon placement, need, or request, clients are provided with clothing immediately if needed, or later if they prefer to shop at a variety of stores not available in the community. Based on LPA’s interviews and records review, although the allegations may have happened, or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violations did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099, LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Amy Green, Facility Supervisor. LPA conducted the complaint investigation. LPA initiated the investigation with the facility on 05/22/2025 and three staff members were interviewed. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed seven other staff members, one probation officer, one county social worker, and five other confidential interviewees. LPA reviewed records including: Mental Health Rehabilitation Team’s weekly minutes, Needs and Services Plans, Client Safety Plans, staff discipline and annual evaluation reports, client accounting record, Unusual Incident/Injury Reports, disciplinary notices, employee reviews, daily progress notes, emails, texts, and written statements. It is alleged that staff did not intervene when a client reported inappropriate touching by other client(s) at the facility. Staff interviews were consistent that if or when inappropriate touching is reported, immediate

narrative: were inconsistent as to whether this occurs however one staff person admitted to swearing at clients but getting better at not doing so. Record review of one staff file indicated one staff had received correction for speaking negatively of a client. It was further alleged that staff do not treat clients with dignity and respect, including provoking clients when interacting with them. In interview with LPA, one staff person indicated that they were smiling and laughing while restraining a client. In a separate incident, interviews were consistent from individuals present that a staff person told a client they were at fault for an incident while efforts were underway to de-escalate the client. Based on LPA’s interviews and records reviewed, the “preponderance of evidence” standard has been met. Therefore, the allegations are SUBSTANTIATED. One citation is being issued for violating Interim Licensing Standards sections 87072(c)(15) and (32): 87072 Personal Rights (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child…is accorded the personal rights…(15) to be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons. (32) To have placement that utilizes trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques. An exit interview was conducted. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, LIC-9099D, and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description: 87072(c)The licensee shall ensure that each child…(15) to be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff.. (32)have placement that utilizes trauma-informed and evidence-based and de-escalation and intervention techniques. This regulation was not met as evidenced by interviews and records review that demonstrate that staff swore at client(s) and assessed blame to a client when escalated which posed a risk to the health, safety and personal rights of clients in care.

An announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Jean Stidman and Shoua Xiong on 2/24/21 at 12:00pm. During the inspection, LPA Stidman met with Gloria Losh, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via Facetime and Microsoft Teams. All files and medication documents were sent to LPA Stidman prior to the inspection. A medication count was also conducted by Facetime on this date. LPA reviewed four child’s records prior to the inspection on 2/17/21 and on site at the facility on 2/24/21 at 1:00pm. LPA reviewed five staff personnel files prior to the inspection on 2/22/21. LPA interviewed four staff on site at 2:00pm. LPA interviewed four children currently taking psychotropic medication at 3:00pm. Facility cited per Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87068.2(e) Needs and Services Plan The licensee shall obtain written approval from the child, if age and developmentally appropriate, and the child’s authorized representative prior to implementing the child’s needs and services plan. Based upon record review of children’s records for clients C1, C2, C3 and C4, the licensee did not obtain the authorized representative’s signature prior to implementing the child’s needs and services plan. Facility cited per ILS 87070(b)(11) Children’s Records. A copy of the current court order, or written authorization of the child's parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication, as defined in Section 87001(p)(8). Based upon record review of Client C4, the licensee did not ensure the psychotropic medication on the current court order is what the client is receiving. The JV-223 dated 11/2/2020 states the maximum total mg/day for Wellbutrin is 100mg. The client is currently taking 150mg once a day as documented by the prescription dated 1/19/2021 which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. LPA conducted exit interview with Gloria Losh, Administrator at 5:00pm. LPA provided the Summary Report to Gloria Losh, Administrator upon completion by email with a request for signature and to scan this back to the LPA with their signature by 2/25/21.

On June 2, 2021 at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley King, made an unannounced video call to the above facility and met with Delores Martinez, Facility Manager, to conduct an unannounced case management teleconference. A teleconference call was conducted due to Covid-19 protocols. A case management was initiated by the Department being informed of C1 (see confidential names list) having an expired JV-220. LPA requested copies of the C1’s medication list, medication administration record, expired JV-220, physician’s denial of emergency authorization, medication authorization from Placer County, and needs & services. On May 28, 2021, LPA was informed by Amberly Sabado, Facility Social Worker (FSW), a child in the facility was being issued psychotropic medication without a current JV-220. FSW stated C1 went to the doctor on 04/07/2021 to have a medical assessment done as a part of requesting a renewal for C1’s JV-220. FSW stated that a medical assessment was not completed but a medication management appointment was completed instead. FSW informed LPA C1’s JV-220 expired 05/08/2021. FSW stated it takes approximately 30 days for a new JV-220 to be issued after the application is submitted along with the medical assessment. FSW stated C1 is scheduled for a medical assessment 06/03/2021, after which the renewal will be submitted to the court for approval. FSW stated a request was made to C1’s doctor to obtain documentation that C1’s medication was being administered without a current JV-220 due to an emergency situation but it was denied. FSW stated they have continued to issue C1 their medication despite not having a current JV-220 on file. FSW stated a CFT was conducted on 05/27/2021 to discuss attempting to have the request for a new JV-220 expedited by C1’s attorney. C1’s county social worker, C1’s attorney and Placer County Public Health were present at the CFT. This incident was not reported to the Department within 24-hours of the initial incident, nor was a written incident report received by the Department within 7 days.(cont.)

An Interim Licensing Standard deficiency was cited on the attached LIC809D. The facility is being cited for a violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6 Continuing Care Requirements 80061(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements: Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. The facility is also being cited for a violation of Interim Licensing Standards 87070(b)(11) Children’s Records: The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record: A copy of the current court order, or written authorization of the child’s parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication, as defined in Section 87001(p)(8). Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, and appeal rights were emailed to the facility. LPA is requesting that all documents be signed and returned electronically via email.

investigation_findings: 13On 06/17/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Connie Goldie met with Facility Administrator Gloria Losh at 2:05 PM and explained the purpose of the visit was to deliver complaint findings for the above allegation. LPA Shawndra Miles initiated the complaint at the above named facility on 11/08/2021and met with Facility Manager Dolores Martinez regarding a personal rights violation allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA Goldie investigated the complaint that “Staff spoke inappropriate to resident in care." LPA Goldie conducted a records review of documentary evidence on 05/05/2022. LPA Goldie conducted a physical plant inspection of the home on 05/20/2022 and interviewed three staff. Additionally, nine foster youth, the facility administrator and the social worker were interviewed on 05/03/2022, 06/03/2022 and 06/10/2022. All staff collaborate that that they have not heard nor stated anything inappropriate to youth in care. Continued on LIC9099C

narrative: The Department has investigated the complaint that Staff improperly restrained youth. C1 was heading towards the front door entrance to run away and S1 was following behind C1. S1 was talking to C1 as C1 was trying to leave the home. C1 turned around and called S1 a “bitch” and attempted to hit S1. S1 then attempted to place C1 in a Small Child Restraint. C1 confirmed S1 placed one hand on C1’s shoulder and turned C1 around. C2 and S1 stated C1 let her body go limp during the restrain and went to the floor. Protocol was not followed as outlined in the Program Statement by staff which resulted in a youth being placed in an improper restraint. The Program Statement states “Physical interventions will be employed when a child is in immediate danger of harming her/self or other and when other less restrictive interventions have failed, and a “Restraint” is defined as: The use of trained staff members to hold a young person to contain acute physical behavior” the restrain was not executed properly which resulted in C1 going to the floor. Also, staff did not follow the Program Statement regarding “Staff will first employ protective interventions (releases, deflections, proximity, and protective stance) when a child attempts to physical harm to staff or peers. Staff did not allow enough space between C1 therefore, the staff was not implementing proximity and a protective stance which resulted in a improperly restraint. The youth was restrained for behavior that did not present an imminent danger for injuring self or others which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. As a result of the interviews conducted, documentation reviewed and investigation conducted, the allegation that staff improperly restrain youth is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 87095.00(d) General Provisions: All children placed in a short-term residential therapeutic program have the right to be free from the use of restraints imposed as a means of coercion, discipline, convenience, or retaliation by staff An exit interview was conducted with Gloria Losh, STRTP Administrator, a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton conducted a visit on July 1, 2022, and LPA spoke to Gloria Losh, Administrator to deliver findings of the investigation on the complaint allegation as stated. deficiencies.description: 87095.00(d) General Provisions: All children placed in a short-term residential therapeutic program have the right to be free from the use of restraints imposed as a means of coercion, discipline, convenience, or retaliation by staff. This requirement was not met by evidence by: Based on interviews conducted and a review of the incident report, the youth was restrained for behavior that did not present an imminent danger for injuring self or others which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. Staff was not following protocol outlined in the Program Statement by not allowing proximity.

narrative: The Department has investigated the complaint that Staff handled youth in a rough manner and staff threatened youth. C1 and S1 were by the front door entrance according to C2 and S1 tried placing C1 in a restraint. C1 confirmed S1 placed one hand on C1’s shoulder and turned C1 around. C1, C2, and C3 confirmed that C1 wasn’t threatened or handled roughly. C1 and C2 all confirmed C1 did not open the front door and was not pushed back into the home. C1, C2 and C3 confirmed that C1 was not chocked before or after the restrain. C1 stated “I thought, I was “I say stuff when I’m angry and don’t mean it”. C1 and C2 confirmed S1 had hands on C1 shoulders. C1 stated “I was not hurt”. The reporting party did not observe any bruises or marks on the minor and the minor did not report any after the incident. Based on LPA’s interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Exit interview conducted and no Title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was given to the Gloria Losh.

Contact with the administrator, Gloria Losh, was attempted via phone and communication was done only through Ms. Cash text messaging Ms. Losh who advised that this LPA could speak with Ms. Cash regarding the matter at hand. LPA is providing the Order to Individual of Immediate Exclusion to Ms. Cash and Ms. Losh and advised them accordingly. LPA toured the interior and exterior areas of the Program's physical plant, observing no deficiencies. There was only one other direct care staff present: Facility Manager Samantha Dewalt; the individual in question was not on the premises. No deficiencies were cited as a result of today's inspection.

No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, and appeal rights were left with Gloria Losh, Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt of these documents.

During the investigation LPA Ajaero interviewed the administrator and facility managers on 1/19/23 and learned that staff accompanied FY1 to the hospital and stayed with FY1 till the doctor directed the staff to leave. Staff was directed to leave because the hospital had a sit-in staff that remained with FY1. Staff stated that it was based on this reason that Staff presence was no longer required by the hospital. On 1/20/23, the Program Director provided the facility policy. The policy did not have any requirement that the staff should stay at the hospital with clients when they are taken for psychiatric treatment. LPA Ajaero was informed by LPA Michael Almaraz that during LPA’s visit on 2/9/23, FY1 appeared to be under the influence and could not be interviewed by the LPA. On 2/2/2023, Reporting Party stated that at the time of FY1’s evaluation, FY1 was attended to by a hospital sitter and that Hospitals in San Joaquin County have different protocols regarding if a legal guardian, referring to Facility staff, has to be present in the ER. Therefore, he could not firmly state whether the Staff was required or not. Additionally, reporting party stated that due to the emergent need for a mental health evaluation on the client, it was necessary to complete the evaluation without a legal guardian present. In addition, the Administrator denied any knowledge of any staff making inappropriate comments towards FY1. On 1/19/23, LPA interviewed the staff and they denied making the alleged statement. Lastly, LPA Ajaero made several attempts to interview FY1. FY1 is not available to respond to questions at this time because FY1 has been hospitalized with no definite day of release. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the Administrator, Gloria Losh.

narrative: On 5/24/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero conducted an unannounced visit to deliver the outcome of a case management visit initiated on 12/23/2022. On 12/20/2022, the Administrator reported an attempted suicide at the facility by C1. It was reported that at approximately 7:40 PM on 12/19/2022, Facility Manager (FM) Dewalt found C1 in the bathroom on the floor, where C1 hung herself using a towel rack. FM Dewalt called 911 as the Administrator Losh and Staff Scholes started CPR. C1 was transported to Saint Joseph’s hospital in Stockton then Life-flighted to Oakland Children’s Hospital. On 12/22/22, C1 was declared brain dead at which time her biomother made the decision to remove C1 from the ventilator. C1 was pronounced deceased on 12/22/22 at 10:30 pm. During the course of the investigation, LPA Ajaero requested a copy of the death report and Paul Houser, Assistant Chief of the Investigation’s Branch requested a copy of the Coroner’s Report. The Coroner’s Report did not list any drugs, alcohol, or suspicious activity that would contribute to the incident. The cause of death was listed as suicide by hanging. After a review of the interviews and documentation obtained but not limited to which includes the coroner’s report, death certificate, Needs and Services Plans, CFT Notes, Progress Reports, Suicide Prevention Checklist, Incident Reports and Mental Health Services provided, this agency has determined that there were no violations of Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations. No deficiencies were cited and no further follow up is required. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, and appeal rights were delivered to the Administrator

On 6/8/23, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPAs) Uchenna Ajaero and Monica Roberts made an unannounced annual random visit to the facility, Environmental Alternatives, Losh, an STRTP. LPAs met the facility Administrator and the inspection commenced. The facility has 3-bedrooms and 2-bathrooms. The current census is 6 youths. Criminal record clearances were reviewed, and the facility is in compliance. The incident reports, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to visit. The licensing fees were checked and it is current. The STRTP has a capacity of 6 residents. There are 12 staff members associated to the license and they are all currently working at the facility. LPAs reviewed 5 staff files. The files that were reviewed were complete and up to date. 5 youth's files were reviewed. The needs and services plan/Individual Program Plan, and quarterly reviews were complete and up to date. Immunization records were current. Medical consent forms were signed by authorized representative and are current. Personal rights, menu, license, emergency exit plan, house rules, and floor plan were posted prominently in the facility. 10:55 AM, the facility was inspected jointly with the Administrator of the Facility. The clients' bedrooms each had firm mattresses, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket, pillows and personal affects. The rooms were lighted and free of clutter. The common areas were bright enough and have couches and chairs to sit in, and a TV for the clients. The facility is in good repair and clean. There is a linen cabinet in the hallway with additional linen and towels for the bedrooms and the bathrooms. Client and staff files are in a locked cabinet. The garage is locked with an extra fridge with perishable food. The passageway from the front to the back of the bedrooms is unobstructed. The backyard has a locked pool area and the stairs is also locked away in the locked garage. LPAs observed enough perishable food for 3 days and non-perishable food for 5 days and for 6 clients. Smoke detectors were last checked on 6/2/23. There are 2 carbon monoxide detectors. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were in a locked cabinet under the kitchen sink and an additional cabinet in the laundry area.

Sharps were kept locked away in the kitchen. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 6 clients. The water temperature from the kitchen faucet was 108 degrees Fahrenheit. Medication disbursement on the MAR is reviewed and cross reconciled with the bubble packs. They are all stored in a locked cabinet. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in the medication cabinet and in the car. The car registration and insurance is current. The 2 SUVs, (facility transport) are neat and in good working order. LPAs checked the allowance on LIC 405. The youths receive a basic $10 and extra allowance is earned up to $80 every month at $2 daily. Exit interview was conducted and discussed with the Administrator. No citations were issued and a copy of this annual random inspection report was provided to the Administrator.

The Department investigated the complaint that staff lock the refrigerator. C1 stated there was a child lock placed on the middle drawer of the refrigerator in the kitchen. The refrigerator has three different ways to access opening; two top doors that swing open, a middle drawer that pulls out and a bottom drawer that pulls out and opens. During confidential interviews the administrator, three staff and three clients stated that they have never seen a lock on the refrigerator door in the kitchen. A former client and mother who works for CPS also stated that there was not a lock on the refrigerator door. LPA Shelton observed the refrigerator in the kitchen and to place a child lock on the middle drawer would not prevent the drawer from opening. Based on the investigation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. No Title 22 deficiencies were cited. LPA Shelton provided a copy of report along with appeal rights were discussed.

narrative:
On Monday, October 28th, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass made an unannounced case management inspection at the Facility. LPA met with the Administrator, Gloria Losh, who assisted with the inspection. During the course of an Unsubstantiated complaint investigation, it was revealed that the facility did not follow proper Removal and/or Transfer regulations, as well as their Plan of Operation procedures. C1 was placed at this Facility on 9/10/24, and then was given a 14-day notice of removal two days later, on 9/12/24. The youth was transferred to another Facility on 9/20/24, due to the staff not being able to keep her safe because of her frequent AWOL’ing and dangerous behaviors while AWOL’ing such as accepting rides from strangers. On 10/23/24, LPA requested the youth’s Child Family Team (CFT) meeting notes to discuss preservation of placement prior to being removed. Although Administrator Gloria Losh stated that C1’s therapist did do an Individual Crisis Intervention Management Plan (ICMP) and clinical assessments, there was no CFT meeting held. On 10/28/24. Gloria Losh stated they made numerous attempts to schedule a CFT meeting, but was unable to reach C1's County Social Worker, or the Social Worker's Supervisor. Page H-2 of the Facility’s Plan of Operation state, “It is always the goal of EA to maintain the youth’s placement when they are having difficulties with behavior or not meeting the Needs and Services Plan. Should a youth’s placement be in jeopardy, the EA Social Worker will request an urgent or immediate CFT meeting to discuss the issues and develop action plans with the CFT, the youth and family to prevent possible transition.” (Continued on LIC 809-C).

The Facility’s Plan of Operation also states that, ‘EA has adopted a removal and discharge procedure in accordance with… Section 87068.4 of Community Care Licensing regulations’. Section 87068.4(e)(1)(E) states, ‘Upon a concern that the facility cannot meet the needs of the child or when there is an indication that the placement may be disrupted, the licensee shall: Make a reasonable and good faith effort to engage in the development and implementation of placement preservation strategies in collaboration with the county placing agency and in consultation with the Child and Family Team’. On this date, the Agency is being cited for a violation of the Foster Family Agency Interim Licensing Standards, Version 6, Section 87068.4, Removal and/or Transfer Procedures. See 809-D page. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator, Gloria Losh. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given.

deficiencies.description:
Upon a concern that the facility cannot meet the needs of the child...the licensee shall: Make a reasonable... effort to engage in the... implementation of placement preservation strategies...with the county placing agency and in consultation with the Child and Family Team. This was not met as evidenced by:

The Administrator stated that there was no CFT meeting held prior to the child being issued a 14-day removal notice, two days after placement.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: By 11/25/24, the Administrator will retrain  all staff involved in the removal process, on Removal and/or Transfer regulations, as well as retrain on the Transfer policies in the Facility's Plan of Operations. Administrator will email LPA an attendance sheet, as well as what topics were covered.

narrative: It was alleged that staff members S1, S2, and S4 pushed the child, pulled her by her arm, and threw a water bottle at her. Confidential interviews revealed that during the child’s two week stay, she had many physical altercations with another youth in care, and that staff had put hands on her once when attempting to prevent a physical fight between clients. An Incident Report (IR) was sent in by the facility on 9/12/24 describing an incident where S4 held C1’s wrists for less than 20 seconds when she was going in to beat up another client and was also swinging at the staff member. Confidential interviews with staff revealed that C1 was threatening to hit C2 with a water bottle, so staff collected all water bottles in the facility, and locked them up to prevent this from happening. In an interview with C1, when asked about an incident with a water bottle, the youth stated that she was the one who tried to, “hit C2 upside the head with a water bottle”. C1 stated, on another occasion, S1 told her to ‘get out of the way’ and pushed her. C1 stated S3 was a witness. S1 stated, no staff had ever pushed C1, and S3 stated she never saw anyone push C1 either, resulting in conflicting information. This Department has investigated the complaint alleging that the minor is being physically abused in care. We have found that the complaint is Unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator, Gloria Losh. A copy of this report, and appeal rights were given.

deficiencies.title:
Modifications to The Needs And Services Plan

(a) The needs and services plan as described Sections 87068.2 and 87068.22, shall be updated at least every 30 days to determine the following

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with staff Gloria Losh, Administrator, who assisted LPA with the inspection. CCL received an incident report dated 03/01/2025, sent to CCL on 03/03/2025. This Case Management was opened at the facility on 03/19/2025. LPA reviewed this incident by conducting confidential interviews with a child involved and the Administrator on 03/19/2025. LPA conducted a record review on 03/24/2025 of documents obtained on 03/19/2025. Based on the interviews and the record review, LPA found although the incident happened, staff provided appropriate supervision, as confirmed by the child. This case management is now closed, no further action necessary. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.

On 06/11/2025, at 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie met with Gloria Losh, Administrator to continue unannounced/random Annual inspection. Ms. Losh stated that three staff are present and all clients are at summer intercession (school). LPA Goldie conducted 2 staff (S4 and S5) and 5 youth interviews C1, C2, C3, C5 and C6. No deficiencies were observed. The Annual inspection is complete. An exit interview was conducted with Ms. Losh and a copy of the report was provided to the facility.

Confidential interviews reported that C1, C2, & C3 was in cohesion attempting to get S4 in trouble. Other confidential interviews reported that C2 was upset with S4 for writing up C2 and holding C2 accountable. Confidential witnesses informed LPA that C4, C5, C6, and C7 haven’t had any unprofessional relationships with staff, staff touching them inappropriately, or staff attempting to have unprofessional relationships with them. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff (S4) is providing illegal items to minors (C1, C2, & C3) while in care; more specifically, cigarettes and alcohol. Confidential witnesses revealed that S4 and other staff have not given, C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7 any alcohol or cigarettes. Confidential interviews informed LPA that staff has never seen other staff giving clients alcohol or cigarettes. Multiple confidential interviews reported that C4, C5, C6, and C7 denied the allegation of staff providing any alcohol or cigarettes to them. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff’s conduct presents a risk to minors (C1, C2, & C3) in care and staff is providing illegal items to minors (C1, C2, & C3) while in care, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. narrative:
On the above date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Jazmond Harris and Val Wilson conducted an annual required inspection. LPAs met with Administrator, Steven Lechuga. LPAs began a physical plant inspection at 9:30 AM and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment, books, and games were observed for client’s recreation time. All facility smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in staff office. Chemicals/poisons and sharp objects are locked and stored in the staff office. First Aid Kits are also stored in the staff office and are complete. Licensee has provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was deemed safe. The facility has a building in the rear, which has three rooms and a bathroom area. The building is not utilized to currently house clients. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. The facility has a waiver on file to use the cameras and are meeting the terms and conditions. Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with a wrought iron exterior. The enclosure was measured to be over 5 feet tall, with a self-latching gate that swings outward. Per Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Administrator is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one social worker, one therapist, four facility managers, and four direct care staff. Licensee has obtained National

Accreditation through Council On Accreditation. The Accreditation is valid through February 29, 2024. Annual Fees are current. LPAs reviewed five client files. All required documents were present in the files with required dates and signatures. LPAs also reviewed medication logs, JV-220s, and medication. Client #1 and Client #4's needs and service plan will be sent to LPA Harris for review at a later time. Personnel files are maintained off-site at the corporate office in Baldwin Park, but the facility did have employee documents available. LPAs reviewed six staff files. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. LPAs reviewed the staff's first Aid/CPR certificates and proof of TB tests LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388, law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. Based upon the inspection of facility records and observation, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of the report will be provided to the facility.

On January 26, 2024 at 11:00 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, conducted a visit at Ettie Lee- Robertson Memorial Home, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Angelita Arellano, Facility Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a confidential interview with a client for an investigation. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the this report was provided to facility representative.

Additionally, a former employee staff #1 (S1) could not be reached for comment after multiple attempts made by the Investigator for an interview. On December 14, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging S1 is providing alcohol to minors while in care, S1 is providing marijuana to the minors while in care, S1 is providing nicotine products to the minors while in care, and minors provided S1 their allowance to buy nicotine products. During the investigation there was no corroborating evidence to support the allegations. Although CCL received detailed information that S1 provided alcohol, marijuana, and nicotine products to clients in care during transportation services that were facilitated by S1, and that clients provided S1 with their allowances to buy these products. The information provided to the Investigator regarding these allegations was inconsistent. Confidential interviews deny the allegations while another confidential interview maintains that the allegations involving S1 are true. Confidential interviews further reported that facility staff inquired about these allegations with S1 prior to resignation and the allegations were denied. A confidential interview reported that when reviewing receipts of the client’s allowances there was nothing suspicious observed that would indicate that allowances were spent on alcohol, marijuana, or nicotine products. There were no other known witnesses to the allegations and S1 could not be reached for comment. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegations that staff is providing alcohol to minors while in care, staff is providing marijuana to the minors while in care, staff is providing nicotine products to the minors while in care, and minors provided a staff member their allowance to buy nicotine products, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager, Angelita Arellano.

Confidential interviews reported that clients missed their medical or dentist appointments if clients refuse to attend. Some staff may reschedule when they are at the doctor’s office if the clients refuse to wait to be seen by the doctor due to getting tired of waiting. The facility manager and designated staff schedule the medical appointments for the clients. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was unable to recall if C1 missed any schedule medical or dental appointments. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff did not take client (C1) to medical appointments while in care, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. On December 28, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) LPA Sarah Smith arrived at the facility and met with Patrick Williams, Facility Administrator regarding an issue that arose when obtaining information regarding an incident involving client 7 (C7) and Facility Administrator (FA). LPA Smith was informed that on December 02, 2020, C7 became aggressive and upset with FA. It was disclosed that FA was forced to place C7 in a one-person floor restraint due to C7 becoming physically aggressive with FA. FA was informed that a one-person restraint is an improper restraint. FA stated that he had restraint training through Pro-Act. LPA reviewed the Ettie Lee Youth and Family Services approved Plan of Operation, which revealed the facility will maintain accordance with ProAct as its Emergency Intervention training curriculum. During this incident, FA did not follow PRO Act principles. Based on information obtained, Facility is cited for a violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, regulation 80022(k): Plan of Operation. Based on interviews and record review the facility failed to follow the approved Plan of Operation when FA failed to follow the PRO ACT principles on 12/02/2020. A copy of this report, and the appeal rights were discussed, printed and given to facility representative.

confidential interviews revealed that there was no evidence to prove the allegation did occurred. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff (S4) threaten minor (C1) in care.
