investigation_findings: 13On December 28, 2021 at 11:35 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cheraki Davis met with Patrick Williams, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Administrator to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegations. On 09/22/2021 at 11:25am, LPA conducted a safety inspection and no immediate safety hazards were observed. The investigation was conducted by Special Investigator Brittany Hudec of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Bureau. Investigation included interviews with clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, & C7), staff (S1, S2, S3, & S4), and Program Manager. Incident report was reviewed. LPA was unsuccessful with interviewing client 6 (C6) due to C6 not currently residing at the facility. On September 20, 2021, Community Care Licensing received an allegation which stated staff (S3) inappropriately touched minor (C1 & C5) while in care. Confidential interviews deny that there was any inappropriately touching in the home while other confidential information received stated that the inappropriately touching occurred in the home when S3 woke C1 and C5 up in the morning. Other confidential interviews reported that C1 and C5 denied being touched on their private parts. Additional

narrative:
in a timely manner, Lack of supervision resulting in minors smoke marijuana on the premises, and Facility staff does not safeguard minors’ belongings. Confidential interviews revealed that C7 refused medical attention on several occasions. Confidential interviews revealed C7 did request medical attention, but when the appointments would come the C7 often refused to go. LPA Smith could not prove that on all occasions the client requested medical attention that they refused to go. Confidential interviews revealed that there was an incident where C7 and Staff 1 were in an altercation. Confidential interviews disclosed that C7 was offered medical attention but LPA was unable to interview C7 to obtain specific details regarding the allegation. Regarding the allegation that minors are smoking on facility grounds due to lack of supervision, confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff does address any appearance of the clients smoking. Confidential interviews revealed that the procedure to follow if a client is smoking is to ask them to put it out, and if the client refuses then the staff monitors the client to ensure that they are not in any immediate danger. Confidential interviews of the clients revealed that the staff does not allow the clients to smoke at the facility while other confidential interviews revealed that the clients in care smoke at the facility without being redirected. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Regarding the allegation that staff does not safeguard (Client 1) belongings, confidential interviews revealed that inventory is taken upon client entry into the facility. Documentation showed that clients in care had property stolen and was reimbursed for the items. It was not clear whether the items were kept in a manner that was appropriate. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Regarding the allegation that staff mismanages minors’ medication, during the course of the investigation LPA received documentation showing that C7 did receive medication according to the prescribed manner. No evidence was collected to support that C7 received medications with adverse interactions. C7 could not be interviewed to gain specific details about this allegation. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that Staff did not seek medical attention for minor in a timely manner, Lack of supervision resulting in minors smoke marijuana on the premises, Facility staff does not safeguard minors’ belongings, and Staff mismanages minors’ medication may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. ------continued on the next page-----

A copy of this report and Appeals Rights were provided and explained to Facility Administrator Williams.

On 11/18/2021, Community Care Licensing received allegations that staff are not reporting incidents accurately, staff engaged in a physical altercation with minor, facility is in disrepair, and facility poses a safety hazard to minors in care (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, & C7). Confidential interviews revealed that there was a Serious Incident Report involving Law Enforcement dated 12/02/2020 that was submitted as a “normal” notification and left out details regarding what actually occurred. Consistent confidential information received revealed that the serious incident report was not reported accurately and did not include pertinent details of the incident. Confidential interviews revealed that a staff member did engage in an altercation with a client in care (C7) which lead to the staff member (S1) performing a one-person restraint on C7. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 placed C7 in a restraint after being physically attacked by C7. Consistent confidential interviews revealed that the roof of the facility was leaking in the game room. During the health and safety inspection on 10/26/2021, LPA noted that the walls in bedrooms two and three needed to be painted because there were areas where the paint is peeling. In addition, the side door to the facility had a piece of cloth in it to prevent the facility alarm from going off when the wind blew. LPA observation and confidential interviews revealed that the outside weight benches had no locks to hold the weights in place while the clients exercised. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegations of staff are not reporting incidents accurately, staff engaged in a physical altercation with minor, facility is in disrepair, and facility posed a safety hazard to minors in care (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, & C7) are substantiated which poses a health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care. Facility is cited for violations of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) , Version 3.1, 87072(d)(11) Personal Rights and (ILS) 87088.3 Outdoor Activity Equipment in addition to California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80012(a) False Claims and 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were given and explained to Patrick Williams, Facility Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On December 28, 2021 at 2:30 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Sarah Smith, conducted an in person inspection with Patrick Wiilliams, Facility Administrato of Ettie Lee Home- Fontana Home to discuss the findings for the above stated allegations. On 10/26/2021 at 9:40 p.m., LPA conducted a health and safety inspection and safety concerns observed are being addressed in a case management. The above allegations involved clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, C7). During the course of investigating the allegation, LPA Smith conducted confidential interviews with clients (C2, C4, C5) and staff (S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, and S6) . Client 1 (C1), Client 3 (C3), and Client 6 (C6) refused to be interviewed. LPA attempted to interview C7, however, C7 no longer resides at the facility and current whereabouts are unknown at this time. LPA reviewed reports and the records for the STRTP, staff, and clients. --------continued on the next page--------

deficiencies.description:
87072(d)(11) Personal Rights. (11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse,... intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature…
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, documentation, and observations, the licensee did not ensure C7 free of physical abuse when staff engaged in a physical altercation with client. This posed an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff will be retrained on proper emergency intervention and deescalation techniques to ensure Pro-Act procedures are followed. Proof of this training will be emailed to LPA by 01/05/2022.

deficiencies.description: 80012(a) False Claims (a) No licensee, officer, or employee of a licensee shall make or disseminate any false or misleading statement regarding the facility or any of the services provided by the facility This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documentation, the licensee did not accurately report incidents involving Law Enforcement. This posed an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff will be retrained on the correct way to create and submit a serious incident report. Proof of this training will be emailed to LPA by 01/12/2022.

deficiencies.description:
87088.3 OUTDOOR ACTIVITY EQUIPMENT (a) Outdoor activity equipment… (1) Equipment shall be maintained in a safe condition free of sharp, loose, or pointed parts.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and observation the licensee did not ensure that the outside weight equipment was usd in a safe condition. This posed a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Locks for the outside weight benches will be purchased. Facility Adminstrator will submit photo of locks on outside weight benches by 12/29/2021

deficiencies.description:
80087(a) Buildings and Grounds.  The facility shall be kept clean, sanitary and in good repair at all times. 
This requirement was not met as ecidenced by: Based on observations, interviews, and documentation the licesee did not ensure that the facility was in good repair at all times. This posed a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights Risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The roof of the facility will be repaired. Facility Administrator will submit proof of supplies purchased to repair roof by 12/29/2021.

narrative: during interviews. Confidential interviews denied allegations that staff have ever hit, mistreated, denied food or ever forced any client to eat food against their religious beliefs. According to confidential information staff always accommodate or offer substitutions whenever a client does not want to or prefers to eat something else than what is being offered. Confidential interviews also denied that any staff have ever come to work impaired or inappropriately touched or crossed personal boundaries with any of the clients, and that it is sometimes the clients who have to be redirected after invading staff’s personal space. According to confidential interviews, staff always follow all COVID 19 safety protocols and have never offered or provided drugs or alcohol to any of the clients in care. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that these allegations had occurred. There were no other known witnessed to these allegations. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff come to work impaired, force clients to eat food against religious preferences, that staff hit, inappropriately touch, threaten and deny youth food, encourage youth to fight, do not treat youth with dignity and respect, do not follow COVID 19 safety protocols, do not provide a safe environment for youth in care, as well as that youth have access to drugs and alcohol and that staff supply youth with drugs and alcohol, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena met with Administrator, Patrick Williams to issue the findings for the above stated allegations. An investigation was conducted by LPAs Sarah Smith and Daniel Mena regarding allegations. LPA Smith conducted an investigation at the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on January 31, 2022 at 1:35pm and on June 06, 2022 at 12:30pm. No immediate hazards noted. LPAs Smith and Mena interviewed Six Staff (S1, S2, S3, S4. S5 & S6), and five clients (C1, C2, C3, C4 & C5), as well as reviewed client and facility records. Community Care Licensing received information on January 25, 2022 alleging that facility staff come to work impaired, force clients to eat food against religious preferences, that staff hit, inappropriately touch, threaten and deny youth food, encourage youth to fight, do not treat youth with dignity and respect, do not follow COVID 19 safety protocols, as well as do not provide a safe environment for youth in care. Allegation also claimed that youth have access to drugs and alcohol and that staff supply youth with drugs and alcohol. Information obtained in confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegations with a preponderance of evidence. LPAs Smith and Mena obtained conflicting information

narrative:
On April 4, 2023, at 09:27 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection and met with Angie Custodio, Facility Manager. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) on July 31, 2018. LPA began a physical plant inspection at 09:34 AM and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment, pool table, basketball court, swimming pool and games were observed for client’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in staff office. Chemicals/poisons and sharp objects are locked and stored in the staff office and staff restroom. First Aid Kits are also stored in the staff office and are complete. Licensee has provisions for contraceptives to be held individually by clients. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was deemed safe and measured at 106.7, 105.7- and 105.3-degrees Fahrenheit. Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with a wrought iron fence. The enclosure was measured to be over 5 feet tall, with a self-latching gate that swings outward. Per Facility Manager, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Continued on LIC 809-c

Administrator, Patrick Williams is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs 5 facility managers, 7 direct care staff, and a therapist. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation, The Accreditation is valid through February 29, 2024. Annual Fees are current. Licensee has mental health approval from July 25, 2022 until July 25, 2023. LPA reviewed five personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Personnel files are maintained off-site in a locked cabinet in staff corporate office in Baldwin Park, but documents were available for review. CPR/First Aid Certificates were observed and were valid. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. No deficiencies were found during this inspection. LPA reviewed five client files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Client files are maintained in a locked cabinet inside staff office (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated April 4, 2023) were also completed. Per review, four out of five client file was missing signed copies of the facility's policy and procedures regarding removal/transfer, discipline, and complaint. Per ILS 87070 (c) If it is determined that the facility can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs, the following additional information shall be maintained in the child's record: (2) Signed copies of the facility's policies and procedures regarding the child's removal and/or transfer; discipline; and complaints. LPA interviewed two staffs and one client, three clients were in the facility at the time, however, one of sleeping and the other was in therapy session. The client interviewed deemed that their needs were being met and they feel safe and secure in the facility. Staffs and client have no issues or concerns regarding the facility. Based upon the inspection of facility records and interviews with staff and clients, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was discussed and will be provided to Facility Manager, Angie Custodio.

On June 4, 2020 at 1:20 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Jazmond Harris and Val Wilson arrived at Ettie Lee Homes-Diamond L. Ranch to complete an annual required inspection. LPA was met at the facility by Facility Manager, Katey Garcia. There were two staff members and four clients present at the time of the inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 3:00 PM, a physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: The facility consists of five bedrooms, five bathrooms, a dining area, living room, kitchen, pantry, staff office, administrator office, game room, therapy room, maintenance office that is utilized for storage, storage room, conference room, recreation room and laundry room. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Pool tables, games, and gym equipment were observed for client’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains more than two days’ supply of perishable and seven days non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in staff office. Individual client beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All bedrooms have individual beds, closet space, and drawer space for each client. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured and deemed to be safe. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Administrator, April Hanley is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one social worker, one therapist, five facility managers and six direct care staff. Licensee has

obtained National Accreditation through Council on Accreditation (COA). The Accreditation is valid through 02/29/2024. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0. LPAs reviewed five client files. All required documents were present in the files with required dates and signatures. Client #1 and Client #2's (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated June 4, 2021, needs and service plans were not up to date. LPA Harris requested that the current needs and service plan be sent to LPA Harris at the earliest convenience. Currently there are no clients on medication. LPAs reviewed five staff files. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. LPAs reviewed the staff's first Aid/CPR certificates and proof of TB tests. LPAs conducted staff and client interviews. Clients indicated that their basic needs are being met at the facility and core services being provided as well. Staff interviews stated there were no issues or concerns. LPA discussed the following with Facility Manager: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388, law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. Based upon the inspection of facility records and observation, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of the report will be provided to the facility.

On August 22, 2022, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging that staff speaks inappropriately to minors. Confidential interviews stated that no staff member at the STRTP has made any threats of killing a client. Confidential interviews did, however, admit that there was an incident that occurred involving S4 and Client 4 (C4). Confidential interviews further stated that S4 called “C4 White trash” and words were exchange between the staff member and C4. Confidential interviews also stated that the STRTP has a zero tolerance for such behaviors and have acted on those staff members behaviors. Other confidential interviews reported not witnessing staff members being inappropriate to clients. During record review LPA Urena found that the incident involving C4, and a S4 was documented by the STRTP. The documents that were collected are dated July 25, 2022, and July 26, 2022. All documents indicate that S4 did engage and exhibited inappropriate behaviors which resulted in S4 calling C4 “White trash”. Based on confidential interviews and file reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that S4 speaks inappropriately to C4 is supported and proven by evidence. The facility is cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Treatment Facility (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards Section 87072(c)(10) PERSONAL RIGHTS. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager, Sydney Casillas

On August 22, 2022, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging that the facility does not meet minors' dietary needs. More specifically, staff lock the pantry and do not provide bread or fruit to C1 after 8:30 PM. LPA obtained conflicting statements throughout the investigation. Confidential interviews revealed that the staff prepares three meals per day and snacks between each meal. Confidential interviews revealed that the pantry closes at 8:30 PM and the bread is locked, however, the clients are provided a couple of options; they can have the left-over food from that day or they can make a sandwich and the staff will provide the clients with the ingredients. Other confidential interviews revealed that the left-over food cooked by staff was left out and exposed to flies therefore some clients refused to eat the food. Confidential interviews revealed that the clients have complained about only having sandwiches for a late-night snack and that C1 wants special food and if C1 did not get what C1 wanted C1 ended up breaking into the pantry at the facility. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that the facility is not meeting minors’ dietary needs, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager, Sydney Casillas
investigation_findings: 13On November 10, 2022, at 12:57 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena met with Ettie Lee Diamond L. Ranch Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Facility Manager Sydney, Casillas to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. On August 29, 2022, at 8:45 A.M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena initiated the investigation at the STRTP. LPA Urena conducted a Health and Safety inspection, and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Additionally, LPA Urena interviewed three staff (S1 – S3) and 3 clients (C1-C3). At 11:30 A.M., LPA Urena conducted a collateral interview, and on November 9, 2022, LPA Urena interviewed a County Social Worker (CSW). LPA Urena attempted to conduct three additional interviews however Client 4 (C4) refused an interview, Client 6 (C6) could not be located for an interview, and Staff 4(S4) was terminated from employment, and could not be reached for an interview.

deficiencies.description:
PERSONAL RIGHTS 87072(c) The licensee shall ensure that each child… in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, …(10) To be accorded dignity in *their* personal relationships with staff and other persons.
This requirement has not been met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and documents reviewed, S4 called C1 “white trash.”  This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: On August 31, 2022, S4 was terminated from employment due to ongoing behaviors. Facility Manager stated that she would email LPA Urena a copy of staff training by Nov 15, 2022.

narrative:
On March 14, 2023 at 09:03 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Sarah Lo arrived unannounced at Ettie Lee Homes-Diamond L. Ranch to complete an annual required inspection. LPA was met at the facility by Administrator, April Valdepena-Hanley. There were two staff members, and six clients present at the time of the inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 09:07 AM, a physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: The facility consists of five bedrooms, five bathrooms, a dining area, living room, kitchen, pantry, staff office, administrator office, game room, therapy room, maintenance office that is utilized for storage, storage room, conference room, recreation room and laundry room. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Basketball court, games and gym equipment were observed for client’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains more than two days supply of perishable and seven days non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in staff office. Individual client beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All bedrooms have individual beds, closet space, and drawer space for each client. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms were measured (105.4, 112.4, 113.9 and 110.6) and deemed to be clean and safe. Per Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. (Continues on LIC 809-C)

Administrator, April Valdepena-Hanley is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one social worker, one therapist, five Facility Managers and five Residential Counselors. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through Council on Accreditation (COA). The Accreditation is valid through 02/29/2024. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0. LPA reviewed five client files. All required documents were present in the files with required dates and signatures. Client #2 (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated March 14, 2023, is missing the signed copies of policy and procedure for the removal/transfer, discipline and complaints. Per ILS 87070 (c) If it is determined that the facility can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs, the following additional information shall be maintained in the child's record: (2) Signed copies of the facility's policies and procedures regarding the child's removal and/or transfer; discipline; and complaints. Client #1-#5 (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated March 14, 2023, is missing Tuberculosis (TB) test result, per Administrator, the client’s refused getting the TB test at the initial health screening. Administrator was told will need to provide proof with client’s signature to show client refused to get a TB test. Per CCR 80069 (c) The medical assessment shall include the following: (1) The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. LPA conducted three staff and three client interviews. The clients indicated that their basic needs are being met at the facility and core services being provided as well. The staff interviews stated there were no issues or concerns. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of the this report (LIC 809 and LIC 809-C) and appeals right is provided to the Administrator, April Valdepena-Hanley.

resulting in inappropriate interactions between minors (Child #1 (C1), C2, and C3) in care. Specifically, it was reported during C1’s stay at the facility C1 had participated in a relationship with another resident. Record review revealed on May 13, 2017 C1, C2, and C3 were observed participating in a sexually related incident. Record review also revealed in May of 2017, S1 received disciplinary action related to lack of supervision regarding this incident. Record review further revealed communication from ADM discussing the incident with C1, C2, C3 and Staff. Confidential interviews revealed staff was disciplined for lack of supervision. Based on record review, confidential witness statements, the allegation of lack of supervision resulting in inappropriate interactions between minors in care is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s needs. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was discussed and emailed to Facility Manager, Gloria Thomas for signature. Original signature will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On November 13, 2020 at 10:34 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Father’s Heart Ranch Facility Manager, Gloria Thomas, via tele-inspection due to COVID-19 Public Health Emergency to deliver the finding for the above stated allegation. The investigation included a review of facility and one of three foster youth records. An inspection of the facility was conducted by LPA L. Valenzuela on February 27, 2020. LPA N. Strickland conducted interviews with two of three County Social Worker’s (CSW #1, CSW #2), two of three foster children (Child #2 (C2) and Child #3 (C3), three of four staff members (Staff #1 (S1), Staff #2 (S2), Staff #4 (S4) who worked for the facility at the time of the incident leading to the above allegation, and facility administrator (ADM). Two of three confidential witnesses did not respond to LPA's telephone and written request to interview, therefore were not interviewed. On February 26, 2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation of lack of supervision ***CONTINUED ON PAGE 2.****

deficiencies.description:
Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s needs 

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and confidential witness statements, the facility did not ensure  supervision met the needs of Child #1 (C1), Child #2 (C2) and Child #3 (C3) which posed a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will hold a re-training for staff regarding appropriate supervision by POC date of 11/30/2020.  A copy of training outline and attendees will be submitted to LPA via email by POC due date.

narrative: Confidential interviews revealed the injury was observed on January 11, 2021 around 6 pm when S1 was assisting C1 with showering. Confidential interviews and record review revealed on January 10, 2021 around 8 pm, S2 assisted C1 with showering and S2 did not observe any marks or injuries to C1. Additional confidential interviews and record review revealed the night of January 10, 2021, C1 did not sleep well and was up most of the night so the morning of January 11, 2021, C1 did not want to get up for school. Confidential interviews and record review revealed around 8:30-8:45 am, S3 and S6 were in C1’s bedroom trying to get C1 to get up for school. Record review and confidential interviews revealed C1 was combative by kicking and hitting S3 and S6 during this time. Confidential interviews with S3 and S6 revealed they did not have to use physical force to get C1 out of bed but used verbal encouragement. Other confidential interviews revealed there was yelling and clapping heard from C1’s bedroom while S3 and S6 were trying to get C1 out of bed. Confidential interviews revealed C1 eventually got up and went to the restroom where S3 and S6 assisted C1 with changing. Confidential interviews indicated S3 and S6 did not observe any marks or injuries to C1 at that time. Confidential interviews also indicated that after C1 changed and before going to school, C1 was jumping on the beds and couch in the facility as well as climbing over C1’s dresser in C1’s bedroom. Confidential interviews revealed at 9:00 am C1 then went to school at the facility campus cafeteria. Confidential interviews revealed around 9:30 am, S5 took C1 to the restroom and noticed a scratch and redness on C1’s upper thigh. Other confidential interviews revealed no one was sure how C1 obtained the injury and no incidents resulting in an injury to C1 had been observed. Further confidential interviews revealed C1 is an active boy and plays on the swings and trampoline often. Further interviews revealed no staff had been observed to physically restrain or hold C1 in any way. AD also stated she checked the cameras at the facility and did not observe C1 to have had any incidents resulting in an injury that day. AD stated it was also a possibility the injury may have been from the desk at school. Additionally, CSW had no concerns of C1’s care in the facility and had not observed any prior injuries to C1. Based on confidential interviews and record review, C1 did sustain an unexplained injury while in care. However, the Department could not determine if the injury occurred due to physical abuse, lack of supervision, or while child was playing. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and emailed to Facility Manager Gloria Thomas for signature. Signed reports will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On February 12, 2021 at 1:30 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jessica Rubio made contact with Father’s Heart Ranch, Facility Manager Gloria Thomas and Office Manager Sylvia Luna via Facetime video due to COVID-19, to discuss the investigative finding of the allegation listed above. On January 20, 2021 at 12:20 pm, LPA Rubio conducted a safety tele-inspection of the facility. No safety hazards were observed and no deficiencies were cited. During the investigation, confidential interviews were conducted with Administrator (AD), staff 1 through 6 (S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6) and county social worker of C1 (CSW). An interview with client #1 (C1) was attempted however was not completed due to C1 being nonverbal. LPA Rubio obtained copies of the client and staff rosters, the needs and services plan and daily report for C1. On January 12, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging youth sustained unexplained injuries while in care; specifically that C1 sustained an injury on C1’s upper left thigh appearing to be a scratch with redness or bruising behind it. (Continued on LIC 9099-C)

narrative:
On the above date at 12:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rubio conducted an annual tele-inspection. LPA met with Administrator Christina Torres via Google Duo video. The facility consists of four separate, one-story client housing units with (3) bedrooms, (1) bathroom, living room and kitchen area in each. Each housing unit also has a separate laundry area. The facility has a cafeteria, three buildings consisting of staff and therapy offices, a game room and an employee residence. At 12:20 pm, a physical plant tele-inspection was completed with Administrator and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors are hard wired and in working order. Carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in working order; fire extinguishers are in each unit and properly charged and serviced as of July 2020. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are double locked and centrally stored in the hallway closet of each housing unit. Licensee has provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. All individual twin beds in each client house were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms of each unit were measured as follows: C house 117 degrees, D house 120 degrees, F House 106 degrees, G House 117 degrees. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. Per Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Administrator Christina Torres is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interview. (Continued on LIC 809-C)

Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs four social workers, seven facility managers and 35 direct care staff as well as two volunteers that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Administrator verified the Board of Directors are meeting quarterly. Licensing fees have been paid and there is no outstanding balance. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. Client files are maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in a staff office in the J building as well as in a locked cabinet in each house and on a computer system. Personnel files are maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in an office in the I building and also on the computer system. Due to the virtual inspection and time constraints, client and personnel files will be reviewed at a later date. LPA requested Administrator to deliver (5) staff files and (5) staff files to LPA via email or hard copies. No deficiencies were cited during time of inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was reviewed and emailed to Administrator Christina Torres for signature.

On the above date at 1:10 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rubio met with Father’s Heart Ranch (STRTP) Administrator Christina Torres via Google Duo (due to COVID-19) for the continuation of the annual inspection. LPA received client and staff files from the STRTP for review. A sample of five client files were reviewed. All client files reviewed were complete however five of five client’s (C1, C2, C3, C4 & C5) needs and services plans were missing the signature of their authorized representative. A Technical Assistance Advisory Note (TA) will be issued. A sample of five personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. All personnel files were complete. All staff reviewed met the training requirements with the exception of one staff (S4). S4 did not meet the required 40 hours of annual training. Technical Assistance Advisory Note (TA) will be issued. The STRTP also provided the following updated records: LIC 500, LIC 308, fire clearance granted 5/13/2020, evidence of CARF Accreditation extension through 4/30/2021, Medi-Cal Certification effective 7/18/2020 and Mental Health Program Approval effective 6/2/2020. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, TA notes, LIC 858, LIC 859, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and emailed to Administrator Christina Torres for signature.

Interviews and record review revealed approximately 12-13 clients attend virtual schooling in the STRTP cafe through five different schools. Five clients attend the same school as C1 however do not have the same teacher. Confidential interviews and record review revealed clients have different schedules but a majority of the clients attend school Monday through Friday between 8:30 am and 8:45 am and work until approximately 2 to 3 pm. Interviews and record review revealed that day shift staff schedules are from 6 am to 3 pm and the same staff are in the cafe with clients for the whole school day. Record review revealed approximately 20 messages sent from ST between August 2020 through February 2021 indicating students (referring to C1 as well as other non-client students) were not logged in for small groups or ST was waiting for students (referring to C1 and other non-client students) to join. Record review revealed these messages were all sent between 1:20 pm and 1:30 pm. Confidential interviews revealed these messages were sent out if students were not yet logged back in after lunch and as a reminder. Additional confidential interviews revealed C1 would come back from lunch around 1:30 pm and would join small groups making it possible for the messages to go out before C1 joined. Confidential interviews revealed C1 had no attendance issues during small groups with RT from 1:30 pm to 2:00 pm, although noted the small groups did start at 1:15 pm. Interviews revealed C1 was returning late from lunch due to all clients being lined up to return to the cafe together. Review of C1’s report card showed 59 days present and 2 days absent in the first trimester and showed 61 days present and 0 days absent in the second trimester. Confidential interviews revealed attendance is taken in the morning and not again in the afternoons but is monitored by ST in the afternoons. Confidential interviews revealed that there have been times C1 has missed afternoon class or logged off early and record review revealed that two messages were sent indicating C1 not being logged on after 2 pm. Interviews revealed after 2 pm to approximately 3:30 pm is independent work time for C1. Interviews revealed that due to clients’ disruptive and dangerous behaviors in the afternoon AD asked SP that students from C1’s school be able to log off of school at 2 pm. Confidential interviews revealed that all clients in virtual schooling were logged off at 2 pm to manage clients’ disruptive behaviors for approximately 3-4 weeks from February to March 2021. Other interviews revealed only students that were completed with their school work were logged off at 2 pm while others stayed until 3 or 3:30 pm to complete work. Further confidential interviews revealed C1 had missed some afternoon class due to C1 saying C1 was finished with school and C1 also made it appear C1 had no further work by deleting it or rushing through it. (Continued)

Confidential interviews also revealed in the first trimester of virtual schooling it was difficult to keep track of all the client’s differing schedules however staff are in communication with clients’ teachers when issues arise. Based on record review, confidential interviews and conflicting statements of what occurred, the allegation facility staff do not ensure that youths attend school may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and emailed to Administrator Christina Torres for signature. Signed reports will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On April 29, 2021 at 10:25 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jessica Rubio made contact with Father’s Heart Ranch, Administrator (AD) Christina Torres via Google Duo video due to COVID-19, to discuss the investigative finding of the allegation listed above. On March 22, 2021 at 1:34 pm, LPA Rubio conducted a safety tele-inspection of the facility. No safety hazards were observed and no deficiencies were cited. During the investigation, confidential interviews were conducted with three clients (C1, C2, C3) attending virtual schooling on the STRTP campus, Administrator (AD), staff 1 through 3 (S1, S2, S3), school teacher of C1 (ST), resource teacher of C1 (RT) and school principal for the school C1 attends. LPA Rubio obtained copies of the client and staff rosters as well as the needs and services plan, individual education plan and report card for C1. On March 18, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging facility staff do not ensure that youths attend school; specifically, that C1 is missing a significant amount of virtual schooling in the afternoon due to clients being pulled away from schooling due to staff shift changes. (Continued)

narrative: An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheraki Davis and Licensing Program Manager Natasha Dunlap on 07/26/2021 at 10:13 AM. During the inspection, LPA Davis and LPM Dunlap met with Christina Torres, Administrator/Facility Director and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 10 out of 22 child’s psychotropic records on site at the facility at 2:01 PM. During the review of children’s records, LPA Davis and LPM Dunlap observed two out of 10 children (C1 & C2) did not have a current JV 220 and JV 223. The JV 220 and JV 223 expired for C1 and C2. During the review of children’s records, LPA Davis and LPM Dunlap observed eight out of 10 children (C3-C10) Needs and Services Plan were not signed by the child’s Social Worker. A LIC 9102 Advisory Note were issued. LPA reviewed four staff personnel files on site at the facility at 11:20 AM. LPA began four staff interviews at 10:40 AM. LPA interviewed 10 out of 22 children currently taking psychotropic medication at 11:50 AM. LPA conducted exit interview with Christina Torres, Administrator at 4:10 PM. LPA provided the Summary Report, LIC 809D, 9102TA, Appeal Rights, to Christina Torres, Administrator upon completion. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and cited from the Health and Safety Code during the inspection.

Confidential interviews and record review revealed that there was one incident where C1 and C2 were in the living area of their house playing the tickle game, which consisted of the two clients tickling each other in areas like the arms. Interviews revealed C1 moved and C2 accidentally touched C1 across C1’s private area. Some interviews revealed there was no staff or other clients around to see the incident while other interviews and record review revealed S1 and S2 were present in the house, S1 in the same room as the clients and S2 in the hallway. Interviews with staff revealed that staff observed C2 tickling C1 and staff reminded C2 of boundaries and not to touch C1. These interviews further revealed neither staff actually saw C2 touch C1 in the private area however, S2 heard C1 say that C2 touched C1 in C1’s private part. Interviews revealed S2 spoke with each client after the incident and C1 and C2 are not allowed to be near each other. Confidential interviews revealed C2 touching C1 in the private area was an isolated incident and an accident. CSW revealed there have been no prior disclosures of inappropriate touching between C1 and C2 or any other clients and no prior concerns of lack of supervision in the STRTP. Based on confidential interviews and conflicting statements of what occurred, the allegation C1 was inappropriately touched by C2 in care due to lack of supervision may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and provided to Administrator Christina Torres.

On December 22, 2022, at 2:33 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson. arrived at Father’s Heart Ranch Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Administrator, Christina Torres, to conduct a case management visit for the purpose of decreasing the capacity for clients’ placement as requested by the licensee. The STRTP was licensed to provide care for 24 ambulatory males, ages 6-17 years of age. The licensee requested a capacity decrease to a total capacity of 16 Clients. The STRTP had 13 Clients placed on the date of inspection. At 2:45 PM, LPA began the inspection of the facility with Christina Torres. LPA toured the facility inside and out. LPA observed that there was a total of ten buildings. Father’s Heart Ranch sits on 11-acres and is divided in three parcel sections by a six foot high fence. The lower parcel section has a commercial well that is capped. The five acre center parcel section includes a dining hall/multi-purpose room (A), recreation hall (B), four Client houses(C,D,F,G), staff housing (E), and offices (H). Lastly, the upper parcel section has an administrative (I) and mental health building (J). The Client dorms consists of four separate, one-story Client housing units with (3) bedrooms, (1) bathroom, living room, medication storage closet, locked storage with emergency binders, and kitchenette area in each. Each housing unit also has a separate laundry area. Locked contraceptive containers were not available for each Client. House Unit C has three bedrooms. Currently there are five Clients: Bedroom #1: consisted of two single beds and slept one Client age 12. Bedroom #2: consisted of two single beds and slept two Clients aged 12 and 13 Bedroom #3: consisted of two single beds and slept two Clients aged 11 and 12. (continued on next page)

(Continued from page one) House Unit D has three bedrooms. Currently there are three Clients: Bedroom #1: consisted of two single beds and slept one Client age 10. Bedroom #2: consisted of two single beds and slept one Client age 11. Bedroom #3: consisted of two single beds and slept one Client age 10. House Unit F has three bedrooms. Currently there are three Clients: Bedroom #1: consisted of two single beds and slept two Client ages 14 and 11. Bedroom #2: consisted of two single beds and slept one Client age 9 Bedroom #3: consisted of two single beds and slept zero Clients. Dorm G has three bedrooms. Currently there are two Clients: Bedroom #1: consisted of two single beds and slept one Client age 10. Bedroom #2: consisted of two single beds and slept zero Clients. Bedroom #3: consisted of two single beds and slept one Client age 8. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two Clients share a room, and there was one Client per bed. However, the beds need to remain at no more than 16 single beds, equal to the capacity. Additional beds may be kept in storage. There was adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the Client bathroom was measured to be not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C). All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where Clients will have access. Client’s medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked closet in each House Unit. Each of the houses require touch-ups on chipped paint, patched walls, and in the door jams of each bedroom. Client files are maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in a staff office in the J building as well as in a locked cabinet in each house and on a computer system. Personnel files are maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in an office in the I building and also on the computer system (EHR Your Way). Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a locked cabinet located in the laundry rooms of each home. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the cafeteria. A First Aid Kit is located in each home and contains all required supplies. (Continued)

(Continued from page 2) LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 4-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for Clients in the Unit Homes as well. Menu is posted in the cafeteria. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. All facility smoke detectors are hard wired and in working order. Carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in working order; fire extinguishers are in each unit and properly charged and serviced as of October 2022. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility and outside. There are no guns or weapons in the facility, as stated by Christina Torres. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/ books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. However, the outdoor play equipment located near Houses B/C/D no longer have the bark under them. The Administrator shared the wind consistently removes the bark. The outdoor play equipment located near House E has adequate bark covering the the ground of the play equipment with a sail style sunshade coverage overhead. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy, grievance forms, and Personal Rights were posted. However, the grievance forms are not accessible in each dorm and must be requested of the facility manager at the main office. Administrator corrected this prior to LPA exit. Administrator verified the Board of Directors are meeting quarterly and a Board Resolution dated December 6, 2022, was received resolving to reduce capacity to sixteen children. Facility will complete a fire safety inspection for the approved decreased capacity of 16 Clients and a copy of the approved fire safety clearance will be sent to the Department. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. The request for the license capacity change will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Based on file review, interviews, and observations made during the inspection, the licensee did not comply with the sections cited which poses/posed a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care: Technical Violation: Health Related- 87075(b)(1)(A); Buildings and Grounds 80087(a); Outdoor Activity Space 87087.2(b) An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Administrator, Christina Torres.

On the above date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Erika Lopez, met with Facility Manager, Christina Torres, and conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct confidential interview with a client. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the LIC 809 was provided to Christina Torres.

On the above date at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Lopez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith conducted an required annual inspection. LPA and LPM met with Administrator Christina Torres and Manager Sylvia Luna. The facility consists of four separate, one-story client housing units with (3) bedrooms, (1) bathroom, living room and kitchen area in each. Each housing unit also has a separate laundry area. The facility has a cafeteria, three buildings consisting of staff and therapy offices, a game room and an employee residence. At 10:30am, a tour of the physical plant was completed with Administrator and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors are hard wired and in working order. Carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in working order; fire extinguishers are in each unit and properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are double locked and centrally stored in the hallway closet of each housing unit. Licensee has provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. All individual twin beds in each client house were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms of each units were measured as follows: C house 109 degrees, D house 116 degrees, F House 120 degrees, G House 116 degrees. There were some technical violations observed in individual houses. Room number 1 of house D has a hole in the wall that needs to be repaired. Room number 2 has a damaged/cracked door that needs to be replaced. Room number 3 has a bedroom door that is hard to move and a door knob missing. The carbon monoxide detector is missing but administrator states that there was a fire inspection today and the detector may have been removed to replace the battery. House F, room number 2, has holes in the wall near the door jam that need to be repaired and there is no door to that bedroom. Administrator states it is in the process of being replaced.

There are two trampolines on grounds which have safety nets. The net on the trampoline closest to the basketball court is torn and needs to be replaced. Administrator states that the clients will not be using the trampoline until it has been repaired and will only be using the other one. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. Per Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Administrator Christina Torres is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interview. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs four social workers, nine facility managers and 34 direct care staff as well as two volunteers that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Administrator verified the Board of Directors are meeting quarterly. Technical violations are being issued for the following: ILS 87087(d) Buildings and Grounds, ILS 87075(b)(1)(A)(1) Health Related Services, and CCR 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. Due to time constraints, a continuation of this inspection will be conducted on a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was reviewed and provided to Administrator Christina Torres for signature.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena met with Administrative Director, Christina Torres to discuss the investigative findings for the above stated allegation. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Erika Lopez conducted an inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on December 12, 2022, at 10:45am. No immediate hazards observed. LPAs Erika Lopez and Cynthia Urena interviewed Facility Administrator (FA), two staff (S1 & S2), three foster children (C1, C2 and C3), as well as reviewed client and facility records. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information on December 09, 2022, alleging that Staff did not prevent inappropriate touching between minors in care. Information obtained in confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegation with a preponderance of evidence. LPAs Lopez and Urena obtained conflicting information during confidential interviews. Confidential interviews denied a lack of supervision and stated that on one occasion when C1 attempted to touch C2 in their groin area during bedtime, Staff # 1 (S1) immediately intervened and redirected C1, as well as closely monitored C1 for the remainder of the night. Incident was said to have occurred after C1, C2 and C3 were allowed to sleep in hall/living room area by S1 after they refused to go to bed. According to confidential information, S1 reported this incident to administrative staff. While other confidential information received by CCL stated that this

narrative: knee into C1’s back during a restraint. Confidential interviews provided conflicting statements regarding staff using excessive forms of restraints with some statements reporting staff are quick to restrain and residents occasionally are left with marks and/or bruises or soreness from the excessive forced used by staff during the restraint. Conflicting statements reported staff use a variety of de-escalation techniques prior to initiating a restraint on a resident and when restraints are used staff follow Pro-Act training. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute the allegations of excessive forms of restraint or C1 being handled in a rough manner. An additional allegation alleging Staff (unnamed) speaks inappropriate to minor (C1) in care was also received by CCL on July 24, 2023. Specifically, it was reported C1 was called slow, dumb, and stupid by unnamed staff. Confidential interviews and records reviewed revealed conflicting reports of staff speaking inappropriately to C1. Confidential interviews reported C1 claimed C1 was called slow on an unknown date by a staff member. Confidential interviews reported C1 interpreted this to mean C1 was stupid and dumb; however conflicting statements reported C1 was being told C1 was moving slow as the residents were transitioning from one activity to another. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute that the way the word slow was used was in an inappropriate manner. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations alleging Staff (unnamed) uses excessive forms of restraint on minor (C1) in care, staff (unnamed) handles minor (C1) in a rough manner and Staff (unnamed) speaks inappropriate to minor (C1) in care may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights to Father’s Heart Ranch Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Facility Manager Gloria Thomas.

Additionally, the confidential interviews stated that putting pressure on the neck and the back of a client during restraint is not the usual protocol and the staff would never do that to the client. Furthermore, a confidential interview stated that the staff are well trained on how to utilize restraints and have never seen or heard of a staff placing extra pressure on a client’s neck during a restraint. The Department received another allegation that stated the staff (S1) handled youth (C1) in a rough manner while in care. Specifically, it was stated that S1 slammed C1’s head on the floor. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements: Confidential interviews stated that S1 slammed C1’s head on the floor in the cafeteria for no apparent reason, there were no witnesses, and no staff was notified of this incident. Additionally, the confidential interviews stated that they have never seen S1 slammed C1’s head on the floor or any other clients at the facility. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that the S3 inappropriately restrained C1 while in care and S1 handled C1 in a rough manner while in care may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Father’s Heart Ranch Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), Gloria Thomas, Facility Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On 02/28/2024 at 10:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo met with Gloria Thomas, Facility Manager, to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegations at Father’s Heart Ranch Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). On 10/23/23, LPA inspected the facility’s physical plant, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. The investigation included interviews with four staff members (S1-S4), five clients (C1-C5) and County Social Worker (CSW). Clients’ Needs and Services Plans and case notes were reviewed. narrative: During the investigation there was no corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Although CCL received information stating that C1 was inappropriately restrained in care following an incident involving another client in care. The Investigator received inconsistent statements that supported a violation of neglect by staff during a restraint performed on C1 during a behavioral episode that posed a threat to C2 in care. Confidential interviews stated that staff members are trained in the usage of Professional Assault Crisis Training (Pro-ACT) and denied restraining C1 inappropriately during the incident in care. It was indicated that a restraint was used because C1 was choking C2 in care and after multiple verbal redirections by staff C1 refused to stop and staff intervened by using an appropriate Pro-ACT restraint on C1 during the incident. There were no other known witnesses to the allegation. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that staff inappropriately restrained C1 in care, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Director, Christina Torres.

narrative: In regard to the allegation that due to lack of supervision, a minor was assaulted by other minors, it was specifically reported that four clients and one of the bigger clients jumped C1 at the STRTP resulting in C1 being hit on the face, the head, the left arm, and the leg. During investigation, it was disclosed that staff was present during the incident with the appropriate staff to client ratio. Another confidential interview stated staff tried to deflect the incident from progressing but the incident among clients escalated quickly. Additionally, a confidential interview mentioned that staff didn’t say anything to prevent C1 from being assaulted. Other confidential interviews denied that the assault was due to a lack of supervision. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Regarding the allegation that staff did not report the incident to authorized representatives, confidential interview stated that the incident was reported. A confidential interview stated that the incident was not reported to C1’s relative. However, the facility staff indicated that the incidents were not to be reported to the C1’s relative; they were reported to all authorized representatives in a timely manner. Based on interview and record review, the allegation that C1 was assaulted by C2, C3, and C4 due to lack of supervision and staff did not report incident to the authorized representatives may have happened, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Office Manager, Sylvia Luna.

narrative: Multiple confidential interviews denied that C2 was sexually inappropriate with C1 or other clients in care. deficiencies.description:
80061(b) Reporting Requirements
Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report … shall be submitted…within seven days…This requirement is not met as evidence. Based on interviews and record review, the facility didn’t report an incident involving C1 requiring a medical attention within 24-hour to the Department which posed a potential health and safety or personal rights risks for the client in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrative Director, Christina Torres will review reporting requirements with staff and provide LPA Maya Chavez with Plan of Correction within 30 days from 07/10/2024 The facility will send the training to LPA on reporting requirement by 8/10/24.

narrative: In regard to the allegation, it was specifically reported that the STRTP staff did not prevent a physical altercation between minors in care. During investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that clients were playing, then argued and the argument escalated quickly to a physical altercation, and staff could not prevent the altercation resulting in C1 being injured. Confidential interviews stated that staff intervened immediately when the injury was observed on C1’s head which was bleeding. Facility applied first aid and took C1 to a medical facility and the doctor applied staples on the injury. LPA did not receive additional information. Based on interview and record review, the allegation staff did not prevent a physical altercation between C1 and C2 while in care may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation, therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Office Manager, Sylvia Luna.

narrative: Regarding the allegation staff did not ensure care and adequate supervision was provided resulting in child elopement, it was specifically reported that a ten-year-old non-verbal client who is medically fragile entered a house and ransacked it at 4:00AM in the morning. During investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that overnight staff do bedroom checks every fifteen minutes, but on the morning the client left the facility, bedroom checks were not conducted from 2:30AM-5:30AM according to documentation. In addition, confidential interviews disclosed that staff left the client’s house for unclear reasons and clients were left unsupervised. A confidential interview stated that staff went to use the restroom while documents gathered indicated that staff went to do laundry. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that when a client leaves the facility, staff would notice it right away and will follow AWOL protocol, however, a confidential interview and incident report corroborated that facility staff was not aware that the client AWOLed until law enforcement brought back C1 to the facility. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined staff did not ensure care and adequate supervision was provided resulting in C1’s elopement. Therefore, this allegation is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards, 80078(a). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to facility manger, Gloria Thomas.

deficiencies.description: 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a)	The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement in not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and record reviews, the facility staff didn’t ensure the bedroom checks were completed every 15 minutes correctly or noticed that C1 was missing which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility plans and already took disciplinary action by suspending staff present during C1's elopment without pay. Facility will also retrain staff who was present during C1's elopment before returning to work. In addition to already required fifteen minute bed checks facility now requires an over-night floater to conduct bed checks every thirty minutes with a log that requires dual signatures.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi on October 31,2024 at approximately 9:31 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Choi met Administrator Gloria Thomas and facility Nurse Yvonne Hemminger, and conducted a tour of the facility. LPA reviewed five of child’s records and three of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed five of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed three staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA will interview three children, that are currently prescribed psychotropic medication, at their assigned schools, after the facility visit. After reviewing client and staff records, one deficiency is being cited at this time, please see LIC 809D. The facility was also provided a Technical Advisory (TA). LPA provided a copy of this licensing report, LIC 809D, TA and appeals rights, and conducted an exit interview with Administrator Gloria Thomas.

narrative: **This is an amended report of the original dated November 15, 2024** Regarding the allegation that staff falsify minors’ documentation, it was specifically reported that the facility manager engages in fraudulent practices when it comes to clients’ documents specifically needs and service plans (NSP’s) and a client’s physician’s note was recreated by staff and physician’s signature was photocopied. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff have been instructed to create NSP’s after the due date and put incorrect dates. Another confidential interview disclosed that staff was instructed to recreate a physician’s handwritten document into a typed document. In addition, confidential interview disclosed that on the recreated physician’s document S6 forged physician’s signature onto the typed document to expedite process rather than obtain typed/signed document from the physician. Other confidential interviews disclosed that management has not asked staff to falsify a document. LPA reviewed the documents gathered and noticed discrepancies. Additional interviews corroborated that facility staff modified the Children and Family Services C1’s medical procedure authorization’s document. However, another interview denied that staff has forged physician's signature onto the typed medical document. Staff transcribed the Physician's notes and took back the notes to the Doctor for signature. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined staff falsity C1’s documentation. Therefore, this allegation is substantiated. The facility is being cited for the violation of the title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 False Claim 80012(a). See LIC9099D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report were provided to Office manager, Sylvia Luna.
