Administrator will retrain mental health department staff about abiding timelines and dating documentation correctly
regarding needs and service plans (NSPs). **This is an amended report of the original dated November 15, 2024**

narrative:
An informal conference was held with Father’s Ranch STRTP at the Riverside South Children’s Residential Program office to discuss licensing concerns. Present at the meeting were Natasha Dunlap, Regional Manager (RM), Abdoulaye Traore, Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Maya Chavez, Licensing Program Analyst, Christina Torres, Administrator, Gloria Thomas (GT), Facility Manager, Sylvia Luna (SL), Office Manager, Julia Tyler (JT), Head of Service, Maxwell Kraft, Program Coordinator. Virtual attendees included Tasha Inman, San Bernardino County Short Term Therapeutic Residential Program (STRTP) Coordinator, Dawn Waters, Dept. of Behavioral Health Program Specialist II. The following subjects were discussed: · Lack of Oversight by facility management · Lack of Supervision (deficiency) · Incident Reports and reporting requirements (deficiency) · Needs and Services (falsification and backdated) (deficiency) · Allowances · Excessive use of restraints

The meeting included a discussion regarding the above concerns. At the beginning of the discussion, Regional Manager (RM) Dunlap and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Traore explained the reason for the meeting and explained that the meeting would be a collaborative meeting which included the participation and input of all departments listed above that provide services to Father’s Ranch STRTP. During the meeting, RM Dunlap and LPM Traore addressed CCL’s concerns regarding the above-mentioned issues and requested input from the various oversight agencies participating in the meeting discussion. In regard to the oversight, Christina Torres stated additional leadership staff received administrator certification. JT will be overseeing the mental health Program at the facility, SL will be overseeing administration, and GT will be overseeing the program directly by ensuring the facility is in compliance with title 22 and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) in all areas. SL will initiate any additional trainings as needed. In regard to the lack of supervision, AT addressed the deficiency. CT stated that the facility will continue to do room checks every fifteen minutes during overnight shift. CT stated that an emergency safety plan was put together in order to correct the lack of supervision. CT stated that AWOL records have been reduced with the last year. SL stated that the client to staff ratio is better than the CCL requirement. Facility provided walkie talkie system to all staff to assist with instant communication and the implementation has been re-enforced. Regarding special incident reports (SIRs) CT stated that the facility will continue to ensure that staff are writing SIRs in a timely manner. Additionally, CT indicated that she rather over report that not report incidents occurring at the facility. MK reported that all incidents are documented however, minor incidents such as a scrape may not be written in a special incident report but are documented. In regard to the Needs and Services Plans (NSPs). The facility’s staff have been retrained on NSPs protocols according to Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) and all staff must turn in NSPs no later than the 5th of each month for review and approval by management. In regard to the allowance, CT addressed that the allowance log is kept behind multiple locks, and it is possible when a copy was requested, staff were unable to retrieve logs due to it being locked and after office hours. The facility stated that they pay for all necessities and clients are allowed to request items to be ordered off Amazon. The client’s funds are kept in to two different pouches. The first pouch includes the client’s base allowance, and any funds clients comes to the facility with which is not used towards damages. The facility brought template of their allowance record keeping and will continue to utilize and enforce record keeping.

In regard to the overuse of restraints, the facility stated that their goal for the year was to reduce the amount of restraints. Facility provided a chart which demonstrated the reduction in restraints used at the facility. The chart showed clients who started the year off with multiple restraints in a single month ended the year with less restraints used within multiple months. Facility believes that the reduce of restraints is a result of adequate supervision and the training the staff have received. The facility stated that all staff are Pro-Act certified including maintenance staff and office staff. The Department provided a copy of contact information of the Catalyst Center Kelsie Tatum Martinez kmartinez@catalyst-center.org and a Technical Support Program Basics, Workflow for Providers brochure to the licensees for additional resources. A copy of this report was provided to the licensee.

**This is an amended report of the original dated November 15, 2024** Regarding the allegation that staff falsify minors’ documentation, it was specifically reported that the facility manager engages in fraudulent practices when it comes to clients’ documents specifically needs and service plans (NSP’s) and a client’s physician’s note was recreated by staff and physician’s signature was photocopied. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff have been instructed to create NSP’s after the due date and put incorrect dates. Another confidential interview disclosed that staff was instructed to recreate a physician’s handwritten document into a typed document. In addition, confidential interview disclosed that on the recreated physician’s document S6 forged physician’s signature onto the typed document to expedite process rather than obtain typed/signed document from the physician. Other confidential interviews disclosed that management has not asked staff to falsify a document. LPA reviewed the documents gathered and noticed discrepancies. Additional interviews corroborated that facility staff modified the Children and Family Services C1’s medical procedure authorization’s document. However, another interview denied that staff has forged physician's signature onto the typed medical document. Staff transcribed the Physician's notes and took back the notes to the Doctor for signature. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined staff falsity C1’s documentation. Therefore, this allegation is substantiated. The facility is being cited for the violation of the title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 False Claim 80012(a). See LIC9099D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report were provided to Office manager, Sylvia Luna.

deficiencies.description: False Claims: No licensee, officer, or employee of a licensee shall make or disseminate any false or misleading statement regarding the facility or any of the services provided by the facility. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and record reviews, the staff falsified documents and backdated needs and services plans which poses a potential health and safety and personal right risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Administrator will retrain mental health department staff about abiding timelines and dating documentation correctly
regarding needs and service plans (NSPs). **This is an amended report of the original dated November 15, 2024**

narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff mishandled a minor's personal belonging, it was specifically reported that S1 picked up C1’s remote-control car and threw it against the wall causing it to break. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that S1 broke C1’s toy car during an altercation but replaced it afterwards. Another confidential interview disclosed that out of frustration, S1 swiped the toy cars remote off the dresser accidentally causing it to break. In addition, S1 understood that it was not right and replaced the toy car. In regard to the allegation that staff threw a minor against the wall, it was specifically reported that S1 picked up C1 from underneath C1’s arm and threw C1 against the wall. Confidential interviews disclosed that although they were inside the same house, they did not see nor hear S1 throwing C1 against a wall. Another confidential interview disclosed that S1 was only deflecting C1 from throwing toys at S1, and C1 was already angled near the wall during the incident, however, S1 didn’t intentionally put C1 against the wall. In addition, confidential interview disclosed that at no point did S1 restrain C1 due to S1 being the only staff on duty and S1 was not allowed to restrain by themselves. Another confidential interview disclosed that S1 grabbed C1 and threw C1 against the wall then pushed C1’s head against the wall but there was no one around. Another confidential interview disclosed that they witnessed S1 restrain C1 against the wall and had C1’s arm pressed against the wall. In addition, confidential interview disclosed that S1 was the only staff present. Based on interview and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that staff mishandled a minor's personal belonging and staff threw a minor against the wall. Therefore, the allegations are substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards Section 87072 Personal Rights(c)(11). See LIC 9099 D. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Administrative Director, Sylvia Luna.

deficiencies.description: (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child… is accorded the personal rights… the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights … (11) To be free of physical..., and from corporal or unusual punishment,…of a punitive nature including, but not limited to… This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations and confidential interviews, the staff admitted that the minor's remote was broken, and an additional witness observed staff throwing a minor against the wall. This posed a potential risk to the Health, Safety and Personal Rights to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility gave LPA Chavez a copy of S1's disciplinary notice stating that S1 will remove themself and call for assistance during a crisis intervention. If a client needs to be restrained, at no point will S1 place their hands on a client. Signed and dated by S1 on 01/28/2025. In addition, the facility will continue to give refresher trainings and recertify staff on crisis and intervention protocol per CCL guidelines.

narrative: Documentation and confidential interviews confirmed that C1 did sustain a fracture to their left arm, however the injury was caused by C1 falling off their bike. The incident report submitted to the Department reported that on October 5, 2025, C1 was seen riding their bike when they crashed while attempting to make a turn. The report notes that several staff members were present and attended to C1’s "cuts and scrapes." However, at the time of the fall, it was not known that C1 had broken their arm as a confidential interview reported that C1 got back on the bike afterward. C1 was kept under staff supervision to monitor for any pain or swelling to their arm. The following day, staff transported C1 to urgent care where a fracture was confirmed. There were allegations that C2 caused C1's injury, as it was reported that on the same day of the fall, C2 kicked in C1's bedroom door, potentially further injuring C1's arm. However, confidential statements regarding this incident were inconsistent and did not establish that C2's actions caused the fracture. Regarding the claim that STRTP staff did not prevent bullying, multiple confidential interviews indicated that C1 and C2 were housed in the same dormitory, and C1 frequently provoked C2. It was also reported that, in addition to clients always being under staff supervision, staff routinely intervened during conflicts. Although C2 and other clients occasionally "teased" each other, staff members were present to redirect behaviors and de-escalate situations as much as possible. Additionally, statements about whether C2 coerced C1 or other clients into bringing C2 food were inconsistent. Based on confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the allegations that due to a lack of Supervision a minor (C1) sustained a fracture while in care and staff did not prevent minor (C2) from bullying another minor (C1) may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, along with the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated October 11, 2024, and appeal rights, was explained and provided to Chief Executive Officer Christina Torres.
investigation_findings: 13On May 15, 2025, at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete made an unannounced visit to Father’ s Heart Ranch Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Chief Executive Officer, to deliver the investigative finding for the allegations mentioned above. The investigation was conducted by Special Investigator (Inv) Shawniece Poinsette of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Bureau. The investigation included interviews the facility staff (S1-S4), clients in care (C1-C6), and the County Social Worker (CSW). On October 9, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that due to a lack of supervision a minor (C1) sustained a fracture while in care and staff did not prevent minor (C2) from bullying another minor (C1). Specifically, there were concerns that the contentious relationship between C1 and C2 led to C2 purposely causing the injury to C1’s left arm, as well as C1 bullying and coercing C2 and other clients in care. (Continued on LIC 9099C)

narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent physical altercation between C1 and C2, it was specifically reported that C2 socked C1 in the eye resulting in a black eye and that it is unknown whether the staff witnessed the incident or how they became aware of the incident. During investigation, multiple interviews disclosed that C1 and C2 were in a verbal altercation and staff told C1 and C2 to stop but then it escalated to a physical altercation. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that when the physical altercation started staff attempted to separate C1 and C2 by placing themselves between C1 and C2 but C2 was still able to hit C1. Additionally, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff prevent altercations between clients by using verbal redirection and physically separating clients if needed. LPA received conflicting information. Regarding the allegation that staff made inappropriate comment towards minor, it was specifically reported that after a physical altercation between C1 and C2, a staff member at the facility told C1 "if this incident occurs again, whatever has to happen will happen." It was reported that it was unknown what that staff member meant. During investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that what that staff member said, could have meant numerous things such as reporting it to the administrator, calling the police, etc. but it did not seem inappropriate. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff have never said anything inappropriate towards a client in general. Based on interviews, the allegations that staff did not prevent physical altercation between C1 and C2 and staff made inappropriate comment towards C1 may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator, Christina Torres.

narrative: Confidential witness statement revealed that C1 did not look well and went to C1’s bedroom. Confidential witness’ statements revealed that C1’s school contacted the facility and disclosed that C1 may have ingested drugs as school staff had received information that C1 uploaded a video to social media of C1 engaging in drug usage. FM stated that facility staff informed FM that C1’s belongings were searched but nothing was located. FM stated that C1 did not look well and when offered medical attention C1 refused. FM stated that he did not believe that C1 had taken pills at the facility. Confidential witness’ interviews also revealed that facility staff supervise clients well and if a client is suspected of having contraband on their person then staff request that clients conduct self-searches . Confidential witness statement revealed that they were unsure if C1 had taken drugs at the facility or elsewhere. Confidential witness’ statements revealed that they were unsure how long C1 needed medical attention before staff called the ambulance. OHI stated that she had no concerns of staff and was informed that staff acted immediately in seeking medical attention for C1. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that there was a lack of supervision resulting C1 engaging in self-harm and facility staff failed so seek medical attention for C1 in a timely manner, may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Michael Barnett. Documents emailed to Michael Barnett. Original signature on file.

narrative: On November 12, 2020 at 10:47 AM. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Hamilton conducted a case management tele-inspection at Ferree’s Group Home (GH) and met with Facility Manager Michael Barnett via Cisco Webex. Due to COVID-19 a tele-inspection was conducted. The purpose of the inspection was to address issues and concerns regarding incidents that occurred on or around April 25, 2020 and April 29, 2020. It was discovered through information received via confidential interviews that Client #1 (C1) was allegedly involved in a fight with three other clients of the GH on 04/25/2020. This incident resulted in Law Enforcement (LE) being contacted and C1 being transported to the hospital for medical treatment. In addition, C1 was AWOL 04/29/2020 to 05/05/2020 and the GH did not contact Community Care Licensing (CCL) or C1’s County Social Worker (CSW). The Serious Incident Reports (SIRs) regarding the above incidents were obtained by LPA during a complaint investigation and during confidential interviews it was reported that GH staff forwarded the SIRs regarding the AWOL and the fight to CCL and CSW. LPA was unable to locate any SIR’s regarding these incidents. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80061(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements. GH failed to report special incidents to CCL or C1’s county social worker of C1’s involvement in a fight and C1 being AWOL for multiple days. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, Confidential Names List, LIC 811 and appeal rights were emailed to facility manager Michael Barnett for signature. The signed reports will be placed in facility file.

Confidential witness’ statements revealed that the clients at the facility who take medication are always offered medication and the facility has not ran out. narrative: Confidential witnesses disclosed that C1 and C2 would leave facility grounds to engage romantically or would kiss one another quickly when staff was not around. Confidential witnesses stated that C1 did not seem uncomfortable and they never witnessed anyone pressure C1 into sexual acts. Confidential witness’ statement revealed that they did not hear facility staff disclose health information of any client. Confidential witness stated that in December 2020 law enforcement officers stopped by the facility and one officer mentioned something about C1’s health information and that is how some clients began to speak of C1’s health information. FM stated that facility staff attempt to be in the same general area while clients are at the facility and when this is not possible facility staff check on clients often. FM stated he did not have any suspicions that C1 and C2 were romantically involved with one another or that C1 was engaging in sexual activity with any other clients. FM stated that C1 felt that staff had revealed C1’s health information to another client but FM recalled C1 disclosing C1’s health to a past client. County social worker 2 (CSW2) stated that she visited that facility and did not see any inappropriate interactions between clients. CSW2 also stated she was never informed that clients were being pressured to perform sexual acts or that facility staff disclosed a client’s health information to other clients. Other confidential witness statement revealed that staff was made aware of the inappropriate sexual interactions going on between C1 and C2 but did nothing and that other clients forced C1 in to performing sexual acts. Other confidential witnesses stated that facility staff revealed C1’s health information to other clients. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that there was a lack of supervision resulting C1 and C2 engaging in inappropriate interactions, other clients forced C1 to perform sexual acts and that facility staff disclosed C1’s health information, may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Michael Barnett. narrative: On May 27, 2021 at 12:54 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz met with Ferree’s Group Home #3 Supervising Facility Manager, Michael Barnett, to discuss an incident that occurred involving clients (C1, C2) see LIC 811 confidential names list dated May 27, 2021. Other confidential witness’ statements revealed that facility staff had not been transporting C1 to C1’s anger management appointments and therapist appointments. Another confidential interview stated staff not providing transportation for C1’s appointments was not necessarily due to the facility not having enough facility staff to transport C1. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met that the facility failed to ensure that C1 was transported to health-related services. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5 Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Articles 1 through 10, and Subchapter 7.5, Version 3.1 87074 (c) (1) Transportation. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Pat Prior.

narrative:
On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Jose Gonzalez, and LPA Michael Almaraz conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was inspected inside and out with Supervising Facility Manager Michael Barnett. The home is a one-story residence with three bedrooms and two bathrooms. One client was present at time of inspection. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean with one shower fixture in need of repair. The temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured at 109 degrees (F). All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the staff office. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in pantry. First Aid Kit is located in the staff office and contained all required supplies. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Facility Manager, Michael Barnett. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, and current menu. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the staff office. LPAs observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. One client was interviewed and indicated that he feels safe in the home and accorded personal rights. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to not be clean, free of waste, and or maintained well. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is no swimming pool located at facility. (Continued ...)

A sample of staff files were reviewed during the inspection. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. Facility manager was present at time of inspection, and there was one client present at time of inspection. Facility cited for violation of Health Related Services, Fixtures, Furniture and Equipment Supplies, Personnel Records, Personnel Requirement and Training Requirement. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to Facility Manager, Michael Barnett along with a Confidential Names List (LIC 811).

***This is an amendment to a report that was issued on September 23, 2021:*** However, FA stated that they reviewed facility cameras located in the common areas and they didn’t observe or noticed anything that showed a lack of supervision. Confidential witness statement revealed that clients were left unsupervised for approximately 25 minutes. Another confidential witness corroborated that facility staff were outside the facility during C1 and C2's inappropriate interaction. Confidential witness’ statements disclosed that the inappropriate interactions only occurred between C1 and C2. Other confidential interviews didn’t provide information regarding the allegation due to not being present during the incident. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that facility staff did not properly supervise C1 and C2 resulting in an inappropriate interaction. The allegation is therefore substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5 Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Articles 1 through 10, and Subchapter 7.5, Version 3.1 87065.2 (b) (1) Personnel duties. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Pat Prior.

FA indicated that law enforcement was contacted to report this incident. (continued on next page...)

narrative: SFM added that the wall had been cut open for a week as the facility was waiting for the supplies they ordered to arrive. SFM stated that they had neither smelled nor had been approached by any clients about the existence of a mold. Other Confidential witnesses stated that they did not smell mold or any other unpleasant odor and had not experienced headaches. Additional confidential witness statements maintained that the facility smelled moldy which had caused clients and staff to experience headaches. During LPA inspection of the facility LPA did not smell mold or any unpleasant odor. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation that the facility smells like mold which lead to clients and staff having headaches may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Michael Barnett.
investigation_findings: 13On October 7, 2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Michael Almaraz and Lisi Leon arrived at the facility and met with supervising facility manager, Michael Barnett, to issue the finding for the above stated allegation. On May 27, 2021, at 10:11 AM LPA Almaraz conducted a safety inspection and interviews. During the inspection, LPA reviewed client’s records and conducted interviews with two of four clients and five staff. Additionally, LPA interviewed two clients and one staff. On May 27, 2021, the Department received a building and grounds complaint against the facility. It was specified that the facility smells like mold which causes clients and staff to suffer headaches. Confidential witness’ statements revealed that the client’s bathroom shower had a leak in the walls which lead to the carpet getting wet. Confidential witnesses indicated that facility staff reported the leaking pipe and facility started repairing the leak, but they were waiting for plumbing supplies to complete the repair. Supervising Facility Manager (SFM) stated that facility addressed the leaking pipe immediately by cutting open the wall to allow the saturated carpet and wall to dry. (continued on next page...)

narrative: Additionally, confidential witnesses stated that facility staff was always checking on the clients and engaging with them by asking them questions and conversating with the clients. Confidential witness’ statements revealed that some clients smoke marijuana at the facility but it was not allowed or condoned by facility staff. Supervising facility manager (S1) disclosed that staff always try to supervise clients by keeping line of sight and conducting room checks. S1 stated that several clients smoked marijuana, and some have smoked in the facility even though it was not allowed. S1 stated that clients were counselled and advised about the dangers and negative impact of drugs, but the clients continued to smoke marijuana. Other Confidential witnesses stated that on May 5, 2021, they witnessed clients smoking marijuana outside the facility at approximately 10:15 PM. Additionally, when the confidential witness contacted the facility but staff was not aware of clients being outside. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that clients were outside of the facility at night without staff knowledge and lack of supervision resulted clients smoking marijuana at the facility may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Michael Barnett.
investigation_findings: 13On October 20, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz arrived at the facility and met with supervising facility manager, Michael Barnett, to issue the findings for the above stated allegations. On May 17, 2021, at 10:20 AM LPA Almaraz conducted a safety inspection and interviews. During the inspection, LPA reviewed client’s records and conducted interviews with three of five clients and one staff. Additionally, LPA interviewed two county social workers and five staff. Two of five clients were unavailable for interview. On May 06, 2021, the Department received a lack of supervision complaint against the facility. It was specified that clients were outside of the facility at night without staff knowledge and clients were smoking marijuana at the facility. Confidential witness’ statements revealed that on or around May 5, 2021, client #1 (C1) (see confidential names list LIC 811 dated October 20, 2021) was outside the facility late at night listening to a speaker when staff asked C1 to come in the facility but C1 refused. Confidential witnesses stated that they did not see C1 smoking marijuana outside the facility that night. (continued on next page...)

narrative: Confidential witnesses also stated that while C2 was attacking C1, S2 walked over “slowly” and did nothing to stop or prevent C2 from attacking C1. Confidential witness stated that S2 was laughing at C1 while C2 was striking C1 several times on the face and body. LPA was provided a video of the incident and in the video C1 is being attacked by C2. LPA observed in the video surveillance that S2 does not show a sense of urgency and does not attempt to redirect the clients. LPA observed C1 attacked twice once in the game room and another time outside the facility. During the attacks, S2 did not attempt to get C1 to a safe place or separate C1 from the attacker. Other confidential witness statements revealed that S2 walked over and attempted to stop the attack but C2 would not listen. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that facility staff did not prevent a physical altercation between C1 and C2. The allegation is therefore substantiated which poses a health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5 Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Articles 1 through 10, and Subchapter 7.5, Version 3.1 87072 (c) (11) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Michael Barnett.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse...This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confiden- tial interviews and record review S2 failed to intervene during the physical altercation which poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per supervising facility manager facility will provide training to all employees on ILS personal rights section 87072. Facility will provide LPA with proof of training by the POC due date.

narrative: Regarding minors consuming alcohol in the facility, it was specified that night shift staff fell asleep and minors in the home brought alcohol in the facility and consumed it. During the investigation, confidential interviews denied that minors had consumed alcohol in the facility while staff was sleeping. A confidential interview reported that minors will come back to the facility from a pass under the influence of drugs or alcohol. Another confidential interview stated that they did not witness minors consuming alcohol. Other interviews did not have any information regarding minors’ consuming alcohol in the premises. For the allegation regarding minors’ needs were not met, it was specified that staff are supposed to take minors to their medication appointment after crisis, but they don’t. A confidential interview indicated that when a client is going through a crisis, staff contacted facility Therapy for advice and sometimes clients will be scheduled for Doctor’s appointment. Another interview reported that medication appointments are scheduled upon placement, but they were not aware medication appointments needed to be scheduled after crisis. Other confidential interviews declined to provide information regarding the staff failing to take clients to appointments. Other confidential interviews stated that they have not witnessed clients going through crisis. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that C1, C2, C3, C4 and C5 were consuming alcohol in the premises due to lack of supervision and staff failed to meet C1, C2, C3, C4 and C5 needs may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Supervising Facility Manager Michael Barnett.

narrative:
Moreover, confidential witnesses disclosed that the facility did not have a current Order on Application of Psychotropic Medication (JV-223). For the allegation that staff was not reporting incidents to the Department, it was reported that C1 had AWOLed several times and the facility didn’t report them to the Department. Confidential interviews confirmed that C1 would AWOL on a daily basis during C1’s placement. During LPA’s review of special incident reports (SIR) from the facility, LPA noted the facility did not report all of C1’s AWOL incidents. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that facility staff administered medication to C1 without the proper documentation, and staff was not reporting incidents involving C1. The allegations are therefore substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5 Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (ILS) Sections: 87075(c) Health Related Services and 87061(b)(4) Reporting Requirements. sessions. LPA was unable to verify if those sessions of therapy were appropriate for C1. deficiencies.description:
87075 HEALTH RELATED SERVICES
(c) Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 87070(b)(11).
This requirement was not met as evidenced by:
Based on confidential interviews and record review the facility administered C1 medication without the proper documentation which poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per supervising facility manager (SFM) the facility staff will be trained on ILS 87075(c) Health related services. SFM also informed LPA that C1 is no longer placed at the facility. SFM stated that the POC will be provided to LPA by POC due date.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review the facility did not report incidents involving C1’s absence from the facility which poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: For the allegation regarding that staff did not protect a client during a mental health, it was specified that client 1 (C1) told staff that C1 wanted to commit suicide with a gun. It was added that C1 was depressed, and C1 medication was making C1 suicidal. Furthermore, it was indicated that facility staff took C1 to San Gorgonio hospital due to C1 being incoherent. A confidential interview reported that when clients are in crisis, staff will immediately act to get clients in a safe place and C1 was taken to the San Gorgonio hospital when C1 was in a health crisis. The confidential interview disclosed that C1 was only placed at the facility for one week and C1 was constantly leaving the facility without permission. Other confidential interviews did not provide any information regarding this matter. Regarding the child accessing illegal substance, a confidential interview stated that C1 used marijuana often and it was immediately addressed when observed to be under the influence. Facility staff denied child had access to marijuana while at the facility. It was reported that C1 was constantly AWOL (absent without leave). Two clients refused to interview. LPA Caballero was unable to interview C1 at C1’s current placement due to C1’s AWOL. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that client #1 was not protected by staff during a mental health crisis and C1 had access to an illegal substance may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Facility Representative Phillip Ferree gave Shift Manager Pat Prior verbal authorization to sign this report. A copy of this report was provided to Shift Manager Pat Prior.
investigation_findings: 13On April 22, 2022 at 10:52AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero met with Ferree’s Group Home #3 Shift Manager Pat Prior to discuss the investigative findings for the above stated allegations involving a client in the facility. On April 1, 2022, LPA Caballero visited the facility for additional interviews but LPA was unable to interview clients. LPA Caballero obtained client roster dated August 26, 2021 and updated client roster dated March 17, 2022. On April 13, 2022 LPA Adaleyci Caballero interviewed Facility Administrator. On April 22, 2022, LPA Caballero conducted interviews with two clients at the facility.

narrative: County social worker (CSW) stated that staff at the facility interacted appropriately with the clients and C1 had not informed CSW that staff were abusing clients. Furthermore, CSW stated that she had not seen any injuries on C1 to suggest that C1 was being abused at the facility. Confidential witnesses stated that they had not seen S1, or any facility staff become physically aggressive towards clients. Other confidential witness maintained that S1 was upset with C1 on the evening of November 22, 2022 and choked C1. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation that S1 physically abused C1 may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and provided to Tina Willis.
investigation_findings: 13On February 2, 2023, at 10:10 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz arrived at the facility and met with Supervising Facility Manager, Tina Willis, to issue the finding for the above stated allegation. On November 1, 2022, at 8:53 AM LPA Almaraz arrived at the facility to initiate the investigation and conducted a safety inspection. During the safety inspection, LPA interviewed one facility staff, two clients (see confidential names list LIC 811 dated February 2, 2023) and reviewed three client records. Additionally, LPA conducted interviews with one client, three county social workers and one additional staff. In total three of three clients were interviewed. On October 24, 2022, the Department received a complaint that alleged facility staff handled youth in a rough manner. More specifically, it was alleged that staff #1 (S1) physically abused C1 by choking C1. During the investigation, confidential witness stated that on the evening of November 22, 2022, C1 and S1 were involved in altercation at the facility. The confidential witness continued stating that C1 attacked S1 due to C1 being upset with facility policy. (continued on page 2...)

narrative: Additionally, confidential witnesses stated that on August 17, 2022 and August 18, 2022, facility staff were outside of the facility supervising the clients asking the clients to go inside but the clients ignored the staff’s request. County social worker (CSW) stated that facility staff provided supervision to clients and CSW did not suspect a lack of supervision occurring at the facility. County social worker 2 (CSW2) added that her client would ignore staff’s request and would not follow direction. County social worker 3 (CSW3) stated that staff’s supervision was appropriate. Other confidential witness stated that on August 17, 2022 and August 18, 2022, staff was not outside with the clients and staff did not ask the clients to go inside. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation that due to inadequate supervision on August 17, 2022 and August 18, 2022, clients were outside of the facility at late hours of the night disturbing the community may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and provided to Tina Willis.

narrative: On June 29, 2023, at 10:03 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz conducted an unannounced inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an inspection for STRTP annual inspection. LPA completed the physical inspection of the facility, reviewed operational requirements, disaster preparedness, emergency intervention plan, core/therapeutic services, staffing records, and client records. During this annual inspection continuation LPA reviewed files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Based on observation and file review, the facility is being cited on the following area: physical plant operational requirements, and core/therapeutic services. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 809-d and appeal rights were provided to supervising administrator Phillip Ferree.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that S1 left client 1 (C1) unattended. It was specifically stated that “Life Coach” needed to come pick up the client from a Stater Brother's parking lot 45 minutes before the scheduled placement was to take place. A confidential interview stated C1 was driven to a meeting location where C1 was to be picked up. The confidential interview added that C1 did not want the facility to know C1’s new location/home, therefore, C1 preferred to be dropped off and be picked up outside of the facility. Another confidential interview stated there was communication between S1 and the driver picking C1 up. The confidential interview added S1 had to leave to pick other clients for appointment, however, the other driver was five minutes away when S1 left. LPA was unable to gather additional information regarding the time frame C1 was left unattended. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that S1 left C1 unattended, may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation. Therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and the appeal right was reviewed and provided to STRTP representative.

During investigation, LPA interviewed Staff 1, (S1), Facility manager (FM), Administrator (A1). LPA was unable to interview County Social Worker (CSW).

narrative: On the above date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, conducted a tele-visit due to COVID 19 and met with Supervising Facility Manager (SFM), Tisha Robbins, to ask questions regarding Perry Williams (PW) ID # 7517586730. SFM stated that PW is not working for the facility in any capacity. LPA thanked SFM and the interview concluded. A copy of this report was provided to Tisha Robbins. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.

CSW stated that she was informed by facility staff that C1 had several days were C1’s blood pressure was high and C1’s doctor was contacted. CSW stated that when she contacted C1’s doctor C1’s doctor revealed that the facility had not contacted him. Confidential witness’ statements revealed that C1 had high blood pressure on several different days but on August 25, 2020, C1 had a higher than normal blood pressure reading. Confidential witness’ statements revealed that on August 25, 2020, facility staff did not seek medical attention for C1. Facility records revealed that on August 25, 2020, C1’s had a high blood pressure reading. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met that C1 had a high blood pressure level and staff did not seek medical attention. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. The facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5 Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Articles 1 through 10, and Subchapter 7.5, Version 3 87072 (d) (17) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Tisha Robbins. Documents emailed to Tisha Robbins. Original signature on file.

Other confidential witness statements revealed that facility staff do not always offer clients their medication and clients have to request the medication at times. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation that staff is not ensuring C1 is not taking C1’s prescribed medication, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Tisha Robbins. Documents emailed to Tisha Robbins. Original signature on file.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, conducted a tele-inspection due to COVID19 and met with Supervising Facility Manager, Tisha Robbins, to issues the finding for the above stated allegation. The investigation was conducted by LPA Almaraz. LPA inspected the facility on September 2, 2020, at 10:35 AM and reviewed one client’s records. During the LPA’s inspection, an interview was conducted with supervising facility manager and one client. During the course of the investigation four clients, county social worker and four facility staff were interviewed. On September 1, 2020, the Department received a complaint that alleged staff did not seek medical attention for minor. More specifically, that client #1 (C1) (see confidential names list LIC 811 dated November 4, 2020) had dangerously high blood pressure and staff did not seek medical attention for C1. Confidential witness’ statements revealed that C1 takes medication for blood pressure and C1’s blood pressure is checked daily. Confidential witness’ statements revealed that facility staff were untrained on how to properly check C1’s blood pressure. (continued on page 2...)

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights 87072 (d) (17) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that... each child is accorded the following personal rights: To receive medical, dental, vision and mental health services. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential witness interviews and record review staff did not seek medical attention for C1 when C1’s blood pressure was high on 8/25/20.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Supervising Facility Manager (SFM) staff will be trained on how to properly take a blood pressure reading and when to contact medical professionals based off of the blood pressure readings. SFM will provide LPA with a copy of proof that training has been conducted by 11/5/20.

narrative: Confidential witness statements revealed that staff rarely enter client’s bedrooms and staff have not walked into the client’s bedroom while a client is changing. Confidential witness statement revealed that staff always knock before opening doors. SFM denied that she walked into C1’s bedroom while C1 was changing. SFM stated that she and all staff always knock prior to opening any closed doors at the facility. CSW stated that she visited C1 at the facility and C1 did not mention that C1 felt uncomfortable or that staff was entering C1’s bedroom without knocking while C1 was changing. Other confidential witness statements revealed that SFM walked into C1’s bedroom without knocking while C1 was changing. Also, revealed was that C1 was made to feel uncomfortable at the facility due to SFM not allowing C1 privacy. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that SFM enters C1’s bedroom while C1 is changing and makes C1 feel uncomfortable, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Tisha Robbins.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, conducted a tele-inspection due to COVID 19 and met with Facility Supervising Manager, Tisha Robbins, to issue the finding for the above stated allegation. The investigation was conducted by LPA Almaraz. LPA inspected the facility via tele visit on November 4, 2020, at 1:11 PM. During LPA inspection an interview was conducted with supervising facility manager (SFM) and five client’s records were reviewed. During the course of the investigation additional interviews were conducted with three additional facility staff, county social worker (CSW) and three of five clients. Two of five clients declined to participate in LPA interview. On October 29, 2020, the Department received a complaint that alleged a personal rights violation that a staff is entering a resident’s room when the resident is in the room with the door closed. More specifically, that client #1 (See confidential names list LIC 811 January 14, 2021) is made to feel uncomfortable when SFM enters C1’s bedroom without knocking while C1 is changing . Confidential witness’ statements revealed that staff always allow the clients privacy at the facility. (continued on page 2...)

narrative:
An informal conference was held with Ferree’s Group Home Inc. (FGH) to discuss current licensing concerns. Present at the meeting was LaCresha Cook, Regional Manager (RM), Abdoulaye Traore, Licensing Unit Manager, Michael Almaraz, Licensing Program Analyst, FGH Head of Service Mitchica Smith, Ferree’s Group Home #5 Administrator, Alisha Jones, Ferree’s Group Home #3 Executive Director Phillip Ferree, Riverside Behavioral Health Nisha Elliot, San Bernardino County Hannah Gutierrez, Riverside County Jonelle Ross, Riverside County Alan Dominque, Riverside County Probation Juan Bretado, Riverside County Probation Naomi Durley, Riverside County Sofia Williams, Department of Health Care Services Sandi Shelgrove and Department of Health Care Services Dave Gutierrez. The following information was discussed: · Expiration of provisional license. · Medi- Cal certification. · Mental Health program approval. · Closure plan. · RM discussed withdrawal of application. · Facility referred to Community Care Licensing Legal Department for review of Administrative Action. The facility has agreed to the following · Facility has submitted the corrections to insurance that were requested by Riverside Behavioral Health. · Facility has hired a Licensed Vocational Nurse and will submit this information to Mary Walsh with Riverside Behavioral Health by August 31, 2021. · Facility will submit their Mental Health application to the Department of Health Care Services by August 31, 2021. (continued on next page...)

· Facility will submit possible closure plan by September 3, 2021. The possible closure plan will include an update to the counties and the Department of what is occurring and provide dates as to when expected Mental Health Program Approval or closure date of facility. A copy of this report was given and explained to Alisha Jones.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Michael Almaraz and Adaleyci Caballero arrived at the facility to conduct an annual inspection. During the inspection, the facility was inspected inside and out with Facility Manager Tina Willis. The home is a one-story residence with three bedrooms, four bathrooms, three staff offices. Five clients were present at time of inspection. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. LPAs observed vents covered with dirt and dust and walls in need of repair. Bedroom #3 had a cracked bathroom sink. The facility is not clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. The temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured at 111 degrees (F). The medications were stored and locked in a locker in the closet. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Facility Manager Willis. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, and current menu. The facility license was not posted in an area accessible to the public. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the medical room. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. The outside facility grounds were inspected. LPAs observed the outside grounds littered with a washer, refrigerator debris, trash, and an unmaintained overgrown, tilled lawn. There is no swimming pool located at facility, and emergency exits were free from obstruction. (continued on next page...)

A sample of seven staff files were reviewed during the inspection. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. Supervising Facility manager was present at time of inspection, and there were five clients present at time of inspection. Facility cited for violation of Health-Related Services, Building and Grounds, Fixtures, Furniture and Equipment Supplies, Personnel Records, Personnel Requirement, Food Service, Posting of License and Criminal Record Clearance. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to Facility Manager Tina Willis along with a Confidential Names List (LIC 811).

On the above date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, arrived at the facility to continue the the Annual Inspection which was started on September 30, 2021. Due to technical difficulties LPA will have to return at a later date to continue the annual. LPA explained this report to Tisha Robbins and provided her with a copy of the signed report.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, conducted an inspection and met with Supervising Facility Managers, Tina Willis and Tisha Robbins. During the course of an annual inspection on September 29, 2021, LPA observed several violations. The violations included Health-Related Services, Building and Grounds, Fixtures, Furniture and Equipment Supplies, Personnel Records, Personnel Requirement, and Criminal Record Clearance. A plan of correction for the citations was given a date of October 14, 2021. Facility did not meet plan of correction in a timely manner therefore the facility will be cited for failure to correct violations. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report, LIC421FC, and appeal rights was provided to Tina Willis.

Confidential witnesses added that C1 and C2 had conflict, but they had not seen clients inappropriately touching one another. Confidential witnesses added that facility staff increased supervision of C1 after being made aware of the conflict C1 had with C2. County social worker (CSW) stated that she was informed that C2 had poked C1, but it was not in a sexual manner. County social worker 2 (CSW2) stated that he felt that the supervision that staff provided was appropriate. Other confidential witness stated that C2 walked in on C1 while he was changing and pushed C1. Furthermore, it was disclosed that C2 had bothered C1 often, but facility did not do anything to prevent or stop C2’s behavior. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation due to lack of supervision C2 walked in on C1 while C1 was changing clothing and inappropriately touched C1 may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Pat Prior.
investigation_findings: 13On February 8, 2023, at 9:55 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz arrived at the facility and met with facility manager, Pat Prior, to issue the finding for the above stated allegation. On November 1, 2022, at 10:40 AM LPA Almaraz initiated the investigation and conducted a safety inspection. During the safety inspection, LPA interviewed one facility staff, interviewed one of the four clients as listed on the confidential names list (LIC 811) dated February 8, 2023, and reviewed four client records. Additionally, LPA conducted interviews with three county social workers, one staff, two clients, and Riverside Out of Home Investigations (OHI). One of four clients was unavailable for LPA interview. On October 26, 2022, the Department received a complaint that alleged minor inappropriately touched another minor in care. It was specified that due to lack of supervision client 2 (C2) walked in on client 1 (C1) while C1 was changing clothing and inappropriately touched C1. Confidential witnesses stated that staff positioned themselves in the hallway of the facility to supervise the clients when the clients were in their bedroom.(continued on page 2...)

narrative: During the investigation, confidential witnesses stated that S1 treated all clients equally and S1 did not demonstrate favoritism. County social worker (CSW) stated that she was not informed that C1 was treated differently than other clients. County social worker 2 (CSW2) stated that he was not informed that some clients were treated better than others. Other confidential witnesses stated that S1 treated client 2 (C2) better than other clients and they felt that S1 mistreated C1. Regarding the allegation that S1 called C1 names confidential witnesses stated that they had not heard S1 call C1 any names and that it was C1 who called S1 names. CSW stated that she was not informed that S1 called C1 names. Other confidential witnesses stated that they had heard S1 call C1 names. LPA receive inconsistent information. In regard to the allegation that C1 was not accorded dignity and respect and S1 would tell other staff and clients that S1 did not like C1. Confidential witnesses stated that they had not heard S1 say to C1, staff, and clients that S1 did not like C1. CSW stated that she was not told that S1 or any staff had said they disliked C1. Other confidential witnesses stated that they heard S1 saying that S1 did not like C1. LPA received conflicting information. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that S1 did not treat clients equally, S1 spoke inappropriately to C1, and S1 did not accord C1 dignity and respect while in care, may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Pat Prior.
investigation_findings: 13On February 8, 2023, at 10:54 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz arrived at the facility and met with facility manager, Pat Prior, to issue the finding for the above stated allegations. On August 23, 2022 at 10:21 AM, LPA Almaraz initiated the investigation and conducted a safety inspection. During the safety inspection, LPA interviewed two facility staff and reviewed three client records (see confidential names list LIC 811) dated February 8, 2023. Additionally, LPA conducted interviews with three county social workers, one staff, and two of three clients. One of three clients was unavailable for interview. On August 15, 2022, the Department received a complaint that staff do not treat minors in care equally, staff do not speak appropriately to minor in care and staff did not accord minor in care dignity and respect. It was specified that staff #1 (S1) demonstrated favoritism to certain clients, S1 called client #1 (C1) inappropriate names, and S1 would tell C1, other clients and staff that S1 did not like C1. (continued on page 2...)

narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff did not ensure minor attended school, it was specified that the facility has allowed C1 to miss 52 days of school. During investigation, confidential interview stated that facility has many in-house incident reports about C1’s lack of school attendance. It was added that C1 and other client would procrastinate then be late to school. Additionally, it was stated that the facility would make multiple trips to school so no client would be late due to others taking to long to get ready. Confidential interview stated staff would encourage clients to get ready earlier so they could arrive to school on time. Additional confidential interview stated that C1 would always be late to school by choice. It was added that staff would encourage C1 to be on time and explained the importance of being at school and on time. Another confidential interview stated that it was staff’s fault C1 was late to school because staff would take C1 to school late. It was added that sometimes the staff would take too long and so C1 would refuse to go to school rather than be late. LPA received conflicting information. In regard to the allegation that staff did not ensure minor attended appointment, it was specifically alleged that C1 had driver’s training and staff wouldn’t get C1 up after informing staff about the appointment in the same morning. Confidential interviews disclosed that messages would be received over the weekend for appointments for the following day, but the problem was that only facility managers have access to the voicemail box. It was added that drivers training was never confirmed with staff. Additionally confidential interview stated that staff ensured they went to their appointments and got them there on time. Another confidential interview stated that C1’s mother called and left a message over the weekend about drivers training but that the day of the training staff did not wake C1 up and C1 missed the appointment. LPA received conflicting information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff did not ensure C1 attended school and staff did not ensure C1 attended appointment may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was reviewed and provided to facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On February 16, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez arrived at Ferree’s Group Home and met with Supervising Facility Manager Tina Willis to deliver the finding for the allegations stated above involving the GH staff (S1 & S2) and clients (C1 & C2) as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated February 16, 2023. On June 27, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff did not ensure minor attended school and that staff did not ensure minor attended appointment. On July 06, 2022, at 10:39 AM, LPA Almaraz initiated the investigation at the GH and obtained documents from the files and conducted a safety inspection. There were no immediate hazards observed. LPA interviewed S1, S2, and C2. LPA was unable to contact the County Social Worker. On February 02, 2023, LPA Almaraz conducted collateral interview for C1.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, was met at the facility by manager Shane Williamson. The purpose of the site inspection was to address information that was obtained on May 15, 2022. It was discovered that the facility had a change in Head of Services. The facility did not have a Head of Service at the time of inspection and had not had a Head of Service since November 10, 2022. LPA contacted facility administrator, Alisha Jones, during time of inspection to verify the information. Ms. Jones verified that there had not been a Head of Service since November 2022. This is a violation of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 4 section 87061(f) Reporting Requirements which states the licensee shall notify the Department, in writing, within ten (10) *calendar* days of any change in the mental health program head of service, See page 2 for violation cited. Exit interview conducted with Mr. Williamson and a copy of this report was also provided and explained along with the Appeal Rights.

deficiencies.description: 87061 REPORTING REQUIREMENTS (f) The licensee shall notify the Department, in writing, within ten (10) calendar days of any change in the mental health program head of service. Based on confidential interviews and record review,... the facility had not had a head of service since November 10, 2022 and the Department had not been informed of this change which poses a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per facility administrator the facility will retrain staff on reporting requirements 87061(f) and provide proof of training to LPA by the POC due date. The facility will also continue to advertise and conduct interviews for a new head of service.

narrative: On June 28, 2023, at 1:19 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Michael Almaraz, conducted an annual inspection. Facility manager Shane Williamson granted LPA access into the facility. There were four out four clients present during the inspection. A physical plant inspection was completed at 1:27 PM and included the following checks: Facility grounds were clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There was adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were in appropriate working order. The fire extinguishers were properly charged and serviced. LPA observed adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the facility appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, visitation policies, personal rights, and Foster Care Ombudsman posters. Medications were locked and centrally stored in a locked closet. The hot water temperature was measured, and it was within the range. Facility had cameras in common areas of the facility. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Based on observation the facility is being cited on the following area: Physical plant. Deficiencies were observed and cited on 809Ds. A case management inspection will be conducted at a later date to complete the annual inspection. Exit interview was conducted, 809 and 809Ds were provided and deficiencies were advised to Shane Williamson.

Confidential witness stated that clients had not been provided with marijuana or cigarettes from staff. Confidential witnesses added that they had not witnessed or been informed that staff were smoking at the facility. County social worker 7 (CSW7) stated that she was not informed that staff provided clients with contraband or staff smoked at the facility. County social worker 3 (CSW3) stated that he did not suspect staff were providing the clients with contraband. Additionally, CSW3 reported that he was never told that staff smoked at the facility and CSW3 never observed signs that staff were smoking at the facility. Other confidential witnesses maintained that staff provided clients with marijuana and cigarettes and staff smoked at the facility. Based on confidential interviews and records review, the allegations staff gave C1 marijuana and cigarettes, and that facility staff would smoke at the facility may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Tina Willis.
investigation_findings: 13On July 20, 2023, at 3:15 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, arrived at the facility and met with facility manager, Tina Willis, to issue the finding for the above stated allegations. On April 18, 2023, at 9:09 AM LPA Almaraz arrived at the facility to initiate the investigation and conducted a safety inspection. During the safety inspection, LPA interviewed two facility staff, interviewed two clients, and reviewed six client’s records. Additionally, LPA conducted interviews with six of seven clients (C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7) listed on the confidential names list (LIC 811) dated July 20, 2023, two county social workers, and one additional staff. LPA Almaraz was unable to interview one of seven clients due to the client’s parents declining the interview. On April 10, 2023, the Department received a complaint that alleged staff were providing marijuana to children in care, staff were providing cigarettes to children in care, and staff were smoking in the facility. More specifically, it was alleged that staff gave client #1 (C1) marijuana and cigarettes, and facility staff would smoke at the facility. (continued on page 2...)

narrative: Confidential witnesses stated that on the evening of the incident, the clients at the facility were rowdy and not following staff directives. In addition, it was disclosed to LPA that C2 had a broom and entered C1’s bedroom while C1 slept and poked C1 with the broom handle. It was reported to LPA that staff was present, and C2 did this against the staff’s orders not to enter C1’s room. Confidential interviews stated that the County Social Worker (CSW) was informed that the clients were joking around, and CSW was never told that C1 did not feel safe at the facility. Furthermore, CSW stated that facility staff always provided suitable client supervision. Other confidential witnesses stated that when the incident occurred, staff were not present, and staff did not attempt to redirect C2. LPA received conflicting information regarding the staff supervision surrounding the incident. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation that staff did not prevent an inappropriate sexual interaction between minors (C1 and C2) while in care is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Tina Willis.
investigation_findings: 13On January 26, 2024, at 10:02 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz arrived at the facility and met with Supervising Manager, Tina Willis, to issue the finding for the above stated allegation. On August 16, 2023, at 11:47 AM, LPA Almaraz conducted a health and safety inspection, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the inspection, LPA reviewed six clients’ (C1-C6) records (see confidential names list LIC 811 dated January 26, 2024) and conducted interviews with two (C4 and C5) of the six clients, a County Social Worker (CSW5), and one staff (S4). Additionally, LPA interviewed three clients (C2, C3, C6) two County Social Workers, and three staff members. One of six clients (C1) refused to participate in the LPA interview. On August 7, 2023, the Department received a lack of supervision complaint alleging that staff did not prevent an inappropriate sexual interaction between minors (C1 and C2) while in care. More specifically, due to a lack of supervision on August 4, 2023, C2 inappropriately touched C1 with an object. (continued on page 2...)

narrative: Additionally, confidential witnesses revealed that facility staff did refuse to accept C1 back to the facility. LPA was provided with copy of the policy that prohibits weapons on facility grounds. LPA received other information that C1 was not arrested, and it was unknown if C1 ever had the gun at the facility. LPA received conflicting information regarding the allegation. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation that C1 was not allowed to return to the facility after being arrested with a gun may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Alisha Jones.
investigation_findings: 13On May 1, 2024, at 10:08 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz met with facility administrator, Alisha Jones, to issue the finding for the above stated allegations. On September 18, 2023, at 10:13 AM, LPA Almaraz initiated the investigation and conducted a safety inspection, no deficiencies were noted. During the inspection LPA interviewed one facility staff and reviewed two of six client’s records (see confidential names list LIC 811 dated May 1, 2024). Additionally, LPA conducted interviews with four clients, three county social workers, and four staff. Two of four clients were not interviewed due to LPA being unable to locate one client who was absent without leave (AWOL) and LPA being unable to contact another client.
