narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi on May 20, 2024 at 11:43 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Choi met with Administrator Alisha Jones. LPA Choi conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility. LPA reviewed one child’s records and three staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed one child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed two staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. During the facility visit, one child that is prescribed psychotropic medication, was interviewed. After a record review, one Technical Advisory is being provided and one Type B deficiency is being cited at this time: ILS 87070(b)(14)(F): (b) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child’s record: (14)*A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following: (F) The date and time of each dose taken by the child. See LIC 809D. LPA conducted an exit interview with Administrator Alisha Jones and provided a copy of this report and appeals rights.

deficiencies.description:
ILS 87070(b)(14)(F): (b) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child’s record: (14)*A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following: (F) The date and time of each dose taken by the child. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: 

The facility did not have proper documentation as it related to a client's home pass visit. It was documented in the facility's PMAR that the client went on a home pass but there was no documentation as to whether the client's medication was dispersed during their visit with biological family.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will institute a functional home pass documentation system as it relates to ensuring the caregiver of a client is informed on how and when to disperse a client's psychotropic medication while on a home pass visit.

narrative:
It was specified that staff did not prevent C1 from being bullied by other clients, staff bullied C1, staff did not protect C1 from other clients, and staff did not allow C1 to contact C1’s parent or responsible party when there were concerns for C1’s safety. Additionally, it was reported that staff allow clients to smoke marijuana and blow smoke in C1’s face and staff did not prevent clients from taking C1’s food and destroying C1’s property. Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent C1 from being bullied by other clients. Confidential witnesses stated that staff did not allow bullying to take place and staff would redirect bullying behavior. County social worker 5 (CSW5) stated that they were never informed that bullying was occurring or that staff was allowing their client or other clients to be bullied. Other confidential witness stated that most staff prevent and redirect bullying but one staff allowed it. An additional confidential witness stated that they were informed that staff was allowing C1 to be bullied by other clients. In reference to the allegation that staff bullied C1. Confidential witnesses stated that they had not observed staff bullying C1 or been informed that staff was bullying clients. County social worker 3 (CSW3) stated that staff had good interaction with their client and CSW3 was never informed that staff were mean or bullies to clients. Other confidential witnesses stated that they were informed staff were mean, one staff calls clients names, and a staff pushed a client. Concerning the allegation that staff did not protect C1 from other clients. Confidential witnesses stated that facility staff always protect clients and redirect clients when they become aggressive with one another. County social worker 5 (CSW5) stated that they were never informed that staff allowed clients to behave aggressively toward one another. Another confidential witness stated that C1 was slapped by other clients when staff was not present. With regard to the allegation that staff did not allow C1 to contact his parent or responsible party. Confidential witnesses stated that they had never seen clients denied the telephone. Additionally, it was reported to LPA that C1 was often on the phone for long periods of time and would get upset if other clients or staff needed to use the phone. County social worker (CSW) stated that they were informed that staff would not allow C1 to use phone to contact approved individuals. (continued on page 3...)

***This is an amended report which was originally issued on page 5/1/24*** For the allegation that staff allowed clients to smoke marijuana and blow smoke in C1’s face. It was revealed to LPA by confidential witnesses that facility staff did not allow marijuana use. Additionally, it was reported to LPA that staff would document any drug use and notify client’s authorized representatives immediately. Another confidential witness stated that they observed staff allow clients to smoke marijuana in the facility on at least one occasion. In relation to the allegation that staff did not safeguard C1’s belongings or staff were not preventing C1 from having C1’s food taken away. Confidential witnesses informed LPA that staff did not allow clients in rooms that did not belong to them. Additionally, LPA was informed that staff would intervene if they observed a client’s food being taken by another client. CSW3 couldn’t recall being informed of their client having had items stolen or food taken from them. Other confidential witnesses stated that clients had items stolen and they felt it was due to staff not properly safeguarding client’s belongings. LPA received conflicting information regarding all the allegations. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations: staff did not prevent C1 from being bullied by other clients, staff bullied C1, staff did not protect C1 from other clients, staff did not allow C1 to contact C1’s parent or responsible party when there were concerns for C1’s safety, staff allow clients to smoke marijuana and blow smoke in C1’s face and staff did not prevent clients from taking C1’s food and destroying C1’s property may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Tina Willis.

narrative:
Confidential witnesses informed LPA that sometimes the refrigerator did not have adequate amount of food and when clients would ask staff to restock the refrigerator staff would say no. An additional confidential witness informed LPA that they observed the facility with an inadequate amount of food. During LPA inspection LPA observed the refrigerator did not have an adequate amount of food. LPA observed the refrigerator to have a half full gallon of milk, half a loaf of sandwich bread, lettuce, condiments, and a packet of deli meat. The freezer had a few frozen meals, and a package of ground meat. The pantry had seven cans of different canned meats, vegetables and fruit. Regarding the allegation that the facility was in disrepair with a broken window that did not operate appropriately. Confidential witnesses informed LPA that the bedroom window was broken and not properly working. Additionally, LPA was informed that due to the window being broken the bedroom would be either too hot or too cold. During LPA inspection LPA observed a bedroom window in disrepair and not functioning properly. LPA observed the window had been repaired but the new glass that was installed did not fit properly allowing for air to come in from outside the facility. Based on confidential interviews and inspection, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that facility was not stocked with sufficient amounts of food and the facility was in disrepair. Therefore, the allegations are substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5 Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Articles 1 Through 10, Version 5, 87072(c)(2) Personal Rights and Title 22 80087(a) Building and Grounds.

when they requested records. Confidential witnesses stated that facility staff ensured children’s dietary needs were met. County social worker (CSW) informed LPA that C1 did not have special dietary needs. Another confidential witness informed LPA that C4 had special dietary needs which staff were informed of, but staff did not purchase special food products for C4. In reference to the allegation that the facility’s ventilation system did not work properly leading to the facility being at an uncomfortable temperature. LPA was informed by confidential witnesses that the facility was always at a comfortable temperature. CSW and county social worker 3 (CSW3) informed LPA that during their visits to the facility the facility was at a comfortable temperature. During LPA inspection the facility was at an appropriate temperature. Other confidential witnesses informed LPA that the facility was sometimes too hot and other times too cold. LPA received conflicting information regarding this allegation. Regarding the allegation that staff did not provide child’s records to authorized person. LPA was informed by confidential witnesses that staff always provided any and all records to children’s authorized person. Another confidential witness informed LPA that it may be possible that staff did not provide children’s authorized person records that were requested. Additionally, LPA was informed that some documents that were requested from the facility were not provided to client’s authorized person. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that the facility did not meet C1’s special dietary needs, the ventilation system was not working properly causing the facility to be at an uncomfortable temperature, and facility was not responsive to client’s authorized representatives when they requested records may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Tina Willis.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, *and below,* as applicable (2) To receive adequate and healthy food... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential witness interviews and inspection the facility did not have adequate amounts of food. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per facility manager the facility will create a purchase log for the weekly groceries and document that the kitchen refrigerator was loaded. narrative: Regarding the allegation that C1 smoked in the facility confidential witnesses informed LPA that facility staff did not allow clients to smoke at the facility, but some clients smoked in their bedrooms anyway. Additionally, LPA was informed that clients smoked vape pens when staff were not present. LPA was informed vape pens did not release a strong scent which made it difficult for staff to notice if clients were smoking. Other complaint information revealed that C1 smoked inside the facility. In relation to the allegation that C1 had gone AWOL from the facility several times confidential witnesses informed LPA that staff would redirect clients when staff suspected that clients were going to go AWOL. Furthermore, it was disclosed to LPA that facility staff would shadow clients, offer clients other options when clients were going AWOL, and search for clients in the community when clients went AWOL. LPA was informed by another confidential witness that C1 went AWOL from the facility over three times, and they did not believe that the facility staff did enough to prevent C1’s AWOL. Concerning the allegation that C1 missed three mental health appointments confidential witnesses informed LPA that C1 would refuse to attend mental health and other appointments. Additionally, LPA was informed that when the facility would reschedule C1’s appointments C1 would refuse them again. During confidential witness interviews LPA was informed that the other children attended their appointments and staff would ensure that they did not miss any appointments. Other confidential witness revealed that facility staff did not ensure that C1 attended C1’s appointments and staff did not reschedule missed appointments for C1. LPA received conflicting information regarding this allegation. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that C1 smoked in the facility, C1 had gone AWOL several times, and C1 missed three mental health appointments may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Tina Willis.

narrative: On November 20, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Babatunde Aborchie, conducted an annual inspection. Facility manager, Tina Willis, granted LPA access into the facility. LPA arrived to conduct a continuation to an annual inspection initiated on November 14, 2024. During the inspection LPA conducted a review of Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention Plan, Staffing Records, Client Records, and Core/Therapeutic Services. No deficiencies were found during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to facility manager, Tina Willis.

On November 14, 2024, licensing program analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie conducted an unannounced annual inspection. LPA met with facility manager {FM} Tina Willis and administrator (A1), Alisha Jones. The facility was toured inside and out with A1. There were three clients in placement, all three clients were present during the walk through. Bedrooms were set up so there were two clients per room and one client per bed. There was adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were observed to be clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client master restroom was measured to be 112 degrees Fahrenheit. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications and sharp knives were made inaccessible and stored in a locked hallway closet near the cool down room. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a cabinet in the activity room. The facility's smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector were checked and were operable. There were no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by A1. All Client bedrooms had proper window screens, and they were in good condition. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: fire evacuation procedures, facility disaster plan, personal rights, and foster care ombudsman poster. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients. The facility outside grounds was inspected and it was observed to be clean, and the landscape well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There was no swimming pool located on the facility grounds. There were no deficiencies observed at the time of inspection. LPA will continue the inspection later. A copy of this report was provided to Tina Willis, administrator.

Community Care Licensing received information on September 25, 2024, alleging that staff do not prevent minor from being harassed and staff do not prevent minor from being physically abused by other minors while in care. It was specified that client #1(C1) has been picked on and beat up by other boys in the STRTP. It was further reported that C1 was afraid to tell the staff what has been happening due to fears it would make things worse with the other boys. There were no specific details or incidents reported. Confidential interviews stated not witnessing harassment or abuse from the clients in the STRTP. Other confidential interviews stated C1 would disrupt the other clients in care and would call some of the boys’ racial slurs. A confidential interview stated clients would respond to C1’s constant instigation. Another confidential interview stated staff try to prevent physical altercations between the clients by de-escalation techniques and taking them out for a drive. Additional interviews reported that there were no witnesses to physical abuse or harassment in the STRTP between clients in care. County Social Workers stated not having concerns regarding the stated allegations. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff do no prevent C1 from being harassed and staff do not prevent C1 from being physically abused by other clients in care may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the alleged violations. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and Appeal Rights were provided to Tina Willis

narrative: On October 2, 2024, Community Care Licensing received information alleging that staff member physically abuses minor in care and staff member caused injury to minor in care. It was specifically alleged that at the STRTP staff #2(S2), and Client #2(C2) physically abuse C1. It was reported that C1 was seen with a fat lip and bloody nose. Other confidential interviews denied witnessing C1 with a fatty lip. Three confidential interviews reported that C1 obtained a bloody nose from a physical altercation with client #3(C3). Other confidential interviews did not have information on the alleged violations. County social workers stated not receiving reports on physical abuse or physical punishment at the STRTP. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that S2 physically abuses C1 in care and S2 caused injury to C1 may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and Appeal Rights were provided to Tina Willis

narrative:
Regarding the allegation that staff member transported minors in care in an unsafe manner, it was alleged that staff #1(S1) was seen driving C2, C3, and C4 in a vehicle without the clients’ seatbelts fastened through a social media post. It was further reported that the vehicle was moving, and clients’ seatbelts were not fastened. S1 admitted that S1 was taking C2 and C4 out shopping to Ontario Mills and C2 and C4 took their seatbelts off on their way to the mall. S1 stated that S1 continued to drive to the mall even though C2 and C4 had their seatbelts off. Another confidential interview stated that staff do not have control over the clients’ decisions and S1 just tells the clients to put their seatbelt on. One confidential interview stated that S1 does not drive in an unsafe manner, but S1 advises clients to put their seatbelts on, but clients choose to take their seat belts off. Some confidential interviews stated not having any knowledge of the allegation. Other confidential interviews refused to provide any information regarding the allegation. County Social Worker stated having concerns about the clients not having their seatbelts on during transportation. In regard to the allegation that staff member did not prevent minors in care from possessing alcohol, it was specifically alleged that S1 was seen in a vehicle with C2, C3, and C4 through a social media post. It was further indicated that C2 and C4 had alcohol bottles in their hands while S1 was driving the vehicle. S1 admitted to C2 and C4 already having the alcohol bottle when S1 was driving C2 and C4 to the mall. S1 admitted that S1 didn’t take the bottle from the clients because they were already on their way to the mall, and S1 was the only staff with C2 and C4. S1 admitted to driving the clients C2 and C4 to the mall with alcohol in the client’s possession. S1 reported that the alcohol was discarded when they returned from the mall. One confidential interview stated that S1 did not know that the clients had the alcohol bottles. The same interview stated that S1 was not paying attention because S1 was driving and when S1 realized the clients had alcohol in their possession, S1 made the clients throw out the alcohol at the mall. Other confidential interviews stated not having any knowledge regarding the alleged violation. County Social Worker stated not receiving any reports regarding the alleged violation. Regarding the allegation staff do not report incident(s) involving minors in care as necessary, it was reported that staff do not report all incidents that occur to avoid doing paperwork. Confidential interviews stated that all incidents regarding the health and safety of the clients in care are reported to Community Care Licensing. Records reviews indicate that the above incidents regarding seatbelts not being fastened while clients being transported and clients having alcohol in their possession were not reported to Community Care Licensing.

Based on confidential interviews and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the allegations that staff #1(S1) transported clients in care in an unsafe manner, S1 did not prevent minors in care from possessing alcohol, and staff do not report incident(s) involving clients in care as necessary are substantiated at this time. The facility is being cited for the violation Title 22 General Licensing Requirements Reporting Requirements 80061(b)(E) and Interim Licensing Standards 87065.2 (b)(1) Personnel Duties on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC9099D, Appeal Rights, and LIC811 was provided to Facility Manager Tina Willis.

LPA obtained photographic evidence of the above incidents.

deficiencies.description:
Upon the occurrence, …, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours… (E) Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens... This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on record review and interviews, The STRTP did not report that incident involving clients drinking
alcohol bottles during an outing with staff #1 and clients’ seatbelts were not fastened. This poses a potential health and safety or personal rights risks to the clients in care.

This poses a potential health and safety or personal rights risk to the clients in care.

narrative:
Regarding the allegations that staff did not provide a safe environment for children in care and staff conduct poses a risk to children in care, it was alleged that on January 29, 2025, the Facility Manager’s ex-boyfriend tried to break into the STRTP to get to the Facility Manager. It was specifically alleged that clients in the home attempted to stop the male from trying to attack the Facility Manager. Furthermore, it was reported that the clients in care were all in the street fighting with the male, law enforcement was called out to the home, and no one was hurt. During the investigation, a confidential interview stated that Adult #1(A1) came inside the STRTP to fight a resident because the resident said something to the Facility Manager (FM) that A1 did not like while the FM was on the phone with A1 prior to A1’s arrival to the STRTP. Another confidential interview stated not witnessing the incident, but it was reported that client #1(C1) saw A1 inside the STRTP assisting FM with FM’s belongings and C1 was verbally aggressive to A1 because C1 wanted to start something with A1. The same interview stated that FM and A1 were already inside their car getting ready to leave when C1 opened their car door and started swinging at A1 and a fight broke out. One confidential interview stated that C1 was arguing with FM while FM was on the phone with A1. Then, A1 showed up to the STRTP and C1 was following A1 and FM to the car and C1 opened the door and A1 got out and A1 and C1 started to fight. One confidential interview stated that C1 was being verbally aggressive towards FM and when A1 picked up FM from FM’s shift at the STRTP, C1 opened the driver’s side door and assaulted A1. Then, A1 got out of the vehicle and responded while staff #2(S2) was assisting in blocking C1. The interview continued by stating that C1 got away from S2 and ran towards an opened field to grab a metal pipe and assaulted A1 with the metal pipe. The same interview reported that C1 was hit by A1 once during the physical altercation. An additional confidential interview reported that C1 had been harassing FM the entire morning during FM’s shift and making threats to FM. The confidential interview continued stating that FM was leaving for the day and A1 was waiting for FM at the STRTP’s front door. Then, C1 began to yell at A1 and A1 got upset and FM walked A1 to their car. C1 went around the house and opened A1’s car door and began to assault A1. A1 got out the car and confronted C1. The interviewer tried to deescalate C1 and asked FM to walk A1 up the street; however, C1 got a hold of a metal pipe and hit A1 on the head. The interviewer stated C1, and A1 exchanged punches and law enforcement showed up. County social worker stated not having concerns on the safety in the STRTP because C1 was the aggressor.

Based on confidential interviews and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the allegations that staff did not provide a safe environment for children in care and staff conduct poses a risk to children in care are substantiated at this time. The facility is being cited for the violation of Interim Licensing Standards 87078.2 (a)(3) Trauma Informed Interventions and Treatment Practices and 87065.2 (b)(1) Personnel Duties on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC9099D, Appeal Rights, and LIC811 were provided to Facility Manager Tina Willis.

narrative: Regarding the allegations that staff do not prevent minor from being bullied by other minors while in care and staff did not provide a safe environment for minor; it was specifically alleged that client #1 had self-harming thoughts due to the treatment C1 was receiving from the clients at the STRTP. It was additionally reported that C3 was heard name calling C1 during a phone conversation with C1. Furthermore, it was reported that C3 had threated to kill C1. During investigation, a confidential interview stated that C1 would antagonize the clients, and C1 would say C1 was going to take revenge on them by hurting them. The same interview reported witnessing clients call C1 names, but they were redirected by staff. Other confidential interviews stated that C1 was not called any names and clients in care left C1 alone. Another confidential interview stated that C1 would bully the other clients in care and caused drama at the STRTP. The same interview reported that C1 had a 1:1 supervision during C1’s short stay at the STRTP. Confidential interviews did not witness C3 threatening C1. Other information stated the violations occurred. In regard to the allegations that staff member mismanaged minor's medications, and minor did not receive medications as prescribed, it was alleged that client #1(C1) had not received medications and staff were aware of the situation and were not putting any protective measures in place. A confidential interview stated that when C1 was placed at the STRTP C1 came with a bag of medications but without forms or instructions on the medications. The same interview stated that it appeared that the medication was old because C1 was on runaway status for a long time before being placed at the STRTP. Another confidential interview stated that when the STRTP finally received C1’s JV220 and medications, C1 would refuse to take C1’s medication because C1 would say that the medications would make C1 sleepy. One confidential interview stated C1 did not have a psychiatric appointment because C1 was placed at the STRTP for only a week. Other confidential interviews did not have information regarding the alleged violations. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff do not prevent client #1 from being bullied by other minors while in care, staff did not provide a safe environment for client #1, and staff mismanaged client #1’s medications, and client #1 did not receive medications as prescribed may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, Appeal Rights, and LIC811 were provided to Facility Manager Tina Willis.

narrative: On November 12, 2024, Community Care Licensing received information alleging that staff did not ensure the facility was stocked with a sufficient amount of food and staff do not safeguard minor’s personal belongings. It was alleged that the facility was in poor condition and there was a lack of food with no details. Confidential interviews stated that there was always food at the facility, but clients sometimes didn’t like the food. A confidential interview stated food is always stocked and a supply of food is always stored in a storage closet. Another confidential interview stated that C1 would throw away his food and ask for different types of food and staff would try to accommodate C1’s needs. County social worker did not have concerns about the amount of food at the STRTP. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Regarding the allegation that staff do not safeguard minor’s personal belongings, It was reported that staff would take money from the residents as well as steal their belongings such as personal items and food with no further details. Confidential interviews stated that clients would receive their allowance on a weekly basis. A confidential interview stated that at one-point C1’s cash allowance was withheld due to substance abuse, but C1 would still receive the allowance in a gift card. Other confidential interviews did not witness stealing from staff members. One confidential stated that clients would take belongings from each other here and there, but did not remember the details or the clients specifically. County Social Worker did not have concerns about the alleged violation. County Social Worker stated that C1 had a history of giving away personal belongings. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff did not ensure the facility was stocked with a sufficient amount of food and staff do not safeguard client #1’s personal belongings may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and Appeal Rights were provided to Tina Willis.

Client #1’s(C1) interview was unsuccessful due to C1 running away during LPA’s visit at C1’s school. LPA reviewed pertinent documents from client’s files.

narrative: On 6/10/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the Field Comprehensive Youth Services facility for the purpose of a Case Management Incident inspection, LPA met with Facility Manager Lekeba Riley and discussed the following: On 5/10/2021 the department received an Unusual incident report identifying a child leaving this facility and returning to facility without being searched prior to entry back into the facility. Facility manager stated the following: Staff that were present during the incident had been employed with facility for a couple of weeks. Staff had received all required training's and shadowing prior to working afternoon shift. However, staff were unsure on procedures for searching children upon returning to facility. Staff documented incident and reported incident to required entities of incident and what was observed from child #1 (C1) placing an unknown object into their jacket. Facility manager stated that staff were retrained on searching procedures and provided verbal guidance for future incidents. Child #1 (C1) has been removed from facility. LPA requested copies of all completed staff training's for staff #1 and 2. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was left with facility manager.

The Department received a report alleging a client threatened another client with a gun, a client consumed contraband at the facility, and contraband is present at the facility. FM denied the allegations. It was reported Ref #2 threatened to cause harm to Ref #1 and wielded a gun at Ref #1. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted did not reveal witnesses who observed Ref #2 threaten to harm Ref #1. Furthermore, confidential interviews conducted indicated there are no weapons at the facility. It was reported Ref #1 consumed contraband at the facility. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted revealed clients leave the facility without permission to consume contraband, and not at the facility. Based on information gathered through interviews conducted and records reviewed the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have occurred or are valid, the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.

During the course of the investigation LPA Larios conducted interviews with one client on 6/11/21, three clients on 6/16/21, one client on 10/26/21, two County Social Workers (CSW) on 10/22/21 and one Facility Manager (FM) on 10/22/21. Three CSW’s were not available for statement and one client was not located for statement. (Reference Confidential Names list LIC811 dated 10/27/21.

narrative: On 06/21/2021, the Department received a complaint alleging that a staff handled a client in a rough manner. The focused staff (FS) who was identified in the referral denied the allegation that he hit or handled a client in a rough manner on 06/17/2021, two other staff workers who were present corroborated the explanation and has denied any form of abuse towards the client(s). The FS explained after retrieving some contraband items from a client's bedroom, it was reported that the one focused client (FC) was agitated and was walking behind him in a very aggressive manner and believed that he was going to be attacked. The FS worker turn around and bumped into the focused client, causing the FC to loose his balance and fell on top of his bed. No injuries were reported. Interviews obtained by several staff workers denied the allegation and stated that clients at the facility are never mistreated. All staff workers commented that the FS worker is not that type of a person that would intentionally treat a client in a rough manner. In confidential interviews, the one focused client (FC) declined to provide a statement related the incident that occurred on 6/17/2021. Other clients when interviewed stated that they have no direct information to provide as one client was not present and the other clients stated "I did not see anything and will not provide any information, including they could not recall the specifics of the alleged allegation. Statements provided by the clients interviewed stated they have no complaints about staff working at the facility. The assigned county social worker (CSW) for the one focused client (FC) does not believe the allegation and stated that the FC has a history of being defiant. The CSW has no concerns about staff working at the facility. The interviews revealed that there was some form of contact between one staff and one client that was described as being an accidental contact. However, statements obtained could not corroborate the allegation reported. Therefore, the above allegation is determined unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. An exit interview was conducted and copy of this report was provided to the facility representative for review and signature. No deficiencies were cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/10/21 at 12:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joseph Vargas conducted a follow-up inspection for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint. During the inspection LPA requested for review and obtained copy of the staff and client facility roster reports, special incident reports, clients Needs and Service Plan and placement history, including a review of the county report associated to this complaint investigation.

narrative: On 11/16/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the Field Comprehensive Youth Services facility for the purpose of a Case Management Incident inspection, LPA met with Facility Manager Lekeba Riley and discussed the following incidents: On 7/7/2021 the department received an Unusual incident report identifying facility filing a Child Protective Services (CPS) report regarding a child grooming another child in the facility. House manager stated the following: Children were horse playing around and the horseplay became a little too sexual. Facility immediately completed an incident report and telephoned therapist who directed staff to file a child abuse report. On 7/8/2021 children were given the option to attend a CFT meeting to discuss the incident, however, children declined. Additionally, a request was made to have C1 removed from same bedroom as C2. Based on request for removal facility staff removed C1 from a shared bedroom to a room by themselves. LPA, observed no deficiencies regarding this incident as facility followed their policies in procedures in reporting and addressing the issue within the required time frame. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was left with House manager.

On 11/16/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the Field Comprehensive Youth Services facility for the purpose of a Case Management Incident inspection, LPA met with Facility Manager Lekeba Riley and discussed the following incidents: On 11/1/2021 the department received an Unusual incident report identifying facility telephoning local law enforcement to come to facility to complete a search for C1. Facility manager stated the following: C1 had returned to facility after being on a run away status. Facility staff conducted a self search of C1. Facility staff observed in C1's sock an outline of a lighter. Staff asked C1 to turn in the lighter and C1 declined. C1 left the premises and when C1 returned staff asked for C1 to complete another self search. C1 declined and staff told C1 that they would seek assistance with searching C1 for contraband. Local law enforcement was called to assist facility staff as the lighter was observed on C1 in previous self search. Officers conducted search of C1 and found contraband. However, officers did not complete a police report based on only providing assistance to facility. Facility manager stated after contraband was located C1 turned in items to facility manager and manager took and discarded items at Administrative offices. Facility staff reported the incident on 11/1/2021 to notify agencies. LPA observed no deficiencies during this inspection. Facility reported the incident within the required time frame and utilized the assistance of local law enforcement in confiscating observed contraband. Exit interview completed no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was left with facility manager.

On 11/16/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the Field Comprehensive Youth Services facility for the purpose of a Case Management Incident inspection, LPA met with Facility Manager Lekeba Riley and discussed the following incidents: On 6/16/2021 the department received an Unusual incident report identifying facility filing a Child Protective Services (CPS) report regarding a child being raped and possibly killing someone. Additionally, on 6/17/2021 the department received another incident report regarding a child taking a bottle of unsecured cold medicine out of the manager’s office. Facility manager stated the following: In regard to the incident report regarding child being raped and possibly killing someone the child stated they had consensual sex with a friend. They stated that they did not want to have sex with them but ended up doing it anyway. When staff was questioning child about what happened and inquiring details as to what transpired child made a statement of if I killed someone would you ask me all these questions. Facility manager stated that no specific information was given of friend who child had sex with or that child killed someone. The incident report with the cold medicine was my personal medication for relieving cough. I had the bottle out in the office. I stepped out of the office to ask a child a question and did not lock or close the door behind me. A child went into the manager’s office and took my bottle of cold medicine and placed it in their pants. I was unable to retrieve the bottle as the child refused to give it back or take it from their pants. The cold medicine contained no alcohol and was an over the counter medication. Based on the information provided by the facility manager LPA identified the following deficiency. 80075 Health Related Services (k) The following requirements shall apply to medications which are centrally stored: (1) Medication shall be kept in a safe and locked place that is not accessible to persons other than employees responsible for the supervision of the centrally stored medication.

LPA requested a copy of completed training for deficiency cited. Exit interview completed, the following deficiency was cited and a copy of this report was left with facility manager.

narrative: On 05/27/2022, the Department received a complaint alleging that clients are allowed to smoke marijuana while at the facility. Staff members who were interviewed denied the allegation that clients are allowed to smoke in the facility, including activities outside of the facility grounds. LPA was informed by some staff members that at times they have caught client(s) smoking or vaping inside their bedroom while conducting routine checks and were able to confiscate the contraband and document the incident. Staff workers, including the Administrator, stated that staff are always present and are working professionally. In confidential interviews, all clients interviewed denied the allegation that staff working at the facility allowed them to smoke marijuana or any other form of tobacco or device such as a vape. Two clients denied that clients ever smoke at the facility and were not aware of others doing so. Other clients admitted smoking marijuana away from the facility. The other clients disclosed that they obtained the marijuana from other students at the school and were smoking on the school grounds. One individual identified as other reportedly disclosed that a client commented that staff knows and does nothing when they see clients smoking. Individual identified as other could not be contacted and therefore no statement was obtained. County Social Worker that was mentioned in the county referral could not be contacted, therefore no statement was obtained. When interviewed, the County Emergency Response Worker (ER) did not have any immediate concerns at that time. Statements obtained could not corroborate the allegation reported. Therefore, the above allegation of neglect/lack of supervision is determined unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility representative for review and signature. No deficiencies were cited at this time

narrative: On 10/7/2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Fields Comprehensive Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of a Case management incident inspection. LPA met with facility manager Lekeba Riley and discussed the below identified incidents: 1. Tylenol bottle found in child room 2. Empty Nyquil bottle found in child room Facility manager stated the following: Both incidents were involving the same client. One bottle was discovered during a room check administered on client’s room. The other bottle was presented to the therapist by client for no known reason. We do not administer over the counter medications to the children, so we believe child is stealing the items from the store. Child is on psychotropic medications and was transferred from our sister location where it was noted of child’s behavior. The facility conducts room checks frequently and continue to monitor children with community passes to be aware and prevent any incidents such as this from occurring again. LPA obtained emailed copies of child’s needs and service plan, medication log and any case notes involving incidents of child storing or stealing medications. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited, and a copy of this report was left with facility manager

Based on the information gathered, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was met, therefore the allegation is substantiated per California Code of Regulations Title 22 – refer to LIC9099-D for deficiencies. investigation_findings: 13On August 8, 2022 at 11:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joshua Rarela conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegation above. During the course of the investigation, LPA Rarela interviewed the facility manager (see Confidential Names Form dated August 8, 2022). LPA Rarela also reviewed documents including facility incident reports and placing agency service logs. It was alleged that the facility is out of ratio. The investigation revealed that the facility had only one staff on shift during the night when incidents occurred where facility clients engaged in physical altercation, an incident where a client was aggressive toward staff requiring law enforcement to be summoned, and incident where clients left the facility during the night without permission. (CONTINUED)

deficiencies.description:
87065.5(a)(2) DIRECT CARE STAFF/CHILD RATIOS - During the hours of 10 pm to 7 am, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum.

This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on the information obtained, it was determined that only one staff was present at the facility during the night shift, a finding which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The facility will re-assign current staff to fill the need in having a facility manager and a direct care staff during the hours noted in the regulation.

The plan of correction will be provided to the LPA by the due date.

narrative: On 5/4/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Fields Comprehensive Youth Services STRTP for the purpose of a case management- incident inspection. LPA met with and discussed the below identified incident: 1. February 6, 2023 Client that was not himself, would be skipping around, crying and was transported to Montclair Hospital for medical reasons. Facility manager stated the following: Child was transported to hospital due to child acting unusual. Staff observed child acting erratic throughout the day and staff called local law enforcement to have child assessed. Law enforcement instructed staff to call paramedics. Child was transported to hospital and diagnosed with alcohol poisoning and a fever and was released back to the facility staff. Child admitted to drinking alcohol but did not disclose to staff where alcohol was obtained. Special incident report notifying all associated agencies was submitted February 7, 2023. LPA requested facility case notes of day and days prior to incident occurring; child's last two CFT meeting notes, any documented emails from county or probation regarding care of child or instructions to facilities supervision/ monitoring of child. Additionally, LPA requested child's last Needs and service plan, incident reports associated to child and any complaints. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA told Facility manager that LPA would return at a later date to follow up on incident. A copy of this report was provided to facility manager

On 5/4/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Fields Comprehensive Youth Services STRTP for the purpose of a case management- incident inspection. LPA met with and discussed the below identified incident: 1. December 6, 2022 client inhaling dust off electronic compressed gas duster and lint remover in the facility. Facility manager stated the following: Client was meeting with therapist in the back of home for therapy. Facility manager and therapist were with client at the time. Client returned to room and staff heard an unusual sound coming from clients bedroom. Client was observed inhaling from a compressed duster. Staff confiscated duster from client and assessed clients well being. Staff filed incident report and notified all associated parties of incident occurring. Staff were unsure where client obtained duster or how long client had duster on their persons or in their bedroom. Client refused medical treatment and was monitored by staff for the remainder of the day. Based on the information received, it is unclear how child obtained duster. However, based on the documentation provided staff responded and addressed incident in a timely manner and reported incident to all associated parties. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was provided to Facility manager.

Staff denied the allegations. Staff stated they encourage the clients to attend school as much as they can and try to make sure if they need any school supplies to provide it for them. narrative:
On 12/14/2023 at 9:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the Field Comprehensive Youth Services facility for the purpose of a Annual/ Required inspection. LPA met with Administrator Lekeba Riley and together did a walk-through of the facility both inside and out. LPA observed the following: This is a single-story single-family residence with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, game room, TV room, living space, kitchen, dining room, mental health area, attached garage and outdoor activity space. Home has operational surveillance cameras both inside and out. LPA did not observe cameras to be in bathrooms or bedrooms. LPA observed TV room, living room, game room, kitchen, dining room, office area, one (1) staff bathroom, mental area and attached garage. Additionally, LPA observed mental health area, garage, (1) bathroom identified as client bathroom. The kitchen has the required perishable and non-perishable food supply. Knives and cleaning supplies are kept behind locked doors and kept in locked cabinets. Medication, medication logs and file folders are kept behind locked doors. All areas observed at this time were clean, working and furniture was in good repair. The garage housed extra supplies, (4) additional deep freezers and an extra fridge. Bedroom #1 occupied by 2 children located opposite common bath two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bedroom #2- Occupied by 1 child, two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bedroom #3- Occupied by 1 child two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bedroom #4- utilized as an office space with an attached bathroom used only by staff Bathroom #1- common bathroom water temperature (107 degrees Fahrenheit)

LPA reviewed four (4) children folders including four (4) children's medication log, four (4) staff folders and vehicle maintenance logs. Additionally, LPA reviewed camera monitoring system, outdoor shed and ensured all smoke detectors and carbon monoxide machines were in working order. Files were maintained and required documents were present. Facility vehicles were last serviced in November. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies observed or cited and a copy of this report was given to Administrator.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Pamela Silva and Timika Martin on 05/10/24 at 9:15 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Lekeba Riley, Administrator, and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed one (1) of the children’s record and three (3) of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed one (1) of children’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff on site to discuss the facility's policies and procedures of operation. LPAs will conduct client interview at a later date due to the client not being available during the time of inspection. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPAs conducted exit interview with Lekeba Riley, Administrator, and provided a copy of this licensing report.

Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection on 05/22/24 at 9:49 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 05/22/24). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, and youth safety plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Facility Manager/Administrator, Lekeba Riley.

On 2/22/24 the Department received a complaint alleging the facility staff did not ensure clients were free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings. It was further alleged that the facility staff will search client’s backpacks once clients return from school. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, relevant parties indicated the facility staff will search clients backpacks each time the clients return to the facility from school. The facility staff will also direct clients to do a self-search prior to entering the facility where the clients take off their shoes, put out their pockets, raise their shirt or shake their waist band. The facility staff stated that the searches are performed to all clients in order to prevent contraband from entering the facility. LPA reviewed facility documents which did not indicate the facility’s policy is to search clients’ belongings each time a client returns to the facility. Based on the information gathered, the allegation stated above is/are SUBSTANTIATED. A substantiated finding means the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. These violations pose an immediate and/or potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The facility is being cited Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Chapter 7.5 Section 87072 (C)(10) Personal Rights. Appeals rights were provided, and a copy of the report and LIC 9099-D has been provided to the facility representative mentioned above.
investigation_findings: 13On May 24, 2024, at 9:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Larry Cabral conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with the facility administrator Lekeba Riely. During the investigation, LPA Cabral interviewed two facility staff (S1 & S2) and attempted to interview one client (C1) on 2/28/24. LPA interviewed three clients (C2, C4, C6) and attempted to interview two clients (C3, C5) on 4/9/24 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated May 24, 2024). LPA attempted to interview three county social workers (CSW2, CSW4, CSW6) on 4/19/24. LPA reviewed incident reports, the facility’s discharge, removal, termination policies and procedures forms, the facility’s visitation policy, discipline policy, program violation agreement, facility house rules and client guidebook.

deficiencies.description: 87072 PERSONAL RIGHTS (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care... (10) To be free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on the information obtained, staff and clients indicating that the staff searched the clients backpacks when coming back to the facility from the outside, this violation poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility is to conduct a training with staff on trauma-informed and child specific approaches on personal rights violations. The facility is to provide proof of training with dates and signed signature of the staff, including the staff who provided and verified training was completed via email to LPA

narrative: On 9/13/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Fields Comprehensive Short Term residential therapeutic program (STRTP) for the purpose of a case management- incident inspection. LPA met with representative and discussed the following incident. -Staff going back and forth with client regarding radio in the car (Trauma informed care) Staff/ Child #1 Facility manager stated the following: Staff and child were having a disagreement regarding the radio station. Child was not following staffs directives or following identified house rules. Staff and child were talked to regarding incident and agreed to drop issues and be in compliance with house rules. Facility manager stated that they talked to both staff and child together and separately. Staff was retrained in how to handle issues or disagreements with children and child was reminded of house rules. It was alleged that staff do not provide adequate care and supervision to the minors in care after a report of two juveniles supposedly selling drugs to an individual near the facility. During the course of the investigation, there was no evidence found to confirm the identity of the juveniles and if they were minors in placement at the facility. The investigation revealed third party information of an alleged exchange of unconfirmed items between parties. Furthermore, it revealed an opposition to the facility being in the neighborhood. The minors denied the allegation and causing any issues with their neighbors. Minors have community passes but they do not loiter around the neighborhood or trespass in neighbors’ properties. Staff denied being aware of the incident as alleged and stated that minors in care do not engage in such criminal activity. Although there were issues with some of their neighbors in the past, the issues were resolved. Neighbors know to contact the Administrator for any concerns. Based on the evidence above, the allegation of neglect/lack of supervision is closed as unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence found to prove that the allegation occurred. The following reports were provided to the facility representative at the conclusion of today’s inspection: LIC9099 and LIC9099-C. Appeal rights forms were also given and explained. There was no deficiency citation issued.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection on 06/26/25 at 9:30 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 6 out of 13 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 06/26/25). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, and youth safety plans, and crisis prevention intervention plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA, Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator, Lekeba Riley.

Mental health area, garage, bathrooms and two (2) closets have locks that are only accessible by staff. Kitchen has required perishable and non-perishable food supply. Knives and cleaning supplies are kept behind locked doors and kept in locked cabinets. Medication, medication logs and file folders are kept behind locked doors. Water temperature was checked in staff bathroom #1 and temperature measured at (136.8 degrees Fahrenheit). All areas observed at this time were clean, working and furniture was in good repair. Garage housed extra supplies, (4) additional deep freezers and extra fridge. Upstairs: Consisted of four (4) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms and outdoor balcony space. Bedroom #1 w/ attached bath (water temp 140+)- occupied by 2 children located opposite common bath two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bedroom #2- Occupied by 1 child, two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bedroom #3- Occupied by 1 child two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bedroom #4- utilized as a office space Bathroom #2- common bathroom water temperature (140+ degrees Fahrenheit)

LPA reviewed two (2) children folders including one (1) child medication log, five (5) staff folders and vehicle maintenance logs. Additionally, LPA reviewed camera monitoring system, outdoor shed and ensured all smoke detectors and carbon monoxide machines were in working order. LPA observed the following deficiencies: At 2:15 PM LPA observed water temperatures in all bathrooms to be over the required temperature of 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Temperatures in downstairs bathroom was 136.8, and upstairs bathrooms 140+ degrees Fahrenheit. Per Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 80088 Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies (e) Faucets used by clients for personal care such as shaving and grooming shall deliver hot water. (1) Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to automatically regulate temperature of hot water delivered to plumbing fixtures used by clients to attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C). On 12/10/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the Field Comprehensive Youth Services II facility for the purpose of a Case Management Incident inspection, LPA met with Facility Manager Jonathan Lamothe and discussed the following incidents: On 11/18/2021 the department received an Unusual incident report identifying facility night staff gave client the wrong medication. Facility manager stated the following: Staff placed two different client’s medications on a dresser and then prompted one client to wake up so she could give him the medication. However, staff handed the client the wrong medication mixing up the two cups on the dresser. Staff realized the mistake and called Administration and poison control. Per the direction of poison control facility kept client home to monitor status of symptoms and continued monitoring clients health. Staff who administered the wrong medications was given a written reprimand and was retrained on administering medications. The training was completed on 11/23/21. Additionally, facility has changed their protocols in administering medications by having children come to areas that are controlled and monitored by staff to ensure children are given their medications one at a time. Based on the information provided by the facility manager LPA identified the following deficiency. 80075 Health Related Services (k) The following requirements shall apply to medications which are centrally stored: (1) Medication shall be kept in a safe and locked place that is not accessible to persons other than employees responsible for the supervision of the centrally stored medication. 1. The following deficiency was reported: Staff mixed up medications that should be centrally stored giving the wrong medication to child Exit interview completed, the following deficiency was cited and a copy of this report was left with facility manager.

narrative: On 12/10/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the Field Comprehensive Youth Services II facility for the purpose of a Case Management Incident inspection, LPA met with Facility Manager Jonathan Lamothe and discussed the following incidents: On 12/9/2021 the department received an Unusual incident report identifying client being physically assaulted by unknown males at client’s school. Facility manager stated the following: Client (C1) was at school and engaged in a verbal altercation with another student. Students were then in a physical altercation with one another that was not reported to the school, but incident was recorded by a witness. The student then contacted their parent who called and had two older men come to the school to beat up C1. The altercation between those men and C1 again was caught on camera and local law enforcement were called on scene. The facility has been requesting information from the school and have yet to receive anything regarding the incidents. However, C1 was suspended for three days and the facility verified that the other student was expelled following this incident. Additionally, on 12/9/2021 the facility reported incident to Child Protective Services (CPS) and were told that no report was filed by the school to local law enforcement. Facility manager stated he will be filing a formal police report 12/13/2021 regarding incident. Facility has a scheduled meeting with the school for 12/13/2021 at 8:30AM and will be discussing the incident, creating a plan of security for C1 and inquiring about the suspension when C1 does not appear to be at fault. LPA requested a copy of a brief synopsis of incidents and what information and documents have already been obtained. Additionally, LPA requested documented evidence of fights and copies of any law enforcement reports taken regarding this incident. Exit interview completed, the following deficiency was cited and a copy of this report was left with facility manager.

Client#1 denied the allegation and stated the nobody has ever used any inappropriate discipline on him or the others in the home. Other clients interviewed also denied the allegation. Social workers interviewed had no concerns. Others interviewed stated there was concern as to what was said. Based on interviews conducted and conflicting information received, the allegation that staff demonstrate inappropriate form of discipline may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. The allegation is, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were provided to the facility representative. The original signed report will be placed in the facility file.

met_with: Anyssia Johnson, Head of Service/ Clinical therapist
narrative: On February 16, 2023 at approximately 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha conducted an unannounced Case Management visit at the facility for the purposes of issuing citations for deficiencies observed by the Department. LPA met with the representative named above and discussed the purpose of the visit. On December 31, 2022 the Department received a Special Incident Report regarding an incident that occurred at the facility on December 30, 2022. Upon review of the Special Incident Report, it was determined that due to the nature of the incident, a suspected child abuse report to the county hotline was warranted but not completed by the Licensee. Based on records reviewed, the Licensee is being cited for violation of California Code & Regulations Title 22, Div. 6, Section 80061, Penal Code 11166(a), which requires that mandated reporters make a suspected child abuse report immediately or as soon as possible. While conducting an assignment related to the above incident, it was also discovered that the Licensee was out of compliance regarding staffing regulations. In an interview conducted, the Facility Manager stated that their regular working hours were from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM. A review of the facility’s LIC 500 Personnel Report indicated that the Facility Manager’s working hours were between 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM. Interviews conducted with other staff and clients in the home confirmed that the Facility Manager’s working hours were between 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM and that the facility was generally without a Facility Manager between the hours of 5:00 PM to 8:00 AM unless an emergency incident required their presence. Based on interviews conducted and records reviewed, the Licensee is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, STRTP, Article 6 Section 87065(f), which requires that a Facility Manager be present in the facility at all times when one or more clients are present.

met_with: Anyssia Johnson, Head of Service/ Clinical therapist
narrative: On February 16, 2023 at approximately 11:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha conducted an unannounced Case Management visit at the facility. LPA met with the representative named above and discussed the purpose of the visit. Special incident report (SIR) submitted 10/14/2022 regarding threats and possible weapons: Clinical therapist stated the following: A incident report was submitted 10/14/2022 based on one child C1 making threats towards another child C2. Children were taken to school and later that afternoon when staff went to pick C2 up from school staff discovered C2 had runaway. A police report was filed for C2 running away but staff later identified that C2 may have been looking to purchase a firearm from a friend. When C2 returned to facility, local law enforcement was called and C2 was searched by police and no firearm was retrieved. A meeting was held with both C1 and C2 regarding the threat made to C2 by C1 and C2 looking to buy a firearm. A safety plan was completed and children came to an agreement to respect one another. LPA obtained copies of children's Needs and service plans, safety plan completed, SIRs updated and submitted and any additional case notes or follow up completed regarding law enforcement contact and search. Based on the information received facility notified agencies of runaway and completed follow up and therapy to address the concerns and incident that had occurred. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was provided to facility representative.

It was alleged that in December of 2022, staff failed to properly supervise clients in care resulting in an unidentified, unauthorized female minor entering the facility undetected for an extended amount of time. During the course of this investigation, the female minor was not able to be located and was listed as a runaway. Therefore, an interview was unable to be obtained with her. In an interview conducted, one client stated that the unauthorized female minor (UFM) was snuck into the facility in the middle of the night towards the end of December 2022. The client stated that the UFM was brought in through a back bedroom window on the second floor of the facility. The client stated that prior to the UFM’s unauthorized entry into the facility, security cameras had been covered with sticky notes and the bedroom window had been cracked open earlier in the day so that the sensor would not make an alert sound when it was later opened for UFM. The client stated that for the approximately 2 days that UFM was inside the facility, she was hidden from staff by hiding on the floor between a bedroom wall and bed. The only time she left the bedroom was to use the bathroom while staff were downstairs and performing other duties. Food was brought upstairs to her without the knowledge of staff. The client stated that staff generally conducted checks every 15 – 30 minutes and would come upstairs into their rooms to see if clients needed anything. However, the UFM was able to avoid detection each time. In another interview conducted, a second client corroborated the above statements and stated that all of the clients that were present in the facility during that time period were aware that UFM was in the home but no one alerted staff. The client also admitted that they actively assisted in covering up cameras on at least one occasion with sticky notes. A third client stated that they were initially unaware that UFM was present in the facility but also confirmed that they did not alert staff when they were finally aware. In interviews conducted, staff confirmed after checking security footage that the UFM was brought into the facility in the middle of the night through a second-story bedroom window. Footage also showed clients temporarily covering up security cameras with sticky notes in order to facilitate UFM sneaking into the home. Staff stated that when clients are upstairs in their rooms, staff members will check on them every 15-30 minutes to see what they are up to and if they need anything. This also occurs during overnight shifts when clients are asleep. Staff stated that during the period of time when this incident occurred, they would make regular checks but they did not see UFM as she would hide on the side of the bed closest to the wall and under blankets. In an interview conducted, a third-party individual stated that all indications pointed towards clients actively assisting the UFM in entering the facility and avoiding detection.

It was also alleged that one client had access to a weapon in the facility. Further investigation revealed that the weapon in question was a CO2 BB gun. In an interview conducted, one client stated that it was brought into the facility unbeknownst to staff. A second client stated that they were unaware that the item was in the home until it was discovered and a third client stated that they were aware the first client had it in his possession, but decided not to alert staff to it. All clients stated that staff will ask to conduct searches when clients are returning from the community but stated that they sometimes refuse. Clients stated that room searches are conducted periodically by staff if there is reason to believe there may be contraband hidden. In interviews conducted, staff confirmed that they will ask to conduct light contraband searches on clients to include flipping out pockets, checking backpacks, having clients pat down their own pockets, and more. Clients will sometimes refuse, and when this occurs, staff will document the refusal. Staff stated that room searches are routinely conducted and the thoroughness of the check will depend on if there is a specific reason to believe that contraband may be hidden somewhere. Based on interviews conducted and records reviewed, there is not a preponderance of evidence to suggest that the above allegations occurred. Although the allegations may be valid or may have happened, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met. Therefore, the allegations are deemed UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.
