On 5/23/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Fields Comprehensive Youth Services II for the purpose of a case management Incident inspection. LPA met with Administrator and discussed the following incidents: 1. Child being placed on 72 hour hold 3/14/2023 2. Child having cuts on both arms 3/23/2023 3. Youth detained for attempted car theft 4/11/2023 4. Child having cuts to face being beaten up 4/12/2023 Administrator stated the following: Child would run away a lot from the facility and would come back after weeks away from facility with various cuts and injuries. Child was placed on a 72 hour hold based on mothers request due to observing cuts on child while child was on run away status at mother home. Two children were detained by local law enforcement and were taken to juvenile hall. Children were released from juvenile hall and brought back to the facility. Child was removed from home prior to child's scheduled court dates. Child was on run away status from facility on 4/12/2023 and child showed up to school with cuts to face and stated someone attempted to stab them. Facility was notified of observations made and information given by child. Facility requested school have child taken to hospital where child was evaluated and a police report was taken by Officer Swink of local police department. Child was removed from home by social worker on April 13, 2023 and further follow up was to be conducted by social worker. LPA requested copies of special incident reports, hospital discharge paperwork, any police reports, and child's discharge paperwork from facility. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited or observed during this inspection and a copy of the report was provided to Administrator.

Page 2 The Department received a complaint alleging a staff member (S1) inappropriately touched a client (C1) on his genital area. The investigation revealed that on or about the evening of 7/11/23, C1 and S1 left the facility on a therapeutic walk. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted revealed that during the walk C1 requested a hug from S1, and as they embraced, S1 allegedly reached down and placed his hand on C1’s genitals, over his clothing. S1 denied the allegation. S1 stated he validated C1’s feelings, discussed boundaries with C1 and offered a hug as a supportive gesture. S1 denied his hands went below C1’s waistline during their embrace. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with facility staff and a review of the placing agency investigation revealed C1 recanted the allegation occurred during multiple follow up interviews. In addition, statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff revealed there were inconsistencies in C1’s account of the incident with respect to when he disclosed he was attracted to S1. During the telephone call to the Child Abuse hotline it was reported C1 disclosed being attracted to S1 on the morning of 7/12/23. There were no reported witnesses to the alleged incident. Based on information gathered from interviews conducted and record review the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. A copy of this report and Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 11/7/23 were given to the above mentioned facility representative. Exit interview conducted. No deficiencies were cited.

narrative: On 3/15/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Fields Comprehensive II Youth facility for the purpose of a case management-other inspection. LPA met with facility manager and discussed the following: Child being asked to remove toys by staff and expressing getting a gun and killing everyone: Facility manager stated the following: Staff were trying to clean and de-clutter the room to give room to a new client. Child made direct threats to get a gun and kill everyone to staff because staff came in and were touching child's belongings. Child made same allegations at school. School did not get law enforcement, however, we did. Law enforcement came out and they spoke with child regarding severity of threats. Our mental health team and therapist got involved and created a safety plan for child. Child is to be removed due to safety concerns but as of now staff follow safety plans and continue to work with child. LPA requested the following documents: Special incident report regarding incident and completed safety plans.

On 3/15/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Fields Comprehensive II Youth facility for the purpose of a case management-other inspection. LPA met with facility manager and discussed the following: Child being left unattended at YMCA for 2/3 hours and child stole a vehicle: Facility manager stated the following: Currently, we have a verbal agreement with the YMCA to drop off children to play in basketball league or to play at the YMCA. On this particular day one staff took child to play basketball, walked the child in and then received a call of an emergency back at the home. Staff then notified YMCA staff and told YMCA staff that child would be left to play and that staff would return to pick child up in a few hours. The emergency lasted a little longer than intended but staff returned as soon as possible to pick up child. After reviewing the cameras it was observed that staff did walk and check child in. Child was then observed after staff left taking someone's keys off the bleachers. Child was picked up by staff and later that evening Awoled from facility and we were later notified that child was picked up in a stolen vehicle. All reports were reported and notifications were made of incidents. Staff followed proper protocol and notified management of incidents that transpired at YMCA and home. LPA Requested: most recent children and family therapy (CFT) notes/ needs and service (NSP), recent reports of AWOLs, and incidents of being picked up by law enforcement/ history of stolen vehicles.

Continue from page 1 . . . The staff indicated that the clients are searched when they come back from outside the facility and were without direct supervision. The staff stated that the clients do a self search where the clients take off their shoes, put out their pockets, raise their shirt or shake their waist band. The staff stated that the staff does search the client's back packs and go through it or that the client's can go through their backpacks themselves. The staff stated that the searches are done to all clients and is done to prevent contraband from entering the facility. The confidential interviews revealed that the clients are search when coming back to the facility from the outside. The confidential interviews indicated that a staff searches the client's backpacks when entering the facility back. The confidential interviews revealed that the clients also conduct self searches by taking out their pockets, taking their shoes off and such. The statements obtained indicated that the clients are not padded down when conducting a search. Based on the staff statements and confidential interviews the allegation is found to be substantiated. A substantiated finding means that the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation is found to be true. Exit interview completed. The following deficiencies cited and a copy of this report and appeal rights were left with facility representative mention above.
investigation_findings: 13On April 25, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Heriberto Perez conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with Jonathan Lamothe, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed one staff (S1) on 03/01/24, LPA interviewed five clients on 03/04/24, LPA interviewed County Social Worker (CSW) and one staff (S2) via telephone on 04/16/24, LPA interviewed County Social Worker (CSW2) via telephone on 04/17/24 and LPA interviewed County Social Worker (CSW3) via telephone on 04/18/24 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated April 25, 2024). LPA also reviewed documents including but not limited to Client's Intake packet, Policy and Procedure Section and other documents. It was alleged Staff are searching residents' belongings without a cause. Continue on page 2 . . .

deficiencies.description: 87072 PERSONAL RIGHTS (C)(10): The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care... (10) To be free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on the information obtained, staff and clients indicating that the staff searched the clients backpacks when coming back to the facility from the outside, this violation poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC: The facility is to conduct a meeting with staff to discuss the violation & consequences for future violations. The facility will provide Personal Rights training to the staff. The facility is to provide proof of training with dates and signed signature of the staff, including the staff who provided and verified training was completed via email to LPA Heriberto Perez, Heriberto.Perez@dss.ca.gov

narrative: On 6/18/2024 Licensing Program Managers (LPMs) Yan (Ina) Yeung, Gustavo Garcia, and Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Dawn Mahecha and Heriberto Perez met with Fields Comprehensive management team including Executive Director Arby Fields, Board member Tyrone Smith, Head of Service Dana Wogahn, Clinical Director Ny’Shae Fields, and Administrator Lekeba Riley. LPMs and LPAs met with fields comprehensive team regarding facilities submitted appeal and facilities identified search policies. Discussion consisted of the following: Fields Comprehensive management team was told that facility cannot have a blanket policy on conducting searches on clients and clients’ belongings. On 4/25/2024 the Fields Comprehensive facility was cited for conducting unreasonable searches on clients’ belongings. Facility appealed the citation on 5/14/2024. On 6/10/2024 facility was denied appeal and was told that appeal and current searching policies did not meet interim licensing standards (ILS) of trauma informed care. Management team was told that facility should maintain a searching policy that is individualized for each child that is approved by licensing and county representatives. Licensee was also told that all updates need to be submitted to licensing and county representatives for approval prior to implementation. Based on information discussed and provided agency will be processing appeal and looking at current policy. Exit interview conducted and the following report was provided to representative.

On 11/5/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Fields Comprehensive II STRTP for the purpose of a case management-medication inspection. LPA met with head of service and discussed the following observed violations. Child #1 (C1) missing staff signature on documented MARs and medication bubble pack management of disbursement of medications. Head of service stated the following: Staff missed signature for administering medication to child. Head of service stated that child started medication on the right of bubble pack with date identified above and then staff moved to the 1st on the other side of the bubble pack to showcase that child was continuing medication on the first of November. LPA issued the following technical violation for missed signature and told head of service that staff should be retrained on documenting medication and administering medications. Exit interview completed, and the following violations were noted. A copy of this report was provided to representative.

On 11/5/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Fields Comprehensive II STRTP for the purpose of a case management-other inspection. LPA met with head of service and discussed the following observed violations. Camera usage policy, safety policy, food storage, broken screen in downstairs sliders, broken dresser drawers in bedroom #1 and #2, broken door to bedroom #2, hallway fire extinguisher and over compacted vents. Head of service stated the following: The facility has just updated the policies and are awaiting the final approval from management regarding the camera usage and safety policies. The facility has not sent out any updated policies or implemented any policies to date. The facility has been working on finalizing and implementing new policies and procedures within the facility. LPA told head of service no policies should be implemented until approval is obtained from county and state licensing. Regarding the food storage staff did not observe the expired food, however, the facility will discard the expired food and we will ensure that food is properly labeled. LPA observed broken screen in downstairs slider, three (3) broken dressers, missing fire extinguisher and over compacted vents. Facility manager stated the facility weekly sends a status report to management regarding repairs and maintenance to the facility. The facility manager sends the work orders and then management has the maintenance worker come out to fix or address the issues within the facility. LPA observed last work orders submitted 10/25/2024 addressing all observed violations listed above. Facility manager also provided LPA with text messages to maintenance worker of intended dates or completion. Exit interview completed, the following violations were noted and a copy of this report was provided to head of service.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins made an unannounced annual inspection to this facility. LPA met with Kenneth Porter Administrator . LPA reviewed files with Administrator and Tandra Dubose Operations Manager (OM). The facility is licensed for 12 residents (all can be ambulatory) ages 12-18 and currently 6 clients reside in facility. The facility consists of 6 bedrooms (6 double occupancy rooms for clients) and 5 1/2 bathrooms (4 for clients and 1 1/2 for staff). House is a double level building and another facility in the back that consists of two offices, conference room and a place where staff hold group meetings. No more than two clients to a room. At 11:00 AM, LPA Rollins and Administrator toured the facility inside and out. The kitchen is clean. The hot water in the bathroom and kitchen measured at 114 degrees F which is currently between 105 - 120 degrees. The facility has plenty of nonperishable and perishable food supply. Medication, cleaning supplies and knives are locked away. Medication logs are up to date and current. There are enough folks, spoons, plates and cups. All passageways are unobstructed. All smoke detectors are update and working. The home is clean, safe, and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. The fire extinguisher has been checked and is up to date. There are no bodies of water on the property. LPA observed first aid kit to be fully stocked. The home is maintained at a comfortable temperature. Personal rights, floor plan, food menu and Emergency disaster forms were posted and in clear view. At 12:00 PM, LPA Rollins observe sex client files with Administrator and OM. LPA Rollins observed all six client files to be complete and found no deficiencies. The documentation in the clients file are complete and up to date.

At 1:00 PM, LPA observed all six staff files with Administrator and OM. LPA observed all six staff files to be complete, all correct documentation and all staff were up to date with there 40 hours of annual training for the year. At 1:45 PM LPA Rollins conducted staff and client interviews. During inspection, LPA receive a updated copy of the LIC 500 Personnel Report to maintain their file current. A review of Licensing Information System on September 14, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the program has DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

On 2-3-23 10:38AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at listed facility. LPA's met with Ken Porter, Licensee, and toured the facility inside and out. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask wearing. The Short Term Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve twelve clients. Present during the inspection were two staff and one client. At 10:55AM, LPA Karkazis reviewed client and staff files. Client files were complete and in order. Staff files were incomplete. S1's file was missing CPR certification and LIC 503 Health Screening. All staff files were missing LIC 198A. At 1:50PM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed six bedrooms and five bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 118 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 69 which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in a locked cabinet, in an office. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed two staff and one clients. At 2:35 LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. continued on LIC 809-C

continued from LIC 809 Citations were issued at this time. The facility is in violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80066(a)(10) Health Screening and 87065.1(d)(6)(A) First Aid Training. A Technical Violation was issued for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80019.2(a)(1) An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Ken Porter, Licensee.

On 3-26-24 10:18AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at listed facility. LPA's met with Ken Porter Administrator and toured the facility inside and out. The Short Term Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve 12 clients. Present during the inspection were 2 staff and 2 clients. At 10:30AM LPA Karkazis reviewed staff files. Ken Porter was able to re-associate S5 back on to the facility roster before the end of this inspection. S3 did not have a current CPR Certificate on file. LPA Karkazis reviewed client files. C4 is a new placement. C4 is waiting for Needs and Service Plan. At 2:25PM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed 6 bedrooms and 5 bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 117 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 71 which is within range. Sharps were locked in the kitchen cabinet and chemicals were safely stored in the locked office. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in the office, in a locked cabinet. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed 2 staff and one client. The other client was non-verbal. At 2:57PM, LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. continued on LIC 809-C

continued from LIC 809 At this time the facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards 87065.1(d)(6)(A) Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements, Type B. A Technical Advisory is issued for Interim Licensing Standards 87070(c)(1) Children's Records. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Ken Porter, Administrator.

On 6-19-24 10:05AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced visit at Filbert House and met with Administrator Ken Porter. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an incident which occurred 6-14-2024 0000724-FN. LPA toured the facility, two clients and four staff were present. LPA conducted interviews and requested documents. Further investigation is needed at this time. LPA conducted an interview with Head of Services Valentina Fiero, for complaint 14-CR-20240606144854 dated 06-06-24. An exit interview and a copy of this report was given to Ken Porter, Administrator/Licensee.

On 06-28-24 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis made an unannounced inspection at Filbert House and met with Ken Porter, Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to follow up on an incident that occurred on 6-14-24, incident number 0000724-FN. Present during the inspection were two staff and two clients. LPA conducted document research in an incident report dated 6-14-24, sent by the Administrator, which indicates that staff hit the client several times and threw the client to the ground. LPA conducted confidential interviews, interviewees stated they witnessed staff physically assaulting a client, providing accurate details of the physical altercation. Staff immediately terminated. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6 Personal Rights 80072(a)(3). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was given to Ken Porter, Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
80072(a)(3)- (a)	Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following; (3) To be free from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature, ........  or withholding of shelter, clothing, medication or aids to physical functioning.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records review, staff (S1) hit client several times and threw the client to the ground.  This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Immediate termination of S1. LPA has received termination letter of S1 dated 6-17-24. Facility shall conduct de-escalation training for staff.  Training materials and staff sign in sheet shall be submitted to George.Karkazis@dss.ca.gov by 7-22-24.

investigation_findings: 13On 6-28-24 9:27AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at Filbert House, and met with Ken Porter, Administrator, who helped with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the complaint findings. The complaint alleged that uncleared staff allowed to work at the facility and staff falsified youths’ rehabilitation documents. On 6-10-24 10:15AM, LPA made an unannounced inspection at Filbert House. LPA was greeted by S1, LPA obtained S1’s California Identification Card and confirmed S1’s identity. S1 stated that they have been employed at Filbert House for over one year. LPA checked S1’s status on Guardian and found it “In Process”. S1 does not have fingerprint clearance. LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff that stated S4 had copied/pasted and erased youths’ rehabilitation notes, S4 immediately terminated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 03 Criminal Record Clearance 80019(e)(1), with a civil penalty, and Interim Licensing Standards, Article 06, Needs and Service Plans 87068.2(a). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was given to Ken Porter.

deficiencies.description:
80019(e)(1)- (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility:................ Department.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, it was revealed that S1 had worked at the facility for one year without criminal record clearance.  LPA met S1 working during an inspection dated 6-10-24.  Based on record review, S1’s criminal record clearance in Guardian, is “In Process”, not fingerprint cleared. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: S1 shall immediately cease empoyment at facility until criminal record clearace is obtained.

deficiencies.description:
87068.2(a)- Social work staff shall obtain the information specified in Section 87070, and shall develop an individual needs and services plan, within 30 days of placement, for the child that meets the requirements specified in (b) through (e) below and includes the anticipated duration of the treatment,.... environment.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, interviewees stated that S4 had copied and pasted client needs and service plans/rehabilitation documents for April and May of 2024.  Once discovered, S4 erased needs and service plans/rehabilitation documents for April and May of 2024.  This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: LPA advises that Head of Services check client files weekly to ensure they are intact and services rendered.

narrative: On 08/13/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made an announced collateral visit to the facility to conduct a confidential interview. LPA met with Administrator, and informed Administrator on the purpose of the visit. LPA conducted one confidential interview related to an outside investigation. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with, Administrator whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 5-21-25 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced an unannounced inspection at Filbert House and met with Administrator Ken Porter. The purpose of the visit was to follow up on IRFU 0001739FN. See LIC 811 Confidential Names List dated 5-21-25. LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff. S1 stated the reason she did not give the house phone to C1 was because C1 was in a violent mood, reciting lyrics of shooting someone, wanted to call someone that was not approved, to come and assault S1. S1 stated it was a safety concern, and waited for the supervisor to arrive and handle the situation. S2 stated that C1 wanted to call his uncle, to come to the facility to assault staff. S2 stated that C1 had his own cell phone at the time of the incident and was purposely causing an unnecessary argument. S2 also stated staff safety was a concern. S2 stated that C1 shortly after apologized for his behavior. C1 went on AWOL 5-9-25 and has not returned, not available for comment. LPA conducted document research. C1's needs and service plans show a history of violent assaultive behavior. The incident report and shift notes both indicate that C1 wanted to call an unauthorized person to come and assault staff. At this time there are no deficiencies or further follow up needed.

The facility staff indicated they have advised neighbors to call law enforcement since clients are on AWOL. The confidential interviews conducted did not collaborate the allegations, interviews revealed contradicting statements in regard to the allegation’s statements were made indicating staff provides adequate supervision to clients, however if clients are AWOLing from the facility staff can only follow the clients for a certain distance then staff return to the facility and call law enforcement to report an AWOL. Facility staff informed LPA that staff will occasionally check on the park area in the neighborhood when clients are on AWOL. There are two STRTP facilities in close proximity and although it may appear that the activity is coming out from one STRTP it is possible it is a combination of both. The placement agency social workers indicated having no concerns with the facility. There was no corroborating information obtained through interviews and review of records to confirm the allegations. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On December 9, 2020 at 10:45 AM Licensing Program Analyst Larry Cabral (LPA) conducted a follow-up tele-conference for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA Cabral met with administrator Gina Sodaro. During the course of the investigation, LPA Cabral interviewed four clients on 10/5/20, 12/3/20 and 12/4/20 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated December 9, 2020). LPA interviewed two facility staff on 9/28/20, one facility staff on 12/3/20 and two facility staff on 12/4/20 . LPA interviewed two county social workers on 9/28/20 and 10/5/20 and attempted to interview three county social workers on 10/5/20. LPA Cabral obtained and reviewed client’s incident reports, police reports, facility shift progress notes. The facility staff denied the allegations indicating clients are supervised at all time when clients are at the facility. The facility staff indicated staff can not physically prevent clients from AWOLing.

narrative: The facility staff indicated all clients are provided clothing and when clients AWOL from the facility and return the clients return with clothes on.Staff indicated no clients have had access to gasoline, made death threats against other clients and no clients have been left unsupervised by facility staff when staff leaves with other clients. The confidential interviews conducted did not collaborate the allegations. The placement agency social workers indicated having no safety concerns with the facility. There was no corroborating information obtained through interviews and review of records to confirm the allegations. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On March 18, 2021 at 2:15 PM Licensing Program Analyst Larry Cabral (LPA) conducted a follow-up tele-conference for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA Cabral met with lead facility manager Byron Butler. During the course of the investigation, LPA Cabral interviewed three clients and attempted to interview one client on 12/4/21 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated March 18, 2021). LPA interviewed three facility staff on 12/4/20. LPA interviewed once county social worker on 12/4/20 and two county social workers on 3/17/21. LPA obtained and reviewed client’s incident reports and clothing log. The facility staff denied the allegations that staff are not ensuring that clients have appropriate clothing, clients have access to gasoline, clients are making death threats to each other and staff left clients without supervision.

narrative: Continued from pg. 1 It was alleged that the facility staff failed to adequately supervise group home youth, resulting in FC1 going AWOL and causing disturbances in the community the facility is located in. Statements obtained from the confidential interviews did not provide sufficient information to corroborate the allegation. The staff that were interviewed denied the allegation. Staff stated that when neighborhood disturbances occur, FC1 is always present which results in FC1 being blamed. Staff said that FC1 will sometimes admit to having part in the disturbances and at times FC1 denies participation. Two residents denied the allegation and stated that the facility staff always supervises the residents and encourage residents not to go AWOL. One witness stated not witnessing any disturbances caused by FC1. However, the reporting party (RP) has made the witness aware of the disturbances allegedly caused by FC1. LPA Mundo was unable to get statements from 2 residents and FC1. There was no corroborating information obtained through the interview and review of records to confirm the allegation. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegation is found Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation. The following reports were provided to the facility representative: LIC 9099, LIC 9099C, LIC 811, and Appeal Rights. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On 4/20/2021 at 11:00 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jenny Mundo conducted a follow-up complaint inspection with the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) via telephone conference and electronic mail for the purpose of providing the finding for the above allegation. LPA Mundo spoke to the Facility Manager, Byron Butler and provided a copy of the report to facility representative. During the course of the investigation, LPA Mundo conducted interviews with 1 facility staff on 11/12/2020 via telephone, 1 witness on 11/13/2020 via telephone, 2 facility staff and 2 residents on 11/16/2020 via telephone and 1 CSW on 11/19/2020 via telephone (see Confidential Names form LIC 811 dated 4/20/2021). LPA Mundo also reviewed documents on 11/20/2020 including but not limited to the placement agency reports and the facility’s Special Incident Reports (SIRs) for the period of 9/2020-10/2020.

narrative: The confidential interviews revealed statements indicating staff provides adequate supervision to clients, however if clients are AWOLing from the facility, staff can only follow the clients for a certain distance then staff return to the facility and call law enforcement to report an AWOL. Facility staff informed LPA that staff will occasionally check on the park area in the neighborhood when clients are on AWOL. Per reporting party there are two STRTP facilities in close proximity and although it may appear that the activity is coming out from one STRTP it is possible it is a combination of both. Reporting party stated he was frustrated that the police and group home could not do much and understood the clients were troubled youth. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegation is found unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegation. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On April 15, 2021 at 2:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst Pedro Ramos (LPA) conducted a follow-up tele-conference for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint allegation. LPA met with Byron Butler, Lead Facility Manager. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed two clients on 4/2/21 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated April 15, 2021). LPA interviewed three facility staff on 4/2/21. LPA obtained and reviewed client’s and staff documents. The facility staff denied the allegation indicating clients are supervised at all time when clients are at the facility. The facility staff indicated staff can not physically prevent clients from AWOLing.

narrative: Facility staff reported that the clients are aware of their rights and know they can only do so much to prevent them from awolling out of the facility; however, the staff attempts to re-direct them whenever they can. The confidential interviews did not corroborate the clients are being disruptive or causing the community any issues due to the lack of supervision. Interviewed parties were not familiar with the allegation of clients asking anyone for money or trying to take anyone belongings. Furthermore, facility staff denied having children on awol during the morning hours due to them being in school or doing schoolwork at that time. Therefore, based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation. No other agency investigated the allegation. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the Facility staff for review and signature due to Covid-19 restriction. There were no citations.
investigation_findings: 13On 6/02/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Lofton conducted a telephonic follow-up inspection at First Step Group Home with the purpose of delivering findings regarding the above complaint allegation. LPA Lofton spoke to Lead Facility Manager Byron Butler and discussed the findings. During the investigation LPA Lofton made several attempts to reach the complainant on 11/19/20, 01/04/21 and 2/25/21. LPA Lofton left messages each day except 2/25/21 due to voicemail being full. LPA Lofton interviewed Staff #1 on 11/19/20, Staff #2 on 4/16/21, Staff #3 on 4/21/21 and Staff #4 on 4/23/21. LPA Lofton interviewed Client #1, Client #2 and Client #3 on 3/12/21. See LIC811- Confidential Names List dated 6/02/21. The allegation was denied by all interviewed parties. The facility staff denied the allegations that staff members are not supervising the clients.

narrative: However, the facility addressed it and child was removed and moved to a different placement. Facility manager stated that staff coverage is typically one (1) overnight staff and 2 to 3 staff on duty for the mornings and afternoons. Staff #1 (S1) stated that they were unaware of any incidents where children acted inappropriately or where children got in trouble being on community passes. Additionally, Staff #2 (S2) stated that children in home get along and no issues have been observed or reported. Interviews conducted with children identify no issues in the home. Child #1 (C1) stated that all children got along and that he felt as though staff coverage was enough to tend to everyone’s needs. Interviews conducted with child#4 (C4) stated that home is nice, and staff are attentive. LPA observed two (2) children who were non-verbal both clients were observed to be comfortable around staff, clean and being attended to. Interviews conducted with children and staff did not provide any specific information or details related to any one incident or occurrence. Documents reviewed did not depict any unusual or inappropriate behavior. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail. There were no deficiencies cited during this tele-inspection.

investigation_findings: 13On October 20,21 at 9:00AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs)Zeyda Loera and Pamela Silva conducted an unannonced inspection visit for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint allegation. narrative:
On 12/08/21 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Zeyda Loera and Pamela Silva conducted an Annual Required Inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPAs met with Administrator Gina Sodaro and Lead Facility Manager Bryon Butler. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) male ambulatory clients ages 7-17 and is also licensed to provide services to Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). There are six (6) clients currently in placement. The LPAs requested the following: Personal Report LIC 500, Client Roster, Board of Directors Meeting Minutes, Clients and Staff files. At 9:15 AM, LPAs conducted a walkthrough of the entire facility. Physical Plant The STRTP license, Mental Health Certification, National Accreditation and the Emergency Disaster Plan are posted in the facility. Passageways are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, other chemicals, sharps and knives are kept locked in the hallway closet. Medications are centrally stored in a locked closet. The temperature inside the facility is maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperature was measured at 118 degrees (F). Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors were tested and observed to be operational. The fire extinguishers are fully charged. Facility has a working telephone. First Aid kit is complete. All confidential files are in a locked cabinet inside the staff office. All sinks, showers and toilets are in working order. No more than 2 clients share a bedroom. All beds are in good condition, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. There were adequate supply of beddings and linens. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. The facility has cameras installed in the common areas of the facility.

There are no firearms and ammunition in the facility. Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The Board of Directors regularly conduct meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility administrator and manager are the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. The facility has developed and maintained and implemented written complaint procedures. Client Records LPAs reviewed six (6) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures, medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables, education records, personal rights forms and medication administration records. Staff Records LPAs reviewed three (3) staff records. All staff have been subjected to criminal records review and have been fingerprinted and cleared with DOJ, FBI and CACI. The administrator meets the required qualifications and/or experience. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. Facility Managers meet requirements. Annual training records and certificates are on staff files. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services, transition support services, educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency.

Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts drills at least quarterly for each shift. The drills are documented and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, needs and services plans for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff members. LPAs were unable to interview clients due to no client was present in the facility at the time of inspection At the conclusion of the inspection, LPAs discussed the findings with the facility Administrator. LPAs agreed to work with the facility administrator to collaborate with guidance to get the facility in compliance with ILS and Title 22 regulations. The administrator was provided with information on where to locate the Provider Information Notices (PINs), guidance to the new CARE Tools inspection process and Guardian. There was no deficiency cited during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report and LIC811 were provided to the Administrator..

The Department received a complaint regarding alleged sexual abuse on C1 by a FM. The FM denied the allegation. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted by SI Barragan, County Social Workers and Law Enforcement were consistent and revealed there were no witnesses who observed FM physically or sexually abuse clients placed at the facility. The investigations conducted by other agencies and departments revealed there was no evidence to corroborate the allegation. Based on statements obtained from interviews conducted and records reviewed the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence standard was not met. Exit interview conducted. No deficiencies were cited. A copy of this report and Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 4/21/22 were given to the above mentioned facility representative.

SI Barragan interviewed one County Social Worker (CSW) on 1/10/22, one CSW on 1/27/22, four Clients (C2, C3,C4,C5) on 2/8/22, one CSW on 2/18/22, two Facility Managers (FM) on 2/22/22, two FM on 2/23/22 and one Administrator on 2/23/22, one FM on 3/10/22, one Detective on 3/10/22 and one FM on 3/17/22. SI Barragan attempted to interview Client (C1) on 2/18/22, but C1 is nonverbal and did not provide a statement. narrative: Confidential statements obtained during the investigation were unable to corroborate the allegations as there were no statements obtained to support the allegations. One of the residents is autistic and non-verbal. Facility staff denied the allegations. An unannounced tour of the facility revealed that the facility has ample food supply and hygiene products for the residents. Based on the information gathered, the allegations are unsubstantiated as the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met although the allegations may have happened or are valid. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On April 21, 2022 at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joshua Rarela conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegations above. LPA Rarela met and discussed the findings with the facility representative named above. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed facility staff on 2/4/22, 2/7/22, 2/15/22, 4/15/22 and 4/21/22, and facility residents on 4/21/22 (see Confidential Names Form dated April 21, 2022). LPA also reviewed documents including placing agency service logs and reports, medical records, resident case plans and facility personnel records. It was alleged that the facility is not addressing changes in minor's health, and the facility is not ensuring minor's dental needs are being met. (CONTINUED)

narrative: The LPA observed that the client was placed at the facility on March 5, 2020 and removed on September 30, 2021. The LPA observed an Appraisal/Needs and Services Plan dated October 1, 2020. The LPA observed that the County Placement Worker signed the document on January 20, 2021. The LPA observed a Quarterly Report dated September 17, 2021. The investigation revealed that the initial County Social Worker was no longer assigned the case. It is determined that the facility provided an Appraisal/Needs and Services Plan as required by the Plan of Operation. It is noted that the Appraisal/Needs and Services Plan is not within the 90 day plan, but consideration is given due to the Covid19 Pandemic. The LPA cannot corroborate that the facility did not provide paperwork. The investigation revealed that the facility was aware for two-to-three months of the plan to transfer Ref. #1 to an adult residential facility. It revealed that the facility had less than less than 24 hours to pack Ref. #1's belongings for the transfer once they received the call that a placement was open for Ref. #1. The LPA was provided inconsistent statements as to whether Ref. #1's belongings were provided in either a box or bags. It revealed that the witness stated a box, but no details were provided as to whether it was a moving box. The investigation revealed that the witness was concerned more with the lack of contents in the box as opposed to the container the belongings were transported in. The LPA cannot corroborate the allegation that Ref. #1's belongings were not provided. The LPA cannot corroborate evidence to determine if there was a Personal Rights violation based upon the type of container Ref. #1's belongings were transported. The LPA reviewed the Medical Treatment Record dated June 23, 2020 signed by the physician; and the Health and Education Passport dated February 16, 2021. The LPA cannot corroborate the allegation that the client was not taken to their medical appointment. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On May 10, 2022 at 3:35 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, arrived at the facility for the purpose of delivering complaint investigation findings. The LPA met with Facility Manager, Crystal Carrillo. On October 22, 2021, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: the Administrator Gina Sordano and Lead Facility Manager (LFM), Byron Butler were interviewed at the facility on October 25, 2021 by LPA Belinda Gilmer; LPA McGee conducted a follow-up interview with the LFM on May 9, 2022. The LPA did not interview the client, Ref. #1, because Ref. #1 is non- verbal. The LPA reviewed the following documents: Quarterly Report dated September 17, 2021; Individual Program Plan dated February 12, 2021; Appraisal/Needs and Services Plan dated 10/01/2020; Plan of Operation, The policies and procedures for removal or transfer from the facility; Health and Education Passport: Well-Exam dated 2/16/21; Medical Treatment Record dated 6/23/20; Special Incident Reports (SIRs); and a signed note for medication dated September 30, 2021.

narrative: Ref. #1 revealed that the proper procedures were followed for them to foster Ref. #2 and Ref. #2 was provided home passes in order to visit Ref. #1's home and meet Ref. #1's maternal parent and sister, who lived in the home. Ref. #2 denied the allegation, stating that Ref. #1 served as a role model and took care of Ref. #2. The investigation revealed that there were no allegations of sexual inappropriateness made against Ref. #1. It revealed that the facility conducted a meeting with Ref. #1 regarding favoritism with the clients. The CSW expressed concerns about the rumors started by another client at the facility. The LPA cannot corroborate the allegation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that an alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: On June 3, 2022 at 3:00 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, arrived at the facility for the purpose of delivering complaint investigation findings. The LPA met with Facility Manager, Ronnie Mackey. On November 10, 2021, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: the Lead Facility Manager (LFM), Byron Butler and Staff (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 Ref. #1 dated June 3, 2022) via telephone on June 2, 2022; the County Social Worker (CSW) via telephone on February 16, 2021; Client, Ref. #2 outside the new placement on June 3, 2022. The LPA reviewed the Appraisal/Needs and Services Plan dated August 10, 2021. The LPA was informed that there were no Special Incident Reports involving Ref. #2. Staff Ref. #1 denied the allegations stating that they were in the process of fostering Ref. #2. The Staff revealed that they were interviewed by the CSW, the CSW's manager and approved to serve as Ref. #2's Resource Family Parent (RFP). The LPA observed the History of Child's Placement Report from the CWS/CMS System which indicated that Ref. #1 served as Ref. #2's RFP starting January 2022.

narrative: Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged that minor sustained an unexplained bruise while in care. Manager denied the allegation. Manager stated that children who were roommates had a physical altercation where one child bit a child and the other child reacted to being bit by hitting the child. A bruise was not initially observed by staff but child had teeth mark impressions on their arm and child later developed bruising. Manager stated incident was documented and children were moved to separate rooms. LPA was unable to interview children as one child is non-verbal and other child refused to speak with LPA. LPA reviewed interviews and observations conducted by LPA Joshua Rareula on March 23, 2022 and April 21, 2022. LPA Rarela made observations of child who was non- verbal and received confirmation from his teachers that child is unable to speak or respond to questioning. In additional interviews conducted with other children made by LPA Rarela children had similar statements in identifying issues with one child but that all children got along with staff and that they had not observed or been victim to any staff be physically abusive to children. Documents reviewed coincide with statements received in how child obtained bruising. Staff reported incident to agencies reporting incident and addressed the issue by transitioning children to different rooms and intervening when necessary. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jenny Mundo and Pamela Silva on August 17, 2022 at 9:15 AM. During the inspection, LPAs met with Gina Sodaro, Administrator. LPAs and the Administrator inspected the facility inside and out. On 05/19/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joe Martinez made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility mentioned above. LPA met with facility manager (FM) On 05/10/23, the Department received an Incident Report (IR) communicating an upset minor, who had been reprimanded at school for using his phone during class hours. The minor reacted violently to staff, when he arrived at the facility. Behavior included cursing, hitting and kicking another resident with a blender and a broom, and damaging the facility's van by slashing its tire with a pocketknife. Staff attempted to de-escalate the situation verbally, however, the client left the facility before law enforcement arrived. The police later apprehended the client at 4:15 PM in the community and transferred him to a juvenile hall. During the time of inspection,LPA interviewed FM in order to gather additional details related to the incident.More information is needed to conclude the investigation related to the above incident. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and due to technical difficulties with the LPA's printer, a copy of this report was emailed to FM.

The LFM disclosed after Ref. #1 was asked if Ref. #1 was okay to attend school, Ref. #1 informed staff that Ref. #1 was okay to attend school. The LPA observed an SIR from the facility to MPCRP reporting the incident and a Law Enforcement Contact Report (LIC 624-LE) dated February 4 reporting that law enforcement came to the facility to conduct a wellness check on Ref. #1. The investigation revealed inconsistent statements regarding the request for communication from the facility. The investigation revealed statements that the facility was telephoned several times and messages were left regarding Ref. #1 being taken to the hospital. The statements alleged that Ref. #1's biological mother was contacted to reach the facility. The LFM disclosed that they received the telephone calls while in a meeting. The LFM disclosed that no message was left on the voicemail. It revealed that the LFM returned the call, but did not know who was calling. The LFM revealed that they received a telephone call at around 10:45 or 11 a.m. that Ref. #1 was being transported to the hospital by ambulance. The investigation revealed that the LFM met the client at the hospital. An interview with Ref. #1 revealed that the LFM had told Ref. #1 the morning of February 3 that they would take Ref. #1 to the hospital, but Ref. #1 did not tell the LFM that Ref. #1 wanted to go. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegations There was no preponderance of the evidence to substantiate the allegation. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: On May 11, 2023 at 3:10 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, delivered the findings of a complaint investigation. The LPA met with Facility Manager (FM), Crystal Carrillo On February 3, 2023, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: Lead Facility Manager (LFM), Byron Butler at the facility on February 7, 2023; client (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 Ref. #1 dated May 11, 2023) at school on April 14, 2023. The LPA was unable to speak with the County Social Worker after leaving messages. The LPA reviewed Special Incident Reports and Ref. #1's Needs and Services Plan. The investigation revealed that on the January 28, 2023 Ref. #1 sustained an injury in his private area after horseplaying with another client at the facility when the other client accidently kicked Ref. #1. The LPA was provided inconsistent information as to when the injury was reported to the facility staff. One statement alleged that it was reported to staff on the same date that it was sustained. The LFM disclosed the incident was not reported until February 3, 2023 after Ref. #1 was observed limping at the facility before going to school.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Timika Martin, Juliet Robles and Angelina Garibaldo on 08/24/23 at 9:40 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). LPAs reviewed one (1) of children’s records and three (3) of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed one (1) of children’s psychotropic medications and medication records. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Byron Butler, Facility Manager and provided a copy of this licensing report.

On 11/2/23, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Joe Martinez and Juliet Robles conducted an Annual/Random Inspection of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPAs Martinez and Robles met with Lead Facility Manager Byron Butler. The STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) male ambulatory clients ages 7-17 and is also licensed to provide services to Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). There are five (5) clients currently in placement. At 11:57 AM, LPA Martinez conducted a walk through of the facility. Physical Plant: · The Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license, Mental Health Certification, National Accreditation, and Emergency Disaster Plan are posted in the facility. · Passageways are unobstructed. · Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, other chemicals, sharps, and knives are locked in the hallway closet. · Medications are centrally stored in a locked closet. · The facility maintains a temperature range of 68 to 85 degrees (F). · Hot water temperature measures at 115 degrees (F). · Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are operational. · Fire extinguishers are fully charged.

A working telephone is available. · The First Aid kit is complete. · All confidential files are in a locked cabinet inside the staff office. · All sinks, showers, and toilets are functional. · No more than two clients share a bedroom. · All beds have good springs, clean mattresses, and pillows. · There is an adequate supply of bedding and linens. · The facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. · Cameras are installed in the common areas of the facility. · There are no firearms or ammunition in the facility. · Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair Operations: • The facility maintains a register of clients. • The Board of Directors regularly reviews and discusses STRTP's operation. • The facility administrator and manager communicate with emergency personnel. • The facility has written complaint procedures in place. Client Records: • Five (5) client records were reviewed during the inspection. • All client records are available to the licensing agency upon demand. • Client records contain required information,examples included consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures, medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables, education records, personal rights forms..

Staff Records: • LPAs reviewed five (5) staff records. • All staff have cleared criminal records reviews and fingerprinting by DOJ, FBI, and CACI. • The Administrator meets the required qualifications and experience. • Documentation of education and experience requirements is maintained in personnel files. • Facility Managers meet requirements. Core/Therapeutic Services: • The facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents, including: • Medi-Cal specialty mental health services. • Educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports. • Activities to support children and non-minor dependents. • Services to achieve permanency. Disaster Preparedness Plan: • The facility maintains a current written disaster and mass casualty action plan. • Drills are conducted and documentation is maintained for at least a year. • An emergency and disaster plan, a register of clients, needs, and services plans for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician are maintained. Interviews: • Two (2) staff interviews • Two (2) client interviewed during the inspection. Findings: • No deficiencies were cited during the inspection. • An exit interview is conducted, and a signed copy of the LIC809 are provided to the Facility Manager.
