On January 24, 2025 at 11:40 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, conducted a Case Management for the purpose of reviewing an issue regarding the bathroom in the master bedroom. The LPA met with Lead Facility Manager, Crystal Carillo. On January 23, 2025, at LPA McGee's request, Lead Facility Manager (LFM), Crystal Carillo provided the LPA a tour of the bathrooms and bedrooms at the facility. The LPA observed three bedrooms. The LFM informed the LPA that they have six clients, two clients in each bedroom. The LPA observed that the first bedroom (master) has a bathroom. The bathroom had a sign marked staff bathroom. he LFM informed the LPA that they were given permission by their Monitoring LPA to use that bathroom for staff. LPA McGee confirmed that the facility was given information in error and informed the LFM and Administrator Gina Sordano that the facility was in violation of Interim Licensing Standard (ILS): Buildings and Grounds.87087(b)(5). No bedroom shall be used as a public or general passageway to another room, bath or toilet. The LPA requested that the facility personnel remove the sign, and informed them that no facility staff or clients not assigned to sleep in the master bedroom are allowed to utilize the master bedroom as a walkway to the bathroom located in that bedroom. The facility was given an Advisory Note for a Technical Violation in lieu of a citation since they were provided information in error. The LPA directed the facility personnel to their Monitoring LPA's Manager for further consultation regarding that bathroom. A copy of this report was emailed to the facility's authorized representative.

On February 14th, at 10:00am Licensing Program Analyst, Caitlin Chambers, made a visit to First Step for the purpose of writing the report as a revision page. The following report was conducted on January 7th, 2025 as a continuum report by Licensing Program Analyst Caitlin Chambers and Licensing Program Analyst Joe Martinez. While generating a continuum page on January 7th, 2025, and 809C was generated for the annual report from November 7th, 2024. The purpose of this visit was to do a continuation of an annual inspection on the date of January, 07, 2025. Licensing Program Analyst Caitlin Chambers and Licensing Program Analyst Joe Martinez met with Lead Facility Manager (LFM), Crystal Carrillo , the facility manager. Licensing Program Analyst Chambers (LPA) reviewed one psychotropic medication was checked with a medication log filled out appropriately, for C3 (See 811 Client Confidential names).on 01.07.25. This client was the only client who took a psychotropic medication. No other clients were prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA Chambers reviewed one client file and one staff file, and all medical history files (all medical files for all clients were in one binder) and LPA Martinez, reviewed three client records and three staff records. Client records reviewed included, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs, and services plan, activity sheets by the month, removal/discipline/complaint procedures,; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education; personal rights forms. LPA Chambers observed a current, written disaster plan, disaster drill plans there were completed each month, an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. All personnel have submitted fingerprints. All personnel subject to a criminal record review have obtained a California clearance by the Department or requested a transfer of criminal record clearance prior to working. The agency social workers have master's degrees from accredited graduate schools of social work or meet additional requirements. Staff members are qualified for their responsibilities. Personnel records are maintained on the licensee, supervisors and employees which contain health screening, tuberculosis test documents, valid CPR certificates and child abuse trainings. A copy of this report was given to the facility manager with an LIC 811 dated January 7th,2025. No deficiency were found at this time. No citation was given during this visit. An exit interview was conducted. A printed report was given to the LFM Carillo.

On February 14th, 2025 at 11:15am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA, Caitlin Chambers, conducted a case management at First Step. The purpose of the visit is to review an issue regarding the bathroom in the master bedroom. The LPA met with Lead Facility Manage (LFM), Crystal Carillo. LPA Chambers toured the facility with LFM Carillo of the bathrooms and bedrooms at the facility. The LPA observed three bedrooms. The census of the facility is six clients, two clients per bedroom. The two clients that occupy the master bedrooms as their rooms are (C5 and C6 ) The LPA observed that the first bedroom (master) has a bathroom, creating a passageway to anyone who is not a client occupying the two beds in the master bedroom. LFM Carillo stated that the facility was using the master bathroom as the staff bathroom only which had two clients utilizing the master bedroom as their bedroom, but not the bathroom. The LFM allso stated they only use the bathroom when the children are at school, as a staff bathroom prior to LPA Chambers visiting the facility on November 7th, 2024. A technical violation was issued by LPA Karen McGee on February 24th, 2025, based on the following: Interim Licensing Standard (ILS): Buildings and Grounds.87087(b)(5). No bedroom shall be used as a public or general passageway to another room, bath, or toilet. LPA Chambers advised LFM, Carillo that no one should be allowed to use the master bathroom except for the two clients that occupy the bedroom. An exit interview was conducted. A work order will be given one month from now, March 14, 2025. A printed report was given to the LFM Carillo.

The LPA observed Ref. #1's allowance log. The LPA observed an accumulated balance and no withdrawal of funds from Ref. #1's allowance from August 2024 thru mid-October 2024. The LPA observed a withdrawal of funds at a mid-point in October 2024. The LPA observed another accumulated balance from mid-October thru November 2024. The LPA observed Ref. #1's initials by each entry starting in August and ending in November on the allowance log. There was a statement made that staff would not allow Ref. #1 to utilize a bathroom that was located in the master bedroom. The investigation revealed that Ref. #1 was not assigned to sleep in the master bedroom, but slept in the middle bedroom that did not have a bathroom. Two other clients were assigned to the master bedroom. It revealed that Ref. #1 was allowed access to the bathroom in the hallway. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegations. There was no preponderance of the evidence to substantiate the allegations. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On January 24, 2025 at 11:40 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, delivered the findings of a complaint investigation. The LPA met with Lead Facility Manager, Crystal Carillo. On October 9, 2024, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: the Administrator via telephone and the Lead Facility Manager at the facility on January 23, 2025. The LPA reviewed the Client's Ref. #1's Needs & Services Plan and Allowance Log. After checking, the LPA did not observe any incident reports involving Ref. #1. There were statements made that the facility would not give the client their allowance in a timely manner. The investigation revealed that the facility staff dispensed the allowance on the weekends, and asked clients if they wanted to spend or save their allowance. It revealed that Ref. #1 was 18 years old and would leave the facility on the weekends, not being present when the allowance was dispensed.

narrative: On 2/27/25, the Department received a complaint alleging: Staff kicked client. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, all relevant parties denied the allegation. Confidential interviews conducted during the investigation were unable to corroborate the allegation as there were no witnesses nor statements obtained to support the allegation. Based on the information gathered, the allegation is unsubstantiated as the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met although the allegations may have happened or are valid. A copy of this report, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.
investigation_findings: On April 17,2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo made an unannounced visit to the STRTP for the purpose of delivering findings to the above complaint investigation. LPA met with representative and discussed the following findings. Investigation consisted of the following: On 3/4/25 LPA conduced 10-day at facility, reviewed files of (2) clients, requested copies of the current LIC500 Personnel Report, Client Roster, Client’s Needs and Services Plans for C1 and C2, and school information for all client in care, LPA Garibaldo conducted interviews with one staff (S1) and three clients C1, C2, C3. On 3/24/24 LPA Garibaldo interviewed Reporting Party (RP) and County Social Worker (CSW). On 3/31/24 LPA Garibaldo interviewed one Client (C4) and three staff (S2, S3, S4). (see Confidential Names forms LIC811 dated, April 17, 2025).

narrative:
On 6/07/2021 at 12:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) M. Lopez conducted an announced required annual inspection of the facility. LPA met with Program Director (PD) Deanna Mellos and inspected the facility inside and out. The facility is a one story residence with four bedrooms, two bathrooms, dining room, living room, kitchen, laundry room, and staff room. The facility has been operating with the capacity of six male from ages 13 years old to 17 years old and non-minor dependents. There were five male clients residing at this facility. The bedrooms are set up as follows: Bedroom #1 is occupied by two clients; two twin beds, all required linen, mattress in good condition. Bedroom #2 is occupied by two clients; two twin beds, all required linen, mattress in good condition and share a bathroom. Bedroom #3 is occupied by one client; one twin bed, all required linen, mattress in good condition. Bedroom #4 is occupied by one client; one twin bed, all required linen, mattress is good condition. Bedroom #1, Bedroom #3 and Bedroom #4 share a bathroom. All bedrooms contained adequate shelf and closet space for resident's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The closet in the living room is locked and contains office supplies, knives, medication, medication logs, first aid kit and clients’ files. The medication is locked in a locked box inside a cabinet in the lock closet. All hazardous items were made inaccessible to areas where residents do not have access. Cleansers/chemicals were stored in a locked cabinet above the washer in the laundry room. The facility's smoke detectors in the hallways and bedrooms were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector are located in the hallway across from Bedroom #1 and across bedroom # 2; and was tested and in operable condition.

The following required posted items were observed and accessible to children: Ombudsman and Foster Youth Bill of Rights, Grievance Procedures, the updated Personal Rights, Visitation policies, house rules, current menu and neighborhood complaint. LPA observed a sufficient supply of 7-day non-perishable food for six residents and a sufficient supply of 2-day perishable food in the kitchen. LPA observed the kitchen to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. The facility outside grounds were inspected. LPA observed the outside ground to be clean and maintenance. There was an ample amount of recreational and leisure supplies such as books, games and television available for client use. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Licensee has National Accreditation through CARF and is valid until August 31, 2022. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. Personnel Files are maintained off-site and transported to LPA within reasonable time. All staff who work at the facility have Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance index check clearances. A review of client records was also completed on this date including the Medication Administration Record (See Confidential Name List- LIC 811 dated on June 07, 2021). Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation. Children and staff records are organized. Staff’s CPR and First Aid card were current. Child's records contain original needs and services plan signed by the child and their authorized rep. Child's records contain authorization for emergency medical care signed by each child's authorized rep. Licensee has a current needs and services plan for each resident on file. Facility personnel meet staff training requirements. Based on observations made during the inspection, no deficiencies observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted and this report was reviewed with Program Director (PD) Deanna Mellos and a copy of this report was provided.

Confidential interviews stated C1 was at the facility for about ten days, C1 refused to follow facility rules and C1 was an AWOL risk. Confidential interviews stated all clients are treated with respect, the food menu and the activity calendar are followed however, other information provided alleged the incidents occurred. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff argue with Client #1 (C1), facility staff do not provide enough for C1 to eat and facility staff do not provide activities for C1 while in care may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report was emailed to Facility Administrator Deanna Mellos.
investigation_findings: 13On August 05, 2022, at 12:00 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Facility Administrator Deanna Mellos of First Step Treatment Home to discuss the investigative findings for the allegations noted above. On September 09, 2021, at 12:15 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez met with Facility Manager Antonio Tucker to conduct an unannounced initial complaint investigation. LPA conducted a safety inspection and no deficiencies were observed at that time. During the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with four staff (S1-S4), four clients (C1-C4), and reviewed incident reports. On September 01, 2021, the Department received allegations that facility staff argue with Client #1 (C1), facility staff do not provide enough for C1 to eat and facility staff do not provide activities for C1. Confidential interviews contradicted the information stating that staff do not argue with any clients; food and snacks are always available to clients; and clients are provided with daily activities, weekend outings and follow a monthly activity calendar. (see continuation form LIC9099-Cdated 08/05/2022)

narrative: Confidential interviews stated it was unknown what provoked C1 to contact law enforcement, however when law enforcement arrived, C1 was put on a 5150 due to threats of self-harm. Confidential interviews denied C1 was bullied by other minors or staff however, C1 was unable to be interviewed for further information. Based on confidential interviews, although the allegations that staff is allowing C1 to be bullied by other minor(s) in care, may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report was provided to Facility Manager Antonio Tucker.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/02/2022, at 1:25 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Facility Manager Antonio Tucker, of First Step Treatment Home to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. On 03/01/2022 at 2:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an unannounced complaint investigation at the above facility and met with Facility Manager (FM) Antonio Tucker. LPA conducted a safety inspection, and no deficiencies were observed at that time. The investigation consisted of confidential interviews with one facility administrator, three facility staff, one service worker and review of incident reports. LPA attempted to interview client #1 (C1) however C1 was unable to be interviewed. On 02/24/2022, the Department received an allegation that staff is allowing C1 to be bullied by other minor(s) in care. Confidential interviews stated C1 was not bullied however, C1 called law enforcement on multiple occasions stating C1 was being hurt. (see continuation form LIC9099-C dated 12/02/22)

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Latricia Rogers conducted a case management inspection on May 9. 2023 @ 10:43 am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 4 out of 9 Child Care Workers and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 9 Child Care Workers and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated May 9, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Latricia Rogers observed documentation of completed training records indicating staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Antonio Tucker, Administrator.

On June 27, 2023, at 9:55 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived unannounced to First Step Treatment Home and met with Amber Carter, Shift Supervisor. The purpose of this visit was to address a deficiency that was noted. On March 20, 2023, the Department received information regarding an incident that took place at the facility. On June 19, 2023, LPA Jauregui was conducting confidential interviews which revealed S1 placed C1 in a bear hug during a physical altercation, falling to the floor, and continuing bear hug. Based on interviews, the Licensee did not follow their plan of operations in utilizing physical restraint on C1; plan of operation indicates there will be no use of physical restraints. An exit interview was conducted, and plan of correction was developed and discussed with Amber Carter, Shift Supervisor. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Amber Carter, Shift Supervisor.

deficiencies.description:
80022  Plan of Operation Health and Safety Code section 1531.15 provides in pertinent part: (f) (4) A description of how the facility will manage residents' lack of hazard awareness and impulse control behavior, which shall emphasize positive behavioral supports and techniques that are alternatives to physical, chemical, or mechanical restraints, or seclusion.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews the facility did not follow their plan of operations in utilizing physical restraint on C1, due to S1 placing C1 in an inappropriate hold, which poses an immediate personal rights risk to the residence in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will provide descalation training and provide CCL proof of completion by Friday July 7, 2023.

deficiencies.title: Plan of Operation Health and Safety Code section 1531.15 provides in pertinent part
deficiencies.description: (f) (4) A description of how the facility will manage residents' lack of hazard awareness and impulse control behavior, which shall emphasize positive behavioral supports and techniques that are alternatives to physical, chemical, or mechanical restraints, or seclusion.

narrative: On October 12, 2023 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived to the facility's corporate office and met with Deanna Mellos, Director. The purpose of this Case Management inspection is to conduct an annual continuation from 10/6/2023. LPA Jauregui reviewed three staff files (S1-S3). The staff files have the acknowledgement of child abuse reporting requirements, criminal record clearances, staff qualifications, job duties, and training requirements. LPA reviewed Board Meeting notes to be filed and conducted quarterly. Based on observations made during the inspection and file reviews no deficiencies were observed during today’s inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Deanna Mellos, Director.

On October 6, 2023, at 8:25 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducted an unannounced annual inspection. LPA met with administrator Antonio “Sean” Tucker and explained the purpose of the visit. LPA began the inspection by conducting two client interviews and two staff interviews. LPA inspected the facility’s physical plant. The facility is a one-story residence with a circular driveway and separate office in the back yard. Inside the main facility there are four bedrooms, two bathrooms, kitchen, staff room, living room, and laundry room. There are currently five clients residing at this facility with no more than two clients sharing a bedroom. All four bedrooms had mattresses and pillows in good condition, clean sheets and blankets, and closet or dresser space with clothing. LPA observed extra linens and towels in the closet, which were clean and in good condition. Both bathrooms were clean and sanitary with a working shower, sink, and toilet. Additionally, the sink in each bathroom fell within the regulations for water temperature: 118.4- and 109.8-degrees Fahrenheit. LPA observed the kitchen to be clean and sanitary with fresh fruit available on the counter. LPA observed the refrigerator, pantry, and chest freezer to be fully stocked, exceeding the requirement for food supplies. Finally, LPA observed a menu for the week posted on the refrigerator door consisting of three meals and snacks. Adjacent to the kitchen area, the staff room prominently displays the facility license, grievance procedures, foster child bill of rights, facility sketch, and emergency disaster plan. LPA observed the living room to be clean and contain a large couch, two TV’s, video games, and board games. CONTINUED...

...CONTINUED The closet in the living room is locked and contains sharps, medication, medication logs, and first aid kits. The facility contains multiple carbon monoxide and smoke detectors, all of which were tested to be operable. The laundry rooms consist of a washer and dryer machine, and all detergents, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are made inaccessible and locked in cabinets above the washer and dryer. The backyard consists of several patios, a basketball hoop, and exercise area. LPA observed no safety hazards in the backyard. Finally, LPA tested the seatbelts and blinkers in the car used to transport clients, all of which were operable. Client files were provided to LPA for review, and of which contained the required paperwork, including signed admission agreement, signed needs and services plans, and records of cash resources and personal property. Additionally, one staff file was reviewed, and no deficiencies were observed. Due to time constraints, the annual is being extended to conduct an inspection of the remaining staff files. Based on observations made during the inspection, there were no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Tucker. A copy of the report was emailed for signatures and the signed documents will be kept in the facility file.

Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that S1 handled C1 in a rough manner is SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. This posed an potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care, the facility will be cited for violating Interim Licensing Standards STRTP, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, 87072 Personal Rights (c)(10)To be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons. An exit interview was conducted, and plan of corrections was developed with Deanna Mellos, Director and Amber Jansen. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Deanna Mellos, Director.
investigation_findings: 13On October 12, 2023, at 10:06 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced complaint inspection at the facility's corportate office. The purpose of the inspection is to deliver the findings for the above allegation and met with Deanna Mellos, Director. LPA Jauregui conducted an inspection of the facility on August 2, 2023, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA conducted three staff (S1-S3) interviews and three client (C1-C3) interviews. On July 28, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received the allegation that staff handled minor in a rough manner. Confidential interviews indicated C1 had escalated inside the facility, went outside to the front of the facility, and began hitting staff’s vehicle with their casted arm. To prevent C1 from causing damage to staffs vehicle S1 grabbed C1’s arm to move C1 away from the vehicle causing C1 to fall to the ground. S1 grabbing C1’s arm leading C1 to fall to the ground did not accord C1 dignity in their personal relationships with staff. CONTINUED....

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights (c)(10) The licensee shall ensure that each child…To be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons.

This requirement was not met based on: Based on confidential interviews, C1 was not accorded dignity in their personal relationship with staff by S1 grabbing C1’s arm, causing C1 to loose their balance and fall to the ground.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will provide Personal Rights Training and Prudent Parenting Training. Facility will provide proof of completed training to CCL by Friday October 27, 2023.

narrative: On January 23, 2023 at 8:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem arrived unannounced to the facility and met with First Step Treatment Home (FS) Antonio "Shawn" Tucker, Administrator to discuss a case management inspection. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information that the Facility did not report to CCL multiple incidents that occurred in the home which involved Client #1 (C1) prior to discharge. Confidential interviews reveal that C1 absconded from FS for several days after stealing $140.00 from staff, often appeared under the influence of “something stronger than marijuana,” and attempted to break into the medicine and knife cabinet. Record review reveals that CCL did not receive incident reports for any of these occurrences. The facility is being cited for violating California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, regulation 80061(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted with Antonio "Shawn" Tucker, and a signed copy of this report and appeal rights were provided.

deficiencies.description:
80061(B)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements:
 …a written report…shall be submitted to the licensing agency…following the occurrence of…Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, FS staff were aware of reportable incidents involving C1 and did not report the incidents to Community Care Licensing (CCL), which poses a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator Tucker, the responsibility of writing and submitting special incident reports to CCL will be delegated to shift supervisor Amber Carter, and training on reporting requirments will be conducted with both staff members. Additionally, proof of training and training materials will be submitted to CCL by 1/31/24.

narrative: CONTINUED... Based on confidential interviews the allegation alleging Staff made an inappropriate comment to youth on multiple occasions may have occurred, however it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights to Antonio "Shawn" Tucker.
investigation_findings: 13On January 23, 2024, at 8:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacob Salem met with Antonio "Shawn" Tucker, Adminstrator of First Step Treatment Home to deliver the finding for the above stated allegation. LPA Salem conducted an inspection of the facility on 10/23/23 and no deficiencies were observed. LPA Salem conducted interviews with Staff (S1-4) and Clients (C1-C6). In addition, LPA reviewed C1’s Appraisal/Needs and Services Plan and Child and Family Team meeting notes. On October 16, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging Staff made an inappropriate comment to youth on multiple occasions. Specifically, it was reported that S2 called C1 a “bitch” repeatedly during the morning of 10/13/23. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements of whether S2 used profanity towards C1 and what language S2 specifically used. CONTINUED...

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi on April 18, 2024 at 9:38 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Choi met with Residential Director, Robyn Reyes and conducted an inspection of the facility. LPA reviewed two of child’s records and three of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed two of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed two staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA will interview two clients that are prescribed psychotropic medication, at a later time and/or date. . During the inspection LPA observed no deficiencies. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Residential Director Robyn Reyes.

...CONTINUED A conflicting confidential interview disclosed that S1 and S2 did not yell at or approach C1 aggressively during this incident, but S1 did get in C1’s face in a threatening manner on separate occasions. Confidential interviews indicate that S1 “matches clients’ energy” and goes “chest to chest” with clients when they are escalated. Conflicting confidential interviews indicates that C1 would get in S1’s face while living at the facility, and that S1 does not yell at clients or make them uncomfortable. Confidential interviews and a record review of special incident reports reveal that C1 became escalated during a therapy session with S2, leading to C1 punching out the kitchen window and being placed on a psychiatric hold. A confidential interview indicates that S2 was heard yelling back and forth with C1 during the therapy session and calling C1 a liar. A conflicting confidential interview indicates that S2 was using an assertive tone rather than yelling and was instructing C1 to leave their office for being vulgar and unruly. A confidential interview with C1 indicates that S2 treated C1 respectfully during the therapy session. Confidential interviews indicate that S2 is respectful towards clients during therapy sessions and has not been seen yelling at or calling clients names. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegation that staff members (S1 and S2) spoke inappropriately to youth in care (C1) is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Antonio "Shawn" Tucker, Facility Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On July 11, 2024 at 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Antonio "Shawn" Tucker, Facility Manager of First Step Treatment Home to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegation. LPA Salem initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on 1/23/2024 at 8:45 AM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, LPA Salem interviewed Clients (C1-C4), Staff (S1-S5). LPA Salem obtained and reviewed pertinent records. On January 19, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff members (S1 and S2) spoke inappropriately to youth in care (C1). Confidential interviews and record review of special incident reports indicate that C1 became escalated during a house meeting by threatening staff and peers. A confidential interview indicates that S1 and S2 responded by yelling in C1’s face, causing C1 to escalate further. CONTINUED...

narrative: ...CONTINUED However, a conflicting confidential interview stated that after attempts at redirection failed, S1 tried to position themself in front of the door, which inadvertently struck S1’s foot. As a result, C1 took a step back, but the door did not hit C1. A confidential interview with C1 indicated that S1 did put their foot in the door, but the door did not hit C1. Other confidential interviews with witnesses present during the incident indicated that although S1 did push back on the door as C1 was closing it, C1 was not hit by the door and was not injured during or after the incident. During an inspection of C1’s bedroom door, LPA Salem observed two medium-sized holes toward the bottom on the bedroom side of the door. Confidential interviews and a review of an incident report suggest that C1 barricaded themself in the bedroom after the back-and-forth with S1 by pushing the bed against the door, which may have caused the holes. Additionally, confidential interviews indicated that S1 is not perceived as aggressive or threatening toward clients when they are misbehaving or not following instructions. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegation that Staff (S1) engaged in an inappropriate interaction with a youth (C1), resulting in the youth (C1) getting hit by a door is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to D'Andre James, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On September 6, 2024 at 4:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with D'Andre James, Administrator of First Step Treatment Home to deliver the finding for the above-stated allegation. LPA Salem initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on 3/5/2024 at 3:40 PM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, LPA Salem interviewed Clients (C1-C5), Staff (S1-S4), and a Court Appointed Child Advocate. LPA Salem obtained and reviewed pertinent records. On February 28, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that Staff (S1) engaged in an inappropriate interaction with a youth (C1), resulting in the youth (C1) getting hit by a door. It was reported that S1 placed their foot in C1’s door while C1 was closing it, causing the door to bounce back and strike C1. A confidential interview indicated that after a back-and-forth exchange involving C1 slamming and S1 opening the bedroom door, reportedly, S1 admitted to pushing the door, which hit C1 and caused C1 to lose balance. CONTINUED...

narrative:
CONTINUED... During the investigation, LPA Saeteurn interviewed clients (C2-C6), Staff (S1-S2), one witness (W1), and reviewed facility pertinent records. Confidential interviews revealed an incident in which C1 became upset with S1. Confidential interviews indicated that while C1 and other clients were being transported to school, S1 requested C1 to fill in open seats in the back of the facility van after C1 sat between two clients in the middle row, leaving minimal space between them. A confidential interview indicated that although there are no rules regarding client seating, C1 was asked to leave space after both clients sitting next to C1 complained about there not being enough room and to prevent clients from touching each other due to the lack of space. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 became upset and began to yell at S1. Confidential interviews revealed S1 asked C1 multiple times to stop their behavior due to C1 yelling. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 did not yell at C1 and was not disrespectful while addressing C1. Confidential interviews did not reveal any additional information on how S1 interacts with C1 or other clients in care, and due to C1 refusing an interview, LPA was unable to receive additional information regarding the way S1 treats C1. During the investigation a confidential interview revealed that C1 later expressed not wanting their video games taken away. Confidential interviews revealed that the facility wi-fi is disconnected from clients’ personal devices as a form of consequence. Additionally, confidential interviews revealed that the disconnection from Wi-Fi prevents clients from playing games online. Confidential interviews revealed that all clients, including C1, are aware of this consequence. Additionally, confidential interviews revealed there was no specific time frame of how long these consequences can last however, confidential interviews revealed the length depends on the severity of the clients’ actions. Confidential interviews did, however, reveal that in situations in which clients need to utilize the internet to complete homework or other important needs, facility staff will provide internet connection. A review of the facility’s Program Statement revealed that when consequences are given to clients their privileges are limited. The program statement includes that appropriate forms of limiting privileges include, limiting radio, TV, and outings, however, there is no information on the disconnection of Wi-Fi. CONTINUED...

CONTINUED... Based on interviews conducted and record review, the allegations that staff did not treat minor with dignity and staff used inappropriate forms of punishment are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Robyn Reyes, Residential Director. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Robyn Reyes, Residential Director, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.
investigation_findings: 13On December 5, 2024 at 9:28 AM. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abby Saeteurn made an unannounced visit to First Step Treatment Home and met with Robyn Reyes, Residential Director to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA Saeteurn initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on September 25, 2024, at 1:50 PM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. On September 19, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff did not treat a minor in care with dignity and staff used inappropriate forms of punishment. It was reported that S1 treats C1 unfairly and C1 is the only client that gets in trouble when bringing up concerns about other clients in care to S1. It was reported that S1 threatens to take away C1’s games and Wi-fi as a form of punishment. It was also reported that S1 raises their voice and is rude and does not treat C1 with respect and C1 believes it us due to their race. CONTINUED...

narrative: It was reported C1 and the other client were throwing sand at each other when S1 called C1 over to a table. It was reported C1 tried to explain the situation to S1 when S1 used profanity while responding to C1, causing C1 to feel uncomfortable. Confidential interviews and a review of pertinent facility records confirmed that on September 28, 2024, the facility hosted an outing to Mission Beach. Confidential interviews revealed all clients attended the outing which was supervised by S1 and S2. In addition, confidential interviews revealed that W1 also attended the event. A confidential interview and review of pertinent facility records revealed that during the outing, C1 and C2 engaged in an inappropriate conversation which led to C1 throwing sand at C2. A confidential interview and review of records confirmed that staff prompted both clients to stop, resulting in C1 becoming upset and punching C2. Confidential interviews and a review of pertinent facility records revealed that staff intervened by putting separation between clients and prompting both clients to stop, however, C1 proceeded to hit C2 a second time and C2 defended their self. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was upset at staff intervening and was reported to be defiant in their behavior by arguing with staff. A confidential interview indicated that S1 used profanity when addressing C1, and one confidential interview confirmed that S1 used a profane word while in the proximity of C1. The confidential interview revealed that the word was said under S1’s breath and was not directed at C1 or any other client. The confidential interview revealed that C1 mistakenly thought S1 told C1 to shut up and S1 clarified they did not. An attempt to complete an interview with S2 who was reported to be present during this interaction was unsuccessful. Based on conflicting interviews and records review, the allegation that staff spoke to minor in an inappropriate manner is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Antonio "Shawn" Tucker, Facility Manager. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Antonio "Shawn" Tucker, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.

met_with: Claudia Rice, Jennifer Woolery, Jake Caskill
narrative:
On the above date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Meghan McGee conducted an unannounced annual/required inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on June 1, 2018. LPA met with Claudia Rice, Division Director, Jennifer Woolery, and Jake Caskill for a tour of the inside and outside of the facility was conducted. Currently in placement are 38 clients. The facility is licensed to care for 70 clients ages 6-14 years, ambulatory only. The facility is located in a residential area and was set as follows: There are 6 Residential Cottages on the premises: 1) LARK COTTAGE (girls) consist of 10 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and laundry room. All bedrooms were equipped with one twin size bed, dresser locker space, adequate lighting, first aid kit, two extinguishers, staff office and private bathroom. 2) DOVE COTTAGE (girls) consist of 10 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and washer and dryer room. All bedrooms were equipped with one twin size bed, dresser drawer space, adequate lighting, first aid kit, two extinguishers, staff office and private bathroom. 3) FALCON COTTAGE (boys) consist of 10 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and laundry room. 9 bedrooms were equipped with one twin size bed. 1 bedroom was equipped with two twin size beds and all bedrooms had adequate dresser drawer space, adequate lighting, first aid kit, two extinguishers, staff office and private bathroom. 4) EAGLE COTTAGE (boys) consist of 10 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and washer and dryer room. All bedrooms were equipped with one twin size bed, dresser drawer space, adequate lighting, first aid kit, two extinguishers, staff office and private bathroom.

5) KODIAK COTTAGE (boys) total of 10 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and washer and dryer room. All bedrooms were equipped with one twin size bed, dresser drawer space, adequate lighting, first aid kit and two extinguishers. 6) SPRUCE COTTAGE used to be a cottage for clients. Jennifer Woolery let LPA know that the cottage has been converted to staff offices for TSCF. Spruce cottage was converted over about 2 years ago. 7) SEQUOIA COTTAGE (currently vacant, no clients placed) consist of 10 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and laundry room. All bedrooms were equipped with one twin size bed, dresser drawer space, adequate lighting, first aid kit, two extinguishers, staff office and private bathroom. There is also a Nurse’s Station where the client's medication is kept inaccessible to clients and only available to the nursing staff through a double door combination lock. Main building consists of multiple staff offices and meeting rooms. Food is prepared on facility campus and is equipped with a dining area. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials were observed. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Licensee has provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. Currently no clients are using contraceptives. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair.

Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Administrator Claudia Rice is present at the facility with a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. Licensee has obtained Mental Health Certification. The MH Certification is valid through June 6, 2022. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA (Council of Accreditation). The Accreditation is valid through December 31st, 2019. The facility has a camera waiver that is meeting the terms and conditions that approved when the facility was a licensed group home. LPA will return to review personnel and clients files to ensure it meets regulatory requirements. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel Files and client files are maintained on-site. Client and staff interviews will be conducted at a later date. There were deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards. Exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility for due to COVID-19 Public Health Crisis.

narrative:
On September 15., 2021 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Meghan McGee had a Technical Assistance (TA) call with Five Acres regarding concerns with sections of the program statement (PS) and Special Incident Reports (SIR). On the call were the following: Community Care Licensing (CCL), Five Acres Staff, System of Care (SOC), Department of Mental Health Services (DMHC), and representative of Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS). During the TA call, the following items were discussed: 1. The purpose of this TA call was to discuss SIRs; making sure staff are taking appropriate actions when LPA's conduct review. 2. Board Director's Meeting Notes - LPA Larios recently conducted a Law Enforcement (LE) inspection. LPA Larios reviewed the board of directors notes and noticed there was no evidence discussing LE contacts on SIRs. LPA Larios had a conversation and Jennifer Woolery will circle back and review the notes to make sure that was discussed and not missed during future meeting. 3. Program Statement - Updates needed to be based on newest version of STRTP ILS Version 3.1. - Section 17 of PS: Restitution program needs to be defined differently and not use restitution. Define it as clinical intervention, how it teaches other skills to clients in care, and go into detail of PS so it is a clearer picture. - Section 22 of PS: Needs to be more descriptive of how it is Trauma Informed and needs to be clear that it meets the needs of clients from 6-NMD.

4. Review of SIRs - SIRs need to include the following: 1) What happened before and triggered the restraint of client, 2) what happened during the restraint, and 3) debrief of the incident (Follow up). - If same child is being restrained time and time again, there needs to be progress notes and treatment plan needs to be discussed or changed. - Need to add time of incident. - Need to have more clinical staff present for incidents regarding restraints. If they are present then it needs to be noted in SIR. - Claudia Rice mentioned that there needs to be more training for staff on how to write SIRs. Making sure full story content is detailed in the SIR. - In regards to belt pivot, include description of belt pivot, purpose of it and how it is used. Address Emergency Intervention in section of PS and the types of restraints from least restrictive to more severe. Discussed bared wire on the roof. Facility staff have been keeping youth engaged in activities to deter them from going on the roof. Youth are able to go places and have other creative ideas to alleviate the idea of going on the roof. LPA will follow up with Five Acres in 30 days for submission of revision for PS. A copy of the report will be emailed for signature.

On December 29, 2020 at 3:00PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Meghan McGee contacted Division Director, Claudia Rice, for the purpose of conducting a case management for an incident that occurred. On January 27, 2021 at 2:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Meghan McGee had a virtual tour with Five Acres regarding the barbed wire on the roof where clients at the facility are getting injured from AWOLing. On the call were the following individuals: Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Alan Henry, Regional Manager (RM) Kellee Coleman, Claudia Rice Division Director and Tiffani Tran Division Director of Residential Programs. During the virtual tour the following items were discussed: 1. Clients having access to barbed wire on the roof. - A virtual tour was given of the barbed wire on the roof. Clients are able to access the barbed wire from climbing on the pillars which leads to the catwalk to have access to the roof. Although, Five Acres had tried various ways to limit children from accessing the roof, clients became creative and still found ways to access the roof. Los Angeles Department of Child and Family Services (DCFS) has concerns with clients eventually seriously injuring themselves on the barbed wire located on the roof. Community Care Licensing (CCL) main concern with this is the health and safety for the youth in care. -Due to where the clinicians offices are located in the main building, clients are able to exit through the emergency exit and access the roof. RM Coleman requested pictures of campus where the barbed wire is located to have a better visual to assess the situation at hand. 2. Plan of Correction (POC) from October 2019 - A review of what was corrected from the Plan of Correction (POC) sent from Five Acres in October 2019. LPM Smith asked the following: Did Five Acres get permission to install barbed wire from CCL? Claudia Rice Division Director clarified that the barbed wire already existed on the roof and fence around the facility prior to POC in October 2019. Currently, there is barbed wire around the 10 foot fence that surrounds the campus and on the roof.

After the virtual tour the following items were discussed to have a follow up regarding the barbed wire: - Five Acres collecting data to see how many injuries have occurred from the barbed wire on the roof. - Meeting with DCFS to discuss further action regarding clients getting injured from accessing the roof. - Brainstorming ideas to prevent clients from climbing on the roof where barbed wire is located. - Joint meeting with CCL, DCFS, and Five Acres to determine what will be done regarding the barbed wire on the roof. A copy of the report will be emailed for signature.

On November 16, 2021, at 8:30am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Emelyn Sanchez P. and Olivia Rosas arrived at the above facility unannounced for the purpose of conducting a SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Case Management- Medication Inspection Visit. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas met with Claudia Rice, Division Director. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas reviewed ten (10) client files and three (3) staff files. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas conducted three (3) staff interviews. Currently there are thirty-three (33) clients residing in the above facility. This is a facility located in a residential area and there are six (6) Residential Cottages on the premises. LPAs inspected the Lark Cottage (girls), Dove Cottage (girls), Falcon Cottage (boys) each cottage consist of ten (10) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and laundry room. All bedrooms were equipped with one (1) twin size bed, dresser locker space, adequate lighting, first aid kit, two extinguishers, staff office and private bathroom. Common areas area clean and in good repair. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured. The backyard had play area and basket ball court. Outdoor space is free of obstructions. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed adequate staffing in the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas also observed medication to stored in the nursing unit, triple locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative:
The matter was brought to the attention of Facility Administration and upon facility internal investigation, it was discovered that S1 was communicating with C1 via text message and Instagram. It was also discovered that S1 had purchased gifts for C1. When confronted by facility Administration, S1 denied buying gifts or texting C1; however, facility obtained proof to support the claims that S1 was communicating with C1 and had purchased gifts for C1. On May 26, 2021, S1 was terminated from employment for reasons including, but not limited to, having inappropriate unauthorized communication and purchasing various gifts for C1. The Department has investigated the complaint and found that the allegation is Unsubstantiated at this time meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove sexual abuse by S1 on C1. There were no deficiencies cited at this time.

The text messages contained messages alluding to inappropriate content by S1. It was further revealed that S1 had purchased various gifts for C1 that were against facility gift policy. An interview with S1 by CCL Investigator Seng revealed admission by S1 of sending text messages to C1 and purchasing various gifts for C1. Based on information obtained from interviews and documentary facts, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The Department has determined former staff member S1 engaged in inappropriate conduct with C1 while in care. The allegation is deemed substantiated at this time and thus poses potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The following citation is issued in accordance with the Health and Safety Code 1550(c) Conduct Inimical. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, Confidential Names List and appeal rights emailed to Facility Administrator Claudia Rice. (Continued on page LIC9099-D)

narrative: LPA review of video footage did not reveal injuries consistent with C1 receiving such injuries while in care. LPA was unable to substantiate the allegation that staff failed to prevent minor from harm while in care. Confidential interviews revealed that residents are supervised at all times but sometimes they may fall or hurt themselves while playing which is not always preventable. Confidential interviews also revealed that Client #1 (C1) did have a few scratches due to being “hyper” and also “bumped” their chin during play which could not be prevented. LPA review of video footage determined that C1 appears to be “hyper” and unable to control movements which could possibly result in injuries if not careful. LPA was unable to substantiate the allegation that staff failed to notify minor's authorized representative of incidents. Confidential interviews revealed that incidents are cross reported to all reporting agencies including C1’s authorized representative. LPA was unable to substantiate the allegation that staff failed to safeguard minor’s personal belongings. Although documentary evidence shows an inventory of C1’s missing clothing items when C1 returned home from Five Acres, it did not reveal that staff failed to safeguard C1’s personal belongings as it only reveals that clothing items can be lost, missing, or mixed up with other client belongings. It was also revealed that C1 would run out of the cottage with one shoe on which would result in a missing shoe. Confidential interviews did not reveal that staff did not meet C1’s needs. Confidential interviews revealed that there was a misunderstanding by the parents of C1 of services being provided for C1. The parents of C1 were under the impression that staff would be providing a one-on-one for C1 and became upset with Five Acres with not being in agreement with what C1’s diagnosis should be necessitating the need for C1 to have a one-on-one. Based on the interviews conducted, documentary evidence, and LPA video review, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. LPA Edison was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

narrative: This an amended report from the original date of 7/28/2022. Documentary evidence revealed that Staff #1 (S1) caused an injury to Client #1 (C1) in the form of a red handprint on C1’s back which is consistent with statements that S1 “slapped” C1 on the back. LPA obtained photos of the injury to C1’s back which clearly show the red imprint of a hand on C1’s back. LPA obtained a copy of the Health Services Illness/Injury Report completed by the nurse who treated C1 for the injury. Information provided in the report revealed “there was a visible imprint of a hand” on C1’s mid back area which was red but not yet bruised. Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence, the preponderance of standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. Facility cited on the attached LIC 9099-D for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 87072(c)(11) Personal Rights. Staff caused an injury to Client #1 by slapping C1 on the back leaving a red handprint on C1’s back. Appeal rights were discussed with Crisis Intervention Specialist. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

deficiencies.description:
This an amended report from the original date of 7/28/2022.    87072 Personal Rights (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights:
(11)  To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and documentary evidence, S1 caused an injury to C1 by slapping C1 on the back leaving a red handprint on C1’s back, which poses/posed a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: LPA advised Crisis Intervention Specialist (CIS) to submit a written plan stating how to ensure incidents like this won't happen again. CIS stated that they will inform Division Director of POC and POC due date.

On November 3, 2022 at 10:19am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an announced visit to Five Acres STRTP for the purpose of conducting a Case Management, (Licensee Initiated). LPA met with Claudia Rice, Division Director who granted access to the facility and together with LPA Edison, a tour was conducted. The purpose of this visit is licensee is requesting a change, reducing capacity from seventy (70) to a capacity of sixteen (16) children. The facility is currently licensed to provide care and supervision for seventy (70) children, ages 6-14 years, ambulatory only. There is a gated pool on the premises. Naloxone Hydrochloride waiver is on file. The census on the date of this visit is eleven (11). The facility is in a residential neighborhood with a total of eight (8) cottages on the premises. 1) DOVE COTTAGE (STRTP): Females only. Consists of ten (10) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and laundry room. All bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin size bed with drawer storage, closet space, and adequate lighting. All bedding is clean and in good condition. There is a hall storage area with extra linens and hygiene products. The bathrooms have a toilet, shower and are clean and sanitary and in operable condition. The cottage is equipped with two (2) fully charged regulation fire extinguishers, staff office and staff bathroom. Currently there are seven (7) clients housed in Dove Cottage. 2) FALCON COTTAGE (STRTP): Males only. Consists of ten (10) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and laundry room. All bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin size bed with drawer storage, closet space, and adequate lighting. All bedding is clean and in good condition. There is a hall storage area with extra linens and hygiene products. The bathrooms have a toilet, shower and are clean and sanitary and in operable condition. The cottage is equipped with two (2) fully charged regulation fire extinguishers, staff office and staff bathroom. Currently there are four (4) clients housed in Falcon Cottage. Continued on LIC 809-C

3) WILLOW COTTAGE: Females only. Currently used for housing Five Acres Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) clients only. Consists of seven (7) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and laundry room. Four (4) bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin size bed and three (3) bedrooms are equipped with two (2) twin size beds. All beds have drawer storage. All bedrooms are equipped with closet space and adequate lighting. All bedding is clean and in good condition. The bathrooms have a toilet, shower and are clean and sanitary and in operable condition. Also houses a Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS) co-locater staff office. 4) KODIAK COTTAGE: Males only. Currently used for housing Five Acres Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) clients only. Consists of ten (10) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and laundry room. All bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin size bed with drawer storage, closet space, and adequate lighting. All bedding is clean and in good condition. The bathrooms have a toilet, shower and are clean and sanitary and in operable condition. Also houses a Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS) co-locater staff office. 5) SPRUCE COTTAGE: Currently utilized for Willow Cottage (TSCF) Unit Program Coordinator staff offices only. Also utilized for extra storage space. 6) SEQUOIA COTTAGE: Currently utilized for Kodiak Cottage (TSCF) Unit Program Coordinator staff offices only. Also utilized for extra storage space. 7) LARK COTTAGE: Vacant. Utilized for extra storage space. 8) EAGLE COTTAGE: Vacant. Utilized for extra storage space. The campus also houses a Nurse’s Station on the premises where client's medication is kept inaccessible to clients and only available to the nursing staff through a double door combination lock. Main building consists of multiple staff offices and meeting rooms. Food is prepared on facility campus and is equipped with a dining area. Continued on LIC 809-C

Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials were observed. There are no firearms or weapons located at the facility. All posting requirements have been met. Facility is currently operating within the limits of their license. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

investigation_findings: 13On November 1, 2022 at 11:08am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres and spoke with Claudia Rice, Division Director. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, a total of one (1) client, three (3) staff, and one (1) witness were interviewed. Statements made during confidential interviews with Staff #1 (S1), Staff #2 (S2), and Staff #3 (S3) revealed that Client #1 (C1) may not have been in placement at Five Acres during the time the incident was alleged. Staff interviews revealed no knowledge of the identity of C1. LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff who were employed at Five Acres during the time the alleged incident occurred. Confidential interviews with Witness #1 and C1 revealed C1 was placed at Five Acres approximately in 2018. Continued on LIC 9099-C

narrative: Confidential interviews also revealed the incident did not involve Client #2. LPA conducted confidential interviews with Staff #3 (S3), Witness #1 (W1), and Client #2 (C2) which revealed consistent statements that the incident may have occurred between Client #4 (C4) and C1, not C2. Confidential interviews revealed that C4 goes by the same first name as C2. Although it could not be determined whether the allegation occurred, a plan was implemented after facility staff conducted their investigation to separate C1 and C4 by moving C4 to a different cottage. Documentary evidence revealed that an incident occurred between C1 and C4, not C2. LPA Edison obtained a copy of Special Incident Report (SIR) # 758640. LPA Edison was unable to substantiate the allegation: Staff did not properly supervise minors in care. Confidential interviews revealed that there was adequate supervision provided on the day of the incident regarding the allegations. LPA Edison made several unsuccessful attempts to locate and speak with C1 regarding the allegations. Based on the interviews conducted, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegation. LPA Edison was not able to determine if the above said allegation occurred, therefore the allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

This an amended report from the original dated May 4, 2023. Although, C1 and the other youth were prescribed the same medication, their prescribed dosage was not the same. LPA obtained Special Incident Report #849205, documentation from C1’s visit to urgent care and hospital stays, C1’s medication log, C1’s Health and Education Passport, C1’s Needs and Services Plan, facility Illness/Injury report for C1, and C1’s JV-220(A)-Physicians Statement. Although it was determined that staff mismanaged C1’s medication by dispensing another youth’s medication to C1, it is unclear what caused minor to have an adverse reaction after taking the medication. Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence, the preponderance of standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. Facility cited on the attached LIC 9099-D for violation of Interim Licensing Standards(v4), Article 06, 87075(c) Health Related Services. Staff dispensed another youth’s medication to Client #1 (C1). Appeal rights were discussed with Division Director. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

deficiencies.description:
This report has been amended to correct the deficiency.

87075 Health Related Services (c) Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 87070(b)(11).  This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documentary evidence, Staff dispensed another youth’s medication to Client #1 (C1) which is not in accordance with the written directions as prescribed by C1’s physician, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: LPA advised Division Director (DD) to submit written plan of how to prevent incident from re-occurring and explain how they will ensure client’s medication are re-filled timely.  LPA advised DD to provide re-training to staff on Health-Related Services, Title 22 Regulations by 7/13/2023.  LPA advised Division Director to provide training roster which includes name of training, date of training, and staff in attendance.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA interviewed Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3 and the Director Claudia Rice, Client #1 and the DCFS Emergency Response Worker. LPA made three telephone attempts and one written attempt to contact the Sheriff's Detective who investigated the case. However she did not respond. LPA Jones-Steward also reviewed the the Medical Hub Report, the DCFS Investigative Report and the security footage of the incident. The security video clearly showed Staff #1 lifting C1 of the floor in a violent manner. However the alleged choking could not be seen on screen. Staff #1 admitted to grabbing and lifting C1 but denied choking him. The Medical Hub Report indicated bruising congruent with the allegations that Child #1 was grabbed by Staff #1 but did not substantiate the choking. Based on the investigation by this LPA it is unsubstantiated that Client #1 was chocked by Staff #1.

deficiencies.description:
Emergency Intervention Prohibition

The following emergency interventions are prohibited: Aversive behavior modification interventions including, but not limited to, spanking and corporal punishment, body shaking, water spray, slapping, pinching, ammonia vapors, sensory deprivation and electric shock.

The facility violated this requirement when Staff #1 lifted client off the floor and assualted him as part of a prohibited restraint
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee shall present a corrective action plan to the Dept. The plan shall include but not be limited to how Staff #1, Staff2 and Staff #3 will be disciplined and/or retrained on the proper use of restraints.

deficiencies.description:
Penalties
Notwithstanding Section 80054(a), an immediate penalty of $150 per day shall be assessed for any of the following: Sickness, injury or death of a client has occurred as a result of the deficiency.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee shall pay the civil penalty upon receipt or invoice.

narrative: Statements indicated minor approached staff in an inappropriate manner of “play fighting”, dancing inappropriately in front of staff, and not following staff directives. Staff made several efforts to re-direct minor’s behavior. Documentary evidence revealed minor’s behaviors consist of displaying poor boundaries which consist of inappropriate dances in front of male staff and not following directions. LPA obtained minor’s Needs and Services Plan (NSP). Statements made during confidential interviews indicated minor became upset when staff tried to re-direct minor’s inappropriate behavior and minor reported that staff “bit” minor. Inconsistent statements indicated minor was not bitten by staff. Documentary evidence obtained indicated minor had no visible bite marks present but more of an “imprint” due to minor leaning against something or from a clothing item. LPA obtained Special Incident Report (SIR) 825630 and facility illness/injury report for minor on the day of the incident. Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. LPA Edison was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.
