narrative: On 10/26/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell conducted an unannounced Case Management- Incident inspection in order to follow-up on a Serious Incident Report that the Department received on 10/18/23. LPA O'Connell requested a copy of the LIC500- Personnel Report as well as the client roster. DD communicated that both documents would need to be produced by human resources. LPA asked if LIC500 is available upon demand and DD reports that it is not and is maintained by the human resources department. On 10/18/23, the Department received a Serious Incident Report (SIR) from the facility, reporting that a minor, C1, was not provided with prescribed medication due to staff being unable to locate medications. Missing medication was found during the next day and it was determined that LVN2 misplaced medication and did not follow facility policy for storing meds upon a client's return from a visit home. During the time of inspection, LPA O'Connell conducted investigative interviews with DD, LVN1, S1, S2, C2, and C3 [See LIC811, dated 10/26/23, for CONFIDENTIAL NAMES LIST]. Confidential interviews revealed that staff did not follow the facility policy to store medications after a client returns from a home visit. Further, it was determined that the facility does not have a clear documentation procedure related to tracking missed medication. During the investigation, LPA reviewed findings and observations with DD and retained pictures of evidence for Department records. PER California Code Regulation, there is one deficiency to be cited at this time. See LIC809D for details. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the Divisional Director at the facility.

deficiencies.description:
(k)	The following requirements shall apply to medications which are centrally stored:(7)	The licensee shall ensure the maintenance, for each client, of a record of centrally stored prescription medications which is retained for at least one year and includes the following:
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: The administrator did not ensure that medications were centrally stored and documented correctly, resulting in a missed medication for C1. This poses a potential risk to the health safety and personal rights to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: DD will provide proof of training to all nursing staff regarding regulatory requirement. DD will develop a policy and procedure that ensures complianace with the related regulation. DD will provide proof of training and established policy to LPA O'Connell by 11/13/23 via email at nancy.oconnell@dss.ca.gov.

narrative:
On December 1, 2023 at , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Deborah Lee and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith made an unannounced visit to Five Acres for the purpose of conducting an Annual Random Inspection. LPA met with Claudia Rice, Division Director, who granted access to the facility. The facility is licensed to care for 16 clients ages 6-14 years, ambulatory only. There is a gated pool on the premises. Naloxone Hydrochloride waiver on file. The facility is in a residential neighborhood with a total of eight (2) cottages on the premises for the STRTP program.. 1) DOVE COTTAGE (STRTP): Females only. Consists of ten (10) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and laundry room. All bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin size bed with drawer storage, closet space, and adequate lighting. All bedding is clean and in good condition. There is a hall storage area with extra linens and hygiene products. The bathrooms have a toilet, shower and are clean and sanitary and in operable condition. The cottage is equipped with two (2) fully charged regulation fire extinguishers, staff office and staff bathroom. Currently there are seven (9) clients housed in Dove Cottage. 2) FALCON COTTAGE (STRTP): Males only. Consists of ten (10) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, kitchen, living room area and laundry room. All bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin size bed with drawer storage, closet space, and adequate lighting. All bedding is clean and in good condition. There is a hall storage area with extra linens and hygiene products. The bathrooms have a toilet, shower and are clean and sanitary and in operable condition. The cottage is equipped with two (2) fully charged regulation fire extinguishers, staff office and staff bathroom. Currently there are four (6) clients housed in Falcon Cottage. 3) LARK COTTAGE: Vacant. Director reported cottage will be utilized for storage.

The campus also houses a Nurse’s Station on the premises where client's medication is kept inaccessible to clients and only available to the nursing staff through a double door combination lock. Main building consists of multiple staff offices and meeting rooms. Food is prepared on facility campus and is equipped with a dining area for staff. .A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials were observed. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains 2 day supply of perishable and 7 day supply of non-perishable food. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. Facility has a pool which is fenced and secured. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Licensee has obtained Mental Health Program Approval, valid through June 6, 2024. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA (Council of Accreditation). The Accreditation is valid through December 31, 2027. One staff file and one client file was reviewed during today's inspection. LPA will return to review additional client and staff files. Client and staff interviews will be conducted at a later date. There were no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Claudia Rice, Division Director.

On January 18, 2024 at 9:09 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Deborah Lee made an unannounced visit to Five Acres for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Incident inspection order to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) that the Department received on December 27, 2023. LPA met with Claudia Rice, Division Director, who granted access to the facility. The facility is licensed to care for 16 clients ages 6-14 years, ambulatory only. There is a gated pool on the premises. Naloxone Hydrochloride waiver on file. On December 27,2023, the Department received a Special Incident Report (SIR) from the facility, reporting that a minor, C1, was rape while on Unauthorized Absence (UA) from facility around Thanksgiving. During the time of inspection, LPA conducted a confidential interview with Claudia Rice, Division Director. The confidential interview revealed that C1 initially disclosed the rape to her Social Worker (CSW) who took her to get a forensic exam and any medical needs taken care of from the "HUB" which is one of several local health facilities that is associated with DCFS. Thereafter, C1 was returned to Five Acres where she met with Clinician to ensure her mental health needs where met. The facility ensured that C1 attended any follow up appointments. LPA determined that the facility took appropriate follow up steps to ensure well-being of client in care (C1). There were no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Claudia Rice, Division Director.

On June 24,2021 at 9:30AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Meghan McGee arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual Inspection for Five Acres Solita Home. LPA met with On Call Staff Jesus Lozano who granted access into the home and Sarah Carretino Residential Treatment Counselor conducted a tour of the facility. Facility provides care and supervision to 6 children, ages 12-17 years old ambulatory only and provide services to non-minor dependents. Currently residing in the facility are 4 clients. Facility was set up as follows:4 bedrooms, 4 bathrooms, Living room, TV room/game area, dining room and kitchen. There was a fireplace in the home with a secure screen. There are no bodies of water on the premises. Kitchen: There is a stove/oven with four (4) burners. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer. Bedroom #1 Occupied by client #4, has two twin size beds and adequate drawer and closet space. Bedroom #2 Occupied by client #1, has two twin size beds and adequate drawer and closet space. Bedroom #3 Occupied by client #2 & #3, has two twin size beds and adequate drawer and closet space. Bedroom door is missing. LPA McGee let staff know that door needs to replaced. LPA McGee let staff know to follow up with clients completing daily chores ie. taking out trash and monitoring food in the bedrooms. Bedroom #4 is being occupied as the staff office. Bathrooms: All are operating properly.

The home was inspected, and the following was observed: Facility is safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passageways, stairways and open porches are unobstructed. Knives, disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are made inaccessible to clients. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks. Medications are locked/accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. Smoke detectors/ carbon monoxide were working properly in the home. Fire extinguisher were available and working properly in the home. There were no bars on the windows at the time of the visit. There are cameras outside in the walkway with censored lights. There is a monitor in the staff office where you can see camera footage. There are no firearms or weapons on the premises. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility posts child's rights if licensed to provide foster care for six or more clients. Clients are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Clients in care are supervised and always protected. Clients can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. Clients attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Facility personnel instructed to report violations of personal rights. Caregiver(s)/adults working/residing in the home have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Checks. LPA McGee will follow up regarding staff 1, staff 2, and staff 3 to ensure they are cleared to work at the facility. LPA McGee will come back at a later date to complete a records review. LPA McGee collected a copy of the personnel report and client roster. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 08/12/2021 at ___ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Meghan McGee made an announced visit to Five Acres-Solita Home for Annual Continuation licensing inspection. LPA met with Cathy Pidfigurny, STRTP Manager who granted access to the facility. LPA reviewed the following during the inspection: Staff records review, client records review, and facility vehicle. LPA reviewed staff records and client records. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility.

On 9/9/2021 at 12:08 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Dahl Larios conducted a Case Management – Law Enforcement Contacts inspection at the above-named facility, and met with STRTP Manager, Cathy Pidfigurny, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Jennifer Woolery, Program Manager.

On November 2, 2021, at 8:50am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Emelyn Sanchez P. and Olivia Rosas arrived at the above facility unannounced for the purpose of conducting a SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Case Management- Medication Inspection Visit. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas met with Cathy Pidfigurny, Facility Administrator. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas reviewed three (3) client file and three (3) staff files. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas conducted two (2) staff interviews. Currently there are five (5) clients residing in the above facility. This is a facility located in a residential area and equipped with three (3) bedrooms, one (1) staff office, four (4) bathrooms, living room, TV room/game area, dining room and kitchen, and laundry room. There was a fireplace in the home with a secured screen. There are no bodies of water on the premises. Common areas area clean and in good repair. Rooms are fully furnished with two beds, closet space and bathroom. Outdoor space is free of obstructions. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed adequate staffing in the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas also observed medication to stored in the staff office, triple locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On April 5, 2022 at 9:40am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres (Solita) for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Incident Inspection in response to Special Incident Report (SIR) #802331 dated 03/16/2022 Assaultive Behavior (Caregiver). LPA met with Cathy Pidfigurny, STRTP Manager. During this visit, LPA Edison conducted confidential interviews. Additional confidential interviews will be conducted on a later date. LPA requested a copy of the LIC 500, Needs and Services Plan for Client #1, and a copy of the police report. STRTP Manager provided a copy of the LIC 500 to LPA and stated will email Needs and Services Plan for Client #1 to LPA Edison. STRTP Manager provided law enforcement contact information to LPA to obtain a copy of the police report filed. STRTP Manager stated that they do not have a copy of the police report. Based on the interviews and information gathered, this incident needs further investigation. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the STRTP Manager.

On May 10, 2022 at 9:56am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres Solita Home for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection. LPA met with Cathy Pidfigurny, Administrator who granted access into the home and together a tour of the facility was conducted. This facility is licensed to provide care and supervision to six (6) children, ages 12-17 years old, ambulatory only. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The census on the date of this visit is two (2). Facility is set up as follows: Three (3) bedrooms, four (4) bathrooms, Living room, TV room/game area, staff office, dining room and kitchen. Living Room: Equipped with a sofa, table, and TV. All furniture is in good repair. TV Room/Game Area: Equipped with 2 chairs, books, TV, and table. All furniture in good repair. Dining Room: Equipped with a table and seven (7) chairs. All furniture is in good repair. Staff Office: All office furniture and equipment is in good repair. Staff Bathroom: Equipped with a toilet and shower. Clean, sanitary, and in good operable condition. Basement: Equipped with a hot water heater. Continued on LIC 809-C

Kitchen: Equipped with a stove/oven with four (4) burners, microwave oven, and a refrigerator/freezer. Bedroom #1: Occupied. Equipped with two (2) twin size beds. There is adequate lighting, drawer and closet space. Bathroom #1: Located inside of Bedroom #1. Equipped with a toilet and shower. Clean, sanitary, and in good operable condition. Bedroom #2: Vacant. Equipped with two (2) twin size beds. There is adequate lighting, drawer and closet space. Bathroom #2: Located inside of Bedroom #2. Equipped with a tub/shower combination. Clean, sanitary, and in good operable condition. Bedroom #3: Vacant. Equipped with two (2) twin size beds. There is adequate lighting, drawer and closet space. Bathroom #3: Located inside of Bedroom #3. Equipped with a toilet and shower. Clean, sanitary, and in good operable condition. Backyard: Clean and free from hazardous items and debris. Garage: Clean and used for storage. Equipped with two (2) refrigerator/freezers for extra food storage. The home was inspected, and the following was observed: Facility is safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, and open porches are unobstructed. Knives, disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are kept locked in the staff office and made inaccessible to clients. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two (2) days. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks. Continued on LIC 809-C

Medications are kept locked/accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. Smoke detectors/ carbon monoxide tested audible and were working properly in the home. The facility is equipped with two (2) regulation fire extinguishers. Hot water was tested and found to be within a safe temperature range. First Aid kit is complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer and First Aid Manual. Facility vehicle is in good repair with valid and current California vehicle registration and insurance. LPA will review client records and conduct client interviews on a later date. Children in care are supervised and protected at all times. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Children can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. It was reported that children attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. LPA reviewed two (2) staff records and conducted one (1) staff interview. Additional staff interviews will be conducted on a later date. Caregiver(s)/adults working/residing in the facility have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Checks. Emergency Mass Disaster Casualty Plan was available for review. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. The facility is operating within the capacity and limitations of the license. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Administrator.

On January 24, 2023 at 11:47am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres (Solita) for the purpose of conducting a Case Management for Special Incident Report #840982, Unauthorized Overnight Guest. LPA requested and was provided with a LIC 500. LPA provided facility with a new Foster Youth Bill of Rights poster. Facility cited on the attached LIC 809-D for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. On March 2, 2023 at 9:39am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres (Solita) and spoke with Cathy Pidfigurny, STRTP Manager. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for Case Management for SIR #802331. During the investigation, one (1) staff and one (1) client were interviewed. Consistent statements made by Client #1 (C1) to LPA Edison and law enforcement revealed C1 was hit on the right side of C1’s face with a closed fist by Staff #1 (S1) on 3/15/2022. Documentary evidence revealed redness on C1’s right jaw. LPA obtained photographic evidence of C1’s face from Pasadena Police Department and Pasadena Police Report #22002884 dated 3/16/2022. LPA made several unsuccessful attempts to interview S1. Although LPA was unable to interview S1, confidential interviews with staff who witnessed S1 hitting C1 and statements made by S1 to law enforcement revealed S1 admitted to hitting C1. Documentary evidence revealed statements made by S1 to law enforcement. LPA obtained Pasadena Police Report #22002884 dated 3/16/2022. Documentary evidence also revealed S1 was arrested on 3/16/2022 for PC 273a(a), Child Abuse. Due to S1 exiting Five Acres (Solita) on 3/15/2022 after hitting C1, LPA Edison obtained a termination report from Five Acres (Solita) dated 3/15/2022 which states the employment relationship between Five Acres (Solita) and S1 ended effective 3/15/2022. Based on the interviews conducted, information gathered, and documentary evidence, the preponderance of standard has been met, and is therefore is found to be substantiated. Facility cited on the attached LIC 809-D for violation of STRTP ILS version 4, 87072(11) Personal Rights. Staff #1 (S1) hit Client #1 (C1) with a closed fist on the right side of C1’s face. Appeal rights were discussed with STRTP Manager. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

This is an amended report of the original dated 4/25/2023. On April 25, 2023 at 9:46am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres (Solita) for the purpose of conducting a Case Management for Special Incident Report #851035, Unauthorized Guest. LPA met with Cathy Pidifigurny, STRTP Manager and discussed the incident. LPA requested and was provided with a current LIC 500 and copies of the staff communication log for the period of 4/18/2023-4/20/2023. LPA requested and was able to review video footage of the incident. Based on the interviews and information gathered, this case management needs further investigation. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the STRTP Manager.

Statements indicate that on the day of the incident, staff conducted a room check of the bedroom that Client #1 (C1) and Client #3 (C3) share. Statements indicate room checks consist of staff searching under clients’ beds and searching client closet in the bedroom. Statements indicated that during the room check, staff discovered Client #2 (C2) hiding in the closet. Consistent statements indicated that Client #2 (C2) was previously placed at Five Acres (Solita) but was no longer in placement. Documentary evidence indicate C2 AWOL’d from current placement. LPA obtained Special Incident Report (SIR) #844753. Statements indicate C2 returned to Five Acres (Solita) with C1. Statements indicate that C2 climbed through the bedroom window which was left open. Statements indicated C1 had returned from AWOL and Pasadena Police Department was present at the facility when C2 was found by staff in the bedroom. Statements did not indicate facility staff are not adequately supervising minors. Documentary evidence indicates adequate direct care staff and client ratio on the date of the incident. LPA obtained email documentation from Division Director of staff schedule dated 2/17/2023-2/19/2023. Division Director stated that there is no paper documentation of staff schedule for the requested dates. LPA also obtained documentary evidence: Special Incident Reports (SIR), and Pasadena Police Report. LPA reviewed video footage of the exterior of the facility on the date of the incident. LPA observed C2 knock on the bedroom window. LPA observed someone opening the bedroom window and C2 climbed through the window. LPA was unable to identify who opened the window. Based on the interviews conducted, documentary evidence and LPA video footage review, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. LPA was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-THE BOYS & GIRLS AID SOCIETY OF LA
met_with: Claudia Rice, Cathy Pidfigurny, Elizabeth Gonzalez
narrative:
On September 7, 2021 at 1:30PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Meghan McGee and Daphne Edison arrived at the above facility for conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection of Five Acres – Colby. LPA met with Claudia Rice, Cathy Pidfigurny, and Elizabeth Gonzalez who granted access and provided LPA with a tour of the facility. Five Acres - Colby will provide care and supervision for a capacity of 14 male children, ages 6-14 years of age, ambulatory only. There were zero clients present during inspection. Colby is constructed as follows: The facility is 2 story building with a total of 7 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms for clients. All client bedrooms and client bathrooms are located on the second floor. All bedrooms contain 2 twin beds and personal storage space. All bedrooms have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, and adequate storage space. There are 2 bathrooms equipped with a sink, toilet and shower. Hot water was measured within a safe temperature. On the first floor, the living / dining room is equipped with two TV’s, adequate seating, and furniture was observed to be in good repair. The living/dining room is equipped with two wooden tables with 14 chairs. The entrance of Colby has books, board games, and DVDs for clients. The Kitchen was observed to be clean and is equipped with refrigerator/ freezer, toaster and a microwave. The kitchen trash can is covered with a lid. Meals are provided through Huntington Culinary. Three meals and snacks will be provided for the clients and will be brought to Colby from Ketch. Laundry area is equipped with a stackable washer and dryer on the second floor in a locked closet. Closet has a locked cabinet. Hall closet on the first-floor stores linen and blankets. Staff office is located on the first floor. All medications will be double locked in the staff office, accessible and administered only by nursing staff. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and are operable. Two fire extinguishers were available and last checked January 2021 and August 2021. Facility also has a Fire Alarm Pull System. First aid kit located in staff office. Outdoor space has a bench. Continued on LIC 809C

LPA will follow up with the following: Blankets and pillows for all beds, curtains and screens for all bedrooms. LPA will follow up regarding the kitchen needing a stove. Kitchen needs dishes, perishable and nonperishable foods. An additional first aid kit fully stocked and physical address will be added to the front of building. LPA and LPM will follow up on badge system to enter in and out of facility. LPA was notified the system is currently deactivated and can be done manually. LPA and LPM notified that the facility cannot be a locked facility. Broken glass on the catwalk needs to be removed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy will be emailed to facility staff.

narrative:
On September 30, 2021 at 9:30AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Meghan McGee and Daphne Edison arrived at the above facility for conducting a follow up Pre-Licensing Inspection of Five Acres – Colby. Five Acres - Colby will provide care and supervision for a capacity of 14 male children, ages 6-14 years of age, ambulatory only. There were zero clients present during inspection. LPAs completed a walk through to address concerns from previous inspection. All 7 bedrooms had screens and curtains on the windows and the broken glass on the catwalk has been removed. Bedrooms had blankets and pillows on all beds. Food service waiver request has been granted. The waiver applies to regulations section 80076(a)(7) due to staff informing CCL that meals (breakfast, lunch and dinner) will be transported from one facility (Ketch) to another (Colby). Food service Procedure in Plan of Operations has been submit to CCL for review. LPAs completed a walk of how meals will be transported to the facility. There is walk way once you exit the backyard of the facility that leads to Ketch which has access to the kitchen. Kitchen has labeled carts that are covered for the meals to be transported to Colby. Colby kitchen has the following: stove, utensils, and dishes. According to ILS version 3.1 for STRTPs it states the following: 87088 Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies (e) The following facilities shall maintain a signal system which meets the requirements specified in (e) and (f) below. Such system shall be used by children to summon staff during an emergency: (2) All facilities having separate floors and not providing full-time staff on each floor whenever children are present.

Colby will not install a signal system on the second floor and acknowledges they must maintain a staff on the 1st and 2nd floor at all times when children are present. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy will be emailed to facility staff.

An announced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Rosslyn Gray and Zena Phillips, on April 11, 2023 at 9:30AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs Gray and Phillips met with Claudia Rice, Division Director and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed #5 of child’s records and #3 of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed #5 of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed #3 of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPAs interviewed #2 of the children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. The other three (3) children were not available for interviews. LPAs provided a copy of this licensing reports to Claudia Rice. No deficiency were cited per Interim Licensing Standards for STRTP Version 4. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Claudia Rice / Division Director

During confidential interviews, it was revealed that staff mishandled a minor in care by “dragging” Client #1 (C1) out of bed to give C1 their medication, however, inconsistent statements did not corroborate the allegation. Additional confidential interviews revealed C1 had a history of medication refusal. LPA obtained a copy of C1’s medication log and Needs and Services Plan. Documentary evidence and consistent statements revealed that staff do not force but instead encourage clients to take their medication as prescribed. deficiencies.description: 87072 Personal Rights (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning .  This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documentary evidence, Staff used inappropriate language towards C1 and handled C1 in a rough manner, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Division Director stated staff was terminated in 8/2022. investigation_findings: 13On March 22,2024 at 2:30PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to FIVE ACRES STRTP COLBY to conclude the investigation. Confidential statements and evidence obtained indicated that Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings were held at the Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS) office and the Individualized Education Plan (IEP) meetings are held off campus at the C1's school. narrative: Documentary evidence revealed Y1 resided at the facility from December 2023 through July 2024. Records indicate on February 18, 2024, Y1 suffered accidental injuries when hiding from staff and a door/closet closed on minor’s thumb. Facility staff called 911 immediately upon occurrence and Y1was sent to the hospital for treatment. Information reviewed revealed no documentation of any suspicion of child abuse within the Medical Records. On June 19, 2024, Y1 sustained an injury (bruise on his genital area). Records reviewed revealed youth sustained the injury during an outing at the local park while riding their bike. Facility nurses completed an assessment of client's genital area after the incident. Client observed with bruising to scrotum area. Youth was offered an ice pack however client declined. Confidential interviews and review of documentary evidence including client file history produced a lack of evidence to prove allegations that staff physically abused Y1, resulting in severe injury or that staff did not prevent minor from being harmed by another minor. Evidence obtained was not sufficient to substantiate the allegations. Therefore, the allegations are determined Unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to Facility Representative.

(Continued on page LIC9099-C)

narrative:
On 11/30/2020 at 9:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray conducted an announced Annual Required Tele-Inspection to the For the Future. LPA met with Staff#1 (S1) who granted access to the facility. The entire physical plant was inspected. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) female clients, ages 13-17 years, ambulatory only. The facility has transitioned from (GH) Group Home to a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRP). The facility obtained the Mental Health Certification from Ventura County Behavioral Health; approved as of 11/1/2020 and has National Accreditation through Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF) since 12/14/ 2017. S1 states that there is no weapons or guns on the premises. There is no swimming pool or any other bodies of water on the premises. A camera waiver was granted in 2009 but the Administrator stated that the cameras are not operable; and will notify the department if they decide to activate the cameras. LPA inspected the facility via FaceTime with the S1 and observed the following: The outdoor perimeter ( front yard, side yard and backyard) were inspected and found cleared of hazards materials. All windows, screens and blinds from the inside and outside of the facility were observed to be in good condition. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan and personal rights). Cleaning solutions, disinfectants, medication and sharp knives are inaccessible to the clients (stored in the staff office). All prescribed medications are locked in the staff office in a locked file cabinet behind the locked closet doors; accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. LPA observed S1 activate the smoke detectors in the hallways and inside the bedrooms. All carbon monoxide detector were tested and operable. LPA observed three (3) operable fire extinguisher fully charged; located in the living room, kitchen and staff office. LPA observed coverage trash cans in the the kitchen, bathroom and staff office. Report continues on LIC-809-C

Living Room/Dining room: Observed to be clean and organized; equip with living room furniture (two (2) sofas, L- Section and a 2 seater "Love seat"). Kitchen: Is equipped with a gas stove/oven that has four (4) working burners. The dining table seats six (6), only four (4) chairs are used due to CDC-Guidelines for Social Distances. Extra chairs and a (2) folding tables on the outside patio. The sharp knives and chemicals are made inaccessible locked in container in the staff office. There are two (2) extra refrigerators in the garage used for extra storage. The garage is also utilized to store extra linen, non perishable food items and other facility supplies. Bedroom #1: Is occupied by Client#1 (C1), Client #2(C2) it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #2: Is occupied by Client#3 (C3) and Client #4 (C4), it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #3: Is occupied by Client# 5 (C5) and Child #6 (C6), it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. BATHROOMS: The bathrooms were inspected and found to be clean. LPA observed S1 test the water temperature, bathroom sinks and ensured that all toilets flushed. Bathroom #1 The community bathroom is equip with a shower, tub, toilet and a sink. Bathroom #2 Staff bathroom is equip with a shower, toilet and a sink. The Laundry room: is located in the garage equip with a washer and dryer unit. The laundry detergent is distributed to children individually according to the load of their laundry. LPA observed 4 boxes fully stocked First-Aide Kits; 1 box still in plastic. All First aid Kits displayed the required items inside (age-appropriate, and complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide. The facility has a working telephone and clients are allowed to use the telephone unless restricted by court order. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Due to the COVID-19 Pandemic all clients attend school on line with materials such as a Chrome Book provided by the Simi Valley Unified school, additional school supplies are provided by the facility. The staff accompanies clients to local recreational facilities based on the rules of the COVID-19. Other outside extracurricular activities and social events that take persons into public or crowded places have been canceled. Extracurricular activities include portable bowling set, canvas painting, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Clients can contact Community Care Licensing or Foster Care Ombudsman office in confidence without threats or punishment. LPA observed Grievance forms and a Grievance box. LIC-809 Page 2 of 3.

LPA obtained and reviewed the Facility Roster, Clothing Inventory Log, Food Menu, and the Weight Log for all clients. LPA recommended that staff ensure that CDC Guidelines are implemented in effort to prevent other from contracting the COVID-19 virus (i.e wash hands with alcohol based hand sanitizer, display colorful preventative hygiene posters, temperature checks, maintain social distancing (six feet of space), disinfect commonly used areas and items (remote controls, mouse’s, cards cell phones, practice “cough etiquette”. LPA suggest that the facility keep an inventory of of the PPE supplies and to report when they are depleted. The Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 11/30/2020 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility administrator for signature 11/30/2020.

The internal Investigation revealed that there is no evidence to support the allegation that the STRTP did not prevent minors from AWOLING. LPA obtained statements from four (4) children; three (3) staff and four (4) Witnesses; including County Social Workers. All four (4) children interviewed denied ever being offered drugs, neither influenced or persuaded to engage in using drugs. Children willingly disclosed why they went AWOL and what the facilities has done to keep them from going AWOL. LPA reviewed several Unusual Incident Reports to confirm that the staff’s effort to meet the needs of the children, by using crisis communication to encourage the children to make better choices. Staff provided counseling based on the individual Safety Plan. LPA also reviewed Law Enforcement Contact reports to confirm that youth that returned from AWOL were to adhere to the self-search; asked to engage in contraband check (i.e empty pockets and conducted random room searches), and no items were found. AWOL Protocol and procedure were implemented in addition to what is indicated in the facilities 60 Page: Emergency Response and Intervention, Runaway plan. LPA assessed that all statements were congruent with the method of interventions implemented to ensure that the facility provided proper supervision to support that met the needs of children in placement; In addition, no disclosure or reports indicate that drugs were illicit. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The Department has determined that the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision is unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There are no deficiencies noted or cited per California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3. An exit interview was conducted via phone, and the report will be e-mailed to the Administrator on 03/24/2021 for signature.
investigation_findings: 13On 03/24/2021 at 1:00PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray contacted FOR THE FUTURE, INC- to conclude the investigation on the above allegation/s and to deliver the findings via email. RP did not identify a specific youth or staff in this complaint investigation to be interviewed. RP admitted that during her length of employment she had never confiscated contraband from a client that return from AWOL, neither did she witness drugs being illicit among the children.

narrative: The internal Investigation revealed that there is no evidence to support the allegations Neglect and Lack of Supervision. LPA obtained statements from four (4) children; two (2) staff. All four (4) children interviewed denied that freely drank alcohol at the facility without consequences. The children also stated that the staff are not allowed to put hands on at time of placement. LPA reviewed several Unusual Incident Reports to confirm that the staff’s effort to meet the needs of the children, by using crisis communication in effort encourage client to make better choices. Reports disclosed the effort of the staff that was present and attempted to defuse the situation and break up the fight before it escalated outside of the facility. Staff provided counseling based on the individual Safety Plan. LPA reviewed the facility Pro-Act Protocol and procedure that indicate "No Hands on policy". LPA reviewed the facilities 25 Page: Emergency, Intervention Plan, Protocol and Procedures. LPA assessed that all statements were congruent with the method of interventions implemented to ensure that the facility provided proper supervision to support that met the needs of children in placement. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The Department has determined that the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision is unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There are no deficiencies noted or cited per California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3. An exit interview was conducted in person and the report was provided to the Administrator on 06/15/2021 for signature.
investigation_findings: 13On 06/15/2021 at 1:55PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Rosslyn Gray conducted an unannounced complaint inspection to FOR THE FUTURE, INC- to conclude the investigation on the above allegation/s and to deliver the findings via email. LPA spoke with the Program Administrator of the (STRTP). During the investigation process LPA-Gray interviewed and accounted for all relevant parties; including the children who were in placement when the incident occurred. Based on the interviews and statements obtained during the investigation process, the allegation cannot be corroborated because supporting evidence for this complaint is as follows: LPA interviewed the RP who was identified as a third party reporter, witnessed the alleged allegations. RP did not identify a specific youth and chose not to disclose the neighbors information who was allegedly assaulted. Althought to the RP was adamant that there is lack of supervision, evidence and supporting documents indicate the effort of the program to use crisis communication according to the facilities Emergency Response plan. LPA gathered information in which it was stated that staff redirected the clients to a safe place and to protect the staff from possible injuries and or violating personal rights.

narrative:
On 07/22/2021 at 9:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA's) Rosslyn Gray, Meghan McGee and LPM JoAunne Griffin made an unannounced to For the Future for Annual/Required licensing Inspection. LPA's met with Rubi Valerio (S1) who granted access to the facility. The entire physical plant was inspected. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) female clients, ages 13-17 years, ambulatory only. The facility acquired The National Accreditation through Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF) 04/20/2021 valid through 11/30/2023. LPA observed the following during the inspection: This is a one story home equipped with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, living room, dining area and kitchen. Dining area is also used as an arts and crafts activity space. Clients personal lockers were observed in living room. Attached garage is used as a storage space for washer, dryer, deep freezer, two additional refrigerators, dry goods, paper goods and clients in care personal belongings. Staff Office is equipped with one bathroom and access to additional office space. Bedroom #1: Is occupied by Client#1 (C1) it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #2: Is occupied by Client#2 (C2) has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #3: Is occupied by Client# 3 (C3) it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. There is no swimming pool or any other bodies of water on the premises. S1 states that there is no weapons or guns on the premises. The passageways and open porches are unobstructed. House rules, menu and alternative meals, grievance process, emergency disaster plan and personal rights were observed posted in kitchen area. The outdoor space is free of debris. LPA observed a broken wooden slate with an exposed nail. LPA observed chemicals such as cleaning solutions, disinfectants in the kitchen area under the kitchen sink. All medication and sharp knives are inaccessible to the clients and located in locked closet inside staff office. All prescribed medications are locked in the staff office; accessible only to employees supervising stored

prescribed medications are locked in the staff office; accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at the time of inspection. Facility is also equipped with pull alarm. LPA's observed two operable fire extinguisher located in the dining area and living room. Fire extinguishers were last serviced May 2021. LPA observed individual first aid kits fully stocked for each client in care. The bathrooms were inspected and found to be clean and good repair. The hot water was tested in the kitchen and bathrooms and was at a safe temperature. The facility was observed to have a working telephone. Clients can use the telephone unless restricted by a court order. Phone is operable and available to client in care throughout the day. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable environment and are treated with respect. Clients currently attend school virtual via ZOOM, participate in extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Clients can contact Community Care Licensing or Foster Care Ombudsman office in confidence without threats or punishment. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. LPA will return to the facility at later date to complete the Annual Inspection (i.e Staff Records review, Staff and client interviews and include information regarding the Emergency Preparedness.) There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at facility.

investigation_findings: 13On 01/20/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility to conduct a follow up complaint investigation regarding the allegation that Facility staff touched child inappropriately. LPA Karnsrithong met with Administrator, Melissa Kagan to discuss the complaint investigation. During the investigation of the allegation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documentary evidences. Statements were consistent and did not produce corroborating evidence to support that facility staff touched a child inappropriately. There were no witnesses, physical or documentary evidence to corroborate that a child was touched inappropriately by staff. This agency has investigated the complaint allegation and has found that the complaint was unsubstantiated, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview conducted with administrator. Report will be emailed to the facility on a later date.

narrative: Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with the administrator and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility. (Page 2 of 2)
investigation_findings: 13On 01/20/2022, at 3:45pm Bernice Karnsrithong, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with the administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation of the allegations that facility has a bug infestation, youth sustained an injury while in care and staff failed to prevent youths from engaging in a physical altercation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documentary evidence. Action Pest Control Inspection report dated 10/20/2020 indicates that there was no evidence of bed bug infestation in the facility on that day. Incident reports and consistent statements suggest that appropriate emergency intervention protocols were observed, appropriate medical treatment was provided to clients who sustained injuries and that staff conducted appropriate safety and health measures to ensure the safety and well-being of clients in care. (Page 1 of 2)

narrative: Based on confidential interviews and the facility’s positive discipline procedures; instances of bullying between clients may have occurred however interviews and incident report indicated that facility staff utilized emergency intervention protocols and follows through appropriate positive discipline procedures when such incidents occur in the facility. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred. Therefore, the allegations are all unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and copy of this report will be provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 02/03/2022 at 12pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong conducted a follow-up complaint inspection and met with Facility Manager, Rubi Valerio. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation of the allegations, that facility staff failed to obtain a restraining order against a known adult predator harassing the group home youth; youth was bullied by another youth in the group home; and lack of supervision resulted in inappropriate activities between group home youth; LPA Karnsrithong conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documentary evidences. Based on the confidential interviews and documentary evidences, the facility attempted to file a restraining order however, law enforcement was not able to complete this process this due to lack of biographical information. (Page 1 of 2)

narrative: The facility staff conducted random room searches to confiscate illegal drugs and contraband. Evidence of Unusual Incident Reports were written, and authorized representatives were notified. There was no evidence to suggest children in care were not properly supervised. Documentary evidence also showed that the Licensee provided individual services to meet the children’s needs which included Child Family Team meetings, Alcohol and Drug Program, a CSEC Mentor Program and Incentives. Staff followed emergency interventions utilizing methods of crisis communication to redirect and encourage children to make better choices for the health and safety. Due to lack of evidence and conflicting statements obtained during the investigation, LPA determines that the allegation is Unsubstantiated at this time meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On August 5, 2022, at 11:12 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the investigation and to deliver the findings. LPA conducted a Health and safety risk assessment upon arriving at the facility. During the investigation, LPA-Gray interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information in reference to the allegations. The Licensee denied the allegations. Based on confidential interviews and review of documentary evidence there is no evidence or witnesses to support that the facility staff did not prevent youth from smoking marijuana in the facility, engaging in CSEC activity, and that the facility staff do not ensure that youth attend school. Documentary evidence show that staff implemented the proper protocol to prevent the children from going AWOL and documented evidence of school refusal. Staff followed emergency interventions utilizing methods of crisis communication to redirect and encourage children to make better choices for the health and safety.

narrative: On 4/4/23, at 1:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell, made an unannounced collateral visit to the above-listed facility, and met with the Facility Administrator (FA), who granted access to the facility. The purpose of this visit is to conduct a collateral interview with a resident that currently resides in the facility. During the collateral visit, LPA O'Connell conducted a confidential interview with C1 [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 4/4/23, for names]. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 4, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted a copy of this report will be emailed to FA.

LPA Rosas conducted interviews with staff, and pertinent parties regarding to allegations. LPA Rosas conducted a file review on Client#1 (C1) on 10/27/2022 and obtain copies of JV-220 dated 05/18/2022, Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (MAR) and Special Incident Reports (SIR). During the investigation, it was reported that C1 was placed on 5585 hold in the hospital and was schedule to be released on 10/31/2022. The facility placed 14-day discharge notice on 10/17/2022 to the safeguard the health and well-being of facility employees and residents in care. The 14-day discharge notice expired on 10/30/2022 and during Child Family Team (CFT) meeting the County of placement was informed to coordinate C1 transition as facility would not be able to pick up C1. The documentation and interviews with pertinent parities detail that 14-day was given but County of placement was seeking additional time to coordinate pick up of C1. File review, of JV-223 stated that C1 was prescribe five (5) psychotropic medications upon arrival to the facility. On 08/09/2022, C1 medication prescription was updated, and Psychotropic Medication #1 (SM1) was removed and JV-223 was pending update. Upon discharge, the facility provided the current psychotropic medication prescription that did not include SM1 as noted in JV-223. Confidential statements obtained produced no corroborating evidence to corroborate the allegations of Personal Rights and Medication. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegations of Personal Rights and Medication are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios conducted a case management inspection May 4, 2023, at 10:53 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 17 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 17 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated May 4, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dahl Larios observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Head of Service, Maral Sultanian.

On May 17, 2023, at 8:38 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA),Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to For The Future Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA Wilson met with Staff #1 (S1) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. (1) staff S1 was on site, and at 9:17AM Staff #2 (S2) arrived on site. (2) client residents (C1, C2), were at the facility and (2) client residents (C3, C4) were at school. Individuals mentioned in this report are identified on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 05/17/2023. LPA Wilson and Staff#1 (S1), toured of the entire physical plant. This facility has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license to provide care and supervision for six (6) female children ages 13-17 years old, Ambulatory only. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. Licensee may provide care and supervision to six(6) female children, ages 13-17 years. Licensee serves ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water in the premises. The facility has obtained a Mental Health Program Approval contract with the Department of Health Care Services and Ventura County, which expired on March 3, 2023, and have submitted a Corrective Action Plan (CAP) to the Department of Health Care Services (DHCS). Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. There are no functional cameras in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. Accreditation is current. (Page 1 of 3) LPA Wilson inspected the following: This is a one (1) story (STRP) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, located in a residential neighborhood. This is a three (3) three-bedroom, two (1) bathroom, one (1) staff office in a family residence that includes a living"communal" room, dining area, kitchen, backyard, and an attached garage used for storage and laundry service. There are (2) unattached storage sheds. (continued on 809C page 2 of 3)

(Page 2 of 3) During the facility was inspected, the following was observed: Vehicles: There are two (2) facility vehicles parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition, and with current insurance and registration. Vehicles are; a gray 2015 Toyota Sienna VIN 5TDKK3DC3FS613180, ODO 95, 887 and a white 2016 Ford Fiesta VIN 3FADP4EJ6GM143652, ODO 113,945. Ford Fiesta did not have a copy of license or registration in the vehicle. S1 made copies and immediately placed information in the vehicle. Both vehicles had a first aid kit. S1 stated "We have a mechanic that comes and maintains the cars. I dont think he gives us any paperwork on it." Last documented oil change was 7/17/2019. LPA observed a well kept front yard and front entry. All windows were in good condition. Windows had no screens. There were no security bars on the windows. There are two (2) fire extinguishers with last inspection date of 02/21/2021. (1) carbon monoxide detector is were working properly in the facility. Outdoor Area: There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves. The facility is surrounded by wood fence observed to be good condition. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. Garage/Laundry Area: This is a locked entry. S1 stated "The youth are not allowed to be in here doing laundry by themselves and are always with a staff person." The washer and dryer units are located in the attached garage. The laundry is equipped with a washer and dryer unit that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent, bleach and other cleaning solutions are made accessible to the children and is located in a storage cabinet. Additional perishable and non-perishable food are stored here in a cabinet, refrigerator and freezer. Dining Area/Kitchen: LPA observed ample towels and linen closet. The dining/kitchen area has a large table with (6) chairs, where clients can participate in art and studying. There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. There is a gas stove/oven with four (4) burners, all operating. There is a dishwasher, microwave, refrigerator with freezer and an air fryer. LPA Wilson observed (2) days of adequate perishable/ and (7) days of adequate nonperishable food supplies on the premises. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions are made inaccessible to the youth locked in the staff office closet with medications. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees fahrenheit. Most leftover perishable food is labeled with a made-by date. LPA Wilson asked how often food was checked for expiration dates. S1 responded "Every three days.". Two (2) items: hummus (exp: 05/07/2023), and milk (05/14/2023) were expired, and were removed by S1 and disposed of. (Report Continues on LIC809-C Page 3 of 3)

(Page 3 of 3) Living "communal" Room: The living room has a small table, couch and television. The facility has one living "communal" room area used for recreating and activity room, which provide the necessary space and/or separation to promote and facilitate the program of planned activities and to prevent such activities from interfering with other functions. The living area has, books, DVDs, and magazines.. Bedrooms: There are (3) bedrooms in the facility with space for (2) clients in each. At the time of this report, (2) of the (4) clients placed have their own bedroom, and (2) clients share a bedroom. Windows were in working condition. Windows in each bedroom had no screens. There were no security bars on the windows. S3 stated they are currently on order. Clients had space for clothing and personal belongings. Bedroom 1: (2) beds and sleeps (1) client (C3), equipped with two twin-size beds, closet and dressers. Bedroom 2:(2) beds and sleeps (1) client (C2), equipped with two twin-size beds closet and dressers.Bedroom 3: (2) beds and sleeps (2) clients (C1, C4), equipped with two twin-size beds closet and dressers. Bathroom: There is (1) shared bathroom for all (4) clients. Bathroom has a functional sink, toilet, shower and lights observed to be in good working condition. Staff Interviews: Staff interviews were conducted with (S1, S3 and S4) LPA Wilson will need to return to facility to complete the staff file review. Client Interviews: Client interviews were conducted with (C2, C3 and C4) LPA Wilson will need to return to facility to complete the client file review. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 05/17/2023 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response.LPA Wilson will return to complete inspection at a later date. A (1) deficiency Type A has been determined at this time. Regulatory Reference 80076(a)(1): (2) items: hummus (exp: 05/07/2023), and milk (05/14/2023) accessible to clients are expired. A Technical Violation and a Technical Advisory have been determined at this time. Regulatory Reference 87009(a): TV: License posted in the staff office, which remains locked. Regulatory Reference 80088(b): TA There are no screens or bars on (2) bedroom windows. A copy of the report and the appeal rights were left at the facility.

On 05/19/2023 at 8:48am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson conducted an unannounced inspection, at the above-said facility,For The Future Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting the continuation of an Annual inspection. LPA Wilson met with Staff #5 (S5) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility files was conducted together. (3) staff (C2, S5, S6) were on site. (2) client residents (C1 and C2), were at the facility and (2) client residents (C3 and C4) were at school. Individuals mentioned in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811 and LIC811C) dated 05/19/2023. S5 stated a new client will be arriving this afternoon. This will bring the census to five (5). LPA Wilson reviewed Emergency Response Services plan, Training plan and conducted the file review for two clients (C2, C4), reviewed the Needs and Services Plan (NSP) for each client (C1, C2, C3, C4) and conducted a file review of three (3) staff (S1, S2, S5).. [See Confidential Names form (LIC811 and LIC811C) dated 05/19/2023.), for names.] Emergency Response Services: LPA Wilson reviewed Emergency Procedures. Licensee provided plan "Emergency Response Services" and disaster drills, which are conducted u to (4) times per month. Training: LPA Wilson reviewed (2) Relias training logs date range 1/1/22 through 12/31/22 and 1/1/23 through 5/4/23. Licensee has a written record of all training, dates and hours, proof of on-going training which cover Trauma Informed Care, Emergency intervention techniques and handling aggressive behavior. LPA Wilson requested stat S3 provide (3) Pro-Act certificates of long-term staff. S3 stated that new employees have completed (8) hours of Pro-Act before working with clients, and additional hours are still in process. Client Files:LPA Wilson reviewed (2) client files. Medical information, NSP, client signed copies of relevant consent forms and licensee policies and procedures. NSP: Needs and Services Plan is current and signed by clients Staff Files: LPA Wilson reviewed (3) staff files. Copies of staff CPR Certification, criminal record clearance, driving records, health physical, TB clearance, legal identification, facility employee documents and diplomas were available. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3, No deficiencies were cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Facility Administrator (S5).

On May 30, 2023 at 8:33am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson arrived a the above mentioned facility for a Plan of Correction (POC) inspection, to verify the correction of deficiency(ies) cited in the licensing visit made on 05/17/23. LPA Wilson met with Staff (S5) regarding a Type A deficiency 80076(a)(18). Upon inspection, LPA Wilson observed food is not expired, and protected against contamination. Due to a technical difficulty, the licensee was given a copy of the signed deficiency page (809D) the licensing visit made on 05/17/23, and civil penalty was removed. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On September 7, 2023 at 1:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conduct a case management incident inspection, regarding SIR dated 08/26/23. LPA Wilson interviewed staff (S1) and obtained shift notes and shift schedule for week of 08/21/23. During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on 08/26/23 the youth (C1, C2, C3 and C4[See LIC811 dated 09/07/23 for list of confidential names] were not supervised by enough staff to care for and meet the needs of clients, and licensee was out of ratio for client's behavioral needs, which included intoxication and resulted in property damage, due to a lack of supervision by staff A (1) deficiency Type A has been determined at this time. The following deficiency has been cited. (See LIC 809D) An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Correction was developed and reviewed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with licensee. (S1) whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

deficiencies.description:
80078	Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision		  

(a)	The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.


This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA record review and interviews conducted the licensee did not ensure Staff did not ensure supervision in (4) out of (5) clients, which poses an immediate danger to the health safety and personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will provide a plan of correctin to LPA which includes a plan with protocols for staff coverage, to ensure enough supervision to meet clients needs.

narrative: (Continued from 9099) Based on all interviews conducted, and documents obtained, the Department has found the above allegations to be unsubstantiated, meaning that, the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time.

LPA Wilson was greeted by (S1) who provided access to the home. It was alleged that staff pushed minor, staff do not distribute minor's medication as prescribed, staff speak inappropriately to minor, staff do not meet minor's dietary needs, staff did not allow minor access to their personal belongings. Alleged victim (C1) did not choose to interview or give statements to LPA Wilson. (Continued on 9099C)

narrative: Based on records reviewed and confidential statements, the allegations cannot be substantiated due to a lack of evidence. Information obtained revealed contradiction to alleged neglect as confidential statements determined knowledge of C1's medical condition was discovered approximately two days after their initial admission (5/26/2023) during a Child and Family Team (CFT) meeting. Upon notification, facility staff took immediate action, and after the CFT meeting, C1 was taken to a hospital for non-injury purposes to obtain a medical evaluation and medication. The investigation found no evidence at this time to support neglect/lack of supervision as alleged; therefore, the allegation is determined Unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 or Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report was provided to the Facility Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On September 15, 2023, at 3:25 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at For the Future, Inc. to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. LPA Martin met with Tessa Koziol, Administrator, to discuss the outcome. The allegations were referred to Community Care Licensing Investigations Branch for assignment. On June 2, 2023, the El Segundo Children’s Residential Program Regional Office received a complaint referral alleging neglect/lack of supervision as it was reported that Staff did not seek medical attention for a youth in a timely manner resulting in hospitalization, and that Staff did not treat youth with dignity and respect [see Confidential Names form, LIC 811, dated 9/15/2023]. On June 6, 2023, LPA Regina Martin met with Rubi Valerio, Facility Administrator, informed receipt of allegation and obtained client/facility records. The investigation further included confidential interviews with Client #1 (C1), staff members, and review of client file history and associated medical reports (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

13On 03/22/2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Christine Wilson, concluded the investigation of the above allegations. During the course of this investigation, LPA Wilson conducted witness interviews, record reviews, and made observations. Based on all interviews conducted and documents obtained, the above allegation was found to be unsubstantiated, meaning that the allegations may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Supporting evidence includes the following: • Witness accounts substantially differed over how child in care was monitored during the outing. • Although there was a police report, there were no other witness accounts or documentation to support that reports or other forms of documentary validation available establishing the cause or the likelihood of abandonment by the alleged perpetrators. • Documentation substantially differed in that there was staff involvement in altercation between clients.. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed the facility.

13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA interviewd C1, C2, C3 and C4. LPA also interviewed Staff 1, administrators and social workers. LPA reviewed incident reports, the facility's internal investigative report and the police report. There was no needs and services plan for the victim (C1) because she had only been at the facility for four days prior to the overdosing incident. The interviews and reports yielded conflicting information regarding the source of the pills on which C1 overdosed and also whether or not Staff 1 intervened when the other clients were fighting with and bullying C1. Therefore the allegations are resolved as unsubstantiated.

narrative: Page 2 Further, room checks for contraband and alcohol are completed on a daily basis and interviews reveal, that staff and house residents; deny any observance of staff having a lack of supervision minors.
