narrative: Evidence obtained from confidential interviews with pertinent witnesses including one resident, two staff members, Facility Administrator, assigned Social Worker and review of client records revealed that minor Y1 resided at the facility from 11/13/2023 through 03/20/2024. Youth returned to live at the facility on 05/17/2024 through 02/18/2025. From 07/03/2024, through 01/25/2025. Youth left from the facility without permission thirty-seven times to visit a friend. Youth was moved from Simi Valley High School in September 2024 to Options for Youth – Duarte, Inc. where Y1 was enrolled from 10/21/2024, through 02/11/2025. On 02/12/2025, facility staff conducted a search of Y1’s room and recovered a marijuana pipe which staff seized. On 02/18/2025, Y1 was moved to another placement. Confidential interviews determined denial of knowledge Y1 was ever observed abusing narcotics in the facility or during outings. Y1 declined to speak with Investigator Spindola during the investigation. The investigation revealed a lack of evidence to prove that the facility allowed Y1 to abuse narcotics, allowed Y1 access to alcohol or did not ensure Y1 was enrolled in school, therefore the allegations are determined unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 or Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) at this time. Exit Interview conducted. A copy of this report was provided with Facility Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On 4/30/2025 at 12:05 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin arrived at FOR THE FUTURE, INC. and met with Tessa Koziol, Administrator to deliver investigation findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. narrative:
On 05/21/25 at 9:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell made an unannounced visit to the above-listed facility for an Annual/Required licensing Inspection. LPA met with Tessa Koziol, facility Administrator (FA) and Kathleen Burrell, Program supervisor (PS), who granted access to the facility. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) female clients, ages 13-17 years, ambulatory only. LPA observed the following during the inspection: This is a one-story home equipped with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, living room, dining area and kitchen, and two staff offices. Attached garage is used as a storage space. Bedroom #1: Is occupied by C1 and C2- it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #2: Is occupied by C3- has one twin size bed, adequate closet and drawer space. FA communicated that the second twin bed is missing due to C3 moving the bed out of the room repeatedly. FA confirmed that an additional bed is available and will be replaced immediately. Bedroom #3: Is occupied by C4 and C5- it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bathroom#1: located in the main hallway and contains a toilet, sink, and standing shower. Bathroom had paper towels, and soap. LPA observed hygiene products in the shower and outside of the shower. FA agreed to remove items to ensure that hygiene products are not available for common use. LPA observed all items removed before concluding inspection.

Bathroom#2: located in the staff office. This bathroom has a toilet, sink, and standing shower. Clients are allowed to use this bathroom if needed. Living room: contains enough seating for six (6) clients, a tv, and recreational games. This area is used for display of personal rights, the emergency disaster plan and the facility license. Dining room: contains enough seating for all clients in care. Area is used as an arts and crafts activity space. Kitchen: contains a refrigerator, stove, microwave, oven, and plenty of cabinet space. All appliances were observed to be in working condition. There were enough plates, cups, utensils for clients in care. LPA observed food within the refrigerator and freezer to be in the required amount and stored properly. Menu was posted with a date. A trash can was available and located within a contained storage area. Garage: contains washer, dryer, extra refrigerators, a deep freezer and additional recreation equipment/personal items for youth in care. LPA observed cleaning chemicals to be locked and inaccessible to youth in care. This area is kept locked and is inaccessible to youth without staff supervision. Outdoor-back yard: area is unobstructed and free from tripping hazards. The backyard had table seating for all youth, along with an umbrella for shade. The yard extends around the sides and back portion of the facility. The area in the back of the facility has two locked sheds that contain additional client/staff files along with extra client belongings. FA did not have keys to the two sheds and contacted additional off-site staff to unlock the sheds. LPA informed FA and PS that the facility must ensure access all areas within the facility property. Outdoor-front yard: area is unobstructed and free from tripping hazards. This area contains a driveway used to park two (2) facility vehicles. LPA inspected a 2015 Toyota Sienna and found it to be registered, insured and in working condition. LPA also inspected a 2016 Hyundai Accent and found it to be registered, insured and in working condition. Medication station: medications were observed to be locked and secure within the staff office. LPA observed medications to be properly stored, and kept with required documentation. This area is also designated as the storage area for sharps. This area is a locked closet in the staff office. Staff office#1: Located at end of bedroom hallway and secured with a metal security gate. This area contains an office computer, telephone line, and space for confidential meetings

Staff office#2: this area is located adjacent to staff office #1 and has a door in staff office #1 that leads into staff office #2. During the time of inspection, LPA was informed that FA did not have access to the staff office as it is not in use. FA contacted off-site staff to gain access to staff office #2. S1 arrived and provided access. This office contains a large area with a desk, meeting table, printer, bookshelves, refrigerator, and telephone. There are a total of four doors that allow for exit (two doors lead outside and two lead back into the facility. Staff report that this office was previously used by the Head of Service until she moved her office to an alternate location. This office is currently unused and is kept locked at all times, preventing anyone from entering. LPA informed FA and PS that a plan will need to be developed to ensure access during investigations and required inspections. PS and FA understood and agreed. There is no swimming pool or any other bodies of water on the premises. There are no weapons or guns on the premises. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at the time of inspection. There are two fire extinguishers located in the dining area and living room, observed to be in working condition and charged. LPA observed individual first aid kits fully stocked for each client in care. During this inspection, LPA completed the following sections of the Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) Care Tool: Physical Plant. Per California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulation, and Short Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 5, there were no deficiencies cited during this inspection Due to time constraints, LPA will return on another day to complete the Annual Inspection. Exit Interview was conducted with the FA, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas conducted a case management inspection July 23, 2025, at 9:30am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 17 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. In the inspection, 3 out of 17 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 4 youth were interviewed (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated July 23, 2025). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the youth sase plans, Crisis Safety Plan,Child and Family Team summary, Needs and Service Plan (LIC625), the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Rosas observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance with their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Tessa Koziol, Administrator.

narrative:
On October 13, 2021, at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ronnesha Fountain, Leslie Covarrubias and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith arrived at Forecast, Short Term Residential Program (STRTP). LPAs and LPM met with Residential Manager, Ricardo Calzada. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. At 10:45 AM, Residential Manager, Ricardo Calzada, led the physical inspection of the facility. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1- Was furnished with one twin bed. No client is placed in this room at this time. Bedroom #2- Was furnished with one twin bed. Sleeps one client. Bedroom #3- Was furnished with one twin bed. No client is placed in this room at this time. Bedroom #4- Was furnished with one twin bed. Sleeps one client. Bedroom #5- Was furnished with one twin bed. No client is placed in this room at this time. Bedroom #6- Was furnished with one twin bed. Sleeps one client. Bedrooms are arranged so that only one child is placed per room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The dresser drawer in room #4 was observed to be broken approximately at top-left corner of bottom drawer. Bedroom #2 has a hole in the wall and the back of the door. Bedroom #3 door is cracked in the middle. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s kitchen area, four refrigerators/freezers, food storage areas, client rooms, two bathroom/showers, and community gathering area and dining area. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for client's recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working

order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were posted. At the time of inspection the facility license was observed to be posted by the staff office. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff office. The Residential Manager stated they did not have individual contraceptive containers for clients. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms was measured to be 120 for bathroom #2 and bathroom #1 was 121.2. Per the Residential Manager, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. LPAs and LPM inspected the facility vehicle, and observed that there was a difficulty latching the third row seat into place. The facility was advised to have the third row seat serviced. LPAs and LPM observed the First Aid Kit to be complete. LPAs and LPM conducted a client record review of three of three client files. Client #1 did not have a current needs and service plan in the file. Licensee has Mental Health Program Approval that is valid through 12/13/2021. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation that is valid through 10/31/2021. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0. Based on review of Physical Plant and Client Records, the facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards Version 4, Chapter 7.5, Sections: Client Records 87068.3(a) and Title 22 Regulations Divsion 6, Chapter 1 Fixture, Furniture, Equipment and Supplies 80088(e)(1). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 809D, LIC9102, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to Residential Manager, Ricardo Calzada.

investigation_findings: 13On May 19, 2022 at 11:02 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Forecast Short Term Residential Therapeutic (STRTP) Program Administrator, Ricardo Calzada, to deliver the finding for the above stated allegations. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility on September 28, 2021 at approximately 2:00pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. The investigation was conducted by Special Investigator Georgina Tallagua and LPA Strickland which included interviews with Staff #3 (S3), Staff #4 (S4), four of four foster children (Child #1 [C1], Child #3 [C3], and Child #4 [C4], and Child #5 [C5]), and one Probation Officer (PO). Two confidential witnesses did not respond to LPA’s request for an interview and therefore were not interviewed. In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On September 20, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received two allegations alleging that staff (unknown) sexually abused youth (Child #1 [C1]), and staff (unknown) smoked with youth (C1). Record review revealed a conversation insinuating C1 had sex and smoked with staff (unknown) had been made resulting in the above allegations. Confidential interviews and record review were unable to confirm or

narrative: permission and have since returned but were unable to confirm any knowledge of, or disclosures made alleging sexual abuse. Confidential interviews were unable to confirm or dispute the allegation. A second allegation alleging facility staff (Staff #1 [S1]) had an inappropriate relationship with youth (Child #1 [C1]) was received by CCL. Specifically it was reported that S1 would purchase underwear for C1 on a weekly basis and made comments to C1 about getting C1 showered. Confidential interviews reported conflicting accounts on how purchases of personal items (ie. underwear) were made. Confidential interviews reported youth were given their clothing allowance and allowed to purchase needed/wanted items including underwear. Additional confidential interviews reported that staff assisted youth in making the purchases to ensure appropriate sizes were selected. However, it was also reported that S1 often frequently picked up various items from thrift shops and would provide these items to youth. It was unknown if these items included underwear. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute the allegation. A third allegation alleging facility staff (unnamed) did not accord youth (Child #1 [C1]) privacy. Specifically it was reported on an unknown date, while in the shower C1 felt as though C1 was being watched. Confidential interviews reported facility protocol is the bathroom door is the only door in the facility that is permitted to be closed and/or locked to allow for privacy. Confidential interviews reported if staff feel that foster youth are taking too long in the shower or bathroom they will continually knock the door and bother the youth. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute this allegation. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations of staff (Staff #1 [S1]) sexually abused youth (unknown), facility staff (Staff #1 [S1]) had an inappropriate relationship with youth (Child #1 [C1]), and facility staff (unnamed) did not accord youth (Child #1 [C1]) privacy, may or may not have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights was provided to Forecast Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Residential Manager Ricardo Calzada.

narrative:
On November 29, 2023 at 9:19 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, conducted an unannounced visit at Olive Crest - Forecast, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the visit was to conduct a required annual inspection of the facility. LPA met with Residential Manager, Tyresha Calhoun. While at the facility, LPA reviewed client and facility records, conducted three staff interviews, and two client interviews. At, approximately, 11 am LPA conducted a walk through and physical inspection of the facility. Youth Partner, Shahana Zeigler, led the walk through of the facility. While conducting the physical inspection, LPA made the following observations: the facility’s kitchen area was in good repair and free of hazards, there are four refrigerators/freezers, a dining area, and a community gathering area. There are six client bedrooms, two bathroom/showers, one staff restroom, one staff office, one clinician office, and one administrator office. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Washers and dryers are in working order. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for client's recreational time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors, carbon monoxide detectors, and fire extinguishers are in good repair and appropriate working order; The facility maintains a designated food storage area (pantry), an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods, and the menu was accessible. Licensee has Mental Health Program Approval that is valid through 12/13/2023. All required forms are posted near the facility entrance or staff office and included: the Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications, knives, and laundry supplies are locked and centrally stored inside staff office. Cleaning supplies are locked and centrally stored in a cabinet near the laundry room/pantry storage. Per the Residential Manager, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. *Continued on next page...*

The facility currently has three occupied beds and three open (vacant) beds. The bedroom living arrangements are as follows: Bedroom #1- Furnished with one twin bed, sleeps one client, and is occupied. Bedroom #4- Furnished with one twin bed, sleeps one client, and is occupied. Bedroom #5- Was Furnished with one twin bed, sleeps one client, and will be occupied by an incoming client. Bedrooms #2, 3, and 6- Are furnished with one twin bed and sleeps one client. No clients are placed in those rooms at this time. The bedrooms are arranged so that only one child is placed per room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, storage space, and mattresses in good repair. During the inspection, LPA reviewed three of three client records. Three of three client records reviewed were in compliance and contained required documentation per Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). The facility has an Administrator that is qualified and has a current STRTP Administrator certificate. Based on staff/client interviews (please refer to LIC 811, Confidential Names List), the facility appears to be meeting Core Therapeutic Services, and Supports, and Emergency Intervention Plan requirements. Staff records are not kept on facility grounds; On November 13, 2023, LPA met with Human Resources Administrative Manager to conduct the Staff Records review portion of the inspection at Olive Crest (336425183) located at: 525 Technology Court Suite 105 Riverside, CA 92507. LPA reviewed five personnel records, to ensure they contained required documentation per Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Five out of five personnel records reviewed were associated to the facility and the following background clearances were completed and on file: Department of Justice (DOJ), Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and Child Abuse Central Index (CACI). Five out of five personnel records reviewed had a health screening and tuberculosis (TB) test on file. Five out of five personnel records reviewed had annual training's, current cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), and first aid certification on file. Based on observation and record review, there are no deficiencies noted at this time during the inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report along with LIC 9102 and LIC 811, Confidential Names List, was provided to Residential Manager, Tyresha Calhoun.

Confidential interviews reported S1 was observed to have been smoking with clients. Other confidential interviews reported that there were no witnesses that saw S1 smoking with any of the clients while at the hotels. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff (S2) smoked marijuana with a minor while in care. Confidential interviews reported that S2 also worked the weekend that clients had to evacuate because of the power outages in the area, to a hotel and was seen smoking with clients. Other confidential interviews reported that S2 did work that weekend but denied witnessing S2 smoking with clients. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations of staff (S1) smoking with the minors while in care and staff (S2) smoked marijuana with a minor while in care are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Shahana Zeigler, Youth Partner.

narrative:
On August 13, 2025, at 10:25 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Julian Lucas, arrived unannounced at Forecast Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) located at 20051A Vista Del Lago, Perris, CA 92570. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a required annual inspection of the facility. LPA met with Administrator, Stacy Rougely. LPA began a facility tour at 10:35 am with Shahana Zeigler, Youth Partner. During the inspection, LPA observed the Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster posted near the entrance of the facility. The living room area consisted of two sofas and two chairs, a coffee table, two end tables, television, books, and board games placed on shelves. There is a dining area with a table with four chairs and two benches. The kitchen has one refrigerator with freezer. There are six client bedrooms, two bathrooms, with one shower in each bathroom, one staff office, one staff restroom, one clinician office, and one administrator office. There are two washers, and one dryer all are in working order in a separate locked room from the kitchen. There is sports equipment which includes bikes, and exercise equipment located in the garage are, which is locked. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All smoke detectors, carbon monoxide detectors are in working order. There are two fire extinguishers that are up to date. The facility maintains a designated food storage area (pantry), an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods, and the menu was accessible. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. During the inspection, LPA reviewed 3 client files, facility records, 3 staff files. LPA conducted one staff interview Continued on 809C

Medications are locked and centrally stored in the facility staff's office inside a locked file cabinet. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Chemicals/poisons are locked inside the facility staff’s office and sharp objects stored in the staff office inside a locked file cabinet. The facility staff’s office always remains locked. First Aid Kits are complete and stored in the staff office. Based on the annual required inspection on this date, there were no deficiencies found. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator, Stacy Roughley and a copy of this report was given to the administrator. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator, Stacy Roughely.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted an unannounced case management tele inspection with Fred Finch Youth Center and spoke with Mar Smith Senior Director (SD). The purpose of inspection was to follow up on an incident report that was reported to the licensing agency in the form of an Law Enforcement Incident Report (LIC 624 LE) dated 03/23/21. Incident report stated a client was in a restraint hold for 25 minutes. The report identified a 14 year old client who was in a restraint for 25 minutes because client was a danger to himself and staff. LPA interviewed SD and Administrator about the incident. SD and Administrator both stated that this was a common practice and pattern to de-escalate client. SD e-mail over past incident reports that staff had to restraint client. LPA review incident report and saw a pattern that staff had to de-escalate. LPA ask both Adminstrator and SD if client was hurt in the restraint? SD and Administrator stated that client was not hurt. At this time, further investigation is not needed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was e-mailed to SD for signature.

met_with: Mar Smith Senior Director and Grace Helton Administrator
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Fred Finch Youth Center. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on October 15, 2018 . During the inspection, LPA met with Mar Smith Senior Director (SD) and Grace Helton Administrator as well as additional facility personnel. The STRTP is licensed to serve 14 clients ages 12-18. The facility consists of 10 bedrooms (6 double occupancy and 4 single occupancy) and 11 bathrooms (10 client and 1 staff). At 12:00 PM, LPA Rollins toured the facility with SD and Administrator inside and out. LPA observed the kitchen is clean. Water measured 113.4 degrees F. The facility has plenty of non perishable and perishable food supply. Medication and knives are locked away. There are enough folks, spoons, plates and cups. All passageways are unobstructed. All smoke detectors are up to date and working. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. There are no bodies of water on the property. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature. Personal rights, floor plan, food menu and Emergency disaster forms were posted in clear view. Fire Extinguisher was up to date and carbon monoxide was in good working shape. There were no Title 22 violations regarding physical plant observed at this time.

Ten client files were reviewed. LPA observed all ten client files and found no deficiencies. Needs and services plan are updated. The documentation is in the clients files are complete. LPA observed medication logs to be updated and current. Facility already received their mental health approval as of August 2, 2019. LPA observed five staff files and found no deficiencies. Staff have completed there 40 hours annual training. All staff documentation is current. LPA discussed with Senior Director and Administrator overview of required Core Services and Supports and based upon inspection of facility records. Licensee appears to be meeting requirements. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during the inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

Based on the information obtained; there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that facility staff shared a video of a client in care without guardian consent. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was sent to the Adminstrator for signature.

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that facility staff increased client in care medication without medical approval, facility staff did not observe changes in client in care physical condition, facility staff are not transporting client in care to medical appointments, facility staff did not develop client in care needs and service plan and facility staff did not meet client in care hygiene needs,therefore the above allegation is unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted with SD and LPA left report at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted a complaint inspection with Fred Finch and met with Mar Smith Senior Director. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documentation, the licensee did not ensure that facility staff got consent to share a video, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to residents in care.

narrative: On 8/4/2022 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted an unannounced case management at the above facility and met with Program Administrator (P1) Roland Williams. The purpose of the case management is to amend documents dated 06/27/22. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was given to Program Administrator Roland Williams.

On 8/4/2022 at 1:55 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted an unannounced case management at the above facility and met with Program Administrator (P1) Roland Williams. The purpose of the case management is to follow-up on information received by community care licensing. On 02/24/2022, the Department received information that client #1(C1) overdosed on 02/14/2022 resulting in hospitalization and C1 was transported to the hospital on due to an overdose on medications. Confidential interviews and documents provided determined the facility did not follow Fred Finch’s home visit medication policy. LPA reviewed the pass medication form and the form was incomplete missing the counter signature by the caregiver. Fred Finch Home Visit Medications Policy: The Medical Coordinator receives notification of a participant's home visit via a social worker communication at least 24 hours before visit. The pharmacy prepares the proper amount to be sent with the participant on his/her home visit. A completed Home Visit Medications Form must accompany a participant for any home visits and be counter signed by a residential staff and the caregiver. A copy of the signed form will be retained for FFYC records and a copy provided to the caregiver for reference. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility did not operate in accordance with the terms specified in the plan of operation and the pass medication form was incomplete. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care. The facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Interim Licensing Standards 80022(h) Plan of Operation . An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was given to Program Administrator Roland Williams.

Confidential interviews contradicted the information stating that the decision to remove C1 had already been made, however it was reported that a new emergency one on one staff was being offered to the facility if C1 returned to the facility. Confidential interviews stated C1’s behaviors were threat to the safety of all clients and staff at the facility and a new emergency staff would have inflamed the situation. Confidential interviews stated the facility had scheduled multiple child and family team meetings (CFT’s) to work together and build the best plan possible for C1 however, the plans had been unsuccessful and C1 was being removed. Confidential interviews stated staff followed procedures in discharging C1 however, it was reported that the facility could have done more to keep C1 safe and in placement. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that facility staff refused C1's return to the facility after hospitalization may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this signed report was emailed to Facility Administrator Roland Williams.
investigation_findings: 13On 08/31/2022, at 11:15 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Program Administrator Roland Williams, of Fred Finch Youth Center to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. On December 07, 2021 at 10:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted an unannounced complaint investigation at the above facility and met with Program Administrator Roland Williams. LPA conducted a safety inspection and no deficiencies were observed at that time. The investigation consisted of confidential interviews with one program supervisor, one program administrator, four facility staff, client #1(C1), and review of incident reports. On 12/06/2021, the Department received an allegation that facility staff refused C1's return to the facility after hospitalization. It was reported C1 attempted to self-harm and threaten staff at the facility however, C1 was medically and psychiatrically cleared to return to facility and the facility refused intake. (see continuation form LIC-9099C dated 08/31/22)

narrative: Confidential interviews stated C1 is unpredictable in C1’s behaviors and the facility has scheduled multiple Child and Family Team meetings (CFT’s) to work together and build the best plan possible however, the plans have been unsuccessful. Confidential interviews stated staff follow procedures with C1 to prevent AWOL’s however staff are limited in their authority as a result of personal rights. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff are not adhering to the facility emergency intervention plan preventing Client #1(C1) from AWOLing may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this signed report was emailed to Facility Administrator Roland Williams.
investigation_findings: 13On 08/31/2022, at 12:15 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Program Administrator Roland Williams, of Fred Finch Youth Center to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. On 11/19/2021, LPA Carol Anderson conducted an unannounced complaint investigation at the above facility and met with Residential Supervisor Erica Rowan. LPA Anderson conducted a safety inspection and no deficiencies were observed at that time. The investigation consisted of confidential interviews with one program supervisor, one program administrator, four facility Staff (S1 – S4), Client #1(C1), and review of incident reports and emergency intervention plan. On 11/12/2021, the Department received an allegation that staff are not adhering to the facility emergency intervention plan preventing Client #1(C1) from AWOLing. Confidential interviews contradicted the information stating that the facility adheres to C1’s emergency intervention plan; staff redirect C1; provide C1 with space to return to baseline; staff remove identified triggers to keep C1 and others safe; staff follow C1 if C1 AWOL’s; and law enforcement is contacted as a last resort. (See continuation form LIC-9099C dated 08/31/22)

narrative:
On May 4, 2023 at 09:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced annual facility inspection. LPA and LPM met with Roland Williams, Program Administrator who provided LPA and LPM with a guided indoor and outdoor tour of the facility. The facility serves a capacity of 14, age range 12-17 years old upon intake with a current census of 7 clients. The facility has two cottages. Cottage 1 is a six bedroom, two bathroom, dinning area, living room, and staff office. Cottage 2 is a five bedroom, two bathroom, kitchen, laundry room, dinning area, living room, and staff office. All bedrooms serve one client each. All beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Each cottage living room has a TV, chairs, and board games for indoor activities. Each Cottage had combined living spaces of dinning and living room area. The dinning area contained a large dinning table with six chairs. The kitchen in Cottage 2 was observed to be free from hazards. The kitchen contained a walk in pantry where it was observed to have supplies of staple non- perishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable food for a minimum of two days. Sharps were maintained in a lock box in the pantry. Medication was stored in the staff office of each cottage in locked cabinets. Controlled medications were in a locked cabinet in a locked safe. The facility contained security bags for when clients go on day passes. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. There is a large backyard for outdoor activities such as soccer and basketball. There is a picnic table in the front and back yard. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. CONTINUED....

The hot water temperature was measured in the bathroom and is currently 111.0 degrees which is in ration. Per Program Administrator there are no firearms in the facility. LPA observed the following items posted Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policy, Facility sketch, Activity Schedule, Meal Menu, Staff Schedule and Emergency Plan. There are two separate buildings on grounds. Cottage three is the staff office. Cottage four is the family center with a sensory room. In addition, there are two sheds for the maintenance coordinator. Client files are maintained off-site and transported to LPA and LPM within reasonable time. Personnel files were maintained electronically by HR. LPA and LPM reviewed five client files. LPA reviewed five electronic staff files via Microsoft Teams with HR. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Based on today's visit there are no deficiencies observed at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Roland Williams, Program Administrator.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi on June 1, 2023 at 10:41 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Choi met with Medical Coordinator Jessica Vera, and conducted a tour of the facility. LPA reviewed four of child’s records and three of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed four of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed three staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA will interview three children, that are currently prescribed psychotropic medication, at their assigned schools, after the facility visit. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report and conducted an exit interview with Administrator Roland Williams.

Confidential interviews confirmed that S1 and S2 placed C1 on a wall assisted restrain, however, C1 was not pushed and the bruising was due to C1 resisting the restrain. Confidential interviews did not provide consistent statements and there were no witnesses to the event. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff pushed minor resulting in injuries, may have occurred, however is not supported, or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report was provided to Roland Williams, Administrator.

narrative: Confidential interviews indicate C2 punched C1 in the mouth and C1 bit C2 on the leg. Confidential interviews indicated staff are not allowed to step in between clients during physical altercation, however, it is unknown whether a restraint would have negated the physical altercation as one was not performed. Record review indicated C2 kicked C1 and punched C1 in the head numerous times. Confidential interviews indicated S1 and S3 attempted to separate clients and there were no witnesses to the event. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff did not provide adequate supervision resulting in physical altercation between foster youths, may have occurred, however is not supported, or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report was provided to Roland Williams, Administrator.

On June 26, 2023, the Department received an allegation that staff did not provide adequate supervision resulting in physical altercation between foster youth. narrative: Confidential interviews revealed an emergency IEP was held for C1 discussing this is C1’s last chance before terminating placement. However, there was no exact date of when C1’s placement would be terminated. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements; staff provided a safe environment by interacting with C1 with sports, crisis communication, coping skills and following C1’s behavioral plan, and that staff did not prevent C2 from triggering C1. Confidential interviews indicated C1 received individual therapy once a week and family therapy once a month. Other interviews indicated that when C1 wanted to speak with a therapist in between therapy sessions one was not provided. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that facility did not follow proper eviction protocols, staff did not provide a safe environment for minor in care and staff did not ensure that minor was provided necessary behavioral treatment services while in care, however is not supported, or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this signed report, and appeal rights was provided to Roland Williams, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On August 22, 2023, at 10:36 AM AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Lucero Jauregui and Jacob Salem arrived at the facility unannounced and met with Roland Williams, Administrator to discuss the investigative findings for the allegations noted above. LPA Marisol Lopez conducted an inspection of the facility on March 28, 2023, and no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation, LPA Lopez conducted one confidential interview (P1), requested current client roster, staff roster with contact information, incident reports, and conducted record review of C1’s CFT’s and IEP. LPA Jauregui conducted four staff interviews (S1-S4), four client interviews (C2-C5), one Regional Center Service Coordinator interview (RC1), and record review. LPA Jauregui made multiple attempts to interview Client # 1 (C1) but was unsuccessful. On March 21, 2023, the Department received an allegation that facility did not follow proper eviction protocols, staff did not provide a safe environment for minor in care and staff did not ensure that minor was provided necessary behavioral treatment services while in care. CONTINUED....

narrative: Confidential interviews mentioned an incident where C1 became upset with behavior escalating into self-harm and property destruction. During the incident C1 went outside of a cottage located at the facility and with a rock began to make scratches on their forearm. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 then attempted to reenter the cottage but was not allowed entrance into the cottage by staff members assigned to work in the cottage. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 became more upset when staff would not allow C1 entrance back into the cottage, so C1 threw a rock at the cottage glass window. Resulting in the breaking/shattering of the window. While C1 remained outside and not being allowed entry into the cottage, C1 picked up some broken glass, and began to cut their forearm with the shards of glass, while staff remained inside the cottage. Information provided indicated that staff contributed to C1 becoming unable to de-escalate and manage the self-harming behavior by remaining inside the cottage and not opening the entrance door, when C1 was attempting to re-enter the facility. Confidential interviews indicated that staff remained inside the cottage while using crisis communication through the window. LPA did not receive information regarding staff implementing a safety plan, following C1’s needs and service plan, attending to C1’s wounds, nor providing guidance to a safe area away from the broken glass. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that due to neglect, C1 sustained injuries while in care, staff did not prevent C1 from self-harming, staff are not properly supervising minors while in care, and staff did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for minors are SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care, the facility will be cited for violating Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 4, STRTP, Article 06. 87065.2(b)(1) Personnel Duties and Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9(a)(1) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, and a plan of correction was developed with Roland Williams, Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Roland Williams Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
87065.2(b)(1) Personnel Duties.  (b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and confidential interviews the facility staff did not ensure that C1 was properly supervised and protected as C1 was left outside of the facility cottage with shards of glass, which C1 used to cut their forearm while staff remained inside the facility, which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will provide Supervision training and submit proof to CCL by 10/3/2023.

deficiencies.description:
Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9(a)(1) Personal Rights: All children placed in foster care… shall have the rights specified in this section.  To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect…

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and confidential interviews the facility staff did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for C1 by ensuring that C1 did not have access to glass; C1 had broken a window and staff did not guide C1 away from the shards of glass to safeguard the environment and prevent C1 from using the glass to cut their forearm, and did not provide a comfortable environment when staff did not allow C1 access into the facility, which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will provide Personal Rights training and submit proof to CCL by 10/3/2023.

Confidential interviews disclosed C1 and C2 had a “crush” on each other. It was also stated during confidential interviews that C1 and C2 liked each other, and staff often had to separate them. Confidential interview indicated C1 and C2 resided in different cottages and, on one occasion, C1 was caught by staff going into C2’s bedroom through the window after hours. Confidential interviews revealed C1 and C2 often disabled the window alarms by removing the battery from the alarm or removing the alarm from the window. Record review indicated windows were often replaced due to clients breaking them; however, the window alarms were not maintained, although interviews indicated that staff were aware that clients disabled or removed alarms. Record review indicated C1 and C2 interacted sexually on at least two occasions while in C1’s bedroom. Record review indicated C2 admitted to having sex with C1 and being in a relationship with C1 when they were placed at the facility. The Department received consistent information regarding C1 and C2 having a sexual interaction while they were placed at the facility due to disabling the window alarms and staff not conducting frequent status checks on the clients. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation that due to lack of care and supervision, minors engaged in inappropriate sexual activity while in care is SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence has been met. This posed immediate Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risks to children in care. The facility will be cited for violating Title 22. Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, Section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision [See LIC 9099D]. An Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) determination is pending. If an ECP is assessed, a Community Care Licensing representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment. An exit interview was conducted, and Plan of Correction was developed with Roland Williams, Administrator. A copy of this signed report, LIC 9099D and appeal rights were provided to Roland Williams, Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s needs.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, C1 and C2 engaged in inappropriate sexual activity while they were placed at the facility which posed immediate health, safety, and personal rights risks to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Personal Rights and Supervisoin training completed on 9/18/24. 

Within 24 hours, the facility will provide a written plan of correction to CCL on how they plan to address care and supervision. Facility has increased level of supervision, will continue to supervise clients, clients are always in line of sight, if serious safety issues arise facility will increase ratio to 1:1 to ensure all clients are safe and supervised at all times.

narrative: On November 6, 2024, at 11:03 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced case management visit at the above facility. LPA Jauregui met with Roland Williams, Administrator. The purpose of this case management visit is to amend findings delivered on 9/17/24. An exit interview was conducted with Roland Williams, Administrator. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Roland Williams, Administrator.

On January 10, 2025, at 10:46 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui met with Erica Rowan, Residential Supervisor, of Fred Finch Youth Center-San Diego to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). On November 6, 2024, LPA Jauregui delivered an amended Complaint Investigation Report to the facility. The allegation that due to lack of care and supervision, minors engaged in inappropriate sexual activity while in care was substantiated. The investigation provided sufficient evidence that the minors engaged in inappropriate sexual activity on two occasions due to lack of supervision. The licensee was cited from Title 22 Regulations, Section 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s needs. Based on an analysis of the confidential interviews and documentation, the Department has determined that an ECP is warranted for the facility not ensuring that C1 and C2 were provided sufficient supervision to prevent C2 from entering C1’s room and engaging in inappropriate sexual activity. Penal Code section 11165.1 defines sexual abuse as involuntary sexual penetration. Therefore, pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty Law, Health, and Safety Code section 1548(f)(1)(C), the Department will be issuing an immediate Civil Penalty of $2,500.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, and the Civil Penalty Assessment-Serious Bodily Injury/Sexual Abuse (Form 421-D) were provided to Erica Rowan, Residential Supervisor. The signed copy will be retained in the facility file.

On March 21, 2025 at 10:55 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Lucero Jauregui and Lisa Bernabe arrived unannounced to the facility and met with Erica Rowan, Residential Supervisor for the purpose of conducting a Case Management inspection to check on the health and safety of the clients in care. No immediate deficiencies were observed or cited during today's case management inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Erica Rowan, Residential Supervisor.

It was reported that staff speak inappropriately to children in care and do not treat them with dignity or respect. It was also reported that facility staff are aggressive and punitive with the clients. Confidential interview indicated clients were having a conversation with each other during which C1 inquired about a statement said in the conversation. Confidential interview indicated C1’s response was “well that’s very ghetto.” Confidential interview indicated staff intervened and told C1 they were offending cultural background. Confidential interview indicated C1 made a joke and staff indicated it was racist. Confidential interviews indicated C1 makes comments regarding race and politics. Confidential interviews indicated staff have addressed concerns with C1 regarding C1’s comments. Confidential interviews denied clients being spoken to inappropriately by staff. Confidential interview indicated clients are spoken to in a nice way. Confidential interviews indicated staff speak kindly and with respect. Confidential interviews indicated staff’s tone can change during different situations to be assertive however, it is never aggressive. It was reported that on June 30, 2024, C1 was in a power struggle with staff; specifically, the staff had a bowl of fruit that they were distributing to the clients, but C1 did not want the staff to select and touch their fruit. Confidential interview indicated C1 did not want S1 to touch their eating utensils or their meal when S1 was passing it out. Confidential interview indicated it is part of C1’s diagnosis to not like their food touched. Confidential interview indicated it is observed that C1 doesn’t have a problem when other staff pass out the meals. Confidential interview indicated S1 touched C1’s fruit and handed it to them. Confidential interview indicated S1 asked C1 if everything was okay, however, C1 did not engage and became argumentative with S1. Confidential interviews did not provide corroborating statements and there were no witnesses. It was reported that staff do not ensure that children are adequately fed. It was reported that staff do not allow C1 to select their own fruit and only allow C1 to eat what is given to them. It was reported that C1 expressed their concern to staff to not touch their fruit, and C1 was denied the fruit. It was reported that C1 is being denied milk and needs a doctor’s note for milk. Confidential interviews indicated there are three meals and snacks served at the facility. Confidential interview indicated an alternative meal is offered when a client doesn’t like the meal or snack being provided for the day. Confidential interviews denied clients being denied food. Confidential interviews denied clients being denied a meal. CONTINUED.....

It was reported that staff do not keep the facility free from pests. It was reported that C1 saw roaches in their room and staff denied that there are roaches. It was reported that C1’s bedroom was cleaned but not treated for pests. Confidential interviews indicated ants and spiders have been observed outside the facility. Confidential interviews denied witnessing roaches inside the facility. It was reported that staff do not ensure that children attend doctor appointments. It was reported that a doctor appointment was scheduled by C1’s relative, and the appointment was cancelled by staff. Confidential interview indicated an appointment was made for C1 by their relative; however, it was cancelled by staff. Confidential interview indicated a medical appointment was scheduled by staff; however, it was cancelled by C1’s relative. LPA received conflicting statements regarding C1’s medical appointment being scheduled. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff speak inappropriately to children in care, staff do not treat children with dignity or respect, staff do not ensure that children are adequately fed, staff do not keep the facility free from pests, and staff do not ensure that children attend doctor appointments may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report and appeal rights were provided to Erica Rowan, Residential Supervisor.

narrative:
On November 2, 2021 at 8:43am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Fred Jefferson Memorial Home for Boys #1 to conduct an annual required inspection at the above location. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision for six (6) children, ages 14-17 years old, ambulatory only. This facility also provides services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1(C)(1). Provisional license extended through 11/20/2021. Waiver on file. Currently there are three (3) clients in placement. There is no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. LPA Edison met with Heather Boucher (Facility Manager) who granted access into the home and together a tour of the home was conducted. The home is a single-story home located in a residential neighborhood. The home has 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, living room, kitchen, laundry area, an office, a meeting room, front and a backyard. No bodies of water on the premises. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. There is a locked room off of the living room which contains 2 refrigerators for extra frozen foods, meats, dairy products. There is a locked cabinet inside of the room that contains extra hygiene products and extra linens. Kitchen: Equipped with refrigerator, 4 burner gas stove, oven, and microwave. There is adequate perishable and nonperishable food supply. Facility provides nutritious snacks between meals. Dining Area: (located in Kitchen) One table with six chairs Bedroom 1: Is not occupied on the date of inspection. It is equipped with two twin beds, two dressers, adequate lighting and closet space. Bedroom 2: Occupied by one client, equipped with two twin beds, two dressers, adequate lighting and closet space. Bedroom 3: Occupied by two clients, equipped with two twin beds, two dressers, adequate lighting and closet space. Bathroom 1: (located in Meeting room) Toilets, sinks, and showers clean and operable at time of visit. Bathroom 2: Toilets, sinks, and showers clean and operable at time of visit. Meeting Room: is located along the hallway, it has table with six (6) chairs, and there is a locked closet that is used for food storage. Office: Is located along the hallway and contains staff and client files in locked file cabinets. Also contains a locked closet which holds extra snacks and non-perishable foods. Continued on LIC 809-C

The home was inspected, and the following was observed: The home is clean, safe, and sanitary. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions, and medicines are made inaccessible to clients. Hot water kept at a safe temperature. The beds have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets and pillows, all in good repair. Caregiver maintains a safe and comfortable temperature in the home. First aid kit was checked and found to have appropriate supplies. Fire extinguishers located in the meeting room, laundry room, and kitchen were fully charged All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested audible and were working properly. Emergency numbers, facility license, evacuation plan, and first aid information were posted. No guns or weapons are in the home. There is a working telephone readily accessible to clients in the home at all times. Children’s Personal Rights and house rules are posted. Outdoor activity space is free of obstruction. During this visit, LPA conducted 2 client interviews and 3 staff interviews. LPA informed Administrator of past due licensing fees. Administrator will contact Financial Executive to find out the status of fees being paid. Administrator will update LPA of fees being paid. LPA advised administrator of Mental Health waiver expiration date of 11/20/2021. Administrator spoke with the Head of Service who advised approval should be received by 11/12/2021. Administrator will email the approval certificate to LPA Edison. LPA will return at a later date to complete the inspection. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility.

LPA reviewed following during the inspection: Staff Records Review: LPA reviewed five (5) staff records stored in individual personnel file/binders provided by the facility manager. LPA ensured to thoroughly review the records of the primary active staff (i.e The Program Administrator, Primary Therapist, Clinical Director, Residential Director, Facility Manager; and Five (5) Direct Care Staff. Client Records Review: LPA reviewed three (3) client records stored in individual personnel file/binders provided by the facility manager. LPA thoroughly reviewed the records of the clients including the Needs and Services Plan for each client along with Personal Rights. LPA was advised by S3 that approval should be received before expiration date and will be emailed to LPA. LPA provided email information to S3. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 87064 Administrator - Qualifications and Duties. The current administrator does not meet educational/experience qualifications and was not an administrator of a group home prior to January 1, 2017. Has a certificate of a group home administrator effective 5/20/2018 and expires 5/20/2020. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility.

Special Incident Report # 809823, Child & Family Team notes, Needs & Service Plan, Staff work schedules, facilities emergency intervention policies and procedures. Pro Act certifications. Staff #3 denied hitting Child #2 and stated was working in the office when Child #2 rushed and attacked Staff #3 in office. Staff #1, Staff #2, & Staff #4 all denied allegations and stated Staff # 3 was rushed and attacked by client. Child #2 stated did square off with Staff # 3 and stepped into the office but did not want to fight. Staff #3 & Staff #4 attempted to de escalation but Child #2 & Child #1 rushed Staff # 3 shoving Staff #3 into office wall. Staff #4 stated used Pro Act De escalation techniques to calm Child #1 & Child #2. Photographs show evidence of impact to office wall. Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegation. LPA Phillips was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Yvonne Robinson/ Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
87072 PERSONAL RIGHTS
(c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, and below, as applicable...
(1) To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. If the child is an Indian child, to live in a home that upholds the prevailing social and cultural standards of the child’s Indian community, including, but not limited to, family, social, and political ties.* This requirement is not met as evidenced by:

Based on interviews and record review, the licensee verbally abused minors while in care, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care

On June 23, 2021, at 8:55 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar arrived at Future Stars Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation inspection for STRTP annual inspection that was initiated on June 22, 2021. LPA already completed the physical inspection of the facility and reviewed facility client files on the first day of the annual inspection. During this annual inspection continuation, LPA Escobar reviewed ten personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Personnel Files are usually maintained in a locked closet by the front door. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Ten of the ten files that were reviewed were for employees who converted from group home personnel to STRTP personnel. LPA observed the converted staff members were trained according to the STRTP training requirements. Files for staff 5 (S5) and staff 8 (S8) did not have a copy of driver's license. Staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), and staff 10 (S10) did not have proof of TB test. S10 and staff 7 (S7) files did not have education verification. S5 and staff 6 (S6) did not have signed employee rights. S1, S2, and S10, did not have updated job descriptions. S5 and S6 did not have job descriptions. S8 and S10 did not have current job evaluations and S7 did not have one in file. S2, and S4-S10 did not have employer verification form in files. S3 file does not have copy of fingerprint clearance in file. Technical Assistance Advisory Note will be issued for personnel files. Administrator R'Nisha Parker is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. LPA discussed the following with the facility manager: incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports.

Based upon the inspection of facility records and interviews with staff and clients, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. Two youth counselors (direct care staff) and one facility manager present during annual inspection were interviewed in regard to their job duties, training, and services provided at the facility. All staff were able to provide sufficient information in relation to the facility's program. Staff have no issues or concerns regarding the facility. Based upon the inspection of facility records and interviews with staff and clients, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. LPA requested the recent board meeting minutes be provided via email by June 28, 2021. Additionally, Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. The facility has an exception on file to use the cameras and are meeting the terms and conditions. A copy of this report, the advisory notices, and appeal rights, were provided to Facility manager, Iyonna Matthews.

On June 22, 2021 at 9:05 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar arrived at Future Stars Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by Ms. Ronnie Lusk. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There were two staff and five clients present at the time of the inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection, however, no facility manager was on site at the time of the inspection. The facility is being cited under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards chapter section 87065, Personnel Requirements. No facility manager was available to arrive at the facility during the time LPA conducted the inspection. At 9:15 AM, Ronnie Lusk led the physical inspection of the facility. The facility consists of three bedrooms and two bathrooms. The facility has a small dining area, kitchen area, living room, open common area, laundry room, and a garage. The facility has a clinician's office for therapeutic services. Staff areas are located in the open common area as well as a corner of the main living room. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. During the inspection, it was observed that the basketball hoop in the backyard has fallen over and is on the ground, creating a potential hazard. It was also observed that the outside of the garage wall has white graffiti/markings that need to be painted over. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Books, crafts, movies, and other activities, were observed for client’s recreation time. The client's bedroom windows were also missing screens. Carbon monoxide detector is in appropriate working order, and per staff, all facility smoke detectors are also in working order, however, this could not be verified as fire system is hard-wired into the home with standard fire alarms and fire alarm handles available for use during an emergency. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures,

Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. There was no activities calendar posted in the facility. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked closet near the front door. The hot water in the kitchen was deemed to be at a safe temperature. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of the license. Chemicals and/or poisons are locked in a cabinet in a restroom by the kitchen/garage area. Sharp objects are locked and stored in the locked closet by the front door/common area. First Aid Kits are also stored in the staff area and are complete, however, a First Aid Manual was unavailable. The facility employs one Facility Administrator, one Facility Manager, one Case Manager, three direct care/youth counselor staff, one Head of Service and one Program Director. Facility has not yet obtained Mental Health Certification, however, have submitted the application and are awaiting approval. Facility has obtained National Accreditation through CARF effective through September 30, 2023. Currently, there is a balance of $227 in Licensing fees for the facility. At 9:55 AM, five of five client files were reviewed during time of inspection. Client 1 (C1), client 2 (C2), client 3 (C3), client 4 (C4) and client 5's (C5) (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated June 22, 2021, needs and service plans were not up to date. C1, C2, and C3, did not have proof of TB test. C1, C2, and C3 did not have proof of immunizations. C1-C5 did not have a signed copy of removal/discharge procedures, the facility complaint/grievance process, signed house discipline/rules, and C1 and C4 did not have an updated EIP. Additionally, all clients did not have a current allowance log or current inventory log. LPA Escobar requested that the current needs and service plans, immunization records, signed facility policies, and updated logs aforementioned, be sent to LPA Escobar as soon as possible. Currently there are four clients on medication. There are no observable current JV220 forms for C1, C3, C4, and C5. LPA requested copies of current JV220s also be sent to LPA Escobar. Technical Assistance Advisory Notes (TA) will be issued. LPAs conducted client interviews. Clients indicated that their basic needs are being met at the facility and core services being provided as well. LPA Escobar began the review of staff files, however, due to time constraints, was not able to conclude the review. LPA Escobar will return to complete staff file review and interviews at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Case Manager, Ms. Ronnie Lusk.

narrative: threatened C1. Specifically, it was reported that S1 threatened to hit C1 and also called C1 “bitch”. While two witnesses maintain this is true, S1 denies calling C1 “bitch” and also denies threatening C1. Confidential interviews revealed a verbal altercation occurred between S1 and C1 at the facility. A couple of witnesses report hearing S1 call C1 a “bitch” and also verbally threaten C1, saying something along the lines of, “You must not know who you’re talking to. I’m about to slap those glasses off your face!” and “Shut the fuck up before I choke you!” to C1 during verbal altercation between S1 and C1. A witness maintains this was said by S1 as S1 was about 1-2 inches from C1’s face. Another party states though they did not visually witness this occur, they heard S1’s comments and remarks which corroborate what was reported. A couple of witness observed C1 being emotionally distraught due to the verbal altercation involving S1 and what was allegedly said by S1. S1 denies getting loud or yelling at C1. Several other statements corroborate this did occur. S1 was unable to articulate what trauma informed care/service was provided to C1 during this incident, S1 simply denied both allegations. Based on interviews conducted and information obtained, the allegations that S1 spoke inappropriately to C1 and S1 threatened C1 are SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met for the allegations. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care. The facility is being cited under Interim Licensing Standards section 87072 Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were provided to Facility Manager, Iyonna Matthews, for signature.

deficiencies.description: (c)	The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11)	To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: S1 threatened to knock C1’s glasses off C1’s face and to choke C1.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Facility Manager, S1 will be retrained in personal rights, with emphasis in trauma-informed care for de-escalation. Proof of retraining will be provided to LPA. S1 is also being put on 6 month probationary period.

deficiencies.description: (c)	The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (10)	To be accorded dignity in *their* personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:  S1 spoke inappropriately to C1, calling C1 a “bitch” and getting into loud, yelling verbal altercation with C1.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Facility Manager, S1 will be retrained in personal rights, with emphasis in trauma-informed care for de-escalation. Proof of retraining will be provided to LPA. S1 is also being put on 6 month probationary period.
