narrative: On February 2, 2023, at 4:20 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Carmen Escobar conducted an in-person inspection of Future Stars Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a physical walk through of the facility to inspect the building and grounds. While LPA conducted a physical inspection of the facility, it was observed that room 2 and room 3, do not have doors. The doors have been replaced with curtains. By removing all the bedroom doors, the facility is in violation of clients' personal rights. The facility is being cited under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87072, Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with appeal rights, was signed by, and provided to Facility Manager, Iyonna Mathews, via facility email due to technical difficulties.

On March 6th, 2023 at 10:16 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete, conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Future Stars Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was met at the facility by Facility Manager (FM) Iyonna Matthews. LPA Peete visited the facility on 03/03/2023 to complete inspection of the Physical Plant. The FM left the facility at 10:20 AM to retrieve the staff and client files, that are kept off site. LPA waited off facility grounds for the FM to return. The FM returned at 11:30 AM and LPA began a review of client records. LPA reviewed five client files (C1-C5) assisted by the FM and Head of Services Tabitha Lopez . At 11:45 AM it was observed the C3’s client intake packet, which covered the facility's policies and procedures regarding the removal and/or transfer; discipline; and complaints. was missing a few signatures and forms were not dated. The FM stated the packet was reviewed with C3’s at the time of placement and the required forms will be signed and dated by C3. A technical assistance advisory note was issued from Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87070(c)(2).. (c) the following additional information shall be maintained in the child's record. (2) Signed copies of the facility's policies and procedures regarding the child's removal and/or transfer; discipline; and complaints. At 2:30 PM the licensee was cited with a technical violation of ILS 87068.2(b)(6)… (b) The needs and services plan shall be trauma informed… and shall identify the child's needs in the following areas:(6) Visitation, including the frequency of and any other limitations on visits to the family residence and other visits inside and outside the facility and ILS 87068.2(e) The licensee shall document in the child’s needs and services plan how family members are integrated into the treatment process for the child… and how sibling connections are maintained… The needs and services plan or C1-C5 did not include the required information as stated above. (Continued on LIC 809 C)

At 2:45 PM it was observed the medical assessment for C1-C5 did not include the required tuberculosis examination results. The licensee is not in compliance with Title 22 California Code of Regulations 80069(c)(1) The medical assessment shall include the following: (1) The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to complete the inspection at a later date. Based on observations made during the inspection, deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, the LIC 811, and appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager Iyonna Matthews.

On March 7th, 2023, at 8:11 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete, conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Future Stars Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) LPA was met at the facility by Director Danette Seay. LPA Peete visited the facility on 03/03/2023 to complete inspection of the Physical Plant and on 03/06/2023 to complete the review of five client files. Per the Directors statement the Facility Manager (FM) Iyonna Matthews had the keys to the staff files and would not be on site until 10:00 AM. The FM arrived at the facility at 10:00 AM. At 10:15 AM , assisted by the FM, LPA began review of Operations, Disaster Preparedness, and Core Therapeutic Services. All the documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. At 11:00 AM LPA began review of the Emergency Intervention Plan. Per FM statement staff is trained on assaultive behavior management techniques and restraints are used as a last resort; from least to most restrictive. FM stated training for the year of 2023 has been scheduled for staff. The licensee will provide proof of emergency intervention training to LPA. Licensee did not have a restraint log and will be cited with the following technical violations of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) : ILS 87095.61(f): The licensee must maintain a monthly log of each use of manual restraints. The log must include: ILS 87095.61(f)(1) The licensee must maintain a monthly log of each use of manual restraints. The log must include:(1) Name of each child. ILS 87095.61(f)(2) The licensee must maintain a monthly log of each use of manual restraints. The log must include:(2) Date and time of the intervention. ILS 87095.61(f)(3) The licensee must maintain a monthly log of each use of manual restraints. The log must include: (3) Duration of the intervention.

ILS 87095.61(f)(4) The licensee must maintain a monthly log of each use of manual restraints. The log must include: (4) Name(s) of facility staff member(s) who participated in the manual restraint. ILS 87095.61(f)(5) The licensee must maintain a monthly log of each use of manual restraints. The log must include: (5) Description of the intervention and type used. ILS 87095.61(f)(6) The licensee must maintain a monthly log of each use of manual restraints. The log must include: (6) Result of licensee review. ILS 87095.61(g) The monthly log must be available for review, and subject to reproduction by the Department upon request during normal business hours. At 11:30 AM LPA began review of five staff files ( S1-S5) assisted by the FM. During file review it was observed the tuberculosis test results were not on file for S1. The licensee will be cited for Tittle 22 California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80066(a)(11) …The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (11) Tuberculosis test documents… At 12:00 PM it was observed S1 and S2 did not complete the required 40 hours of annual training for the year 2022. S1 completed 38 hours and S2 completed 32 hours. The licensee will be cited with the technical violation of ILS 87065.1(e)(1) … all direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 40 hours of annual training… LPA interviewed two clients and staff. Based on observations made during the inspection, deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, the LIC 811, and appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager Iyonna Matthews.

On March 03, 2023, at 8:39 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete arrived at Future Stars Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by Youth Counselor Lea Cash. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. Per staff statement FM was off site dropping clients off at school. The facility manager arrived at 9:09 AM. At 9:12 AM LPA began a physical plant inspection assisted by the Facility Manager. The physical plant inspection included the following checks: The facility consists of three bedrooms, one staff bathroom and one client bathroom. Per FM statement clients are allowed to use and access the staff bathroom, (toilet and shower) when the client bathroom is in use. LPA observed burned paper in the staff shower. The FM stated they did not know when or who burned the paper. Youth Counselor Lea Cash cleaned the shower at the time if inspection. The facility has a small dining area, kitchen area, living room, open common area, laundry room, and a garage. The facility has a clinician's office for therapeutic services. Additional staff areas are in the open common area as well as a corner of the main living room. Bedrooms are arranged so that there are two clients per a room and one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. Extra linens are stored in the hall closet. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. Cleansers, chemicals, and cooking knives are inaccessible to clients. Cleaners and chemicals are locked in the laundry room closet and in the garage. The cooking knives are locked inside of the staff office. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of food and a variety of snacks for clients. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and a two-day perishable supply of food. Extra food for stored in the garage, LPA observed moldy strawberries in the garage refrigerator . The FM disposed of the expired food immediately. Additionally, LPA observed the following postings: facility license, grievance procedures, personal rights, Ombudsman poster, visitation policies, and current menu. Continued on LIC 809 C.

Age-appropriate toys, games and books were observed for client’s recreation time. The facilities outside grounds (front yard, backyard) were also inspected and were found to be clean, well maintained, and free of observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space; all exits, and walkways were free from obstruction. Per Facility Manager there are no guns or weapons on facility grounds. The facility has an operable smoke detector located throughout the facility. The carbon monoxide detector is operable and located in the kitchen. Fire extinguishers are properly charged, serviced, and located in the kitchen and entry. The medications are centrally stored inside of a locked hall closet. The First Aid Kit is complete and kept in the hall closet. The facility has a one vehicle that is used to transport clients to appointments and recreational activities. The vehicle is operable, good repair , and the registration is current. At 9:46 AM LPA observed the staff bathroom and client licensee was not in compliance with Title 22 California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80088(e)(1) The regulation is stated as follows: … (1) Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to automatically regulate temperature of hot water delivered to plumbing fixtures used by clients to attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C). The water in the staff bathroom measured 129.3 degrees Fahrenheit. The water in the client bathroom measured 126.3 degrees Fahrenheit. The FM adjusted the water temperature during the inspection. LPA tested the water again at 01:23 PM. The water in the staff bathroom measured 106.1 degrees F. and water in the client bathroom measured 97.7 degrees F. At 9:50 AM LPA observed the client and staff bathrooms did not have the required trash can lids. The facility will be cited for Title 22 CCR 80088(f)(1) … All containers, including movable bins, used for storage of solid wastes shall have tight-fitting covers kept on the containers; shall be in good repair… At 10:00 AM LPA observed client bedroom #3 was not clean. The bedroom was unsanitary, had trash, clothes and various other debris covering the floor dressers. The furniture in the room was stained, the bed linens were observed to be unkempt and pillowcases were missing. The FM stated the room has not been cleaned because the clients will not let staff enter. The FM provided pillowcases at the time of inspection and cleared the debris from the floor. The facility will be cited for Title 22 CCR 80087(a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors; (Continued on LIC 809 C)

and Interim Licensing Standards ( ILS) 87088(c)(1). The licensee shall provide and make readily available to each child the following furniture, equipment and supplies necessary for personal care and maintenance of personal hygiene: (1) An individual bed maintained in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillow(s) which are clean and in good repair. LPA also observed portable dresser staked on top of each other creating a safety Hazzard for clients. The FM stated the clients stacked the dressed that way and refused to have the new dresser in the room. LPA observed a new portable dresser in the hallway. The FM removed the stacked dresser from the room at the time of inspection. At 11:00 LPA observed the facility did not have locked containers in which clients can store their contraceptives. The FM stated the staff lockers will be converted and used for the storage of client contraceptives. The facility will be cited with a technical violation Interim Licensing Standards ( ILS) 87075(b)(1)(A) The licensee shall provide the child with a locked container in which to store their contraceptives and ILS 87075(b)(1)(A)(1) The licensee shall provide the child with a locked container in which to store their contraceptives… Due to time constraints, LPA will return to complete the inspection at a later date. Based on observations made during the inspection, deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager Iyonna Matthews.

Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute S1 had inappropriate text messages with C4. investigation_findings: 13On March 20, 2023 at 1:23pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Future Stars Facility Manager-Iyonna Matthews, to deliver the finding for the above stated allegation. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility on April 4, 2022 at approximately 3:20 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. The investigation included interviews with three staff (Staff #1 [S1], Staff #3 [S3] and Staff #4 [S4]), three foster youth (Child #1 [C1], Child #2 [C2], Child #4 [C4]), and two County Social Workers (CSW#3, and CSW#4). One confidential witness did not respond to LPA’s request for an interview and therefore was not interviewed. In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On March 25, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging facility staff member (Staff #1 [S1]) had inappropriate text messages with group home minor (Child #4 [C4]). Specifically it was reported over 30 inappropriate text messages between S1 and C4 were obtained. CCL obtained and reviewed the copies of text messages and Instagram messages allegedly sent between S1 and C4. Confidential interviews and review of the Instagram messages provided to CCL could not confirm or dispute they were from ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

narrative:
record review could not confirm or dispute this allegation. CCL received three allegations alleging staff (Staff #2 [S2]) caused injuries to a client (Child #1 [C1]) while in care, staff (S2) slapped a client (C1) while in care, and staff (S2) spits at a client (C1) while in care. Specifically it was reported C1 had bruises caused by S2. Confidential interviews provided conflicting statements as to S2, causing injuries, slapping and spitting at C1. At least one confidential witness provided statements confirming these allegations but was unable to provide any specific information as to when, where, or other details of the alleged incident or incidents, or when C1 was observed to have bruising caused by S2. Record review revealed a confidential interview acknowledged hearing of staff (unknown who) hitting C1 but not witnessing the incident. Additional confidential interviews deny these allegations reported feeling safe and not being harmed while in care. CCL also received an allegation alleging staff (Staff #2 [S2]) isolated a client (Child #1 [C1]) while in care. Confidential interviews provided conflicting statements regarding C1 being isolated. Confidential interviews stated C1 would often be sent to C1’s room so staff would not have to deal with C1. Additional confidential interviews stated that C1 would only be sent to C1’s room as a time-out to help redirect C1 when C1 was having behavior issues. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute C1 being isolated. An additional allegation alleging staff (Staff #2 [S2]) financially abuses a client (Child #1 [C1]) while in care was received by CCL. Specifically it was reported that S2 takes money from C1’s account. Confidential interviews reported that C1 is unaware of how much money is in C1’s account and therefore does not realize when S2 uses money from C1’s account for personal purposes. Additional confidential interviews reported that C1 needs assistance with managing C1’s money and therefore S2 helps when C1 is purchasing items using C1’s money. Record review revealed C1 was provided with both weekly and clothing allowances which were documented. Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute that the money used from C1’s account was not also used by S2 for personal purposes. CCL received an allegation alleging staff (unnamed) do not properly supervise minors while in care. Confidential interviews and record review provided conflicting reports of supervision in the facility. Confidential interviews were not able to provide specific details or a date of any instance where there was a lack of ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

supervision by staff however reported that residents come and go from the facility without being reported as AWOL. Additional confidential interviews reported residents are supervised and any absence from the facility is reported to all appropriate and required parties. Confidential interviews reported that staff check on residents throughout the day at various times. Additional confidential interviews reported staff seldomly check on the residents. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute this allegation. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations alleging Staff (Staff #2 [S2]) inappropriately touched a client (unknown which client) while in care, staff (S2) caused injuries to a client (Child #1 [C1]) while in care, staff (S2) slapped a client (C1) while in care, and staff (S2) spits at a client (C1) while in care, staff (S2) isolated a client (C1) while in care, staff (S2) financially abuses a client (C1) while in care, and Staff (unnamed) do not properly supervise minors while in care, may or may not have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights to Future Stars Facility Manager-Iyonna Matthews.

narrative: On March 28, 2023 at 9:07 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jessica Peete met with Facility Manager Iyonna Matthews. The purpose of today's visit is to clear a Type B deficiency cited during an annual inspection on 03/03/2023. The deficiency, initially cited during an annual visit on 03/03/2023, have been cleared. No deficiencies observed or cited during this visit. Exit interviewed conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager, Iyonna Matthews.

Regarding the allegation that staff yells at minors, at least one confidential witness provided statements that the allegation was true. Other interviews provided information that confirmed the allegation was true but was unable to provide any specific information as to when, where, or other details of the alleged incident or incidents. Other confidential interviews and evidence gathered revealed that staff does not yell at minors in care but will use redirection when situations with clients escalate while other interviews did not witness or hear staff yelling at minors in care. Regarding the allegation that staff was rough with minors in care, one confidential witness provided statements confirming these allegations but was unable to provide any specific information as to when, where, or other details of the alleged incident or incidents. Other confidential interviews stated that they had not witnessed or heard of any minors being handled roughly in care. Regarding the allegation that youth are doing drugs and drinking at the facility, confidential interviews provided statements that minors may use substances when they are absent from care, but that alcohol and drugs are not used within the facility premises by minors in care. Other interviews provided information that confirmed the allegation was true but was unable to provide any specific information as to when, where, or other details of the alleged incident or incidents. Regarding the allegation that staff encourages minors to physically fight at least one confidential witness provided statements and evidence confirming these allegations. Other interviews provided information that confirmed the allegation was true but were unable to provide any specific information as to when, where, or other details of the alleged incident or incidents. While other interviews did not witness or hear staff encouraging minors in care to physically fight. Regarding the allegation to that staff call minor names, at least one confidential witness provided statements and evidence confirming these allegations. Other interviews provided information that confirmed the allegation was true but were unable to provide any specific information as to when, where, or other details of the alleged incident or incidents. Other confidential interview denied that staff calls minors in care names. Next page...

Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations alleging that staff yells at minors, staff was rough with minors in care, youth are doing drugs at the facility, youth are drinking alcohol at the facility, staff encourages minors to physically fight, and staff call minor names, may or may not have occurred. However, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute these allegations; Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided. A copy of the report was given to Future Stars Facility Manager, Iyonna Matthews.

narrative:
Confidential interviews also reported that hospital staff called the facility the evening C1 was released and informed staff (S3) that C1 should have been picked up at 3:00 PM from the hospital. Additionally, a confidential witness interview reported that C1 was driven to the facility by hospital staff at 10:40 PM and dropped off at the facility. Confidential documents obtained as part of the investigation show that C1 was discharged and transported back to the facility by the hospital. Per review of the facility Program Statement/Plan of Operation regarding transportation arrangements, it states the following: “Future Stars Youth Services Inc stipulates that the staff on duty and that is on call are mainly responsible for children and non-minor dependents transportation when needed.” Additionally, a confidential interview reported that the facility vehicle was on site the night C1 was returned to the facility by hospital staff and confirmed that C1 was not picked up by facility staff. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met based on confidential interviews and document reviews. Staff did not provide transportation to a minor (C1), resulting in the minor (C1) being left at the hospital. Therefore, the allegation is substantiated. The Department has determined that the licensee did not follow their program statement, specifically the terms regarding the transportation arrangements for clients in care. The facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6 Plan of Operation, 80022(a)(b)(10)(k). (a) Each licensee shall have and maintain on file a current, written, definitive plan of operation. (b) The plan and related materials shall contain the following (10) Transportation arrangements for clients who do not have independent arrangements (k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. The facility did not ensure C1 was provided transportation when C1 was discharged from the hospital. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were given and explained to Iyonna Matthews.

and C2 trying to hit S1 with a stick when they (C1 and C2) returned. Confidential interviews reported that clients are allowed to have cell phones unless the use of a cell phone is prohibited by the County Social Worker ( CSW) or court order. Confidential interviews reported at the time of the incident; C2 did not have cell phone privileges. Confidential interviews reported that S1 took a cell phone away from C2. C2 then hit S1 in the head and placed their arm around S1’s neck. Confidential interviews reported that C1 and C2 hit S1 and threw multiple items at S1, striking S1 in the left arm. A confidential interview reported that C1 hit S1 after S1 hit C1 on the hand. Confidential interviews reported that staff (S1 and S2) did not hit C1 or C2. A confidential interview reported that S2 tried to de-escalate the situation. LPA received conflicting information regarding the use of restraints. A confidential interview disclosed that restraints are used at the facility as a last resort, and any use of restraints is documented on a Special Incident Report. A review of the incident report and another confidential interview did not mention the use of restraints on C1 or C2. It was unclear whether the staff (S1 and S2) used or did not use restraint, and rather the incident report that the Department received was missing some information regarding restraint. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff speaks inappropriately to minors in care. It was alleged that S1 threatened C1 during the incident on 02/09/2023. Confidential interviews reported hearing loud voices and staff yelling, but the interviews did not reveal what was said. A confidential interview reported that S1 threatened to hurt C1 physically. A confidential interview also noted that S1 could not speak because C2 had their arm around S1’s neck. Confidential interviews also reported that S1 and S2 did not threaten, curse, or say anything inappropriate to C1 and C2. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and document review, the allegations that staff engaged in a physical altercation with minors in care and staff speaks inappropriately to minors in care may have occurred. However, the allegations are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were given and explained to Iyonna Matthews Facility Manager

deficiencies.description:
Plan of Operation, 80022(a)(b)(10)(k)         (a) Each licensee shall have and maintain on file a current, written, definitive plan of operation... The plan and related materials shall contain the following ...(k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, and document review, the facility did not ensure C1 was provided transportation which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will provide proof that staff will be retrained on the program statement regarding the transportation arrangements for clients in care. The licensee shall include the date and time the training will take place. In addition, to include how this deficiency can be avoided in the future.

narrative:
Regarding the allegation that staff inappropriately touched a minor, all interviewed parties denied any inappropriate touching and have not seen staff touch any client inappropriately. Other confidential information received reported that the allegation was true. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Regarding the allegation that staff encouraged other minors to fight a minor while in care, one confidential witness provided statements confirming this allegation but was unable to provide any specific information as to when, where, or other details of the alleged incident or incidents. Other confidential interviews stated that they had not witnessed or heard of staff encouraging other clients to fight a minor while in care. Regarding the allegation that staff caused injuries to a minor while in care, two confidential witnesses provided statements confirming this allegation but was unable to give the exact date and time of when the incident occurred. Other confidential interviews with staff and other clients stated that they have not seen or witnessed injuries to minor in care. Regarding the allegation that staff demonstrated inappropriate forms of discipline, all interviewed parties confirmed that staff does not use inappropriate forms of discipline. During a file review and based on confidential interviews, client has a history of client and destructive behaviors and often goes to their room to regulate. Staff assist uses appropriate de-escalation techniques. Regarding the allegation to that staff made inappropriate comments towards a minor, three confidential witnesses provided statements and evidence confirming these allegations but were unable to provide any specific information as to when, where, or other details of the alleged incident or incidents. Other confidential interviews denied that staff makes inappropriate comments towards a minor. Regarding the allegation to that staff spit on a minor, all interviewed parties confirmed that they have not seen or heard staff spit on a minor. Other confidential information received reported that the allegation was true. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. (Next Page..)

Regarding the allegation that staff mishandled a minor’s personal funds, all interviewed parties stated that they have not seen or heard a staff mishandle a minor’s personal funds. During a record review of the allowance logs, all clients receive weekly allowances and are signed with both staff and client signatures upon receiving or removal of funds. Regarding the allegation that staff mishandled a minor while in care, two confidential witness provided statements confirming this allegation but was unable to give the exact date and time of when the incident occurred. Other confidential interviews with staff and other clients stated that they have not seen staff mishandle a minor while in care. Regarding the allegation that staff are denying minors access to food, all interviewed parties stated that staff did not deny minors access to food. After a review of documents and interviews, staff had to lock up snacks due to a client throwing food at the facility but never denied snacks to clients in care. On April 4th, 2023, LPA Ng did a walkthrough of the facility and observed sufficient snacks and food. Regarding the allegation that facility does not have comfortable accommodations, all interviewed parties stated that facility would remove small picture frames and the TV remote due to client’s property destruction. All interviewed clients stated that the facility had comfortable accommodations. On April 4th, 2023, LPA Ng did a walkthrough of the facility and facility to have comfortable accommodations. Regarding the allegation that staff choked a minor while in care, one confidential witness provided statements confirming this allegation but was unable to give the exact date and time of when the incident occurred. Other confidential interviews with staff and other clients stated that they have not seen staff choke a minor while in care. Regarding the allegation that staff threatened a minor while in care, two confidential witness provided statements confirming this allegation but was unable to give the exact date and time of when the incident occurred. Other confidential interviews with staff and other clients stated that they have not seen staff threaten a minor while in care. (Next page..)

Although, the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that staff inappropriately touched a minor, staff encouraged other minors to fight a minor while in care, staff caused injuries to a minor while in care, staff demonstrated inappropriate forms of discipline, staff made inappropriate comments towards a minor, staff spit on a minor, staff mishandle a minor’s personal funds, staff mishandled a minor while in care, staff are denying minors access to food, facility does not have comfortable accommodations, staff choked a minor while in care, and staff threatened a minor while in care. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute these allegations; Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided. A copy of the report was given to Future Stars Facility Manager, Iyonna Matthews.

narrative: During investigation confidential interviews stated that C1 instigate fights with other clients in care that result in verbal altercations and staff intervention. Confidential interviews further stated that there have been multiple verbal and physical altercations involving C1 where C1 is identified as the person who starts fights with peers. Confidential interviews also stated that staff intervene and redirect all clients specifically C1 due to ongoing behaviors. Another confidential interview supported the statements that C1 initiates fights with other clients and added that C1 has been physically aggressive towards staff, and social workers as well. Confidential interview added that CSW is aware of C1’s behaviors but CSW does not know when C1’s statements about C1’s current placement are true or not true due to C1’s history. Another confidential interview stated that C2 hit C1 multiple times in the head with a closed fist and when C1 asked for help staff did not stop C2 from hitting C1. C2 could not be reached for comment regarding the allegations. Other confidential interviews maintained that staff intervene and stop fights among clients in care and there were no concerns reported. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegations. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that minors engaged in a physical altercation with C1 in care, and that staff did not intervene in a physical altercation between C1 and other clients in care, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights will be emailed to Head of Service, Tabitha Lopez.

Regarding the allegation mentioned above, confidential interviews alleged that staff did not address a concern with a medication for C1. *Continued on LIC 9099-C*

narrative: information from confidential interviews alleged that staff did not prevent C1 from engaging in self-harming behaviors which resulted in C1 breaking a facility window with a brick and being put on a 51/50 hold. Details from confidential interviews allege that C1 sustained an injury from the broken window. Details from other confidential interviews alleged that C1 used a rock to break the window. Confidential witnesses could not confirm if C1 intended to self-harm themselves on purpose and there were no additional witnesses. Regarding the allegation that minor brought drug paraphernalia onto the facility grounds, information from confidential interviews alleged that upon a return from an unauthorized absence, C1 brought drug paraphernalia into the facility. There were no witnesses to confirm that C1 brought drug paraphernalia into the facility. Details from confidential interviews detail that staff has procedures in place to ensure that clients do not bring drug paraphernalia into the facility. Staff will communicate expectations with clients, and clients are aware that drugs are not allowed on facility grounds. Regarding the allegation that staff did not report an incident involving a minor, information from confidential interviews alleged that staff did not report an incident involving a minor at the facility who was absent from care. Confidential interviews detailed that C1 was at the facility for less than a month but was known to be chronically absent without permission or be out on 51/50 holds. Confidential interviews detailed that staff would contact law enforcement when a client is absent from care. Details from confidential interviews stated that staff will report incidents involving minors by documenting on incident reports or making law enforcement contacts. Records reviewed showed that incident reports involving minors were submitted. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations that staff did not prevent a minor from engaging in self-harming behavior, minor brought drug paraphernalia onto the facility's grounds, and staff did not report an incident involving a minor, may or may not have occurred. However, it is not supported or proven by evidence. LPA received inconsistent information and varying details regarding the above allegations. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute these allegations; Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided. A copy of the report was given to Future Stars Facility Manager, Iyonna Matthews.
investigation_findings: 13On August 18, 2023 at 1:50 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, met with Future Stars Facility Manager, Iyonna Matthews, to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. LPA Carmen Escobar conducted an inspection of the facility on September 1, 2022 at approximately 3:55 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. The investigation included interviews with three staff (S1, S2, and S3) and four out of four foster youth (C1, C2, C3, C4). In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On August 23, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received three allegations alleging that staff did not prevent a minor from engaging in self-harming behavior, minor brought drug paraphernalia onto the facility's grounds, and staff did not report an incident involving a minor. Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent a minor from engaging in self-harming behavior, *Continued on next page 9099-C*

narrative: There was lack of witnesses and information received to support the allegation that C1 was inappropriately restrained. The interviews that were provided to the LPA were not consistent regarding the allegation of a personal rights violation. Based on interviews and record reviews the allegation that staff (unknown name) inappropriately restrains C1, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Ronnie Lusk.
investigation_findings: 13On January 17, 2024, at 9:15 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegation. LPA met with Ronnie Lusk. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility on February 15, 2023, at 8:20 am and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Four of the four children (C1, C2, C3, C4), four staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff (unidentified) inappropriately restrains C1. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 was not inappropriately restrained by any staff. Confidential staff interviews reported that when C1 leaves the facility absent without leave (awol), staff will verbally give C1 directives but C1 refuses to follow verbal directives of staff. Confidential staff interviews reported that no staff has ever placed C1 in a hold to prevent C1 from leaving the facility without permission. Confidential staff interviews reported that when C1 leaves the facility without permission staff will just follow all protocols of a client awol. Other confidential information received stated that the allegation was true. Continued on next page

narrative: altercation. According to confidential information, a video taken by one of the clients that has since been deleted, revealed staff using profanities directed at C2. According to confidential information obtained, S1 admitted to saying “if I did not care about you, I would have let them fuck you up” towards C2. Additionally, S2 was heard saying “you should have kept your fucken mouth shut” towards C2. According to confidential information, S1 and S2 were temporarily suspended as a result of this incident. Based on interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegation that staff’s behavior posed a risk to a minor while in care, more specifically that Staff # 1 (S1) and Staff # 2 (S2) had cursed and used profanities towards Client # 2 (C2) during an altercation between clients in care is substantiated. This posed an immediate health and safety risk to the child placed in care. The facility is being issued a citation for violations of the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5, Version 5, Section 87072(c)(16) Personal Rights. See attached LIC 9099D for cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided.

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights
To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or
unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, 
threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including………………. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
Confidential interviews and information obtained corroborated allegation that staff’s behavior posed a risk to a minor while in care, more specifically that Staff # 1 (S1) and Staff # 2 (S2) had cursed and used profanities towards Client # 2 (C2) during an altercation between clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility Manager Stated that both Staff # 1(S1) Staff # 2 (S2) no longer worked at this facility and that staff have since been retrained on Client Personal Rights. Proof of training will be provided by the POC date.

narrative:
On April 14, 2023, at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Jessica Peete and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis conducted an announced Pre-Licensing Inspection and Component II & III meeting. The Licensee listed above submitted Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) relocation application. Presently there are no clients in care at the proposed new location. The Pre-Licensing inspection was conducted with Program Director Danette Seay. The facility is a single-story home with four bedrooms, one to be used as a staff office, two bathrooms, and one mental health office. The bedrooms will be arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room, and there will be one client per bed. The bedrooms are not yet furnished; per the Directors statement new furniture will be purchased. The Director was advised that all Individual beds must be in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses, and pillows. LPA observed adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. LPA was unable to test the hot water as the gas line has not been turned on. The Director was advised that the hot water should measure within 105 degrees Fahrenheit and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. and located throughout the facility. Fire extinguishers are properly charged. The following deficiencies were observed: Gas not turned on. The dining room is not yet furnished. Refrigerator missing. There wasn’t a two-day supply of perishable foods, and a week of nonperishable foods. Client’s beds, mattress, bedding, dressers, desk, and linens are missing. Kitchen appliances, pots/pans, plates, bowls, cups, and utensils are missing.

Non-slips rugs in the showers and in the home. Lock boxes for contraceptives and medication are missing. Recreational activities for the clients are missing. Landline and internet services are not connected. Required postings (CCL Complaint hotline number flyer, Foster Care Bill of Rights, Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster, Facility Sketch, food menus, Ombudsman Poster, Grievance Procedures, and weekly client activities) Dining table is missing. Staff office missing desk, computer, and a chair. Mental Health office missing desk, computer, and a chair The following LIC forms are needed: Applicant Information LIC 215 Designation of Administrative Responsibility LIC 308 Affidavit regarding Client/Resident Cash Resources LIC 400 Financial Statement LIC 403 Financial Information Release and Verification LIC 404 Budget Information LIC 420 Personnel Report LIC 500 Personnel Record LIC 501 The following supportive documents are needed: Partnership Agreement/Articles of Incorporation Verification of Administrator /Director Qualifications

Monthly Operating Statement LIC 401 Copy of Administrator Certificate Component III Orientation provided to licensee which included information regarding incident reporting procedures, including those specific to law enforcement contacts; facility, client and staff record requirements; application of prudent parent standards and client personal rights. The facility was advised that the plan of corrections, is due Friday, May 5, 2023, prior to the close of business day. After the above stated deficiencies are corrected in-person, a final file review will be conducted, and the facility will be submitted for licensure. Pre-Licensing inspection, review of application was completed, and a copy of this report was given to the Program Director during the exit interviewed.

narrative:
On August 1, 2023, at 9:47 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete arrived unannounced to Future Stars Short Term Therapeutic Program (STRTP); to conduct a post-licensing inspection. LPA met with the Facility Manager Iyanna Matthews and Head of Services Tabitha Lopez. LPA began and tour of the physical plant at 10:00 AM. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean; free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Books, games and art supplies were observed for client’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguishers is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. Sharp knives, medications, and a complete first aid kit are kept locked and secure in the entry way hall closet. Cleansers and chemicals are locked in the staff office. The facility has one staff office, one mental health office, and 3 bedrooms. The bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room. Each bedroom has two beds with one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The facility has two bathrooms for clients' use. The bathrooms were in working order. The hot water in both bathrooms measured between 105 degrees and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The Facility does not have a pool or any open bodies of water Per Facility Managers, there are no firearms or weapons on the facility grounds. ( Continued on LIC 809 C)

At 11:000 AM LPA began the review of Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Interventions, and Core Therapeutic Services. All documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. At 12:30 PM LPA reviewed five staff files ( S1-S5). All staff have current CPR/First aid certification. S2 did not have the Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances on file. Per Title 22 California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80019(e)(2) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing, or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption…. The license was issued a Technical Violation. LPA was able to access Guardian Background Check System and observed S2’s documents (LIC 508, LIC9182, and Driver’s license) were uploaded to Guardian on 04/03/2023. Per the facility managers statement S2 has cleared background. As there are known issues with the Guardian system; LPA will follow-up with Licensing Program Manager (LPM) and LPM will follow up with Guardian to verify clearances. LPA observed that S2 and S3 did not have the required health screening forms. Per Title 22 CCR 80066(a)(10)… Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (10) A health screening… S3 and S4 did not have the required Tuberculosis (TB) documents. Per Title 22 CCR 80066(a)(11)… Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (11) Tuberculosis test documents… Technical violations were issued; per Facility Managers statement the staff files are in the process of being updated licensee was instructed to follow up with LPA and provide the documentation. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, the LIC 811, and appeal rights was provided to Head of Service Tabitha Lopez

On August 18th, 2023 at 1:50 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, conducted a collateral visit at Future Stars Youth Services Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of delivering investigative findings. On Tuesday October 24, 2023 at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Peete arrived unannounced to Future Stars Youth Services Short Term Residential Therapeutic Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Mental Health Specialist Ronnie Lusk to deliver an amended LIC 9099 report originally issued on 09/12/2023.

However, the type of insect that caused the bites was not identified. Confidential interviews reported that the facility had mosquitoes in the backyard and received regular pest control services that treated the outside grounds and inside the facility upon request. Additional confidential interviews reported that all the clients had new mattresses, and the bed linens were washed weekly. In addition, LPA toured the facility with the Facility Manager and observed that all the client bedrooms had clean mattresses in good repair, with protective coverings. LPA did not observe bed bugs or any other insects inside the facility. Based on confidential interviews and facility records, the allegation that the staff does not ensure the facility is free of bed bugs is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and given to Case Manager Ronnie Lusk.
investigation_findings: 13On November 30, 2023, at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced visit to Future Stars Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program ( STRTP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. On 08/22/2023, LPA Peete inspected the physical plant, and no immediate safety hazards were observed. LPA obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. LPA also conducted interviews with clients (C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) and Staff (S1, S2, and S3.) LPA Peete attempted to interview client 1 (C1) but was unsuccessful due to C1’s refusal to be interviewed. On 08/17/2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that the facility staff did not ensure the facility was free of bed bugs. It was alleged that C1 had bed bug bites. Multiple confidential interviews denied seeing any bed bugs inside of the facility. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was the only client who reported being bitten by bed bugs. Pertinent documentation from the investigation shows that C1 received medical treatment for insect bites.

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that if clients choose to skip meals, staff will encourage clients to eat and document food refusals. Confidential interviews reported that clients can access the kitchen and prepare food with staff supervision. Confidential interviews reported only breakfast and dinner are served at the facility. In addition, a confidential interview reported that staff does not provide breakfast or lunch, and clients are responsible for preparing those meals. Other confidential interviews also reported that clients are served breakfast, lunch, dinner, and snacks daily according to the posted food menu. LPA toured the facility with staff and observed the facility's food menu is posted in a central location accessible to clients, staff, and visitors. LPA observed two days of perishable and seven days of non-perishable food in the kitchen cabinets and refrigerator. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegation that staff are not providing nutritious meals to foster youth (C1-C6) is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and given to Case Manager, Ronnie Lusk.
investigation_findings: 13On November 30, 2023, at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced visit to Future Stars Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. On 08/22/2023, LPA Peete inspected the physical plant, and no immediate safety hazards were observed. LPA obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. LPA also conducted interviews with clients (C1, C2, C4, C5, and C6) and Staff (S1, S2, and S3). LPA Peete attempted to interview client 3 (C3) but was unsuccessful due to C3’s refusal to be interviewed. On 08/17/2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that staff are not providing nutritious meals to foster youth (C1-C6). It was alleged that the STRTP was not providing breakfast or dinner. Confidential interviews reported that C1 and other clients (C2-C6) would choose to skip meals but have the option for meal substitutions if the clients do not like the meal being served.

narrative: On 01/18/2024 at 4:11 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Peete arrived unannounced at Future Stars Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) . The purpose of the visit was to amend the LIC 9099 and LIC 9099-C reports originally issued on 01/12/2024. A copy of this report was given to Case Manager Ronnie Lusk.

Confidential interviews reported that S2 and C1’s authorized representative agreed that C1 could have a cell phone to be used as an incentive for good behavior. Confidential interviews and documentation show that S2 ordered and set the phone up on C1’s behalf. A confidential interview was also reported when the cell phone was set up; due to the C1’s age, parental controls were automatically installed on the phone. Confidential interviews disclosed that parental controls were installed unknowingly, and when S2 became aware of the situation, C1’s cell phone was factory reset. In addition, information obtained as part of the investigation shows that in order for the parental control application to be effective, S2 would need to install the application on their personal cellular device to monitor C1’s cell phone activity. Moreover, a confidential interview denied that S2 had parental control applications installed on their (S2’s) personal or business cell phones. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the allegation that staff (S2) is not allowing the client (C1) to have confidential telephone calls is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Head of Service Tabitha Lopez. This is an amended report of a report that was originally issued on 01/12/2024
investigation_findings: 13This is an amended report of a report that was originally issued on 01/12/2024 On January 12, 2024, at 9:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced visit to Future Stars Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. On 09/12/2023, LPA Peete inspected the physical plant, and no immediate safety hazards were observed. During the investigation, LPA obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. LPA also interviewed clients (C1-C6), staff (S1 -S3), and the County Social Worker. On 09/11/2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that staff (S2) is not allowing the client (C1) to have confidential telephone calls. It was alleged that S2 installed a parental control application on C1’s cell phone, allowing S2 to monitor C1’s cell phone usage. (Contineued on LIC 9099-C)

narrative: On Friday March 29, 2024 at 9:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Peete arrived unannounced to Future Stars Youth Services Short Term Residential Therapeutic Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Facility Manager, Tanicki Wallace to deliver a report. A copy of this report was given to the Facility Manager.

Another confidential interview denied staff verbally or physically abused clients in care and reported all staff and client interactions are professional and trauma-informed. The department also received an allegation that staff (S1) had inappropriate conversations with a minor (C2), and staff did not safeguard a minor's (C2) personal belongings. It was reported that C4 took C2's cell phone and found phone calls between S1 and C2. More specifically, it was alleged that the phone calls between S1 and C2 were exchanged outside of S1's regular working hours. A confidential interview witness interview reported C4 found text messages exchanged between S1 and C2. The confidential witness did not see the text messages and learned, second hand, from C4 that S1 offered C2 money to spy on other clients and a STRTP staff. LPA received inconsistent information to support the alleged misconduct. Although it was reported that S1 had inappropriate phone conversations with C2, LPA did not obtain additional statements from those who saw the text messages or witnessed the phone calls between S1 and C2. Other confidential interviews either denied the allegation or denied having any knowledge of S1 contacting C2 or other clients after hours to spy on clients and staff. In addition, confidential interviews disclosed that C1 did have S2's phone number. However, conversations between C1 and S2 were not inappropriate. C2 only contacted S1 when C2's roommate was "upset," or other clients were "out of control." Information from confidential interviews also reported that S2 was a good employee, and there were no concerns about S1's interaction with clients. Regarding the allegation, the staff did not safeguard C2's belongings, and LPA again received conflicting information to prove the allegation. A confidential interview denied that C2's cell phone was taken by C4 or any other clients in care. Another confidential interview reported that clients stole from each other but did not recall the alleged theft of C2's cell phone. Other confidential interviews reported clients could keep their items in the staff office and had access to personal lockers to store their property. Furthermore, a confidential interview reported that at the time C2 was in care, there were no reports of theft. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations Staff (S2) yelled at minor (C3), staff (S1) had inappropriate conversations with minor (C2), and staff did not safeguard minors (C2's) personal belongings are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Facility Manager, Iyonna Matthews. This is an amended report of a report that was originally issued on 03/28/2024

An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman at 9:00 am. LPA interviewed two children currently taking psychotropic medication at 1:00pm. No deficiencies being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Jamie Taylor Child Care Worker at 1:30pm. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton made an unannounced annual inspection on 3/7/22 at 9:00 AM and met with, Catherine Matthews, Executive Director, Jeffrey Beesley, Deputy Director and Ramzy Shehadeh, Program Director. All Gateway properties were inspected by LPA on 3/1/22. LPA did advise the agency that the inspection is being completed with the use of the CARE Tool. LPA Shelton conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. There were no clients present during the inspection due to school. LPA observed four bedrooms with both single and double beds in each room. Two bathrooms with soap, paper towels hygiene products and towels. LPA Shelton inspected and/or reviewed the following: · Postings of facility license and Personal Rights Poster were appropriately posted · Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were inaccessible and locked as required · Nonperishable Foods for one week and fresh perishable for foods two days minimum were present · Menu was present and posted · LPA observed a working telephone on the premises · Carbon monoxide detectors and Smoke Detectors were present and functioning · First Aid Kit was present and fully stocked as required · Common Room (living room) was available as was a separate room in each wing for privacy · Dining area with enough seating for clients in care was present and in good condition · Medication was centrally stored, locked/inaccessible. Centrally stored medication and log reviewed.

· LPA's reviewed five (5) client files. LPA verified that for staff that have been here longer than a year, the 40 Hours of annual training was also present · Trauma informed practices are implemented as needed (including specialty mental health services and extracurricular activities and social supports) per discussion with the administrator. narrative: while playing a boxing game. C1 missed the punching bag and punched the medal post behind the bag and fractured his hand. S6 was present at the time of the incident and had asked if C1 was OK, which he replied yes. S1, S4, S5 and C2 state that C1 refused to go to the ER because he did not want to wait for a long time. Staff called S4 who was the Resident Care Coordinator, and the on-call emergency contact that day. She asked to speak to C1 and asked how he was doing and if he wanted to go to the ER? S4 states that C1 did not want to go to the ER because of the wait so S4 advised staff to give him Ibuprofen and to use the first aid kit and put a splint on his hand. Staff did keep asking him throughout the weekend if he needed more Tylenol for the pain. That following Monday, March 13, 2023, S4 called C1s pediatrician to make an appointment, the soonest they could get him in was March 15, 2023. S4 states that C1 felt content knowing he would have an appointment with his doctor. C1 was seen on March 15, 2023, and had X-rays done which showed his right hand to be fractured. His hand was splinted up and a week later he had a cast put on. Regarding the allegations staff did not seek medical attention for minor in a timely manner, staff did not treat minor with dignity and respect and staff did not address a change in minor’s health condition, four out of nine confidential interviews stated that C1 refused to go to the ER because he did not want to wait for a long time. Seven out of nine confidential interviews stated that staff always show concern when it comes to client’s health and safety and if a client would insist on going to the ER, they would take them immediately. C2 states that staff treat all the clients with dignity and respect and take good care of them. He states that, “if C1 wanted to go to the ER, staff would have taken him.” C2 also states that he heard staff ask C1 if he wanted to go to the ER and C1 refuse to go. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report along with a copy of the appeal rights were provided to Ariana Gomez, Residential Counselor.

The Department received a complaint on January 23, 2025, regarding C1 being injured and not receiving medical attention in a timely manner. C1 was a client at Gateway-Palm house in 2023. No interviews were conducted. · Motor Vehicle was not present during inspection due to school. · LPA observed that the facility appeared to be free of vermin · LPA observed Locked Facilities included a shed with lawn equipment · LPA reviewed complaint procedures for clients. · Board Minutes were reviewed · Disaster Preparedness was updated and available for review, quarterly drills are completed and logged in a binder and there are disaster preparedness supplies available and verified by LPA · Staff training was in compliance · Criminal record clearances were verified by LPA and in compliance · Certified Administrators certificate was valid and current · Staff job titles/qualifications were verified along with the required 24 Hours of initial training. LPA verified that for staff that have been here longer than a year, the 40 Hours of annual training was also present · Trauma informed practices are implemented as needed (including specialty mental health services and extracurricular activities and social supports) per discussion with the administrator. The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: Administrator Certificate for Catherine Matthews is current and verified Fees have been paid and documentation was provided No citations were issued at the conclusion of the inspection. Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided to the facility.

The Department has investigated the complaint that a child was restrained inappropriately. Gateway’s Program Statement repeatedly establishes that they are a “hands off” program due to the residents needs to feel physically safe. Gateway does not train staff in the use of restraints nor allow staff to restrained clients. The staff involved in the incident was terminated. C1 stated that C1 keep pushing S1 to S1's limits, trash talking, and one thing led to another. C1 ran up to S1 and put his shoulder into S1. S1 then placed C1 in a headlock lock like you’re getting a knuckle noogie. C1 picked up the staff and then release the staff and the incident ended at that point. As a result of the interviews conducted, documentation reviewed and investigation conducted, the allegation that a child was restrained inappropriately is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Facility cited for violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 87095.00(d) General Provisions: All children placed in a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program have the right to be free from the use of restraints. An exit interview was conducted with Jeff Beesley and copy of the report and appeal right were provided. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton conducted a visit on 8/18/2022, and LPA spoke with Jeff Beesley, Executive Director to deliver findings of the investigation on the complaint allegation that a child was restrained inappropriately. LPA Shelton informed the complaint investigation included a tour of the home on 5/25/2022. The initial 10-day complaint inspection was conducted by the LPA, at the home on 5/25/2022 and LPA, requested Needs and Service Individual Treatment Plan, facility sketch and training records. Interviews were conducted by LPA Mary Shelton, which included C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, S1, S2 and the agency social worker between 5/25/2022 and 8/5/2022.

deficiencies.description:
87095.00(d) General Provisions: All children placed in a STRTP program have the right to be free from the use of restraints imposed as a mean of coercion, discipline, convenience, or retaliation by staff.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, C1 was restrained inappropriately by staff and the agency does not train nor allow staff to restrain clients, which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: An agency wide retraining on Gateway's Staff/Client Boundaries Policy from the Gateway Policies and Procedures were completed prior to 8/18/2022 documentation was provided to the LPA.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia on 03/03/2023 at 9:45 AM . This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Valencia met with Ramzy Shehadeh, Program Director and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed no child records and four (4) staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed no child’s psychotropic medications or medication records. LPA interviewed four (4) of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA did not interview any children that were under eighteen (18) or a ward of the courts that are currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Ramzy Shehadeh, Program Director. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Ramzy Shehadeh, Program Director.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced Case Management inspection at the facility and met with staff Brian Perrott and Program Director Ramsay Shehadeh, Executive Director Jeff Beesley who assisted with the inspection. CCL received an incident report dated 8/21/2023 concerning an allegation made by a client that a staff member (S1 - See Confidential Names List dated 8/29/2023) purchased one vape device for two clients, let them vape in the facility vehicle, and the staff vaped in the vehicle as well. The incident report stated a meeting with the staff would be held on 8/24/2023. LPA is conducting this Case Management inspection to learn what the outcome of this investigation is and to conduct additional investigation if necessary. LPA spoke with staff, Program Director, Executive Director and found that they conducted an internal investigation which consisted of them interviewing all clients. On 8/29/2023 S1 was terminated for this incident. Administration attempted to call S1 in on 8/23/2023, but S1 did not come in. S1 offered to do Zoom, and Administration accommodated this on 8/24/2023, however S1 did not attend. Administration asked S1 to come in again on 8/25/2023, S1 did not appear. Today, 8/29/2023, Administration sent out a Job Abandonment and Termination Letter. On this date, the facility is being cited for a violation of the Health and Safety Code Section 1558(a)(2), Conduct Inimical, which is detailed on the attached LIC809-D page. An exit interview was conducted with ED and PD and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left with them.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton made an unannounced Case Management - Annual Continuation inspection on 4/17/2024 and met with Jeffrey Beesley, Deputy Director and Ramzy Shehadeh, Program Director, who assisted with the inspection. LPA Shelton conducted a walk-through of the home inside and out. LPA did advise that today inspection was done using the Care Tools. LPA Shelton inspected and/or reviewed the following: · Postings of facility license and Personal Rights Poster were appropriately posted. · Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were inaccessible and locked as required. · Carbon monoxide detectors and Smoke Detectors were present and functioning. · First Aid Kit was present and fully stocked as required. · LPA observed the Grievance/Complaint Policy is posted as required. · Allowance binder was in compliance. · Common Room (living room) was available as was a separate room in the home for privacy. · Dining area with enough seating for clients in care was present and in good condition. · Clients bedrooms/bathroom. · LPA observed that the home's water was at required temperatures at all faucets within the home. · LPA inspected the Medication Log and the Controlled Medication Log for clients in care. · LPA observed that the facility was clean and maintained during the inspection and meal menu displayed.
