deficiencies.description:
Criminal Record Clearance 88019(a)(2): All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (1) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by a records review, interviews and observation. This poses an immediate risk to the health and safety to clients in care. The licensee did not comply with the section cited above when it was determined that 3 staff are working at the facility without a criminal record clearance, which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will ensure that the uncleared staff are no immediately stop working as of 4/25/25, until they get an eligable clearance. Norma Leon Romero will contact the Guardian today to verify what is missing for the clearance. Administrator and Norma will email LPA with a follow up no later than May 2, 2025.

narrative:
On February 7, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA's) Nicolette David and Winston Moroney conducted an unannounced Annual inspection at the facility at 10:00 AM. LPA met with Lisa Denbo Facility Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection of the facility. The STRTP’s Mental Health Program Application is approved. The STRTP has CARF accreditation that expires on 08/31/2024. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (8) ambulatory children ages 13-17 years of age. Currently, there are two (2) clients in placement. The facility is a 3- story house located in a residential neighborhood. It consists of 5 bedrooms (1 bedroom is located adjacent to staff office and is for Relief Staff). There are 4 1/2 bathrooms (2 bathrooms are located in the staff office), living room, dining room, kitchen, TV room, staff office and a clinician’s office. The 3rd floor is an attic which is used for a computer Lab and arts craft. The living, dining, kitchen and TV room are located on the first floor, along with outside laundry area and downstairs basement which is used for storage. LPA observed the facility license, facility sketch, COVID signage posters, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, visitation policies, emergency disaster plan and activity calendar posted by the front entrance of the facility. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom # 1, two twin beds, two dressers and closet Bedroom # 2 sleeps C-1, two twin beds, two dressers and closet Bedroom # 3, two twin beds, two dressers and closet. Bedroom # 4 sleeps C-2, two twin beds, two dressers and closet.

All beds are clean and in good repair. Bedding and sheets were sufficient. There is adequate supply of perishable and non -perishable food. There is 2 refrigerator being used and one freezer in the laundry room. The kitchen utensils, glasses and dishes were found to be in good condition Medications, first aid kit, all cleaning supplies and laundry detergent, sharp knives and client files are kept in a locked storage room inside the locked staff office. Hot water was tested and found to be within regulatory guidelines at 120' degrees Fahrenheit. Fire/earthquake drills are conducted once a month and kept in a log. The carbon monoxide/smoke detectors were tested and found to be in good working condition. The facility is equipped with a fire alarm system which is tested annually by local fire department. In the backyard of the facility, (LPAs) observed a pool with a locked fence surrounding it, and patio furniture. There is a separate detached structure in the backyard area that is being temporary use by an employee that works at the Boys Republic site. Interviews: LPA's interviewed 3 staff that included the Administrator , Supervisor and HR . There are currently 17 staff working at the facility. LPA interviewed 2 Clients. File Review: A review of 2 client flies and 6 staff files was conducted. Client files contained an original admission agreement. There are 2 clients currently taking medication. Files for clients currently taking prescribed medication contained all the required documentation such as the medical consent forms and authorizations. Overall, clients are provided adequate services in accordance with their needs and services plan and are being updated. Staff files contained criminal record clearances or exemptions and child abuse index check, job descriptions (except for the Administrator's file), required training and work evaluations. All documents were complete and signed by employee. All staff requiring training, including Mandated Reporter, Emergency Intervention, initial and annual training, was current. all adult individuals who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemption.

Operations Facility maintains a current, written plan of operation that meets licensing standards. Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conducts meeting to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least every month for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition port services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children with services to achieve permanency. On today's inspection, there are no citations assessed during this inspection. LPA was provided with Board Minute Meetings and staffs schedule/personnel report An exit interview was completed, and a signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative. .

On 09/09/2022 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted an unannounced follow up case management inspection at the above facility and met with Head of Service, Ellen Strickland. The purpose of the visit was to follow-up an incident reported to the Department on 08/18/2022 regarding a client (C1) who disclosed to facility staff that she snorted the medication administered to her on the night of 08/13/22. C1 also disclosed that she deliberately hid her medication between her lips and teeth, and then passed on the medication to another client C2 who admitted to snorting the medication on the night of 08/14/22 (see Confidential Names List LIC811 dated 09/09/22). During the inspection, LPA Silva conducted a tour of the facility, interviewed Head of Service regarding medication administration procedure, and reviewed clients' medication vs. medication records. LPA also interviewed four (4) staff members via telephone prior to today's inspection. All five (5) staff members confirmed that the facility’s protocol on medication administration is that clients take their medications in staff’s presence and that clients cough, blow and hold open their mouth and lift their tongue to ensure that medication was taken and swallowed. Based on interviews, staff S1 followed correct medication administration procedure. Staff is unsure of how C1 managed to hide and not swallow the medications she took on the nights of 08/13/22 and 08/14/22. Interviews with staff indicated that all staff who assist clients in medication administration received the proper medication training. Staff training on medication is given during initial training and is also part of their annual and in-service training. Interviews also indicated that additional training was given to staff members after the incident to ensure careful medication distribution and to prevent similar incidents from occurring. During medications vs. records review, LPA observed that C1 had missed doses of her medication but are not documented or explained on the Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR). A deficiency citation is issued , see LIC809D.. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC809D, LIC811 and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative.

On March 1, 2023 at 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez made a case management inspection to the facility and met Danielle Lopez, Assistant Supervisor . The purpose of the case management was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department regarding medication error Per the SIR, on 02/05/23 staff (S1) made an error distributing the wrong medication to client (C1) see LIC 811 (Confidential Names List). The nurse advised the staff on shift to monitor C1's behavior and for any possible side effects but did not anticipate any major concerns. C1's authorized representative was informed of the incident. S1 will be provided additional training by the nurse regarding medication distribution. Per Assistant Supervisor Lopez, S1 was given a verbal warning regarding the incident and had a virtual retraining on 02/07/23 regarding Medication Distribution and Administration. Section 80075(b)(5)(B) provides that once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 809D and LIC 811 were provided to the facility representative. A deficiency citation is issued to the facility per above section.

On March 30, 2023 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Ashley Ruacho and Pamela Silva conducted an unannounced case management inspection to the facility and met with Tanya Miller, Administrator. The purpose of the case management was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department regarding medication error. Per the SIR, on 02/25/23 staff (S1) made an error distributing the wrong medication to client (C1) (see LIC 811 Confidential Names List dated 03/30/23). The nurse advised the staff on shift to monitor C1's behavior and for any possible side effects but did not anticipate any major concerns. C1's authorized representative was informed of the incident. Medication training was provided to all staff on 03/08/23 but S1 was not present during the training. Since this was S1’s second error regarding medication distribution a write up was given. S1 will be provided additional medication training and shadow staff for 4-5 months before she can distribute medication again. During the inspection, LPA’s reviewed medication log vs medication packets, LPA’s also checked JV 220’s for all clients on psychotropic medication. No deficiency citation was issued during today’s inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

It was alleged that staff did not inform client of notice of removal, staff requested client’s removal prior to updating the Needs and Services Plan and staff prevented authorized persons from communicating with client. Confidential interviews reveal that an emergency CFT Meeting was held on 10/3/22 to preserve client’s placement. Client was in attendance and the emergency CFT meeting notes state in part that, “the identified client continues to meet criteria for placement in an STRTP and the level of care provided.” However, a 14-day notice of request for removal was submitted by the facility on the same day, without client’s knowledge. Staff explained that client was not informed of the removal request for client’s own safety and that it’s the policy of the facility not to inform clients of any planned removal for safety reasons. Staff explained that client was unable to commit to safety. There was no record found of any incident or safety issues involving the client during and after the CFT meeting to indicate the need for a removal request. There was no record found that the removal request was discussed with the client. The client’s NSP was not updated prior to the removal request. There was no record found showing that the client was offered an opportunity in the development of any transfer plan. The client became aware of the removal request after being informed by the client’s legal team during a scheduled court hearing. The client’s legal team informed staff of the need to speak to the client prior to the scheduled court hearing. The client’s legal team made several attempts to speak to the client, by phone calls and emails to staff, before and after the client’s court date. All attempts to speak to the client, through staff and the facility, were unsuccessful. There was no record found that client refused to speak to the legal team. Based on information obtained from confidential interviews and records obtained, the allegations are substantiated, based on the preponderance of evidence. The following deficiency citations are issued under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards – 87068.4(e)(2)(E)(1) and 87068.4(e)(2)(D) Removal and/or Transfer Procedures and 87072(c)(4) Personal Rights. These violations pose an immediate and/or potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. A Plan of Correction was discussed with the facility representative. Copies of the following were provided at the conclusion of the inspection: LIC 9099, LIC 9099-C, LIC 9099-D and LIC 811 Confidential Names dated 5/4/23. Appeal rights forms were provided and explained.

It was alleged that staff did not ensure sharp objects were inaccessible to client and staff did not provide client’s record to authorized person. Confidential interviews reveal that client had access to a compact mirror, which was an age and developmentally appropriate personal item used for grooming and make up. Although client has a history of self injurious behavior, there was no record found that such item was prohibited. Client used the compact mirror to engage in self injurious behavior while inside the bathroom, resulting in hospitalization. The client’s safety/crisis intervention plan was updated after the incident. Regarding the request for client’s record, the document not immediately provided by staff who explained to the requestor that information was being added to the document. The document was provided after a week. There was no evidence found that the facility refused to provide or was withholding client’s record. Based on information obtained, the allegations are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met. A copy of this report and the LIC 811 Confidential Names Form dated 5/4/23, were provided to the facility representative. Appeal rights forms were provided and explained.
investigation_findings: 13On May 4, 2023 at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a complaint inspection at the facility. LPA met with the facility representative named above. The purpose of the inspection is to deliver the findings for the above allegations. The investigation was conducted by LPAs Heriberto Perez and the undersigned LPA. On 11/2/22, LPA Perez conducted the initial complaint inspection at the facility and obtained the staff and client rosters, Needs and Services Plan (NSP), Incident Reports (IR) and Request for Removal. LPA Yamamoto conducted interviews with former and current staff on 3/6/23, 3/30/23, 4/11/23, 4/12/23, 4/26/23 and 4/28/23. Placement agency staff was interviewed on 4/24/23. Current clients in placement were interviewed on 4/11/23. LPA attempted to obtain statements from other related parties on 3/2/23, 4/10/23, 4/24/23 and 5/1/23; those attempts were unsuccessful. Additional records were obtained and reviewed by LPA Yamamoto on 3/2/23, 3/6/23, 4/24/23 and 4/28/23 which include, but not limited to the Child and Family Team (CFT) Meeting notes, Discharge Summary, Safety/Crisis Intervention Plan, Student Chronological Record, Behavior Report, Intake Report and Admission Agreement.

deficiencies.description:
The facility shall notify the child of the transfer or removal in a manner that is consistent with trauma-informed practices.
The facility shall work with the child to develop a trauma-informed plan to support a successful transition to the child’s next placement. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Staff did not inform client of notice of removal. This violation poses an immediate and/or potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall develop and maintain a written plan to ensure that this regulation requirement is met. The plan must be submitted to the Department by email on or before the plan of correction date.

deficiencies.description:
Requests for placement change shall not be initiated prior to the first update of the child’s Needs and Services Plan.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Staff requested client’s removal prior to updating the Needs and Services Plan. This violation poses an immediate and/or potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall develop and maintain a written plan to ensure that this regulation requirement is met. The plan must be submitted to the Department by email on or before the plan of correction date.

deficiencies.description:
The licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: To have communications to the facility from their relatives and/or authorized representative(s) answered promptly and completely.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Staff prevented authorized persons from communicating with client. This violation poses an immediate and/or potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall develop and maintain a written plan to ensure that this regulation requirement is met. The plan must be submitted to the Department by email on or before the plan of correction date.

narrative: Continue from page 1 . . . The staff stated that during a group meeting an altercation took place with clients in the facility. The staff stated that the meeting was to discuss an argument between two clients at school. The staff stated that one client became aggressive toward the other client and the staff was redirecting the client but the client was not receptive to the staff redirection. The staff stated that the client left the room where the meeting was taken place and went to the kitchen but was followed by one of the staff, the staff stated that the client got a fork and attempted to use it against other clients. The staff stated that they were redirecting the client to give up the fork and creating space between the clients. One staff stated that she attempted to take the fork from the client but the client got loose from the staff grasp. The staff stated that the fork was obtained from the client when another client grabbed and restraint the aggressor client. The staff stated that the Law Enforcement was called when the incident was getting out of control. The confidential interviews indicated that the clients were having a group meeting to discussed the altercation between two clients at school but one of the client became upset and began to hit others in the facility. The confidential interviews indicated that the staff was redirecting the aggressive client and was creating space between the clients. The confidential interviews revealed that the aggressive client went to the kitchen and got a fork while the other clients went outside the facility to create space. The confidential interviews revealed that the aggressive client was being follow by one of the staff and was being redirected to give up the fork but the aggressive client went outside. The aggressive client was used the fork against another client and resulted in injuries (scratches) on the client. The confidential interviews revealed that another client help to restraint the aggressive client and the staff was able to get the fork from the aggressive client before law enforcement got to the facility. The confidential interviews indicated that the staff was always with the clients and were redirecting the aggressive client and attempted to take away the fork from the client. Based on the interview and records reviewed the allegation is found unsubstantiated. Although the allegation have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegation was due to neglect or lack of supervision. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On May 10, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Heriberto Perez conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with Danielle Lopez, Assistant Supervisor. LPA also reviewed documents including but not limited to Client's Need and Service Plans, Special Incident Reports (SIR) and Law Enforcement investigation report. It was alleged Minors engaged in a physical altercation with each other at the facility resulting in injuries.

An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

On January 5th, 2024, at 8:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with the above representative. The purpose of the case management was to follow up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department which stated a client (C1) had fallen down the staircase. (See confidential name list LIC 811). Per the SIR, C1 fell down the stairs and sustained bruises on one of their legs, along with scrapes and swollenness on their cheeks. The injuries were stated to be a result of the extent of the fall. The medical report suggested youth to refrain from skipping any meals, stay hydrated, and to sit in a squat position when they feel like fainting. LPA Ashley Ruacho conducted in person interviews with the Administrator (AD), Case Worker (CW), and client 2 (C2), and client 3 (C3). C1 was on AWOL status and LPA was unable to obtain an interview with them. Proper actions were taken by the facility, and it was revealed that C1 has a medical history of fainting spells. LPA toured the facility and inspected the facilities food supply, there was a surplus of both perishables and non-perishable foods. Based on information provided in interviews LPA observed that the incident was not a result of lack of supervision or lack of food supply. No deficiency citation was issued during today’s inspection. No further follow-up is required. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

On December 6th, 2023 at 3:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with the above representative. (See confidential name list LIC 811). During the visit LPA conducted in person interviews with the Administrator (AD) , Case Worker (CW), and client 2 (C2), and client (C3). LPA also took a tour and checked food supply with AD. LPA needs to conduct additional interviews and document review for this incident. No deficiency citation was issued during today’s inspection. Further follow-up is required. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

On February 22nd, 2024, at 9:30AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an annual/required inspection. LPA met with Assistant Supervisor, Danielle Lopez. LPA and the Assistant Supervisor toured the facility. LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: · LIC 500 Personnel and Client Roster · LIC 610 C Emergency Disaster Plan · Board of Directors report and Program Statement · Employee Grievance Policy/ Grievance Procedures · Emergency Preparedness: Disaster and Mass Casualties Drills · Emergency Evacuation Routes · Facility Monthly Activities Calendar · Emergency Intervention Plan · Complaint Procedures The facility was in full compliance with 7 applicable areas of the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools for Children’s Residential Licenses. Annual compliance review consisted of the following domains: Physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness plan, emergency intervention, staffing, and client records. Community Care Licensing (CCL) focuses its efforts on three priority areas: prevention, compliance, and enforcement. There are two (2) fire extinguishers throughout the facility, all fully charged and all last serviced on November 3, 2023.

The facility is a 3- story house located in a residential neighborhood. It consists of 5 bedrooms (1 bedroom is located adjacent to the staff office and is for extra storage space). There are 4 1/2 bathrooms (2 bathrooms are in the staff office), a living room, dining room, kitchen, TV room, staff office and a clinician’s office. The 3rd floor is an attic which is used for storage and donations. The living, dining, kitchen, and TV room are located on the first floor, along with the outside laundry area and downstairs basement which is used for storage. LPA observed the facility license, facility sketch, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, visitation policies, emergency disaster plan and activity calendar posted by the front entrance of the facility. The facility has a working telephone that is accessible to clients and staff. All passageways and grounds were free of any obstructions. The medications and cleaning solutions were locked inside the cabinets in separate storage rooms. There was perishable foods enough for 3 days and non-perishable foods enough for client's consumption for more than a week. Each bedroom has two twin beds with clean sheets and linens. There were drawers and closet space in each bedroom for client use. The hot water temperature was tested and was in working order. At the time of this inspection the facility was observed to be clean, safe, and in good repair. The facility has a Honda Odyssey minivan used to transport clients. The vehicle has an active insurance policy. Facility provides core services and supports to children as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition port services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children with services to achieve permanency. For this review, four (4) Los Angeles County placements, and one (1) Riverside County placement clients were selected for the sample to assess the level of care and services they receive. Additionally, LPA reviewed six (6) staff files for compliance with Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Requirements. LPA also conducted an interview with one staff member as they were the only staff at the facility during the time of this inspection. Clients in the facility were unable to be interviewed due to being at a culinary course off site. An exit interview was conducted. LPA provided the facility representative above a signed copy the LIC 809 and LIC 811 reports. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of this inspection.

On January 29, 2025, at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez conducted an un-announced annual/random inspection to the facility. LPA met Administrator, Tanya Miller. The facility is a three-story building with 4 bedrooms and 4 1/2 bathrooms located in a residential neighborhood. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to eight (8) ambulatory children ages 13-17 years of age and Non-Minor Dependents. Currently, there are two (2) clients in placement. Physical Plant LPA conducted the inspection accompanied by Administrator, Miller. The facility is a three-story building with 4 bedrooms and 4 1/2 bathrooms located in a residential neighborhood. LPA observed the following at the time of the inspection. The posted license, Emergency Disaster Plan, Foster Care Ombudsman's information and Youth's Personal Rights, Grievance Procedure, and Mental Health Program Approval. The facility has a staff office and therapist offices, a living room/dayroom, and a laundry room. A maximum of two (2) beds in each bedroom. All bedrooms have closet and drawer spaces for the clients clothing. The water temperature was tested (117 degrees Fahrenheit) and within the temperature allowed by regulation. All cleaning solutions were observed locked in cabinets. There was extra linens and hygiene supplies in the cabinets. All medications were stored locked inside a room in the staff office. The First Aid kit was complete. There were adequate perishable foods for at least 2 days and non-perishable foods for at least 7 days in the facility. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were working. The pool was locked and surrounded by a fence. All indoor and outdoor passageways were unobstructed. Client Records LPA reviewed two (2) client records. All client records are available to licensing to review. The current clients in the facility are less than 30 days in placement. The client records have some of the required forms.

Staff Records LPA reviewed five (5) staff records. Staff records contain documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training. All staff subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and cleared. Emergency Intervention Plan The facility has written emergency intervention plan. The staff records have current proof of training. Disaster Preparedness Plan The facility has a disaster and mass casualty plan of action and conducts disaster drills at least quarterly. The facility maintains register of clients, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Operations The facility maintains a register of clients available upon licensing staff request. The client records are centrally stored in a room inside the staff office. The board minutes meeting was available for review. The board of directors conducts meetings at least on a quarterly basis to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility has written complaint procedures to file a complaint for the clients and/or their representatives. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of LIC 809 and LIC 811s were provided to the administrator. No deficiency citations were issued at the time of the inspection.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli made an unannounced complaint investigation at the facility and met with Deputy Director Timothy Dimick, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings on the above allegation. During the course of the investigation LPA Bertoli interviewed 2 staff and the complainant, and reviewed records. The records and the interviews indicated that although the Needs and Services Plan was prepared for client C1 (see LIC 811 form dated 02/03/22), it was not sent for signature of the Authorized Representative until it was requested by them in August 2021. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility did not properly complete the Needs and Services Plan. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Title 22 deficiencies were cited and Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with Deputy Director Dimick.

deficiencies.description: 87068.2  Needs and Services Plan (f) The licensee shall obtain written approval from ... the child’s authorized representative prior to implementing the child’s needs and services plan. This requirement is not met, as evidenced by: Based on LPA interviews and record review, the Facility did not ensure that the client's Needs and Services Plan was properly completed, which is a potential Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility stated that all files have been reviewed for completion.  New clinical staff are also being trained on proper procedures.  Facility will send training and protocol to CCL by 2/10/22.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge conducted an annual/required inspection at the above facility. LPA McCambridge met with Administrator, Tim Dimick. The facility has not been operating since August of 2021, so the facility has been vacant. Therefore, LPA McCambridge did not use the Inspection Tool during today’s inspection. Please note that the facility has been in communication with CCL regarding their current status, and the department is working closely with the facility. LPA McCambridge toured the facility inside and out and found the facility to be safe, clean, and in good repair. The refrigerator and freezer were empty due to the facility closure. LPA toured the upstairs, and there were a total of 5 bedrooms. All bedrooms were empty except for dressers, mattresses, and bed frames. The Administrator confirmed that their maintenance person visits the facility to ensure it remains in good standing. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli met with Clinical Director Robin Hausserman at the facility for the purpose of completing an Annual/Required Inspection. Prior to the inspection a COVID pre-screening call was made, and there were no current cases, known exposures, or symptomatic persons at the facility. The facility is currently inactive and has no placements or staff. Greenacre Homes is in the process of hiring staff and will accept placements as soon as they meet the staffing requirements. Due to their inactive status, only the inspection of the facility and the Physical Plant section were completed (per LPM Isabel Mendoza). No Title 22 deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left with the facility. Due to technical difficulties, the original signed copy of this report was deleted in error and a second copy was sent for signature.

investigation_findings: 13On 05/20/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge conducted a follow-up complaint investigation at the facility and met with Administrator Timothy Dimick. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation LPA McCambridge conducted staff and client interviews. During the interviews there were conflicting statements with the initial report. According to RP and staff, staff knew nothing about the incidents that occurred, but have ensured that staff will intervene and provide adequate supervision to ensure clients safety. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that there was inappropriate interactions between children in care; therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with staff and no deficiencies were cited. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

facility_name: GUIDING LIGHT HOME FOR BOYS INC.
narrative: Confidential witness interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that all shifts are not covered properly; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed that there are two to three staff scheduled per shift. In addition, confidential interviews revealed that STRTP utilizes the 3:1 ratio at the STRTP as stated in the STRTP’s program statement. Confidential interviews also revealed that none of the clients have missed any medical or court appointment due to staffing. If a client missed an appointment it was due to the client refusing to go to an appointment. Confidential interviews also revealed that all clients’ needs are being met and clients are taken to shop for necessities. Confidential interviews disclosed to LPA that the facility is cleaned daily, deep cleaning is done on Fridays and Saturdays and facility does not have an issue with cleanliness. LPA Hamilton conducted a health and safety tele-inspection on 10/01/2020 and did not observe any issues regarding the cleanliness of the STRTP. It was also alleged that Staff #2 (S2) worked from 3am on 09/20/2020 to 10pm on 09/21/2020. Confidential interviews and document review disclosed that S2 did work from 3:30am 09/20/2020 to 10pm on 09/20/2020 due to two other staff not reporting for their scheduled shifts. S2 worked along with Staff #1 who came in from 9am – 10pm and STRTP was working within the correct ratio. Based on confidential interviews and document review, the allegation that the facility has insufficient staffing to meet clients’ needs, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator, Shugella Weaver-Thomas for signature. The signed report will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On December 9, 2020 at 3:20 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Hamilton met with Guiding Light Home for Boys (STRTP) Administrator, Shugella Weaver-Thomas to deliver the findings for the above stated allegation. Due to COVID-19 a tele-inspection was conducted via Facetime. During the investigation, LPA Hamilton conducted interviews with three of five clients, four staff, and Administrator. LPA Hamilton conducted a health and safety tele-inspection of the STRTP on October 1, 2020 and no safety concerns were noted. LPA obtained and reviewed the facility’s 15-minute log, placement agreements, client appointment schedule, and staff schedules. LPA Hamilton attempted to interview Client #3 and Client #4 but both clients declined to interview. On September 22, 2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information stating that the facility has insufficient staffing to meet clients’ needs. It was alleged that there is usually only one staff working the floor per shift, clients are missing appointments, facility is unkept and clients are not taken to shop for necessities.

facility_name: GUIDING LIGHT HOME FOR BOYS INC.
narrative:
On June 11, 2021 at 9:25 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Hamilton conducted an annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on 06/11/2021. LPA was met at the facility by Facility Manager Cathy Gooden. A physical plant inspection was completed at 9:42 AM and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. Some required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. LPA observed that the facility did not have a visitation policy posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored in locked closet next to the kitchen. Licensee did not have provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured to be 107 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Administrator is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one therapist, five facility managers and 11 direct care staff. that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Licensee obtained Mental Health Certification with San Bernardino County. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF International. The Accreditation is valid through December 31, 2023. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0.00.

LPA discussed the following with the facility manager: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. Based upon the inspection of facility records and interviews with staff and clients, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Personnel Files are maintained at the corporate office in Riverside. LPA observed that staff #1 (S1) did not have criminal record and child abuse index clearances or exemptions. LPA reviewed six staff files. A review of six client records was also completed on this date. Client and staff interviews were conducted and did not reveal any health and safety concerns. Based on file reviews S1 did not have any proof of criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Regulation 80019(e)(3) Criminal Record Clearance. S1 has been employed by the facility since May 16, 2021. Immediate civil penalties are being assessed for $500.00. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to facility manager.

facility_name: GUIDING LIGHT HOME FOR BOYS INC.
narrative: interviews confirmed C1 slept in the loft of the facility on 10/11/2021 due to fear of sharing a room with C2. Confidential interviews reported when C1 woke up a gun was being held to C1’s head. Confidential interviews and record review confirmed C1 sleeping in the loft. Confidential interviews and record review revealed C2 was removed from the facility on 10/11/2021 after which C2 contacted residents looking for a backpack which was found a few days later with a handgun in it. Record review and confidential interviews reported the handgun was turned into the local police department. CCL received and additional allegation that Minor (Child #1 [C1]) was being bullied by another minor (Child #2 [C2]) in care. Confidential interviews provided consistent statements of C2 intimidating residents and bullying residents. Confidential interviews confirmed C1 sleeping in the loft on the morning of 10/11/2021 due to C1’s fear of sharing a room with C2. Confidential interviews provided consistent statements of the facility environment being hostile while C2 resided in the facility due to C2’s bullying and intimidating the residents and staff. Based on confidential interviews the allegations Minor (Child #2 [C2]) threatened another minor (Child #1 [C1]) with a firearm and Minor (Child #1 [C1]) was being bullied by another minor (Child #2 [C2]) in care are substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87072 (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9 as applicable, and ILS standard 87072 (d)(11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and form corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including , but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Guiding Light Home for Boys Administrator (ADM) Cathy Gooden.
investigation_findings: 13On January 26, 2022 at 10:20am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Guiding Light Home for Boys Administrator (ADM) Cathy Gooden, to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility on October 20, 2021 at approximately 12:30 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. The investigation was conducted by LPA Strickland and included interviews with five of six foster youth (Child #1 [C1], Child #3 [C3], Child #5 [C5], and Child #7 [C7]), two Staff (Staff #1 [S1] and Staff #2 [S2]), Riverside Out of Home Institutions (OHI) investigator, and County Social Worker (CSW). One confidential witness did not respond to LPA’s multiple requests for an interview and therefore was not interviewed. In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On October 12, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging Minor (Child #2 [C2]) threatened another minor (Child #1 [C1]) with a firearm. Confidential interviews provided consistent statements of C2 making threats to residents in care and C2’s statements of having a gun. Confidential ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights: (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9 as applicable.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review the facility did not ensure Child #1 (C1) was in a safe living environment when a handgun was used to threaten C1 and later found on the facility which posed an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
C2 was removed from the faciltiy on 10/11/2021.  

ADM stated that unannuonced random room checks have incresased and will continued to be completed to ensure saftey of residents.

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights (d)(11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and form corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat...l functioning: 

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews the facility did not ensure Child #1 (C1) was free from intimidation and ridicule when C1 was bullied by Child #2 (C2) which posed a potential  Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
ADM had an accountability meeting to address bullying with all residents.  ADM spoke with staff about anti-bullying after the incident. 

In addtion ADM will do an all staff training on anti-bullying to include signs, prevention, de-escaltion, and documentation.  ADM will provide LPA with outline and staff signatures by POC date of 2/4/2022 via email.

facility_name: GUIDING LIGHT HOME FOR BOYS INC.
narrative: Regarding staff not adequately maintaining minors' medication records allegation, a confidential interview denied staff does not adequately maintain clients’ medication records. Confidential interview stated that medication administration records were checked and audited daily. Another confidential interview denied staff does not adequately maintain minors' medication records. Confidential interview disclosed that a staff member did not complete the medication record and resigned the same day. Additional confidential interview did not provide information regarding medication records being adequately maintained. LPA was unable to contact an additional witness due the phone being disconnected. Regarding staff are not administering medication as prescribed, a confidential interview denied staff were not administering medication as prescribed. Confidential interview disclosed that medications were administered in the morning and evening time and all medications were administered as prescribed. Another confidential interview stated that all staff were trained on how to administer medications. Additional confidential interview received medication but was not sure if it was administered as prescribed. A confidential witness stated not witnessing a prescribed medication not being administered. LPA was unable to verify whether medications were given without prescription due to a confidential witness not being available. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that the staff does not adequately maintain minors' medication records, staff are not administering medication as prescribed may have occurred, however, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with LIC 811 to Guiding Light Home for Boys Clinical Director (CD).
investigation_findings: 13On March 16, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Guiding Light Home for Boys to deliver investigative findings for the above allegation involving the group home (GH) and clients listed in the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated 03/16/2023. LPA met with of the group home Clinical Director (CD). On August 18, 2022, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging staff does not adequately maintain minors' medication records, staff are not administering medication as prescribed. On August 24, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at the GH to initiate investigation and met with Clinical Director (CD) Adri Vermilion. LPA interviewed clinical director (CD) and staff 1 (S1). On February 8, 2022 LPA interviewed Facility Administrator (FA), clients 1, and 2 (C1 and C2). Additionally, on March 6, 2023 LPA interviewed clients 3 and 4 (C3 and C4).

facility_name: GUIDING LIGHT HOME FOR BOYS INC.
narrative: Regarding facility is operating out of ratio, it was specifically stated that “S1 has been left alone in charge of five residents”. A confidential interview agreed that facility operated out of ratio but for a short period of time. Confidential interview added that there were some difficulties with staffing. Another confidential interview disclosed that five clients were left with one staff on September 25, 2023 from 8:00 AM to 2:30 PM. Confidential interview added that clients became uncontrollable after a misunderstanding. Additional confidential interview maintained that there were five clients to one staff in the facility. A confidential witness disclosed there was only one staff at the home with five or six clients and could not remember the exact number of clients. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that facility was operating out of ratio Therefore, the allegation is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87065.5 (a)(1). Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios (see LIC 9099 D). A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Guiding Light Home for Boys Clinical Director (CD).
investigation_findings: 13On March 16, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Guiding Light Home for Boys and met with Clinical Director (CD) to deliver investigative finding for the above allegation involving the group home (GH) and clients listed in the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated 03/16/2023. On September 27, 2022, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging facility was operating out of ratio. On October 3, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at the GH to initiate investigation and met with Clinical Director (CD) Adri Vermilion. LPA interviewed clinical director (CD) and staff 1 (S1). On February 8, 2022 LPA interviewed Facility Administrator (FA), clients 1, and 2 (C1 and C2). Additionally, on March 6, 2023 LPA interviewed clients 3 and 4 (C3 and C4).

deficiencies.description: 87065.5 (a)(1): Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios (a) In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: (1) During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:Based on confidential interviews and record review, facility did not ensure the staff/child ratio is met. There 5 or more clients left with one staff. This poses a potential  health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility immediately hired additional direct care staff and hired on-call staff with ability to respond in a timely manner when needed. Facility will continue to ensure there is adequate staff at 7 am to 10 pm and all hours that need coverage.

facility_name: GUIDING LIGHT HOME FOR BOYS INC.
narrative: Guiding Light Home for Boys Inc., STRTP to initiate the complaint and met with Teresa Lara, Floor staff (S1) who granted LPA access into the facility. A health and safety inspection were conducted, and no immediate health or safety concerns were observed. Additionally, LPA interviewed one staff and one client, and gathered documents from clients’ files. On March 23, 2023, at 10:15 AM (LPA) Beal met with Administrator Cathy Gooden to continue an investigation of the above allegations. LPA reviewed the clients and staff files. LPA Beal interviewed one staff and four clients at the facility. On April 11, 2023, LPA Beal conducted one interview and review client and staff files for STRTP #2. In regard to facility emotionally abused minors while in care, confidential interviews did not provide any information that staff would emotionally abuse the clients. Facility staff denied abusing clients. LPA received inconsistent information. In regard to facility staff yelled at a client, made inappropriate comment and threaten a client in care, it was disclosed that a staff made a comment in reference to a court date, threatened a client and it was heard staff screaming in the background during a phone call. Confidential interviews revealed there were no inappropriate comments made to clients. LPA didn’t receive additional information. LPA was unable to interview a witness. Facility staff denied these allegations. Regarding the facility staff are not adequately supervising clients, confidential interviews stated that staff were always around, however, it was indicated that a client goes to someone else's room in the group home to hang out and that is against the group home policy. LPA was unable to receive additional information. In regard to facility staff did not ensure that minors had access to the internet at the facility, it was specified that staff cut the WIFI in the home for one client while the other clients can access to the interview from their devices directly. Confidential interviews revealed the internet was always assessable to all clients and majority of the clients have their own devices with internet access. LPA wasn’t unable to verify the information. In regard to the facility is odoriferous, confidential interviews state the facility only smells when a client decides to smoke in the facility. Other confidential interviews denied the house was odoriferous. LPA was unable to verify this information during safety inspection. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff emotionally abused clients while in care, facility staff made an inappropriate comment to C6 while in care facility staff threatened C6 while in care, facility staff yelled at C6 while in care, facility staff are not adequately supervising clients while in care, facility staff did not ensure that clients had access to the internet at the facility and facility is odoriferous, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are Unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were discussed and given to Administrator Georgina Doyle.

facility_name: GUIDING LIGHT HOME FOR BOYS INC.
narrative:
On July at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal conducted an annual inspection. The facility name is Guiding Light for Boys Inc. Short Term Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was met by Facility Administrator Georgina Doyle. On July at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal conducted an annual inspection. The facility name is Guiding Light for Boys Inc. Short Term Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was met by Facility Administrator Georgina Doyle. A physical plant inspection was completed at 10:25 AM and included the following checks: The facility is a two- story home with 5 bedrooms with one bedroom converted to the mental health office, 2 bathrooms. Also, on the second level there is a loft area that is used as a lounging area. Downstairs is the family room, living room, bathroom, laundry, kitchen, and an office space, The clients’ bedrooms consist of two people per bedroom which include closet space for each client and a dresser for each client. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and no observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. A basketball court is outside the facility for the client use.All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. Some required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights form, menu, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Continued on LIC 809-C

Continued from LIC 809 Medications and sharp items are locked and centrally stored in locked closet next to the kitchen. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured to be 110 degrees. Four staff files were reviewed. One staff has an expired CPR/1st Aid certification. The certification expired 11/30/2022. Six client files were reviewed, and all client files are missing Needs and Services plans from March 2023 to July 2023. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. A copy of this report was reviewed and copy was provided to Administrator Georgina Doyle.

narrative: Regarding facility staff calling youth inappropriate names allegation, a confidential interview denied staff called youth inappropriate names. The confidential interview stated that staff had a good rapport with C1 and was not certain staff called C1 inappropriate names. Another confidential interview disclosed being called inappropriate names by staff. Confidential witness did not hear staff called C1 inappropriate names, however, confidential witness was unable to tell if the allegation occurred or not. In regard to staff threatening C1. It was specifically alleged that staff member had threatened C1 with a gun. Confidential interview denied hearing S1 threatening C1. The confidential interview disclosed that S1 had good rapport with C1 but was not sure about the conversation between S1 and C1. A confidential interview disclosed that S1 mentioned being a gun holder and did not use it to threaten. A confidential witness did not hear C1 being threatened by S1. The confidential witness did not receive any reports of a threat to C1 hence, could not tell if the allegation was valid. Finally, it was alleged that S1 wanted C1 to sell marijuana for them and in exchange C1 to have marijuana to smoke. Confidential interview denied engaging with C1 a marijuana conversation. The confidential interview disclosed that C1 did not know if the alleged allegation happened. Another confidential interview stated that S1 mentioned selling marijuana in exchange for free marijuana. Confidential interview disclosed that C1 was not sure if S1 was joking or not. A confidential witness did not hear a conversation between S1 and C1 to sell marijuana. Confidential witness disclosed that S1 had good rapport with clients and was not sure such conversation occurred. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that S1 called C1 inappropriate names, S1 threatened C1, S1 wanted C1 to sell marijuana for them and in exchange provide C1 with marijuana to smoke, may have occurred, however, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with LIC 811 to Guiding Light Home for Boys administrator Georgina Doyle.

narrative: On March 4, 2024 at 1:30PM LPA Peete arrived unannounced to Guiding Light Home for Boys Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). At 2:00 PM, assisted by staff Brandee Ramirez, LPA completed a health and safety inspection. During the health and safety inspection LPA observed the following: At 2:00 PM LPA observed one hole in the living room wall and one broken kitchen cabinet. At 2:10 PM while inspecting the three client bedrooms (B1-B3) LPA observed B1 and B2 had wall damage. B1 was observed to have one hole in the wall. B2 was observed to have multiple holes in the wall as well as damage (holes) to the bathroom and bedroom door. LPA also observed B2's shared client bathroom needed additional cleaning and had a broken door frame with exposed nails. While inspecting B3, LPA observed a broken dresser drawer still in use and writing on the wall. The dresser drawer was replaced and removed from grounds during the inspection. At 2:30 PM LPA observed the shared client bathroom, located in the upstairs hallway, required additional cleaning. LPA also observed the client bathroom had missing light bulbs, the glass shower door was off the track, and broken window blinds. AT 3:00 PM LPA observed damage to the door of the Administrator office. Per the Administrator statement work orders for the above-mentioned damage have been placed. Based on observations the licensee is not incompliance with Title 22 California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80087(a) deficiencies are being cited; see LIC809 D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Administrator, Georgina Doyle.

facility_name: GUIDING LIGHT HOME FOR BOYS INC.
met_with: Georgina Doyle Administrator, Adrianna Vermilion Program Director
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Raymond Canal conducted a case management inspection on 5/9/24 at 11:04 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 23 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 23 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 5/9/24). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, and Crisis Intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Canal observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Georgina Doyle and Program Director Adrianna Vermilion.

facility_name: GUIDING LIGHT HOME FOR BOYS INC.
narrative: On July 1, 2024, at 12:07 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete met with Guiding Light Home for Boys Administrator Georgina Doyle to discuss deficiencies regarding reporting requirements. During a complaint investigation information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL) revealed that the licensee did not adhere to the reporting requirements. An incident related to a minor smoking marijuana on facility grounds occurred on 02/11/2024; the licensee did not provide CCL with a written report of the incident until 03/08/2024. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22 California Code Regulations 80061 (b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements (b) … a written report …shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. (1) Events reported shall include the following (E) Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Administrator, Georgina Doyle.

deficiencies.description: (b) … a written report …shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. (1) Events reported shall include the following (E) Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. This requirement is not met, as evidenced by:Based on the record review, the facility did not submit the Special Incident Report (SIR) to the Department within the required timeframe which This poses an potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will provide proof of staff retraining and/or a detailed training plan on reporting requirements which will also include ways to avoid this deficiency in the future.

narrative: Confidential interviews also reported that S1 did not redirect the minors or confiscate the substance. In addition, S1 admitted to being in the backyard while the clients engaged in marijuana use and acknowledged they (S1) did not dispose of the marijuana. Instead, S1 reported they (S1) passed the marijuana back to the client smoking and provided no reason for their (S1’s) inaction. Additionally, the investigation revealed that staff informed the Administrator of S1’s conduct, but the Administrator did not immediately report the incident to the Program Director. Information from confidential interviews further reported the STRTP conducted an internal investigation; after a review of the facility cameras, screen shots of those images were provided to LPA, a client was observed smoking, not S1. The internal investigation noted staff (S1-S3) violated the facility policy regarding “appropriate supervision of youth” and failed to submit a Special Incident Report. Furthermore, a confidential interview reported that S1’s employment was terminated when another client at the other facility located at 25123 Middlebrook Way, Moreno Valley, CA 92555, alleged and later recanted that S1 provided clients with pills and marijuana. Based on confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the allegation staff was contributing marijuana to the delinquency of minors is substantiated; the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited with a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS )87065.2 (b)(1) Personnel Duties (b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties (1) supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, appeal rights, and the deficiencies report LIC 9099-D were explained and given to Administrator Georgina Doyle.

narrative:
In regard to the allegation that the facility has insufficient staffing to meet the clients’ needs, it was alleged that some staff work alone when facility is at full capacity and clients are not being taken to their appointments. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that staff have had to work shifts alone if another staff calls off or quits but this does not happen often; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed that this STRTP does not have an issue with staffing or staff calling off causing staff to work over their shift. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided regarding clients missing appointments due to staffing. Confidential interviews disclosed that Client #3 may have missed an appointment due to staffing; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed that none of the clients have missed any appointments due to staffing. In regard to the allegation that the food served to clients is not of the quality nor quantity to meet the clients’ needs, it was alleged that the food purchased for the facility is cheap and does not taste good. It was also alleged that there is not enough food to satisfy the clients’ hunger. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that there is always enough food in the facility and that shopping is done weekly by the administrator. In addition, if the STRTP needs something the administrator will purchase it from the store, or have it delivered. Confidential interviews also revealed that the clients are provided three meals per day and snacks. Also, clients are able to prepare food if necessary and have access to food at all times. Confidential interviews revealed that the STRTP is provided with frozen turkey rolls (turkey with stuffing in the middle) from the Department of Education free lunch program. During the tele-inspection on 10/01/2020, LPA Hamilton observed the cabinets, refrigerator and freezers to be adequately stocked. Other confidential interviews disclosed that sometimes there is not enough food in the STRTP and that staff may have to go to the other site to get food. Also, during the tele-inspection LPA did not observe any expired foods. A confidential interview also revealed that clients wish for name brand foods. In regard to the allegation that the facility is not being cleaned regularly, it was alleged that due to lack of staffing the facility is not being cleaned regularly. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that the cleaning of the STRTP has suffered due to lack of staffing; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed to LPA that the facility is cleaned daily, deep cleaning is done on Fridays and Saturdays and facility does not have an issue with cleanliness. LPA Hamilton conducted a health and safety tele-inspection on 10/01/2020 and did not observe any issues regarding the cleanliness of the STRTP.

In regard to the allegation that the facility van is not in good repair, it was alleged that the van is in bad shape, the check engine light is on, runs rough, and is worn and dirty inside. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that van makes noise and slows down while driving it; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed that the van has been recently repaired, is kept clean and receives maintenance regularly. Also, confidential interviews and document review revealed that van had recently been vandalized by clients and has received the required maintenance. Based on confidential interviews and document review, the allegations that the facility has insufficient staffing to meet clients’ needs, the food served to clients is not of the quality nor quantity to meet the clients’ needs, the facility is not being cleaned regularly and the facility vehicle is not in good repair, may have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator, Shugella Weaver-Thomas for signature. The signed report will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On December 9, 2020 at 3:27 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Hamilton met with Guiding Light Home for Boys (STRTP) Administrator, Shugella Weaver-Thomas to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. Due to COVID-19 a tele-inspection was conducted via Facetime. During the investigation, LPA Hamilton conducted interviews with three of five clients, four staff, and Administrator. LPA Hamilton conducted a health and safety tele-inspection of the STRTP on October 1, 2020 and no safety concerns were noted. LPA obtained and reviewed the facility’s 15-minute log, placement agreements, client appointment schedule, and staff schedules. LPA Hamilton attempted to interview Client #3 and Client #4 but both clients declined to interview. On September 22, 2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information stating that the facility has insufficient staffing to meet clients’ needs, the food served to clients is not of the quality nor quantity to meet the clients’ needs, the facility is not being cleaned regularly and the facility vehicle is not in good repair.

narrative:
However, C1’s CSW and CCL were not notified within 24 hours of the incident as regulated in Title 22. Confidential interviews and document review revealed that C1’s CSW was made aware of the incident 12/10/2020 via an outside party and CCL was notified on 12/11/2020 when the allegations were received via a complaint report. In addition, the Special Incident Report (SIR) dated 12/08/2020 regarding C3’s attempted suicide was not sent to C1’s CSW and LPA Hamilton until 12/15/2020. Administrator stated that she was aware of the client being 5150’d on 12/08/2020 but was not aware that it was due to client attempting suicide. The Administrator did not learn of the attempted suicide until C3’s IEP meeting on 12/08/2020 at 2pm. Administrator also stated the SIR was completed on 12/08/2020 but she was not included on the email and the SIR had only been sent to the acting facility manager after the incident. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that the staff did not properly report an incident involving C3. The allegation is therefore substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06 Section 80061(b)(1)(E): Reporting Requirements. The facility failed to report to CCL and C1’s CSW/authorized representative an incident of self-harming within the timeframes outlined in Title 22 Regulations. This poses immediate and potential health, safety or personal rights risk to children in care. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided via email to Administrator Shugella Weaver-Thomas for signature. The original signed report will be placed in the facility file.

Confidential interviews disclosed that S2 was informed of C3 attempting suicide and S2 did nothing; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed that another client was able to intervene and stop C3 from harming themselves prior to S2 intervening. A Confidential interview disclosed that S2 was in the upstairs restroom at the time of the incident tending to an injury and another client was able to remove the curtain from around C3’s neck just prior to S2 entering the bedroom. Confidential interviews disclosed that once S2 was in the bedroom, S2 was briefed by the other clients as to what had transpired with C3. Based on confidential interviews and document review, the allegation that S2 did not protect C3 from harm while in care, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator, Shugella Weaver-Thomas for signature.
