narrative:
On March 12, 2021 at 1:05 PM. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Hamilton conducted a case management tele-inspection for Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 (STRTP) and met with Administrator Shugella Weaver-Thomas via Facetime. Due to COVID-19 a tele-inspection was conducted. The purpose of the inspection was to address issues and concerns regarding incidents that occurred on or around October 28, 2020 and December 15, 2020. It was discovered through information received via confidential interviews that Client #1 (C1) was pushed by Staff #4 (S4) at the STRTP on 10/28/2020 when C1 became upset because S4 did not allow C1 to cook food at 1:00 AM. C1 began to destroy items in the STRTP. It was reported that S4 observed C1 heading towards the fire extinguisher, S4 jumped in front of the fire extinguisher and pushed the side of C1’s shoulder. S4 pushed C1 to prevent C1 from retrieving the facility’s fire extinguisher. The facility is being cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1 (09/16/2020), Section 87072(d)(10) Personal Rights. Per confidential interviews, S4 pushed C1. This poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk to children in care. It was further discovered through confidential interviews that on 12/15/2020, the facility was out of ratio. It was reported that on this date at 3:00 PM, there were two staff on duty at the STRTP with six clients. One staff left the facility with one client going to the hospital at 3:35 PM. This staff did not return to the facility until 7:51 PM and left again at 8:55PM to go back to the hospital to supervise C1. During the time the staff was away from the facility, the facility was not operating within the direct care staff/child ratio as stated in the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards. One staff was left to supervise and manage four clients between the hours of 6:30 PM to 7:51 PM and five clients from 8:55 PM – 10:00 PM. Therefore, the STRTP is being cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1 (09/16/2020), Section 87065.5 (a)(1) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. Per confidential interviews, the STRTP did not ensure the STRTP was properly staffed with the correct Staff/Child ratio during the above

listed time frames. This poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk to children in care. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, Confidential Names List, LIC 811 and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator Shugella Weaver-Thomas for signature. The signed reports will be placed in facility file.

food because C1 was hungry. S4 denied C1’s request to cook due to the time and STRTP rules so C1 became upset and started to destroy facility property. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that S4 bumped into C1, C1 pushed S4 and then S4 put C1 into a chokehold; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed S4 did not strangle or put C1 into a choke hold. Confidential interview did reveal that S4 did push the side of C1’s shoulder as C1 was trying to get access to the facility’s fire extinguisher as C1 was causing damage throughout the facility. In regard to the allegation that S5 harassed C1, it was alleged that S5 verbally harassed C1. A confidential interview disclosed that S5 told C1 “you should be in jail not a group home”. S5 denied the allegation. Other confidential interviews disclosed that C1 and the other clients in the STRTP have never been verbally harassed by staff. In regard to the allegation that staff did not seek medical attention for C1, it was alleged that on December 15, 2020, C1 reported to the STRTP staff that C1 did not feel well and C1 had to call an ambulance for self. Confidential interviews and document review disclosed that C1 advised staff at 4:45 PM on 12/15/2020 that C1 wanted to go to the hospital but ignored staff when staff inquired why. C1 then requested staff call an ambulance at 5:15 PM and staff assessed that C1 had no life-threatening symptoms or needs. At 5:18 PM, C1 advised the staff on duty that C1 was feeling really sick and may have COVID-19 and C1 then used another client’s phone to call an ambulance. Confidential interviews and document review revealed that the STRTP did not have sufficient staff or transportation to transport C1 to the hospital at the time of C1’s request. There were two staff on duty and one staff had taken another client for medical attention at 3:37 PM. Confidential interviews disclosed that C1 was advised of this information and that C1 would have to wait for staff to return and then be taken to the hospital. CSW had no issues or concerns with the care and supervision provided at the facility. Based on confidential interviews and document review, the allegations that S4 strangled C1, S5 harassed C1 and staff did not seek medical attention for C1 may have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator, Shugella Weaver-Thomas for signature. The signed report will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On March 12, 2021 at 12:57 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Hamilton met with Guiding Light Home for Boys (STRTP) Administrator, Shugella Weaver-Thomas to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. Due to COVID-19 a tele-inspection was conducted via Facetime. During the investigation, LPA Hamilton conducted interviews with five of six clients, five staff, county social worker, Administrator (ADM) and Client #1’s biological aunt. LPA Hamilton conducted a health and safety tele-inspection of the STRTP on December 22, 2020 at 4:06 PM and no safety concerns were noted. LPA obtained and reviewed the facility’s 15-minute log, placement agreements, needs and services plans, special incident reports, and staff schedules. On December 18, 2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information stating that Staff #4 (S4) strangled Client #1 (C1), Staff #5 (S5) harassed C1 and staff did not seek medical attention for C1. In regard to the allegation that S4 strangled C1, it was alleged that on October 28, 2020, S4 strangled C1. Confidential interviews disclosed that on October 28, 2020 at approximately 1:00 AM, C1 requested to cook

narrative: C1’s roommate. It was also alleged that C2 sustained a cut to the lip, a bump on the back of C2’s head, bruises on both arms and a headache. Confidential interviews and document review disclosed to LPA that there were two staff in the STRTP at the time of the incident and that STRTP was utilizing correct direct care staff/child ratio as regulated in STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Confidential interviews also disclosed to LPA that staff did not witness the altercation but responded to the incident as soon as they heard noise coming from the bedroom. Conflicting information was provided via confidential interviews and document review as to whether or not C2 was injured as a result of this altercation. Document review disclosed that C2 AWOL’d (Absent Without Leave) after the incident. CSW stated CSW had no issues or concerns with the care and supervision provided by STRTP. Based on confidential interviews and document review, the allegation that lack of supervision resulted in C1 causing injuries to C2, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator, Shugella Weaver-Thomas for signature. The signed report will be placed in facility file.

narrative:
On June 10, 2021 at 9:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Hamilton and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore conducted an annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on 06/11/2020. LPA was met at the facility by facility Manager Martin Morales. A physical plant inspection was completed at 9:23 AM and included the following checks: LPA and LPM observed in the bathroom of the master bedroom a broken vanity with exposed staples, the gate on the side of the facility did not close properly due to a missing latch and also an opening in the ceiling outside of the facility manager’s office. There was adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher was properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. Some required forms were posted including the Personal Rights form and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Visitation policies and the Disaster Plan forms were not posted in the facility. Medications were locked and centrally stored in a toolbox in a locked closet next to the facility entrance. Licensee did not have provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured to be 119 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Administrator is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one therapist, seven facility managers and 13 direct care staff as well as a volunteer that were used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Licensee has obtained Mental Health Certification with San Bernardino County.

Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF International. The Accreditation is valid through December 31, 2023. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there was current balance of $641.50.. LPA discussed the following with the facility manager: Incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. Based upon the inspection of facility records and interviews with staff and clients, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Personnel Files are maintained in a locked office at Site 1, located at 26624 Saffron Cir, Moreno Valley, CA 92555. LPA and LPM observed that staff #1 (S1) and staff #2 (S2) did not have criminal record and child abuse index clearances or exemptions. LPA and LPM reviewed six staff files. A review of client records was also completed on this date. Client and staff interviews were conducted and did not reveal health and safety concerns. Based on file reviews S1 and S2 did not have any proof of criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Regulation 80019(e)(1) Criminal Record Clearance. S1 has been employed by the facility since March 2019 and S2 has been employed since June 2021. Immediate civil penalties are being assessed for $800.00. Additionally, LPA and LPM observed exposed staples sticking out of the bathroom vanity and two cabinet doors missing in the master bathroom. This poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights violation for the clients in care. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Regulation 80087(a) Building and Grounds. The facility shall be clean, sanitary and in good repair at all times. The facility was issued advisory notes due to LPA and LPM observed the gate on the side of the facility did not close properly due to a missing latch, the facility did not provide locked containers for client’s contraceptives, the facility did not have grievance procedures and Disaster Plan posted in the facility and for the open hole in the ceiling outside of the facility manager’s office. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to facility manager.

On June 25, 2021 at 1:23 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Hamilton conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Georgina Doyle. The purpose of the case management inspection was to discuss the incident reported to Community Care Licensing on (CCL) on April 19, 2021. LPA was informed that the clients who were placed at the facility at the time of the incident are no longer at the facility. LPA conducted one staff interview on this date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Georgina Doyle

Confidential interviews also confirmed that the door was nailed shut because the licensee did not want clients out on the balcony due to a possible liability to the facility. Confidential interviews also disclosed that the balcony was stable but there was a possibility someone could get hurt. LPA observed pictures of facility maintenance removing the screw from the track of the sliding glass door on 03/10/2021 and the door being opened. In addition, LPA conducted a health and safety tele-inspection via Microsoft Teams on 03/18/2021 and staff demonstrated that the sliding glass door in the master bedroom was able to be opened and closed. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that the facility did not ensure the sliding glass door in C1’s bedroom was free from obstruction. The allegation is therefore substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 7 Section 80087(c): Building and Grounds: All outdoor and indoor passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, open porches and other areas of potential hazard shall be kept free of obstruction. This poses immediate and potential health, safety or personal rights risk to children in care. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to facility manager.

In regard to the allegation that the facility lacks sufficient food for clients, on 03/05/2021 it was alleged that the facility only had butter and condiments in the refrigerator and frozen corndogs and banquet meals for weekend staff in the overflow freezer. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that the facility did not lack food and there were additional refrigerators and freezers full of food; whereas another confidential interview disclosed the facility did lack food sometimes. Confidential interviews also disclosed to LPA that the facility would advise ADM when food was low, ADM would do an Insta-Cart order and food would be delivered in approximately one to two days. Confidential interviews also disclosed that the facility also had an overflow refrigerator and freezer at Site 1, located at 26624 Saffron Cir, Moreno Valley, CA 92555 due to that site having more space for the extra refrigerators and freezers. LPA observed pictures were taken at the facility showing the refrigerators and cabinets lacked food and receipts of the food purchased that same day. LPA Hamilton conducted a health and safety tele-inspection via Microsoft Teams on 03/18/2021 and observed additional refrigerators and freezers with plenty of food. Furthermore, on 03/18/2021 County of San Bernardino Open Complaint Investigator (OCI) conducted an unannounced facility inspection and did not observe any shortage of food according to their Investigative Narrative. In regard to the allegation that the facility does not provide a comfortable environment for C1, it was alleged that C1’s bedroom had no ventilation and was stuffy due to the sliding glass door being nailed shut. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that all clients were comfortable in the facility and there were no complaints regarding the environment; whereas another confidential interview disclosed that both staff and clients are uncomfortable in the facility due to the heat. In regard to the allegation that the facility windows lack screens, it was alleged that on 03/08/2021 there were no window screens on any of the facility’s upstairs windows. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided to LPA. Confidential interviews disclosed that the screens staying on the client windows was an issue due to the clients going out on the roof to smoke; whereas other confidential interviews disclosed to LPA that all the facility windows have screens. LPA also observed a picture that was taken of a window at the facility that did not have a screen. LPA Hamilton conducted a health and safety tele-inspection on 03/18/2021 and did not observe any missing window screens. Moreover, on 03/18/2021 County of San Bernardino Open Complaint Investigator (OCI) conducted an unannounced facility inspection and observed screens on all bedroom windows and a sliding glass door.

Based on confidential interviews, observations and document review, the allegations that the facility lacks sufficient food for residents, facility does not provide a comfortable environment for C1 and the facility windows lack screens, may have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to facility manager.

On Septermber 3, 2021 at 11:02 AM. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Hamilton conducted a case management inspection at Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 (STRTP) and met with Administrator Georgina Doyle. The purpose of the inspection was to address issues and concerns regarding an incident that occurred on or around April 09, 2021. It was discovered through information received via records review and confidential interviews that Client #1 (C1) had AWOL'd from the facility on April 2, 2021 and Community Care Licensing (CCL) was not notified of C1's AWOL status. In addition, C1 was AWOL 04/02/2021 to 04/06/2021 and the STRTP did not contact CCL or C1’s County Social Worker (CSW). The Special Incident Report (SIR) regarding the above incident was obtained by LPA during a complaint investigation on 04/15/2021. Also, during confidential interviews it was reported that STRTP did not forward the SIR prior to April 15, 2021 to CCL or CSW. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80061(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements. STRTP failed to report special incidents to CCL regarding C1 being AWOL for multiple days. The facility is also being assessed an immediate civil penalties in the amount of $1,000.00 for repeat violation of the above section. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Administrator Georgina Doyle.

On September 3, 2021 at 11:54 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Hamilton conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Georgina Doyle. The purpose of the case management inspection was to discuss an incident that occurred on or around 08/19/2021 and was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 08/24/2021. LPA conducted two staff interviews on this date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator

CSW disclosed that she had not been notified of C1’s AWOL status prior to arriving at STRTP. CSW also disclosed to LPA on April 14, 2021 that CSW still had not received a copy of the Special Incident Report (SIR) regarding C1’s AWOL. Records review revealed that the SIR was prepared by STRTP staff on April 09, 2021 and reviewed and approved by previous Administrator (ADM) on April 1 ,2021. Confidential interviews disclosed that the staff who prepared the report did not follow the STRTP’s protocol to notify the client’s authorized representative directly or call the county’s hotline. ADM disclosed the SIR was sent to CSW and CCL on the morning of April 15, 2021. CSW also advised LPA that CSW was not notified of C1’s return to the STRPT on April 6, 2021 until CSW contacted the STRTP via telephone on April 12, 2021. Confidential interviews disclosed the STRTP’s protocol is for staff writing the SIR to make notifications to CCL, CSW/authorized representative, law enforcement and STRTP management. CSW added that the facility has previously failed to notify CSW timely of C1’s AWOL status. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that facility staff did not properly report C1’s AWOL to C1’s authorized representative. The allegation is therefore substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6 Section 80061(g): Reporting Requirements. The facility failed to report to C1’s CSW/authorized representative that C1 had AWOL’d from the STRTP within the timeframes outlined in Title 22 Regulations. This poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to children in care. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Administrator Georgina Doyle.

deficiencies.description: 80061(g) Reporting Requirements. (g)The items specified in (b)(1)(A) through (H) above shall also be reported to the client's authorized representative, if any. Based on record review and staff interviews, the licensee did not ensure special incident report for C1's AWOL was reported tor C1’s CSW/authorized representative, which poses an potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Adminstrator will provide training to all staff regarding the facility's reporting protocols.  Administrator will provide proof of staff trained, the training materials, copy of facility's reporting protocol.  Training is to cover CCR & ILS Reporting Requirements sections.  This information will be provided to LPA via email by POC due date.

narrative: that “a kid yelled and C1 was scared for no reason” and was scared to fight clients back. LPA was provided with conflicting information regarding the allegation, the information received disclosed C1 was scared for no reason; whereas confidential interviews disclosed C1 had not disclosed that C1 felt unsafe or was scared at the STRTP. Confidential interviews disclosed that facility is safe and staff does rounds and checks to ensure facility is safe for clients; whereas other information received stated the facility is not equipped to be STRTP and additional staff is needed to handle certain types of clients. Confidential interviews disclosed that none of the clients in the STRTP ever expressed feeling unsafe at STRTP. CSW disclosed to LPA that CSW spoke with C1 on April 4, 2021 via email and C1 advised CSW that everything was fine, C1 felt safe and C1 did not want to be moved from the STRTP. Confidential interviews disclosed that staff does safety checks of the STRTP every 15 minutes. In regard to the allegation that C1 was physically assaulted by other minors while in care, it was alleged that C1 was jumped by a client and punched in the face and could not remember what happened. It was also alleged that that a client tried to fight C1 but C1 was scared to fight back. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting information being provided by confidential interviews and document review disclosed that C1 was punched in the face by C2 on March 19, 2021 after C1 and C2 had a disagreement. Confidential interview and document review also revealed staff intervened by separating the clients and debriefing with clients. Confidential interview and document review also revealed medical attention was declined by both clients. Document review disclosed to LPA that C1 was conscious and repeatedly refused medical attention. Confidential interview also disclosed that the incident was not witnessed by any of the clients in care. CSW stated CSW had no issues or concerns with the care and supervision provided by STRTP. Based on confidential interviews and document review, the allegation that the facility does not provide a safe environment for C1 and C1 was physically assaulted by other minors while in care, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to Administrator, Georgina Doyle.

narrative: During investigation, LPA gathered pertinent documents and interviewed the Administrator. On April 6, 2023, LPA interviewed four staff and three clients (C1, C2 and C3). On April 11, 2023, LPA conducted a phone interview with a staff. In regard to cannabis is used by the youth in care on facility premises, confidential interviews stated that cannabis was not observed on the facility premises. Other confidential interviews indicated seeing clients smoking marijuana There was inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Facility staff denied observing youth smoking marijuana inside the facility. In regard to facility staff yell at the youth in care, Facility staff denied yelling at the clients, however, staff may use firm voice or a higher tone to redirect clients in they were misbehaving. LPA was unable to obtain additional information regarding this allegation due to a client not being available for interview. There was inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Regarding the allegation that facility staff speak inappropriately to youth in care, facility staff disclosed that staff will repeat after clients to correct inappropriately language that was said to them. Staff will continue to redirect clients not use inappropriate language because they are disrespectful. There was inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that cannabis is used by the clients in care on the facility, facility staff yell at clients in care, and facility staff speak inappropriately to clients in care, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were discussed and given to Administrator Georgina Doyle.
investigation_findings: 13On May 11, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal arrived at Guiding Light for Boys #2 (STRTP) ) and met with Administrator Georgina Doyle to deliver the finding for the allegations stated above involving clients and the STRTP staff as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated on March 30, 2023. On March 28, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging cannabis is used by the youth in care on the facility premises, facility staff yells at the youth in care, and facility staff speak inappropriately to youth in care. On March 30, 2023, at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA)Karen Beal arrived unannounced to Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 STRTP to initiate the complaint. LPA met with the Administrator who granted access into the facility. A health and safety inspection were conducted, and no immediate health or safety concerns were observed.

narrative: On May 31, 2023, at 9:00 am, an unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Natasha Dunlap, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Thomas. The facility was toured inside and out at 10:20 am with facility manager (FM), Helena Ellis and Residential Counselor Jaymina Ranson. There are currently five clients in placement. At the beginning of inspection there were no clients on grounds and 2 client's arrived during the inspection. Bedrooms are set up so there is two clients per room and one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were observed to be clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client master restroom was measured to be 120 degrees Fahrenheit. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications and sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked hallway closet downstairs near front door. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a cabinet in the staff office. The facility's smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by FM. All Client bedrooms have proper window screens, and they are in good condition. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: fire evacuation procedures, facility disaster plan, personal rights, and foster care ombudsman poster. LPA and LPM observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean, and the landscape well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is no swimming pool located on the facility grounds. During the time of the inspection LPM and LPA began reviewing five personnel files and completed one client interview. At this time an annual continuation inspection will need be conducted on a later date. A copy of this report was provided to Helena Ellis Facility Manager.

On June 5, 2023, at 8:30 am, an unannounced continuation annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Natasha Dunlap, and Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Erika Thomas. During time of inspection LPA and LPM reviewed five client records and completed reviewing staff files. LPM and LPA interviewed two staff and one client who were present during the time of inspection. Staff files were reviewed to ensure they contain the required documentation per Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances. Based on review of five staff files and five client files, facility cited for title 22 California Code of Regulation (CCR) section 80070(d) Client Records and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87026(c) Safeguards forr Cash Resources, Personal Property, and valuables (see LIC 809-d). A copy of this report was reviewed and given to Administrator Georgina Doyle, along with the confidential names list (LIC 811), LIC 809-d and appeal rights.

investigation_findings: 13On October 19, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 to deliver investigative finding for the above allegation involving the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and clients listed in the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated 10/19/2023. LPA met with the STRTP’s administrator Georgina Doyle. On January 5, 2023, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging due to lack of supervision, minors physically assaulted another minor in care. On January 13, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at the STRTP to initiate investigation and met with facility administrator (FA) Georgina Doyle. LPA interviewed (FA), staff 1 (S1) clients 1 and 2 (C1 and C2). On October 13, 2023, LPA interviewed Facility manager (FM).

narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff do not ensure that C1 in care was enrolled in school, a confidential interview denied the allegation and disclosed that staff ensured C1 was enrolled in school, but the process took longer than usual due to C1’s past record at former school. Another confidential interview maintained that staff did not ensure C1 was enrolled in school and did not know reasons why C1 had not been enrolled in school. Additional confidential interview denied staff did not ensure C1 was enrolled to school. Additional confidential interview was aware that C1’s history at former school was delaying the process of admission into C1’s new school. Regarding the allegation that staff did not safeguard C1’s personal possessions, a confidential interview denied staff did not safeguard C1’s personal possessions. Confidential interview revealed that C1 was selling C1’s new clothes, accusing the facility of not safeguarding C1’s personal possessions. A confidential interview stated that staff did not take measure to prevent other clients accessing C1’s personal possessions and stated other clients in care stole C1’s personal belongings. Another additional confidential interview reiterated that C1 sold new clothes with the tags and used the money to buy drugs. LPA received a conflicting information. In regard to the allegation that staff verbally abused C1 while in care. It was specifically stated that staff called C1 “crackhead”. A confidential interview denied that staff or witnessed anyone calling C1 crackhead. Confidential interview stated that C1 was told not to be a crackhead during a conversation. Another confidential interview believed to be called a crackhead but did not give any specific reason why C1 was being called a crackhead. Additional confidential interview denied staff verbally abused C1. Confidential interview stated there was cordial relationship between staff and C1. Other confidential interviews didn’t provide any relevant information regarding the allegation. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that staff do not ensure that C1 in care was enrolled in school; staff did not safeguard C1 in care's personal possessions and staff verbally abused C1 while in care, may have occurred, however, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with LIC 811 to Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 facility manager.
investigation_findings: 13On July 12, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 and met facility manager, Steven Hooks to deliver investigative finding for the above allegations involving the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and clients listed in the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated 07/12/2024. On August 11, 2023, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging staff do not ensure that minor in care is enrolled in school; staff did not safeguard minor in care's personal possessions and staff verbally abuse minor while in care. On August 21, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at the STRTP to initiate investigation and met with administrator (A1) Georgina Doyle. LPA interviewed (A1), staff 1 (S1) and clients 1, 2 and 3 (C1, C2, C3). LPA was unable to contact county social worker (CSW).

narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff does not pick C1 up from school on a timely basis, it was specifically reported that sometimes C1 had to walk home from school which is two hours away from the facility. During investigation, a confidential interview denied the allegation. Confidential interview stated that staff was always on time to pick up C1 from school. Another confidential interview maintained that C1 was not being picked up on time from school, however, confidential interview did not confirm that C1 walked from school to the home. Additional confidential interview stated C1 was always picked up on time and the distance from school to the home was not a walking distance. In regard to the allegation that staff does not ensure that a youth is adequately fed, a confidential interview denied staff did not ensure C1 was adequately fed. Confidential interview stated there was always food in the home. Another confidential interview stated there was no food in the home when C1 wanted to eat. Additional confidential interview revealed food was thrown all over the home and facility was in disorder. A confidential witness observed clients being disruptive and throw food all over the place. LPA received inconsistent information. Based on confidential interviews and observations, the allegations that staff does not pick C1 up from school on a timely basis and staff does not ensure that C1 is adequately fed, may have occurred, however, they were not a preponderance to support the alleged violation. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and the appeal right was reviewed and provided to STRTP representative.
investigation_findings: 13On August 28, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Guiding Light Home for Boys #2, Short Term Therapeutic Residential Program (STRTP) to deliver investigative finding involving the STRTP. narrative: Regarding the allegation that C1 was inappropriately touched by C2 while in care. A confidential interview stated that RC1 was within a short distance from the incident. The confidential interview stated the incident happened in a flash and what RC1 observed was C1’s reaction. Another confidential interview denied touching C1 but admitted attempting to touch C1. The confidential interview continued stating that RC1 was in the living room not far from where the incident occurred. However, a confidential interview maintained that C1 was touched inappropriately by C2 and RC1 did not do anything about it. In regard to the allegation that staff made an inappropriate comment to C1 in care, a confidential interview denied making an inappropriate comment to C1. Confidential interview stated RC1 was firm with C1 but C1 misinterpreted it. Another confidential interview believed RC1 was making inappropriate comment toward C1. The confidential interview stated RC1 commented that C1 should clean C1’s stinking room. Additional confidential witness did not know what happened for sure. Based on confidential interviews and observations, the allegations that C1 was inappropriately touched by C2 while in care due to a lack of supervision and RC1 made an inappropriate comment to C1 while in care may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and the appeal right was reviewed and provided to STRTP representative.
investigation_findings: 13On August 28, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Guiding Light Home for Boys #2, Short Term Therapeutic Residential Program (STRTP) to deliver investigative finding involving the STRTP. LPA met with facility manager, Steven Hooks. During investigation, LPA interviewed Administrator 1 (A1), Residential Counselors 1, 2 (RC1 and 2), client 1 and 2 (C1 and C2). LPA was unable to interview County Social Worker (CSW).

narrative: On November 8, 2024, at 8:50 am, licensing program analysts (LPAs) Babatunde Aborchie and Maya Chavez conducted an unannounced annual inspection. LPAs met with facility manager {FM} Steve Hooks and administrator (A1), Georgina Doyle. The facility was toured inside and out with FM. There were five clients in placement, one being a non-minor dependent (NMD). LPAs reviewed NMD's transitional plan. There were two clients on grounds during the inspection. Bedrooms were set up so there were two clients per room and one client per bed. There was adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were observed to be clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client master restroom was measured to be 111 degrees Fahrenheit. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications and sharp knives were made inaccessible and stored in a locked hallway closet downstairs near front door. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a cabinet by the staff office. The facility's smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector were checked and were operable. There were no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by A1. All Client bedrooms had proper window screens, and they are in good condition. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: fire evacuation procedures, facility disaster plan, personal rights, and foster care ombudsman poster. LPAs observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean, and the landscape well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There was no swimming pool located on the facility grounds. During the time of the inspection LPAs reviewed five personnel files and five clients’ records. LPAs interviewed one client. There were no deficiencies observed at the time of inspection. LPAs will continue the inspection later. A copy of this report was provided to Georgina Doyle, administrator.

Regarding the allegation that facility vehicle does not have adequate working seat belts for children in care. A confidential interview stated the seat belts had a problem that was discovered during transportation. The confidential interview stated the seat belts were repaired and in good working condition. Another confidential interview stated seat belt had no grip when at the time of use but that was some weeks ago. Additional confidential interview stated the seat belt was repaired when it was observed to be faulty. LPA observed the seat belts in good working condition during investigation. Based on confidential interviews and observations, the allegation that facility vehicle does not have adequate working seat belts for children in care, may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation. Therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and the appeal right was reviewed and provided to STRTP representative.
investigation_findings: 13On January 8, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Guiding Light Home for Boys #2, Short Term Therapeutic Residential Program (STRTP) to deliver investigative finding involving the STRTP. LPA met with facility manager, Steven Hooks. On June 11, 2024, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging facility vehicle does not have adequate working seat belts for children in care. On June 20, 2024, (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at the STRTP to initiate investigation of the above allegation and conducted a safety inspection. There were no safety issues observed. During investigation, LPA interviewed Staff 1, 2 (S1 and S2), client 1, 2 and 3 (C1, C2 and C3). LPA was unable to interview County Social Worker (CSW).

narrative:
In regard to the allegation that staff (S2) speaks inappropriately to youths (C1, C3) in care; it was reported stated that S2 was cursed at C1 and other youths in the facility. It was further reported that S2 stated that C1’s room smells like “ass” and that S2 called the client’s mothers “bitches.” Other confidential interviews reported S2 was cursing at someone on the phone and not at C1. Other confidential interviews reported S2 does not usually use inappropriate language around clients. LPAs didn’t receive additional information. In regard to the allegation that staff (S2) threatens youth in care (C3); it was reported that S2 threatens C3, when C3 refused to accept their medication during the facility’s medication distribution time. It was further reported that S2 threatened to “write up” C3 and inform their county worker. Confidential interviews reported that S2 took a forceful tone when talking to C3 about accepting their medication after C3 initially refused. Other confidential interviews reported that S2 did not threaten C3 about their refusal of medication. Other confidential interviews reported that S2 was trying to encourage C3 to take their medication. Other confidential interviews reported that C3 and S2 had a positive relationship. In regard to the allegation that staff (S1-S5) does not award youth (C2) with scheduled visitation with biological parent; it was reported that C2 missed visitation with their family for three consecutive weeks. Confidential interviews reported that staff “did not feel like taking C2 to their family visit.” Other confidential interviews reported that staff always transported C2 to all of C2’s appointments including family visits. One confidential interview reported that only one of C2’s visit had been missed and another confidential interview reported that C2 had not missed any visits. Another confidential interview could not remember missing any scheduled visits. LPAs received inconsistent information. In regard to the allegation that staff (S1-S5) did not provide timely medical care in a timely manner; it was reported that on 6/10/2024, C2 had an “ear pain” and that C2 told staff about their ear pain. It was further reported that facility staff did not take C2 for medical treatment until 6/11/2024. Confidential interviews reported that facility staff did not take C2 for medical treatment right away because the facility was short staffed. Other confidential interviews reported that C2’s personality of being quiet and non-needy caused C2 to be late, in terms of communicating their ear pain immediately. Confidential interviews reported that as soon as C2 told staff about an ear pain, that S3 then took C2 for medical attention. Confidential interviews reported that the hospital provided medical discharge instructions for C2. Other confidential interviews confirmed that due to C2’s quiet personality, they might not communicate any health issues about themselves right away. Continued on the next page

Based on confidential interviews, reviews and observations, the allegations that staff speaks inappropriately to youths in care, staff threatens C3, staff does not award C2 with scheduled visitation with bioparent, and staff did not provide medical care in a timely manner may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager Steven Hooks.
investigation_findings: 13On 01/30/2025, at 09:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced visit at Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Facility Manager Steven Hooks to deliver the investigative findings for the above stated allegations, involving the STRTP staff and clients as listed on the confidential names list (LIC811). On 06/24/2024, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging that staff speaks inappropriately to youths in care, staff threatens youth in care, staff does not award youth with scheduled visitation with biological parent and staff did not provide timely medical care in a timely manner. On 06/28/2024, LPA Babatunde Aborchie arrived at the facility, obtained pertinent documents and conducted a health and safety inspection. No immediate health and safety hazards were observed. In addition, on 1/22/2025, LPA Joon Choi conducted a follow-up visit to the facility and on a later date, staff 3, 4, and 5 (S3-S5) were interviewed. LPA Aborchie interviewed client 1, 2, 3 and 4 (C1-C4) and staff 1 and 2. Continued on the next page

narrative: On July 24, 2024, at 9:51AM, LPA B. Aborchie arrived unannounced to Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 to initiate the investigation. LPA Aborchie conducted a health and safety inspection with facility manager (S1). No immediate health and safety hazards were observed at the time of inspection. In addition, LPA M. Chavez obtained client roster, copies of Special Incident Reports (SIR’s), Medical Logs, and other pertinent documents to the investigation. In addition, LPA Chavez interviewed clients 1-4 (C1, C2, C3, and C4), staff 1-4 (S1, S2, S3, and S4), and C1’s County Social Worker (CSW) as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811). LPA was unable to interview S5 due to S5 no longer employed at the facility. Regarding the allegation that staff did not administer medication as prescribed, it was specifically reported that a staff member gave C1 a full pill although C1 should only be taking half a pill. During multiple confidential interviews, it was disclosed that C1 was given a full pill instead of half by S5 but only on one occasion. Another confidential interview disclosed that S5 immediately reported the incident, and an SIR was completed and sent to all appropriate parties including CCL. Another confidential interview disclosed that C1’s CSW was never made aware of the incident. LPA did not obtain any further information. Based on interview and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that staff did not administer medication as prescribed. Therefore, the allegation is substantiated. The facility is being cited for the violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 Article 06, Continuing Requirements, Health Related Services 80075 (b)(5)(B). (See LIC 9099D) An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Facility Manager, Steven Hooks.
investigation_findings: 13On 03/24/2024, at 11:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez arrived at Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 and met with Facility Manager, Steven Hooks to deliver the investigative finding regarding the above allegation involving client 1 (C1) and the facility staff. On July 17th, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff did not administer medication as prescribed.

deficiencies.description: Health Related Services Clients shall be assisted as needed with self-administration of prescription… medications. If the client's physician has… that the client is unable to determine his/her own need for non-prescription... Based on observations and confidential interviews the facility did not ensure C1’s medication was given as prescribed. This posed a potential risk to the Health, Safety and Personal Rights to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Facility will email LPA Chavez POC by end of business day 03/25/2025.

narrative:
On July 24, 2024, at 9:51AM, LPA B. Aborchie arrived unannounced to Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 to initiate the investigation. LPA Aborchie conducted a health and safety inspection with facility manager (S1). No immediate safety hazards observed at this time of inspection. In addition, LPA M. Chavez obtained client roster, copies of Special Incident Reports (SIR’s), Medical Logs, and other pertinent documents to the investigation. In addition, LPA Chavez interviewed clients 1-4 (C1, C2, C3, and C4), staff 1-4 (S1, S2, S3, and S4), and C1’s County Social Worker (CSW) as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) LPA was unable to interview S5 due to S5 no longer being employed at the facility. In regard to the allegation that staff are not properly trained and staff falsified medication log, it was specifically reported that the facility did not do a proper medication training and that staff members are constantly making mistakes with medications. In addition, it was reported that when S5 mistakenly gave C1 the incorrect dosage that the facility manager tried to cover up the incident and fixed the Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (MAR) and told S5 to sign the MAR on 07/13/24. During multiple confidential interviews, it was disclosed that all staff are property trained to administer medication and fill out MARs prior to working at the facility with clients. Another confidential interview disclosed that it was unknown why S5 crossed out their initials on the MAR but the MAR was never tampered or falsified with to cover up the incident by facility manager. Another confidential interview disclosed that after S5 gave the incorrect dosage to C1, S5 was written up and retrained. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff have never given clients the incorrect dosage while administering medications. LPA did not receive further information. In regard to the allegation that the facility couch is unkempt, it was specifically reported that the couch at the facility is broken up into pieces and the wood is hanging out. During investigation, multiple interviews disclosed that they recalled getting new couches one day but never recalled a broken couch with pieces of wood sticking out. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that they didn’t remember the couch being broken at all. Other multiple confidential interviews disclosed that when the couch did break a work order was placed promptly and the couch was removed from facility and replaced within reasonable time. Another confidential interview disclosed that the couch was broken on the backside, but wood was not sticking out. LPA received conflicting information.

Based on interview and record review, the allegations that staff are not properly trained, facility couch is unkempt, and staff falsified medication log may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Facility Manager, Steven Hooks.
investigation_findings: 13On 03/24/2024, at 11:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez arrived at Guiding Light Home for Boys #2 and met with Facility Manager, Steven Hooks to deliver the investigative finding regarding the above allegations involving client 1 (C1) and the facility staff. July 17th, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff are not properly trained, facility couch is unkempt, and staff falsified medication log.

narrative:
On May 8, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie began a pre-licensing relocation inspection for Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license for Guiding Light Home for Boys #2. LPA met with director Adriana Vermilion who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there is no child placed in the home. The applicant is applying to relocate six ambulatory, minor and non minor dependents children (NMD). The residence is a five bedroom two story house with four bathrooms. Downstairs The downstairs area consists of the following: Bedroom #1 – It will be used as staff office. It was vacant A living room family room, visitor room, storage down the stairs, a kitchen, dining area, laundry room, a bathroom, the garage, and the backyard. Upstairs Bedroom #2 – It was furnished with two twin sized beds. It would sleep two clients. It was vacant. Bedroom #3 – It was furnished with two twin sized beds. It would sleep two clients. It was vacant. Bedroom #4 – It was furnished with two twin sized beds. It would sleep two clients. It was vacant. Bedroom #5 – Master bedroom. It was furnished with a conference table and chairs/couch/therapy chair. It would be used as a conference room and mental health office.

Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closet space for children’s belongings. Towels and linens were stored in a cabinet by the clients' bathroom. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxides were checked and were working properly. The fireplace was in the family room area, and it was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients would have access. The medications and sharp objects/knives will be locked and stored in a storage box in the under the stair closet. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room. The first aid kit was in a cabinet in the kitchen area by the kitchen sink, accessible and contained all required items. There were no guns or weapons as stated by applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 109 degrees. There was adequate food storage supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. There were no pool or other body of water and the backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. Currently, the facility is appropriate for relocation of six ambulatory clients, ages fourteen to seventeen and non-minor dependents. All requirements were met at this time. Licensing Program Manager will complete a final review prior to issuing a license. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided the director, Adriana Vermilion

Based on the interviews conducted and documents obtained, the above allegation is found to be

narrative: On June 19, 2021 at 12:39 PM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility. During today's inspection, AGPA along with staff conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility. See LIC 809D for cited deficiencies. A copy of the LIC 809S was left at the facility. This report is a transcription of the original report. See hard copy of LIC 809S for signature.

Staff S2 physically blocked X2 unsuccessfully on five separate occasions. X2 attempted physical contact with X1 on five separate occasions. It was reported that physical contact, with intent to harm, was made by X2 to X1 five times, including kicks to X1 while on the ground. The physical altercation began in the clients shared bedroom and continued into the back yard area. It is unclear as to the physical contact made by either X1 or X2 prior to the arrival of staff inside the bedroom. X1 was diagnosed by a physician with a head injury requiring Sleep Monitoring. X2 required law enforcement intervention resulting in an arrest. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, GOY initiated a health and safety plan to honor the Center for Disease Control and California state government mandates. The order to refrain from utilizing or engage in physical intervention as outlined in the Pro-Act training became effective for staff on March 13, 2020. However, alternative safety measures were unsuccessful in maintaining the health and safety of clients in care as it relates to the aforementioned allegation. Based on the confidential interviews conducted and the information reviewed during the investigation process, the above allegation is substantiated meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Exit interview conducted. A deficiency was cited. Copy of this Report sent via email to Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On July 1 , 2021 at 8:40 AM, Out of State Certification Analyst (AGPA), Ron Leslie conducted a a follow-up complaint investigation via telephone with Melissa Kagan, Administrator, to discuss complaint allegations. During investigation of the allegations; youth engaged in physical altercation while in care resulting in injury, the AGPA conducted interviews, reviewed serious incident reports, medical reports and law enforcement contact reports. Although the staff directly involved were not available to be interviewed, the documents outlining the incident along with interviews conducted confirmed that staff did not de-escalate the event appropriately. X2 was noted to have been the agressor and was alotted multiple opportunities to physically engage X1. Staff utilized their person to block X2 from X1 after assaults from X2 to X1 had occurred. The use of physical intervention as a result of failed attempts to re-direct or verbally de-escalate was not initiated.

deficiencies.description: 87072(d)(11): To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature....This standard was not met as evidenced by: Client engaged in physical altercation while in care resulting in injury.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Review current policy related to physical intervention as it applies to the health and safety of staff and clients due to Covid-19 restrictions.  Decisions will be based on the status of Covid-19 restrictions.

narrative: It was alleged that Client #1 (C1) provided methamphetamines (meth) to Client #2 (C2) who ultimately had to be taken to the Emergency Room due to an overdose [see LIC811, dated 10/14/2021]. Interviews conducted revealed C1 denied distributing meth to any of the clients at the facility. C1 acknowledged using meth prior to being placed at the facility. However, C1 denied possessing meth during the time C1 was placed at the facility except for one occasion at a party C1 attended during a time C1 was AWOLed (absent without permission). Other clients denied using any illegal drugs at the facility or having any knowledge of any of the clients possessing or using illegal drugs. However, C2 admitted to using meth at the facility that was given to C2 by C1. Interviews revealed both C1 and C2 used meth in their room they shared at the facility. Interviews further revealed that meth was difficult to detect by the facility staff because there is no distinct odor. It was revealed that it is difficult for staff members to always detect drugs used at the facility in general due to their facility policy of not being able to search the client’s personal belongings or their person for contraband. It was revealed while staff members do what they can according to facility policy, staff are not always able to recover contraband from the clients because the clients must consent to the searches. Clients admitted they do not always consent to the searches. Interviews further revealed staff members perform routine unannounced room checks at the facility. However, the clients acknowledged that the staff are not always able to find contraband because the clients hide it very well. A review of incident report dated 03/28/2021 reveals reported substance abuse, harm to self and hospitalization concerning C2 occurring during a home pass as C2 admitted to having plans with C1 to obtain meth with the intent to smoke enough to overdose. C2 was taken to the hospital for evaluation and released to a higher level of care. On 04/06/2021, a 14-day notice of removal was issued for C1. During the investigation there was no active criminal case by the local Police Department regarding the alleged distribution of meth at the facility. Information obtained revealed former resident C1 was cited for possession of meth following C1’s placement at the facility. Based on information obtained during the investigation, the finding for neglect/lack of supervision is deemed Unsubstantiated meaning, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove a violation occurred. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview conducted. Copy of this Report sent via email to Dr. Sultanian, Head of Service.
investigation_findings: 13On October 14, 2021 at 3:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. The investigation was conducted by Investigator Dennis Douglas of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Bureau. Information obtained during the investigation, including confidential interviews with facility residents and staff members, review of related records including, but not limited to, facility incident report, facility’s resident Handbook, Ventura County sheriff’s Incident report and records from the Department of Children and Family Services, revealed a lack of evidence to support the alleged (Continued on next page 9099-C)

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Olivia Rosas made an unannounced visit to Guiding Our Youth for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Inspection to address concerns regarding the Unusual Incident/Injury Report (SIR) dated 02/04/2022. LPA Rosas and Staff#1 (S1) discussed the details SIR (See confidential name list LIC811 dated 02/23/22). On 02/04/22 at 9:20pm, Staff#2 (S2) had verbal altercation with Client#1 (C1) and Client#2 (C2). S2 went to the garage and clients locked out S2 from the facility. S2 contacted facility Administrator and was instructed to call 911. S1 informed LPA that employee responsible (S2) is not in the schedule and currently on leave. Facility debriefed with clients in a group session and individually. LPA Rosas, received a copy of the video recording verbal engagement of S2 and updated SIR dated 02/07/2022. LPA Rosas was not able to interview clients and staff and will return to continue the case management inspection. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 02/23/2022 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 03/10/2021 at 11:00 AM , Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Olivia Rosas made an unannounced visit to Guiding Our Youth for the purpose of conducting a Case Management- Incident Inspection to obtain further information regarding the Unusual Incident/Injury Report (SIR) dated 02/19/2022. LPA Rosas and Staff#1 (S1) discussed the details SIR (See confidential name list LIC811 dated 03/10/22). The incident report dated, 02/19/2022 was received by the Department on 02/19/2022. Involved Client#1 (C1) got into a car accident while leaving the facility without permission. Client# 2 (C2) asked Staff#2 (S2) to pick up C1 from the accident scene. S2 stated she was doing paperwork and could not pick her up. C1 was brought back to the house by Simi Valley Police Department (SVPD). C1 screamed at S2 and threatened physical harm of S2. S2 exited the office and C1 charged staff and hit S2. C2 attempted to pull the two apart. The SVPD was still in the home from dropping off C1 and pulled C1 off of S1. C2 went after S1. C1 and C2 were handcuffed and taken outside. Client#3(C3) and Client#4 (C4) started yelling at S2 and were handcuffed and sat on the sofa in the living room. C1 and C2 were taken to Ventura County Juvenile Detention Center. C1 was charged with battery. C2 was charged with making threats. On 02/20/22, C1 was picked up from the Ventura County Juvenile Detention Center. C2, is still detained at Ventura County Juvenile Detention Center and was released on 02/22/22. The facility will continue to receive Mental Health and socially rehabilitative services. LPA Rosas interviewed Staff#1 (S1), and Client#1 (C1). LPA Rosas was not able to interview Staff#2 (S2). On 03/10/2022 at 11:00AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Olivia Rosas made an unannounced visit to Guiding Our Youth for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Inspection to continue to gather additional information regarding the Unusual Incident/Injury Report (SIR) dated 02/04/2022. LPA Rosas and Staff#1 (S1) discussed the details SIR (See confidential name list LIC811 dated 03/10/22). On 02/04/22 at 9:20pm, Staff#2 (S2) had verbal altercation with Client#3 (C3), Client#5 (C5). S2 went to the garage and clients locked out S2 from the facility. The verbal altercation between S2 and C3, C5 was verbal nature. The facility provided opportunities to clients to debrief and process with the facility clinical team members their experience. Guiding Our Youth administration notified the Department on 03/07/2022, that Staff#2 (S2) would not be working in the organization. The facility was following guidelines from PIN 20-04-CRP regarding staffing ratios waiver due to COVID-19 pandemic. On 02/25/2022, LPA Rosas emailed facility administrator reporting that staffing ratio waiver expired June 30, 2020, from PIN 20-04-CRP. PIN 20-04-CRP was superseded by PIN 20-13-CRP, which does not include the staffing ratio waiver. The most current COVID-19 PIN is PIN 21-31-CRP. Based on the interviews conducted and documentation gather the following Advisory Note- Technical Violation was issued. The Advisory Note- Technical Violation was issued for 87065.5 DIRECT CARE STAFF/CHILD RATIOS. (a) (1) In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: (1) During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. The facility needs to follow Direct Care Staff to Child Ratios as PIN 20-04-CRP staffing ratios waiver has expired. Report continues on LIC809-C

A Advisory Notes- Technical Assistance was issued for 87072 PERSONAL RIGHTS (11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. Facility makes all efforts to address clients toward preventing re-traumatization and thwarting the possibility or occurrence of secondary trauma. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 03/09/2022 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. LPA Rosas interviewed Staff#1 (S1), and Client#1 (C1). LPA Rosas was not able to interview Staff#2 (S2). Client#2 (C2) denied to be interview by LPA. LPA was not able to interview Client#4 (C4) because they were sleeping during the inspection. LPA Rosas will return to continue the case management inspection. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

The facility is in the process of obtaining a Mental Health Program Approval contract with the Department of Health Care Services and Ventura County. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA Rosas inspected the following: This is a one (1) story (STRP) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, located in a residential neighborhood. This is a (3) three bedroom, (2) two bathroom (one in the hallway and one in the staff office), single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, staff office, backyard, and an attached garage for storage. There are two (2) facility vehicles parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition. Outdoor Area: There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves. The facility is surrounded by brick fence and is observed to be good condition. On September 15, 2022, at 09:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas conducted an unannounced inspection to Guiding our Youth Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose to conduct a Case Management-Deficiencies inspection. During the inspection, LPA Rosas met with Staff#1 (S1) and the deficiency was discussed. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 09/15/22. On 06/29/2022, LPA Nancy O’Connell, made an unannounced inspection and observed 12 out 20 current staff members listed in the LIC500 dated 06/2022 were not associated in the Guardian system for the facility. Facility stated, they do not have access to Guardian, and they been mailing the completed LIC9182 and supporting documents to the El Segundo Children’s Residential Regional Office for associations. 06/29/2022, facility submitted a request to Guardian to obtain access. On 07/15/2022, LPA Rosas was not able to verify that Staff#2 (S2), did not have criminal background clearance. On 07/26/2022, facility was able to obtain access to Guardian and associated employees to facility. LPA Rosas was informed that employee S2 will not work in the facility till obtaining background clearance. Based on record review on 06/29/2022, LPA O’Connell and Rosas observed that S2 did not have Criminal Record Clearance which poses which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. Report continues on LIC809-C

One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, 80019(e)(1) Criminal Record Clearance: All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility. Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department. One Technical Violation Note was issued for California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, 80019(f) Criminal Record Clearance: A licensee or applicant for a license may request a transfer of a criminal record clearance from one state licensed facility to another, or from TrustLine to a state licensed facility by providing the following documents to the Department. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Olivia Rosas made an unannounced visit to Guiding Our Youth for the purpose of conducting a Case Management - Other Inspection to address concerns regarding Cross reference referral report dated 11/21/2022. LPA Rosas and Staff#1 (S1) discussed the details SIR (See confidential name list LIC811 dated 11/22/22). The Department received cross reference referral from Client#1 (C1) County of Placement dated 11/21/2022. The referral alleged C1 had been contacted by a unknown man via social media. It was reported that the male was offering marijuana and alcohol. C1 is currently runway away (AWOL) from the facility and Law Enforcement has been notified. S1, reported that C1 AWOL from the facility on 11/20/2022. County of Placement asked for the bed to be closed by 11/28/2022. S1 reported, C1 had pattern of running away, drinking alcohol, smoking marijuana. During emergency room visit tasted positive for drugs. C1 was only in placement for one month. Was in enrolled in school but would not attend. The school provided alternatives for C1 to attend but C1 was not receptive to them. S1 noted that C1 had multiple Special Incident Reports during the stay in the facility. Based on information obtained there is not enough information and there were no witnesses identified to corroborate the allegations. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 11/28/2022 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Interviews reported that Client#1 (C1) had a pattern of running away from the facility to drink alcohol, smoke marijuana or do drugs. Interviews reported that C1 would engage in drug use while being away from the facility. Interviews revealed that C1 social media was not active in social media. LPA Rosas was not able to verify Instagram post or account. All persons interviewed denied the allegation, of facility allowing youth to use drugs while in care in the facility. Facility uses verbal prompts, therapeutic services, and safety plans for residents to encourage them not to runway or use drugs. Residents are searched (visually) upon their return to the facility and room searches are done to check for contraband. LPA Rosas conducted interviews with clients and facility staff that provided information on staff schedules, therapy resources and policies and procedures for care and supervision for clients. The facility has a zero smoking policy and drug use. The instagram post was when C1 was out of the facility in unknown location. There was not enough evidence and information to corroborate the allegations of Neglect and lack of supervision. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision and Other are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.
