narrative: LPA Rosas conducted interviews with residents, staff, and pertinent parties regarding to allegations. During the investigation, it was reported that on 06/07/2022 Client#1 (C1) and Client#2 (C2) went to near by park for community outing. Staff#2 (S2) contacted the facility to report C1 and C2 had eloped from the park. C1 and C2, returned to the facility walking and did not disclose additional information. LPA reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that Direct Care Staff Ratio present for clients in placement. Interviews disclosed how clients are provided daily therapy services, individual therapy, and rehabilitative services. Clients interviewed did not indicate that staff failed to intervene, but residents ignored staff directives about returning to the car at agreed time. LPA Rosas conducted interviews with residents and staff that describe the internet use and access in the facility. Residents can use their cell phone that has internet access, and school internet hot spots. The school internet hot spots are given to each resident to use with their school computer (Chrome books). The facility applies reasonable and prudent parent standard to residents in care when allowing the use of internet access. Confidential statements obtained produced no witnesses or corroborating evidence to corroborate the allegation of Personal Rights. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegations of Personal Rights are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: LPA Rosas conducted interviews with residents, staff, and pertinent parties regarding to allegations. During the investigation, it was reported that Client#1 (C1) entered the facility with five psychotropic medications but not an active prescription. LPA Rosas conducted file review on C1 and obtain copies of JV-220 dated 05/07/2022, Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (MAR) and Special Incident Reports (SIR). On 08/22/2022, C1 refused to attend Behavior Health appointment and was rescheduled to 09/21/2022. Between 08/14/2022 to 09/12/2023, C1 was admitted to Simi Valley Hospital due to 5150 holds. Upon resealed from Simi Valley Hospital, the facility was not able to obtain refills on medication due to medical not being active when released from Simi Valley Hospital. On 09/14/2022, facility was able to obtain prescription and administer medication. The facility made all possible attempts to obtain medication for C1 but was difficult as resident missed scheduled Mental Health appointment and was taken to the hospital and receiving new medication. Interviews disclosed how clients are provided daily therapy services, individual therapy, and rehabilitative services. Clients interviewed did not indicate that staff failed to provide medication. Confidential statements obtained produced no witnesses or corroborating evidence to corroborate the allegation of Medication. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios conducted a case management inspection May 25, 2023, at 10:57 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 24 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 24 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated May 25, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dahl Larios observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Head of Service, Melissa Kagan.

investigation_findings: 13On June 6,2023 at 9:22 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced case management visit to Guiding Our Youth (565801693) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of concluding the investigation and to deliver findings on the above allegation. On 05/22/2024 at 9:31AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Christine WIlson made an unannounced visit to Guiding Our Youth for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA Wilson met with Staff#1(S1) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 05/22/2024. LPA met with Staff#1 (RC1), who granted access into the home, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant. This facility has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license to provide care and supervision for six (6) female children ages 13-17 years old, Ambulatory only. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. The facility currently has Accreditation with CARF International dated 09/24/2021 and with expiration date of 09/30/2024. The facility has a current Mental Health Program Approval contract with the Department of Health Care Services and Ventura County, with expiration date of 05/27/2024. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA Wilson inspected the following: This is a one (1) story (STRP) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, located in a residential neighborhood. This is a (3) three bedroom, (2) two bathroom (one in the hallway and one in the staff office), single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, staff office, backyard, and an attached garage for storage. There are two (2) facility vehicles parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition. 9:44am Outdoor Area: There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed a picnic table with seating for (8), circuits, utility shut -off valves. The facility is surrounded by brick fence 6 feet and is observed to be good condition. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 2 of 5

Page 2 There was a window screen missing from bedroom 3. Staff replaced window screen in the presence of the LPA. LPA Wilson reviewed following during the inspection: LPA Wilson requested the following forms for review, Register of Youth (LIC 9020), Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC610C), Emergency Intervention Plan, vehicles registration and auto insurance. In addition written menus, staff weekly schedule, and The accreditation CARF International Commission approval certificate. Rubi Valerio Cruz is still associated to the Guardian facility roster. Jessica Flores is "In Process" and associated to the Guardian facility roster. *RC1) stated "she is scheduled to work at Casarin" Administration was notified by (RC1) Staff Office: The office is equipped office furniture (i.e desk, computers, printers). Additional medication is kept locked inside of the staff office. The client and staff files are kept in a locked in file cabinet. LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies such as razors,sharps and medication. There is a full bathroom for staff use only. Laundry Room: The laundry room is located next to the kitchen. The laundry room is kept locked and only used when staff is present with youth. The laundry is equipped with a washer and dryer unit that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent is made inaccessible to the children and is disputed according to the load of the laundry. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked and made inaccessible to clients. Dining Area/Kitchen: There is adequate furniture and a breakfast bar which appears to be in good condition, with seating for six (6). All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are clean, free of litter and rubbish. There is two televisions. One round table and island with stools next to the Kitchen: There is a gas stove/oven with four (4) burners, all operating. There is a dishwasher is not being used, microwave, refrigerator with freezer and a toaster oven. LPA observed adequate perishable/nonperishable food supplies. The facility supplies a staple nonperishable food for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days shall be maintained on the premises. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions made inaccessible to the youth locked in the staff office. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 3 of 5

Page 3 Living Room/Family Room (Den): There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. The living room has dining table and televisions. The facility has two living room areas used for recreating and activity room, which provide the necessary space and/or separation to promote and facilitate the program of planned activities and to prevent such activities from interfering with other functions. The living area has game board games, books, magazines and art supplies. Windows had torn screens (see photo). 10:47am Bedroom # 1: Currently occupied by one (1) client (C3), has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. Bedroom # 2: Currently occupied by one (1) client (C1), has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. Bedroom # 3: Currently occupied by one (1) client (C2), has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms. Bathroom #1 is the common bathroom for the clients. It is a full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and showers. Bathroom #2 is located inside of the staff office is full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and shower. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Garage: The garage is kept locked and only staff uses has access to the garage. The attached two car garage is used as storage and is kept locked. The garage has additional fridge and deep freezer for food. LPA observed overstock of nonperishable food, frozen food, snacks and supplies. Additional disinfectants, chemicals, and hygiene supplies are kept in garage are locked in storage closet making them inaccessible. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 4 of 5

Page 4 Vehicles: There is one (1) vehicle available to transport youths; make and model is a 2018 Dodge Grand Caravan Insured by Non Profits Insurance Alliance of California, Inc. The vehicles used to transport clients appeared to be in a safe operating condition. The registration of the vehicles was valid. During the inspection, the following was observed: LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, and cleaning solutions. All windows were in good condition with screens and blinds. There were no security bars on the windows. There are three (3) fire extinguishers and was fully charged and eight (8) smoke alarms and two (2) carbon monoxide detectors were working properly in the facility. LPA observed ample towels and linen closet. Telephone located in garage area and office. Carrier is AT&T. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. Posting Requirements: All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children’s Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The home has a working telephone and youths can use the telephone in the staff office, unless restricted by court order. The Emergency Evacuation Plan (LIC610C) and facility sketch is posted. All posting requirements were met. LPA observed two (2), complete First Aid Kits and a 1st Aid Manual in the staff office. All posting requirements were met. Children will be accorded personal rights. The facility current License, Ombudsperson Grievances and Personal Rights; are posted on the wall. Children are not restricted to make phones calls based on the court and or authorized representative. Staff Interviews: LPA conducted a confidential interview with one (RC1) on duty staff present during the inspection. Client Interviews: LPA was not able to conduct confidential interviews with clients, due to all clients asleep after returning from awol. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 5 of 5

Page 5 Staff Records Review: Facility files are not located off site at the STRTP office. LPA was unable to inspect staff files this day and will return to inspect files a different day. Clients Records Review: LPA reviewed three (3) client records (C1, C2 and C3) which meet qualification. LPA reviewed consent forms, completed by the child's authorized representative(s), to permit the facility to authorize medical care. LPA review copy psychotropic medication log. Record of client cash resources and allowance. The needs and services plan, Admission Agreement, Health History, and Personal Rights. LPA observed the child’s Needs and Services plans kept in client’s personal file; (filed in an individual binder). Children are accompanied to outside extracurricular activities and social events and alternate activities have been implemented. LPA reviewed record of client cash resources logs for three (3) youth. LPA verify the Needs and Services plans for three (3) clients that are kept in an individual binder. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 05/22/2024 indicates that all but one (S1) personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. A Technical Violation was observed and cited at this time (see LIC809D). Exit interview was conducted with RC1 and a copy of this report will be emailed the facility.

narrative: On February 6, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Kevin Sauk, scheduled and met with the facility licensee, administrator, and management team for an Informal Office meeting, held at the Woodland Hills Regional Office. The purpose of the meeting was to gain clarification about the current state of operation, as well as address concerns related to various concerns and complaints received within the Department. Community Care Licensing Division staff in attendance: Bernice Karnsrithong, Children’s Residential Regional Manager (RM), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Kevin Sauk, Licensing Children’s Residential Program Manager (LPM), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Nancy O’Connell, Children’s Residential Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Guiding Our Youth staff in attendance: Andrew Lang- Licensee. Tessa Koziol, staff Introductions were conducted and LPM Sauk provided a copy of the meeting agenda to all in attendance. The following topics were addressed: Staff Roles, Staff Schedule, Inspection Authority, Care and Supervision, Emergency Intervention Plan, and Staff training. narrative:
On 05/21/25 at 1:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell made an unannounced visit to the above-listed facility for an Annual/Required licensing Inspection. LPA met with Madison Hall, Facility Administrator and Kathleen Burrell, On-call Social who granted access to the facility. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) female clients, ages 13-17 years, ambulatory only LPA observed the following during the inspection: This is a one story home, located in a residential area. The Facility was set as follow: 3 bedrooms, 2 bathroom(one in the hallway and one in the staff office), Living room/family area, kitchen and dining area. Bedroom #1: Is occupied by C1andC2, it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #2: Is occupied by C3 and C4,it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #3: Is occupied by C5 and C6, it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. LPA observed that all bedrooms had an excessive amount of belongings, and contents on the ground. There is a hole in the wall of BR#2 above C3 bed. Bathroom#1: contains a toilet, standing shower, sink, with mirror. LPA observed towels on the floor, hygiene products in the shower, trash debris in area. LPA inquired about reason for objects observed and FA stated that clients forget to remove items after use. LPA observed paper towels for handwashing were missing and FA reported that a client destroyed the handtowel dispenser. Bathroom#2: located within the staff office Living room: contains enough seating for six (6) clients,and recreational games. LPA observed that two smoke alarms were removed during the time of inspection. Family/recreational living room- contains seating for all clients, items for therapurtic exercises, and a door that leads out to the front of the facility.

Dining room: adjacent to the kitchen and contains enough seating for all clients in care. Kitchen: contains a refrigerator, stove, microwave, and oven. All appliances were observed to be in working condition. There were enough plates, cups, utensils for clients in care. LPA observed food within the refrigerator and freezer to be in the required amount and stored properly. Menu was posted with a date. A trashcan with a lid was observed. Washroom: located adjacent to the kitchen and contains cleaning chemicals were observed to be locked and inaccessible to youth in care. Garage: contains additional supplies, food, and additional client belongings. Outdoor-back yard: area is unobstructed and free from tripping hazards Outdoor-front yard: area is unobstructed and free from tripping hazards. This area has a driveway with two facility vehicles. One is a 2019 Nissan Versa which was found to be in operating condition, with registration and insurance. The second car is a van and was observed to have a sliding door that is off the track. FA communicated that the door still works but needs to be placed back on the track. LPA informed FA that the car cannot be used until the door is fixed. Medication station: medications were observed to be locked and secure within the staff office. LPA observed medications to be properly stored, along with required documentation Staff office: Located at end of bedroom hallway and, secured with a metal security gate. This area contains an office computer, telephone line, and space for confidential meetings. This are also contains secured sharps in a metal drawer. During this inspection, LPA completed the following sections of the Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) Care Tool: Physical Plant. Per California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulation, and Short Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 5, there is one deficiency cited during this inspection Due to time constraints, LPA will return on another day to complete the Annual Inspection. Exit Interview was conducted with staff and a copy of this report was provided to the facility

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas conducted a case management inspection August 6, 2025, at 9:30am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 17 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. In the inspection, 3 out of 17 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 3 youth were interviewed (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 8, 2025). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the youth case plans, Crisis Safety Plan, Child and Family Team summary, Needs and Service Plan (LIC625), the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Rosas observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance with their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Melissa Kagan, Head of Service.

On September 16, 2020 at 09:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray made an announced Tele-Inspection via Zoom at GUIDING OUR YOUTH (1672 Casarin street Serrania Ave, Woodland Hills CA 91364); due to a SIT ALERT (client tested positive for COVID-19); which will cause Risk to the Health and Safety of the children and staff at the facility. Present in the meeting conducted via ZOOM three (3) staff; including this LPA-Gray. Staff #1 (S1) Jamie Barnett/ Administrator Staff #2 (S2) Rebekah Bird-Wohlgemuth/ RN PHN MSN; Health Facilities Evaluator Nurse/ CDPH Licensing and Certification Program. LPA-Gray ensured that all participants were linked and present. LPA-Gray introduced herself and cross introduced the participants (S1, S2). LPA and participants objective were to ensure the Health of Safety of the Children in placement will be exhibited by ensuring that CDC Guidelines are implemented in effort to prevent the virus from spreading. LPA-Gray and S2 asked a series of questions and observed the following preventive measures in reference to the COVID-19 during the video tour: S1 provided a virtual inspection of the facility. LPA asked “If one or more of the youth tests positive, will the facility be able to isolate the youth from others? S1 stated that the youth that initially tested in August 18, 2020 is currently being Quarantine in an isolated room; supported provided meals and school supplies. S1 stated that confirmed that no other youth or staff has tested positive and discussed their plan procedure in to isolate the youth from others if necessary. LPA observed the main entrances at the facility and confirmed that staff is required to ty immediately washes their hands with alcohol based hand sanitizer upon entry. S2 recommended that S1 refer to the CDC website for a list of approved disinfectants.

S2 also provided information on how to measure and dilute bleach with water as an active disinfectant/cleaning agent. S1 displayed the visitor policy and ensured that signs are posted at each entrance; displaying preventative hygiene posters; posted throughout the facility. LPA-Gray asked were the youth and staff’s temperature checked daily and logged as well. S1 stated Yes and displayed the thermometer and the temperature log. S2 inquired about the number staff that has been tested who are assigned to the facility, that encountered the youth that tested positive. S2 also recommended that refer to the CDC website regarding the reading on the thermometer. LPA-asked has a plan been developed in the event when a youth returns from AWOL for short-period and extended period. S1 discussed the emergency plan in event that a child or staff displays symptoms. S1 stated that youth’s temperature are taken; they are instructed to shower and quarantined depending on how long they have been gone on AWOL. LPA-asked have residents and staff been informed of the purpose of the visit and understand that they must always maintain social distancing (six feet of space). S1 stated that essential visitors are limited (i.e Social Workers, Probation Officers) and have been notified of the Positive COVID-19 Test. LPA recommended that resident youth and staff are directed to wash hands upon return to the facility. S1 ensured that the youth rooms are cleaned, commonly used areas and items (laptops, key boards, computer mouse, remote controls, cell phones, playing cards (i.e UNO) and are disinfected throughout the day and evening every 30 minutes due to the Positive COVID-19; staff wears gloves as an option. In addition, a cleaning service comes on site 2xs a week for a thorough cleaning. Each youth are in their individual room and they are permitted to eat room are or taken offsite to eat. S1 also ensured that social distancing, correctly wash their hands and displayed by practicing “cough etiquette”. LPA observed plenty of perishable and nonperishable food items and covered trash cans. S1 ensured that the food is delivered by Instacart and dropped off without entering the facility. LPA asked did the facility have enough supply of soap, paper towels and tissue. S1 reported the current status the PPE supplies and picked up PPE on Tuesday 09/15/20, afternoon from the Woodland Hills office. LPA recommended that the facility staff S1 review the CDC Resource Packaged items that was emailed in reference to reporting requirements for confirmed COVID-19 cases (County Public Health Department, Primary Physician, Responsible party/family, CCL Regional Office). LPA-Gray concluded the Tele-Inspection Positive and ask the S1 if any questions or needed further technical assistance. A copy of the report will be emailed to the Administrator S1

continued from 9099 AGPA reviewed special incident reports that were generated around 2020 (during time of complaint allegations), past client’s records and one current client record. The investigation revealed that client’s medications are logged properly, and it indicates on the form when a client has refused their medication. Staff training records indicate staff were trained in medication handling. A review of daily communication logs indicate that documentation is done for AM, PM, and NOC shifts. Staff complete incident reports right away and/or prior to leaving their shift. Client statements were not conclusive, or they declined to be interviewed. Based on interviews, file review, and review of supportive documentation, AGPA Woodard has determined there wasn’t any evidence to support the allegations, and the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met to prove that staff were neglectful in dispensing medication as prescribed, or record keeping, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated.

narrative: continued from 9099 AGPA reviewed special incident reports that were generated around 2020 (during time of complaint allegations), and past client’s records. The investigation revealed that clients have a history of drug and alcohol abuse. There were incidents reported where staff have caught clients smoking and drinking. Staff followed protocol and clients are redirected, the house rules are reiterated, and paraphernalia was disposed of properly. Staff will then complete an incident report right away. Staff deny having inappropriate interactions with clients. Client statements were not conclusive; either declined to answer, stated it wasn’t true, or a male staff will say weird stuff. Based on interviews, file review, and review of supportive documentation, AGPA Woodard determined that although clients are smoking marijuana and drinking alcohol in the facility, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met to prove neglect/lack of supervision or personal rights violations, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated.

narrative:
On 04/05/2022 at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Olivia Rosas and Nancy O'Connell made an unannounced visit to Guiding Our Youth for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA Rosas and O'Conell met with Staff#1(S1) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 04/05/22. LPA met with Staff#1 (S1), who granted access into the home, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant. This facility has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license to provide care and supervision for six (6) female children ages 13-17 years old, Ambulatory only. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. The facility currently has Accreditation with CARF International dated 09/24/2021 and with expiration date of 09/20/2021. The facility is in the process of obtaining a Mental Health Program Approval contract with the Department of Health Care Services and Ventura County. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA Rosas inspected the following: This is a one (1) story (STRP) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, located in a residential neighborhood. This is a (3) three bedroom, (2) two bathroom, single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, detached staff office, backyard, and an attached garage for storage. There are two (2) facility vehicles parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition. Outdoor Area: There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves. The facility is surrounded by wooden fence and is observed to be good condition. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of 4

Laundry Room: The laundry room is located next to the garage. The laundry is equipped with a washer and dryer unit that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent is made inaccessible to the children and is disputed according to the load of the laundry. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked in cabinets made inaccessible. The garage is kept locked and only used when staff is present with youth. Garage: The attached two car garage is used as storage and is kept locked. There are two (2) vehicles available to transport youths; make and model are a 2017 Nissan Centra, and 2016 Hyundai. The vehicle has full coverage auto insurance with HUB International Insurance Services Inc. Dining Area/Kitchen/Family Room (Den): There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. There is a television. One table and island with stools next to the Kitchen: There is a gas stove/oven with four (4) burners, all operating. There is a dishwasher, microwave, refrigerator with freezer and a toaster oven. LPA observed adequate perishable/nonperishable food supplies. The facility supplies a staple nonperishable food for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days shall be maintained on the premises. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions made inaccessible to the children locked in the staff office and closet by the kitchen. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. The living room has dining table and television. Additional disinfectants, chemicals, hygiene supplies and medication are locked in storage closet in the living room making inaccessible. Staff Office: The detached garage is used as staff office. The office is equipped office furniture (i.e desk, computers, printers). Additional medication is kept locked inside of the staff office. The client and staff files are kept in a locked in file cabinet. LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, cleaning solutions, and medication. Bedroom # 1: Occupied by two (2) clients, the bedroom is equipped two (2) twin sized beds, comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) wall closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. This bedroom was a bathroom. Page 2 of 4

Bedroom # 2: Currently occupied by one (1) client, has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms. Bathroom #1 is the common bathroom for the clients. It is a full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and tub/showers. Bathroom #2 is located inside of Bedroom#1 is full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and shower. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. During the facility was inspected, the following was observed: LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, and cleaning solutions. All windows were in good condition with screens and blinds. There were no security bars on the windows. There are two (2) fire extinguishers and was fully charged and carbon monoxide detectors were working properly in the facility. LPA observed ample towels and linen closet. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children’s Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The home has a working telephone and youths can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The Emergency Evacuation Plan is posted. All posting requirements were met. LPA observed several First Aid Kit complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, gauzes, antiseptic and a 1st Aid Manual in the staff office. All posting requirements were met. Children will be accorded personal rights. The facility current License, Ombudsperson Grievances and Personal Rights; are posted on the wall. Children are not restricted to make phones calls based on the court and or authorized representative. The lounge is utilized for clients to make phones calls and the Phone Call Log is kept near the facility phone. LPA observed the child’s Needs and Services plans kept in client’s personal file; (filed in an individual binder). Children are accompanied to outside extracurricular activities and social events and alternate activities have been implemented. LPA Rosas reviewed following during the inspection: LPA Rosas requested the following forms for review, Register of Youth (LIC 9020), Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC610C), Emergency Disaster Plan including log that drills were conducted every six months. In addition written menus, staff weekly schedule, and The accreditation CARF International Commission approval certificate. Page 3 of 4

Staff Records Review: Facility files are not located on site. LPA ensured Administrator Certificate was current. LPA reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that Direct Care Staff Ratio present for the five (5) clients in placement. LPA confirmed that All staff have required criminal record clearance. DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response, which meet qualification. The Administrator provided evidence of staff training transcripts stored RELIAS Training Program with a schedule to complete 40 Hours of training for various topics including Trauma Informed and CSEC training. LPA Rosas was not able to complete staff file review and will need to return to complete. Clients Records Review: LPA reviewed one (1) client records which meet qualification. LPA Reviewed Consent forms, completed by the child's authorized representative(s), to permit the facility to authorize medical care. LPA review copy psychotropic medication log. Record of client cash resources and allowance. The needs and services plan, Admission Agreement, Health History, and Personal Rights. Staff Interviews: LPA conducted a confidential interview with two (2) on duty staff. Client Interviews: LPA conducted confidential interviews with two (2) of the five (5) clients according to the census willing to be interviewed. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 04/05/2022 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. LPA Rosas by email send the following PINS to S1 PIN 20-17-CRP: New Background Check Requirements, Assembly Bill 819 (Chapter 777, Statutes of 2019), PIN 21-20-CRP: Statewide Launch of New Inspection Tools for Children’s Residential Licensees, PIN 21-05-CRP: The Family Urgent Response System (FURS), Medications Guide TSP 2017-03 (version 08/23/21). Advisory Technical Violation was given for 87070(b)(13)(F) medication log shall document and maintained. (b) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record: (13) A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following: (F) The date and time of each dose taken by the child. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Torres conducted a case management inspection April 12, 2022 at 9:16 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of 15 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 4 out of 15 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated April 12, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA David Torres observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Paulette Poutre, Administrator.

This amended report supersedes report dated 10/27/22. LPA Rosas conducted interviews with clients and facility staff that provided information on staff schedules, therapy resources and policies and procedures for care and supervision for clients. Facility denied the allegations of Neglect/Lack of Supervision. Facility reported that Client#1 (C1) upon arrival to the facility would runway to smoke marijuana. C1 would also contraband marijuana to smoke and facility staff would confiscate it. Facility reported by C1 receiving therapeutic services and following the program and C1 has attempting to be sober. Interview with C1 detail how is in the path to recovery and admitted of running away to the park to smoke marijuana. All persons interviewed reported how facility encourages clients to stay in the facility. All persons interviewed denied the allegation, reported illegal drugs are not permitted in the facility, and employees strictly enforce the no drug policy. Residents are searched (visually) upon their return to the facility and room searches are done to check for contraband. On 10/11/2022, C1, Child#2 (C2), Child#3 (C3), Child#4 (C4) were inside of the garage watching a movie and C1, and C2 started to kiss each other. The facility encourages residents no to have relationships within the residents. Facility addressed the situation and closed off the garage to prevent residents from engaging in inappropriate behaviors. There was not enough evidence and information to corroborate the allegations of Neglect and lack of supervision. During the course of the investigation the allegation of facility does not have available staff to transport clients to medical appointments. LPA Rosas conducted confidential interviews and based on the information collected. The facility reported making all the possible attempts to transport residents to medical appointments, and outside activities. Facility reported medical appointments are reschedule if clients refuse to attend or runway from the facility. In addition, if staff calls out sick, they do have to reschedule appointments or make outings shorter to accommodate the resident appointments. The facility took C2 to county of origin for medical appointment but had to reschedule follow up appointment due to resident running away. There was not enough evidence and information to corroborate the allegations. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegations of Neglect/Lack of Supervision and Other are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative:
Facility reported that on 01/20/2022, at approximately 12:00AM, Client#1 (C1), Client#2 (C2), Client#3 (C3) decided to leave the facility out the front door. Staff#2 (S2) jogged to catch up to them but any re-direction from staff was ignored. As residents continued to quickly walk towards avenue towards the directions to an Uber/Lyft that they order. Facility contacted Simi Valley Police Department to notify the runway away. On 1/21/2022, facility was notified by Ventura County Police Department that they had found C2 and C3 at Paloma Elementary School. They were picked up by law enforcement by facility staff. C1 returned to the facility and complied with self-search and did not turn in any contraband. Facility reported that on 1/23/2022 at approximately 3:00pm C1, C2, C3 runaway from the facility. Facility contacted Simi Valley Police Department to notify the runway away. At 2:50am C1 retuned to the facility alone and no contraband was found, and resident refused any medication attention. On 1/24/2022, C2 and C3 returned to the facility. The residents complied with self-search and did not turn in any contraband. Residents appeared to be either under the influence or coming down from something. Residents disclosed that had drunk alcohol and decline needing medication attention. Facility staff provided supervision to ensure safety. On 1/27/2022, residents disclosed to staff sensitive information about possible Commercially Sexually Exploited Children (CSEC) activity from C2 and C3 during the last time they runaway. On 02/03/2022, facility called Simi Valley Police Department was contacted to report C2 statements. C2 was taken to Safe Harbor by Simi Valley Hospital or further investigation. On 2/3/2022, C2 bed was closed from the facility and returned to County of origin. Interviews reported that C1, C4 was not involved in CSEC activity. Based on disclosed information C2 reported that C3 forced CSEC activity during when they runway from the facility. Facility uses verbal prompts, therapeutic services, and safety plans for residents to encourage them not to runway or use drugs. Residents are searched (visually) upon their return to the facility and room searches are done to check for contraband and offer medication if needed. There was not enough evidence and information to corroborate the allegations of Neglect and lack of supervision. The incidents happen when residents when they runaway from the facility. Report continues on LIC9099-C Page 2 out of 3

Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility. Page 3 out of 3.

narrative: On 02/27/2022, the Facility reported to the Department that approximately 6:00PM, Client#1 (C1), and Client#2 (C2) ignored staff redirection and eloped from the facility. Facility contacted Simi Valley Police Department (SVPD) to locate and report missing persons report. C1 and C2, returned to the facility at 6:45pm. Staff conducted self-check for contraband. C1 denied any contraband and showed a backpack full of stolen makeup from Target. C2 ignored staff inquiry for a self-check and walked directly to bedroom with backpack that appeared to have something heavy weighing it down. C2 was using both hands to hold up backpack. C1 came into the living room with a gun magazine and showed it to staff. Staff informed C1 that residents are not allowed to have weapons in the facility. C1 returned to bedroom and ignored staff request. SVPD was notified and arrived at the facility and confiscated the gun magazine and star blade weapon. On 02/28/2022, SVPD arrived at the facility to speak with C1, and C2. SVPD reported that residents were involved in a burglary and that there was a gun missing from that location. C1 and C2, denied the knowledge of the weapon. SVPD search resident’s bedroom with their approval. SVDP found shot gun that was found between the bed and wall and ammunition in makeup box in C1 bedroom. C1 and C2, were arrested under breaking and entering. Facility informed related parties that beds will be closed to the severity of their actions and brining a gun into the facility and placing their safety, resident's and staff safety at risk. After clients were detained by the police the facility conducted a room search and found items that were confiscated and were disposed of properly. Interviews disclosed that facility uses verbal prompts, therapeutic services, and safety plans for residents to encourage them not to runway or use drugs. Residents are searched (visually) upon their return to the facility and room searches are done to check for contraband and offer medication if needed. The residents were eloped when they stole the gun and facility attempted to self-search residents. SVPD was contacted upon C1 having the gun magazine. There was not enough evidence and information to corroborate the allegation of Neglect and lack of supervision. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision and Other are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative:
On 01/01/2023, the facility took Client#1 (C1), Client#2 (C2), Client#3 (C3), and Client#4 (C4) to Target for an outing and for residents to get Starbucks during the day. Later in the evening C1, C2, C3 were in bedroom listening to music while C4 was in bedroom watching Netflix. C4 reported to staff that C1 was unconscious in the bedroom due to being drunk. Staff#2 (S2) called 911 and S2 began to provide first aid to C1. Upon the arrival of the ambulance C2 began to seize because of the lights and dropped to the floor. C1 and C2 were sent to Simi Valley Hospital and C2 was sent to Los Robles. At 7:00pm, C3 was released by Simi Valley Hospital due to refusing medical attention in the hospital. At 11:00pm, C2 was released from the hospital after being treated for alcohol intoxication. C1 was placed on an incubator to assist with breathing because vomit was stuck in airway impacting ability to breath. Residents disclosed they smoke marijuana earlier in the day and consuming alcohol in the bedroom, hiding it from staff. During the rooms checks, residents conducted normal by being social, and listening to music. Residents reported they sneaked in marijuana to the facility they got while eloped from the facility. It was reported, the alcohol was stolen from Target, and they played a challenge on who can drink the most. LPA Rosas conducted interviews with residents, staff, and pertinent parties regarding to allegations. No techniques could have been used since the clients planned to drink the alcohol bottle within minutes between room checks. The staff and clients described the care and supervision of the facility. It was disclosed that staff was present during the incident, but residents quickly drank and smoke marijuana earlier in the day. The facility conducted room search and removed vodka bottles. LPA reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that Direct Care Staff Ratio present for clients in placement. Interviews disclosed how clients are provided daily therapy services, individual therapy, and rehabilitative services. Clients interviewed did not indicate that staff failed to intervene or conduct room checks, although the incident did happen. All person interviewed denied the allegation, reported illegal drugs and alcohol are not permitted in the facility, and facility staff strictly enforce the no drugs policy. In addition, residents are searched (visually) upon their return to the facility and room searches are done to check for contraband. Facility staff did take measures to prevent future incidents. Confidential statements obtained produced no witnesses or corroborating evidence to corroborate the allegation of Neglect and Lack of supervision. Report continues on LIC9099-C page 2 out of 3

narrative:
On May 5, 2023, at 12:03 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA),Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to Guiding Our Youth Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA Wilson met with Case Manager (CM) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. (3) staff (CM, S1, and S2) were on site. (2) client residents (C1, C2), were at the facility and (1) client resident (C3) was at school. and Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 05/05/2023. LPA Wilson met with Staff#1 (CM), who granted access into the home, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant. This facility has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license to provide care and supervision for six (6) female children ages 13-17 years old, Ambulatory only. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. The facility has obtained a Mental Health Program Approval contract with the Department of Health Care Services and Ventura County. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. There are no functional cameras in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. (Page 1 of 4) LPA Wilson inspected the following: This is a one (1) story (STRP) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, located in a residential neighborhood. This is a three (3) three-bedroom, two (2) bathrooms, one (1) staff office in single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, backyard, and an attached garage used for storage and laundry service. There is an unattached storage shed. There are two (2) facility vehicles parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition, and with current insurance and registration. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 2 of 4 .

(Page 2 of 3) During the facility was inspected, the following was observed: LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, and cleaning solutions. All windows were in good condition. Windows had screens and blinds. There were no security bars on the windows. There are three (3) fire extinguishers and was fully charged and carbon monoxide detectors were working properly in the facility. LPA observed ample towels and linen closet. Outdoor Area: There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves. The facility is surrounded by brick fence observed to be good condition. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. Laundry Area: The washer and dryer units are located next to the kitchen in the attached garage. The laundry is equipped with a washer and dryer unit that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent is made inaccessible to the children and is disputed according to the load of the laundry. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked and made inaccessible to clients in the staff office. Dining Area/Kitchen: The dining/kitchen area has a bar table with bar stools, where clients were doing art and studying. There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. The living "communal" room has a small table and television. The facility has one living "communal" room area used for recreating and activity room, which provide the necessary space and/or separation to promote and facilitate the program of planned activities and to prevent such activities from interfering with other functions. The living area has game board games, books, DVDs, and magazines.. Kitchen: There is a gas stove/oven with four (5) burners, all operating. There is a dishwasher, microwave, refrigerator with freezer and a toaster oven. LPA Wilson observed adequate perishable/nonperishable food supplies. The facility supplies a staple nonperishable food for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days maintained on the premises. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions made inaccessible to the youth locked in the hall closet with medications. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees fahrenheit. Bedrooms: There are (3) bedrooms in the facility with space for (2) clients in each. At the time of this report, each of the (3) clients placed have their own bedroom. (Report Continues on LIC809-C Page 3 of 3)

(Page 3 of 3) Bedroom 1: (2) beds and sleeps (1) client (C2), equipped with two twin-size beds and dresser. Bedroom 2:(2) beds and sleeps (1) client (C1), equipped with two twin-size beds and dresser. Bedroom 3: (2) beds and sleeps (1) client (C3), equipped with two twin-size beds and dresser. Window screen in disrepair. Bathroom 2: On-Suite bathroom for bedroom 3. sink, toilet, lights observed to be in good working condition. Staff Office: The office is equipped office furniture (i.e desk, computers, printers). Medication is kept locked inside of the staff office. The client and staff files are kept in a locked in file cabinet. LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, cleaning solutions, and medication. Additional disinfectants, chemicals, hygiene supplies and medication are locked in storage closet in the living room making inaccessible. The office has additional a deep freezer for food. LPA observed overstock of nonperishable food, frozen food, snacks, and supplies. LPA Wilson reviewed following during the inspection: LPA Wilson requested the following forms for review, Register of Youth (LIC 9020), Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC610C), Emergency Intervention Plan, vehicles registration and auto insurance. In addition, written menus, staff weekly and schedule. Staff Interviews: Staff interviews were conducted with (CM, S1 and S2) LPA Wilson will need to return to facility to complete the staff file review. Client Interviews: Client interviews were conducted with (C1, and C2) LPA Wilson will need to return to facility to complete the client file review. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 05/05/2023 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. LPA Wilson observed a window screen in bedroom 3 in disrepair. A Technical Advisory is given on this day. 80088 Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies (b) All window screens shall be in good repair and be free of insects, dirt and other debris. Exit interview was conducted with S3 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 05/09/2023 at 8:41am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson conducted an unannounced inspection, at the above-said facility,Guiding Our Youth Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA Wilson met with Case Manager (CM) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility files was conducted together. (2) staff (CM, S1) were on site. (1) client residents (C3, was at the facility and (2) client residents (C1 and C2) were at school. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 05/09/2023. LPA Wilson conducted the file review for three clients (C1, C2, C3), and four staff (CM, S2, S3, and S4).. [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 05/09/2023, for names.] Operational Requirements: LPA Wilson observed that non-discriminatory notice, facility license, notice of problem resoution, activity calendar, daily chore list, evening schedule, foster youth bill of rights, facility sketch floor plan, emergency plan, crisis hot line contacts, Covid-19 resource important phone numbers and weekly group schedule were posted upon entrance to the facility. Disaster Preparedness: LPA Wilson observed written procedures to address storage and preservation o f medications, training on emergency procedures, monthly emergency drills, a disaster and mass casualty plan, a roster and contact information for clients and vehicles for evacuation. Emergency Intervention:Restraints are not used in the facility. Staffing Records: A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ and Child Abuse Index Check clearances, educational transcripts, first aid/cpr certification and identification. Client Records: A review of records shows that all clients have a Needs and Services Plan, placement agency forms, intake packet, mental health documents, medical forms, court documents, educational documents, incident reports and financial documentation of allowance (Continued on 819C page 2of 2)

(Page 2 of 2) Core Theraputic Services: All clients receive core theraputic, psychiatric and medical services, as part of their needs and services plan. Special Health Care Needs:There are no clients with special health care needs PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3, No deficiencies were cited at this time. Four (4) Technical Advisories will be given on this day.(See LIC809-D) ILS 87070 (b)(11) (1 out of 3) Child's legal guardian signature required to complete consent form. narrative: On July 31, 2024 at 10:29am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility for the purpose of conducting an case management inspection. LPA Wilson was greeted by Clients (C1) followed by (C2) who left the front door open, providing LPA Wilson with access to the home. There was one housekeeper (HK) in the home with (4) clients. LPA Wilson asked which staff were in the home. (C1) stated staff were outside and pointed to the backyard. LPA Wilson walked into the backyard, where LPA was greeted by the Facility Manager (FM ), who stated she and staff (CM) were in the detached office. LPA Wilson obtained documents: Shift Notes 7/20/24 and 7/21/24, email dated 07/24/24 from (FS), SIR dated 07/18/24, 07/20/24, hospital Release Form, and reviewed client file for (C1). LPA Wilson conducted confidential interviews with clients (C1, C2, C3 ) and staff (FM). LPA made a phonecall to (HOS) and requested staff fingerprints and identification of the housekeeper (HK) which will be sent by email. Further investigation is required in order to resolve the case management; once completed, LPA will return to deliver and discuss the findings. LPA discussed staff ratios with (FM) (LIC9102). There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility manager.

On October 1, 2024 at 1:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conclude a case management inspection, which began on July 31, 2024. LPA Wilson was met by (CM6) who allowed entry to the facility. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was left with the licensee, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 11/19/2024 at 9:53am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced inspection to the above listed facility, Guiding Our Youth, for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation: Facility staff did not prevent physical altercation between youths. The investigation included confidential interviews with, including but not limited to, facility staff members, and administrative staff, as well as review of records from Law Enforcement. deficiencies.description:
80078	Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA observations and interviews, the licensee did not ensure the care and supervision of client in care by staff, while  transporting, admission, receiving hospital care which is an immediate danger to the health safety and personal rights risk to persons in care.

narrative: On February 6, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Kevin Sauk, scheduled and met with the facility licensee, administrator, and management team for an Informal Office meeting, held at the Woodland Hills Regional Office. The purpose of the meeting was to gain clarification about the current state of operation, as well as address concerns related to various concerns and complaints received within the Department. Community Care Licensing Division staff in attendance: Bernice Karnsrithong, Children’s Residential Regional Manager (RM), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Kevin Sauk, Licensing Children’s Residential Program Manager (LPM), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Nancy O’Connell, Children’s Residential Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Guiding Our Youth staff in attendance: Andrew Lang- Licensee. Paulette Poutre, Facility Administrator. Melissa Kagen, Head of Service. Maral Saltanian, staff. Madison Hall, staff. Kathleen Burrell, staff. Tessa Koziol, staff Introductions were conducted and LPM Sauk provided a copy of the meeting agenda to all in attendance. The following topics were addressed: Staff Roles, Staff Schedule, Inspection Authority, Care and Supervision, Emergency Intervention Plan, and Staff training. LPM Sauk provided general information about the applicable regulations related to aforementioned topics, and obtained clarification on facility policies and procedures. Facility staff provided responses to all topics addressed and were in agreement to provide information requested by the Department, update the facility program statement as needed and adhere to regulatory requirements. CCLD informed staff that reports would be generated and sent for review and signature.

It was further alleged that Staff do not ensure minor's attend scheduled doctor's appointments. investigation_findings: 13On 4/30/2025, at 1:05 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a subsequent complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. The allegation was referred and investigated by CCLD Investigator Douglas Real. Confidential interviews with residents and staff determined denial of the allegation. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

narrative:
On 4/22/25 at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Kevin Sauk arrived at the above-listed facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual Inspection. LPA and LPM met with Paulette Poutre, Facility Administrator, who granted access into the facility, and together, toured the home both inside and out. LPA requested a copy of the LIC500 and client roster upon arrival. Overview: This is a one story home, located in a residential area. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) female children ages 13-17 years, ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no cameras functional cameras used in the facility. The client receives services on site but attend school in the community. LPA/LPM observed the following: Front of facility- this area has an unobstructed walkway, a front lawn, and a driveway. The pathway was clear and free from tripping hazards. Entryway/living room- area contains facility postings including personal rights, and the facility license. Continued on LIC809C

Kitchen- contains refrigerator, stove, microwave, enough utensils/plates/cups for 6 residents. Refrigerator was observed to contain enough perishables to meet requirement. Pantry cabinets in kitchen and garage contained enough non-perishables for required duration. There is a trashcan with a lid. There is a menu posted and dated. There is fruit available on the kitchen counter along with snacks in the cabinets. LPA inquired about the location of sharps and observed knives to be secured in the med closet. Living Room- contains a couch and enough seating for 6 residents, and a tv. This area is utilized for relaxation and leisure activities. Dining Area/countertop- contains tabletop counter and can support seating for up to 6 residents. This space is located near the living room. Bedroom #1 - equipped with one twin size bed, drawers, dresser space and lighting was adequate in each bedroom. Bedroom #2 - equipped with two twin size beds, drawers, dresser space and lighting was adequate in the bedroom. Bedroom #3 - equipped with two twin size beds, drawers, dresser space and lighting was adequate in each bedroom. This room has an adjoining bathroom that is only reserved for clients residing in bedroom #3. Garage- located adjacent to the living room. This area is locked and can be utilized as additional activity/storage space. There is a washer and dryer and laundry chemicals. LPA observed laundry chemicals to be locked and secured. Clients are not allowed to be in this space unsupervised. Staff office- located in detached garage. This area contains two computers, desks, a table, chairs, and printer. This space shares a wall and adjoining door that provides access to another facility associated with the licensee. Staff report that the space is secured and each facility is kept separate. Backyard- there is a large backyard space that is enclosed and utilized for recreation and relaxation. There is grass, an area for gardening, and a picnic bench with seating positioned Continued on LIC809C.

underneath an awning. During the time of inspection, LPA observed that there were metal objects laying on the ground adjacent to a SUV vehicle. LPA inquired about the metal objects and reason for their placement, and FA communicated that the metal objects are car parts belonging to the non-operational vehicle. Medication station/closet- The First Aid Kit was fully stocked. Medications were observed to be secured and staff report that only authorized personnel have access to the medication. There was a carbon monoxide alarm in the home which was tested and in working order. The smoke detectors were also tested, and they all appeared to be in working order. LPA observed several fire extinguishers located throughout the facility and fully charged. LPA reviewed the employee roster (LIC500) and verified that all staff have obtained a criminal background clearance. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA observed the facility vehicle ( vehicle #1, 2013 Hyundai Elantra) and verified that the insurance and registration was present in the vehicles and current. LPA/LPM observed that the rear left brake light was non functional during inspection. LPA asked FA if she was aware of the brake light not workign and she communicated that she was not aware. During the time of the inspection LPA O’Connell conducted confidential interviews with FA, C1 and C1, and C2. C4 declined to be interviewed and C3 was not available in the facility. [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 4/22/25, for names]. Per California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulation, and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 5, there are two deficiencies cited during this inspection. See LIC809D for details. Due to time constraints, LPA O'Connell will return to complete the Annual inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility administrator via email.

met_with: Emerald Wade, Residential Counselor (RC), and Madison Hall, Mental Health Practitioner (MHP)
narrative: On 4/22/25 at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Kevin Sauk arrived at the above-listed facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual-Continuation Inspection. Facility staff, Clinical Director (CD), communicated to LPM that staff files would not be available for review today during normal business hours. LPM communicated that a future unannounced annual continuation inspection will be conducted to finalize the Annual Inspection. Staff Interviews: LPA conducted a confidential interviews with two (2) on duty staff- DSP 1, and DSP2. Client file reviews: LPA reviewed three (3) clients records for C1, C2, and C4 Review revealed that there were missing signatures on the intake policies, discipline, complaint procedures documents for C1, C2, and C4.MHP communicated that she was unaware of reason for missing signature. Per California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulation, and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 5, there are 2 deficiencies cited during this inspection. See LIC809D for details. LPA and LPM will return on a different day to complete the annual inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility administrator via email.

On 5-15-/25 at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell, Wendy Moodie-Naranjo and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Kevin Sauk arrived at the above-listed facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual-Continuation Inspection. An announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura on 11/20/2020 at 11:00am. This inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams due to COVID19 restrictions on conducting on site inspections at licensed facilities. LPA Segura sent the Administrator Noelle Kinder a Document Request checklist on 10/26/2020. LPA Segura received requested documents on 10/30/2020. LPA Segura conducted this inspection with medical coordinator Jess Macintire with the permission of the administrator Noelle Kinder. A tour of the facility was facilitated via facetime with Jess Macintire. On 11/05/2020 LPA Segura reviewed Assessment Needs and Services Plan, Centrally Stored Medication logs, and medication authorization documents. On this date LPA Segura also reviewed the facility program statement, staff training documents and medication policies and procedures. During this review LPA Segura found that the facility is using their own medication administration record. See advisory note dated 11/20/2020 LPA Segura conducted two staff interviews and two client interviews on 11/10 via Microsoft Teams at 9am. LPA conducted the administrator interview on 11/17 at 3pm via Microsoft Teams. On todays inspection LPA Segura requested the medical coordinator conduct a pill count for C1 and C2 (Client 1, 2, see LIC 811 confidential name list dated 11/20/2020) at approximately 11:00am. This inspection will be continued at a later time to complete medication count review.

There were no deficiencies noted at today's evaluation. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to the administrator Noelle Kinder and Jess Macintire. A read receipt was requested to acknowledge receipt of the report. LPA requested Jess sign and scan a copy of the report to LPA Segura.

An announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura on 11/24/2020 at 11:00am. This inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams due to COVID19 restrictions on conducting on site inspections at licensed facilities. LPA Segura sent the Administrator Noelle Kinder a Document Request checklist on 10/26/2020. LPA Segura received requested documents on 10/30/2020. On 11/20/2020 LPA Segura and Jess Macintire counted pills that should be left by reviewing the centrally stored log and medication administration log submitted. At approximately 11:30am LPA and Jess Macintire found that the Centrally Stored log for C1's medication could not account for the amount of pills for Medication 1 (M1, See confidential name list dated 11/24/2020). The Centrally stored log indicated that M1 is a 30 pill bottle started on the 14th of November which should result with 24 pills being present in the bottle. The actual count was 26 pills, it is an extra two pills, which could not be accounted for by reviewing the PMAR for missed meds or refusals. The count for Medication 2 was correct, no irregularity was found. On 11/24 LPA Segura called the administrator to revisit the medication count and found that C1 had refused medication on 11/17; which means there is one extra pill. On 11/20/20 A count was conducted for C2 as well at around 12:00pm. The count for Medication 2 was found to be correct. However, the count for Medication 1 for C2 did not add up initially and suspected missing medication. On 11/24 at around 11:50am LPA Segura spoke with Continued on 809C

Administrator Noelle Kinder and LPA Segura recounted pills and the centrally stored medication record was reviewed. LPA Segura and Administrator Kinder detected the error made in counting the medication on 11/20 was that it was erroneously believed to be a 30 pill bottle; however, it was actually a 14 pill bottle. Count made today 11/24 resulted in a correct pill count. Per Title 22 Regulations, deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of the report was emailed to the facility with a read receipt requested to acknowledge the report was received.
