Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Kyane and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection on September 22, 2021 at 10:54 AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. 4 of 16 direct care staff and 6 of 6 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 confidential names dated September 22, 2021, were reviewed. 2 of 16 direct care staff and 5 of 6 youth were also interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedure were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Noelle Kinder, Administrator.”

On October 26, 2021, at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Oquendo conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA Oquendo met with Residential Counselor (RC) - Annie Sampson. RC and LPA toured the facility, inside and out. The facility is licensed to serve six clients, ages 12-17 years. Currently in placement are six clients. All six of the clients were at school during the inspection. This facility is a two story house that consists of 4 client bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. LPA Oquendo observed at the time of this inspection, the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. All fire alarms, and carbon monoxide detectors were in good working condition, and the fire extinguisher is current. This LPA reviewed the staff and client files, medication logs, and they had the necessary forms. The files are kept locked to ensure confidentiality. Food supply, linens and fire extinguisher were observed. There is sufficient perishable food for over two days and nonperishable food for over seven days. Toxins and sharps are properly stored. Medication storage and procedures were also reviewed. The following documents are posted in the facility: facility license, emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, menu, activity calendar and personal rights. The hot water temperature was at (Kitchen Sink - 105, downstairs bathroom 105, and upstairs bathroom 106 degrees). Facility has no firearms or bodies of water at the facility which meets title 22 regulations. There are currently no exceptions on file, and there have not been any deficiencies cited in the past year. A review of Licensing Information System on October 26, 2021 indicates that all facility staff are associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. The annual inspection for this facility will continue on another date.

On October 27, 2021, at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Oquendo conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA Oquendo met with Residential Counselor (RC) - Brianda Chavez. RC and LPA toured the remainder the facility. The facility is licensed to serve six clients, ages 12-17 years. There are currently six clients in placement. Some clients were present at the facility and preparing to go to school. LPA conducted interviews with clients and staff. At the time of this visit one Technical Violation was cited as per Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Title 22, Division 6. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with RC, whose signature is on this form.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an announced inspection at the above facility on 11/3/2021 at 9:55 AM. An exit interview was conducted and copy of this report was left with Administrator Noelle Kinder and Davina Polonco.

An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Selena Hood and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Carolyn Flynn on 12/03/2021 at 12:40 PM. During the inspection, LPA Hood and LPM Flynn met with Jess Macintire, Medical Liaison in the staff office. At the time of the inspection, three staff and two clients were present. LPA and LPM reviewed six of child’s records on site at the facility at 12:45 PM. LPA and LPM reviewed two of the staff personnel files on site at the facility at 12:45 PM. LPA and LPM interviewed one staff on site at 3:40 PM. Medical Liaison, Jess Macintire, conducted a pill count for one client while being observed by LPA and LPM at 4:00 PM. LPA and LPM reviewed six children’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA and LPM provided the Summary Report to Jess Macintire, Medical Liaison, upon completion. This inspection is not complete and needs further review. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA and LPM conducted exit interview with Jess Macintire, Medical Liaison at 4:30pm.

An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Carolyn Flynn on 12/20/2021 at 10:00AM. During the inspection, LPA met with Norhan Abolail, Residential Counselor and inspected the facility inside and out. Five clients and two staff members were present. During the tour of the facility, LPA Hood observed the medication cabinet, medication bottles and the office holding medications were locked. LPA Hood also observed a pill count for five residents, the sixth was conducted last visit on 12/13/2021. LPA reviewed 6 client’s records on site at the facility on 12/13/2021. During the review of children’s records, LPA Hood and LPM Flynn observed 5 out of 6 children did not have a signature on their Needs and Service Plan. During interviews on 12/20/21 with clients, one of the two interviewed clients said that they were not given the opportunity to sign their Needs and Services Plan. This is a violation of STRTP ILS 87068.2(d), documented on LIC9102. Continued on LIC 809C...

LPA reviewed three staff personnel files on site at the facility on 12/13/2021. LPA interviewed two staff on site on 12/20/2021 at 11:30AM. LPA interviewed two clients currently taking psychotropic medication at between 10:30AM and 1:30PM. One client was on a family leave and three clients refused an interview. LPA conducted exit interview with Norhan Abolail, Residential Counselor at 2:00PM. LPA also provided the Summary Report to Davina Polanco, Director, and Noelle Kinder, Administrator through email. No Title 22 Deficiencies were cited at this time. One technical violation was given.

On 8/30/2022 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to finish the required annual inspection. LPA met with Noelle Kinder, Program Manager, who assisted in obtaining the files. At the time of the visit there were two clients and four staff members present. LPA reviewed ten staff files. LPA also interviewed one staff member. No Title 22 deficiencies were cited during this inspection. LPA conducted an exit interview with Noelle Kinder, Program Manager, at 12:20PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

Licensing Program Analysts Michelle Kyane conducted a case management inspection on September 15, 2022 at 11:05AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 7 out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated September 15, 2022. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Kyane observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on emergency intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their emergency intervention plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Noelle Kinder

On 11/4/2022 at 11:02AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an announced visit to the facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a Psychotropic Medications Inspection. LPA met with Jess Macintire, Medical Liaison. At the time of the inspection, there were two staff present and no clients in the facility. The facility currently has three clients, all three clients are prescribed psychotropic medications. LPA reviewed the three clients' files and their mental health binders. LPA observed Medical Liaison while conducting the pill count. There were no issues with the pill count. LPA reviewed the centrally stored medication binder and the Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMAR). LPA interviewed two staff members while in the facility. At 12:40PM, LPA Hood traveled to 262 North St. Aptos, CA 95003 where the staff files were kept. LPA met with April Pao, Program Manager, at 12:58PM, who assisted with obtaining the staff files. LPA reviewed five staff files and the training record. No citations were delivered during this visit. This inspection is not completed at this time, and LPA will return to the facility in order to conduct client interviews. LPA conducted an exit interview with April Pao, Program Manager, at 1:40PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

On 11/10/2022 at 4:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an announced visit to the facility. The purpose of this visit was to finish the Psychotropic Medications Inspection and interview the clients. LPA met with Britteny Raynor, Program Manager. At the time of the inspection, there were seven staff present and three clients in the facility. The facility currently has three clients, all three clients are prescribed psychotropic medications. LPA interviewed two client, the other one client declined to interview. LPA conducted an exit interview with Britteny Raynor, Program Manager, at 5:12 PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

Based on confidential interviews, review of the internal investigation, and review of the Sheriff's Office's report, one client alleges that they had an inappropriate, romantic and sexual, relationship with a staff member. Two clients allege that they had heard about inappropriate conduct done by the staff member, but none of the interviewees had viewed inappropriate behavior. Based on interviews, there was an allegation that the staff member gave a client a "hickey" during an outing in January 2022. This coincides with a movie outing that both the staff member and client attended. In daily log notes, staff documented seeing a red "hickey"-like mark on the client, but at the time client would not disclose how they received the mark. The accused staff member denies an inappropriate relationship during the internal investigation and an interview with Law Enforcement. Based on record review and confidential interviews, there is only one first-hand account of the relationship. Based on the information available at the time, the allegation that a staff member had an inappropriate relationship with a minor may or may not have occurred. This allegation has not met the preponderance of doubt and is therefore deemed unsubstantiated. LPA conducted an exit interview with Britteny Raynor, Program Manager, at 12:50PM, whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/3/2022 at 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the listed licensed agency. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the above allegation. LPA met with Joetsna Jocy Vidal. This complaint involves a staff member that was employed at another faciltity as well, there is crossover in the investigation. During the course of the investigation(s), LPA Hood conducted ten confidential interviews. LPA reviewed notes from an internal investigation, daily logs for all clients, alleged victim's Needs and Services Plan, and incident reports. In conjuction with the Community Care Licensing (CCL) investigation, the Santa Cruz Sheriff's Office conducted their own investigation. LPA Hood reviewed the redacted warrant request that the Sherriff's Office sent to the District Attorney.

narrative: Based on confidential interviews, review of the internal investigation, and review of the Sheriff's Office's report, four clients stated that the staff member did share marijuana and nicotine vape pens within the facility/facilities - three of the interviewed claimed that this was done specifically within Halcyon House. The accused staff member denies sharing the vape pens, but during their interview with Law Enforcement stated that they had not reported all of the times that they found youth using vape pens or after confiscating vape pens. Based on the recorded first-hand accounts, the allegations that staff member brought vape pens into the facility and the allegation that a staff member shared their vape with clients have met the preponderance of doubt and this allegation are substantiated. LPA delivered a citation for STRTP Interim Licensing Standards Version 4 87065.2(b) Personnel Duties (see LIC9099D). LPA delivered appeal rights and devised a Plan of Correction with Britteny Raynor, Program Manager. LPA conducted an exit interview with Britteny Raynor, Program Manager, at 12:50PM, whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

deficiencies.description:
87065.2(b) Personnel Duties:
Direct care staff shall...  Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times... duties that may be necessary to ensure the health and safety of children in the facility.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and confidential interviews, staff member allowed for youth to smoke within the facility and shared marijuana and nicotine vape pens with clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff member was let go on 2/15/2022 based on internal investigation into these allegations. Faciltiy did an additional refresher on child abuse prevention with all other staff.

narrative: Based on confidential interviews, five out of six interviewees state that staff prevent youth from physically fighting in care. The allegations that staff did not react in trauma-informed manner in emergency intervention situation, a staff member offered weed to a minor in care, and that staff do not prevent youth from fighting in care may or may not be true. The allegations have not met the preponderance of doubt, and therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. LPA conducted and exit interview with Jocey Vidal, Residential Counselor, at 1:50PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/14/2022 at 1:20PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the listed allegations. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted six confidential interviews. LPA reviewed training records, staff background clearance, clients files, facility Program Statement, and incident reports. Based on record review and confidetnial interviews, staff is trained in and consistently utilizing trauma-informed practicies during emergency situations. Based on confidential interviews, the staff alleged to offer weed to minor in care denies the allegations and explained that the youth discussed marijuana with them, but they declined the conversation. The reporting party declined to say which client this was, but the staff involved said they were aware of the situation at hand and the allegation may have been a misunderstanding.

The staff member was previously found to allow vape pens in the facility, which was previously substantiated and cited on in Complaint: 26-CR-20220217124844. Based on the MDI and the acceptance of the criminal case, the allegations that a staff member had inappropriate contact with a client has met the preponderance of the doubt and the allegation is substantiated. narrative: On 10/11/2023 at 10:36 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield, LPA Celest Aparicio, and Student Assistant Jasmine Cardena, conducted an unannounced inspection to the above licensed facility. The purpose of this visit is to conduct a case management inspection regarding an incident report received by the department regarding C1 (see LIC 811 dated 10/11/23). According to the report received, C1 was on awol from the facility and reported that they were sexually assaulted. LPA met with staff Joise Vidal who assisted with this inspection. A tour was conducted of the facility with staff Vidal. During a walk through of the facility LPA observed that one of the clients bedrooms had a missing socket plug. Staff stated that the room had been recently painted and the cover was taken off. Technical Advisory issued. LPA Belfield requested the following documents from staff Vidal: needs and service plan of C1, staff roster, and client roster. LPA also requested information on a past client whose name was unknown at the time of this inspection, but was later found by staff Vidal. Due to interviews that need to be conducted and more information that is needed, the inspection cannot be completed at this time and will be completed at a later date. Technical Advisory issued for buildings and grounds section 80078(a) of the Interim Licensing Standards. No violations were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report will be sent to staff Vidal and Administrator Noelle Kinder.

deficiencies.description:
87072 Personal Rights (c)(12)(C) Calls permitted to be restricted...shall not include calls to the child’s authorized representative, placement agency, family members (including siblings and relatives, except by court order), social workers, attorneys, Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA), probation officers, representatives designated by the child’s Indian tribe to participate in the juvenile court proceeding, Community Care Licensing Division of the California Department of Social Services or the State Foster Care Ombudsperson.

This requirement is not met evidenced by: Based on an incident report sent by the facility it was determined that the facility denied a client’s request to call their Authorized Representative. This is a violation of the client’s personal rights.
This poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will create a plan of action to address the phone personal rights violation. The facility will send LPA plan of action by 2/8/25.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an announced visit to the above listed facility to conduct a closure inspection. LPA met with Davina Polanco, Executive Director at 9:30 AM on 5/16/25. LPA Simien toured the facility and observed zero clients in care residing at the facility. Facility was cleared of client items. Davina Polanco, Executive Director surrendered the facility licence to LPA Simien. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Davina Polanco, Executive Director.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia scheduled a Technical Assistance (TA) meeting, via Teams, on above date and time. Attendees to the meeting were: Isabel Diego, Marjana Jackson, Ansar Muhammad, Scott Singer, Jeremiah Presinal, Noeli Zamora and Dan Thorne. The Notice of Incomplete Application sent to Hanna Center on June 19, 2024, was discussed. The following sections were provided with specific clarification. Plan of Operation: Section A - Purpose and Goals (LPA to send copy to SOC analyst) Program Statement: 12 – Participation of Family Members on Treatment and Outreach to Family – standards met 21 – Mental Health Program Approval - specific clarification 22 - Nursing Services - specific clarification Any questions will be directed to LPA Monica Pavia. The estimated re-submission of the Plan of Operation/Program Statement is Friday, July 12, 2024. A copy of this report will be emailed to Scott Singer with a request for signature and to be sent back for the file.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted a pre-licensing inspection on August 1, 2024, 10:00am, at the address listed above. Hanna Boys Center STRTP, Bldgs 403 and 404, has submitted an application for a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), to be licensed for a capacity of 16 ambulatory children ages 14-17, plus nonminor dependents (NMDs). This site inspection was conducted with Scott Singer. The following was observed: The entire Hanna Center campus is sprawled over 100 plus acres, with several multi-use buildings. The campus also includes a swimming pool, soccer field, outdoor basketball court, baseball field, tennis court, kitchen and dining hall, school/classrooms, recreation building, gymnasium, administration offices, health center, staff buildings, along with many congregate care/residential buildings. Building 403 (Carmel House), will be the initial house that receives STRTP placements. Bldg 403 has 10 total bedrooms. There will be an initial 6, single occupancy client bedrooms and 4 staff bedrooms, to be modified if needed for a maximum capacity of 8 clients for bldg 403. There is one dormitory style client bathroom with 4 toilet stalls, 3 urinals and 4 individual private showers. Four staff bedrooms each have a private bathroom. Medications will be kept in a lock box, locked in the staff office. Washer, dryer and cleaning supplies are kept locked in the laundry room. There is a large living room area with several couches, chairs, a television and closet of games. The clients will eat meals in the dining hall and meals will be prepared for them. There is a kitchenette in bldg 403 with a sink, dishwasher, stove, microwave, standard size refrigerator and cupboards. Perishable and nonperishable foods will be kept in bldg 403, along with food in the main kitchen and dining hall. Food for bldg 403 will be stocked, once clients are placed. New dishware, utensils and other kitchen cook ware for bldg 403 was ordered on 7/31/24. Sharps will be kept locked in the office. Individual beds and accommodating furniture were observed in each bedroom. Extra bedding and linens are housed in a warehouse on campus and will be moved into bldg 403, once clients are placed. First aid kit is in the office. Fire extinguishers are throughout the building. This building has been empty (no residents) for many years and the pilot light was turned off. Hot water to be tested prior to placements. Building 404 (Alverno House), is the exact same floor plan as building 403. Bldg 404 currently has live in staff in this building. Staff will be moved to a different building, once applicant is ready to accept additional 8 clients, after bldg 403 is at full capacity. Staff and client files are kept in a locked filing cabinet, in a locked office, in the administration building on campus. All signs and required forms to be posted, prior to placements.

The following items listed below were discussed and need to be completed. Applicant will notify LPA Pavia when completed. 1. Submit a waiver request for Naloxone (Narcan), to LPA Pavia. 2. Bathrooms and kitchen will have paper towels. (Use of common towels is prohibited.) 3. All trash and recycle bins are required to have secure lids. 4. Facility will post foster child's rights (2021) in common area of each building. 5. Add specific information to grievance/complaint policy on how/where a complaint form is to be submitted to staff. 6. Add Ombudsperson information to grievance/complaint policy. LPA Pavia will email instructions to request Narcan waiver. LPA will email medication forms. Reporting requirements were reviewed. An initial report for all reportable incidents is to be made by the next working day, either verbal or written. A full written report is to be remitted within 7 days via email to crpincsantarosa@dss.ca.gov. The submitted STRTP Plan of Operation/Program Statement (POO/PS) is under review. A copy of this report was given Scott Singer.

met_with: Director of Residence Jeremiah Presinal; Director of Transitional Programs Trisha Goodwin
narrative: At 11:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to the facility for a post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Director of Residence Jeremiah Presinal and Director of Transitional Programs Trisha Goodwin Directors informed LPA that the STRTP is not currently in operation. There is no set opening date at this time. There are no STRTP clients in care and none who have been served since licensure. There are no STRTP staff designated at this time. As such, no client or staff files were reviewed, and no interviews were conducted. LPA toured the facility sites. Based on LPA's observations, the facility sites are maintained in safe condition and the environment provides multiple options for recreation. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, no deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Director of Residence, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco traveled to the Creative Alternatives Main Office in Merced and conducted an unannounced Case Management for the Harmony House and met with Director Brandi Boehme. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss multiple incident reports regarding medication errors by Staff. LPA Tinoco reviewed incident reports from the Harmony House facility. It was discovered that there have been 4 medication errors due to staff for this facility (See LIC812 for details) in 2021. LPA Tinoco discussed with Director Brandi the concerns with the amount of incident reports regarding medication errors being received, LPA also addressed what the licensee has been done at the agency level to prevent this from happening, and what the ongoing plans are moving forward to minimize these incidents. Director Brandi stated that a company wide training on administration of medication. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst, Corina Carrillo, conducted a Case Management Inspection on September 22, 2021 at 9:35am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. 11 of 13 Staff files and 5 of 5 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 Confidential Names dated September 22, 2021 were reviewed, 4 direct care Staff and 5 youth were also interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Aaron Holloway, Facility Supervisor.

An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo traveled to the Harmony House STRTP in Merced, California. LPA met with Administrator Aaron Holloway and inspected the facility, inside and out. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 75 degrees. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted. No client requires medications currently, facility has the ability to keep medications locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Licensee has obtained Mental Health Certification Including the following: Mental Health Program Approval valid through September 24, 2021, a review was conducted on August 16-23, 2021 and have not been issued. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF valid through September 30, 2023. The facility has a county contract valid through June 30, 2022. Medical Certification valid through April 26, 2022. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. LPA reviewed three client files and conducted two staff and one client interviews. No Deficiencies were cited on today's visit. A copy of this report was left with Aaron Holloway.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco traveled to the Harmony House STRTP in Merced, California for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Annual Inspection. LPA met with Administrator Aaron Holloway and inspected the facility, inside and out. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 75 degrees. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. Facility keeps some canned foods and non-perishables in the home, there is no perishable food in the house at this time but has access to a full pantry located at Merced Ranch where they can stock the facility should they chose to open the house again. All required forms are posted. Facility has the ability to keep medications locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Licensee has obtained Mental Health Certification Including the following: The Facility is currently under a Corrective Action Plan which was accepted by DHCS on February 14, 2022, the facility expects a review with DHCS in May 2022. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF valid through September 30, 2023. The facility has a county contract valid through June 30, 2022. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Currently the facility is inactive, therefore no children or staff are in placement therefore no files were reviewed. No Deficiencies were cited on today's visit. A copy of this report was left with Aaron Holloway.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Lidia Tinoco and Cynthia Galindo met with Program Director Brandi Boehme. LPA's Received the board of resolution letter for Harmony house as the license is being forfeited. A copy of this report was left at the conclusion of the inspection.

On June 15, 2021, at 1:15 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jesus Cervantes conducted an unannounced annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to a Provisional STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on June 25, 2020. LPA was met at the facility by Administrator Celia Vasquez. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked file cabinet in the staff office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. There are two client bedrooms that contain one twin bed and two client bedrooms contain two twin beds. The facility has one client bathroom and one staff restroom located in a staff office. The water temperature in the bathroom one was tested at 12:54 PM and registered at 119.1 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrator Celia Vasquez is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection.

The facility employs one Clinical Director, one in-house Social Worker, one Care Coordinator, one House Manager, two Administrators, and ten direct care staff that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Licensee is in the process of obtaining their Mental Health (MH) Certification and expects issuance by the end of June 2021. Licensee is in the process of obtaining National Accreditation through CARF and expects accreditation by the end of 2021. Licensing fee payments are current. All the client files are stored and locked in the file cabinet in the staff office. At 2:15 PM, LPA reviewed a sample of four clients files during the time of inspection. Two facility staff were interviewed during the inspection. Four clients declined to be interviewed. All the staff files are stored in the back house/staff office area. At 3:45 PM, LPA reviewed sample of five staff files. All the staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulations requirements. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Facility procedures related to requesting exceptions. Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. LPA also discussed Reasonable and Prudent Parenting Standards, and resident involvement in development of planned activities. No deficiencies were found. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator Celia Vasquez.

On July 06, 2021 at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jesus Cervantes conducted an unannounced inspection with Facility Manager Celia Vasquez (S1). The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a case management to follow up on a preliminary report dated July 04, 2021 regarding the death of Client #1 (C1) at a nearby park. On July 03, 2021, at about 10:46 AM, the facility had reported Child #1 (C1) and Child #2 (C2) AWOL to City of Orange Police. Upon reporting C1 and C2 AWOL, facility staff discovered that a locked filing cabinet in the staff office had been broken into. In the cabinet was the clients cash resource book and medications. Facility staff accounted for all medications but discovered over $300 missing from the book. The facility suspects C1 and C2 may have broken into the locked cabinet and taken the money. The theft was also reported to City of Orange Police. The facility reported that on July 04, 2021, at about 6:51 AM, the facility was notified by an Orange County Sheriffs Coroners investigator that at about 5:00 AM, Orange Police Department responded to a local park regarding a found body. Upon police arrival, they located the deceased body of Child #1 (C1). Found next to C1 was two back packs, drugs, and drug paraphernalia. Investigative preliminary findings show this was a drug overdose per the Orange County Sheriffs Coroner’s investigator. The facility inquired about C2, but there was no information about the whereabouts of C2 at that time. The facility upon learning of the death of C1 notified the following agencies; Orange County Social Services, C1’s Social Worker, Orange County Probation Department, and Community Care Licensing. The facility has identified therapy and counseling services that are being provided to both clients and staff. C2 returned to the facility on July 5, 2021, at about 3:00 AM.

LPA Cervantes conducted confidential staff and client interviews. LPA Cervantes will be requesting the police reports and incident reports to be submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL). An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager Celia Vasquez.

regarding the allegation. LPA was unable to make a determination regarding the allegation. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Margaret Lentner conducted a case management inspection on April 27, 2022 at 9:44am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 7 out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated April 27, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Margaret Lentner observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Celia Vasquez - Administrator.

This is an amended LIC9099 to the original dated 05/02/2022. All confidential interviews disclosed that the clients cell phones are taken from them as a form of discipline when they lose their privileges. Confidential interviews revealed that the clients are asked to turn their cell phones in and if they do not then the staff will confiscate the charging cord to the cell phone. Based on confidential interviews Personal belongings are taken away from residents is substantiated which poses a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) version 3.1 section 87072(d) PERSONAL RIGHTS. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given and explained to Celia Vasquez, Facility Administrator.

With regard to the allegation that Facility manager does not work a sufficient number of hours, during confidential interviews it was revealed that there were times the facility manager was not working the correct number of hours due to a serious medical condition. LPA Smith was unable to interview the facility manager because they passed away. With regard to the allegation that Reporting procedures are fraudulent, during confidential interviews it was revealed that the procedures to submit a Serious Incident Report (SIR) is that the staff write the report and submit it to the facility administrator or clinician for review. Once the SIR is reviewed it is then submitted to the appropriate parties. All confidential interviews denied fraudulent reporting procedures and stated that the correct procedures are followed. Due to the lack of contact information being submitted, LPA was unable to obtain any clarifying information about this allegation. Regarding the allegation that Resident medicines are not locked, LPA Smith observed the resident medications were contained in a digital-lock safe. Confidential interviews revealed that prior to the facility keeping the resident medicines in the safe, the medications were contained in a locked file cabinet. Other confidential interviews stated that the medicine cabinet has been observed not being locked. Regarding the allegation that Residents are not treated with dignity, confidential interviews revealed that the clients are treated with respect and dignity. Additional confidential interviews revealed that clients have not witnessed staff being rude or disrespectful. Confidential interviews revealed that none of the staff members have ever cursed at the clients in care. During other confidential interviews it was revealed that the clients are being cursed at and not treated with dignity and respect. Based on confidential interviews, record review, and LPA observations, the allegations that Facility is out of ratio, Facility manager does not work a sufficient number of hours, Reporting procedures are fraudulent, Resident medicines are not locked, and Residents are not treated with dignity may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and Appeals Rights were provided and explained to Facility Administrator, Celia Vasquez.

deficiencies.description: This is an amended LIC9099 to the original dated 05/02/2022. (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless... is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9(a)(9) To make and receive confidential telephone calls ..., unless prohibited by court order. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews staff take away the clients cell phones as a form of discipline which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The Facility will immediately stop requiring clients to turn in their cell phones as a form of discipline. The Program Statement will be modified to reflect the change. The Facility will retrain staff on personal rights. Proof of this training and the topics covered will be emailed to LPA Smith by 05/31/2022.

narrative:
On 04/24/25, at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Celia Vasquez, Administrator, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve six ambulatory children ages 13-18 years old. The current census is zero children. The Facility is current with their licensing fees. The Facility is a single story dwelling and contains four bedrooms, two bathrooms, kitchen dinning area, two staff offices, and open living room. The garage is located behind the facility and is utilized for the mental health team and used for Child and Family Team Meetings. In the backyard there is a separate structure that is the Head of Service's office. A physical plant inspection was completed with Celia (S1, see LIC811 Confidential Names list) and included the following checks: all rooms listed in first part of this paragraph, locked safe with medications, first aid kit, toiletries, and food in kitchen. All beds were observed with appropriate bedding and mattress in good repair. Bedrooms contained adequate drawers and closet space. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted sample menu. **Continued on LIC809-C**

**Continued from LIC809** Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. The first aid kit was accessible to everyone and had all required supplies. LPA reviewed one staff file (S1) to ensure staff had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Staff records are stored in administrators office. Per review of Guardian, Celia has a criminal background clearance transferred. LPA conducted one staff interview (S1). Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and LIC811 were provided to Celia Vasquez, Administrator. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On April 21, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abdoulaye Traore conducted SB484 Psychotropic Medication tele-Inspection via Microsoft Teams. The tele-meeting was held with the Facility Administrators Esmeralda Rodriguez. and Celia Vasquez LPA conducted a virtual health and safety inspection with the Administrators. During the inspection, LPA guided and observed a medication count and interview with staff and the client (C1) taking psychotropic medication. All file and medication documents were sent to LPA Traore prior to inspection. LPA reviewed 1 client (C1) record and reviewed three staff records. LPA began three staff interviews including the Administrator at 10:00 AM LPA interviewed C1 at 11:15 AM. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Administrator Esmeralda and Celia. LPA scanned and emailed this LIC 809 to Esmeralda with a request for signature. Signed copies will be placed in the facility file.

On June 2, 2021, at 12:30 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jesus Cervantes conducted an unannounced annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to a Provisional STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on June 25, 2020. LPA was met at the facility by Administrator Celia Vasquez. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. A pool is located in the backyard. The pool is gated and secured with a locking gate. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked file cabinet in the staff office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All three bedrooms contain two twin beds. The facility has two client bathrooms. The water temperature in the bathroom one of two was tested at 12:54 PM and registered at 117.1 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrator Esmeralda Rodriguez is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. See Page Two.

The facility employs one Clinical Director, one in-house Social Worker, one Care Coordinator, two Administrators, and eight direct care staff that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Licensee is in the process of obtaining their Mental Health (MH) Certification and expects issuance by the end of June 2021. Licensee is in the process of obtaining National Accreditation through CARF and expects accreditation by the end of 2021. Licensing fee payments are current. All the client files are stored and locked in the file cabinet in the staff office. At 1:30 PM, LPA reviewed a sample of five clients files during the time of inspection. Two facility staff were interviewed during the inspection. Two clients declined to be interviewed. Four clients were not present at the facility during the inspection. All the staff files are stored in the back house/staff office area. At 2:45 PM, LPA reviewed sample of five staff files. All the staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulations requirements. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Facility procedures related to requesting exceptions. Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. LPA also discussed Reasonable and Prudent Parenting Standards, and resident involvement in development of planned activities. No deficiencies were found. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator Celia Vasquez.

Confidential interviews revealed that C1 and C2 were “horse playing” with each other and facility staff told stop. Confidential interviews revealed that C2 entered C2’s room after being told to stop. C1 entered C2’s room when facility staff was occupied and not looking. Confidential interviews revealed C2 then slapped C1 near C1’s groin. However, confidential interviews revealed C2 did not slap C1 near C1’s groin. Confidential interviews revealed that the incident was reported to staff by five days later. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that staff failed to supervise C1 and C2 resulting in C1 inappropriately touching C2 while in care may have occurred; however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Esmerelda Rodriguez.

narrative: An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson, on May 3, 2022, at 2:00PM. During the inspection, LPA Wilson met with Esmeralda Rodriguez, Administrator, and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed four of the four children’s records on site at the facility at 4:30PM. During the review of children’s records, LPA Wilson observed 4 out of 4 children (C1, C2, C3, C4) did not have a current Needs & Services Plan. Administrator was unable to locate Needs and Services Plans that provide updates at least every 30 days LPA reviewed three of three of the staff personnel files on site at the facility at 2:30PM. LPA interviewed three of three of staff on site at 3:50PM. LPA interviewed four of the four children currently taking psychotropic medication at 5:00PM. LPA conducted an exit interview with Esmeralda Rodriguez, via phone, and Claudia Bory, Direct Care Staff, at 7:00 PM. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and cited. Based on the records review and interview, LPA Wilson observed the Needs and Services Plan for four of four children (C1, C2, C3, and C4’s) record did not include Needs and Services Plans updated at least every 30 days. The facility will be cited under STRTP ILS, Version 4, Section 87068.3(a) Modifications to The Needs And Services Plan. LPA provided the Summary Report to Claudia Bory, Direct Care Staff, upon completion.

narrative:
concerned of what the packages contained. However, S1 opened a letter that was addressed to C1. The CSW stated that they were not aware of a letter being opened, but they were aware of the issue with the client receiving a high volume of packages that were not addressed to C1. Regarding the allegation that Personal belongings are taken away from residents, all confidential interviews disclosed that the clients cell phones are taken from them as a form of discipline when they lose their privileges. Confidential interviews revealed that the clients are asked to turn their cell phones in and if they do not then the staff will confiscate the charging cord to the cell phone. Based on confidential interviews Staff open resident mail, and Personal belongings are taken away from residents are substantiated which pose a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) version 3.1 section 87072(d) PERSONAL RIGHTS. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given and explained to Esmeralda Rodriguez, Facility Administrator.

With regard to the allegation that Facility manager does not work a sufficient number of hours, during confidential interviews it was revealed that there were times the facility manager was not working the correct number of hours due to a serious medical condition. LPA Smith was unable to interview the facility manager because they passed away. With regard to the allegation that Reporting procedures are fraudulent, during confidential interviews it was revealed that the procedures to submit a Serious Incident Report (SIR) is that the staff write the report and submit it to the facility administrator or clinician for review. Once the SIR is reviewed it is then submitted to the appropriate parties. All confidential interviews denied fraudulent reporting procedures and stated that the correct procedures are followed. Due to the lack of contact information being submitted, LPA was unable to obtain any clarifying information about this allegation. Regarding the allegation that Resident medicines are not locked, LPA Smith observed the resident medications were contained in a digital-lock safe. Confidential interviews revealed that prior to the facility keeping the resident medicines in the safe, the medications were contained in a locked file cabinet. Other confidential interviews stated that the medicine cabinet has been observed not being locked. Regarding the allegation that Residents are not treated with dignity, confidential interviews revealed that the clients are treated with respect and dignity. Additional confidential interviews revealed that clients have not witnessed staff being rude or disrespectful. Confidential interviews revealed that none of the staff members have ever cursed at the clients in care. During other confidential interviews it was revealed that the clients are being cursed at and not treated with dignity and respect. Based on confidential interviews, record review, and LPA observations, the allegations that Facility is out of ratio, Facility manager does not work a sufficient number of hours, Reporting procedures are fraudulent, Resident medicines are not locked, and Residents are not treated with dignity may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and Appeals Rights were provided and explained to Facility Administrator, Esmeralda Rodriguez.

deficiencies.description: (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless... is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9(a)(9) To make and receive confidential telephone calls and send and receive unopened mail, unless prohibited by court order.This requirement is not met as evidenced by Based on confidential interviews staff did not ensure that C1 was accorded dignity when staff opened C1’s mail and when staff takes away the clients cell phones which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The Facility will immediately stop requiring clients to turn in their cell phones as a form of discipline. The Program Statement will be modified to reflect the change. The Facility will retrain staff on personal rights. Proof of this training and the topics covered will be emailed to LPA Smith by 05/31/2022.

narrative: Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements, some interviews revealed S3 shoved C1 in the face while C1 and S3 were alone in the office, while other interviews revealed C1 followed S3 into the staff bathroom and grabbed the video gaming system and S3 held onto the gaming system for a few minutes before letting go. There are no other witnesses to the incident. As for the allegation that staff did not keep hazardous items inaccessible to minor, there is conflicting information. Some interviews revealed bleach bottles were always locked and inaccessible to clients, except when doing laundry, other interviews revealed bleach was left on top of the washing machine, while other interviews revealed C1 and C2 broke into the chemical closet to obtain the bleach, however, there are no witnesses that saw C1 with bleach in the facility during the incident. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed that staff handled C1 in a rough manner and staff did not keep hazardous items inaccessible to C1, which may or may not have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and appeal rights explained. deficiencies.description:
Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios:

87065.5(a)(1)  In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:  
Based on record review, the facility had a census of five clients and only had one direct care staff working on 11/02/2022 from 9:32-10:00 pm, 11/24/2022 from 7:00-11:54am and 7:56-10:00 pm, and 11/27/2022 from 8:00-10:00 pm, which posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per the Administrator, staff will communicate with the Administrator to let them know if they are out of ratio and an On-Call staffed  will be called to work the shift.  If a staff member needs to leave during their shift, the staff member will wait at the facility until the next staff arrives.   If an on call staff is unavailable, the Facility Administrator will respond to the facility.

narrative: Confidential interviews reported all clients who run away from the facility are given consequences when they return to the facility, such as a level drop and they are not eligible to go on outings or purchase fast food. Conflicting interviews reported C2 did not run away from the facility, rather was not always at the school pick up location, which was considered to be “run away.” Confidential interviews did not provide a preponderance of evidence to prove or disprove the allegation that staff do not treat minors equally. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were reviewed with Esmeralda Rodriguez, Facility Administrator. A signed copy of this report will be kept in the Facility file.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Angela King conducted a case management inspection on 6/13/23 at 10:18am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 13 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 13 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 6/13/23). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, quarterly report assessments, and client safety plans. The licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Rosas and LPM King, observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance with their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Esmeralda Rodriguez.

On February 20, 2024, at 10:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Celia Vasquez, Residential Director, to assess a Civil Penalty. LPA Linley requested copies of the staff roster and asked for any supporting documents the facility may have and what they provided was incomplete it was only the DOJ clearance. Staff roster indicated that S1 and S2 had been working at the facility. LPA Linley is administering two civil penalties during this visit. The facility is being cited for the violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, regulation 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. Record review confirms S1 and S2 have worked in the facility without a criminal record clearance. An immediate civil penalty is being issued for $1,000.00 An exit interview was conducted with Celia Vasquez, Residential Director. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Celia Vasquez, Residential Director. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz on July 10, 2024 at 10:00 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Munoz met with Administrator Celia Vasquez and Facility Manager, Yomaira Vasquez. LPA inspected the facility inside and out and did not observe any deficiencies. LPA reviewed two of two child’s records and two of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed two of two child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. narrative:
On September 24, 2024, at 11:00 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley conducted an unannounced annual required inspection. LPA was met at the facility by Mya Vasquez, Facility Manager, and Celia Vasquez, Residential Director. The purpose of this inspection is to conduct a required annual for the STRTP. The facility has a capacity of six clients with a current census of five clients. LPA toured the facility with Mya Vasquez and Celia Vasquez. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. A pool is located in the backyard. The pool is gated and secured with locking gate. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and 2-day perishable supply of food. The water temperature was measured at 125 degrees at 1:35 pm in the kitchen which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, Foster Care Ombudsman poster, and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients’ medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked file cabinet in the staff office. Medication records were observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. There are two cameras at the facility. One was located in the front of the home and the other was located in the backyard. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. All three bedrooms contain two twin beds. The facility has two client bathrooms. The water temperature in the bathroom one of two was tested and measured at 106 degrees at 1:36 pm, which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

All client files are stored and locked in the file cabinet in the staff office. LPA reviewed a sample of five client files to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22 (see confidential name list, dated 09/24/2024). LPA interviewed two clients. LPA reviewed a sample of five staff files (see confidential name list, dated 09/24/2024). All staff met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. All staff have proof in file of acknowledging the child abuse reporting requirements. LPA interviewed two staff. The licensing fee payments are current. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews on this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report was emailed to the Facility Administrator, Celia Vasquez. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On October 24, 2024, at 3:45 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley was at the facility conducting interviews. LPA was in the driveway and observed a 11.5 inch front windshield crack in front of the driver's side. Confidential interviews indicated the crack in the windshield has been there for over a month and the facility staff has been transporting residents in the van. The facility was asked if they had any documentation of the repairs or a repair date scheduled and LPA was informed there were no documents and a date had not been scheduled for the windshield repair. The facility is being cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80074(c) Transportation. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were reviewed with Mya Vasquez. Due to technical difficulties, a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to the Facility Administrator. A signed copy of this report will be kept in the Facility file.

deficiencies.description:
80074(c) Transportation: Motor vehicles used to transport clients shall be maintained in a safe operating condition.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by:  
LPA observed a 11.5 inch crack in the front windshield in front of the driver's seat. Confidential interviews indicated that the crack has been in the windshield for over a month and the facility has transported residents in the van,  which posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Mya Vasquez, a windshield repair person will be at the facility tomorrow and will replace the windshield. A photo of the new windshield will be sent via email to LPA by end of day on 10/25/2024.

narrative: interviews indicated that on 07/27/2024, the seat belts in the back of the facility car were not working properly while staff transported the residents, thus residents were not able to wear a seat belt while being driven to an outing. Based on confidential interviews and record review the allegations that S2 spoke inappropriately to a minor and staff did not provide safe transportation is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited for violations of the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards regulation 87072(c)(15) Personal Rights and California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80074(c) Transportation. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to Celia Vasquez. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights:
87072(c)(15) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights…… to be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:  
Based on confidential interviews and record review, on 07/27/2024, S2 called the residents  “bitches,” and told the residents, “what the fuck do you want me to do,” which posed immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

Transportation:
80074(c) Motor vehicles used to transport clients shall be maintained in a safe operating condition.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, on 07/27/2024, the facility transported the residents in the facility car and the residents rode in the back of the vehicle without a seat belt that did not work properly, which posed immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: On June 30, 2025, at 10:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu arrived at the facility to perform an annual inspection upon arrival LPA Mutialu met with Administrator, Celia Vasquez. Upon entrance, the LPA was made aware facility was under construction. A case management has been opened on 06/30/25 LPA observed renovations being performed at the facility and Community Care Licensing was not notified. LPA observed a construction worker performing renovations and no furniture in the facility. Per Administrator, Celia Vasquez licensing was notified of renovations when facility notified LPA Linely of facility temporary closure on 02/28/25 and 03/12/2025. LPA advised Administrator, Celia Vasquez there is no mention of restructuring the facility or renovations and only mentions restructuring the program and population served. The facility is receiving a Type B citation. LPA advised the Administrator an inspection must be conducted prior to enrolling clients. The Short-Term Residential Therapy Program facility is being cited for violating California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Section 80086: Alterations to Existing Building or new facility. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator, Celia Vasquez. A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the Administrator, Celia Vasquez.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco conducted an over the phone Case Management tele-inspection with Vernell Watts, Ramesha Savannah and Program Director, Clinard Fletcher, as a result of incident reports that were submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 9/25/2020. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss with Vernell and Fletcher the importance of filling out incident reports with information that meets the licensing standards. Based on the incident reports dated 9/19/2020, 9/20/2020, and 9/22/2020 that LPA Tinoco reviewed, it was determined that the licensing standards were not met and that more information needed to be included when submitting incident reports. According to the Program Director, an all staff retraining will be provided by Facility Administrator via Zoom on Monday October 5, 2020. Summary of training topics and signatures will be provided to LPA Tinoco by Tuesday October 6, 2020. Fletcher stated that they will also provide ongoing monthly training on Incident Reporting. The facility was issued a Technical Violation under the Interim Licensing Standards, 87061(j) Reporting Requirements. A copy of this report was given to Clinard Fletcher at the conclusion of the inspection.

On May 9, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) met with Mr. Fletcher to conduct a Case Management regarding the incident of May 5, 2022 where M1 and M2 absconded from the facility and attempted to car jack and individual. M1 assaulted a female driver in attempt to car jack her car. That individual left the scene and returned with her boyfriend who assaulted M2 as M1 ran back to the facility. M1 returned back to the facility and reported that M2 was shot. Upon this disclosure, staff contacted the House Manager (HM) and the HM informed Mr. Fletcher. Upon hearing of the incident Mr. Fletcher went to scene to find out what had happened. Mr. Fletcher was told by Fresno Police Department that M1 assaulted a female driver in hopes of car jacking that individual. The driver left the scene and returned back with her boyfriend who then assaulted M2 as he was still at the scene. M2 was not shot but sustained multiple contusions and was taken to the hospital where he was released the next morning. Mr. Fletcher contacted M1's probation officer and informed him of M1's actions. M1 was taken into custody upon the request of Mr. Fletcher and M1's bed closed. An incident report was sent to Community Care Licensing.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reyna Martinez conducted a case management visit at the STRTP and met with Joe Vargas. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss incident report's emailed to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on August 30, 2023. Based on further interviews and records review, for incidents that occurred on August 25, 2023 with Staff (S1). Clients (C1), (C2), (C3), (C4), and (C5) reported that S1 failed to provide supervision, protection, and care of the clients individually and in groups. S1 allowed clients in care to engage in inappropriate aggressive acts with each other without intervening. Licensee investigated and terminated S1 for violation of health and safety codes. Based on the information obtained, the STRTP is being issued a citation for the Personnel Duties 87065.2(b)(1). Interim Licensing Standards are being cited on the attached LIC809D page. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
87065.2 PERSONNEL DUTIES (b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties:
(1) Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview and record review, the Direct Care Staff (S1) failed to provide supervision, protection, and care of the clients individually and in groups by allowing clients to have a box match with each other and allowed clients to hit each other with a belt, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
