that during a scheduled Child and Family Team (CFT) meeting held via teleconference with C1 and at least six other participants, a female staff member on the conference call could be heard yelling at C1. During confidential interviews, the involved staff member was identified by three individuals who also participated in the call. It was reported that C1 was elevated and proceeded to curse and scream at participants. C1 was present in the facility with staff #2 (S2) and staff #6 (S6). All other teleconference participants were involved in CFT via telephone. Confidential statements further revealed that the teleconference facilitator made a point to stop interactions and inform female staff, S6, that S6’s behavior was not appropriate nor helpful in de-escalating C1. Based on confidential interviews, record reviews and witness statements, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The Department has determined the allegation that staff #6 yelled at youth is substantiated. The facility is being issued a citation for the facility staff’s actions, posing an immediate and/or potential risk to the children placed in care. These actions are in violation of the California Code of Regulations (CCR) Interim Licensing Standards Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Chapter 7.5, Articles 1-10, Version 3, Section 87072(d)(10) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were scanned and emailed to Mr. Franklin, Assistant Administrator. Original signatures will be filed in the complaint file.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/4/2020 at 1:35 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Natasha Dunlap made a tele-inspection due to COVID-19 with Harvest Safe Haven Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Assistant Administrator Brian Franklin to issue the investigative findings for the above stated allegation. On July 13, 2020, LPA Roby conducted a tele-inspection and observed no immediate safety hazards. During the investigation, LPA Roby conducted interviews with county social worker, seven facility staff (S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, and S7). Five of six clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, and C5) declined to be interviewed. Client #6 (C6) is no longer present in the facility and did not respond to LPA’s requests for information. As a result, C6 was also not interviewed during this investigation. LPA Roby also reviewed and obtained special incident reports and needs, and services plans from the STRP and children’s files. On July 10, 2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information which alleged staff yells at youth. It was reported to CCL that an unidentified female staff member yelled and engaged in unprofessional discourse with C1. Confidential witness statements revealed (continued on next page)

deficiencies.description: 87072(d)(10) Personal Rights - The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the the following personal rights: To be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons.This requirement was not met as evidenced by:  Staff #6 yelled at Client #1 during a CFT meeting held for the support of Client #1. This poses an immediate and/or potential risk to the children placed in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Assistant Administrator, Mr. Franklin a refresher training on personal rights will be conducted for all staff.  Proof of training (sign in sheets and/or training certificates) will be sent to LPA Dunlap no later than 11/17/2020.

narrative: On November 10, 2020 at 3:46 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jazmond Harris conducted a case management tele-inspection with Facility Manager, Brian Franklin in order to provide the information pertaining to the deficiencies being assessed for Direct Care Staff Supervisor (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated November 10, 2020). On September 17, 2020, LPA Harris conducted an interview with Direct Care Staff Supervisor in order to obtain further information regarding a separate incident which occurred at the facility on September 11, 2020. Supervisor stated she was closely supervising an incident where allegations were reported from. It was advised that clients were throwing apples into the neighbors' yard. Supervisor stated that when the incident occurred, she was standing at the back sliding door of the facility. Supervisor stated she supervising the clients and also encouraged one of the client to not engage in the inappropriate behavior. Supervisor also stated that once client came inside, he did not exit out of the facility. At a later time, LPA Harris was able to review video surveillance footage of the incident which she had interviewed Supervisor about. LPA Harris observed that Supervisor came to the back sliding door, after the client came inside and grabbed a piece of fruit off the table, which he threw in the neighbor's yard. The client was able to come back inside, grab another piece of fruit and throw it before Supervisor was in the vicinity and provided directives. The information that Supervisor provided was not accurate according to the footage. LPA Harris discussed the information with Director, Daniel Park and advised that the false statement provided violated the Interim Licensing Standards. The facility will be cited on False Claims, section 80012(a). An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. Due to the COVID 19 guidance, an electronic copy of this report, Confidential Names List, and Appeal Rights were sent to Facility Manager for review and signature. The signed copy will be retained in the facility file.

Client #5 had an apple in his hand and was making a throwing motion towards the backyard fence. Supervisor stated she asked Client #5 not to throw the apple. Supervisor stated Client #5 threw the apple, but stated it was an accident. Supervisor stated she thought the apple only hit the fence. Confidential interviews stated Client #5 did throw the apple, but it was an accident. Information obtained stated it was also believed that the apple hit the fence. It was advised that a staff member was inside the facility in the kitchen area. Confidential interviews had conflicting stories regarding the supervision. The facility is approved to have surveillance cameras. LPA Harris requested and reviewed the surveillance camera footage with Administrator, Daniel Park. LPA Harris observed Client #2 and Client #5 outside in the backyard, by themselves. Client #5 had an object in his hand and was making a throwing motion. Client #5 entered the facility and came back outside and made another throwing motion. The footage on the inside of the facility showed no staff member at the door as advised. The Supervisor enters the frame after the two clients returned into the facility. Based on interviews and surveillance footage, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove facility staff are not adequately supervising youth. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated at this time. This poses a health, safety, and/or personal rights risk to the foster children in care. The facility will be cited on Personnel Duties, section 87065.2 (b)(1). Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report and appeal rights will be provided and the signature will be retained in facility file.

deficiencies.description:
87065.2(b)(1) Personnel Duties. Direct Care Staff shall perform the following duites:
Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups.

This was not exhibited by: Client #5 was not being supervised when he threw the apple into the neighbors' yard.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, all staff will be retrained regarding providing adequate supervision to ensure the safety and security of the facility and neighboring areas.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Natasha Dunlap spoke with the group home director, Daniel Park, to serve immediate exclusion orders and Government Code 11522 for employee #1 (E1). See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 12/15/2020, for the individual involved. Mr. Park, group home Director informed LPA that E1 was hired on 6/16/2020 as a shift manager. Per the Director, all newly hired staff have reference checks completed with previous employers and the Licensing office. All staff have fingerprints associated to work at the licensed facility. E1 worked approximately five months for Harvest Safe Haven facility number 336427799 located at 5425 Sierra Vista Ave Riverside. LPA advised Mr. Park, group home Director of the requiring immediate exclusion orders from any continued or future contact with clients or presence of this person in the facility constitutes a threat to the health and safety of the clients in care. LPA will provide the Director with copies of the immediate exclusion orders and instructed facility to adhere to the order immediately. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was scanned and emailed to Mr. Park, Director with request for signature. Signed copies will be complaint in facility file.

An informal conference was held with Harvest Safe Haven For Boys to discuss current Community Care Licensing (CCL) concerns. Present at the meeting was LaCresha Cook, Regional Manager, Abdoulaye Traore, Licensing Program Manager, Adaleyci Caballero, Licensing Program Analyst, Shanae Pharaoh, Licensing Program Analyst, Lachelle Fenison, Harvest Safe Haven For Boys Administrator, Daniel Park, Harvest Safe Haven For Boys Chief Executive Officer, Susan Pennington, Harvest Safe Haven For Boys Licensed Clinical Social Worker Supervisor, Jason Brunt, Harvest Safe Haven For Boys Board President, Diana Wagner, System of Care Branch, Janelle Ross, Riverside County Placement Liaison, Karen Atkins, Riverside County, David Guitierez, Sandi Snelgrove, Alexandria, Andrews, Department of Health Care Services, Juan Bretado, Riverside County Probation, and Rose Collins, San Bernardino County Placement Liaison. The following information was discussed: SIR's are required to have additional information to indicate precursor to incidents, interventions used according to EIP, and staff follow up. Level system needs to be trauma informed. AWOL policy needs to be trauma informed. EIP needs to be more trauma informed. Program must ensure staff understand the EIP. Update to Program Statement. The facility has agreed to the following: The Clinical Supervisor will review all incident reports before submitting to CCL to ensure clinical interventions, follow-up, and debriefing summary are included. Program Statement will include updated incentive system addendum.

Facility has implemented training and coaching for staff with the Rehab Specialist. Facility will update their Program Statement to address areas mentioned above. Facility will update their Program Statement to include the Risking Connection Model and additional treatment for creating a trauma informed milieu. Facility will ensure staff are receiving training on implementing three trauma informed interventions for all incidents occurring at the facility. Facility will submit their corrective action plan including their addendum to their Program Statement by October 1, 2021. A copy of this report was given and explained to Lachelle Fenison.

met_with: Lachelle Fenison - Admin and Daniel Park CEO
narrative: Licensing Program Manager, Angela King, Licensing Program Analyst, Margaret Lentner conducted a case management inspection on September 28, 2021, at 10:28am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. 5 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 confidential names dated 9/28/2021, were reviewed. 3 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 6 youth were interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedure were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Lachelle Fenison, Administrator STRTP.

Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection 06/28/22 at 8:40 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 06/28/22). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dina Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Daniel Park, Executive Director.

On March 4, 2022 at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shanae Pharaoh conducted an unannounced Annual Required Inspection and met with Facility Director Daniel Park and Administrator Lachelle Fenison. LPA disclosed the purpose of the inspection and was granted entry into the facility by the Administrator. The facility is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1: Has two twin beds -Sleeps C1 and C2 · Bedroom #2: Has two twin beds - Sleeps C3 and C4 Bedroom #3: Has two twin beds -Sleeps C5 and C6 The facility was inspected inside and out with Facility Administrator. The facility is a one story residence with 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms, a study room, staff office, and mental health office. Four clients were present at time of inspection. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the Kitchen was measured to be an adequate temperature. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the staff office. The medication logs are kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a cabinet in the garage. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. The First Aid Kit is located in the staff office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors in the bedrooms were checked and operable. The carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway was operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Facility Administrator. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and current menu. The Facility received Mental Health Approval on January 21, 2022 and CARF Accredidation expires on ,2023

The facility received Mental Health Approval effective January 21, 2022 - January 21, 2023 and CARF Accredidation expires on May 31, 2024. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food; snacks availabletwo clients were interviewed during the inspection. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Patio furniture was available. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There are no bodies of water on the premises. 6 of 6 client and and five of 13 staff files were reviewed during the inspection. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. LPA did not observed lock boxes for 6 of 6 clients C1, C2, C3, C4, C5 and C6 and LPA did not observe the hire dates located in 4 of 5 staff files S1, S2, S3 and S5. The administrator purchased the lock boxes and updated the staff files with their hire dates during the inspection. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews on this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was be provided to the facility representatives.

This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Covarrubias met with Administrator, Lachelle Fenison and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed two of child’s records and three of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed two of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed three of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA attempted to interview 1 of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. During the inspection the LPA observed deficiencies (see attached 809D), plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Administrator, Lachelle Fenison.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi on February 28, 2024 at 08:59 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Choi met with Administrator Lachelle Fenison and conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility. narrative:
On June 07, 2024, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Rafael Enriquez and Maryjane Perez conducted an unannounced required 2-year inspection and met with Licensee Daniel Park. LPAs disclosed the purpose of the visit and was granted entry into the facility. Two clients were present and three staff were present in the facility during the inspection. The facility is a four bedroom, two bathroom house composed of one office, two living rooms, a dining area and kitchen. One bathroom is located inside the office for staff. The facility has an outdoor space accessible to clients in care. Facility Manager Patrick Holland accompanied LPAs inside and out of the facility during inspection. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following areas: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Video games and movies were observed for children’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. Licensee had provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured to be 107.6 degrees.

Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. The facility has an exception on file to use the cameras and are meeting the terms and conditions. Administrator Lachelle Fenison is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by LIC 500 Personnel Report. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one Therapist, two Clinical Social Worker, a Facility Manager, and 9 Direct Care Staff. Licensee has obtained a Mental Health contract with Riverside County. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF). The Accreditation is valid through May 31, 2027. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0.00. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Personnel files are maintained off-site at the corporate office. All appropriate personnel who require Caregiver Background Checks have received Criminal Record and Child Abuse Index clearances. A review of clients’ records was also completed. Client and staff interviews were conducted and revealed no health and safety concerns. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Licensee Daniel Park.

Regarding the allegation that a minor is being hit while in care, it was specifically alleged that C1 stated that C1 was hit and beaten at the facility. During the investigation, confidential interviews denied that C1 was hit or beaten at the facility. It was added that C1 got along with staff and other clients. LPA attempted to interview C1, C2 and C3, however they refused to be interviewed. LPA attempted to interview C4 and C6 on multiple occasions. LPA was unable to gather additional information. In regard to the allegation that staff threatened a minor, it was specifically alleged that staff stated they were going to whoop C1 later. During the investigation, confidential interviews denied that staff threatened C1 or any other client. It was added that C1 never reported being threatened to staff. LPA attempted to interview C1, C2 and C3 however they refused to be interviewed. LPA attempted to interview C4 and C6 on multiple occasions. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that C1 was being hit while in care and that staff threatened C1 may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were reviewed and provided to facility representative.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that that staff did not prevent minor from sending inappropriate pictures while in care, it was specifically alleged that C1 sent one of the group home staff pictures of private parts that appear generated online. During the investigation, confidential interview stated that staff received pictures of a man in underwear and a picture of a sexual related toy to staff’s personal cellphone. It was added that staff did not have a company phone and that staff’s phone number was written on the board in the office. Other confidential interviews stated that inappropriate pictures were sent to the printer in the staff office. The confidential interviews continued stating that the clients had lost the Wi-Fi privilege, and the printer was taken off the Wi-Fi. LPA attempted to interview C1, C2 and C3 however they refused to be interviewed. LPA attempted to interview C4 and C6 on multiple occasions. An additional witness interview did not reveal any information the allegation. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff did not prevent C1 from sending inappropriate pictures while in care may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were reviewed and provided to facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On June 27, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez arrived at Harvest Safe Haven Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Administrator Lachelle Fenison to deliver the finding for the allegation stated above involving the STRTP staff and clients (C1, C2, C3, C4 C5 and C6) as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated June 27, 2024. On December 07, 2023, LPA Enriquez initiated the investigation at the STRTP and obtained pertinent documents. Additionally, LPA conducted a safety inspection of the STRTP, no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the inspection, LPA interviewed staff S1, S2, S3, S4 and C5. LPA attempted to interview C1, C2 and C3 however they refused to be interviewed. LPA attempted to interview C4 and C6 on multiple occasions. On December 07, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff did not prevent minor from sending inappropriate pictures while in care.

narrative:
In regard to the allegation that staff do not properly safeguard the minors’ personal belongings, it was specifically reported that when items get stolen staff do not assist and have even said on occasions it’s not staffs fault client’s get stolen from even when staff are asked to monitor client’s belongings, therefore, clients are not reimbursed for stole items. During investigation, multiple interviews disclosed that each client is given a lock box to keep their smaller belongings and client’s may store belongings in the office as well. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that clients are aware from the beginning that if they do not store their belongings in their lock box nor the office, then staff will not be responsible for stolen belongings but if they are stolen from either of the two options then staff will replace and take full responsibility. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that when a client gets something stolen, staff do not do anything about it nor reimburse clients. Another confidential interview disclosed that when stuff gets stolen staff do a great job reimbursing clients. LPA received conflicting information. In regard to the allegation that staff do not prevent the minors from attacking other minors, it was specially disclosed that a staff member was jumped and attacked by three clients and the facility has done nothing. During investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that fights are not a common occurrence at the facility. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that all staff have TCI (trauma informed care) training including de-escalation techniques and intervene properly. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that when a fight occurs staff will break it up. In regard to the allegation that staff do not provide adequate care and supervision to the minors and that staff do not ensure the minors attend school consistently, it was specifically reported that clients continuously AWOL (absent without leave) and don’t attend school. During investigation, multiple interviews disclosed that certain clients refuse to attend school, staff work with them by looking into independent school programs where clients only need to attend class a few days a week and that has worked well for clients. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that when a client AWOLs staff will take away home passes and that all clients attend school unless they are sick. Additionally, another confidential interview disclosed that staff watch clients AWOL and if they don’t come back staff will call the police, and that staff do not make sure clients attend school. Furthermore, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff use incentives to get clients to attend school and to prevent client’s AWOLs. Another confidential interview disclosed that staff do not make sure clients attend school. LPA received conflicting information.

In regard to the allegation that staff threaten the minors with eviction, it was specifically reported that staff threaten to kick out clients. During investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff have never threatened to evict a client. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that staff will have conversations with clients to remind them they are to abide their contracts otherwise they will be removed. Another confidential interview disclosed that the administrator will have conversations at Child, Family and Team (CFT) meetings if a client needs to be removed for their own safety but not threatened with eviction. Another confidential interview disclosed that staff will threaten to kick clients out whenever staff get annoyed. LPA received conflicting information. In regard to the allegation that staff do not provide the minors with water, it was specifically reported that clients can go days without water because staff forget. During investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that there is always water available at the facility. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that one time the clients went three days without water. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that there is a water dispenser that always has water, and clients are all given a reusable water bottle that they may refill whenever they want. Additionally, a confidential interview disclosed that when the water jug runs out clients may replace it themselves and do not need to wait on staff. LPA received conflicting information. In regard to the allegation that staff do not provide comfortable accommodations for the minors, it was specifically reported that clients can’t even comfortably sleep without the worry of something happening. During investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that a client may request a bedroom change and staff will accommodate clients as long as it’s appropriate. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that they feel safe living at the facility. Another confidential interview disclosed that staff provide comfortable accommodations for clients. Other confidential interviews disclosed that clients feel safe at the facility.

Based on interviews, the allegations that staff do not properly safeguard the minors personal belongings; staff do not prevent the minors from attacking other minors; staff do not provide adequate care and supervision to the minors; staff do not ensure the minors attend school consistently; staff threaten the minors with eviction; staff do not provide the minors with water; staff do not provide comfortable accommodations for the minors may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, this allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Trainee, Christie Anderson.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/25/2025, at 11:05 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez conducted an unannounced visit to Harvest Safe Haven for Boys and met with Administrator Trainee, Christie Anderson to deliver the investigative finding for the allegations listed above. This complaint concerns staff at the facility and clients 1-6 (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811). On 11/05/2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint that staff do not properly safeguard the minors personal belongings; staff do not prevent the minors from attacking other minors; staff do not provide adequate care and supervision to the minors; staff do not ensure the minors attend school consistently; staff threaten the minors with eviction; staff do not provide the minors with water; staff do not provide comfortable accommodations for the minors. On 11/15/2024, LPA MaryJane Perez conducted a health and safety inspection at the facility and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. In addition, LPAs obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed staff 1-4 (S1, S2, S3, and S4), and clients 1, 2, 4, and 6 (C1, C2, C4, and C6), C4’s county social worker (CSW), and client 3 and 5 (C3 and C5) refused to be interviewed.

narrative: the neighbors have been calling and reporting that some clients have been disturbing them. Another confidential interview stated that the clients do not disturb the neighbors. Additional confidential interviews stated that they believe staff does as much as they could when it comes to doing a good job supervising the clients. On the other hand, confidential interview stated they believe the staff needs to have more supervision on the clients when they are outside or when they leave facility. Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documents, the allegation that staff did not adequately supervise minors may have happened or is valid but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and given to facility manager Jeamah Johnson.
investigation_findings: 13On June 27, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez made an unannounced visit to Harvest Safe Haven for Boys STRTP and met with facility manager Jeamah Johnson to deliver the finding for the above stated allegation. On May 06, 2025, Community Care Licensing received complaint allegation that staff did not adequately supervise minors. On May 08, 2025, LPA M. Perez conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility, and no hazards were observed. LPA M. Perez interviewed staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), staff 3 (S3), staff 4 (S4), staff 5 (S5), staff 6 (S6), client 1 (C1), client 2 (2), client 3 (C3), client 4 (C4), client 5 (C5) and client 6 (C6). During investigations, confidential interviews reported that clients are always supervised by staff while in care, but clients have unauthorized absences frequently. Other confidential interviews stated that staff keep in contact with the clients when they have an unauthorized absence. Other confidential interviews stated that when a client has an unauthorized absence, they will come back around 11PM or even as early as 4AM but once they are back, they regain staff supervision. Another confidential interview stated that

narrative: S4 became upset by this and retaliated by pepper spraying C2 and C3. Furthermore, it was reported that S4 also physically struck C1, C2 and C3 during this incident. A review of the facility’s video surveillance footage showed that S4 was sprayed with “silly string” by C2 and C3. The video footage revealed that S4 appeared to have pepper sprayed C2 and C3 (this was later admitted by S4). In addition, the video showed that C1, C2 and C3 physically reacted by attacking S4 after S4 pepper sprayed C1 and C2, therefore, S4 hit C1, C2 and C3. The video clearly shows S4 throwing closed fist punches on the minors’ head and body areas. Confidential interviews with staff and clients corroborated the allegations. Confidential interviews also reported that S4 admitted to brining in an unauthorized chemical agent (pepper spray) into the facility. Further confidential interviews also confirmed that S4 admitted to physically striking clients in care. Confidential interviews and document review confirmed that Law Enforcement responded to the facility and arrested. S4 was charged with child abuse according to the report. Based on confidential interviews, a review of pertinent documentation and a review of the facility’s video surveillance footage, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegations that that staff hit C2 in care and staff pepper sprayed C1 and C2 in care are substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87072(c)(11) Personal Rights, (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child…is accorded the personal rights…. (11) To be free of physical...emotional, or other abuse, ... humiliation, intimidation, ridicule,...mental abuse, or other actions ... interference with the daily living functions... (see LIC 9099D). An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report (LIC 9099), deficiencies page (LIC 9099D) and appeal rights were explained and given to Lachelle Fenison, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On 07/17/2025, at 08:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced visit to Harvest Safe Haven for Boys (STRTP) and met with Administrator Lachelle Fenison to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. On 11/06/2024, Community Care Licensing received allegations that staff hit minor in care and staff pepper sprayed minors in care. On 11/15/2024, LPA Maryjane Perez conducted a health and safety inspection at the STRTP, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the investigation, LPA Perez obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed C1, C2, C3, C4 and C6 (C1-C4, C6) and staff 1, 2, 3, 6 and 7 (S1-S3, S6, S7). C5 declined LPA’s request for an interview and staff 4 and 5 were interviewed by Riverside County Open Case Investigations (OHI). In regard to the allegations that staff (S4) hit minor (C1) in care and staff (S4) pepper sprayed minors (C2, C3) in care; it was reported that C2 and C3 sprayed S4 with “silly string.” It was further reported that CONTINIUED ON THE NEXT PAGE

deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(11) Personal Rights, c) The licensee shall ensure that each child…is accorded the personal rights…. (11) To be free of physical...emotional, or other abuse, ... humiliation, intimidation, ridicule,... mental abuse, or other actions ... interference with the daily living functions....

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and a review of documents and video footage, there was clear evidence that S4 physically hit clients in care and used pepper spray on clients in care. This poses immediate health and safety or personal rights risks for the client in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The facility terminated the employment of S1 on the day of the incident.  In addition, the facility provided follow-up Trauma Informed Re-training for all facility staff. 

The facility has agreed to provide a memo for all facility staff that reminds them that chemical agents (ie. pepper spary/mace) are not allowed in the facility.

The facility has agreed to provide proof of documentation of the above mentioned training and their plan to draft a memo regarding chemical agents; to be submitted via email to LPA Choi, no later than the close of business on 7/18/2025.

met_with: Daisy Delgad Director of Residential Program
narrative: On November 17, 2020 at 1:00 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cameo Banks made an announced tele-visit to Hathaway Sycamores for the purpose of conducting a Case Management- Deficiencies Visit. LPA spoke with Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Program, Gina Peck-Sobolewski, Vice President and Tasian Taylor, Administrator via Microsoft Teams. During a Case Management visit, it was discovered that Staff #1 had improperly restrained Child #1 on June 17, 2020 when Child #1 attempted to leave quarantine area. Per interview statement obtained from from Staff #1, Staff indicated that Child #1 was attempting to leave quarantine area and stood in front of door to discourage Child from leaving. Child #1 ignored staff's demands to stay inside and attempted to barge through the exit, pushing through Staff #1. Child #1 admitted to striking Staff #1 in the face. Video footage was reviewed and it was observed that staff tried to prevent Child #1 from leaving quarantine area by placing him in a one man restraint. Staff #1 admitting to restraining Child #1 by himself, despite a second staff member being present. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3, Chapter 7.5. See LIC809-D. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, including the appeal rights, will be emailed to Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Program.

met_with: Daisy Delgado Director of Residential Programs
narrative: Staff #1 did not hit Child #1. Staff also indicated that all attempts were made to safeguard Child #1's belongings. Interview statements from staff revealed that Child #1's clothing was collected from his room, washed and brought to him in quarantine. Due to lack of evidence, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred; therefore, the above allegations iare Unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Ms. Delgado to sign and return.

investigation_findings: 13On December 1, 2020 at 2:30 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cameo Banks conducted a follow-up complaint inspection via telephone to Hathaway-Sycamores and spoke with Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Programs. narrative:
On May 3, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted a Case - Management Incident inspection via Microsoft Teams Meeting to deliver and discuss findings from the Department’s Investigation on self-reported incident SIR #710958, dated August 8, 2020. LPA met with Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Programs. On August 9, 2020, Community Care Licensing received an incident report reporting assaultive behavior by Staff #1 (S1) on Client #1 (C1). It was reported in part, that S1 and C1 were involved in a physical altercation resulting in injury to C1. The incident was referred and assigned to Investigations Branch, Investigator, Dennis Seng. The investigation including confidential interviews, review of related records and review of facility video surveillance footage revealed evidence to support physical abuse by S1 on C1. On August 8, 2020, during an altercation outside of the facility Cottage, C1 became upset that S1 confiscated a portable speaker from C1 for refusing to lower the volume after being asked by S1 to lower it several times. C1 attempted to retrieve the speaker from S1; however, S1 refused to return the speaker to C1. C1 “flicked,” S1’s hat and pushed him. S1 pushed C1 back and a physical altercation ensued between them. Staff #2 (S2) intervened and separated both parties. C1 was led to Program Support (PSS). After sitting at PSS for several minutes, C1 ran back to the Cottage and pushed S1 again. S1 pushed C1 back and another physical altercation ensued between parties. S2 ran back to the Cottage and separated both parties. Both altercations were captured on surveillance footage. (Continued on page LIC809-C)

C1 was checked by the facility nurse and later taken to the hospital for further assessment. Medical records revealed C1 was hit with fists several times and placed in a chokehold, sustaining mild swelling and a brief loss of consciousness. After the altercation S1 left the facility and never returned. On August 9, 2020, S1 called the facility to officially resign from his position. Upon occurrence, the facility contacted all required parties and conducted an internal investigation pertaining to the incident. Corrections concerning facility policy and procedures pertaining to this incident were reviewed and updated as necessary. Based on gathered information there is corroborating evidence to support claims of abuse. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has therefore determined substantiated findings for physical abuse by S1 on C1 as evidence revealed S1 failed to de-escalate the situation or call for assistance in controlling C1's behavior. S1’s actions on C1 poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care. The facility is issued a citation in accordance with the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1; 87072 (d)(11) Personal Rights. See page 809D for deficiency. Exit interview conducted; Appeal Rights issued, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Ms. Delgado for signature.

Information revealed C2 was the victim of sexual assault from C1. C2 was reportedly scared of C1 and C1 forced C2 to engage in sexual acts. According to statements from an eyewitness having firsthand accounts of the incident occurring on December 10, 2020, it was observed C2 was not performing sexual acts, but was receiving sexual acts from C1. While statements provided contradicting information, the incident may have been a consensual encounter. The incident occurred during the overnight shift. The incident was reported to staff who contacted C2 privately and C2 confirmed that he performed oral sex on C1. C1 was moved to a single room after the incident. All appropriate reporting and contacts were completed concerning the incident. According to statements, C2 complied with C1 due to being threatened by C1 and feeling scared. Statements obtained revealed contradicting information concerning a pre-established rule that requires residents who share a room with their roommates to keep their doors open when both residents are occupying the room. In addition, statements revealed that not all staffs properly conduct 15-minute room checks of the residents as facility policy require staff to conduct. Based on information gathered, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined facility neglected to adequately monitor residents resulting in inappropriate sexual contact by C1 and C2; thus, posing potential risk to the children placed in care. Therefore, facility is cited under the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. See page 9099D for deficiency. Exit interview conducted; Appeal Rights issued and a copy of this report will be emailed to Ms. Delgado for signature.
investigation_findings: 13On May 3, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin met with Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Programs via Microsoft Teams Meeting to deliver and discuss findings from the investigation concerning the allegation as mentioned above. The investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing Special Investigator, Edward Hector. On December 14, 2020, Community Care Licensing received claims alleging a lack of supervision resulting in inappropriate sexual contact between clients as it was reported that Client #2 (C2) was a victim of sexual assault by Client #1 (C1) while in the facility. The investigation included a review of client files, review of the Los Angeles Sheriffs Department report and confidential interviews conducted with clients and staff members. The investigation revealed from gathered information, C1 and C2 engaged in oral sex. Reportedly, C1 coerced C2 to have oral sex with him. (Continued on next page LIC9099-C)

deficiencies.description:
80078 (a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Information obtained from statements revealed facility failed to adequately monitor residents resulting in inappropriate sexual contact/acts between Client #1 and Client #2 while in the facility therefore posing potential risk to the health and safety of children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee shall submit a written statement describing how the facility will always ensure proper supervision for the safety to clients and ensure facility follows its policies and procedures to prevent such incidents from re-occurring. Please include proof of all training including topic, name of Trainer, proof of certification and sign-in list of those in attendance (if applicable).

met_with: Daisy Delgado Director of Residential Programs
narrative: Staff indicated that Child #1 never mentioned any pain or head injury. However, Child #1 was taken to hospital to address escalated behavior. There were no injuries noted during hospital visit. There were no witnesses, documentary or physical evidence to corroborate allegations. There was no evidence to suggest that Child #1 was injured as a result of restraint. Additionally, there was no evidence to suggest that facility is serving a poor quality of food based on review of menus, client and staff statements. Interviews were also held with both clients and staff. Clients expressed that during some meals, inside of chicken was observed to be pink in color. Clients indicated although food is not seasoned well, there is a variety of food to chose from. Staff expressed that clients have complained about taste of food and alternatives were provided. Staff were not able to confirm that poultry served was raw or pink. Due to lack of evidence, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred; therefore, the above allegations are Unsubstantiated
investigation_findings: 13On July 7, 2021 at 2:30 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cameo Banks conducted a follow-up complaint inspection via Microsoft Teams to Hathaway-Sycamores and spoke with Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Programs. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation of the allegations, LPA conducted interviews and reviewed documents. Based on interviews, there were no statements to suggest Child #1 sustained a head injury while being restrained by staff. Nor was there evidence to support facility is serving a poor quality of food. Staff denied all allegations. Staff indicated that Child #1’s behavior had become unsafe and as a result, initiated a Pro-Act standing restraint. Staff continued to use continued to use crisis communication as they explained to Child #1 that he was going to be escorted to Program Support Services (PSS). While in PSS, Child #1 continued to pose a threat to himself by tieing his sock around his neck tightly. Child #1 was placed in another restraint to remove his shoes, which had laces, to further prevent client from causing self harm. Staff stated they did not observe any head injuries on Child #1. Continued on LIC809-C

narrative: On September 21, 2021, at 8:00am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Emelyn Sanchez P. and Olivia Rosas arrived at the above facility unannounced for the purpose of conducting a SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Case Management- Medication Inspection Visit. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas met with Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Treatment Programs. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas reviewed six (6) client files and three (3) staff files. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas conducted three (3) client interviews and three (3) staff interviews. Currently there are twenty-one (21) clients residing in the above facility. This is a facility located in a residential area and equipped with a kitchen/dinning room, three cottages that have a living room, laundry space, small kitchen, bathrooms and bedrooms. There is also an Art Room, Recreational Hall, Medication Office, an outdoor BBQ patio, and basketball court. Outdoor space is free of obstructions. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed adequate staffing in the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas also observed medication to be centrally stored, triple locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

There were no witnesses identified to corroborate the allegation. investigation_findings: 13On October 6, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) JoAunne Griffin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection and met with Jodi Maberry, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation youth was inappropriately restrained, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed Child and Family Team Meeting Minutes, Needs and Service Plan, Incident Reports and facilities emergency intervention policies and procedures. Based on confidential interviews and documentary evidence did not suggest that client in care was restrained inappropriately while in care. Confidential interview indicated that client in care was restrained by staff for attempting to leave the facility, however did not sustain any injuries as a result of the restraint. Confidential interviews indicated that restraints are conducted when clients in care pose imminent danger to self and others, staff have to be Pro-Act trained and two or more staff must conduct the restraint. Documentary evidence did not indicate that client in care was restrained inappropriately. Continued on LIC 9099-C

narrative:
On 10/14/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong and Rosslyn Gray arrived at the facility at 9:30am unannounced for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPAs met with Administrator for the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program at Hathaway Sycamores Child and Family Services. The facility is licensed to care for 43 children ages 11 to 17 and non-minor dependents, ambulatory only. At that time of inspection there were 25 clients present at the facility. The Facility is located in a residential area and was set as follows: Administrative Office and Circle M: Administrative office consist of receptionist area, two bathrooms, staff kitchen and 10 offices. LPAs observed cameras located in hallway and outside rear of building. Circle M consist of therapy room, two bathrooms, 16 offices, staff kitchen and 10 cubicles. Cameras are monitored through the leadership staff and IT Department. There is a camera waiver on file. Postings are available in the administrative office area. Currently, therapy sessions are being conducted outside due to COVID-19. Rowland Cottage (A-Hall and B-Hall): A-Hall consist of 9 bedrooms. 8 bedrooms are equipped with one twin size bed. One bedroom is equipped with two twin size beds. All bedrooms have adequate drawers, closet space, clean linen, lighting, and a desk and chair. B-Hall consist of 7 bedrooms. 6 bedrooms are equipped with one twin size bed. Currently B-Hall has 10 beds. All bedrooms have adequate drawers, closet space, clean linen, lighting, and a desk and chair. Individual beds were observed to be in good repair with clean linens. Each hall is equipped with one staff bathroom and one client bathroom which consist of two showers, two toilet stalls and two sinks. Each hall consists of a kitchen which contains a refrigerator, stove, microwave, toaster, dishwasher, and toaster oven. Knives, cleaning supplies and chemicals are inaccessible to children and located at the staff office. A-Hall dining area consist of ten chairs and two tables. (page 1 of 3)

B-Hall dining area consist of one table and two chairs. There is a staff office, storage room and laundry area on each side of the hall. Each side of the cottage have a common room that is equipped with a television and couch seating for clients in care. There are 3 staff on each side of the hall, supervising children in the common area/kitchen. There are 3 fire extinguishers located in each hall. Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order. Fire extinguishers have been serviced and are fully charged. First Aid kits are located on the staff office. Rules, Personal Rights and menu are posted in cottage. LPAs observed cameras located in living room and hallway of A-Hall and dayroom of B-Hall. Hunter Cottage (A-Hall and B Hall): A-Hall is currently not being used. B-Hall consist of 8 bedrooms. 7 bedrooms are equipped with one twin size bed. 7 rooms have one twin size bed and 1 room has two twin size beds. All bedrooms have adequate drawers, closet space, clean linen, lighting and a desk and chair. Each hall is equipped with one staff bathroom and one client bathroom which consist of two showers, two toilet stalls and two sinks. Individual beds were observed to be in good repair with clean linens. Each hall consists of a kitchen which contains a refrigerator, stove, microwave, toaster, dishwasher, and toaster oven. Knives, cleaning supplies and chemicals are inaccessible to children and located at the staff office. A-Hall dining area consist of 9 chairs and two tables. B-Hall dining area consist of two tables and nine chairs. There is a staff office, storage room, incentive room, shoe closet and laundry area. There is a sensory room that has video game console, comfortable seating and chalkboard walls that can be used by clients. Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order. Fire extinguishers have been serviced and are fully charged. First Aid kits are located on the staff office. Rules, Personal Rights and menu are posted in cottage. Baldwin Cottage: This cottage is currently closed and non-operational. All prescribed medications are locked and centrally stored in the Nurse’s Station with the exception of contraceptives. Licensee has provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers by clients. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Outdoor spaces are utilized for therapy and extracurricular activities. The campus has a recreation room that has sporting and exercise equipment. The campus has a basketball court, outdoor exercise equipment, baseball batting range, swings, and picnic tables spread across the lawn. (page 2 of 3)

Licensee has a plan to ensure core services are provided and all staff are aware of it and are supportive and trained in their respective roles. Licensee is utilizing trauma informed care practices to ensure effective outcomes that promote permanency and client well-being. Licensee has a plan to ensure individual treatment needs are assessed at least every 30 days and recommendations are implemented. Licensee has a plan to assess, coordinate delivery and evaluate specialty mental health services for clients. Licensee has a maintenance office and a centralized kitchen. Meals are being prepared and cooked in the kitchen. Kitchen staff currently deliver the meals to the cottages in food warmers for COVID-19 prevention. Licensee has a designated mental health head of service staff who communicates and collaborates with county inter-agency placement committees to ensure specialty mental services are delivered. Clients are advised of their personal rights and house rules. Gender identity, expression and orientation are respected and kept confidential. Clients receive services, activities and support and are included in child and family teams regarding decisions about their plans. Clients can file a complaint or elevate concerns without retaliation. Licensee provides resident councils and forms for clients to raise issues. Clients are provided extracurricular activities such as hiking, biking, boxing, go on outings (Theme Parks, Movies, Beaches). The facility has 9 vehicles and are all operating in good condition. Administrator is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Administrator job title is Assistant Director and oversees the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified and meet regulations. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure staff meet regulatory requirements. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. All file documentation is complete, signed and current for each staff. All emergency intervention training is current. Staff is aware of the mission and vision, and values for their program’s continuous quality improvement. LPAs will return to the facility at a later date to complete the remaining staff interviews, client interviews and client records. LPAs concluded the inspection and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Administrator on 10/15/2021. (page 3 of 3)

On 03/29/2022 at 9am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong made an unannounced visit for the purpose of conducting a Case Management. LPA Karnsrithong met with Daisy Delgado, Program Director who granted access to the facility. Health and safety assessment were conducted at upon arrival and COVID-19 protocols were observed. During the visit, LPA Karnsrithong conducted a case management regarding the facility’s Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) ONE. This facility only has one client in the program. The program is being housed at the Baldwin Cottage. It has one (1) bedroom that is equipped with a twin sized bed, a sturdy mattress, a desk and closet space with locker. It also has a kitchen that has a four-burner stove, a refrigerator, a microwave, and a sink. Client was observed to be making a sandwich at the time of the visit. There is ample supply of perishable and non-perishable food items at the time of the visit. The client is able to prepare his own meals and have access to utensils, pots, pans, and food supplies when needed. Hot meals that are prepared in the main kitchen are also being delivered to the living unit. There is an extra desk outside the bedroom near the kitchen area that has the telephone. There is a dining table that has four (4) chairs that the client can use during meals or for studying. There is an extra room in the living unit that is currently used as a storage for extra supplies. This room is kept locked and inaccessible for the client. A client bathroom is also located inside the living unit. It has a shower, sink, and toilet that are in good repair. There is a linen cabinet storage outside of the client bathroom. There is a living room/common room in the unit that has three (3) couches, a coffee table, television, and air purifier. Outside the living unit is a staff room that is equipped with a desk, computer, chair, a bed, and closet space with a locker. This is attached to the other side of the Baldwin Cottage and currently has no clients staying onsite. There is a staff bathroom here as well that is equipped with a shower, toilet, sink and cabinet. (Page 1 of 2)

The facility has been observed in good repair. The temperature of the rooms are all in a safe range. During the time of visit, two (2) staff were observed to be supervising the client. LPA Karnsrithong has observed the client being on crisis and was being supported by three (3) staff. Client refused to be interviewed at that time of visit. Staff were observed to provide crisis communication to the client at the time of the visit. At this time, there are no sufficient information to render a decision. There are no deficiencies cited at this time and an exit interview was conducted with Daisy Delgado, Program Director. (Page 2 of 2)

On August 23, 2022 at 9:00am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Emelyn Sanchez P. and Olivia Rosas arrived at the above facility unannounced for the purpose of conducting a SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Case Management- Medication Inspection Visit. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas met with Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Programs and Julie Farino, Assistant Director Medication Support. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas reviewed nine (9) client files and three (3) staff files. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas conducted one (1) client interview and three (3) staff interviews. Currently there are twenty-six (26) clients residing in the above facility. During the review of client records, LPAs Sanchez and Rosas observed that 9 out of the 9 client records had no updated Needs and Services Plan (NSP) within the 30 day period from the last NSP conducted. This is a facility located in a residential area and equipped with a kitchen/dinning room, three cottages that have a living room, laundry space, small kitchen, bathrooms and bedrooms. There is also an Art Room, Recreational Hall, Medication Office, an outdoor BBQ patio, and basketball court. Outdoor space is free of obstructions. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed adequate staffing in the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas also observed medication to be centrally stored, triple locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members. The following deficiency was cited per Interim Licensing Standards for STRTP Version 4 87068.3. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

met_with: Director of Residential Programs - Daisy Delgado
narrative:
On 11/15/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Required Inspection. LPA met with Daisy Delgado, Director of Residential Programs. The facility is licensed to care for 43 children ages 11 to 17 and non-minor dependents, ambulatory only. At that time of inspection, the census was 28. The Facility is located in a residential area and is set up as follows: Administrative Office, Circle M building, 3 cottages (Rowland, Hunter, and Baldwin), a Dinning Hall, Nurses Office, Maintenance Room, Music Room, a Recreation room, and 2 family cottages. Administrative Office: contains a receptionist area, 10 staffing offices, a board room, 2 bathrooms, and a staff’s kitchen. Circle M: contains a therapy room, 16 offices, multiple cubicles, 2 bathrooms, and a staff’s kitchen. Rowland Cottage: The cottage is divided into two sides named Hall A and Hall B. Hall A: contains 8 bedrooms, 1 bedroom is equipped with two (2) twin size beds, the remaining 7 bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin bed. All bedrooms have adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. Hall B: contains 8 bedrooms, 2 bedroom are equipped with two (2) twin size beds, the remaining 6 bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin bed. All bedrooms have adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. All beds were observed to be in good repair. Both halls contain a dining area, a kitchen, two bathrooms, a staffing office, a common area, and a laundry room. The dining area contains a table and ample seating. The kitchens are equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a gas burning stove, a microwave, and dishwasher. Bathrooms, one bathroom is for staff and one bathroom for clients. Client bathrooms contain two showers, two toilet stalls and two sinks. Report continued on LIC 809C

Staffing office is equipped with a desk, chair, computer, and two storage cabinets observed to contain individual storage boxes for each client, additional linen supplies, and hygiene items. Sharp knives, soap/detergent, and disinfectants are also kept locked in the staffing office and made inaccessible to clients. The common area contains a mounted television and ample seating. Laundry room contains a washer and dryer. Hunter Cottage: The cottage is divided into two sides named Hall A and Hall B. (A-Hall and B Hall): Hall A: 7 rooms, 1 bedroom is equipped with two (2) twin size beds, the remaining 6 bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin bed. All bedrooms have adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. This Hall is closed and not currently in use. Hall B: contains 8 bedrooms, 1 bedroom is equipped with two (2) twin size beds, the remaining 7 bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin size bed. All bedrooms have adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. All beds were observed to be in good repair. Both halls contain a dining area, a kitchen, two bathrooms, a staffing office, a common area, and a laundry room. Additionally, Hall B contains an incentive room with a television for video games and a couch. The dining area contains a table and ample seating. The kitchens are equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a gas burning stove, a microwave, and dishwasher. Bathrooms, one bathroom is for staff and one bathroom for clients. Client bathrooms contain two showers, two toilet stalls and two sinks. Staffing office is equipped with a desk, chair, computer, and two storage cabinets observed to contain individual storage boxes for each client, additional linen supplies, and hygiene items. Sharp knives, soap/detergent, and disinfectants are also kept locked in the staffing office and made inaccessible to clients. The common area contains a mounted television and ample seating. Laundry room contains a washer and dryer. Baldwin Cottage: Is non-operational. All prescribed medications, including medications requiring refrigeration are locked and centrally stored in the Nurse’s Station. There are no weapons or bodies of water on the premises. The recreation room was observed to have exercise equipment and games. The outdoor area contains a basketball court, baseball batting area, swings, outdoor exercise equipment, a picnic area, and a garden. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. There are multiple regulation fire extinguishers located throughout the facility and in each cottage. First Aid kits checked and found to be complete. Hot water was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). Overall LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Temperatures in client rooms and common areas were found to be between 68 - 85 degrees (F). Additional disinfectants/cleaning solutions are stored in the maintenance room and made inaccessible to clients. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Personal Rights, menus, and activities were posted in one each side of the cottages. Transportation: The facility has a total of 7 vehicles to transport clients. LPA inspected 3 out of 7 vehicles and found seat belts and horn in working order, travel first aid kits, and current registration and insurance. Vehicles are insured by Nonprofit Insurance Alliance of CA and expire 11/1/2023. LPA observed cameras in the common areas, and on the outside perimeter of the buildings. The cameras are monitored by the administrative staff and the IT Department. There is a camera waiver on file. LPA will return at a later date to review client and staff records, as well as conduct client and staff interviews. There are no deficiencies observed or cited at this during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with the Director of Residential Programs, and of this report was left at the facility.

The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the findings are unsubstantiated. On July 17, 2021, at approximately 2:15pm, Client#1 (C1) suffered a seizure while on an outing to Hurricane Harbor waterpark in the city of Valencia. C1 was swimming in the water pool and was walking out when collapsed to a seizure. Waterpark lifeguards approached C1 and took him out of the pool. Lifeguards told Staff#2 (S2) that C1 will be transported to a local hospital Emergency Room (ER) via ambulance. Per facility C1 had seizures regularly and staff was trained on what to do if a seizure happened. S2 was at eyesight of C1 when he was in the pool and was present during the incident. S2 was informed by the waterpark lifeguard that they would need to transport him to ER as protocol. S2 informed the lifeguard that C1 was with the facility and had seizures regularly. S2 drove with the other two clients in the outing to Henry Mayo Hospital ER in the city of Valencia. C1 upon coming back to normal called relatives to informed them of the incident. The facility was informed by S2 and Valencia Fire Department that C1 had a seizure and was being transported to the ER. C1 was kept was conscious and in observation. C1 was released from the ER at 7:15pm. The hospital requested for C1 to get checked by his neurologist on Monday, 07/18/2021. Facility reported incident to county of placement, and Social Worker. LPA Rosas conducted interviews with client, pertinent parties, and facility staff regarding to incident on 07/21/2021. There were no witnesses identified to corroborate the allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation of staff did not prevent minors from engaging in physical altercations resulting in injuries. LPA Rosas conducted confidential interviews and reviewed Child and Family Team Meeting Minutes, Needs and Service Plan, Emergency Intervention Plan, Special Incident Reports and facilities emergency intervention policies and procedures. Based on confidential interviews and documentary evidence did not suggest that staff did not prevent minors from engaging in physical altercations resulting injuries. Incident Reports had S1 as the aggressor in some incidents with other clients in the facility and in others as the victim. The incidents reported having staff present during the events. The facility always has two to three staff to supervise clients in placement. Report continues on LIC9099-C Page 2 of 3

Confidential interviews indicated that restraints are conducted when clients in care pose imminent danger to self and others, staff must be Pro-Act trained and two or more staff must conduct the restraint. The facility also used variety of verbal redirecting techniques to calm clients during crisis. There was not enough information to corroborate the allegation. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegations of Neglect/Lack of Supervision are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility. Page 3 of 3

Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios conducted a case management inspection March 14, 2024, at 10:18 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 24 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 16 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 24 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 16 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated March 14, 2024). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dahl Larios observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Assistant Vice President Timothy Lin.
