narrative:
On 11/15/2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) C. White and J. Armstrong made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA’s met with Administrator, Tasian Taylor and Assistant Vice President, Timothy Lin. The facility is licensed to care for 16 children ages 11 to 17 and non-minor dependents, ambulatory only. At the time of today’s inspection, the census was 13. The Facility is in a residential area and is set up as follows: Administrative Office, Circle M Building, Rowland Cottage, a Dining Hall, Maintenance Room, Music Room, a Recreation room, and 2 Family Cottages. Administrative Office: contains a receptionist area, 10 staffing offices, a board room, 2 bathrooms, and a staff’s kitchen. Circle M Building: contains the nurses office, therapy room, mental health staffing offices, multiple cubicles, security office, 2 bathrooms, and a staff kitchen. Rowland Cottage is separated into two halls: Hall A and Hall B: Each hall contains a dining area, a kitchen, 8 bedrooms, two bathrooms, a staffing office, a common area, and a laundry room. Dining areas: have a rectangle tables and multiple chairs. Kitchens: are equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a 4-burner gas stove (all operable at the time of inspection), a microwave, and dishwasher. Bedrooms: each bedroom is equipped with one (1) twin size bed. All bedrooms were observed to have beds in good repair, pillows, clean linen, adequate drawers, closet cabinets equipped with locked container, and lighting. Bathrooms: one bathroom is for staff and one bathroom for clients. Client bathrooms contain two showers, two toilet stalls and two sinks. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Staffing Office: is equipped with a desk, chair, computer, and storage cabinets observed to contain individual storage boxes for each client, and hygiene items. Sharp knives, soap/detergent, and disinfectants are also kept locked in the staffing office and made inaccessible to clients. Common area: contains a mounted television and ample seating. Laundry room: contains a washer, dryer, and storage cabinets with extra linen supplies. All prescribed medications, including medications requiring refrigeration, are locked and centrally stored in the Nurse’s Office, located in the Circle M Building. There are no weapons or bodies of water on the premises. The outdoor area contains a basketball court, baseball batting area, swings (area is cushioned with wood chips), outdoor exercise equipment (securely anchored to the ground), and a picnic area. Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. There are multiple regulation fire extinguishers located throughout the facility and in each cottage. First Aid kits checked and found to be complete. Overall LPA’s observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Additional disinfectants/cleaning solutions are stored in the maintenance room and made inaccessible to clients. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Personal Rights, menus, and activities were posted in one each side of the cottages. Transportation: The facility has a total of 5 vehicles to transport clients. LPA inspected 4 out of 5 vehicles and found seat belts and horns in working order, travel first aid kits, and current registration and insurance. Vehicles are insured by Nonprofit Insurance Alliance of CA and expire 11/01/2025. There are cameras on the building which monitor the outer perimeter of the facility. Facility has a camera waiver on file. LPA’s will return at a later date to review client and staff records, as well as conduct client and staff interviews. There are no deficiencies observed or cited at this during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with the Assistant Vice President, and of this report was left at the facility.

investigation_findings: 13On September 22, 2020 at 2:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Green conducted a follow-up complaint Tele-Inspection with the Group Home Facility (GH) and spoke with above staff. The purpose of the call was to discuss and deliver findings for the above compliant allegations. During the course of investigating, LPA reviewed facility records and conducted investigative interviews with the Facility Staff (FS1, FS2, FS3, FS4) a Probation Representative (PO1) and Foster Youth (FC1 and FC2). LPA did not obtain an investigative interview from the Complainant (RP). (Please see Confidential Names LIC 811, dated 9/22/2020). Based on records reviewed RP received information indicating a lack of supervision resulted in FC1 and FC2 engaging in a physical altercation. It was also reported that Facility Staff hit a youth. FS1 denied the alleged allegations and stated all youth are supervised by two or more Facility Staff. FS1 stated when the physical altercation occurred the proper procedures were followed; FC1 and FC2 were not hit by Facility Staff. FS2 denied the alleged allegations and stated youth were supervised prior to the physical altercation and by separated by Facility Staff as a resolve. FS2 did not witness Facility Staff hit FC1 or FC2.

narrative: Investigator Brunelli also reviewed documents on 5/27/20, 8/19/20, 8/24/20, 8/28/20 including but not limited to the police report, autopsy report, placement agency reports, incident reports, facility client records, facility records and facility personnel records. The investigation revealed that a facility client was found unresponsive in his bedroom by a facility staff on May 18, 2020. The facility client died from a drug overdose. Statements obtained from the confidential interviews indicated that the facility client’s death could have been prevented as medical attention could have been administered if staff found him in distress when he vomited during his sleep which was a side effect of the drug overdose. Staff #1 and Staff #2 were assigned to the cottage where the facility client resided. Both staff admitted during the investigation that they did not check on the facility clients during their shift. The video footage obtained of the cottage showed Staff #1 asleep during parts of her shift. Staff #2 was seen on the video to have left the cottage from 0349 hours and returned at 0506 hours. The facility staff failed to conduct their duties per facility policy in checking on the clients every 10 minutes during their shift. Staff #1 and Staff #2 falsified the bedroom check logs and indicated they conducted room checks throughout their shift when they admitted that they did not check on the clients. Both staff were terminated by the facility. Based on the information gathered, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was met, therefore the allegation is substantiated per California Code of Regulations Title 22 – refer to LIC9099-D for deficiencies. Per the new Civil Penalty laws, Health and Safety (H&S) Code section 1548(d), an enhanced civil penalty determination is pending due to the substantiated allegations. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form, LIC 9099-D for deficiency and Appeal Rights were provided to the agency representative.

deficiencies.description:
80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on the information obtained, it was determined that facility staff failed to conduct safety checks on facility clients during an event where a facility client died from a drug overdose and medical attention could have been requested if the client was found in time exhibiting drug overdose symptoms; facility staff also falsified bedroom check logs and indicated they conducted bedroom checks when they admitted that they did not check on the clients during their shift, a finding which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The facility assigned staff supervisors as additional oversight for the facility cottages.  The facility provided re-training with staff regarding documentation. The facility now reviews the camera footages randomly on a weekly basis to ensure that staff conducted safety checks on the clients during their shifts. The facility will also be installing bar codes on each bedroom door for staff to scan in order to complete a client safety check.

Documentation regarding the status of the bar code installation (proof of purchase order) will be provided by the facility to the LPA.

narrative: On 09/18/20, the department received a complaint alleging that a client was constantly running away (AWOL) from the facility. Staff workers that were interviewed provided a statement and denied the allegation of neglect/lack of supervision. It was disclosed that the client has a history of running away and staff acted appropriate in attempting to verbally redirect the client not to run away. Staff interviews did not reveal having any knowledge that the client would return with large amounts of money as a result of any illicit activities when the client was AWOL. Staff workers stated that all clients are always being monitored and staff workers are working within staff to client ratio. The county social worker (CSW) for one of the clients (CSW) expressed no concerns with the care and supervision by the facility. In confidential interviews the client that was identified in the report of running away denied the allegation of having a large amount of money connected to any illicit activities. The client confirmed that he sustained an upper leg injury after climbing over the fence as he was returning back to the facility after being awol. The client stated that staff are present at the facility when he runs away. Two other clients admit to saying comments in the form of "gossiping" about the client doing illicit activities when going AWOL and returning to the facility with large amounts of money. Statements by other stated that the allegation was reported only as an abundance of caution, based on hearing two clients "gossiping". Based on interviews and records reviewed there was no corroborating information to substantiate the allegation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the above allegation did or did not happen. Therefore, this complaint is being closed Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited at this time during this inspection and LPA informed the facility representative that LPA would e-mail a copy of this report for review and signature.

narrative:
On January 6, 2021 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joshua Rarela conducted a case management tele-inspection with the facility named above in order to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). LPA Rarela discussed the following with the facility representative named above. On May 21, 2020, the Department received a complaint requesting the investigation of a facility client’s death and alleging inadequate staff supervision regarding the incident. The investigation was substantiated and revealed that a facility client was found unresponsive in his bedroom by a facility staff on May 18, 2020. The facility client died from a drug overdose. Statements obtained from the confidential interviews indicated that the facility client’s death could have been prevented as medical attention could have been administered if staff found him in distress when he vomited during his sleep, which was a side effect of the drug overdose. Staff #1 and Staff #2 were assigned to the cottage where the facility client died. Staff #1 and Staff #2 were aware that the client had a history of drug abuse and was absent from the facility for 24 hours prior to returning to the facility. Both staff admitted during the investigation that they did not check on the facility clients during their shift. The video footage obtained of the cottage showed Staff #1 asleep during parts of her shift. Staff #2 was seen on the video to have left the cottage from 0349 hours and returned at 0506 hours. The facility staff failed to conduct their duties per facility policy in checking on the clients every 10 minutes during their shift. Staff #1 and Staff #2 falsified the bedroom check logs and indicated they conducted room checks throughout their shift when they admitted that they did not check on the clients. Both staff were terminated by the facility effective June 5, 2020. The facility was cited on September 30, 2020 for 80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision. (Continued)

The Department has concluded an analysis and determined that an Enhanced Civil Penalty is warranted. Under Health and Safety Code section 1548(e)(3)(B), a violation that the Department determines resulted in the death of a person receiving care from a short-term residential therapeutic program with a licensed capacity between 41-100 children will result in a civil penalty of $10,000.00. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form, Appeal Rights and form LIC 421-D(CRP) for a Civil Penalty Assessment – Death / Serious Bodily Injury / Physical Abuse were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail.

On 10/22/20, the department received a complaint alleging that staff failed to protect client in home. Staff workers that were interviewed provided a statements and denied the allegation of neglect/lack of supervision. It was disclosed that the client has a history of having behaviors of defiance, violence and would pick fights with others. Staff workers stated that all clients are always being monitored and staff workers are working within staff to client ratio.The county social worker (CSW) for the client expressed no concerns with the care and supervision by the facility and stated she has always seen staff available when she visits the facility. In confidential interviews the client that was identified in the report confirmed that he was supervised and stated when something happens staff is around. LPA attempted to interview other clients, but they did not want to provide a statement. Based on interviews and records reviewed there was no corroborating information to substantiate the allegation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the above allegation did or did not happen. Therefore, this complaint is being closed Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited at this time during this inspection and LPA informed the facility representative that LPA would e-mail a copy of this report for review and signature.

met_with: Dan Maydeck, CEO and Douglas Yost, Vice President of Therapeutic Programs
narrative: A virtual office meeting was held with Haynes Family of Programs. Present at the meeting from Haynes Family of Programs were Dan Maydeck, CEO and Douglas Yost, Vice President of Therapeutic Programs (VP-TP). Community Care Licensing (CCL) was represented by Kimberly Taylor, Assistant Program Administrator; Monique Turner-Marshall, Regional Manager (RM); Ina Yeung, Licensing Program Manager (LPM); Gilbert Guiterrez, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA); Raymond Wu, Licensing Program Analyst; and Tommy Davis, Licensing Program Analyst. During the meeting, the CEO clarified and advised CCL that both David and Margaret Youth and Family Services (DMYFS) and Haynes Family of Programs will continue at this time to operate as two separate organizations. He stated that he was appointed CEO of both organizations and that each would have its own separate board of directors. Besides the expanded role of the CEO, CCL was also advised that Michael Miller has been designated as the new Senior Director of Residential Programs. He will continue overseeing all the programs at DMYFS as well as the STRTP program at Haynes Family of Programs. The business agreement was signed last week and a copy of the agreement was submitted to CCL prior to the meeting. Further details regarding the future plans involving Haynes Family of Programs and DMYFS were outlined in the agreement. The RO will review the submitted business agreement and follow up with the licensee regarding next steps. The CEO stated that it is their intentions to submit all forms and documentation to CCL next week (04/05/21-04/09/21). The licensee will provide any personnel and departmental changes to CCL by April 09, 2021. Exit interview

narrative: Continue from page 1 . . . . The staff denied the allegations and stated that the clients are made to do a self search when coming back to the facility from the community by putting their pockets inside out, taking off their shoes, shaking their clothing and opening their backups to prevent drugs from coming into the facility. The staff indicated that room searches are done when there is a suspicion of drug possession by a client and that the staff uses a dog to inspect the facility. The staff indicated that the staff does not make inappropriate comments toward the clients and that the staff have not threatened to hit clients. The staff stated that the clients curse or threaten the staff and know what the staff is able to do. The confidential interviews indicated that the clients are made to do a self search when they come to the facility, statements were obtained indicating that the clients empty their pockets, take of their shoes and shake their clothing when coming back form AWOL or the community. The confidential interviews indicated that the clients curse and threaten the staff and that the staff have not made inappropriate comments toward the clients or attempted to hit the clients. The social workers were not available to give a statement regarding the allegations. There was no corroborating information obtained through interviews to confirm the allegations. Based on the information obtained though interviews the allegations are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the allegations occurred, therefore, the above allegations are Unsubstantiated. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report was left with above staff.
investigation_findings: 13On September 21, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Heriberto Perez conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and and met with William Sanchez, Campus Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegations. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed one two staff via telephone on 09/09/21, LPA interviewed one staff via telephone on 09/10/21, LPA interviewed one client via telephone on 09/16/21 and LPA interviewed two clients via telephone on 09/17/21 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated September 21, 2021). It was alleged that the Staff allow minors to bring drugs into the facility, Staff make inappropriate comments towards minors and Staff threatened to hit minors.

narrative: On October 29, 2021 at 10:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a case management inspection at the facility in order to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). LPA Yamamoto met with the facility representative named above and discussed the following: On 3/4/21, the Department received a complaint that staff sexually abused client in care and engaged in conduct inimical to clients in care. Confidential statements obtained during the investigation revealed that the sexual abuse occurred multiple times on facility grounds when client and staff went for one on one walks. Staff orally copulated client and staff allowed client to digitally penetrate staff. Records obtained show the dates and times client and staff were together. Based on this evidence, the complaint was substantiated, and the facility was cited on 9/21/21 under Interim Licensing Standards 87072(d)(11) Personal Rights. The Department has concluded an analysis and determined that an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) is warranted. Per Health and Safety Code section 1548(2), “physical abuse” includes sexual abuse as defined by Penal Code section 11165.1 which includes Section 288a oral copulation. For a violation that the Department determines resulted in the sexual abuse of a person receiving care at a short-term residential therapeutic program, a civil penalty shall be assessed in the amount of $ 5,000.00 for a facility licensed to care for 41 to 100 children. A copy of this signed report, Confidential Names Form (LIC 811), Appeal Rights and Form LIC 421-D (CRP) Civil Penalty Assessment – Death / Serious Bodily Injury / Physical Abuse were provided to the facility representative.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to Haynes Family of Programs on December 08, 2021 at 9:15am for the purposes of an unannounced Required Annual Inspection. The facility is a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) that is licensed to serve seventy-two (72) male clients ages 12-17 years old. LPA met with William Sanchez, Campus Manager (CM), and together they toured the facility inside and outside. The STRTP is located in a residential neighborhood and presently has clients placed in two cottages (Wittryand Burton). As of today's inspection, Wittry has eight clients in placement and Burton has eight clients in placement as well. Overall, there are sixteen clients currently in placement at the facility. LPA observed the kitchen in each cottage to be clean and well stocked with several food items (perishable and nonperishable). Sharp knives and cleaning supplies are kept locked in areas inaccessible to clients. The bathrooms in each cottage were observed to be in good repair and working order. The bedrooms contained twin beds, desks, and closet space. Medications are kept locked in the Health Services office. The facility has designated six vehicles for client and STRTP related purposes. Exit signs were visible in both of the abovementioned cottages. LPA obtained a current copy of the facility's staff roster (LIC500) and client roster. The last fire drill was held on August 26 2021 at 9:30am. The CM stated that there were no guns or weapons on the premises. LPA reviewed four client files and three staff files and found the reviewed files to be in order. There is a properly secured in-ground swimming pool on the premises enclosed with a self-latching gate.

There is adequate seating in each cottage's dining area and living room. All exits were free of hazards and all doors opened freely. The CM provided LPA with copies of the minutes from the Board of Director's meetings that were held on November 18, 2021, September 23, 2021 and July 29, 2021, respectively LPA interviewed clients and staff during today's inspection. LPAs found no Title 22/ILS deficiencies on this date. Exit interview conducted

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to Haynes Family of Programs on December 08, 2021 at 9:15am in order to follow up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing on November 10, 2021. LPA met with William Sanchez, Campus Manager (CM), and discussed the incident. The SIR stated that child #1 (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated December 08, 2021) took a lighter from his pocket and proceeded to light the facility's security camera. During the course of the follow up, LPA obtained information that staff was providing care and supervision at the facility. During a routine accountability check, staff observed the security camera on fire that was located in the corner of the upstairs hallway. Staff investigated the matter and it was determined that child #1 had used a lighter to set the facility's security camera on fire. Staff was unsuccessful in their efforts to get child #1 to empty his pockets. Based on information and facts obtained in this matter, the Department has found that the child was in a gang and struggled with his program while in placement at the facility. The child was able to sneak the lighter into the facility unbeknownst to the staff. Information shows that the child is no longer placed at the facility. Therefore, the situation has been stabilized and no citations will be issued on this date. No further follow up is necessary. Exit interview done

On 05/11/2022, the Department received a complaint alleging allegation for personal Rights violation. It was alleged that a staff worker engaged inappropriately with a client of being in a relationship. Staff workers assigned to the cottage where the client was identified as being the alleged victim denied the allegation. All staff workers stated that there is no inappropriate activities occurring among staff and clients. In confidential interviews, all clients that were interviewed denied the allegation and stated that all staff workers are respectable and they have never committed any sexual advances towards them. One client admitted to saying things that were not true while at school about being in a relationship with a female staff. The one client stated that “it’s just talk” and stated he never had any form of sexual contact with that one staff. Individual identified as other is deemed to be a credible witness who stated that the allegation that was overheard by the one client is accurate when first reported. The County Probation Office representative met with the one client and determined that there were no concerns and no further action was required but will follow up with Licensing Program Analyst Vargas's investigation. Interviews by the clients provided consistent statements and denied the allegation. However, one client admitted to saying that he was having a relationship with a female staff but he was “just talking” to others while attending school off-site. Therefore, the above allegations are determined unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. The resolution to this complaint was discussed with the agency representative and copies of all licensing reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection. An exit interview was conducted and the Appeal rights given were and explained. No deficiencies were cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On 09/20/2022 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joseph Vargas conducted a follow-up inspection for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint. LPA met with Ms. Jasmin Royball, Quality Assurance Coordinator. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted in-person visits, and telephone interviews with two staff workers, five clients, LA County Probation Officer (PO), individual identified as other on 05/13/2022, one staff worker on 5/12/22, one staff worker on 5/16/22, and one staff worker on 5/14/22 (reference confidential names list LIC811 dated 09/20/22). During the inspection, LPA Vargas requested for review and obtained copies of the staff and client files such as client roster, staff roster (LIC500), current Needs and Service Plan (NSP), medical documents (JV-223) and special incident reports (SIR). LPA Vargas researched any prior history of complaints similar to this investigation.

narrative: On March 7, 2024 at the Fresno Regional Office an informational meeting was conducted. The Meeting was to go over the current application information including the financial sections, Plan of Operation and Program Statement. The meeting was attended by Licensing Program Manager Lourey Bartolome and Licensing Program Analyst Leslie Inouye. Hazel's Safe Place was represented by Board Members Odoom Domson and Hazel Domson. . Application supporting documentation information was discussed to determine missing required information, program consistency and to verify information in the application. The meeting is also to resolve any questions, and determine whether the facility is capable of providing the services specified for a Short Term Residential Treatment Program. During the meeting it was determined and agreed that the applicants will review, update and resubmit the application. The application submission due date will be Friday April 5, 2024 at close of business day. If there are any questions or clarification that needs to be discussed the applicants will contact LPA Leslie Inouye. Any changes or modifications to the due date shall be in writing prior to April 5, 2024.

Licensing Program Analyst Corina Carrillo conducted a Case Management Inspection on November 3, 2021 at 10:00am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.7. 4 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 Confidential Names dated November 3, 2021 were reviewed. 3 out of the 6 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 5 youth were also interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Dekeydra Mothershed, Administrator.

An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez at Barstow House in Fresno, CA. LPA met with Administrator, Dekeydra Mothershed. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Outdoor facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility utilizes cameras without audio in common areas of the facility. There are no bodies of water. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. LPA reviewed five client files. LPA conducted three staff interviews and one client interview. Three clients refused to be interviewed and one client was out of the facility on his authorized unsupervised time. An annual continuation will be completed at the facility main office to review staff files. It is requested that the licensee submit the following updated forms to CCL: LIC 308, 309, 500 and emergency disaster plan. In addition, the most recent minutes for the Board of Directors meeting. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. .

On 12/29/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez conducted an unannounced case management inspection for the above facility. LPA was met by Administrator Dekeydra Mothershed. LPA discussed current client’s placements status with Administrator. Currently three of the five clients in placement are on a placement preservation status and one will be placed on preservation status tomorrow. Administrator stated Client 1 will be issued a 14-day notice tomorrow (12/30/2021) during a scheduled Children and Family Team (CFT) Meeting. According to Administrator, Client 1 has participated in 2-3 CFT’s previously; however, still continues with the following behaviors: habitual AWOLing, not attending school, not participating in mental health services, bringing contraband into the facility, and not programming. Administrator stated a 14-day notice is being issued for Client 2 during a scheduled CFT on (01/03/2022) due to the following behaviors: not attending school, smoking heavily in the facility, refusing medication, refusing mental health services, bringing contraband into the facility, and not programming. Administrator stated since being placed C2 has had approximately three to four CFT meetings to discuss these issues and attempt to preserve the placement; however, client’s behaviors have not improved. Administrator stated C2 only attended one of the CFT’s and walked out halfway through and refused to participate in other scheduled CFT’s. Client 3 is scheduled to have a CFT meeting tomorrow (12/30/2021) and will be placed on placement preservation. Client 4 has a CFT scheduled on (01/04/2022) for a possible extension or 14-day notice dependent on the client’s behaviors. Administrator was reminded to keep reporting all incidents to CCL in a timely manner. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. A copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez conducted an unannounced Case Management and spoke with Administrator, Dekeydra Mothershed. The purpose of the Case Management was to discuss an incident that occurred at the facility. LPA obtained information through interviews that there was an incident in which two clients Client 1 (C1) and Client 2 (C2) (see 811 for names) and a staff were followed by several unidentified males in a vehicle. The males in the vehicle were making gang gestures as C1 was wearing a red hat he was not supposed to have. The vehicle attempted to “trap or barricade” C1, C2, and staff; however, they were able to get away and run to the facility. Administrator stated following the incident it appeared another vehicle came to the facility and they were parked at opposite corners of the house. The individuals in the vehicles were flashing the lights. Law enforcement was called to the facility and responded. Additionally, the Executive Director, Kevin Jordan responded to the facility to attempt to de-escalate. Client 3 (C3) was not involved in the incident; however, then called someone to the facility who came and put on a ski mask. C3 is gang affiliated and the facility has concerns due to this. Administrator, stated an initial incident report was not sent. LPA discussed the importance of sending out initial incident reports as well as advising LPA of any incidents that threaten the safety of the clients in care. Administrator stated following the incident emergency Child Team and Family (CFT’s) meetings were held for C1 and C3. C1 was placed on placement preservation status. C3 was given a 14-day notice due to safety concerns with his gang affiliation. Additionally, Administrator stated the social worker of Client 4 (C4) was notified and a message was left with Client 2 (C2) social worker. Administrator was reminded of timeline for submitting incident reports. A copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez conducted an unannounced Case Management and spoke with Administrator, Dekeydra Mothershed. The purpose of the Case Management was to discuss a deficiency for the above facility. LPA obtained information through interviews and record review that a client was being bullied. The client expressed concerns for his safety to staff on multiple occasions; however, nothing was done to address his concerns. Based on the information obtained, the facility is being cited for a violation of Interim Licensing Standards on the attached LIC 9099D. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Administrator.

Review of staff communication logs and incident reports indicates that the ratios were not met in the facility to meet the needs of clients. Clients were continuously staying up at night and AWOLing from the facility or arriving to the facility from AWOL, at times with contraband; however, no additional support staff was provided even with the clients continued behaviors. Based on the above, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the above allegations were found to be Substantiated. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 and Interim Licensing Standards are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator. Appeal rights were also provided to the Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez conducted a complaint inspection at the facility and spoke with Administrator, Dekeydra Mothershed. deficiencies.description:
80088 Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies (c) Fireplaces and open-faced heaters shall be made inaccessible to clients to ensure protection of the clients' safety.

This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on interviews and record review, the Licensee did not ensure open faced heaters were made inaccessible to clients by using the oven as a heating source, which poses an immediate safety risk to the clients in care.

87065.5 Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios (g) If a child requires special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty direct care staff shall be increased.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Corina Carrillo conducted a case management inspection on July 20, 2022 at 10:30AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 5 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 5 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated July 20, 2022. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Carrillo observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Dekeydra Mothershed.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPAs) Reyna Martinez and Jessica Rodriguez conducted an unannounced Case Management and spoke with Program Supervisor (PS), Dekeydra Mothershed. The purpose of Case Management was to discuss an incident that occurred on 10/12/22. Information obtained in an Incident Report (IR) reflects that Client 1(C1) became upset during a Children and Family Team (CFT) meeting, left the meeting then locked himself in his room. When C1 exited his room he advised staff he had ingested "6 pink pills." C1 was then transported by EMS to the hospital for evaluation. LPA's asked PS if she knew how or when C1 obtained the pills. PS stated she was not sure if C1 had "cheeked" the pills or if had obtained them during another medication incident. PS stated there was another incident on 10/11/22 where she was in the office destroying some of C1's pills, and he barged into the office and grabbed a medication pack. PS stated staff was able to get the medication back from C1; however, some of the medications fell and staff retrieved them. PS stated that a medication count was conducted and showed all pills were accounted for. LPA's asked if C1 had any history with medication refusal or "cheeking" his medications and PS stated he did not. LPA's asked what the typical procedure is when clients take medications she stated clients take the medication place it on their tongue, drink water, then open their mouth and show staff heir tongue and underneath their tongue. PS stated since the incident staff are making sure to do an extra check with C1 to ensure that he is not "cheeking" his medications.

PS stated that Mental Health Services for C1 have also been increased and staff are attempting to provide more one on one services and "check ins" with him. PS stated, currently C1 is on independent studies in an attempt to try and get him more stabilized. LPAs spoke with C1 regarding the incident. C1 stated to LPAs that he was feeling upset and suicidal because he is unhappy at school and does not like being around kids. LPAs asked C1 where he got the pills from. C1 said that he was "cheeking" his pills to keep them. LPAs asked C1 if staff would check his mouth after giving him his medications. C1 said that yes they would but he still could hide the pills from staff. LPAs asked C1 if he feels supported from staff and mental health services. C1 said yes he does feel staff is supportive and his mental health services are helping him. C1 said that he does not feel supportive from his school and does not want to be around other kids. Additionally, LPA's discussed reporting requirements with PS and esnuring that IR's are as detailed as possible. No deficiency will be issued at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided to the facility.

Met by Interim Human Resources/Finance Coordinator, Adela Dominguez-Jordan. The purpose of the case management is to review staff files and issue a deficiency for the facility not having mental health program approval effective February 17, 2023. On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reyna Martinez conducted a Case Management inspection at Hazel House and met with Program Supervisor, Dekeydra Mothershed. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss concerns in regards to incident reports received by CCL. LPA reviewed 01/18/2023 incident report sent in by the STRTP. The incident in question is regarding the Care and Supervision of clients, as staff was not able to provide appropriate supervision as the client gained access and ingested a medication. Licensee confirmed oversight and monitoring of psychotropic medications. Licensee confirmed that the office door, which is a split door, was only locked on the bottom half and the top of the door was open. C1 was able to reach over and unlock the bottom door while S1 was counting the medication and gained access to the medications. LPA discussed with Licensee the importance of supervision, having the office door securely locked and appropriate storage of medications. Additionally, LPA discussed information during several incident's that occurred on 01/28/2023 and two incidents on 02/05/2023 regarding staff to client ratios. LPA and Program Supervisor discussed the incidents in depth, gathered additional information. Licensee will work with staff to ensure incident reports contain full details. If further action is needed LPA will address the matter with Program Supervisor at a later date. -Continued on LIC-809C.

Based on the above, there is a preponderance of evidence to substantiate a violation based on Interim Licensing Standards which is being cited on the attached LIC809D. A copy of the report and Appeal Rights was provided to the facility.

PERSONNEL DUTIES.

narrative: On April 5, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reyna Martinez conducted a Case Management inspection at Hazel House and met with Dekeydra Mothershed. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss concerns on an incident report that was emailed to the Department. LPA discussed with licensee the following pertaining to incident report dated 03/22/23 with C1: Medications: Licensee reported that medications were locked away safely and client (C1) had no accessible access. Licensee stated client (C1) broke the lock of the medicine cabinet and gained access to the Melatonin bottle. Licensee confirmed that Staff only provided C1 one pill the night before. Staff Office: Licensee reported that the office door, which is a split door, was closed and locked but the very bottom door bolt was not locked. The facility office door has three bolts on the office door. C1 was able to break into the office while S1 was counting the medication and gained access to the medication cabinet. LPA discussed with Licensee the importance of supervision, having the office door securely locked on all three bolts and appropriate storage of medications. LPA also discussed the STRTP's overall purpose to provide services to youth and keep them safe. No deficiencies are being cited at today's visit. A copy of this report was left at the facility. The facility is temporary closed and has no clients placed at this time.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reyna Martinez conducted a Case Management inspection for Hazel House at the KYJO Barstow House and met with Dekeydra Mothershed. The purpose of the inspection was inform Licensing that LPA drove by Hazel House to confirm it is not operating as an STRTP. The home is occupied by tenants who are leasing the home from KYJO Foster Family Agency. LPA verified and ensured there are no children in the home under the STRTP care placements. Licensee is surrendering their license effective April 4, 2023.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Annette Jumper Director, and Amanda Smith Clinical Program Manager (CPM), who assisted with the inspection. LPA and Director conducted a walk through of the facility. LPA observed that the washing machine was still dirty, however, it was out of use. It has been cleaned during this inspection. CCL received an incident report (IR) on 9/30/2020 for an incident that occurred on 9/28/2020. The IR stated that a client made an allegation against a staff for holding him up against a chalk board wall, causing him to hit his head. During the facility's internal investigation, they put the staff on leave until a conclusion was made. The facility also submitted a Suspected Child Abuse Report (SCAR) as mandated. Facility management spoke with the client, who stated the staff pushed him into the Behavioral Management Center (BMC), and then grabbed him when he tried to run, and then lifted him up, pushing him against the chalkboard, causing him to bang his head on the wall. The facility's internal investigation results for this incident were unsubstantiated, and the staff member is back from leave. LPA interviewed nine clients. Two clients refused to speak with LPA. Further investigation is required in order to resolve this case management. An exit interview was conducted with CPM at 4:28 PM and a copy of this report was left with her.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess met with Annette Jumper, Director, and Clinical Program Manager, Amanda Smith, over WebEx, a video conferencing application, to deliver the findings of this case management which was opened on 10/12/2020. CCL received an incident report (IR) on 9/30/2020 for an incident that occurred on 9/28/2020. The IR stated that a client made an allegation against a staff for holding him up against a chalk board wall, causing him to hit his head. During the facility's internal investigation, they put the staff on leave until a conclusion was made. The facility also submitted a Suspected Child Abuse Report (SCAR) as mandated. Facility management spoke with the client, who stated the staff pushed him into the Behavioral Management Center (BMC), and then grabbed him when he tried to run, and then lifted him up, pushing him against the chalkboard, causing him to bang his head on the wall. The facility's internal investigation results for this incident were unsubstantiated, and the staff member is back from leave. LPA investigated this case management by conducting confidential interviews with nine clients and five staff on 10/12/2020, 11/3/2020, 11/5/2020, and 12/16/2020. Two clients declined to be interviewed. One client stated the accused staff picked him up, threw him on the ground, and pushed him on one occasion in the Behavioral Management Center (BMC). Another client stated that same staff picked him up by the shirt and shoved him against the wall, making the client hit his head on one occasion in the BMC. These clients were credible in their statements. One client was interviewed multiple times about this and remained consistent and credible. All staff denied any physical abuse occurring. The staff accused also denied ever physically abusing the clients. Based on the interviews, LPA has found that the accusation is true.

On this date the facility is being cited for a violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Version 3.1 Section: 87072(d)(10). At 5:12 PM an exit interview was conducted with Director and CPM. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was emailed to them with a read receipt which will serve as their signature.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess called the facility to request to speak with a client. LPA spoke with Clinical Program Manager (CPM) Amanda Smith who let LPA know the client was unavailable at that time. CPM stated she will inform LPA when the client is available and LPA can meet with him. LPA received an incident report on 1/19/2021 that described the client demonstrating inappropriate behavior and making an allegation against a previous foster parent with whom the client used to live with. LPA is making this inspection to gather more information. At 2:47 PM, LPA interviewed the client through WebEx, a video conferencing application. At 3:12 PM an exit interview was conducted with CPM, and a copy of this report was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.

Based on all evidence reviewed and interviews given, IB found the allegation that staff caused injury to a minor while in care to be unsubstantiated, which means that while the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there was not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that it did or did not occur. IB found that, "[Client 1] was in a physical fight with a resident, [Client 2] and during this fight [Client 1] was restrained by [Staff 1] and [Staff 2] for his safety. After [Client 1] was released from the restraint, [Client 1's] left wrist was injured so he was immediately transported to the [Hospital]. [Client 1] was diagnosed with a fractured left wrist. During the interview [Client 1] said the restraint did not cause his injury. It is unknown if [Client 1] injured his wrist in the fight or when he hit himself with (a) scooter or the application of the restraint. Staff [1] and [Staff 2] stated they didn't think they caused the injury during the application of the restraint. Other staff stated they didn't believe [Staff 1] injured [Client 1] on purpose, and [Client 1's] injury was an accident." Additionally, the re-breaking of Client 1's arm/wrist during a subsequent restraint was investigated and has an inconclusive finding as well due to not knowing what specifically caused that re-break as Client 1 also had been hitting his previously injured hand/wrist on windows aggressively immediately before the restraint. An exit interview was conducted with CPM and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess called the facility to let them know she needed to deliver the findings to this complaint. Investigations Branch Investigator Curtis Eichel (IB) investigated this complaint by reviewing medical records, incident reports, case notes, photographs, and conducting confidential interviews with four clients, and 15 staff on 7/31/2020, 10/21/2020, 10/26/2020, 10/28/2020, 11/17/2020, and 12/15/2020. LPA Burgess collected documents and conducted two joint interviews with IB.

met_with: Annette Jumper, David Baker, Todd Aquilina
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess, LPA Chad Cabigon, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez, and Regional Manager (RM) Margo Castaneda met with Director Annette Jumper, CEO David Baker, and Board President Todd Aquilina to discuss recent serious deficiencies. Linda Abdelbaki, Program Planner with CPS, was also present during the meeting. Issues discussed today: 1. Lack of supervision. 2. Administrative oversight. 3. Incident Reporting. 4. Emergency Interventions. 5. False reporting. 6. Personal rights. Discussion: 1: Lack of Supervision - Director explained that they had meetings with staff to explain how getting coverage works, and that they wrote up a system for how staff can get support. Explained who all is on campus who can be contacted for extra support. Explained how they handle staff in crisis situation. Subsequent trainings conducted. How they hold staff accountable. They do not use administrative staff as part of the ratio, however Administration assists in situations. 2: Administrator Oversight: It was discussed that the Administrator needs to be present at the facility for a minimum of 20 hours per week. Director and CEO informed CCL staff present that there are actually multiple Administrator-qualified members of the staff who are present in the facility to meet this requirement. It is understood that the Administrator(s) shall provide oversight of the staff.

3. Incident Reporting: There was an incident regarding bed bugs at the facility for which an incident report was sent to CCL on 5/24/2021, and the facility did not update/report new developments. Director explained all steps they have taken to get rid of the bed bugs since then. The facility did not notify CCL about them moving the clients to the gym while the facility was being treated. It was explained to Director/CEO/President that they must notify CCL about moving clients. LPM asked Director how they are training their staff to write incident reports. Director explained. LPM asked Director about what they ask staff to remove from incident reports, and Director explained. 4. Emergency Interventions: The facility uses the ProAct emergency intervention program which includes non-physical and physical interventions. The facility trains staff in trauma-informed care. 5. False Reporting: CCL and Administration discussed the substantiated finding of false claims from the complaint delivered on 12/18/2020. This complaint was re-opened on 5/6/2021 to obtain more information. CCL explained to Administration that concluding the further investigation, the finding that staff falsified a document, stands. Administration will take further action with the staff who falsified a document, and send the plan and documentation to CCL. 6. Personal Rights: RM discussed the case management finding delivered on 12/18/2020 regarding a staff member violating two clients personal rights by picking them up and pushing them. RM informed Administrative staff that CCL is taking an Administrative Action against that staff to be excluded. LPA Chad Cabigon and Director will develop a plan to check in with each other weekly. An exit interview was conducted with Director and CEO. This report will be emailed to Director with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.

The client needed a refill, however the medication prescribed required a prior authorization from Medi-Cal. The facility worked with the pharmacy to get the prior authorization ahead of time, however, it did not come in time. The facility proactively requested an emergency supply of the medication. The emergency supply ran out, one dose, before the prior authorization was approved and the full prescription could be filled. The misunderstanding in the MAR occurred because staff were giving the emergency supply to the client, however it was miscommunicated and not documented properly, so other staff thought the client missed the medication. LPA found that the pharmacy and Medi-Cal issues caused the missed dose of medication, and not the facility. Since then, the facility did conduct a refresher training with staff to prevent any future confusion. LPA also found that two staff did mismanage two different clients' medications. 1. On 4/25/2021, one staff gave a client another client's medication. The client was monitored and had no issues. The staff was written up and provided a refresher training. 2. On 5/14/2021, another staff gave a different client another client's medication. The client was monitored and had no issues. The staff was written up and provided a refresher training. LPA obtained those write-ups and proof of training. Due to staff mismanaging clients' medications, LPA finds the allegation that staff are mismanaging minors medication to be substantiated, or true. On this date the facility is being cited for a violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, section 80078(a). At 3:00 PM, an exit interview was conducted with CEO and Director. A copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Director with a read receipt which will serve as her signatures.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess, LPA Chad Cabigon, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez met with Director Annette Jumper and CEO David Baker during an informal office meeting to deliver the findings of this complaint. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing Medication Administration Records (MAR), Faxes, Central Stored Medication and Destruction Record (CSMDR), Prescriptions, Incident Reports, Write-Ups and Refresher Training documents, and by conducting confidential interviews with the Reporting Party and three staff, including Administration staff, on 3/18/2021, 6/8/2021, and 6/9/2021. Based on interviews and review of the CSMDR, MARs, Fax, Prescriptions and interviews with staff, LPA found that the client who it was alleged to have missed medication, even though it was still recorded on the client's MAR that he was taking the medication, did miss one dose of medication, however it was not the fault of the facility.

deficiencies.description:
Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

This requirement was not me as evidenced by: Based on interviews, incident reports, and write-ups, two staff failed to properly care for two clients by giving them another client's medication. This is an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility already wrote the two staff up and provided training to them. No further action necessary.

narrative: control company to come out and spray. The company did come out and spray, however afterwards, the gnats tried to escape from under the house, flying through the crawlspace and dying in the pantry. At the time, the food was removed from the pantry and put in the kitchen. Staff sprayed the gnats nightly, and wiped them up the following day. The pest control company did come out to spray again. During interviews, LPA learned that the cycling of gnats lasted for about four weeks. On 2/16/2021 when LPA visited the facility and observed the dead gnats in the pantry, it was about the time that the gnat issue was resolving. After that inspection, the facility had maintenance staff clean out the overhead light where the dead gnats were, and other staff cleaned up the rest. Soon after, the facility put a mat over the closed crawlspace to try to further prevent anymore gnats from coming through. This completely resolved the issue. In subsequent visits (in person, and virtually) to the facility, LPA did not observe any more gnats in the pantry. Based on all the interviews and evidence, LPA found that the facility did have insects, so the finding for this allegation is substantiated, or true, however LPA also found the facility did take the correct actions necessary to rid the facility of the pests. Therefore, no citation will be issued. At 2:53 PM, an exit interview was conducted with CEO and Administrator and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was emailed to Administrator with a read receipt which will serve as the signature.

While C1’s statement to LPA about the purported incident remained consistent and detailed, and LPA found no ulterior motive in C1 to which the allegation might be attributed, none of the other seven children interviewed corroborated, or spoke to being able to witness, the alleged pushing of client C1 into a wall by a direct-care staff. C1’s authorized representative, a Fresno County Worker, also did not report C1 having disclosed the incident at any point. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews, and a review of records, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. No Title 22 Regulations or Interim Licensing Standards were cited as a result of this investigation. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection A continuation SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall on February 17, 2022 at 12 noon. During the inspection, LPA Hall met with Erica Arreygue, Health Services Coordinator, and Amanda Drumheller, Clinical Program Manager. LPA conducted an inspection, reviewed files, and completed interviews on February 16, 2022. LPA completed the assessment of files and interviews on February 17, 2022. This part of the report has been amended from the original report date of 06/14/2021 to remove language regarding the alleged falsification of documents—as, after further review, the Department determined that this was cited incorrectly; the deficiency will be amended to Section 87095 (b) Emergency Interventions. The licensee must use a continuum of interventions, starting with the least restrictive intervention. The Department has determined that there was sufficient evidence of an unwarranted restraint based on the text message sent by the direct care staff. LPA found through interviews that the facility fails to provide adequate supervision of clients. Staff stated there are not enough staff to provide necessary 1:1 supervision of the clients when needed. Staff reported that when multiple escalations are happening simultaneously, there are not enough staff present to assist staff and supervise the remaining clients. Staff also reported that sometimes staff are not able to shadow clients who AWOL due to staff being stretched thinly in a crisis. It was disclosed by staff that four clients were left alone due to staff having to follow a high-risk client who AWOL'd and on another occasion staff left two clients alone with an intern, who is not counted in ratio and is not considered staff. Another staff stated that they had to leave three clients alone in a cottage before due to having to handle another situation, while radioed help needed to come assist. A client also confirmed that; frequently, up to two to three times a day, staff will have to radio for assistance when handling an emergent situation and the clients would be alone for five to ten minutes until someone else can come to assist. LPA observed a common scenario of staff being stretched thinly to where they cannot handle the supervision needs of clients when multiple clients are in crisis, or restraints, or AWOL. Although the facility meets the general minimum ratio required in the Interim Licensing Standards, they are not providing adequate staffing ratios for the clients' needs and behaviors. Based on interviews, LPA has found the allegation that the facility does not provide adequate supervision of clients to be substantiated, or true.

The facility is being cited for violations of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Version 3.1 Section 87095 (b) Emergency Interventions. The facility was also cited for Section 87065.5(g). An office meeting was held on 6/14/2021 with the Department's Regional Manager, Licensing Program Manager, Licensing Program Analyst and facility representatives to further discuss these serious violations. A copy of this report was sent to the Administrator, Annette Jumper, by email with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.
investigation_findings: LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing extermination records and emails, incident reports, and by conducting confidential interviews with nine clients, seven staff, and the reporting party on 9/28/2020, 10/12/2020, 11/5/2020, 12/9/2020, 12/10/2020, 12/14/2020, and 12/16/2020. Two clients declined to be interviewed. Based on the interviews, LPA confirmed that the facility did previously have a flea infestation in the campus's fields of grass, and cottage. This infestation did affect both clients and staff, with them getting bitten. Clients were provided with bug spray and itch cream when needed to keep the clients protected. The facility did address the issue multiple times with exterminators until the problem was erradicated. LPA found the allegation that the facility is infested with insects to be substantiated, or true. However, based on evidence the facility handled the infestation appropriately. No citation will be issued.

deficiencies.description:
If a child requires special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty direct care staff shall be increased.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, the facility staffs at the minimum ratio requirement, when the clients they serve behaviors' demand additional staff to support them. This is an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: By POC due date of 12/21/2020 the facility will submit a written plan detailing what staff they will allocate to provide additional supervision of clients, as well as how they will hold staff accountable. By POC due date of 1/18/2021, the facility will submit this as a written policy and procedure for how staff will provide additional support and supervision, as well as how they will be held accountable.

deficiencies.description:
Clients have personal rights including the right to not be locked in any room, building, or facility premises at any time.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, the facility violated this personal right by mannualy holding a door to a protective separation room closed, trapping clients inside. This is an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: By POC due date 1/20/2021 the facility staff will submit sign-in sheets or comfirmation emails that they received Behavior Management training, which includes the prohibition of locking clients in rooms, as well as a list of the topics covered.

there was at least one staffer present in the cottage where the incident took place, the child in question was in a bedroom and out of the line of sight of that staffer who was farther down the hallway. narrative: On 02/16/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon continued the Required Annual inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program). LPA was received by Sacramento Children's Home Administrator Angelique Stephney-Hasting. LPA then met with Belle Darsie, Quality Improvement Manager, to discuss record-keeping. Residential Clinical Program Manager Amanda Drumheller facilitated a subsequent tour of the cottage where the following were observed: the facility’s license and the Foster Youth Rights were posted in conspicuous locations; the refrigerator and freezer temperatures were at 36 and 0 degrees F, respectively; bathroom fixtures delivered hot water (sinks, showers) whose temperatures were recorded within the required range: 105 – 120 degrees F. Ms. Drumheller was also interviewed as part of this inspection; a Residential Counselor was interviewed, as well. LPA continued the review of client records; additional time is needed to complete the inspection. No deficiencies are being cited as of this time. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

On 02/15/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon started to conduct an unannounced Required Annual inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program). LPA met with Director of Child & Family Programs Annette Jumper who gave a tour of the facility’s physical plant. Part of the cottage’s east wing was under renovation and kept off limits to the residents—but sufficient bathroom facilities (showers, toilets, sinks) and common areas were available for the use of the cottage’s clients. The facility’s fire alarm system was tested and found to be operational. The kitchen, food prep and storage areas were observed to be clean and sanitary. The children’s bedrooms had the required bedding and the furniture were in good repair. A First Aid Kit/Box was fully stocked with the required items. Medication were found to be centrally stored and secured. No potentially hazardous areas or items such as household chemicals and/or cleaning solutions, knives and other sharp kitchenware were found to be left accessible. An interview was conducted with a residential assistant; confidential client records were kept secured and made available for this LPA to review. Additional time is needed to complete this inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility

According to interviews, multiple school personnel were of the opinion, based on the youth’s appearances and their demeanor, that they were not well enough to have gone to school on the day of the incident in question. Some additional first aid was administered at the school after the youth were dropped off by facility staff. Furthermore, the school indicated that there was little to no follow-through on the part of the facility in that not enough was communicated to the school by the Cowell Center by way of endorsement as to what had happened to the youth just that morning. Medical records do indicate that youth were ultimately taken to the hospital later in the day. Corroborating statements from facility staff also indicate that medical treatment was offered, and while youth allowed some first aid to be administered at the Cowell Center, youth initially refused being taken to acute care. As for whether proper interventions were utilized by staff, statements obtained from youth and staff were inconsistent about staff’s actions in responding to the incident in real time. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility
