narrative: Per reports, on 04/02/2024 during a crisis, a youth (C1) got a hold of broken glass from a window that they broke. While in possession of the glass, the youth swung at other youth and facility staff and threatened to harm people with it. Law enforcement officers eventually detained the youth who was transported to a hospital for a 5150 evaluation. As a result of this incident, the facility discharged the youth from the program—when the hospital determined that the youth was no longer a danger to others or the youth’s self and was therefore ready to be discharged from acute care, the facility did not accept the youth back citing safety concerns, and deferred to the youth’s parent for placement elsewhere. In the facility’s Discharge Policy, a copy of which was acknowledged and signed by both the youth and the youth’s adoptive parent, the facility has a provision that allows an unplanned discharge—a more immediate discharge without the usual 14-day notice—if it is determined that a client is “a clear danger to self or others.” In submitted Incident Reports and CFT meeting notes, C1’s difficulty in controlling their anger, impulsiveness, as well as a history of physical aggression towards peers and staff were documented along with the facility’s efforts in trying to address these behaviors. Documentation also shows that there were times during placement when the youth was doing well as evidenced by a decrease in disruptive and problematic behaviors. A more recent interview with the youth and with staff at the youth’s current placement indicated that the youth has not displayed any dangerous behaviors and was generally doing well. Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore the allegations is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 09/23/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to close this complaint investigation. LPA met with Amanda Drumheller, Residential Clinical Program Manager, to whom the following findings were delivered: LPA opened the complaint investigation on 04/10/2024. Interviews were conducted with youth, facility staff, and the youth’s legal guardian. Records reviewed as part of the investigation were the following: a youth’s Needs & Services Plan, incident reports, CFT meeting notes, and intake documents (including facility policies). (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: Of the nine interviewed staff, no one corroborated that a client had ever been kept in the protective separation room (Behavioral Management Center or BMC) for more than 45 minutes; out of seven confidential client interviews, only one other client (apart from the alleged victim) stated that youth have been kept in the separation room for one and a half hours or more—this client described having been kept in the separation room for as long as five hours but that the usual amount of time that a youth is in the BMC is five minutes. Six out of seven youths interviewed did not confirm experiencing, or having witnessed or heard of, any client being lifted, dragged, or otherwise forcibly taken by staff to the BMC. All nine staff interviewed were consistent in describing the protocol for utilization of the BMC, including which actions by staff are allowed and which are prohibited in trying to get youth to the separation room—particularly, staff were in corroboration that when a client drops their weight staff can only wait for that client to get back up, and that no kind of lifting is ever allowed. Regarding a youth being hit by another peer, three of the seven clients interviewed corroborated this but described it only within the context of peer-to-peer fighting involving the client in question, with one of the other clients characterizing the said youth as the actual aggressor. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report is being provided to the facility along with the Appeal Rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 07/08/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) to close the complaint investigation and deliver the findings; LPA met with Clinical Residential Program Manager Amanda Drumheller to whom the following was reported: On 03/27/2025 LPA initiated the investigation at the STRTP during which time a tour of the facility’s physical plant was conducted as well as interviews with staff and youth. LPA investigated allegations that 1) Staff handled minor roughly, 2) Staff used inappropriate discipline, and 3) Due to lack of supervision, minor punched another minor. Throughout the course of the investigation, a total of seven clients, nine staff, and two family members of clients were interviewed; records were also obtained as part of the investigation. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative:
On June 07, 2021 at 9:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted an annual/required inspection at the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met Administrator Tami Tutolo. The facility is licensed to provide services to six (6) female clients ages 12-17 years old and to Non-Minor dependents. There are currently 4 clients in placement. LPA together with the Administrator did a walkthrough of the entire facility at 9:50 AM. Physical Plant: LPA observed the following required posted items were accessible to clients: facility license, grievance procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman poster, Emergency Disaster Plan, daily schedule/activities, and menu. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Sharp knives and sharp utensils were locked inside the cabinet in the office. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were tested and working. The fire extinguisher is in the kitchen and serviced this year. The first aid kit was checked and complete. Each client is supplied with personal hygiene products. There was extra towels and linens for clients use in cabinets. The hot water temperature in the bathroom was checked using a digital thermometer and registered at 112 degrees Fahrenheit. There are two (2) bedrooms that has two twin beds and two (2) other bedrooms that has solo occupancy with one (1) twin bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The facility outside grounds was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There are no swimming pool/bodies of water located on the premises.

Staffing: At 10:20 AM, LPA started to review staff and client files. LPA obtained Personnel Summary report (LIC 500) from the facility. LPA reviewed eight (8) staff’s file. All staff’s file contained the required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Personnel files were maintained in their Human Resource office on a different location. Mr. Mitchell Quintero from HR office brought the staff’s file at the facility for review. All eight (8) personnel who required caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions and associations. Staff’s file contains the Mandated Reporter/acknowledgement form. Facility staff is conducting on going staff performance evaluation and current with CPR/First Aid and Relias training. Client Records: LPA reviewed six (6) client files. Documentation for each client is complete, signed and current. All medications are recorded and logged. Psychotropic medications prescribed have current JV220 court order, medical consent authorization is available for review and current in client’s file. Facility is providing adequate services with the client’s needs & services plan; it is current and updated. At 12:05 PM LPA started the interview. LPA interviewed two (2) clients and two (2) staffs. LPA was provided with current LIC 500, LIC 309 and current Board Meeting minutes. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews on this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator. LPA provided a copy of the following reports: LIC 809, LIC 809C, LIC 858, LIC 859, were provided to Administrator Tami Tutolo.

On June 29, 2021 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted an unannounced case management at Heritage Youth Services-1, a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met Connie Marquez, Case Manager (CM) and Monica Quintero, Facility Manager (FM) regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing Department (CCLD) on June 12, 2021. On June 17, 2021, LPA interviewed STRTP Administrator Tami Tutolo via telephone and today, June 29, 2021 interviewed via telephone Therapist Laura Workman with regards to Non-Minor Dependent’s (NMD) filing a police report (reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated June 29, 2021) at the facility. According to the Administrator NMD filed a police report due to be a victim of domestic violence from her boyfriend. The violence altercation according to the NMD, was that her boyfriend pulled her nose ring that led to a bleeding of her nose. Per Administrator, there was no tearing, or bruise or marks on her nose and face and she did not want to see a medical doctor. Administrator stated that County placement worker has been notified about NMD’s police report and CSW has been in contact with NMD and met her outside of the facility for more support. Per Administrator, NMD refused to file a restraining order to her boyfriend, but nonetheless an Officer gave NMD instructions on how to file a request of restraining order. The plan of action, per Administrator that they have put in place is that they have asked NMD to block the name and telephone number of her boyfriend on her phone, which NMD stated that she did. The CSW was notified and in constant contact with the NMD, she communicates to staff when she signs herself off to the community, NMD let the staff know if she is staying overnight. STRTP staff double checks when NMD leaves, get the license plate number of the vehicle, reminds NMD to answer or reply staffs phone calls or text messages. Per Therapist, she conducts a safety check with NMD twice a week and continues to offer assistance with filing a restraining order should NMD change her mind. Therapist stated that she continues to be in contact with the NMD with safety checks and educate her about the cycle of abuse. LPA Robles informed Administrator to submit an addendum with regards to the safety plan of action for the NMD that was submitted to CCLD on 6/18/21. Based on the information obtained through interviews and records reviewed there is no evidence of any violation of Title 22. There were no deficiencies cited at this time, and a copy of LIC 809, LIC 811 was given to the facility representative.

On July 30, 2021 at 1:18 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted an unannounced case management at Heritage Youth Services-1, a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met Tami Tutolo, Administrator regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing Department (CCLD) on July 07, 2021. Today, July 30, 2021 at 9:40 AM, LPA interviewed STRTP Administrator Tami Tutolo via telephone with regards to Non-Minor Dependent’s (NMD) filing police report (reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated July 30, 2021) that she was sexually assaulted while on pass. According to the Administrator, NMD was in a home pass due to being on a level for attending her therapy, finishing her chores and DCFS CSW approved the home pass with her boyfriend. When NMD returned to the facility on 7/07/21, she reported to staff that she was sexually assaulted while on pass at Los Angeles. NMD reported she was separated with her boyfriend when the sexual assault incident happened. Per Administrator, staff contacted the Pomona Law Enforcement (LE) to report it the same day. Pomona LE responded and took NMD’s statement and informed NMD that an Officer from Los Angeles Police Department LAPD will need to get another statement since the sexual assault took place in Los Angeles. Per Administrator, Dr. Tamayo facility’s Mental Health Supervisor accompanied NMD the following day in 7/08/21 to San Gabriel Valley Medical Center for a medical examination or rape test kit exam. According to Administrator, upon arrival at the facility from the Medical Center, NMD took a shower and when she came out, staff noticed several superficial cuts on her left leg. Staff and Dr. Tamayo implemented crisis intervention. Per administrator she provided first aid until paramedics arrived due to NMD’s expressing loneliness and not wanting to live. SIR disclosed that Dr. Tamayo updated NMD’s safety plan, including social media safety planning and increased therapy sessions with Therapist. NMD will meet individually with her therapist at least 3x weekly. Per Administrator, NMD and all other clients will not be given a razor to shave but will be given a cream instead.

Per SIR addendum, NMD was discharged from the hospital on 7/13/21. Dr. Tamayo met NMD and updated her safety plan. NMD was provided a one on one for a period of 24 hours to assist her emotionally. Per Administrator, NMD now has a job and participated in the Child Family Team (CFT) meeting held on 07/20/21, which documented that NMD agrees that she will continue to practice safety when she goes on out-passes as well as during her time on social media. NMD will continue to practice clear communication with the team about her whereabouts. Staff and therapist will continue to work with NMD about safety and encourage her to reach out to investigators and to notify first CSW and case manager in order to make sure she is safe before communicating or going to a specific meeting. LPA was provided with CFT document held on 7/20/21 and NMD’s written safety plan dated on 3/31/21, 7/06/21 and 7/13/21. Based on the information obtained through interviews and records reviewed there is no evidence of any violation of Title 22. There were no deficiencies cited at this time, and a copy of LIC 809, LIC 811 was given to the facility representative.

When client’s AWOL from the facility staff will attempt to redirect, offer support and provide alternatives to clients. The facility staff indicated once client’s AWOL from the facility, staff will follow on foot, report to law enforcement and the placement agency. The confidential interviews conducted did not collaborate the allegation. The placement agency social workers indicated having no concerns with the facility. There was no corroborating information obtained through interviews nor review of records to confirm the allegation. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegation is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegation. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On July 27, 2021 at 12:45 PM Licensing Program Analyst Larry Cabral (LPA) conducted a follow-up inspection for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint allegation. LPA Cabral met with Facility Program Director Maria Serratos. During the course of the investigation, LPA Cabral interviewed three facility staff, three clients and attempted to interview two clients on 3/26/21. LPA interviewed one client on 7/22/21 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated July 27, 2021). LPA interviewed three county social workers on 7/22/21 and attempted to interview two county social workers on 3/26/21. LPA reviewed other agencies investigative narrative, client discharge summary, facility’s incident reports and facility documents on 7/26/21. The facility staff denied the allegation that staff did not adequately supervise clients. The facility staff indicated clients are supervised at all times.

narrative: Records show that minor admitted to ingesting pills minor illegally purchased during AWOL, resulting in minor overdosing while in transit to an activity. Staff with minor was alerted by minor’s labored breathing and acted appropriately by calling 911 and following 911 operator instructions until emergency medical technicians (EMTs) arrived. Minor was hospitalized and released after two days. Facility staff provided counseling and support to minor through an emergency Child and Family Team (CFT) meeting and safety plan. Information obtained reveal that the incident was accidental. Minor refused to discuss the incident with LPA. Regarding minor’s participation in CSEC, confidential interviews and records show that minor has a history of risky behaviors; these are addressed in minor’s treatment plan. Minor refused to discuss any AWOL incidents with LPA. Other minors in care admitted to going AWOL but refused to provide details. Minors denied being unsupervised. Staff were consistent in explaining facility protocol when minors AWOL: staff will counsel minors not to leave, follow on foot until it’s safe if minors leave, take note of direction of AWOL and if picked up by a vehicle, note vehicle information and direction vehicle went. Staff also described safety procedures when minors return from AWOL. Based on information obtained during the investigation, the allegations are unsubstantiated due to lack of corroborating evidence. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met. A copy of this signed report, the Confidential Names form dated 1/14/22 and Appeal Rights forms were provided to the facility representative. No deficiency citation was issued.
investigation_findings: 13On January 14, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a complaint inspection to deliver the finding of the allegations. LPA reviewed documents such as, but not limited to, the Needs and Case Plan Summary from placement agencies, Needs and Services Plans which include clients’ case plans and treatment plans, incident reports and law enforcement contact reports. It was alleged that minor had a drug overdose while in care and minor participated in CSEC. Information obtained reveal that minor has a history of AWOL and hides contraband items obtained from AWOL in private areas of minor’s body to avoid being confiscated by staff.

investigation_findings: 13On December 30, 2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto delivered the findings of the complaint investigation by tele-conference and electronic mail. LPA discussed the findings with the facility representative named above. LPA investigated the allegation by conducting interviews with facility staff on 9/16/20, 12/22/20 and 12/28/20, placement agency staff on 9/15/20 and client on 12/28/20. LPA reviewed records such as the Needs and Case Plan Summary, Needs and Services Plan, Incident Report and placement agency report. It was alleged that facility staff handled client in a rough manner causing injuries. The staff involved (S1) denied the allegation. S1 denied having physical contact with client and stated that client charged towards S1 from behind and client fell on the bed after S1 avoided contact with client. Other staff (S2) present explained that other clients were in distance learning class and client refused requests from staff to turn down the volume of client’s speaker. S1 intervened by taking the speaker from client. S2 left the scene after S1 requested S2 to call the police because client came up from behind S1 and took S1’s phone.

narrative: On January 29, 2021 at 1:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez conducted a virtual conference via Facetime with Administrator Maria Serratos. The purpose of the virtual conference was to discuss the report with the administrator regarding the follow-up conducted to an incident about the alleged sexual contact between two clients and drug use in the facility. On July 30, 2020 Investigator, Olivia Spindola interviewed client ref #1(C1). On September 29, 2020, LPA interviewed clients C2 and C3 and staff S1, S2, and S3 see LIC 811 (Confidential Names List) and requested records consisted of the client roster and facility daily logs. On October 8, 2020 LPA interviewed C4 and on October 9, 2020 interviewed C5 and reviewed the records received. Also reviewed were the Special Incident Report (SIR) and collateral interviews. On January 12, 2021, LPA interviewed administrator Serratos about the alleged incident. All five clients interviewed confirmed that there are at least two staff in the facility every shift. C1 did not deny the sexual contact but denied she was sexually abused while C2 denied it happened. Both clients denied drug use in the facility. The information received was that C1 and C2 sneaked around and do things in between the time staff conducts checks on clients in their rooms although room visiting is not allowed in the facility. The facility daily logs showed the routine checks conducted by staff every 30 minutes on clients noting their activities or whereabouts. Based on the information gathered, although the alleged incident(s) may have happened, there was no clear evidence to prove neglect or lack of supervision on the part of the facility staff. Therefore, no further follow-up is needed regarding the alleged incident. A copy of the report was emailed to Administrator Serratos for signature. No deficiency citations issued.

On June 14, 2023, at 11:45 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez and John Bonilla conducted an unannounced case management inspection to the facility and met with Administrator, Farrah Richmond regarding an incident report that the Department received on May 12, 2023. The incident report indicated that Client #1 (C1) was sexually assaulted by an individual at the local park while on unauthorized absence (UA) from the facility. LPA conducted an interview with Administrator Farrah Richmond and C1 regarding the incident. Based on confidential interviews and records review, it was verified that C1 was on unauthorized absence when the alleged incident happened. Also based on the information gathered, the facility staff followed their protocol when C1 left the facility without authorization, when she came back and after the alleged incident was reported. The facility took the appropriate action regarding this incident. No further follow-up is necessary regarding the incident currently. A copy of LIC 809 and LIC 811 were provided to the facility representative listed above and an exit interview was conducted. There were no deficiency citations issued at this time.

On August 10, 2023, at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez conducted an unannounced case management inspection to the facility and met Farrah Richmond, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection is to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department. The SIR indicated that client ref#1 (C1) see LIC 811 (Confidential Names List) complained of throat pain and was taken by the staff to the hospital. She was discharged while waiting for the lab result the same day. That same afternoon, staff received a call from the hospital that C1 has an infection. She was prescribed medication and discharged. The treatment team counseled C1 about safe sex and provided her educational materials and a refresher from the sex education she participated before. Per Administrator Richmond, C1 was placed in another facility on 07/10/23. C1 refused to attend Planned Parenthood classes. A copy of In-House Special Incident Report and Refusal of Treatment Form regarding C1's refusal to attend the class were provided to LPA. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the LIC 809 and LIC 811 were provided to the administrator. No deficiency citation is issued at the time of the inspection.

On October 12, 2023 at 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez made a case management inspection to the facility and met Farrah Richmond, Administrator. The purpose of the case management was to follow up regarding the information the Department received. On 10/10/23, the Department received information that client (C1) reported to a school staff that she visited a friend who had a gun. C1's friend accidentally pointed the gun at her which she grabbed and pointed at her own head. She stated, she did it jokingly. She denied being suicidal. The school security checked C1's backpack and did not find any weapon on her. LPA gathered information from the administrator, that C1 runaway with another client (C2) on 10/04//23. C2 returned on 10/05/23 while C1 returned on 10/06/23. The facility staff made an incident report when both clients runaway on 10/04/23 and an addendum regarding their return. C1 reported to the facility staff that the police talked to her at school to make sure she was not suicidal. She denied being suicidal. She denied the gun incident is how it really happened without giving more detail and stated that everything was fine. C1 did not disclose who her friend was who allegedly has a gun. C1 saw and was assessed by a therapist at the facility. A copy of the incident report regarding the clients’ runaway incident with addendum was provided to LPA by the administrator. C1 was not available for interview at the time of inspection. Based on the information gathered, the incident needs no further follow-up currently. No deficiency citation was issued at the time of the inspection. A copy of LIC 809 and LIC 811 were provided to the administrator.

LPA observed the following: a posted license, Children's Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Plan, menu, the staff schedule, activity, and activity schedule. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were working. There was adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All bedrooms have adequate drawers and closet spaces for clients use. All the beds were observed with clean mattresses, linens, and pillows. There were extra towels, linens, and hygiene supplies in the cabinets. All sharp objects, medications and cleaning solutions were stored inside a locked cabinet. The hot water was tested using a digital thermometer and the temperature was (113 degrees Fahrenheit). All confidential records were stored in a locked cabinet inside the staff office. The passageways and hallways were unobstructed. There was no body of water on the premises. LPA interviewed two clients and two staff available for interview at the time.

Client Records LPA reviewed six client records. The client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables, education records, and personal rights forms. Staff Records LPA reviewed five staff records. The staff subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and cleared. There is documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training in the personnel file. The administrator and staff members whose files were reviewed meets the required qualifications and/or experience. An exit interview was conducted and copy of LIC 809, LIC 809C and LIC 811s were provided to the administrator. No deficiency citation issued at the time of the inspection.

The investigation revealed an allegation whereby a foster child in placement uploaded nude pictures of another foster child through Instagram from the child’s personal cellphone. It also alleged that the foster child got beat up by the foster child in placement. Confidential statements obtained during the investigation were unable to corroborate the allegations as the staff denied the incident took place due to lack and supervision and that staff intervene when the foster child attempted to beat up a foster child. Staff indicated that crisis communication was used during the incident. Interviews revealed that the foster child that was previously placed at the facilty climbed through the window which was opened by a new client who had no clue both foster children had issues with each other. Interviews with staff revealed that foster child voluntary had provided the other foster child with the PIN # to her cell phone which gave her access to everything on her phone. Interviews with County Social Worker indicated that both foster children got along well but had a recent fall out because one foster child began dating the other foster child’s boyfriend which created conflict between them. The staff reported that the house rules is something that’s discussed constantly with clients to prevent incidents such as the misuse of cellphones. Other statements obtained during the investigation were unable to corroborate the allegation. LPA attempted to interview both foster children but was unsuccessful due to both foster children being AWOL from their placements. CSW indicated that they cannot be located. Based on the information gathered, the allegation is unsubstantiated as the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met although the allegation may have happened or is valid. A copy of this report and Confidential Names Form were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

It was alleged that NMD was jumped by two other clients. NMD suffered a cut lip, bloody nose and was hit with a mirror on her back. NMD stepped on broken glass and suffered a cut on her foot. Staff when interviewed indicated when the incident happened staff attempted to intervene, and staff attempted to redirect clients from fighting. Staff called law enforcement, reported the incident, and called for medical attention for the clients. Staff indicated NMD refused any medical attention. NMD when interviewed indicated the clients are always supervised, however staff did not do a good job at preventing NMD from being attacked. NMD stated NMD stepped on a broken piece of glass and cut her foot. NMD stated staff attempted to stop NMD from fighting the other clients. NMD stated NMD refused medical attention. C2 when interviewed indicted NMD was the aggressor and stated staff attempted to intervene, called law enforcement, and offer the clients medical attention. LPA attempted to interview C3, however C3 was not home at the time. CSW when interviewed indicated having no concerns with the facility. Although the incident happened staff attempted to intervene, called law enforcement, reported the incident, and sought medical attention for the clients. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited

On 10/25/23 the Department received a complaint alleging the facility did not prevent client from chronically running away from care. It was alleged that client was physically assaulted and sexually trafficked while on AWOL from the facility. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, relevant parties denied the allegation indicating client ran away from the facility six times during client’s stay at the facility from 5/24/23 through 6/13/23. Confidential interviews indicated when clients AWOL from the facility staff will be attempted to redirect clients, offer alternatives, and follow clients as the clients are AWOLing. Staff will then report AWOL, and call law enforcement. Once a client returns staff will offer medical attention and a safety check is conducted. Confidential interviews revealed clients have no concerns with the facility and stated staff will attempt to redirect clients and offer alternatives. LPA was not able to obtain a statement from the alleged victim due to the victim being on run away status. CSW indicated having no concerns with the facility and stated the incident happened when client was on AWOL and no longer placed at the facility. CSW indicated the client has been on AWOL status for a year. The other agency’s delivered service logs and investigative report did not mention client being AWOL’d from the facility, however, there continues to be safety risks for client. LPA reviewed incident reports which indicated client AWOL’d from the facility six times. Each time client AWOL’d, staff wrote incident reports and intervention was attempted. LPA reviewed the STRTP’s run away plan and client’s safety plan which indicated the steps the facility took to try and discourage client from AWOLing. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegation is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.

The STRTP has obtained national accreditation from Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF) which will expire on June 30, 2022.. This STRTP is licensed to serve six (6) female ambulatory children ages 12-17 years of age and Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). The facility has no placement currently. Physical Plant This facility is a one story home with five (5) bedrooms and two (2) and a three quarter (3/4) bathrooms, living room, office, kitchen, dining and, laundry area. investigation_findings: 13On July 14, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Heriberto Perez conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with Tami Tutolo, Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations, LPA interviewed three clients on March 10, 2022, LPA interviewed one client on March 14, 2022, LPA interviewed one staff via telephone on June 23, 2022, LPA interviewed two staff via telephone on June 24, 2022 and LPA interviewed one staff and County Social Worker via telephone on 06/27/22 (see Confidential Names LIC 811 dated July 14, 2022). LPA analyzed pertinent documents such as Foster Child's Need and Case Plan Summary, Child & Family Team Planning Matrix and Special Incidents Reports. It was alleged Staff did not seek timely medical attention for youth in care and Staff do not allow youth to have confidential telephone calls. It was also alleged that Staff speaks inappropriately to youth in care.

narrative:
Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged staff are not providing minors in care a sufficient amount of food. Staff had similar statements and denied the allegation. Staff stated they go grocery shopping weekly for facility. LPA toured facility alongside Administrator and observed ample food for all children in care. Facility had emergency food supply, perishable and non- perishable items for children in care. Children stated that facility provides ample food and various options. It was also alleged; staff are not providing minors planned activities while in care. Staff had similar statements and stated that children are offered to attend various activities provided by the facility. Staff stated that sometimes children decline to attend those planned activities but that children are given the opportunity to attend and the option to see what activities are planned prior to the actual event taking place. Children had similar statements in that facility does have activities for them to do in the home. Additionally, it was alleged staff are using inappropriate forms of punishment with minors in care. Staff and children both denied the allegation. Staff stated that they do not use inappropriate forms of punishment. Staff stated when children get into trouble, they have privileges removed but that they are afforded opportunities to gain those privileges back. Staff stated children are not restricted from receiving essential items or necessities as forms of punishments. Children stated they have never seen or experienced staff restricting them or doing inappropriate forms of disciplines. Furthermore, it was alleged staff do not accord privacy to minors in care. Staff stated that it is policy to knock on doors prior to entering children’s rooms and if children do not answer they will announce entry into the room. Children stated that they are not aware or ever had any staff not afford them privacy in the home. It was alleged facility is in disrepair. Staff and children had similar statements in stating that home is well maintained and that if any issues or maintenance is needed that facility addresses issues immediately. On 10/20/2022 LPA and Administrator toured the facility both inside and out. LPA observed the facility to be in good repair and areas that needed repair already had a date of maintenance scheduled to complete and repair issues. It was alleged staff do not ensure that minor's in care get to school in a timely manner. Staff stated that children sometimes are delayed in getting up in the morning and refuse to go to school. Administrator stated that it has been an issue with tardiness with children and school administration and school resource officer have been to home numerous times to witness children refusing to go to school.

Children denied the allegation and stated that staff do try and get children to school on time but that sometimes children in the home cause a delay in getting to school on time. Lastly, it was alleged staff are interfering with minors' ability to purchase clothing while in care. Staff stated that children are given a monthly clothing allowance and that children usually use most of the allowance. However, if children have left over money, they receive the excess money to save or to use. Staff stated that children sign that they receive their allowances and it is documented in the amount that was used or provided back to child. Children had similar statements that they do receive allowances and that they are afforded opportunities to go to purchase clothing monthly. Documents reviewed identified staff do complete weekly grocery shopping and put in for maintenance repairs for facility. Based on information received and documents reviewed there was no indication that facility was or is in disrepair, children are receiving inappropriate disciplines, staff are not affording privacy to children, or that staff are the reason children are not getting to school in a timely manner. Although the allegations may have happened or may be true there is not a preponderance of evidence to support that the allegations did or did not happen. Therefore, this complaint is being closed Unsubstantiated. Exit interview was completed, no deficiencies cited, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator for review and signature.

narrative:
On August 18, 2022 at 9:49am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison arrived at Hillsides-Off Campus Satellite (OCS) for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection Visit. LPA Edison met with Casey Meinster, Senior Clinical Director and Andrew Hernandez, Director of Cottage Services who granted access into the facility and together a tour was conducted. The facility will provide care and supervision to four (4) children, female only, ages 15-17 years, ambulatory only. The facility will also provide services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W & I code 16501.1 (C) (1). The census on this day is zero (0). OCS is constructed as follows: The facility is located at the back of Hillsides main campus and has a total of three (3) bedrooms and two (2) bathrooms for client use. Bedroom #2 and Bedroom #3 are single occupancy and contain one (1) twin size bed in each of the bedrooms and a full-size desk. Bedroom #1 is double occupancy and contains two (2) twin size beds with two (2) desks to divide the bedroom. Bedroom #3 has a door which leads to the laundry room and is always kept locked. Bedroom #2 has a door which leads into the backyard area. All bedrooms have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, and adequate closet/storage space. All window screens are in good repair. There are two (2) bathrooms equipped with a sink and toilet. Bathroom #1 is also equipped with a stand in shower. Bathroom #2 is equipped with a tub/shower combination. All bathrooms are clean, operable, and sanitary. Hot water was measured within a safe temperature. The living room is equipped with a sofa, love seat, chair, and tables. All living room furniture was observed to be in good repair. The fireplace is not operable and has a screen bolted to keep it closed and secured. There is also a desk for staff use located in the living room. The dining area is located off the kitchen and is equipped with a wooden table with seating for five (5). The kitchen was observed to be clean and is equipped with a burner gas stove/microwave oven combination, dishwasher, refrigerator/freezer, and built-in wall oven. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be kept in a locked cabinet in the kitchen accessible by staff only. All knives and sharp objects will be kept locked in a kitchen drawer accessible by staff only. Continued on LIC 809-C

Meals are provided by Chartwell. Three meals and snacks will be provided for the clients and will be brought to OCS from the main campus cafeteria. The laundry area is located next to the kitchen and is equipped with a full sized operable washing machine and dryer and locked cabinets for laundry supplies. Laundry area has a separate area for staff office use. There is a hall closet between Bathroom #2 and Bedroom #1 which will store extra linens and hygiene products. There is a hall closet near Bedroom #3 which will store extra linens and blankets. All prescribed and over the counter medications will be kept locked in the central nurse’s office located on Hillsides main campus accessible and administered only by nursing staff. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and are operable. There are three (3) regulation fire extinguishers, all fully charged. Facility also has a Fire Alarm Pull System. First aid kit located in laundry/staff area. LPA observed the facility to have adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The front and backyards were inspected and found to be clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Foster youth bill of rights and grievance procedures were posted. Caregiver(s)/adults working/residing in the home must have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Checks. Emergency Mass Disaster Plan was posted. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. The home will operate within the capacity and limitations of the license. LPA Follow Up: · Food Service Waiver due to staff informing CCL that meals (breakfast, lunch and dinner) will be transported from one facility (main campus cafeteria) to another (OCS). Food service Procedure in Plan of Operations must be reviewed by CCL. · Perishable and non-perishable food will be supplied prior to resident move-in Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Senior Clinical Director.

investigation_findings: 13LPA Connie Jones-Steward informed Program Director Christine Gonzalez of the additional allegation that was added to the complaint. Ms. Gonzalez stated that Client #1 started out by wearing a "fake" nose piercing, so staff was not aware of the fact that she had an actual piercing until sometime after the fact. Ms. Gonzalez also admitted that there was no incident report filed regarding the piercing. Ms. Gonzalez stated that she was unaware of an issue with the music that the client had downloaded to her personal device, LPA Jones-Steward also interviewed Client #1. Client #1 stated that initially she wore a false nose ring and then pierced her own nose, She also stated that she wore earphones when she downloaded music so that staff was unaware of what she was downloading. Based on the conversations with the Program Director and Client #1, the allegations of lack of supervision are resolved as "unsubstantiated". A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

13LPA Jones-Steward discussed this additional allegation with Christine Gonzalez. Ms. Gonzalez admitted that a staff person did cut Client #1's hair without parental permission. This is against Hillside policy and the staff is receiving training on that issue.

13LPA spoke to Client #1 regarding the above allgations. Client #1 was very vauge in her answers. She clained that staff and clients were picking on her but in general she wouldn't say who and would not give specific dates. She did name one girl and one incident in particular but that situation was already investigated and resloved as part of a previous complaint. Based on lack of solid identifying information, these allegations are resolved as unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

narrative: On June 10, 2021 at 12:45 p.m Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cameo Banks and Emelyn Sanchez-Peralta. conducted an announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection for Hillsides. During the inspection LPA spoke with Christine Gonzalez, Director of Program Services. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via FaceTime and the facility was inspected inside and out. Both client and staff files and medication logs/documents were reviewed by LPA Banks and LPA Sanchez P. The current census is thirty seven (37) children. LPA Banks reviewed five (5) client files on 6/8/2021, 6/9/2021 & 6/10/2021. LPA Sanchez P. reviewed five (5) staff files on 6/7/2021, 6/8/2021, 6/9/2021, 6/10/2021, 6/11/2021. LPA. Banks conducted staff interviews with Staff #1, Staff #2 and Staff #3 on 6/10/2021. LPA Banks conducted four (4) children interviews on 6/10/2021 from 3:30 p.m. to 4:45pm LPA Banks conducted facility walk through of two cottages (Tradewins & Canyon), Outdoor Activity Space and Nursing Office on 6/10/2021 at 12:50 p.m. Overall, LPA Banks observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA observed adequate staffing at the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPA observed medication to be centrally stored, triple locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted on 6/14/2021 at 3:45pm, and a copy of this report will be e-mailed to the facility for signature.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA interviewed Client #1 and three of the four staff that she named in her complaint. 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA spoke to Client #1, Staff #1 and Staff #2. LPA also reviewed similar special incident reports. Based on the information gathered during the investigation, it was determined that Child #1 did swallow safety glass. It was also determined that there is a pattern developing of children swallowing glass that gets left behind by clean up crews. However at the time there have been no serious injuries reported. Per Ms. Gonzalez the issue was discussed in the leadership meeting held on 06/30/21 and measures are being put into place to lessen the risk of further such incidents. LPA requested a written copy of the corrective action plan to be delivered to the Department by 07/15/21.

deficiencies.description:
Buildings & Grounds
80087(a)The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This requirement is not met as evidenced by Based on staff staff and client interview, and on SIR review. The facility did not ensure that broken glass was cleaned up. As a result, Client #1 was able to obtain and swallow a piece of safety glass. This poses and immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility has already recognized that there is a pattern developing that clients are able to obtain and swallow glass when they are in crisis. On 06/30/21, a plan was developed to purchase shop vacs that will do a more thorough job of cleaning up broken glass. Hillsides will submit a written copy of the CAP to the Department by 07/15/21

narrative: Several clients were interviewed and neither disclosed witnessing any physical abuse of C1 by staff members. During the investigation, several staff members implicated as witnessing the physical abuse were interviewed. Staff all denied witnessing the incidents C1 claimed occurred. The staff members C1 claimed abused C1 were interviewed. Each staff denied the allegations. The Department of Children and Family Services social workers also denied witnessing any marks or bruises on C1 during C1’s time at Hillsides. Therefore, based on the information obtained, the allegation of physical abuse is Unsubstantiated at this time, meaning although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove a violation occurred. There were no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22. Exit Interview conducted with Mr. DaSilva, and a copy of this report and appeal rights are emailed to Mr. DaSilva and Christine Gonzalez, Facility Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On July 23, 2021 at 11:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint investigation and met with Rob DaSilva, Crisis Prevention Coordinator for the purpose of concluding and delivering investigation findings. On February 1, 2021, CCLD received a complaint allegation regarding physical abuse by Staff Members on former resident, Client #1 (C1) [see LIC811 dated 7/23/2021]. It was alleged that staff members used excessive force towards C1 while restraining client causing various bruises and cuts to client’s person on multiple occasions while in care. The allegation was investigated by Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau, Investigator Dennis Douglas. During the course of the investigation, it was disclosed that staff members have “slammed C1’s head on the wall,” and “choke” C1. It was alleged the events were witnessed by other staff members. However, during the investigation it was disclosed that none of the incidents were witnessed by any of the other clients at the facility. The investigation revealed that C1 never alleged physical abuse during the time C1 was a client/resident at Hillsides. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

narrative:
During the investigation, interviews were conducted with, but not limited to, C1, S1, residents, and staff members. A review of facility records including past incident reports and client file history revealed insufficient evidence to support alleged claims. Review of an incident report involving S1 and C1 dated 12/17/2017, revealed in part that C1 was “bullying another client” while S1 was attempting to de-escalate the situation. C1 became upset and attempted to attack S1 as S1 attempted to restrain C1. At some point a physical altercation ensued between C1 and S1 resulting in both parties wrestling on the floor. Other staff were present and assisted S1 with restraining C1. S1 states that any physical contact made with C1 was non-sexual and only with the intent of restraining C1. There was no corroborating evidence to support claim. The investigation revealed that while physical contact was made during an apparent restraint between C1 and S1 on 12/17/2017, to which other staff were present and assisted, there is not enough evidence to support the allegation that S1 touched C1 inappropriately in private areas during the restraint and/or while in care. The finding has therefore been determined as Unsubstantiated meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove a violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights are emailed to Facility Administrator.

C1’s room and on another instance where C1 was showering. S1 reports that the instances were inadvertent, and no knocks were made prior to entering C1’s door. S1 reports being in a rush at the time and accidentally walked in on C1 during both incidents. S1 denies any sexual gratification derived from these incidents and states they were accidents. S1 states that S1 left immediately after both incidents. Based on the confidential interviews conducted and documentary evidence obtained during the investigation the preponderance of evidence standard has been met that a violation occurred, therefore the above allegation is determined Substantiated. Facility is cited per the Interim Licensing Standards for STRTP V 3.1; Section 87065.2 PERSONNEL DUTIES. S1 accidentally walked in C1's room on two separate occasions while C1 was undressing and while C1 was showering. Actions as such pose potential health and safety risks to children in care. Exit. deficiencies.description:
PERSONNEL DUTIES 
Direct care staff shall perform any duties that may be necessary to ensure the health and safety of children in the facility. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Investigation revealed Staff #1 (S1) admitted while employed at the facility between 2017 and 2018, S1 accidentally walked in on Client #1 (C1) on two separate occasions; while C1 was undressing and while C1 was showering. Records indicate incidents were not acknowledged or reported by S1. Actions as such pose potential health and safety risks to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility to submit a written plan of correction describing how facility will correct the deficiency and ensure incidents as such from reoccurring. Please include proof of training and attendance records of those attending (if applicable).

investigation_findings: 13LPA Connie Jones-Steward interviewed Andrew Hernandez (Director of Cottage Services) and Crystal Nava (Cottage Supervisor) regarding the above allegations, Per both staff people, Client #1 is always offered healthy snacks at bedtime. However the client is not always willing to accept the healthy snack. In this incident, the client became agitated because she wanted junk food at bedtime and it was denied to her. Therefore she alleged that she did not receive her snack. Both staff people also stated that Client #1 often provokes other clients as well as being provoked herself. When staff sees disagreements starting, clients are redirected and offered alternative activities such as going for a walk. LPA attempted to interview Client #1 about the allegations on two separate occasions. Both times, she declined to be interviewed Based on the information gathered and the clients unwillingness to be interviewed, these allegations are resolved as unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

narrative: Records reviewed revealed C1 resided at Hillsides from November 30, 2017, through October 8, 2018. Confidential statements obtained revealed the perpetrators who allegedly “raped” former resident (C1), were also clients of the facility and identified to be three male individuals (approximately 16-years of age). Statements obtained did not produce any witnesses to corroborate the incident besides the perpetrators. Statements further revealed the sexual assault incident was not disclose to any of the Hillside staff or C1’s former assigned Social Worker. Confidential statements and record review revealed Hillside staff frequently checked on clients (every 15-30 minutes) during sleep hours, children ages 11 and under resided in a separate cottage from the older age group (12 and up); there was close supervision in each cottage, and statements obtained did not reveal any issues regarding care and supervision. Statements produced denial that C1 ever reported being “raped” while residing at the facility. The investigation could not establish any of the alleged perpetrators. Based on information obtained, the findings, concerning neglect/lack of supervision is therefore determined Unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There were no deficiencies cited per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards or California Code of Regulations, Title 22, at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the Facility Representative.

13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the allegation that C1 and C2 engaged in sexual activity due to lack of supervision. LPA interviewed three Hillside staff members, the reporter and C1. C2 is reported to have aged out of foster care. All staff members denied seeing C1 and C2 engaged in sexual activity. One staff stated that he had heard rumors of them being caught in the act while at the Hillside School but knows nothing of anything sexual happening between C1 and C2 while in STRTP. C1 indicated that there was sexual activity that occurred while at the STRTP. She does not remember if the staff took any action to prevent it or not. LPA did not request records on C1 and C2 since the alleged activity took place over six years prior to the complaint being made. Based on the contradictory accounts given and lack of concrete evidence, LPA resolved the allegation as unsubstantiated.

narrative: C2’s genital area underwater and also that C1 put C1’s mouth on C2’s breast during a GH outing. Additionally, it was alleged that C1 took C2’s hand and forced C2 to touch C1’s genitals. Finally, it was also alleged that C1 jumped on C2’s back and started “humping” C2. Per the allegation, C1 admitted to this behavior. Also alleged in the report is that C1 was doing sexual things to C2 before C1 was moved rooms, as they were roommates. It was also detailed in the allegation that once C2 disclosed this information to GH staff, C2 changed rooms. Confidential witness statements corroborate that C1 did these actions to C2, however, confidential interviews also corroborate that C2 dared C1 to do some of these actions to C2. One witness maintains not all of these actions were solicited. While C1’s needs and service plan does mention C1’s sexual history, there is nothing in the needs and service plan requiring for C1 to be under constant supervision. Finally, all witnesses corroborate that staff members were sitting at a picnic table not far from the lake where C1 and C2 were swimming when these incidents occurred. Staff were within eyesight of C1 and C2 and never observed any of these interactions occur between C1 and C2. All witnesses also corroborate C2 did not tell staff this was happening and remained with C1 during the length of the outing. Based on interviews conducted, the allegation that a lack of supervision resulted in inappropriate sexual interaction between C1 and C2 while in care may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. The allegation is, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were emailed to Ms. Tiffany for original signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.

narrative: the allegation details. Though C1 no longer resides at the STRTP, one witness maintains this occurred while C1 was at the STRTP and confirms there was no physical bullying occurring, primarily verbal harassment and verbal abuse by clients in the STRTP. Most witnesses corroborate that C1 was not bullied or verbally harassed during C1’s time at the STRTP. Several confidential statements corroborate that C1 makes up lies about the STRTP and other clients in the home. Additionally, these confidential statements all corroborate that C1 is an attention seeker and is often the instigator of any verbal altercations that occurred between clients in the home, causing staff to have to redirect both C1 and other involved parties. All witnesses deny ever bullying or witnessing C1 be bullied at the STRTP during C1’s time at the STRTP. Confidential witnesses also deny verbally harassing C1. Staff deny C1 ever reporting to staff that C1 was being bullied or verbally harassed while at the STRTP. While staff confirm several incidents of verbal arguments have occurred between C1 and other clients in the home, most witnesses deny this being labeled as bulling or verbal harassment, but instead, verbal disagreements and client squabbles. Staff confirm C1 did report to staff that C1 did not feel safe at the facility to staff, that is why C1 was relocated. Based on interviews conducted, the allegation that C1 was being bullied while in care may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. The allegation is, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were emailed to Ms. Kay Biggs for original signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.
