narrative:
On June 30, 2021 at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar arrived at Home of Excellence Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by facility manager (FM) Ms. Leticia Castaneda. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There were two staff and five clients present at the time of the inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 10:45 AM, Ms. Leticia Castaneda led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA Escobar. The facility consists of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. One bedroom is used as the staff office and has a restroom inside that is also available for clients to use. The facility has a dining area, a kitchen area, a living room, a staff office, laundry room, and a garage. The laundry room is located off the hallway that leads to the garage. There is a new addition to the back porch area that will be used as the clinician's office for therapeutic services as well as the case manager's office. These services are currently being offered in the staff office space. There are windows and a fan within the addition. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All the bedroom windows are missing screens. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. During the inspection, it was observed that there is an old, disconnected satellite on the ground, creating a potential hazard. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Televisions, a computer, board games, video gaming console, trampoline, punching mannequin and punching tower bag, and books, were observed for client’s recreation time. There is an activities calendar posted and staff are getting back to scheduling outings and outside activities. Carbon monoxide detector is in appropriate working order and facility smoke detectors are also in working order. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. There is an extra freezer in the garage along with an extra refrigerator. An addition was also built off the dining area that is used as a

pantry and storage area. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are stored in a locked box within a locked closet in the hallway. The hot water in the staff and client restrooms was deemed to be at a safe temperature. Per facility staff, there are no firearms or weapons in the facility. Chemicals and/or poisons are locked in a cabinet above the washer/dryer in the laundry area. Sharp objects/knives are stored in a locked box in the locked closet in the hallway. First Aid Kits are also stored in this locked closet and are complete. A First Aid Manual was also available. It was observed that the licensee has cameras in common areas of the facility as well as the staff office, outside facing the front door and in the backyard facing the windows and side wall. There is an exception on file for the facility to use the cameras and the facility continues to meet the terms and conditions of the exception. The facility employs one Facility Administrator, three Facility Managers/Acting Managers, seven direct care youth counselors, two Case Manager, one Head of Service and one Program Director. Facility has not yet obtained Mental Health Certification, however, have submitted the application and are awaiting approval. Facility has obtained National Accreditation through CARF effective through February 28, 2022. Currently, the facility is up to date with Licensing fees for the facility, with a balance of $0. At 11:20 AM, six of six client files were reviewed during time of inspection. Client files are kept in a locked file cabinet within the staff office. Client 1 (C1), client 2 (C2), client 3 (C3), client 4 (C4), client 5's (C5), and client 6's (C6) files were reviewed at time of inspection, (See LIC 857) dated June 30, 2021. C1 and C2 did not have medical consent form in files. C6 did not have a current JV220 in file or a pending JV220 application. The facility will be cited under Interim Licensing Standards section 87070 Children’s Records. C6 did not have a current needs and service plan in file. A Technical Assistance Advisory Note (TA) will be issued. LPAs conducted client interviews. Clients indicated that their basic needs are being met at the facility and core services being provided as well. LPA Escobar began the review of staff files, however, due to time constraints, was not able to conclude the review. LPA Escobar will return to complete staff file review and interviews at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Facility Manager, Ms. Leticia Castaneda.

On July 1, 2021, at 9:05 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar arrived at Home of Excellence Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation inspection for STRTP annual inspection that was initiated on June 30, 2021. LPA already completed the physical inspection of the facility and reviewed facility client files on the first day of the annual inspection. During this annual inspection continuation, LPA Escobar reviewed ten personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Personnel Files are usually maintained in a locked closet inside the staff office. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Nine of the ten files that were reviewed were for employees who converted from group home personnel to STRTP personnel. LPA observed the converted staff members were trained according to the STRTP training requirements. Files for staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), staff 4 (S4), staff 5 (S5), staff 6 (S6), staff 7 (S7), staff 8 (S8), staff 9 (S9), and staff 10 (S10) did not have employer verification form in files. S7 did not have a copy of Driver's License in file, but had DMV print out in file. S5, S7, and S8, did not have signed record of having received copy of Employee Handbook. S3 did not have job evaluation in file. Technical advisories (TA) will be issued for these file issues. S5 did not have proof of current CPR/first aid in file, facility will be cited under Title 22 section 80075: Health Related Services. S2 and S8 did not have record of new hire training or orientation hours in files. Facility will be cited under ILS section 87065.1 Training Requirements. Administrator Tiffany Merritt is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator and Facility Manager: incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA

discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. One youth counselor (direct care staff) and two Facility Managers, present during annual inspection, were interviewed in regard to their job duties, training, and services provided at the facility. All staff were able to provide sufficient information in relation to the facility's STRTP program. Staff have no issues or concerns regarding the facility. Based upon the inspection of facility records and interviews with staff and clients, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. LPA requested the recent board meeting minutes be provided via email by July 7, 2021. A copy of this report, the advisory notices, and appeal rights, were provided to Facility Manager, Leticia Castaneda.

deficiencies.title: Health Related Services
deficiencies.description: (f) Staff responsible for providing direct care and supervision shall receive training in first aid from persons qualified by agencies including but not limited to the American Red Cross.

narrative: It was alleged that on or around 06/30/21, S1 engaged in a physical altercation with C1. Specifically, it was reported that C1 took a pen and S1 charged at C1 and tackled C1. Details state C1 sustained a “fat lip” during the attack and then C1 was placed on a 5150 hold. S1 denies charging and attacking C1 and denies injuring C1 and giving C1 a “fat lip”. S1 states C1 was threatening to hurt and kill S1 and also threatening to self-harm which is why S1 took away the pencil from C1. S1 states S1 raised S1’s arms to block the attack from C1, however, denies hitting, assaulting, or attacking C1 in any form. Additionally, S1 states she did not give C1 a “fat lip” either. Another witness maintains staff put hands on C1, however, witness was unsure of how S1 physically attacked or grabbed C1 as could not provide any details. All witnesses corroborate that there was a verbal altercation between C1 and S1, however, S1 states she had to raise her voice to try to de-escalate C1 as C1 was extremely escalated and yelling loudly. There were no witnesses that observed any physical interaction between S1 and C1. One witness states they heard C1 yell things such as, “Get off me! Get your hands off me!” but did not see what was happening as the room door was closed and the incident occurred in the hallway area of the house. The majority of witnesses state S1 has never put hands on any clients in the STRTP. Based on interviews conducted and information obtained, the allegation that S1 engaged in a physical altercation with C1, may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. The allegation is, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were provided to Ms. Leticia Castaneda for original signature. Signed report will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On December 16, 2021 at 4:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar conducted an unannounced inspection at the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) in order to issue the investigative finding for the above allegation. During the investigation, LPA requested documents from client 1 (C1’s) file including placement agreement, copy of needs and service plan, and special incident reports involving C1 in regards to the allegations reported. LPA also obtained a copy of STRTP client roster, staff roster, and staff 2 (S2’s) training history. LPA Escobar conducted interviews with facility manager (FM), staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), C1, client 2 (C2), client 3 (C3), client 4 (C4), and client 5 (C5) as well as C1’s county social worker (CSW). LPA Escobar completed the initial ten-day inspection at the facility to initiate the complaint on 07/01/21 at 4:30 PM. No safety concerns were observed.

narrative:
On December 08, 2022 at 09:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA’s) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Emina Preciado arrived at Home of Excellence Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by facility manager (FM) Ms. Leticia Castaneda. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There were no clients and two staff present during this inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. Ms. Leticia Castaneda led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA’s. The facility consists of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. One bedroom is used as the staff office and has a restroom inside that is also available for clients to use. The facility has a dining area, a kitchen area, a living room, a staff office, laundry room, and a garage. The laundry room is located off the hallway that leads to the garage. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All the bedroom windows have the screens. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. During the inspection, it was observed that there is an old, disconnected satellite on the ground, creating a potential hazard. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Televisions, a computer, board games, video gaming console, trampoline, punching mannequin and punching tower bag, and books, were observed for client’s recreation time. There is an activities calendar posted and staff are getting back to scheduling outings and outside activities. Carbon monoxide detector is in appropriate working order and facility smoke detectors are also in working order. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. There is an extra freezer in the garage along with an extra refrigerator. An addition was also built off the dining area that is used as a pantry and storage area.

All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are stored in a locked box within a locked closet in the hallway. The hot water in the staff and client restrooms was deemed to be at a safe temperature. Per facility staff, there are no firearms or weapons in the facility. Chemicals and/or poisons are locked the hallway closet. Sharp objects/knives are stored in a locked box in the locked closet in the hallway. First Aid Kits are also stored in this locked closet and are complete. A First Aid Manual was also available. Medications were stored in a locked box in the hallway closet. It was observed that the licensee has cameras in common areas of the facility as well as the staff office, outside facing the front door and in the backyard facing the windows and side wall. There is an exception on file for the facility to use the cameras and the facility continues to meet the terms and conditions of the exception. Client files are kept in a locked file cabinet within the staff office. LPA’s reviewed six client files during time of inspection. All six of the client files reviews had required documents on file. LPA's also reviewed seven staff files and all of the files were complete and had had all required documents. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances, CPR/First aid and training hours. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, are no deficiencies found at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was reviewed and given to facility representative Leticia Castaneda.

On February 2, 2023, at 3:10 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Carmen Escobar and Lisi Leon conducted an in-person inspection of Home of Excellence Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a physical walk through of the facility to inspect building and grounds. While LPA conducted a physical inspection of the facility, it was observed that room 1, room 2, and room 3, do not have doors. The doors have been replaced with curtains. By removing all the bedroom doors, the facility is in violation of clients' personal rights. The facility is being cited under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87072, Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with appeal rights, was signed by, and provided to Facility Manager, Leticia Castaneda, via facility email due to technical difficulties.

investigation_findings: 13On January 26, 2021 at 11:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegations. LPA met with Ebony Jones. LPA Lisi Leon conducted an inspection of the facility on February 10, 2022 at 11:00 am and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Four of four children (C1, C2, C3, C4), three staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff (unknown name) is aggressive towards C1, C1 was sexually assaulted by C2 and staff did not report it. Confidential staff interviews reported that staff treats all of the clients including C1 with respect and appropriate discipline is used. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 did not disclose any sexual abuse to any staff. Confidential interviews reported that when staff did become aware of this alleged incident, staff took appropriate actions to ensure that C1 was separated from C2. The interviews that were provided to the LPA were not consistent regarding staff being aggressive towards C1, C1 was sexually assaulted by C2 and staff did not report it. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Ebony Jones.

13On January 26, 2021 at 11:41am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegation. LPA met with Ebony Jones. LPA Carmen Escobar conducted an inspection of the facility on March 30, 2022 at 02:45 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Three of three children (C1, C2, C3), three staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that C1 sustained multiple injuries due to self-harming. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 does have a history of self-injurious behaviors. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 is always being supervised and staff ensures that C1 has no sharp objects. Additional confidential interviews reported that C1 did self-harm several times while being placed at the facility. However, C1 self-harms while in the shower, even though staff is sitting outside the restroom door. Confidential interviews reported that C1 will find any sharp while at school and hide it on the body and use it while in the shower. There are no other witnesses to C1 during C1’s injurious behaviors while in the shower. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Ebony Jones.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Erika Lopez, was at the facility to conduct interviews with 2 clients.

During the investigation, confidential interviews reported that C1 left the facility on a continuous basis despite staff efforts to keep C1 from leaving the facility while in care. Confidential interviews further reported that C1’s placement was terminated due to safety concerns for staff and other clients in care. Confidential interviews maintained that staff followed the programs protocols when C1 left the facility or attempted to leave the facility. Another confidential interview reported that C1 was placed at the facility with an agreement that C1 was going to have one on one care due to C1’s history however, that care was not provided to C1 at the facility due to staff shortage. Another confidential interview stated that C1 left the facility when C1 felt like leaving the facility and there were times when staff attempted to redirect C1 and other times where staff did not do anything about C1 leaving the facility. Another confidential interview stated not witnessing Absent Without Leave (AWOLs) at the facility and further stated feeling safe at current placement and reported no concerns about staff supervision. Based on the confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that staff did not prevent C1 from wandering from the facility, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Home of Excellence, House Manager, Leticia Castaneda.
investigation_findings: 13On March 24, 2023, at 12:35 PM , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena met with Home of Excellence Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) House Manager, Leticia Castaneda to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. On July 8, 2022, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging that staff did not prevent minor from wandering from the facility. On July 15, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar initiated an investigation at the STRTP. LPA Escobar conducted a Health and Safety Inspection, and no immediate deficiencies were observed. LPA Escobar obtained copies of pertinent documents from the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program staff and client files. Additionally, LPA Escobar conducted interviews with Facility Manager (FM) and one staff member (S1). LPA Urena conducted interviews with Administrator, (ADM), three staff members (S2, S3, S4), two clients (C1, C2) and a County Social Worker (CSW).

narrative: A confidential witness reported C1 was physically assaulted by S6 by putting their hands on C1’s throat and hit C1’s left hand, however the date the incident took place was not known. Additional confidential witnesses reported the alleged incident happened in January 2023. LPA requested but did not receive a copy of the incident report to confirm the validity of the statements provided. A confidential witness reported the incident was a result of C1 not letting go of a pair of pants. It was reported C1 would not loosen their grip on the pants, fell back onto the couch, and then fell to the floor. S6 denied all allegations of physical abuse. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff spoke inappropriately to minor in care. It was alleged that staff called C1 names. A confidential witness reported that staff did not call any of the clients names or speak inappropriately to clients in care. It was further reported, that C1 would get upset when clients made blunt remarks about C1. A Confidential witness also reported that C1 was yelled at by staff, no longer employed at the facility,and S2. However, they did not reveal what was said to C1. It was further stated that staff will use a firm tone when redirecting clients, but they do not yell at the clients. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and lack of documentation, the allegations staff hit minor and staff spoke inappropriately to minor in care in care, may have occurred. However, the allegations are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights were provided to Home of Excellence, Facility Manager, Leticia Castaneda.

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that C1 is always supervised while at the facility. Other confidential interviews stated that C1 does contact these individuals to meet them while awol from the facility through cell phones that C1 would get while awol. The interviews that were provided to the LPA were not consistent regarding the allegations that staff are not properly supervising C1 and did not provide any further specific details regarding staff supervision. Based on interviews and record reviews the allegations that staff did not prevent C1 from awoling from the facility and staff did no prevent C1 from engaging in inappropriate internet usage, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Tiffany Merritt.
investigation_findings: 13On April 12, 2023 at 11:10am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegations. LPA met with facility administrator, Tiffany Merritt. Carmen Escobar conducted an inspection of the facility on April 13, 2022, at 2:15 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Four of four children (C1, C2, C3, C4), four staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff did not prevent C1 from awoling (absent without leave) from the facility and staff did no prevent C1 from engaging in inappropriate internet usage. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 will leave the facility without permission and staff will verbally give C1 directives but C1 refuses to follow verbal directives of staff. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 had a cell phone that was initially approved by C1’s authorized representative. Confidential interviews reported that then there was a court order that C1 could not have a cell phone due to C1 engaging in inappropriate internet usage. Confidential interviews reported staff then took C1’s cell phone away. Additional interviews reported that C1 continued to leave the facility without permission and come back to the facility with a different cell phone.

narrative: Based on the confidential interviews, staff had called law enforcement when C1 had eloped from the facility. Four of the seven interviewed stated that staff reported elopements to CCL, the clients’ county social workers, and law enforcement. Based on interviews and record review, C1 had received a CSEC advocate, but counseling was unsuccessful in redirecting. According to one interview, the facility had been working with the Rialto Police Department to catch the adult men that C1 had engaged with. Based on one confidential interview, the facility did not report elopements with adult men to law enforcement. LPA Hood conducted an interview with C1’s current case worker (CW). CW shared that they were not the case worker at the time of the allegations, the case worker at the time of the allegations was no longer with the county. LPA Hood reviewed the CPS Screener Narratives, two were submitted for this incident with C1. On 5/13/2022, the CPS narrative states that the facility had not yet submitted a referral, but they had alerted the county case worker. Another referral was opened on 5/19/2023 due to other concerns with C1 engaging in CSEC activity. The CPS investigations are not complete, LPA Hood made unsuccessful attempts to contact the investigating case worker. LPA Hood reviewed twelve incident reports between 5/10/2022 and 2/1/2023. Based on a review of the incident reports, the facility did report elopements to CCL, law enforcement, and the social worker. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that client engaged in CSEC activity due to a lack of supervision may or may not be true; however, the allegation has not met the preponderance of doubt. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. No deficiencies were cited during this visit. LPA Hood conducted an exit interview with Lisa Brooks, Youth Counselor, and a copy of this report including appeal rights was provided.

narrative: On June 30th, 2023 at 1:57 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, conducted an unannounced visit at Home of Excellence Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Ebony Jones, Assistant Manager. No immediate health or safety deficiencies were observed. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a collateral interview with a staff. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to Ebony Jones, Assistant Manager

On July 18, 2023, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jessica Peete arrived at Home of Excellence Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to conduct an unannounced annual inspection. LPA met with Facility Administrator, Tiffany Merritt. LPA began the physical plant inspection at 10:15 AM. LPAs toured the facility inside and out at with facility staff . The facility consists of three bedrooms and two bathrooms. One bedroom is used as the staff office and has a restroom inside that is also available for clients to use. The facility has a dining area, a kitchen area, a living room, a staff office, laundry room, and a garage. The laundry room is located off the hallway. The bedrooms are arranged so that there are two clients sharing a room, and one client per bed. There is adequate closet space for client’s belongings. At 10:50 AM LPA observed two mattresses, in bedroom two and one mattress in bedroom three, were not equipped with good springs. The licensee was cited with a type B violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87088(c)(1). At 11:15 AM LPA observed wall damage in bedroom two.The licensee was cited with a type B violation of Title 22 California Code of Regulation(CCR) 80087(a). The bathrooms were observed to be clean and in good repair. The hot water in both bathrooms were within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the laundry room cabinets; additional cleaning supplies are locked in the staff office. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked hall closet. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were operable,the fire extinguishers were observed to be fully charged and in working condition. There are no guns or weapons on facility grounds as stated by the Administrator. LPA observed facility posted items in the entry way and dining area that included: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Foster Care Ombudsman,and current food menu. Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the locked hall closed, inside a lock box. LPA observed a variety of food stored in the refrigerator and kitchen cabinets. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and a two-day perishable supply of food.

There are no pools or other bodies of water on the property. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space; all exits, and walkways were free from obstruction. LPA observed age-appropriate toys, games, and books for client’s recreation time. At 11:30 AM LPA began the review of Disaster Preparedness, Operational Requirements, and Core Therapeutic Services. All documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. At 12:20 PM LPA reviewed four out of four client files (C1-C4). AT 1:00 PM LPA observed the licensee did not have the tuberculosis examination results for C4. The licensee was cited with a type B violation of Title 22 California Code of Regulation (CCR) 80069(c)(1). At 1:45 PM LPA observed the Needs and Service Plans did not have the required information regarding, visitation, family member integration into the treatment process, and outreach to the family members. The licensee was cited with four technical violations: ILS 87068.2(b)(6), ILS 87068.2(e), ILS 87070(b)(16), ILS 87070(b)(17). Due to time constraints, LPA will return to complete the inspection at a later date. Based on observations made during the inspection, deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights was provided to Facility Manager Tiffany Merritt.

On July 25th, 2023, at 5:36 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jessica Peete met with Administrator, Tiffany Merritt. LPA was at the facility to continue with the Annual Inspection and clear a Type B deficiency, initially cited during the annual visit on 07/18/2023. The deficiency has been cleared; no other deficiencies were observed or cited during this visit. An exit interviewed was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator,Tiffany Merritt.

Other confidential interviews reported that C1, C2, and C3 never stepped inside S4’s home. Confidential interviews reported that on the way to a facility outing, S4 stopped at the personal residence along the way and that C1, C2, and C3 waited in the facility car while S4 grabbed an item from the home. Other confidential interviews reported that at no time did any facility staff engage in any inappropriate relationships with clients. Confidential interviews stated that C1, C2, and C3 denied the allegation of having an inappropriate relationship with S4. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation regarding lack of supervision resulting in youths (C1, C2, and C3) obtaining alcohol. Confidential interviews reported that S4 took C1, C2, and C3 to the store, where they were allowed to obtain alcohol. Confidential interviews reported that S4 told a former client (C4) not to mention the purchase of alcohol to anyone else. Other confidential interviews reported that at no time during their placement at the facility did S4 or any other staff allow C1, C2, or C3 to obtain alcohol from a store. Confidential interviews reported no alcohol in the facility at the time of inspection. Other confidential interviews stated that alcohol is not kept at the facility. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation regarding lack of supervision resulting in youths (C1, C2, and C3) AWOLing. Confidential interviews reported that S4 introduced C1 to a former client (C4) of the facility and that C1 has been running away regularly after meeting C4. Confidential interviews reported that a review of Special Incident Reports confirms C1 has run away from the facility twice. Confidential interviews reported that staff was supervising the clients during their AWOL. Confidential interviews reported that staff could not physically prevent clients from leaving the facility per facility policy. Confidential interviews stated that staff verbally encouraged the clients to stay at the facility and not to leave without permission. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that staff (S4) has inappropriate relationships with youths (C1, C2, and C3) in care, lack of supervision resulting in youths (C1, C2, and C3) obtaining alcohol, and lack of supervision resulting in youths (C1, C2, and C3) AWOLing, may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to House Manager Leticia Castaneda.
investigation_findings: 13On 07/13/2023 at 09:26 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced visit to Home of Excellence Short Term Residential Treatment Facility (STRTP) and met with House Manager Leticia Castaneda to deliver the investigative findings for the allegations listed above. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute this allegation; Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided. A copy of the report was given to Home of Excellence, House Manager, Leticia Castaneda.
investigation_findings: 13On September 1, 2023 at 9:05 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, met with Home of Excellence House Manager, Leticia Castaneda, to deliver the findings for the above stated allegation. LPA Erika Lopez conducted an inspection of the facility on September 21, 2022 at approximately 2:15 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. The investigation included interviews with Facility Administrator (FA), five staff (S1, S2, S3, S4, and S5), and two foster youth (C1 and C2), and one confidential witness. In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On September 12, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received one allegation alleging that staff did pick minor up. Regarding the allegation mentioned above, confidential interviews alleged that C1 was observed walking into a restroom at school with a pipe and lighter. Details from confidential interviews detailed that school staff suspected C1 *Continued on next page LIC 9099-C*

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that the only time clients were asked to “wait” was during instances when facility staff were passing out medication, as this was a sensitive time and that clients who weren’t receiving medication were asked to wait until the clients receiving medication were given medication. Confidential interviews stated that when staff is not passing out medication and not doing bedroom checks, they are assisting clients. Community Care Licensing received another allegation that the facility is not meeting the youth's (C1-C5) individual therapeutic goals. Confidential interviews reported that “there is a lack of therapeutic intervention” in the facility. Other confidential interviews reported that the clients are given access to therapy services at least once a week. Confidential interviews reported that clients who did need to speak to a therapist or clinicians on grounds were not denied this service. Other confidential interviews reported that it was unknown if the clients’ therapeutic goals were being met, even though they had opportunities to participate in therapy. Community Care Licensing received another allegation that unspecified staff member called the youth (C1-C5) an inappropriate name. Confidential interviews reported that “staff called youth a liar.” Other confidential interviews reported that all facility staff used appropriate language when interacting with the clients (C1-C5) in care and denied hearing that a client was called “a liar.” Confidential interviews indicated staff does not call clients (C1-C5) inappropriate names. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that staff are unavailable for the youth (C1-C5) in care, the facility is not ensuring that the youth's (C1-C5) individual therapeutic goals are being met. Staff called the youth (C1-C5) an inappropriate name, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Case Manager Tijuana Ross.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/13/2023 at 12:19 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced visit to Home of Excellence Short Term Residential Treatment Facility (STRTP) and met with Case Manager Tijuana Ross, to deliver the investigative findings for the allegations listed above. On 05/16/2023, LPA Jessica Peete visited the facility, obtained pertinent documents, and conducted an initial health and safety inspection. No immediate health and safety hazards were observed. LPA Peete interviewed Client 1 (C1), Client 4 (C4), and Staff (S1-S7). LPA Joon Choi interviewed Client 3 (C3). Client 2 (C2) and Client 5 (C5) refused to be interviewed by LPA. On 05/16/2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that staff (S1-S7) are unavailable for the clients in care (C1-C5). Confidential interviews reported that facility staff were unavailable to the clients in the facility and that “youth were told to wait for other staff” when clients would ask for assistance. Other confidential interviews reported that staff made themselves available to all clients in care whenever they asked for assistance. CONTINUED ON THE NEXT PAGE

narrative: It was also alleged that Staff #1 (S1) stated to C1, “that’s what you get.” Confidential staff interviews reported S1 did not make any inappropriate comments to C1, instead S1 and S2 offered C1 medical attention, in which C1 refused. The interviews that were provided to the LPA were not consistent regarding the allegations that staff are not properly supervising C1 and staff making an inappropriate comment to C1. Based on interviews and record reviews the allegations that that staff did not prevent C1 from the facility and staff made an inappropriate comment to C1, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Ebony Jones.
investigation_findings: 13On November 15, 2023, at 9:00 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegations. LPA met with Ebony Jones. LPA Erika Lopez conducted an inspection of the facility on December 16, 2022, at 2:50 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Four of four children (C1, C2, C3, C4), four staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff did not prevent C1 from awoling (absent without leave) from the facility and staff made an inappropriate comment to C1. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 will leave the facility without permission and staff will verbally give C1 directives but C1 refuses to follow verbal directives of staff. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 had a cell phone that was approved by C1’s authorized representative. Confidential interviews reported that on December 10, 2022, C1 returned from an awol, it was alleged that C1 reported to staff about being sexually abused while awol. Continued on page

narrative: Specifically, it was reported C1 utilizes marijuana, nicotine, and “M30’s” both in and out of the facility. Confidential interviews and record review revealed C1 has been observed returning to the facility after leaving without permission under the influence of unknown substance. Confidential interviews and photographs reported that the facility staff have confiscated contraband and/or substances from multiple residents. Confidential interviews could not confirm where the residents were obtaining the contraband and substances. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute C1 was utilizing substances while in the facility. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegation alleging Minor (Child #1 [C1]) is utilizing substances while in care may have occurred, however is not supported, or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights to Home of Excellence, Letty Castaneda, House Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On January 3, 2024 at 8:35 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, met with Home of Excellence Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Letty Castaneda, House Manager, to deliver the findings for the above stated allegation. A health and safety inspection of the facility was conducted on February 22, 2023, and no immediate hazards were observed. The investigation included interviews with three staff (S1, S2, S3), two of four foster youth (Child #2 [C2] and Child #3 [C3]), and two San Bernardino County Social Workers. LPA was unable to obtain a statement from Child #1 (C1) after multiple attempts due to multiple placement changes and several occurrences of C1 being absent without permission. Two confidential witnesses’ whereabouts are unknown and therefore were unable to be interviewed. In addition, county records, facility records, and photographs were reviewed. On February 21, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging Minor (Child #1 [C1]) is utilizing substances while in care. *Continued on next page LIC 9099-C*

narrative: On 01/29/2024 at 8:45 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Peete arrived unannounced at Home of Excellence Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) . The purpose of the visit was to amend the LIC 9099 and LIC 9099-C reports originally issued on 01/25/2024. A copy of this report was given to Facility Manager, Leticia Castaneda.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Leslie Covarrubias on January 26, 2024 at 10:40 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Covarrubias met with Tijuana Ross, Case Manager and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed one of child’s records and two of staff personnel files at the facility. LPA reviewed one of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed two of staff to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed zero of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. One child refused to be interviewed. During the inspection the LPA observed deficiencies (see attached 809D), plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Tijuana Ross, Case Manager.

deficiencies.description:
Health Related Services 80075(k)(5)Each client's medication shall be stored in its originally received container.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
Based on LPA observation, ... one medication had a broken seal on C1's medication, causing the medication to be tampered with and no longer in its original container which poses a potential Health, Safety and Personal Rights risk to client C1 in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The medication will be taken to pharmacy to be disposed of by 1/26/24. The Centrally stored log will be updated. An SIR will also be submitted to Community Care Licensing and a copy  will be sent to  LPA Covarrubias by 1/30/24.

deficiencies.description:
Children's Records 87070(b)(14)(H) Staff initials for each time a psychotropic medication is taken by a child, as an indication that they supervised the child self-administering their psychotropic medication. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: 
Based on observation and record review there were discrepancies on the medication count for C1, that were administered, which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risks to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Facility Manager, there will be a retraining for the entire facility staff and the proof of training with staff signatures will be emailed to LPA Covarrubias by due date.

narrative: Confidential interviews were inconsistent regarding who was involved and witnessed the incident, except S6. Confidential interviews reported that, based on C1’s past behaviors, staff reasonably suspected that C1 was hiding contraband in their pants pocket. Multiple confidential interviews reported that staff repeatedly asked C1 to let go of the pants and staff tried to de-escalate the situation; C1 would not loosen their grip on the pants and refused to comply with staff. Confidential interviews reported staff (S6) was not aggressive toward C1 but did reach for the pants, resulting in C1 pulling the pants, which caused C1 and S6 to fall to the floor. A confidential witness interview reported that S6 restrained C1 while C1 was on the ground. Other confidential interviews reported that C1 and S6 did not fall to the ground, and S6 did not restrain C1. In addition, confidential interviews reported that S6 did not hit C1, and C1 did not sustain any injuries or require medical attention. Pertinent documentation also reported that C1 had no observable marks or bruising. Other confidential interviews reported that S6 choked C1 and disclosed that C1 reported being physically abused by staff at the STRTP. The LPA did not receive any corroborating information during confidential interviews as the interviews denied staff hit or mistreated clients in care. The Department also received an allegation that staff spoke inappropriately to the minor (C1) in care. It was alleged that staff called C1 names. Confidential interviews reported staff did not yell or speak negatively about C1 or other clients in care. Other confidential interviews reported staff (S1) called names and made derogatory remarks about client behaviors. It was further reported that there were no concerns regarding client and staff interactions; confidential interviews reported staff were respectful and acted professionally. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the allegations that staff (S6) hit a minor (C1) in care and staff spoke inappropriately to the minor (C1) in care are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Facility Manager Leticia Castaneda This is an amended report of a report that was originally issued on 01/25/2024
investigation_findings: 13This is an amended report of a report that was originally issued on 01/25/2024 On January 25, 2024, at 3:55 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced visit to the Home of Excellence Therapeutic Program ( STRTP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegations listed above. On 03/23/2023, LPA Peete inspected the physical plant, and no immediate safety hazards were observed. During the investigation, LPA obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. LPA conducted interviews with staff (S1, S2, S4, S5, S6, S7, and S8,) and client 2 (C2). LPA made several attempts to interview C3, but C3 was unavailable. On 08/29/2023, Community Care Licensing received additional information alleging staff (S6) hit a minor (C1) in care. It was reported that C1 and S6 struggled over a pair of pants. It was alleged that multiple STRTP staff witnessed the incident (S1, S2, S4, S5, S6, S7, and S8). (Continued on LIC 9099-C)

narrative: A confidential witness reported C1 was physically assaulted by S6 by putting their hands on C1’s throat and hit C1’s left hand, however the date the incident took place was not known. Additional confidential witnesses reported the alleged incident happened in January 2023. LPA requested but did not receive a copy of the incident report to confirm the validity of the statements provided. A confidential witness reported the incident was a result of C1 not letting go of a pair of pants. It was reported C1 would not loosen their grip on the pants, fell back onto the couch, and then fell to the floor. S6 denied all allegations of physical abuse. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff spoke inappropriately to minor in care. It was alleged that staff called C1 names. A confidential witness reported that staff did not call any of the clients names or speak inappropriately to clients in care. It was further reported, that C1 would get upset when clients made blunt remarks about C1. A Confidential witness also reported that C1 was yelled at by staff, no longer employed at the facility,and S2. However, they did not reveal what was said to C1. It was further stated that staff will use a firm tone when redirecting clients, but they do not yell at the clients. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and lack of documentation, the allegations staff hit minor and staff spoke inappropriately to minor in care in care, may have occurred. However, the allegations are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights were provided to Home of Excellence, Facility Manager, Leticia Castaneda.

narrative: On Friday April 19, 2024 at 3:50 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Peete arrived unannounced to Home of Excellence Short Term Residential Therapeutic Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Case Manager,Tijuana Ross to deliver a report. A copy of this report was given to the Case Manager.

Confidential interviews reported when law enforcement (LE) arrived at the STRTP, C1 admitted to LE they (C1) used a “razor” to cut their (C1’s) face. Confidential interviews also reported that C1 did not disclose where they (C1) obtained the object used to self-harm, and the safety search conducted by staff did not recover the object. In addition, information obtained from other confidential interviews reported that clients do not have access to sharp objects. However, clients are allowed to use shaving razors, but C1 and other clients are monitored due to unsafe behaviors. Additionally, multiple confidential interviews reported that due to C1's behavior's staff do not ignore C1’s self-harming; staff provide emergency interventions and utilize C1’s safety plan. The Department also received an allegation that staff (S1) teased a minor (C1) in care. It was reported during the same incident, mentioned above, that S1 made offensive remarks about C1 ‘s appearance. More specifically, it was alleged that S1 criticized C1’s makeup. A confidential interview reported that C1 was wearing dark makeup. However, other confidential interviews reported that S1 only mentioned C1’s makeup because it resembled “black face.” A Confidential witness interview reported hearing S1 comment on C1’s makeup, but the witness did not know what was said. In addition, confidential interviews reported that C1 is “creative" and staff complement C1’s appearance. Furthermore, confidential interviews denied S1 or other staff, teasing clients in care and reported staff to allow clients to express themselves freely. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and documentation, the allegations that staff (S1) did not prevent a minor (C1) from self-harming and that staff (S1) teased a minor (C1) in care are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Acting Facility Manager Lisa Brooks. This is an amended report of a report that was originally issued on 04/19/2024
investigation_findings: 13This is an amended report of a report that was originally issued on 04/19/2024 On April 19, 2024, at 8:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced visit to Home at Excellence Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegations listed above. LPA Peete obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed clients (C1, C2, and C3) and staff (S1 and S2). LPA attempted to interview C4, but C4 declined the interview. On 12/29/2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that staff (S1) did not prevent a minor (C1) from self-harming. The incident report received by the Department reported that C1 went into the STRTP bathroom and came out with a cut on their (C1’s) cheek. A confidential interview reported that S1 was present when C1 self-harmed. However, C1’s behavior escalated quickly, and S1 was unaware that C1 had taken an object into the bathroom to injure themselves.
